name: University of San Diego Institute for Civil Civic Engagement
description: The Institute for Civil Civic Engagement (ICCE) is located at the University of San Diego, one of San Diego’s leading tertiary institutions. ICCE works to encourage, promote and increase civility in civic discourse by fellow citizens and public officials, both interpersonally and in all manner of media. The institute seeks to promote ways to be civil in disagreements and respectful in debates, as they confront the political challenges that shape the community. Some of the ICCE’s main goals include to encourage the San Diego community to embrace basic elements of civility in dealing with civic activism and political campaigning, to hold community leaders accountable to conducting public discourse, and to develop and implement programs and curriculum providing effective instruction in best methods of civil civic engagement for educational communities. Meeting focus: Meet with representatives of ICCE to explore initiatives including CivicTalk San Diego, Student Civility Awards, and Richard Nixon: The Musical. University of San Diego – Center for Peace & Commerce www.sandiego.edu/cpc/ The Center for Peace and Commerce (CPC) is a collaborative effort between the School of Business Administration and the Joan B. Kroc School of Peace Studies to prepare new generations of "change agents" who develop and exercise innovative approaches for achieving the 4 Ps– people, profit, planet and peace. CPC contributes to creating new enterprise paradigms and solutions that foster peace-building and poverty alleviation, through courses, scholarship, enterprise development, active engagement with multiple stakeholders and the promotion of good governance.
source_proposal: 10 - Current U.S. Social, Political, and Economic Issues for Young European Leaders I  - Proposal  (1).docx

name: The Preuss School UC San Diego
description: Recognized by Newsweek as the top transformative high school in the nation for three years in a row, The Preuss School UC San Diego is a unique charter middle and high school for low-income students who strive to become the first in their families to graduate from college. Located on the University of California San Diego campus, The Preuss School’s students come from throughout San Diego County to take advantage of an environment that encourage intellectual risk-taking while offering an array of academic supports. There are certain key elements that set The Preuss School apart which are a unique hybrid of research-based best practices proven to help prepare low-income students to be first-time college attendees. These include collaborative, weekly development, essential to their ‘culture of learning, strong connections with the San Diego community, and longer school days and years meaning that after completing middle and high school, Preuss students have accumulated almost an entire extra academic year. Joint School Visit: La Jolla Country Day School (LJCDS) Center for Excellence in Citizenship (CEC) https://www.ljcds.org/centers/citizenship La Jolla Country Day School is an independent college-preparatory school serving students from age 3 through Grade 12 in San Diego’s coastal community of La Jolla. The Center for Excellence in Citizenship (CEC) develops unique opportunities for LJCDS students, faculty and families to engage in the vital work of local, national and global citizenship, focusing on the fundamental importance of human dignity in all interactions. CEC fosters civic engagement and civil discourse, galvanizing students to think about their rights and responsibilities as citizens and to be thoughtful participants in their communities. Community Service Activities
source_proposal: 10 - Current U.S. Social, Political, and Economic Issues for Young European Leaders I  - Proposal  (1).docx

name: Spring Valley Cleanup Crew
description: Spring Valley Cleanup Crew works to keep Spring Valley and surrounding neighborhoods clean and safe. Spring Valley is home to many underserved, immigrant and BIPOC residents who are forced to endure environmental racism and are not granted the privilege of living in the version of San Diego that we see on postcards and travel blogs. The Tijuana River Valley, in the Spring Valley area, has been declared a state of public health crisis due to the unsanitary and unsafe conditions entering the river, and organizations like the Spring Valley Cleanup Crew are working hard to undo human-caused damage. The Spring Valley Cleanup Crew, led by youth, utilizes social media to promote its grassroots organization. Victoria Abrenica, founder of Spring Valley Cleanup Crew, is a community leader in all things public education, sustainability and environmental justice. She also serves as a Youth4Climate Instructor at San Diego 350, which is building a movement to prevent the worst impacts of climate change and climate injustice. Activity Focus: Participate in a cleanup effort with Spring Valley Cleanup Crew, while learning how they utilize social media to promote efforts and engagement, and the work they are doing at the intersection of environment and race.
source_proposal: 10 - Current U.S. Social, Political, and Economic Issues for Young European Leaders I  - Proposal  (1).docx

name: Urban League of San Diego- Civic & Community Engagement
description: The mission of the Urban League of San Diego County is assisting African Americans and other underserved people in San Diego County to achieve social and economic equality through advocacy, bridge building, program services and research. The ULSD is partnering with other community groups in San Diego County to provide a forum for grassroots community input on public policy issues. Over the years, these partnerships have expanded to include partnerships with several organizations that benefit youth, families and community revitalization. Activity Focus: Join the Urban League’s team of volunteers and change makers to advocate for underserved members of the San Diego Community. There are many avenues for volunteering with the Urban League including assistance with college readiness programs, integrated case management services, financial capabilities and housing, fundraising events, and more. Kitchens for Good www.kitchensforgood.org Kitchens for Good is a non-profit and social enterprise with the mission to break the cycles of food waste, hunger, and poverty through innovative solutions in workforce training, healthy food production, and social enterprise. Kitchens for Good bridges the gap between wasted food and hunger by rescuing surplus and cosmetically imperfect food from wholesalers and farmers and engaging students in a culinary apprenticeship program to transform these ingredients into nutritious meals for hungry families. This approach addresses the most immediate need of hunger by feeding the food lines, but also helps to shorten the line itself by giving unemployed people the skills to become self-sufficient. Through the power of kitchens and cooking, Kitchens for Good students transform their lives from one of addiction, incarceration, homelessness, and unemployment, to lives of stability, employment, and a brighter future. Activity Focus: Kitchens for Good relies on volunteers to portion and package hunger relief meals. Shifts are scheduled for three hours on Wednesday afternoons. Government Agencies
source_proposal: 10 - Current U.S. Social, Political, and Economic Issues for Young European Leaders I  - Proposal  (1).docx

name: City of San Diego - Mayor's Office
description: The Mayor's Office of San Diego serves as the chief executive office of the city, overseeing all city departments and setting policy direction for the city government. It plays a pivotal role in shaping San Diego's future, addressing key issues from infrastructure to public safety and economic development. The Mayor is responsible for ensuring the effective and efficient delivery of municipal services to residents and businesses, representing San Diego's interests at various regional, state, and national platforms.
source_proposal: 10 - Current U.S. Social, Political, and Economic Issues for Young European Leaders I  - Proposal  (1).docx

name: City of San Diego - International Affairs Board (IAB)
description: The City of San Diego's International Affairs Board (IAB) advises the Mayor and City Council on the city's international engagements. Dedicated to bolstering San Diego's international ties, the IAB focuses on enhancing cross-border commerce, cultural exchanges, and global collaborations, positioning San Diego as a key player in international affairs.
source_proposal: 10 - Current U.S. Social, Political, and Economic Issues for Young European Leaders I  - Proposal  (1).docx

name: City of San Diego - Environmental Services Department (ESD)
description: San Diego's Environmental Services Department (ESD) is at the forefront of environmental sustainability, handling waste collection, promoting recycling, and advocating for public health protection strategies. With an emphasis on community education and engagement, the ESD champions sustainable solutions tailored for the city's unique challenges. Think Tanks, Public-Private Cooperation Initiatives, and Community Centers
source_proposal: 10 - Current U.S. Social, Political, and Economic Issues for Young European Leaders I  - Proposal  (1).docx

name: Smart Border Coalition
description: The Smart Border Coalition is a catalyst to bring together leading academic, business and civic communities from both sides of the San Diego/Tijuana International region to develop databases and policy positions, deliver special events and programs, and growth of the cross-border economy through jobs creation, workforce development and social interaction. Their mission is to make travel and trade easier and more efficient through the ports of entry between San Diego County and the Tijuana Metropolitan Area.
source_proposal: 10 - Current U.S. Social, Political, and Economic Issues for Young European Leaders I  - Proposal  (1).docx

name: Youth Voice San Diego
description: Youth Voice is a youth leadership program held at the Mid-City Police Division weekly. Law enforcement, university interns and community-based organizations partner with the goal of providing youth with mentoring and opportunities to positively support their leadership development. Youth Voice focuses on Connection with Self, Connection with Others, Connection with Community, and Connection with Law Enforcement. The voluntary mentoring program is supported by Mid-City Division's Juvenile Services Team and connects youth to themselves, their homes, schools, and communities through trauma informed - resilience building curriculum development.
source_proposal: 10 - Current U.S. Social, Political, and Economic Issues for Young European Leaders I  - Proposal  (1).docx

name: Youth 4 Climate
description: Youth 4 Climate San Diego stands at the forefront of youth-led environmental activism in the region. Championing impactful campaigns like "Youth v. Oil" and a robust coalition of high school eco-clubs, they mobilize young minds towards positive environmental changes. This dedicated group plans and executes direct actions, such as rallies and strikes, to raise awareness and instigate actionable changes for a sustainable future. Beyond these public actions, the organization is deeply invested in nurturing the next generation of climate leaders. They roll out diverse programs that are meticulously crafted to bolster the leadership skills of young eco-activists, such as their annual Youth Climate Action Summit, summer programs, and enriching after-school engagements. Collaborating with local organizations, they also strive to integrate the teaching community into their mission, facilitating programs to inspire and mobilize educators towards climate action. Non –Profit and Non-Governmental Organizations
source_proposal: 10 - Current U.S. Social, Political, and Economic Issues for Young European Leaders I  - Proposal  (1).docx

name: RISE San Diego
description: RISE San Diego is a non-profit organization whose mission is to elevate and advance urban leadership through dialogue-based civic engagement, dynamic nonprofit partnerships, and direct training and support to increase the capacity of urban residents to effect meaningful community change. RISE San Diego is about developing the people within communities who make it happen. RISE Urban Leadership Fellows Program is a partnership of RISE San Diego and the Leadership Institute at the University of San Diego School of Leadership and Education Sciences (SOLES). RISE’s unique goal and commitment is to help identify and empower a generation of leaders who will not only bring our urban communities up, but also bring them together. Meeting focus: Explore RISE San Diego’s youth-focused grassroots civic engagement programs, non-profit trainings, and leadership development models. Outside the Lens www.outsidethelens.org Outside the Lens empowers youth to use photography, filmmaking and digital media, catalyzing change within themselves, their community and their world, teaching people from a young age that participation in their community’s future makes a difference. Outside the Lens uses cameras and digital media along with a proven educational strategy that allows youth to think creatively, engage in issues that are important to them, and advocate for social change.
source_proposal: 10 - Current U.S. Social, Political, and Economic Issues for Young European Leaders I  - Proposal  (1).docx

name: Mid-City CAN Advocacy Network – Youth Council
description: Mid-City Community Advocacy Network is a community collaborative based in City Heights, a dense and diverse urban community of about 95,000 people and home to the San Diego Diplomacy Council office. Their mission is to create a safe, productive, and healthy community through collaboration, advocacy, and organization. The most pressing issues are raised by the people themselves and are then addressed through Momentum Teams, which are councils made up of residents from City Heights. Mid-City CAN is invested in developing leaders in City Heights. The Mid-City Can Youth Council exists to create change in their “local Black, Indigenous and Communities of Color”. They envision a world where young people thrive and everything is possible when we invest in education, not incarceration. The Youth Council’s current campaign is to dismantle institutional policies designed to criminalize and incarcerate youth. By giving youth the voice and power to change these policies, they can lead juvenile justice reform and end the school to prison pipeline. Meeting focus: Meet with community organizers and members for an overview of America’s problematic mass incarceration, and to learn about how Mid-City CAN utilizes Momentum Teams and a Youth Council to develop community leaders and advocate for change in an urban, diverse community. May include interaction with Youth Council members.
source_proposal: 10 - Current U.S. Social, Political, and Economic Issues for Young European Leaders I  - Proposal  (1).docx

name: International Rescue Committee San Diego
description: The International Rescue Committee in San Diego is a part of the larger global IRC network, an organization dedicated to providing lifesaving assistance to refugees and other vulnerable populations affected by conflict, disaster, and oppression. The San Diego chapter focuses on helping new Americans in their journey to rebuild their lives after displacement. They offer a range of services, from initial resettlement assistance to longer-term support like job training, English language classes, and citizenship education. In addition to these, the IRC San Diego also actively collaborates with the local community and businesses to ensure that refugees and immigrants integrate and contribute positively to their new homes. Minority communities and the Impact of Immigration Tour of the San Diego-Tijuana Border The largest, fourth-busiest land border crossing in the world, the San Ysidro border crossing plays an integral role in San Diego and Tijuana’s close knit, collaborative relationship. The majority of people living in communities on the San Diego side of the border are People of Color, with over 50% of residents identifying as Hispanic or Latinx, whose diversity of experience contribute to a rich hub of culture, experience, and opportunity. San Diego and Tijuana have long prospered from good-humored cross border relations, recently made even more successful with the honor of being jointly named the Innovation Design Hub for 2024. However, while cross-border collaboration and innovation are things to celebrate, there is lots of work to do on the ground among the minority and immigrant communities living in the border region, to ensure quality of life and access to resources are supported. Proposed stops on the border tour include:
source_proposal: 10 - Current U.S. Social, Political, and Economic Issues for Young European Leaders I  - Proposal  (1).docx

name: San Ysidro Point of Entry: The main artery between San Diego and Tijuana – and, in fact, the U.S. and Mexico – which sees approximately 120,000 passenger vehicles, 60,000 pedestrians, and 6000 trucks crossing back and forth each day, the San Ysidro border is evidence of San Diego and Tijuana’s dynamic relationship. While participants cannot cross into Mexico, they will be able to see over the wall into Mexico, and stand on the bridge atop the border, which leads to the pedestrian crossing site.
url: Cross Border Express (CBX) https://www.crossborderxpress.com/en/ :CBX is a pedestrian bridge for passengers of the Tijuana International Airport that allows passengers to cross the U.S.-Mexico border with ease. The facility saves millions of passengers from being delayed at the San Ysidro border crossing by enabling processing via a service terminal on the San Diego side of the border.
description: Friendship Park: Friendship Park is a binational park situated on the U.S.-Mexico border, overlooking the ocean. Since its opening by Pat Nixon 51 years ago, the park has served as a meeting point for families who have been separated by immigration laws. For some families, Friendship Park offers the only opportunity to reunite with loved ones unable to cross the border. Friendship Park, particularly on the Mexico side, has been cultivated by the community into a place of art and gathering, with regular art installations featured and frequent cross-border events like church sermons and yoga classes. (Currently closed, and based on special availability) Visit to Chicano Park and Barrio Logan The epicenter of San Diego’s Mexican-American culture, Barrio Logan is a must-visit for an authentic taste of what it means to live and work in a community with a large immigrant population. Visiting Barrio Logan, and in particular Chicano Park, will demonstrate the social, economic, and political impact of immigration in the San Diego region, and subsequent cultivation of San Diego-specific Chicano communities and culture. We suggest recruiting Via International to accompany the group on a guided tour of the area. Barrio Logan: The Barrio Logan neighborhood has a longstanding tradition of community participation and engagement, which was particularly tested (and thankfully prevailed) with the construction of the Coronado Bridge in the 1960s. Today, Barrio Logan is renowned for its artwork, both in galleries and on the streets, music venues, restaurant options and small business establishments. Walking through the neighborhood with a guide will enable participants to absorb Barrio Logan’s decidedly bi-national ethos, and its embracement of Chicano culture in cultivating a thriving community. Suggested sites of note include Bread & Salt, and “experimental center for the arts with strong community ties”, La Vuelta Car Cruises (glossy, low ride cars are a common sight and of cultural significance in the area), and Mujeres Brew House, a Latina-owned brewery founded as a community group for Latinas and other women interested in craft beer. Chicano Park: To understand the cultural significance of Barrio Logan, one must first explore Chicano Park. While the construction of the Coronado Bridge had the devastating power to fragment the migrant community forming in the area, the community banded together and turned the area under the bridge into a place of gathering and storytelling. Walking through Chicano Park under the Coronado Bridge today, visitors will see the largest concentration of Chicano murals in the world with more than 80 paintings situated on seven acres dotted with sculpture, gardens, picnic tables and playgrounds. The importance of Chicano Park to the Barrio Logan community is summarized by late musician and activist Ramon “Chunky” Sanchez; “There’s an energy there that’s hard to describe – when you see your people struggling for something positive, it’s very inspiring. The park was brought about by sacrifice and it demonstrates what a community can do when they stick together and make it happen.” _______________________________ Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $46 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. It is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park. Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $27 for one Adult Ticket for two-hour tour Their deluxe tour covers it all: Harbor and Shelter Islands, Point Loma, Cabrillo National Monument, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and much more. Tour is about 25 miles in length, 2 hour narrated tour. Old Town Trolley Tour www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com www.trolleytours.com/san-diego Price: $36 for one Adult Ticket For over 20 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours highlighting the best San Diego attractions. Old Town Trolley Tours is the best way to see the city, highlighting the best San Diego Attractions, with 11 stops and more than 100 points of interest. Old Town offers much to do, from visiting over 23 historic sites to shopping for unique merchandise. They also have many award winning restaurants to choose from. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 29 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 15 major museums, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Coronado Consistently voted one of America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year around due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. From the shores of Silver Strand State Beach to the tip of the Coronado Municipal Beach, you’ll find plenty of wide open sand, gentle waves and gorgeous views. SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $84 for one Adult Ticket Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Shamu show, One Ocean, and thrilling rides like Journey To Atlantis, Shipwreck Rapids and Wild Arctic. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Then dive into the world of sea turtles at the all-new Turtle Reef attraction.
source_proposal: 10 - Current U.S. Social, Political, and Economic Issues for Young European Leaders I  - Proposal  (1).docx

name: Site Visit at Richard J. Donovan Correctional Facility (RJD)
description: The Mission at Richard J. Donovan Correctional Facility (RJDCF) is a multi-mission institution: RJDCF’s primary mission is to provide housing for General Population and SNY, Level I, II, III & IV inmates serving their term of incarceration at RJDCF. Additionally, RJDCF provides health care services and rehabilitative programs to inmates while incarcerated at RJDCF. RJDCF is a designated institution for inmates with severe mental illness, inmates with developmental disabilities and is responsible for providing officer coverage for inmates being treated in community hospitals throughout San Diego County. Warden, James Hill James Hill has been Acting Warden of R.J. Donovan Correctional Facility since November 2022. He began with the Arizona Department of Corrections prior to his CDCR, which began in January 2000.  He has been assigned to several institutions throughout the state. He has experience working with both male and female members of the incarcerated population. Warden Hill’s priorities are to support CDCR’s vision and mission, with emphasis on rehabilitative and restorative justice programs while exemplifying the Department’s values of service, leadership, integrity, accountability, respect, trust, and collaboration. Bakery/Shoe Factory/Laundry Programs – CALPIA operates a full functioning bakery which produces 9,760 loaves of wheat bread daily. The shoe factory produces 1,000 pairs of shoes daily. Laundry provides service for VA hospitals and local prisons. CALPIA also employs inmates in maintenance, warehouse, and also implemented the Health Care Facility Maintenance program. Over 200 inmates are employed and learn job skills through CALPIA Enterprises at RJDCF. San Diego Neighborhood Policing Division Neighborhood Policing Division | Police | City of San Diego Official Website The mission of the San Diego Police Department’s Neighborhood Policing Division (NPD) is to enhance the quality of life and safety in San Diego neighborhoods in a manner that is compassionate, professional and fair to all. San Diego offers a variety of alternatives to the criminal justice system for individuals who have committed certain offenses. Police in this division divert certain individuals from the traditional arbitration system. Programs meet the needs of abusers of alcohol, abusers of narcotics, chronic misdemeanor offenders, and those with mental health issues. Safe Place Program Safe Place Program | Police | City of San Diego Official Website The San Diego Police Department strives to advance the highest levels of public safety, trust, and professionalism by strengthening community partnerships through fair and impartial policing while fostering employee enrichment and growth. The Safe Place Program helps businesses identify their establishments as safe places for victims of hate crimes or harassment to notify police of a crime or suspicious activity. San Diego County Sheriff’s Department Community Inclusion Community | San Diego County Sheriff (sdsheriff.gov) Through Community Outreach, they make available a multitude of programs and initiatives to the community that provide resources for residents of San Diego County. Their mission is to be a conduit to pass information between the Department and the public. Also, they endeavor to develop and maintain relationships through open and candid dialogue with a variety of community-based organizations and members. San Diego County Sheriff’s Department Counter-Terrorism Department Terrorism | San Diego County Sheriff (sdsheriff.gov) The San Diego County Counter-Terrorism Department empowers the public to make reports on suspicious activity they may encounter at their jobs, in their daily lives, and in relation to high-risk or symbolic targets. San Diego Law Enforcement Coordination Center SDLECC Home The San Diego Law Enforcement Coordination Center (SD-LECC) is the all crimes, all hazards fusion center and serves as the High Intensity Drug Trafficking Area (SD/I HIDTA) Investigative Support Center (ISC) for the San Diego and Imperial County region. The SD-LECC also serves as the Regional Threat Assessment Center (RTAC) for San Diego and Imperial counties and is part of the California State Threat Assessment System (STAS). The SD-LECC operates as a collaborative partnership among federal, state and local law enforcement/public safety agencies focused on enhancing coordination, information sharing, regional preparedness, training and investigative support/analysis for first responders and other regional public and private partners.
source_proposal: 11 - Countering Violent Extremism Proposal.docx

name: The City of San Diego, Gang Intervention Unit
description: The Gang Intervention Unit has a unique role within the San Diego Police Department and the community of San Diego. Officers are involved in educating youth about the dangers of gang involvement and aims to reduce juvenile gang initiation and participation through community engagement and other strategies. Gang Resistance Education and Training (G.R.E.A.T.) Program The G.R.E.A.T. program is intended to help with delinquency, deter youth violence and gang membership. Officers work with elementary and middle schools throughout San Diego to provide this educational opportunity. After School and Summer Sports Programs The Gang Intervention Unit partners with local fitness and sports programs to teach young San Diegans sports skills such as soccer, basketball and baseball. This builds confidence and encourages youth to stay healthy and active. Youth Boxing Program SDPD partners with a local boxing gym to offer a free boxing program for youth ages 14-18, who are ready to make changes to their lives and are committed to a team environment. Training takes place three days per week and the Gang Intervention Unit provides transportation to and from classes. Many of the participants of this program have successfully completed their education and found employment. Tattoo Removal Tattoo removal is an integral part of leaving behind gang life. In collaboration with the San Diego District Attorney’s Office, SDPD assists individuals in removing their tattoos for free. An interview is needed prior to acceptance into the program. This program is also open to victims of Human Trafficking. One-on-One Mentorship One on one mentorship and program referral is available with one of SDPD’s experienced gang intervention officers. These officers have access to many community organizations that can assist youth with finding success and achieving their goals. Families in Motion Family input is essential, and the City of San Diego’s Gang Prevention Unit encourage participation from parents and guardians in any intervention program, including their Families in Motion classes that run for five weeks, multiple times per year. Office of the U.S. Attorney (USAO) for the Southern District of California Southern District of California | Southern District of California (justice.gov) The Southern District of California includes San Diego and Imperial Counties. The main office is headquartered in the city of San Diego, in San Diego County. San Diego County is the second most populous county in California. The district’s branch office is located in the city of El Centro, in Imperial County. Imperial County is located in the Imperial Valley and borders both the State of Arizona and the Republic of Mexico. The Office combats the types of criminal activity --violent, drug-related and white collar—found in any metropolitan area. The district, however, is particularly affected by its proximity to Mexico. It’s United Against Hate Week brings together local civic society to stop dangerous hate and bias that threaten community security. Discussion Focus: Discuss the specific problems and opportunities within the Southern District of California, in particular, the United Against Hate program.
source_proposal: 11 - Countering Violent Extremism Proposal.docx

name: National Gang Center (NGC)
description: The National Gang Center (NGC) is a project funded by the Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention (OJJDP), the Office of Justice Programs (OJP), U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ). The NGC is an integral component of the Justice Department’s mission to provide innovative leadership in coordination with federal, state, local, and tribal justice systems to prevent and reduce crime. The NGC disseminates information, knowledge, and outcome‐driven practices that engage and empower those in local communities with chronic and emerging gang problems to create comprehensive solutions to prevent gang violence, reduce gang involvement, and suppress gang‐related crime. The Gang Resistance Education And Training (G.R.E.A.T.) Program Program is a school‐based, law enforcement officer‐instructed classroom curriculum. The program, whose primary objective is prevention, is intended as an immunization against delinquency, youth violence, and gang membership. G.R.E.A.T. lessons focus on providing life skills to students to help them avoid delinquent behavior and violence to solve problems. Metropolitan Correction Center San Diego MCC San Diego (bop.gov) The San Diego County Jail where arrested people are processed and held for trial. There are more jails and correctional facilities throughout the county that interface with it. The correctional center is also right next to the County Courthouse. Community Organizations Anti-Defamation League Anti-Defamation League | About | San Diego (adl.org) Anti-Defamation League | REPAIR Plan: Fighting Hate in the Digital World | San Diego (adl.org) ADL is the leading anti-hate organization in the world. Founded in 1913, its timeless mission is “to stop the defamation of the Jewish people and to secure justice and fair treatment to all.” Today, ADL continues to fight all forms of antisemitism and bias, using innovation and partnerships to drive impact. A global leader in combating antisemitism, countering extremism and battling bigotry wherever and whenever it happens, ADL works to protect democracy and ensure a just and inclusive society for all. REPAIR Plan ADL’s REPAIR Plan focuses on fighting domestic extremism and terrorism but goes beyond these issues to address other manifestations and harms of online hate, including harassment, antisemitism, anti-Muslim bigotry, racism, and extremist disinformation. Repair stands for Regulation and reform, enforcing at scale, people over profit, access to justice, Interrupting disinformation, Research and innovation. Jewish Family Services Anti-Defamation League | REPAIR Plan: Fighting Hate in the Digital World | San Diego (adl.org) Black Women’s Resilience Project - JFSSD Jewish Family Service is a client-centered, impact-driven organization working to build a stronger, healthier, more resilient San Diego. Founded in 1918, they are one of San Diego’s most impactful non-profit human services agencies. During the last fiscal year they served more than 71,000 individuals, including more than 14,000 children and 12,400 older adults.  Jewish Family Services offers a wide range of programs to help with anti-semantic hate and to strive towards a safer community. Black Women’s Resilience Project The goal of the Black Women’s Resilience Project (BWRP) is to support and advance culturally relevant strategies to shift human services delivery models for Black women facing the violence of poverty. Through this program, they seek to understand the racial and ethnic experience of poverty as a social construct, rather than a character deficit, and actively develop solutions to eliminate it. Chabad of Poway Synagogue Chabad of Poway (chabadpoway.com) Chabad of Poway has become a popular center for Jews of all backgrounds who want to learn more about their Jewish roots. Chabad offers a wide variety of educational and spiritual opportunities, including Torah classes and lectures, Shabbaton dinners, and an array of family and social activities. Traditional Jewish values are brought to life in a joyous, non-judgmental atmosphere. Chabad serves all segments of the Jewish community. Everyone is welcome regardless of their personal level of religious observance. The philosophy is in keeping with the Chabad-Lubavitch approach of joy, scholarship and unconditional acceptance and love for every Jew. Chabad experiences a horrific hate crime in 2019, that resulted in one death, and injuring three others including a rabbi. Chabad of Poway offers an abundance of educational classes for the community to learn about Jewish culture. San Diego Immigrant Rights Consortium (SDIRC) San Diego Immigrant Rights Consortium (immigrantsandiego.org) San Diego Immigrant Rights Consortium (SDIRC) is a coalition of various organizations in San Diego that work to protect the rights and dignity of immigrants and refugees. They may also address issues related to hate and discrimination. SDIRC works at all levels; federal through their New Border Vision framework which upholds the dignity and rights of all people at US’s borders, State by monitoring local law enforcement agencies and local to push local measures and resources such as their new campaign “Welcoming San Diego”. Islamic Center San Diego Home (icsd.org) Their mission is to serve the religious needs of the San Diego Muslim population and work with the larger community to serve the less fortunate, to educate, and to better our nation. ​They also work with other Mosques in San Diego county in sponsoring and holding events for the local Muslim community. In addition to these programs, ICSD is increasingly branching out in working with other San Diego organizations for social causes of interest to all people of faith. Meeting focus: Discuss the importance of building communities centered on love and understanding rather than exclusion and stigma. Partnership for the Advancement of New Americans (PANA) PANA (panasd.org) Partnership for the Advancement of New Americans (PANA) focused on ending systematic racism for the Muslim community through civic engagement, tenant protection, policy and campaigns in which they have passed through the City Council the Source of Income Anti-Discrimination ordinance. PANA is founded, led, and staffed by refugees, which makes PANA as an organization uniquely situated to use relational organizing to bring community into a pathway of ongoing engagement and indigenous community leadership development. Meeting focus: learn PANA’s efforts in ending systematic racism for Muslims in San Diego through civic engagement, tenant protection, policy and campaigns. Academia Kroc School of Peace and Justice Joan B. Kroc School of Peace Studies - University of San Diego The Violence, Inequality and Power Lab - Joan B. Kroc School of Peace Studies - University of San Diego Women, Peace and Security - Joan B. Kroc School of Peace Studies - University of San Diego The Joan B. Kroc School of Peace Studies (Kroc School) at the University of San Diego is the global hub for peacebuilding and social innovation. Founded in 2007, the Kroc School equips the next generation of innovative changemakers to shape more peaceful and just societies. They offer master's degrees in peace and justice, social innovation, humanitarian action, conflict management and resolution, and a dual degree in peace and law. With its Institutes and their academic programs, the Kroc School supports positive change beyond the classroom. Through groundbreaking research, experiential learning, and forward-thinking programs, the Kroc School is shaping a future in which peaceful co-existence is the new normal. The Violence, Inequality and Power Lab (VIP Lab) At the Violence, Inequality, and Power (VIP) Lab, they seek to understand how inequalities of power shape the landscape of violence. They deliver practical, actionable ideas that partners can implement at the systems level to confront harmful power inequalities and reduce violence. Women, Peace, and Security Lab At the Women, Peace and Security Lab, they bring together women peacebuilders from around the world, renowned international women, and peace and security organizations. Past reports have focused on women’s experience of extremism. The Applied Research Center for Civility at UC San Diego Applied Research Center for Civility (ucsd.edu) Using the National Conflict Resolution Center’s programming as a springboard, the Center for Civility selects faculty and researchers throughout UC San Diego and the nation to design studies, collect data, and conduct quantitative analysis on how one can foster connection in divisive times. The center conducts cutting-edge research into the dynamics of society’s most pressing issues and creates comprehensive models for national distribution and discussion. UC Institute on Global Conflict and Cooperation About IGCC - IGCC (ucigcc.org) The UC Institute on Global Conflict and Cooperation (IGCC) is a research network comprised of scholars from across the University of California and the Los Alamos and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratories that conducts policy-relevant research to mitigate conflict and promote a more peaceful world order. Their focus is on challenges that have the potential to lead to wide-scale conflict and that can benefit from global cooperation to solve. Youth & Women Organizations

name: San Diego Youth Services
description: San Diego Youth Services’ provides intensive services to more than 17,000 youth every year. San Diego Youth Services offers a continuum of care for children and youth from infancy to age 25. They aim to meet the basic needs of youth such as hunger, poverty and youth homelessness as they are on the rise for many youth and their families today. San Diego Youth Services’ helps meet these basic needs for youth. They also provide safe places to live and long-term solutions through shelter, foster homes, community centers and housing. San Diego Youth Services also help youth focus on positive life changes and healthy relationships as part of providing needed resources and services.
source_proposal: 11 - Countering Violent Extremism Proposal.docx

name: Juvenile Delinquency Prevention, Diversion and Intervention Program (BridgeWays & Community Assessment Team)
description: The San Diego Youth Services provides a wide range of programs including their Juvenile Delinquency Prevention, Diversion and Intervention Program, a community assessment team, and an after-school achievement center. Their Juvenile Diversion comprehensive program, including their partner program BridgeWays, addresses the behavioral health needs of youth involved with the justice system or youth at risk of involvement, up to age 21. This behavioral health needs program provides outpatient clinical services and field support services for youth up to age 21. Their Community Assessment Team provides individualized supportive case management and links youth dealing with behavioral, social or juvenile justice issues and their families with needed resources and services in Central and East regions of San Diego County.
source_proposal: 11 - Countering Violent Extremism Proposal.docx

name: Child Sex Trafficking, Awareness and Recovery Program
description: At San Diego Youth Services, they have helped thousands of children and young adults who are at risk for trafficking, as well as those who have already been trafficked. Their goal is for the youth they serve to become emotionally and financially self-reliant, so that they are able to overcome the trauma they have experienced, heal and lead productive and healthy lives. San Diego Youth Services’ staff members work directly with survivors to get them back on their feet, by providing them with resources, including shelter and food, so that they are able to leave their old lives behind. They also provide mental health services, educational support, employment opportunities, as well as support to their families. David’s Harp Foundation Home Page – The David's Harp Foundation (davidsharpfoundation.org) David’s Harp Foundation aims to inspire, educate and empower at-risk and homeless youth to achieve academic success through music education, sound engineering and multimedia production. Programs include Multimedia Production where instructors teach students to fuse audio, video, still image and animation into a dynamic. The Foundation also hosts a Shelter Nights program in partnership with San Diego Youth Services’ Emergency Youth Shelter. After checking into the shelter for the night, Youth Shelter teens work with instructors in their studio to write, record and produce original music and poetry, motivating teens to stay off the streets and hone their musical interests. ARTS 4 Justice ARTS 4 Justice — A Reason To Survive (ARTS) The ARTS 4 Justice initiative connects system-involved young people with creative arts programming and community-based projects in an effort to confront and respond the root causes of systemic violence and injustice in communities across south San Diego. Youth participants put Creative Youth Development (CYD) practices into action through their stories, ideas, dreams, and visions for a better future that find creative expression in murals, photography, comics, zines, and other works. Barrio Logan College Institute Barrio Logan College Institute – Breaking the Cycle of Poverty Through Education (blci.org) Barrio Logan College Institute is located in Barrio Logan, a part of the San Diego community that is rich in culture but underserved in resources. Their mission is to break the cycle of poverty by preparing students to be the first in their families to go to college through after school programs that begin in third grade. Located in a traditionally low-income community, BLCI promotes higher education as a ticket out of poverty. To date, 100% of Barrio Logan College Institute’s students have enrolled in college. StandUp for Kids StandUp For Kids | Ending the Cycle of Youth Homelessness Teen homelessness rates are on the rise. Their concern is that homeless kids are the most likely target of human traffickers, pornographers, and gangs. These vulnerable kids are forced to endure unimaginable horrors, just to survive. They have a drop-in center, street outreach, mentoring, and a housing support program. StandUp for Kids has been supporting kids for over three decades. They support youth up to their 25th birthday. Their framework has three key steps, Engage, Connect, and Sustain. StandUp for kids seeks to prevent runaways, connect youth to services, and sustain their involvement. Reality Changers Home - Reality Changers Reality Changers transforms lives, schools, and communities by providing youth from disadvantaged backgrounds with the academic support, financial assistance and leadership training to become first generation college students. Today, Reality Changers’ 500 current members and 500 program graduates have earned approximately $40,000,000 in scholarships. Outdoor Outreach Outdoor Outreach Since, 1999, Outdoor Outreach has provided opportunities for more than 20,000 San Diego Youth to explore their world, cultivate belonging, and discover what they’re capable of.  They connect youth to the transformative power of the outdoors. They partner with 40+ schools and social service agencies to provide services to youth aged 9-24 whose communities have been historically impacted by social inequities. Discussion Focus: Discuss their mission of connecting youth to the transformative power of the outdoors. RISE San Diego RISE San Diego RISE San Diego is a non-profit organization whose mission is to elevate and advance urban leadership through dialogue-based civic engagement, dynamic nonprofit partnerships, and direct training and support to increase the capacity of urban residents to effect meaningful community change. RISE San Diego is about developing the people within communities who actually make it happen. RISE Urban Leadership Fellows Program is a partnership of RISE San Diego and the Leadership Institute at the University of San Diego School of Leadership and Education Sciences (SOLES). RISE’s unique goal and commitment is to help identify and empower a generation of leaders who will not only bring our urban communities up, but also bring them together. Meeting focus: Explore RISE San Diego’s youth-focused grassroots civic engagement programs, non-profit trainings, and leadership development models. Community Wraparound Community Wraparound | Non-Profit Organization | San Diego (ueniweb.com) A transformative gang prevention and positive youth development initiative that leverages strategic community alliances to support gang-affiliated youth by offering viable alternatives. Their mission is to provide supportive mentoring services through a trauma-informed and lived experience lens to build resilience in youth, families, and communities. They aim to create a society where young individuals can thrive, break from negative influences, and find success with their families, school, work, and community. Formerly incarcerated people may share their work helping young people with homework, food, and hosting events. Formerly incarcerated people become credible messengers, heal, and assist community healing. San Diego National Organization for Women (SDNOW) San Diego National Organization for Women | About Us (sandiegonow.org) The San Diego National Organization for Women believes that women’s rights are human rights. They focus on safe reproductive access for all women, ending sexual discrimination, promoting diversity, promoting marriage equality, and ending racism and violence against women. NOW is the largest organization of feminist activists in the United States. _______________________________ **Home Hospitality can be offered for the group, as well as a volunteer activity (Saturdays only) ** San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $46 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. It is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park. Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $27 for one Adult Ticket for two-hour tour Their deluxe tour covers it all: Harbor and Shelter Islands, Point Loma, Cabrillo National Monument, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and much more. Tour is about 25 miles in length, 2 hour narrated tour. Old Town Trolley Tour www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com www.trolleytours.com/san-diego Price: $36 for one Adult Ticket For over 20 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours highlighting the best San Diego attractions. Old Town Trolley Tours is the best way to see the city, highlighting the best San Diego Attractions, with 11 stops and more than 100 points of interest. Old Town offers much to do, from visiting over 23 historic sites to shopping for unique merchandise. They also have many award winning restaurants to choose from. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 29 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 15 major museums, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Coronado Consistently voted one of America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year around due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. From the shores of Silver Strand State Beach to the tip of the Coronado Municipal Beach, you’ll find plenty of wide open sand, gentle waves and gorgeous views. SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $84 for one Adult Ticket Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Shamu show, One Ocean, and thrilling rides like Journey To Atlantis, Shipwreck Rapids and Wild Arctic. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Then dive into the world of sea turtles at the all-new Turtle Reef attraction.

name: University of San Diego
description: The University of San Diego (USD) is an academic institution with a student population of around 9,000. USD offers comprehensive education across its seven schools and colleges, particularly standing out for its emphasis on business development and entrepreneurship. The School of Business provides students with valuable resources, mentorship programs, and experiential learning opportunities, empowering them to thrive in the ever-evolving business landscape. In addition, the University of San Diego is renowned for its Joan B. Kroc School of Peace Studies, which offers innovative programs and initiatives dedicated to advancing peacebuilding, conflict resolution, and social justice on a global scale. We suggest a full day of programming at USD including the following resources, however, all can be considered as standalone options as well. Spark @ USD, Joan B. Kroc School of Peace Studies www.sandiego.edu/peace/institutes/ipj Dedicated to fostering peace, cultivating justice, and creating a safer world, the Joan B. Kroc Institute for Peace & Justice (IPJ) of the University of San Diego is an international nonprofit organization working to improve the lives of those caught in the web of armed conflict and human rights abuses. Existing within the Kroc School, Spark is an entrepreneurial hub that fosters innovation and supports aspiring student entrepreneurs. It provides a collaborative space where students can develop their entrepreneurial ideas, connect with mentors, and receive guidance to launch their ventures. Spark offers various resources, including workshops, networking events, and access to a strong network of industry professionals. One of the key meeting focus areas at Spark is social entrepreneurship, where students are encouraged to explore business ideas that address societal challenges and create positive impact.
source_proposal: 12 - Proposal_ Social Entrepreneurship in the United States (1).docx

name: Master of Arts in Social Innovation
description: Look critically at the roots of social challenges and injustice, and then seek to create real change through bold new responses to poverty, inequality, human rights abuses and humanitarian crises. The Master's in Social Innovation degree is unlike any other in that it starts by diving deep into real social challenges, then pairs that knowledge with critical thinking, inventiveness, leadership and sustainable business design. Through the Fowler Global Social Innovation Challenge, university students in San Diego and Tijuana generate ideas for innovative ventures that respond to a social, economic, environmental, or justice issue of their choice, and compete for seed funding to launch or expand their ventures. Meeting focus: Discuss USD’s capitalization of trends towards academic studies of social entrepreneurship, and their push to encourage young entrepreneurs to remain engaged beyond academic settings.
source_proposal: 12 - Proposal_ Social Entrepreneurship in the United States (1).docx

name: Fowler Global Social Innovation Challenge
description: The Fowler Global Social Innovation Challenge is an exciting competition hosted by the University of San Diego's Center for Peace and Commerce. It invites students from around the world to develop innovative solutions to pressing social and environmental issues. Participants form teams and undergo a rigorous process of ideation, prototyping, and refining their ideas with the guidance of mentors. The challenge culminates in a live pitch event where finalists present their solutions to a panel of judges and compete for funding and support. Since 2011, they have connected more than 2,500 students, recognizing their outstanding social ventures. They have also distributed more than $600,000 to seed innovative and promising global ventures.
source_proposal: 12 - Proposal_ Social Entrepreneurship in the United States (1).docx

name: Brink Small Business Development Center
description: The Brink SBDC is an incubator focused on innovation, one of only a handful of its kind in the country, hosted at University of San Diego. The Brink SDBC works with business clients running or starting growth-oriented, innovation-based companies with fewer than 500 employees. The Brink SBDC works with entrepreneurs with an innovative product, solution or service and has a larger than local addressable market and a scalable business model. Their expert advisors provide one-on-one consulting, training workshops, and access to valuable resources and networks. Whether it's developing a business plan, securing funding, or navigating regulatory requirements, the Brink SBDC assists entrepreneurs at every stage of their journey.
source_proposal: 12 - Proposal_ Social Entrepreneurship in the United States (1).docx

name: Lavin Entrepreneurship Center, San Diego State University
description: The Lavin Entrepreneurship Center at San Diego State University (SDSU) is a dynamic hub that nurtures and supports aspiring entrepreneurs in their pursuit of innovation and business success. It serves students, entrepreneurs and business leaders through its entrepreneurial curriculum, workshops, internships, resources and events. The Lavin Center has been recognized for having one of the best entrepreneurial programs in the United States by both Princeton Review and Entrepreneur magazine. One of their popular workshops is on Digital Marketing and Social Media Strategies. This workshop dives into the realm of digital marketing, exploring effective tactics and strategies for utilizing social media platforms, creating engaging content, optimizing online advertising, and implementing search engine optimization (SEO) techniques. Participants gain insights into how to effectively leverage digital channels to reach target audiences, build brand awareness, drive customer engagement, and ultimately enhance their online presence.
source_proposal: 12 - Proposal_ Social Entrepreneurship in the United States (1).docx

name: La Jolla Country Day School – Center for Design and Innovation
description: La Jolla Country Day School (LJCDS) is a private college prep school in the coastal community of La Jolla. The school’s Innovation Program challenges students to identify real-world problems and design innovative solutions to effect positive change for a better world. The curriculum from kindergarten to Grade 12 focuses on learning how to use cutting-edge tools and technologies while developing an understanding of the social impacts of technology, solutions and design. LJCDS’ Innovation Lab serves as a collaborative space that is equipped with a laser cutter (built from scratch by Upper School students), 3D printers, microcontrollers, Wacom tablets, drills, screwdrivers, hammers, sticky notes and anything else students may need for creative design and innovation. Additionally, LJCDS offers a venture capital fund for their students called the Torrey Explorer’s Fund (TEF). Whether students seek to start a business, launch a social campaign, invent a technology or create an art installation, TEF will offer mentorship by a team of local entrepreneurs and professionals and/or funding to help bring students’ ideas to fruition. Incubators, Accelerators, and Resource Hubs Hera Hub www.herahub.com Hera Hub is the first international female-focused coworking space – a shared, flexible work and meeting space where entrepreneurial women can create and collaborate in a professional, productive, modern environment. The platform provides members with connections to other business experts, access to educational workshops, and visibility within the community, thus giving women the support they need to be prosperous. In addition, Hera Fund gathers Angel Investors and pairs them with women owned businesses. The company was founded in San Diego, CA in 2011 and has since then been growing with locations sprouting up all over the U.S. and Europe. Meeting focus: Explore how a coworking space has empowered women by addressing multiple community needs in San Diego. Representatives will give visitors a tour and discuss how Hera Hub empowers female entrepreneurs. A meeting with Hera Hub may feature some incubator members, who can share insight into their work and processes. San Diego Hispanic Chamber of e-commerce www.hiscec.com After realizing there was a digital gap between the Hispanic community and the business world, Tayde Aburto founded the Hispanic Chamber of e-Commerce eight years ago. The Chamber aims to empower small businesses run by Hispanics by enabling these businesses to become successful in e-commerce. The Hispanic Chamber of e-Commerce offers courses and consulting services throughout the County to educate small business owners as to the need to have, at the very least, a website, Facebook page, or LinkedIn account. What started as a small group of advocates is today an organization with more than a thousand members.

name: The Village Up
description: The Village Up aims to help diverse founders and talent in the San Diego startup community thrive. They lead impactful initiatives that engage diverse entrepreneurs and talent, mobilizing people to improve diversity and access to business and career opportunities for the underrepresented in the San Diego tech startup community. While they value performance as a sign of their impact, The Village Up prioritizes capturing stories of impact to fuel motivation, and to keep supporting talent from minority communities. Economic Development and Investment

name: Qualcomm Ventures
description: Qualcomm is renowned as the world’s leading wireless technology innovator. They invent breakthrough technologies that transform how the world connects, computes, and communicates, including 5G enabled smartphones, and other technologies that impact billions of people every day. Qualcomm is committed to driving invention and innovation, and under Qualcomm Ventures, is currently overseeing $2 billion worth of investment across over 150 active portfolio companies.

name: Smart Border Coalition
description: The Smart Border Coalition is a catalyst to bring together leading academic, business and civic communities from both sides of the San Diego/Tijuana International region to develop databases and policy positions, deliver special events and programs, and growth of the cross-border economy through jobs creation, workforce development and social interaction. Their mission is to make travel and trade easier and more efficient through the ports of entry between San Diego County and the Tijuana Metropolitan Area.

name: San Diego Regional Chamber of Commerce – Policy
description: The San Diego Regional Chamber of Commerce is committed to making San Diego the most business-friendly region in California. A strong economy creates jobs that support families, neighborhoods, and the entire region. Since the late 1800s, the Chamber has helped San Diego grow by engaging with elected officials, their members, and the public to address the issues most important to job creation and the region. Today, as much as ever, they are committed to an even better future for San Diego. San Diego and Imperial Small Business Development Center The San Diego and Imperial Small Business Development Center (SBDC) is a valuable resource for entrepreneurs and small business owners in the region. As part of the California SBDC network, they provide expert guidance through one-on-one consulting, training workshops, and access to valuable resources and networks. They assist with various aspects of business development, including business planning, marketing strategies, financial management, and accessing capital. The San Diego and Imperial SBDC plays a crucial role in fostering entrepreneurship, job creation, and economic growth by providing tailored assistance and empowering small businesses to thrive in a competitive market. Director of the SBDC, Briana Weisinger, has worked with hundreds of startups as well as opening and closing her own businesses, thus she understands the struggles related to small business ownership. Her personal missions include uplifting equality in the business world and working with multiple local organizations to promote women entrepreneurs. She believes in giving her time generously to these personal missions.

name: Torrey Project
description: The Torrey Project is an innovative initiative focused on empowering the next generation of entrepreneurs and leaders. They provide a platform for young individuals to develop essential skills, network with industry professionals, and gain real-world experience. Through mentorship programs, workshops, and entrepreneurial challenges, participants are equipped with the tools and knowledge needed to succeed in a rapidly changing business landscape. The Torrey Project fosters creativity, critical thinking, and collaboration, encouraging participants to think outside the box and pursue their passions. The Torrey Project Seed Fund is a vital component of the Torrey Project's mission to support and invest in promising startups and early-stage ventures. The seed fund provides crucial financial resources and mentorship to selected entrepreneurs, helping them turn their innovative ideas into successful businesses. The Torrey Project aims to invest in diverse founders and ventures that exhibit strong growth potential, disruptive ideas, and a commitment to making a positive impact. They seek out entrepreneurs with a drive for innovation, a clear vision for their business, and a scalable business model, and focus on supporting those who are typically overlooked by traditional forms of seed capital. The Torrey Project is particularly interested in supporting ventures in emerging industries such as technology, sustainability, healthcare, and social impact. Government Resources

name: The City of San Diego’s Economic Development Department
description: The City of San Diego's Economic Development Department provides valuable resources and support to entrepreneurs and businesses, helping them succeed and contribute to the local economy. The department offers various programs and initiatives, including business development assistance, workforce training, and access to funding opportunities. Two notable examples of their projects include the Business Acceleration Program, which provides tailored support to high-growth startups, and the Small Business Enhancement Program, which offers grants and resources to small businesses for expansion and improvement. Through their initiatives, the Economic Development Department actively supports entrepreneurship, job creation, and economic growth in San Diego.With the goal of promoting economic opportunity for all segments of the population, the City of San Diego leverages public incentives and assistance to foster community revitalization, attract new businesses and encourage investment in local businesses. The City of San Diego not only assists individual businesses but also helps strengthen business organizations and improve business districts throughout San Diego.

name: U.S Small Business Administration– San Diego District
description: https://www.sba.gov/funding-programs/loans/microloans The U.S. Small Business Administration (SBA) - San Diego District plays a crucial role in supporting small businesses in the region. In the past fiscal year, the San Diego District office provided significant support, including over $200 million in loans to small businesses, helping them access the capital needed to start, grow, and expand their ventures. The SBA San Diego District offers a range of programs and services, with a particular emphasis on microlending. They collaborate with local microlenders to provide small loans to entrepreneurs and underserved communities, fostering economic development and job creation. Through their efforts, the SBA San Diego District is instrumental in driving the success of small businesses and fueling economic growth in the community. Non-profit Resources

name: Connect
description: Connect is a non-profit organization that has assisted in the formation and development of more than 3,000 companies in the San Diego region, and is widely regarded as one of the world’s most successful organizations linking inventors and entrepreneurs with the resources they need for commercialization of innovative products in high tech and life sciences. The program has been modeled in more than 50 regions around the world. In 2019, Connect and San Diego Venture Group merged, combining the deep histories and wide successes of each organization to create a powerhouse of resources such as mentorship, education, and capital for quality companies.

name: San Diego Regional Economic Development Corporation (EDC)
description: The San Diego Regional Economic Development Corporation (EDC) is an independently-funded economic development organization that mobilizes business, government, and civic leaders around an inclusive economic development strategy in order to connect data to decision making, maximize regional prosperity, enhance global competitiveness, and position San Diego effectively for investment and talent. The EDC provides resources, data analysis, and strategic insights to help businesses make informed decisions and navigate the local business landscape. They also engage in advocacy efforts to shape policies that promote economic development and create a favorable business environment.

name: Kitchens for Good
description: Kitchens for Good is a 501(c)(3) and social enterprise with the mission to break the cycles of food waste, hunger, and poverty through innovative solutions in workforce training, healthy food production, and social enterprise. Kitchens for Good rescues surplus and cosmetically imperfect food from wholesalers and farmers, and engages students in a culinary apprenticeship program. Through the power of kitchens and cooking, their students transform their lives from one of addiction, incarceration, homelessness, and unemployment, to lives of stability, employment, and a brighter future. Startup San Diego Startup San Diego is a California 501(c)(3) nonprofit that serves as the gateway to the San Diego Startup Ecosystem. We up-skill, guide, and connect our local community to the right ecosystem resources, networks, and support institutions to foster a cohesive and collaborative community. Their  mission is to connect, educate, and inspire founders and local talent to grow an equitable San Diego startup ecosystem and entrepreneurial community. They envision San Diego as a thriving and inclusive global hub of innovation, producing meaningful and high-growth companies. Startup San Diego has three main initiatives; the Startup Incubator Program, 1st Mondays (a networking program), and San Diego Startup Week.

name: Jacobs Center for Neighborhood Innovation
description: Jacobs Center works to foster a thriving community, as it is envisioned and realized by its residents. They aim to be part of a caring community where people are responsible to echo there, where all cultures are embraced, and residents create the future they envision. Economic development is a core component of the work at Jacobs Center, supporting early stage entrepreneurs and accelerating existing neighborhood businesses to support a more inclusive economy for all residents. Cultural Activities Cafe 21 www.cafe-21.com/ As one of the most innovative restaurants in San Diego, Cafe21 is committed to changing the way their guests think about food. Everything they do at this Azerbaijani restaurant is made from scratch and with love. San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. name: Chicano Park
description: Chicano Park is the geographic and emotional heart of Barrio Logan, located in Logan Heights, San Diego's oldest Mexican-American neighborhood. The park is home to the largest concentration of Chicano murals in the world with more than 80 paintings on seven acres dotted with sculpture, gardens, picnic tables and playgrounds. Throughout the year, it hosts festivals of music and Aztec dance, the biggest being Chicano Park Day held each April. Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $30 for one Adult Ticket for a one-hour narrated tour (south bay or north bay routes); $35 for a full bay two-hour narrated tour which covers it all: ships of the Maritime Museum, Harbor and Shelter Islands, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and more. The full bay tour is about 25 miles in length. Accessibility: The tour begins and ends at the same location downtown along Broadway Pier. Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com Price: $44 for a 1-Day Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) For 30 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours, highlighting the best San Diego attractions. The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50am – 5:00pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $26 for one Adult General Admission Ticket ($1 discount when purchased on-line). Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10am – 5pm (Last admission at 4pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside Navy Pier.

name: Border Field State Park & Friendship Park
description: https://www.friendshippark.org/ Located within the Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve, Border Field State Park sits in the very southwestern corner of the United States, 15 miles south of San Diego. This important wildlife habitat, comprised of sand dunes and salt marshes, gives refuge to critically threatened and endangered birds such as the Western Snowy Plover, the California Least Tern, and the Light-footed Ridgway's Rail. Friendship Park is a binational park located at the western end of the US-Mexico border. For generations people have gathered here to meet up with friends and family "across the line." Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 17 major museums and cultural institutions, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).
source_proposal: 12 - Proposal_ Social Entrepreneurship in the United States (1).docx

name: Coronado
description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year around due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown. SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $99.99 for one Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Orca Encounter, Dolphin Days, and Sea Lions Live shows and thrilling rides like Electric Eel, Manta, and Journey To Atlantis. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Hours vary by season. Also enjoy the opening of Sesame Place in March 2022, a Sesame Street themed section of the park with new water, ride, and musical attractions. Accessibility: A 15-20-minute drive from downtown San Diego.
source_proposal: 12 - Proposal_ Social Entrepreneurship in the United States (1).docx

name: San Diego County Young Democrats
description: San Diego County Young Democrats (SDCYD) is part of the California State Democratic Party, which works closely with local elected officials, and the county party. Open to registered Democrats under 36, SDCYD members work to improve the San Diego community, and to elect Democrats. SDCYD holds regular events for members around the county, including guest speakers, opportunities for political action, community service, and networking events.

name: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs
description: Congresswoman Sara Jacobs is in her second term in Congress, and proudly serves California’s 51st Congressional District. Prior to serving in elected office, Congresswoman Jacobs worked to address, minimize, and prevent conflict, instability, and inequality around the world. As one of the youngest members of democratic leadership in the House, and the youngest member in Congress, Congresswoman Jacobs is a strong advocate of issues pertaining to young people including climate, childcare, education, reproductive rights, and healthcare access.
