name: Mayor Todd Gloria
description: Mayor Gloria has spent his career in public service. After being elected to the California State Assembly to represent the 78th Assembly District in 2016, Mayor Gloria passed legislation on many major issues San Diego is working to address including affordable housing, fighting gun violence, combatting climate change, and providing resources for unhoused people. A third-generation San Diegan of Filipino, Dutch, Puerto Rican, and Native American descent,  Mayor Gloria is motivated to improve San Diego every day.
source_proposal: 12 - The U.S. Electoral Process for the Indo-Pacific and SCA.docx

name: Nora Vargas, San Diego County Supervisor District 1
description: https://www.kpbs.org/news/2021/feb/05/first-latina-supervisor-change-san-diego-politics/ Supervisor Nora Vargas represents District 1 in San Diego’s South County. She is the first immigrant, first Latina, and first Democrat to represent her district. For the last 25 years, Supervisor Vargas has worked to drive positive change and serve her community through public service. She is committed to ensuring that marginalized voices are included in the public dialogue regarding various important issues like health access, civic engagement, and education. Prior to her election, she was an elected member and President of the Southwestern College Governing Board, the only public institution of higher education within San Diego’s South County. Virtual Meeting Focus: Discuss the demographics of Supervisor Vargas’s district and the significance her election has on the region.
source_proposal: 12 - The U.S. Electoral Process for the Indo-Pacific and SCA.docx

name: San Diego County District Attorney’s Office
description: The San Diego County District Attorney’s Office is responsible for prosecuting felony crimes committed in the County. It also prosecutes misdemeanor offenses that occur outside of the City of San Diego. Each year the more than 300 prosecutors in the DA’s Office file about 40,000 cases on behalf of the county’s more than three million residents. The employees of the San Diego County District Attorney, in partnership with the community we serve, are dedicated to the pursuit of truth, justice and protection of the innocent, and the prevention of crime through the vigorous and professional prosecution of those who violate the law. District Attorney Summer Stephan has devoted her life to protecting children and families, providing justice to the most vulnerable, and is a national leader in the fight against human trafficking and sexual exploitation. In 2022, Summer was named one of “The Five Best Prosecutors in America,” utilizing evaluation factors of integrity, fidelity to the rule of law, responsible innovations, and community relations. Academic Institutes

name: Joint School Visit: La Jolla Country Day School (LJCDS) Center for Excellence in Citizenship (CEC) & The Preuss School UC San Diego
description: https://preuss.ucsd.edu/ La Jolla Country Day School is an independent college-preparatory school serving students from age 3 through Grade 12 in San Diego’s coastal community of La Jolla. The Center for Excellence in Citizenship (CEC) develops unique opportunities for LJCDS students, faculty and families to engage in the vital work of local, national and global citizenship, focusing on the fundamental importance of human dignity in all interactions. CEC fosters civic engagement and civil discourse, galvanizing students to think about their rights and responsibilities as citizens and to be thoughtful participants in their communities. Recognized by Newsweek as the top transformative high school in the nation for three years in a    row, The Preuss School UC San Diego is a unique charter middle and high school for low-income students who strive to become the first in their families to graduate from college. Located on the University of California San Diego campus, The Preuss School’s students come from 	throughout San Diego County to take advantage of an environment that encourage intellectual risk-taking while offering an array of academic supports.

name: Institute for Civil Civic Engagement
description: https://www.sandiego.edu/institute-for-civil-civic-engagement/ The Institute for Civil Civic Engagement (ICCE) is located at the University of San Diego, one of San Diego’s leading tertiary institutions. ICCE works to encourage, promote and increase civility in civic discourse by fellow citizens and public officials, both interpersonally and in all manner of media. The institute seeks to promote ways to be civil in disagreements and respectful in debates, as they confront the political challenges that shape the community. Some of the ICCE’s main goals include to encourage the San Diego community to embrace basic elements of civility in dealing with civic activism and political campaigning, to hold community leaders accountable to conducting public discourse, and to develop and implement programs and curriculum providing effective instruction in best methods of civil civic engagement for educational communities. Meeting focus: Meet with representatives of ICCE to explore initiatives including CivicTalk San Diego, Student Civility Awards, and Richard Nixon: The Musical.
source_proposal: 12 - The U.S. Electoral Process for the Indo-Pacific and SCA.docx

name: Zoltan Hajnal, PhD – Professor at the University of California, San Diego
description: https://ucsdnews.ucsd.edu/pressrelease/how-to-double-voter-turnout-and-increase-representation-during-local-elections Zoltan Hajnal is a professor of political science at the School of Global Policy and Strategy, Hajnal teaches courses including Policy Analysis and Public Welfare. Hajnal is a respected scholar on U.S. politics and policy, with a specific focus on how disadvantaged populations are represented in American politics and what can be done to ensure better representation of these groups. His research areas span racial and ethnic politics, urban politics, immigration and political behavior. He is the author of multiple award-winning books including “White Backlash: Immigration, Race, and American Politics” (Princeton 2015), “Why Americans Don’t Join the Party: Race, Immigration, and the Failure of Political Parties to Engage the Electorate” (Princeton 2011), “America’s Uneven Democracy: Race, Turnout, and Representation in City Politics” (Cambridge 2010) and “Changing White Attitudes toward Black Political Leadership” (Cambridge 2006). His research has been featured in The New York Times, Washington Post and a range of other media outlets. Meeting focus: Discuss and explore political behavior across different communities to gain a perspective of how disadvantaged populations are represented in politics. Think Tanks, Community Resources, and Coalitions

name: Voice of San Diego
description: Launched in 2005, Voice of San Diego was the first digital, nonprofit news organization in the country to serve a local community. Their mission is to consistently deliver ground-breaking investigative journalism for the San Diego region and to increase civic participation by giving residents the knowledge and in-depth analysis necessary to become advocates for good government and social progress.

name: Inewsource
description: inewsource is a nonprofit, nonpartisan newsroom dedicated to improving lives in the San Diego region and beyond through impactful, data-based investigative and accountability journalism. Inewsource values, above all else, the importance of a free and credible press, where truth is the cornerstone of democracy. Inewsource is also a proud member of The Trust Project, supporting efforts to increase transparency in journalism.
source_proposal: 12 - The U.S. Electoral Process for the Indo-Pacific and SCA.docx

name: Engage San Diego
description: Engage San Diego is a collaborative network of social justice focused, non-profit groups working to increase civic and voter engagement in historically and systemically excluded communities of San Diego County. Engage San Diego table members are established and effective civic engagement and social change organizations with deep roots in the neighborhoods they serve. Its vision is a San Diego where the electorate and leadership are reflective of people who live and work here.
source_proposal: 12 - The U.S. Electoral Process for the Indo-Pacific and SCA.docx

name: The San Diego LGBT Community Center
description: The San Diego Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Transgender Community Center, Inc., (The Center) is one of the largest and most vibrant LGBTQ community centers in the nation. Functioning as the San Diego LGBTQ community’s anchor organization, The Center provides targeted programs and services to the full diversity of the San Diego LGBTQ community, including lesbian, gay, bisexual, queer, transgender, nonbinary, immigrant, and HIV communities to the betterment of our entire San Diego region. Last year, The Center provided more than 80,000 direct service visits to San Diego community members, and through its events, activities, and advocacy, touched the lives of thousands more. Explore the history of The Center as well as how it has continued to modernize and provide the LGBTQ+ community with helpful resources. We propose a central discussion of The Center’s Young Professional’s Council (YPC), a community of leaders and allies ages 21-40 that offers opportunities for connection, career development, friendship, and power-building.
source_proposal: 12 - The U.S. Electoral Process for the Indo-Pacific and SCA.docx

name: Alliance San Diego
description: Alliance San Diego is a non-profit, community organization whose mission is to provide a means for diverse individuals and organizations to share information, collaborate on issues and mobilize for change in the pursuit of social justice, especially in low-income communities and communities of color. They seek to mobilize communities through: leadership development, policy advocacy, communication strategies, and civic engagement. They focus on human rights, inclusive democracy, educational equity, and tax reform. Discuss Alliance San Diego’s advocacy and community building efforts for most vulnerable communities in San Diego.
source_proposal: 12 - The U.S. Electoral Process for the Indo-Pacific and SCA.docx

name: Community Advocates for Just and Moral Governance (MoGo)
description: Community Advocates for Just and Moral Governance (MoGo) promotes good governance. MoGo is committed to engaging in litigation and various forms of advocacy that will make government more just and fully accountable to all people, particularly those who have been marginalized from society. MoGo was founded by two Black women lawyers who have dedicated their lives and careers to secure racial equality, social justice, and greater access to quality education. Current MoGo campaigns include: stopping discriminatory policing practices against Black people, Indigenous people, people of color, LGBTQ individuals, and individuals with disabilities; protecting San Diegans' fourth amendment rights in regard to transparent and responsible use of surveillance technology in San Diego; and working to bring ranked choice voting to San Diego to improve voter turnout.

name: The Lincoln Club
description: The Lincoln Club Business League advocates for San Diego taxpayers, businesses, and residents who believe in lower taxes, less regulation, and a better quality of life. They work to advance free market principles by recruiting, endorsing, and financing business-friendly candidates and ballot measures that reflect their commitment to responsible public policy, the expansion of economic opportunity, and enhanced quality of life throughout San Diego County. Advocacy and Policy Resources

name: NAACP San Diego
description: The NAACP’s principal objective is to ensure the political, educational, social and economic equality of minority citizens of the United States and eliminate race prejudice. The NAACP seeks to remove all barriers of racial discrimination through democratic processes. This mission is accomplished by seeking the enactment and enforcement of federal, state and local laws securing civil rights, and by informing the public of the adverse effects of racial discrimination. From school desegregation, fair housing, employment and voter registration to health and equal economic opportunity, the NAACP is working successfully with allies of all races and plays a significant role in establishing legal precedents in order to improve the quality of life of America’s downtrodden.

name: Partnership for the Advancement of New Americans (PANA)
description: PANA is a research, public policy, and community organizing hub dedicated to advancing the full economic, social and civic inclusion of refugees. Founded, led, and staffed by refugees, PANA is uniquely situated to use relational organizing to bring the community into a pathway of ongoing engagement and indigenous community leadership development.
source_proposal: 12 - The U.S. Electoral Process for the Indo-Pacific and SCA.docx

name: San Diego Voters Voice
description: https://sdvotersvoice.org/ The Voters Voice Initiative is a coalition of non-partisan organizations working together to create transparency for campaign contributions and expenditures with local San Diego candidates. They are bringing transparency to San Diego elections through their transparency dashboard. With one click, the community can see candidate fundraising numbers for all city elections, providing clear data for voters. Voters Voice believes that making campaign finance data easy to find and read will increase public trust and confidence in the election process.
source_proposal: 12 - The U.S. Electoral Process for the Indo-Pacific and SCA.docx

name: League of Women Voters of San Diego (LWVSD)
description: The League of Women Voters is a nonpartisan political organization encouraging informed and active participation in government and influencing public policy through education and advocacy. LWVSD is dedicated to improving voter turnout and voter education. The San Diego League was founded in 1936 and has more than 500 members. They produce monthly events to inform members and the community about issues that are important to them; they conduct studies to form positions on relevant issues; advocate before the San Diego City Council and Board of Supervisors in support of their positions as they relate to legislation; host monthly committee meetings to enable their members to participate in their work at an in-depth level.

name: Open San Diego
description: Open San Diego is a chapter of the national, non-partisan Code for America, leveraging their resources, but focused on our own local issues. We are San Diegans who   believe a healthier interface between government and technology leads to a healthier democracy and more vibrant civic life. We care about our communities, our fellow citizens, and our civic institutions, and work together to support and bolster our Public.

name: Represent Us
description: RepresentUs brings together conservatives, progressives, and everyone in between to pass powerful anti-corruption laws that stop political bribery, end secret money, and fix our broken elections. Common Cause Common Cause is made up of more than 1 million powerful, fearless, ordinary Americans working together to build a democracy that works for everyone. They operate with the knowledge that the ultimate power in a democracy is the people, and government must reflect everyone it serves.

name: Mid-City CAN Advocacy Network
description: Mid-City CAN’s mission is to create a safe, productive, and healthy community through collaboration, advocacy, and organization. They work with residents and partners to drive positive change across many systems and issues rather than coming in as an outside force. They hold 	events open to the public, training to foster growth, and have a Youth Council to inspire and  prepare youth to take a more active role in their communities. Voter registration and voter engagement are critical power-building strategies for Mid-City CAN. By registering and encouraging people who don’t normally vote to participate, they are helping to build a stronger and more robust democracy. Nonprofit Organizations

name: San Diego Organizing Project
description: A nonpartisan, multi-faith network, San Diego Organizing Project (SDOP) represents more than 70,000 families across San Diego County. As one of the most diverse grassroots organizations in the region, SDOP bridges racial, cultural, and economic divides, unlocking the power of people to bring justice, equality, and greater opportunity to fruition in their communities. Some ongoing campaigns SDOP is currently focusing on include justice system reform, county government accountability, civic engagement, immigrant rights, and affordable housing and homelessness.

name: Alliance San Diego
description: Alliance San Diego is a non-profit, non-partisan community organization whose mission is to provide a means for diverse individuals and organizations to share information, collaborate on issues and mobilize for change in the pursuit of social justice, especially in low-income communities and communities of color. They seek to build collective power to create an inclusive democracy through leadership development, policy advocacy, communication strategies, and civic engagement. Alliance San Diego’s work is guided by three goals: equity and access, voting and governance, and safety and justice. Volunteer Activities San Diego River Park Foundation The San Diego River Park Foundation is dedicated to the celebration and care of the San Diego River, and to creating a better quality of life for the community through the creation of a park system along the 52-mile river. Their programs, projects, and events are designed to connect people to the historic San Diego River, and empower the community to steward and celebrate it. Activity Focus: With help from the San Diego River Park Foundation, learn more about the importance of the river as a biodiverse ecosystem in San Diego, and efforts they are doing to connect community to the River. Activities may include planting and revitalizing native plants, watering, and spreading mulch. ______________________________________________________________ Cultural Activities: San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $67 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).

name: Chicano Park
description: Chicano Park is the geographic and emotional heart of Barrio Logan, located in Logan Heights, San Diego's oldest Mexican-American neighborhood. The park is home to the largest concentration of Chicano murals in the world with more than 80 paintings on seven acres dotted with sculpture, gardens, picnic tables and playgrounds. Throughout the year, it hosts festivals of music and Aztec dance, the biggest being Chicano Park Day held each April. Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $30 for one Adult Ticket for a one-hour narrated tour (south bay or north bay routes); $35 for a full bay two-hour narrated tour which covers it all: ships of the Maritime Museum, Harbor and Shelter Islands, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and more. The full bay tour is about 25 miles in length. Accessibility: The tour begins and ends at the same location downtown along Broadway Pier.s Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com Price: $44 for a 1-Day Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) For 30 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours, highlighting the best San Diego attractions. The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50 am – 5:00 pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $26 for one Adult General Admission Ticket ($1 discount when purchased on-line). Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10am – 5pm (Last admission at 4pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside Navy Pier. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).

name: Presidio Park
description: Presidio Park in San Diego is a tranquil historical site with remnants of the city's original Spanish settlement, offering visitors a chance to step back in time. The Serra Museum within the park provides a deeper understanding of the area's history, while the park's botanical garden and picnic areas invite relaxation. Its elevated location provides a scenic view of San Diego, making it a favorite spot for those seeking a quiet escape, historical insights, or outdoor respite in a peaceful setting.

Meeting focus: Meet with representatives of ICCE to explore initiatives including CivicTalk San Diego, Student Civility Awards, and Richard Nixon: The Musical.
source_proposal: 12 - The U.S. Electoral Process.docx

name: Zoltan Hajnal, PhD – Professor at the University of California, San Diego
description: https://ucsdnews.ucsd.edu/pressrelease/how-to-double-voter-turnout-and-increase-representation-during-local-elections Zoltan Hajnal is a professor of political science at the School of Global Policy and Strategy, Hajnal teaches courses including Policy Analysis and Public Welfare. Hajnal is a respected scholar on U.S. politics and policy, with a specific focus on how disadvantaged populations are represented in American politics and what can be done to ensure better representation of these groups. His research areas span racial and ethnic politics, urban politics, immigration and political behavior. He is the author of multiple award-winning books including “White Backlash: Immigration, Race, and American Politics” (Princeton 2015), “Why Americans Don’t Join the Party: Race, Immigration, and the Failure of Political Parties to Engage the Electorate” (Princeton 2011), “America’s Uneven Democracy: Race, Turnout, and Representation in City Politics” (Cambridge 2010) and “Changing White Attitudes toward Black Political Leadership” (Cambridge 2006). His research has been featured in The New York Times, Washington Post and a range of other media outlets. Meeting focus: Discuss and explore political behavior across different communities to gain a perspective of how disadvantaged populations are represented in politics. Think Tanks, Community Resources, and Coalitions
source_proposal: 12 - The U.S. Electoral Process.docx

name: Voice of San Diego
description: Launched in 2005, Voice of San Diego was the first digital, nonprofit news organization in the country to serve a local community. Their mission is to consistently deliver ground-breaking investigative journalism for the San Diego region and to increase civic participation by giving residents the knowledge and in-depth analysis necessary to become advocates for good government and social progress.
source_proposal: 12 - The U.S. Electoral Process.docx

name: Inewsource
description: inewsource is a nonprofit, nonpartisan newsroom dedicated to improving lives in the San Diego region and beyond through impactful, data-based investigative and accountability journalism. Inewsource values, above all else, the importance of a free and credible press, where truth is the cornerstone of democracy. Inewsource is also a proud member of The Trust Project, supporting efforts to increase transparency in journalism.
source_proposal: 12 - The U.S. Electoral Process.docx

name: Engage San Diego
description: Engage San Diego is a collaborative network of social justice focused, non-profit groups working to increase civic and voter engagement in historically and systemically excluded communities of San Diego County. Engage San Diego table members are established and effective civic engagement and social change organizations with deep roots in the neighborhoods they serve. Its vision is a San Diego where the electorate and leadership are reflective of people who live and work here.
source_proposal: 12 - The U.S. Electoral Process.docx

name: The San Diego LGBT Community Center
description: The San Diego Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Transgender Community Center, Inc., (The Center) is one of the largest and most vibrant LGBTQ community centers in the nation. Functioning as the San Diego LGBTQ community’s anchor organization, The Center provides targeted programs and services to the full diversity of the San Diego LGBTQ community, including lesbian, gay, bisexual, queer, transgender, nonbinary, immigrant, and HIV communities to the betterment of our entire San Diego region. Last year, The Center provided more than 80,000 direct service visits to San Diego community members, and through its events, activities, and advocacy, touched the lives of thousands more. Explore the history of The Center as well as how it has continued to modernize and provide the LGBTQ+ community with helpful resources. We propose a central discussion of The Center’s Young Professional’s Council (YPC), a community of leaders and allies ages 21-40 that offers opportunities for connection, career development, friendship, and power-building.
source_proposal: 12 - The U.S. Electoral Process.docx

name: Alliance San Diego
description: Alliance San Diego is a non-profit, community organization whose mission is to provide a means for diverse individuals and organizations to share information, collaborate on issues and mobilize for change in the pursuit of social justice, especially in low-income communities and communities of color. They seek to mobilize communities through: leadership development, policy advocacy, communication strategies, and civic engagement. They focus on human rights, inclusive democracy, educational equity, and tax reform. Discuss Alliance San Diego’s advocacy and community building efforts for most vulnerable communities in San Diego.
source_proposal: 12 - The U.S. Electoral Process.docx

name: Community Advocates for Just and Moral Governance (MoGo)
description: Community Advocates for Just and Moral Governance (MoGo) promotes good governance. MoGo is committed to engaging in litigation and various forms of advocacy that will make government more just and fully accountable to all people, particularly those who have been marginalized from society. MoGo was founded by two Black women lawyers who have dedicated their lives and careers to secure racial equality, social justice, and greater access to quality education. Current MoGo campaigns include: stopping discriminatory policing practices against Black people, Indigenous people, people of color, LGBTQ individuals, and individuals with disabilities; protecting San Diegans' fourth amendment rights in regard to transparent and responsible use of surveillance technology in San Diego; and working to bring ranked choice voting to San Diego to improve voter turnout.
source_proposal: 12 - The U.S. Electoral Process.docx

name: The Lincoln Club
description: The Lincoln Club Business League advocates for San Diego taxpayers, businesses, and residents who believe in lower taxes, less regulation, and a better quality of life. They work to advance free market principles by recruiting, endorsing, and financing business-friendly candidates and ballot measures that reflect their commitment to responsible public policy, the expansion of economic opportunity, and enhanced quality of life throughout San Diego County. Advocacy and Policy Resources
source_proposal: 12 - The U.S. Electoral Process.docx

name: NAACP San Diego
description: The NAACP’s principal objective is to ensure the political, educational, social and economic equality of minority citizens of the United States and eliminate race prejudice. The NAACP seeks to remove all barriers of racial discrimination through democratic processes. This mission is accomplished by seeking the enactment and enforcement of federal, state and local laws securing civil rights, and by informing the public of the adverse effects of racial discrimination. From school desegregation, fair housing, employment and voter registration to health and equal economic opportunity, the NAACP is working successfully with allies of all races and plays a significant role in establishing legal precedents in order to improve the quality of life of America’s downtrodden.

name: Partnership for the Advancement of New Americans (PANA)
description: PANA is a research, public policy, and community organizing hub dedicated to advancing the full economic, social and civic inclusion of refugees. Founded, led, and staffed by refugees, PANA is uniquely situated to use relational organizing to bring the community into a pathway of ongoing engagement and indigenous community leadership development.

name: San Diego Voters Voice
description: https://sdvotersvoice.org/ The Voters Voice Initiative is a coalition of non-partisan organizations working together to create transparency for campaign contributions and expenditures with local San Diego candidates. They are bringing transparency to San Diego elections through their transparency dashboard. With one click, the community can see candidate fundraising numbers for all city elections, providing clear data for voters. Voters Voice believes that making campaign finance data easy to find and read will increase public trust and confidence in the election process.
source_proposal: 12 - The U.S. Electoral Process.docx

name: League of Women Voters of San Diego (LWVSD)
description: The League of Women Voters is a nonpartisan political organization encouraging informed and active participation in government and influencing public policy through education and advocacy. LWVSD is dedicated to improving voter turnout and voter education. The San Diego League was founded in 1936 and has more than 500 members. They produce monthly events to inform members and the community about issues that are important to them; they conduct studies to form positions on relevant issues; advocate before the San Diego City Council and Board of Supervisors in support of their positions as they relate to legislation; host monthly committee meetings to enable their members to participate in their work at an in-depth level.
source_proposal: 12 - The U.S. Electoral Process.docx

name: Open San Diego
description: Open San Diego is a chapter of the national, non-partisan Code for America, leveraging their resources, but focused on our own local issues. We are San Diegans who   believe a healthier interface between government and technology leads to a healthier democracy and more vibrant civic life. We care about our communities, our fellow citizens, and our civic institutions, and work together to support and bolster our Public.

name: Represent Us
description: RepresentUs brings together conservatives, progressives, and everyone in between to pass powerful anti-corruption laws that stop political bribery, end secret money, and fix our broken elections. Common Cause Common Cause is made up of more than 1 million powerful, fearless, ordinary Americans working together to build a democracy that works for everyone. They operate with the knowledge that the ultimate power in a democracy is the people, and government must reflect everyone it serves.

name: Mid-City CAN Advocacy Network
description: Mid-City CAN’s mission is to create a safe, productive, and healthy community through collaboration, advocacy, and organization. They hold 	events open to the public, training to foster growth, and have a Youth Council to inspire and  prepare youth to take a more active role in their communities. Voter registration and voter engagement are critical power-building strategies for Mid-City CAN. By registering and encouraging people who don’t normally vote to participate, they are helping to build a stronger and more robust democracy. Nonprofit Organizations

name: San Diego Organizing Project
description: A nonpartisan, multi-faith network, San Diego Organizing Project (SDOP) represents more than 70,000 families across San Diego County. As one of the most diverse grassroots organizations in the region, SDOP bridges racial, cultural, and economic divides, unlocking the power of people to bring justice, equality, and greater opportunity to fruition in their communities. Some ongoing campaigns SDOP is currently focusing on include justice system reform, county government accountability, civic engagement, immigrant rights, and affordable housing and homelessness.

name: Alliance San Diego
description: Alliance San Diego is a non-profit, non-partisan community organization whose mission is to provide a means for diverse individuals and organizations to share information, collaborate on issues and mobilize for change in the pursuit of social justice, especially in low-income communities and communities of color. They seek to build collective power to create an inclusive democracy through leadership development, policy advocacy, communication strategies, and civic engagement. Alliance San Diego’s work is guided by three goals: equity and access, voting and governance, and safety and justice. Volunteer Activities San Diego River Park Foundation The San Diego River Park Foundation is dedicated to the celebration and care of the San Diego River, and to creating a better quality of life for the community through the creation of a park system along the 52-mile river. Their programs, projects, and events are designed to connect people to the historic San Diego River, and empower the community to steward and celebrate it. Activity Focus: With help from the San Diego River Park Foundation, learn more about the importance of the river as a biodiverse ecosystem in San Diego, and efforts they are doing to connect community to the River. Activities may include planting and revitalizing native plants, watering, and spreading mulch. ______________________________________________________________ Cultural Activities: San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $67 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).

name: Chicano Park
description: Chicano Park is the geographic and emotional heart of Barrio Logan, located in Logan Heights, San Diego's oldest Mexican-American neighborhood. The park is home to the largest concentration of Chicano murals in the world with more than 80 paintings on seven acres dotted with sculpture, gardens, picnic tables and playgrounds. Throughout the year, it hosts festivals of music and Aztec dance, the biggest being Chicano Park Day held each April. Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $30 for one Adult Ticket for a one-hour narrated tour (south bay or north bay routes); $35 for a full bay two-hour narrated tour which covers it all: ships of the Maritime Museum, Harbor and Shelter Islands, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and more. The full bay tour is about 25 miles in length. Accessibility: The tour begins and ends at the same location downtown along Broadway Pier.s Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com Price: $44 for a 1-Day Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) For 30 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours, highlighting the best San Diego attractions. The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50 am – 5:00 pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $26 for one Adult General Admission Ticket ($1 discount when purchased on-line). Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10am – 5pm (Last admission at 4pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside Navy Pier. Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 17 major museums and cultural institutions, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).

name: Coronado
description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year round due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. (Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown.) SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $99.99 for one Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Orca Encounter, Dolphin Days, and Sea Lions Live shows and thrilling rides like Electric Eel, Manta, and Journey To Atlantis. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Hours vary by season. Also enjoy the opening of Sesame Place in March 2022, a Sesame Street themed section of the park with new water, ride, and musical attractions. Accessibility: A 15-20-minute drive from downtown San Diego.

name: Friendship Park / El Parque de la Amistad
description: A historic meeting place on the US-Mexico border, overlooking the Pacific Ocean.  For generations people of good will from both nations have gathered here to visit with family and friends "across the line.” *Please note, although visitors can see Friendship Park on Friday from outside the gates, access to the park is only open on Saturday and Sunday from 10:00 am – 2:00 pm.
source_proposal: 12 - The U.S. Electoral Process.docx

name: Presidio Park
description: Presidio Park in San Diego is a tranquil historical site with remnants of the city's original Spanish settlement, offering visitors a chance to step back in time. The Serra Museum within the park provides a deeper understanding of the area's history, while the park's botanical garden and picnic areas invite relaxation. Its elevated location provides a scenic view of San Diego, making it a favorite spot for those seeking a quiet escape, historical insights, or outdoor respite in a peaceful setting.
source_proposal: 12 - The U.S. Electoral Process.docx

name: City of San Diego Youth Commission
description: The Commission serves as an advisory body to the Mayor, City Council, and City Manager on issues of interest to youth and pertaining to youth in the City of San Diego. Youth and young adults are impacted by the decisions of City officials, but seldom have the opportunity to directly participate in the process. Establishment of a City of San Diego Youth Commission will facilitate the participation of youth and young adults in local government, as well as provide City officials an opportunity to hear and address their ideas and concerns. To identify critical issues affecting youth in the City of San Diego and provide advice and recommendations to the Mayor, City Council, City Manager, and other City officials on issues affecting youth in the City of San Diego. Community Resources
source_proposal: 13 - Youth and Civic Engagement.docx

name: Aaron Price Fellows Program
description: The mission of the Aaron Price Fellows Program is to prepare a highly motivated and diverse group of San Diego public high school students to be responsible, engaged and caring members of their community. An intensive three-year program teaches Fellows about government, cultural, business and non-profit institutions to illustrate their significance and relevance in their lives; exposes Fellows to exciting career opportunities; and foster friendships between Fellows from diverse ethnic, religious and economic backgrounds. Meeting focus: Learn about this unique, 3-year fellowship opportunity that cultivates youth to be active citizens, caring for their community and helping others. Dive deeper into the fellowship’s curriculum and its emphasis on educating fellows about cultural, business and non-profit institutions significance.
source_proposal: 13 - Youth and Civic Engagement.docx

name: International Rescue Committee (IRC) San Diego – Youth Programs
description: The International Rescue Committee (IRC) helps people affected by humanitarian crises to survive, recover and rebuild their lives. As thousands of Afghan refugees have been resettled in California and  across the U.S. since August 2021, the IRC in San Diego has been working to ensure that schools are  equipped to support refugee youth. The IRC is partnering with seven schools in San Diego Unified School  District (the second largest school district in California) to offer wrap-around services to students  through its Refugee Education, Acculturation, Civic Engagement, and Health (REACH) program. Additionally, founded in 2009, the IRC Peacemakers program was developed in response to refugee students’ desire to help raise awareness about the situation of refugees around the world, and to take action to help their fellow refugees. Through public speaking engagements at schools, community groups, and events, peacemaker refugee and immigrant youth aim to: share their personal stories through speaking engagements, develop public speaking and leadership skills, and foster multi-cultural understanding and raise awareness of issues affecting refugees and immigrants. Meeting focus: Explore how IRC youth programs like IRC Peacemakers and REACH provide wrap-around services to youth new to the U.S. as they navigate their new education system,  while fostering leadership development, social empowerment and civic engagement.
source_proposal: 13 - Youth and Civic Engagement.docx

name: Young Professionals Council at the San Diego LGBT Center
description: The Center’s Young Professionals Council (YPC) is a community of LGBTQ+ leaders and allies ages 21-40ish that offers opportunities for connection, career development, friendship, and power-building. YPC helps to advance The Center’s twin goals of promoting LGBTQ+ health/wellness and human rights, and fosters a culture of diversity, leadership, advocacy, and camaraderie among its participants. The Academy expands the ranks of young people in the LGBTQ+ justice movement by enhancing their skills, broadening their network, and fostering transformative connections with other community leaders. Schools and Academic Resource University of San Diego – Center for Peace & Commerce www.sandiego.edu/cpc/ The Center for Peace and Commerce (CPC) is a collaborative effort between the School of Business Administration and the Joan B. Kroc School of Peace Studies to prepare new generations of "change agents" who develop and exercise innovative approaches for achieving the 4 Ps– people, profit, planet and peace. CPC contributes to creating new enterprise paradigms and solutions that foster peace-building and poverty alleviation, through courses, scholarship, enterprise development, active engagement with multiple stakeholders and the promotion of good governance.

name: The Mulvaney Center for Cultural Awareness and Social Action
description: Through reciprocal community-based learning, the Mulvaney Center engages USD Students, faculty, staff, and alumni to learn and act in partnership with the community, making life-long commitments to promote social change and justice. The Mulvaney Center is a community, one that intentionally welcomes and celebrates students from diverse backgrounds, honoring the wisdom held in communities and striving to learn from and with them through reciprocal partnerships.

description: La Jolla Country Day School is an independent college-preparatory school serving students from age 3 through Grade 12 in San Diego’s coastal community of La Jolla. The Center for Excellence in Citizenship (CEC) develops unique opportunities for LJCDS students, faculty and families to engage in the vital work of local, national and global citizenship, focusing on the fundamental importance of human dignity in all interactions. CEC fosters civic engagement and civil discourse, galvanizing students to think about their rights and responsibilities as citizens and to be thoughtful participants in their communities. Non –Profit and Non-Governmental Organizations

RISE San Diego is about developing the people within communities who make it happen. RISE Urban Leadership Fellows Program is a partnership of RISE San Diego and the Leadership Institute at the University of San Diego School of Leadership and Education Sciences (SOLES). RISE’s unique goal and commitment is to help identify and empower a generation of leaders who will not only bring our urban communities up, but also bring them together. Meeting focus: Explore RISE San Diego’s youth-focused grassroots civic engagement programs, non-profit training, and leadership development models, and the impact they have within the  San Diego community. Outside the Lens www.outsidethelens.org Outside the Lens empowers youth to use photography, filmmaking and digital media, catalyzing change within themselves, their community and their world, teaching people from a young age that participation in their community’s future makes a difference. description: https://www.kpbs.org/news/2021/jun/15/new-city-office-aims-help-san-diego-youth-amidst-d/ Youth Will’s vision is to fight for every young person to have everything they need to be happy, healthy and prepared to reach their full potential. Workshops and Leadership Development Sessions

Alliance San Diego focuses on issues of human rights, inclusive democracy, educational equity, and tax reform. National Conflict Resolution Center (NCRC) www.ncrconline.com The National Conflict Resolution Center is a non-profit organization that serves a variety of communities in both the public and private sectors regionally, nationally and internationally. name: Community Services – Restorative Practices in Education and the Juvenile Judicial System
description: NCRC facilitates the application of Restorative Practices in schools as well as the juvenile justice system. Their programs are an effective alternative to traditional disciplinary action in both the academic and judicial settings, and have achieved great results through partnerships with the San Diego Unified School District and the San Diego District Attorney’s Office. Workshop: Engaging Youth as Leaders by Austin Galy Austin Galy is the Director of Neighborhood and Community Engaged Partnerships at the University of San Diego’s Mulvaney Center for Community, Awareness and Social Action (CASA). Focusing primarily on student leadership development through immersive forms of education, Austin strives to create spaces for students and community members to learn and grow alongside one another through establishing equitable and democratic-reciprocal relationships. Austin formerly studied Meteorology before going on to obtain his B.A. in Sociology and M.A. in Peace and Justice Studies from the University of San Diego’s Joan B. Kroc Institute for Peace and Justice. From 2010 - 2018, Austin served as a member of the United States Air Force, working to support the U.S. and other joint coalition task force efforts during wartime. Community Service Activities

name: Spring Valley Cleanup Crew
description: Spring Valley Cleanup Crew works to keep Spring Valley and surrounding neighborhoods clean and safe. Spring Valley is home to many underserved, immigrant and BIPOC residents who are forced to endure environmental racism and are not granted the privilege of living in the version of San Diego that we see on postcards and travel blogs. The Tijuana River Valley, in the Spring Valley area, has been declared a state of public health crisis due to the unsanitary and unsafe conditions entering the river, and organizations like the Spring Valley Cleanup Crew are working hard to undo human-caused damage. The Spring Valley Cleanup Crew, led by youth, utilizes social media to promote its grassroots organization. Victoria Abrenica, founder of Spring Valley Cleanup Crew, is a community leader in all things public education, sustainability and environmental justice. She also serves as a Youth4Climate Instructor at San Diego 350, which is building a movement to prevent the worst impacts of climate change and climate injustice. Activity Focus: Participate in a cleanup effort with Spring Valley Cleanup Crew, while learning how they utilize social media to promote their service efforts and community engagement, and the work they are doing for their communities. name: Youth Voice San Diego
description: Youth Voice is a youth leadership program held at the Mid-City Police Division weekly. Law enforcement, university interns and community-based organizations partner with the goal of providing youth with mentoring and opportunities to positively support their leadership development. Youth Voice focuses on Connection with Self, Connection with Others, Connection with Community, and Connection with Law Enforcement. The voluntary mentoring program is supported by Mid-City Division's Juvenile Services Team and connects youth to themselves, their homes, schools, and communities through trauma informed - resilience building curriculum development.

name: Youth 4 Climate
description: Youth 4 Climate San Diego stands at the forefront of youth-led environmental activism in the region. Championing impactful campaigns like "Youth v. Oil" and a robust coalition of high school eco-clubs, they mobilize young minds towards positive environmental changes. This dedicated group plans and executes direct actions, such as rallies and strikes, to raise awareness and instigate actionable changes for a sustainable future. Beyond these public actions, the organization is deeply invested in nurturing the next generation of climate leaders. They roll out diverse programs that are meticulously crafted to bolster the leadership skills of young eco-activists, such as their annual Youth Climate Action Summit, summer programs, and enriching after-school engagements. Collaborating with local organizations, they also strive to integrate the teaching community into their mission, facilitating programs to inspire and mobilize educators towards climate action. Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com Price: $44 for a 1-Day Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) For 30 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours, highlighting the best San Diego attractions. The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50am – 5:00pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $26 for one Adult General Admission Ticket ($1 discount when purchased on-line). Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10am – 5pm (Last admission at 4pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside Navy Pier. Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 17 major museums and cultural institutions, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).
source_proposal: 13 - Youth and Civic Engagement.docx

name: Coronado
description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year around due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown. SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $99.99 for one Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) Accessibility: A 15-20-minute drive from downtown San Diego. Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Orca Encounter, Dolphin Days, and Sea Lions Live shows and thrilling rides like Electric Eel, Manta, and Journey To Atlantis. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Hours vary by season.
source_proposal: 13 - Youth and Civic Engagement.docx

name: Alliance San Diego
description: Alliance San Diego is a non-profit, non-partisan 501(c)(3) community organization whose mission is to provide a means for diverse individuals and organizations to share information, collaborate on issues and mobilize for change in the pursuit of social justice, especially in low-income communities and communities of color. They seek to mobilize communities through: leadership development, policy advocacy, communication strategies, and civic engagement. They focus on human rights, inclusive democracy, educational equity, and tax reform.
source_proposal: 14 - Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: City of San Diego Human Relations Commission
description: The mission of the Human Relations Commission (HRC) is to promote activities that foster understanding, respect, and inclusion in San Diego. The HRC believes in protecting basic Human and Civil Rights, while ensuring that San Diegans have the resources available to make positive impacts in their lives. The HRC is comprised of some of the region's most talented and community-focused volunteers that San Diego has to offer. As an advisory commission to the Mayor and City Council, the HRC is empowered to collaborate with civic institutions, educate the public, investigate policy to make our city better, advocate on issues to the Mayor and Council, and mediate disputes of discrimination, exclusion, and bias in the City of San Diego.
source_proposal: 14 - Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: Casa Cornelia Law Center
description: Casa Cornelia Law Center is a public interest law firm providing quality legal services to victims of human and civil rights violations. It seeks to educate others regarding the impact of immigration law and policy on the community and the public good. Since 1993, more than 15,000 children, women, and men have turned to Casa Cornelia for critical legal assistance and humanitarian protection. Casa Cornelia is the only non-profit law firm in San Diego County to provide free legal services to detained unaccompanied children.
source_proposal: 14 - Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: Community Advocates for Just and Moral Governance (MoGo)
description: Community Advocates for Just and Moral Governance (MoGo) promotes good governance. MoGo is committed to engaging in litigation and various forms of advocacy that will make government more just and fully accountable to all people, particularly those who have been marginalized from society. MoGo was founded by two Black women lawyers who have dedicated their lives and careers to secure racial equality, social justice, and greater access to quality education. Current MoGo campaigns include: stopping discriminatory policing practices against Black people, Indigenous people, people of color, LGBTQ individuals, and individuals with disabilities; protecting San Diegans' fourth amendment rights in regard to transparent and responsible use of surveillance technology in San Diego; and working to bring ranked choice voting to San Diego to improve voter turnout.
source_proposal: 14 - Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: Engage San Diego
description: Engage San Diego is a collaborative network of social-justice focused, non-profit groups working to increase civic and voter engagement in historically and systemically excluded communities of San Diego County. Engage San Diego table members are established and effective civic engagement and social change organizations with deep roots in the neighborhoods they serve. Its vision is a San Diego where the electorate and leadership are reflective of people who live and work here.
source_proposal: 14 - Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: Mid-City CAN Advocacy Network
description: Mid-City CAN’s mission is to create a safe, productive, and healthy community through collaboration, advocacy, and organizing. They work with residents and partners to drive positive change across many systems and issues rather than coming in as an outside force. They hold events open to the public, training to foster growth, and have a Youth Council to inspire and prepare youth to take a more active role in their communities.
source_proposal: 14 - Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: Viet Vote
description: Viet Vote is dedicated to bringing all the information about voting to the Vietnamese community. They are a non-profit, non-partisan organization and therefore do not take a position on candidates. They share information about how and where to vote but not who to vote for. They come together to build community voice, leaders, and meaningful relationships through civic engagement, partnerships, trainings, and events.
source_proposal: 14 - Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: PANA – Partnership for the Advancement of New Americans
description: PANA fights to advance the full economic, social & civic inclusion of refugees in the San Diego region, throughout California, and across the country. PANA is founded, led, and staffed by refugees and are uniquely situated to use relational organizing to bring community into a pathway of ongoing engagement and indigenous community leadership development.
source_proposal: 14 - Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: NAACP San Diego
description: The NAACP’s principal objective is to ensure the political, educational, social and economic equality of minority citizens of the United States and eliminate race prejudice. The NAACP seeks to remove all barriers of racial discrimination through democratic processes. This mission is accomplished by seeking the enactment and enforcement of federal, state and local laws securing civil rights, and by informing the public of the adverse effects of racial discrimination. From school desegregation, fair housing, employment and voter registration to health and equal economic opportunity, the NAACP is working successfully with allies of all races and plays a significant role in establishing legal precedents in order to improve the quality of life of America’s downtrodden. Academic Resources
source_proposal: 14 - Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: University of San Diego (USD), Joan B. Kroc Institute for Peace and Justice (IPJ) – Violence, Inequality and Power (VIP) Lab
description: The Joan B. Kroc IPJ’s mission is to end cycles of violence in ways that advance justice for all through learning that is deeply grounded in the lived experience of peacemakers around the world and that is made rigorous by our place within a university ecosystem. The Violence, Inequality and Power (VIP) Lab fosters collaborations that question the status quo, that use bridging language, and that expand access to nuanced knowledge and discussion. The VIP Lab aims to deliver practical, actionable ideas that partners can implement at the systems level to confront harmful power inequalities and reduce violence.
source_proposal: 14 - Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: San Diego Unified School District - OUT for Safe Schools
description: San Diego Unified School District is participating in the National OUT for Safe Schools campaign, along with nine other large urban school districts across the country. This program was created as a way to encourage school staff to publicly identify as supportive LGBTQIA allies. This visual display of support lets students know that " safe spaces" exist anywhere there is an adult who is wearing this badge. This campaign is designed to create safe spaces and resources for LGBTQIA students, staff and parents, and also to foster an inclusive community for all students to celebrate all identities.
source_proposal: 14 - Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: Center on Policy Initiatives - Community Schools Coalition
description: The Campaign for Community Schools in San Diego is a community coalition aiming to transform schools in San Diego Unified into community schools. The coalition is advocating for San Diego Unified School District to adopt a policy to allocate resources and support communities in the implementation of community schools throughout the district. Successful community schools ensure underserved communities receive equitable resources, create community partnerships, and foster the self-empowerment necessary to support student learning, strong families and thriving communities. Integration & Community-Building Resources
source_proposal: 14 - Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: Union of Pan Asian Communities (UPAC)
description: The Union of Pan Asian Communities (UPAC) is a 501c3 non-profit that provides health and human services focused on improving the overall well-being of underserved diverse populations. Providing assistance in over 30 languages at 15 locations across the county, UPAC recognizes and celebrates the diversity of our region and strives to strengthen these communities to achieve self-sufficiency. Programs focus on mental health counseling, community engagement and business development, addiction treatment & recovery, housing counseling, health promotion and cultural competency education.
source_proposal: 14 - Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: MAKE Projects
description: MAKE Projects mission is to create an inclusive San Diego by preparing refugees and immigrants to achieve their dreams. They are an employment social enterprise where they operate an urban farm, restaurant, and events/catering company to provide a paid, real-world work experience for low-income refugee and immigrant women and youth. They aim to provide trainees with job readiness skills to help them achieve their dreams. MAKE Projects vision is to see San Diegans cross social, racial, economic, and geographic lines as they gather over a common love of food, flavors, and cultures. They believe in the power of food to bring diverse populations together, unite a community, and educate each other about their history and differences, as well as their communities.
source_proposal: 14 - Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: Somali Youth United
description: Somali Youth United is a non-profit community based organization in San Diego. Their focus is to promote peace, prosperity and unity within the community through youth development, cultural/intellectual exchange and community engagement. Rahmo Abdi, Executive Director Abdi came to the United States as a refugee from Somalia and personally understands the many difficulties adjusting to life in a new country while preserving one’s cultural heritage. Abdi founded the International Refugee Girls Association where she focused on keeping immigrants connected with their native cultures while stressing importance of education, financial literacy, self-esteem, and sexual health issues in a new environment. Abdi is a strong advocate for increased access to healthcare in the Somali and East African Community which suffer disproportionately from chronic health conditions. Rahmo Abdi has been the Executive Director of Somali Youth United since 2015.
source_proposal: 14 - Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: San Diego Gateway to College and Career, San Diego Workforce Partnership
description: The San Diego Gateway to College and Career program provides young adults who identify as immigrant, refugee and/or English language learner (ELL) with high-touch and intensive support, stipends and paid internships. Recognizing the strength of your diverse ethnicities and languages, students are also supported to achieve their language learning goals, no matter what language you speak. This program offers help in removing barriers to success, finding what career is right, finding a long-term job, starting school, and learning new job skills. LGBTQ+ Resources
source_proposal: 14 - Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: The San Diego LGBT Community Center
description: The San Diego Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Transgender Community Center, Inc., (The Center) is one of the largest and most vibrant LGBTQ community centers in the nation. Functioning as the San Diego LGBTQ community’s anchor organization, The Center provides targeted programs and services to the full diversity of the San Diego LGBTQ community, including lesbian, gay, bisexual, queer, transgender, nonbinary, immigrant, and HIV communities to the betterment of our entire San Diego region. Last year, The Center provided more than 80,000 direct service visits to San Diego community members, and through its events, activities, and advocacy, touched the lives of thousands more.
source_proposal: 14 - Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: San Diego Pride
description: https://sdpride.org/fernando-lopez/ San Diego Pride is a dynamic 501(c)3 non-profit organization that organizes the annual San Diego Pride parade, provides LGBTQ+ educational training, and offers LGBTQ+ programs in a variety of areas including sports, youth, art, and accessibility. Their mission is to foster pride, equality, and respect for all lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender communities locally, nationally, and globally. In addition to their annual festivities, San Diego Pride has donated more than $3 million dollars to LGBTQ-serving nonprofits and runs multiple year-round education, advocacy, and community service programs. They also offer training on cultural humility, inclusivity and skills, and provide resources for the community to remain civically active. Fernando Zweifach López Jr is the Executive Director for San Diego LGBT Pride, and a local leader with extensive experience in advocacy, nonprofit management, public education, diversity consulting, media relations, and organizing. Meeting focus: Discuss San Diego Pride’s impact on the region and their international outreach to further LGBTQ+ rights globally. Border Relations and Immigrant Resources
source_proposal: 14 - Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: Minority Humanitarian Foundation (MHF)
description: https://www.welcomehomelemongrove.com/ The mission of Minority Humanitarian Foundation is to provide a humanitarian response to the issues facing asylum-seekers and refugees on a global scale. MHF believes that all humans should be treated with dignity and respect, despite country of origin. Through on-the-ground relief efforts, health services, housing, transportation services and legal representation they work to ensure the health and safety of the people they work with. Then through education and job placement they work to ensure their success in a new country. In 2021, MHF opened a boutique thrift store and art space called “Welcome Home” seeking to serve as a community space highlighting the local demographics of BIPOC artists.
source_proposal: 14 - Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: University of California at San Diego (UCSD), Center for Comparative Immigration Studies
description: The Center for Comparative Immigration Studies (CCIS) at UCSD provides a unique institutional home for understanding the challenges and opportunities created by international migration to California, the United States as a whole, and other countries around the world.  The CCIS research agenda focuses on Mexican migration to California and comparative, cross-national and cross-regional research on international migratory movements, immigration policy, and citizenship policy.  CCIS is the only academic center in the United States specializing in international migration from a broad geographical as well as interdisciplinary perspective, devoting substantial attention to migrant-sending and receiving countries in North America, Europe, Africa, and the Asia-Pacific region.  CCIS-affiliated researchers encompass all of the social sciences, history, arts and humanities, and legal studies; no single discipline dominates CCIS programming.
source_proposal: 14 - Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: San Diego Immigrants’ Rights Consortium
description: The San Diego Immigrant Rights Consortium brings together more than 50 diverse organizations across San Diego County that advocate for policies that advance the civil and human rights of immigrants and refugees. Beginning in 2007 as a project of Alliance San Diego, this organization aims to support comprehensive immigration reform, prevent the spread of local policies that violate immigrant’s human rights, and to educate immigrants about their rights, as well as enlighten the public about the important contributions immigrants offer to the community.
source_proposal: 14 - Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: Alex Montoya Foundation
description: The Alex Montoya Foundation is a non-profit organization to raise awareness of issues related to disabilities and immigration. Their mission is to provide motivational, educational, and inspiring presentations and support to immigrants, people with disabilities, and those who support them with equity and justice. Alex Montoya is a public speaker and author who has spent his life helping others focus on what they have, rather than what they don’t have. Resources with Religious Affiliation
source_proposal: 14 - Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: The Border Church / La Iglesia Fronteriza
description: The Border Church / La Iglesia Fronteriza is a nonsectarian Christian ministry centered in the celebration of open-table communion on the U.S.-Mexico border. Since November, 2011, people from both the United States and Mexico have gathered each Sunday afternoon to share communion at Friendship Park, the historic border meeting place at the western edge of the border, overlooking the Pacific Ocean.  Friends from near and far also join via Zoom and via livestream on Facebook.
source_proposal: 14 - Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: Interfaith Committee for Worker Justice (ICWJ) of San Diego County
description: IWJSD is an affiliate of Interfaith Worker Justice (IWJ), a national network that builds collective power by advancing the rights of workers through unions, worker centers, and other expressions of the labor movement and by engaging diverse faith communities and allies in joint action, from grassroots organizing to shaping policy at the local, state and national levels. The Mission Question of IWJSD is how they can best advocate, educate, and empower workers, congregations, and communities in support of policies, legislation, and actions that sustain workers’ lives with dignity.
source_proposal: 14 - Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: San Diego Interfaith Collaborative
description: The San Diego Regional Interfaith Collaborative (SDRIC) seeks to nurture and enhance the infrastructure of relationships, resources, mutual spiritual understanding, out-flowing compassion, and working together that emerges from that wisdom and goodwill. SDRIC sees the religious community as a network, so there is no center, and SDRIC is not a lead or umbrella organization, nor does it seek to duplicate what others are doing. Rather, it is a servant, catalyst, and neutral convener, to assist the network in thinking together strategically and addressing the underlying conditions necessary for the success of any interfaith group or effort, whether it involves fellowship, dialogue, social service and/or social action. SDRIC does not take a position on any particular religious’ beliefs, philosophies or policies nor does it favor any particular religious or spiritual discipline. Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown). Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $30 for one Adult Ticket for a one-hour narrated tour (south bay or north bay routes); $35 for a full bay two-hour narrated tour which covers it all: ships of the Maritime Museum, Harbor and Shelter Islands, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and more. The full bay tour is about 25 miles in length. Accessibility: The tour begins and ends at the same location downtown along Broadway Pier. Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com Price: $44 for a 1-Day Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) For 30 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours, highlighting the best San Diego attractions. The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50am – 5:00pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $26 for one Adult General Admission Ticket ($1 discount when purchased on-line). Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10am – 5pm (Last admission at 4pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside Navy Pier. Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 17 major museums and cultural institutions, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).

description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year around due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Hours vary by season.
