name: High Tech High International (HTH)
description: High Tech High is a network of K-12 public charter schools that increases the number of educationally disadvantaged students within the math and engineering workforce by serving a student body that mirrors the ethnic and socioeconomic diversity of the local community. Through the integration of technical and academic education, and a project-based approach, HTH prepares students for post-secondary education in both high tech and liberal arts fields.
source_proposal: 15 - Education in the Digital Age.docx

name: La Jolla Country Day School (LJCDS)
description: Recognized as one of the best private schools in California and San Diego, LJCDS is an educational leader in our region, committed to offering a robust, student-centered learning experience that considers the students’ social, emotional and intellectual well-being. At LJCDS, students are challenged to identify real-world problems and design innovative solutions to effect positive change for a better world. Innovation is the thread that connects technology to the human. The school’s goal is to teach students not only how to solve technical problems but also how to determine the “right” problems to solve by employing the design thinking process. Some highlights of their innovation and technology initiatives include: Trends in education: Integrating digital learning platforms Spatial Vis App – Developed at UCSD Engineering, gamified sketching to enhance mental rotation and visualization. This app lives on students’ phones for homework on-the-go. Code.org courses and similar programming environments and lessons TinkerCAD lessonsTinkerCAD lessons These platforms shift the focus from content-delivery teaching to a coaching model. Teachers then pair that with independent projects that go beyond technical skills to train the students on project management, collaboration and communication. Partnerships: Torrey Corporate Partnership Model The unique Torrey Corporate Partnership Model connects LJCDS students to real-world problems and professionals. Since Fall 2015, LJCDS has partnered with a number of organizations to have our student design teams work on problems directly related to their field. Our student teams are experienced in various parts of the product development process and have delivered high-quality results in the following areas: Ethnographic Research, Ideation, User Testing, Market Analysis, Physical Engineering, Web & App Design, Computer Programming, Data Analysis. Teacher training and continuing education: Credentials and Online Communities Credentials from online learning platforms: SuperHi. The Computer Science Teachers Association is a modern professional membership organization defining standards, creating online geography-based communities of teachers, and aiding professional growth. University Education & Educational Partnerships:
source_proposal: 15 - Education in the Digital Age.docx

name: University of California San Diego (UCSD) *Possible roundtable discussion of UCSD’s e-learning education programs as well as partnerships with K-12 students, educators, and professionals.
description: Recognized as one of the top 15 research universities worldwide, the University of California in San Diego lies alongside the Pacific Ocean in the La Jolla community of San Diego. UCSD includes six undergraduate colleges, five academic divisions and five graduate and professional schools. The university has collaborated with VirBela to provide virtual distance learning for their International Micro-MBA Program and a business course for the Extension of Strategic Innovation and Education Technologies. Currently, UCSD has provided a home for VirBela at the California Institute for Telecommunications and Information Technology (Qualcomm Institute).
source_proposal: 15 - Education in the Digital Age.docx

name: Sally Ride Science
description: Sally Ride Science is a nonprofit organization based at UC San Diego Extension       	(https://extension.ucsd.edu/). Its programs are coordinated jointly by UC San Diego Extension,       	Scripps Institution of Oceanography (https://scripps.ucsd.edu/), and the San Diego Super   	computer Center (https://www.sdsc.edu/). Sally Ride Science offers K12 STEM + Arts (STEaM) education programs; professional development for teachers; and online programs through UCTV. The Sally Ride Science Junior Academy, launched in 2016, offers hands-on workshops that allow middle school and high school students to delve into a variety of STEAM subjects. Other new programs shine a spotlight on women scientists in the University of California system.
source_proposal: 15 - Education in the Digital Age.docx

name: VirBela
description: https://qi.ucsd.edu/news-article.php?id=3081 VirBELA is a virtual reality company that connects remote workers from around the world in an  online environment. They work, collaborate and talk exactly as they would do in the real world, except there is no commute and no one has to wear a tie (although you can change your avatar’s clothes each day). Recently acquired by eXp World Holdings, the company was formed at the University of California San Diego as a partnership between Rady School of Management and the Experimental Game Lab. It has called the Qualcomm Institute Innovation Space (QIIS) home since 2014. GirlTECH Program www.girltechsandiego.org Hosted by the San Diego Supercomputer Center, the GirlTECH program aims to encourage young women to learn and apply computational thinking and coding skills. Through partnerships with local universities, businesses and non-profit organizations, the program provides scholarships, financial assistance and transportation assistance to low-income girls in middle schools and high school to participate in coding and computer science opportunities. Governmental Resources:
source_proposal: 15 - Education in the Digital Age.docx

name: San Diego County Office of Education (SDCOE), Innovation Division and Educational Technology Department
description: https://www.sdcoe.net/innovation/Pages/default.aspx
source_proposal: 15 - Education in the Digital Age.docx

name: The mission of the San Diego County Office of Education (SDCOE) is to inspire and lead innovation in education. SDCOE provides a variety of services for the 42 school districts, 124 charter schools, and five community college districts in the county. Their Innovation Division is focused on accelerating, scaling, and amplifying the number and speed of innovations from the County Office, and their Educational Technology department focuses on technology integration into the curriculum that transforms educational systems.  SDCOE grounds all of their professional development in pedagogical practices that teachers and administrators can take back to their classrooms to support students.
description: No longer just video games, eSports offers serious team competition for students in San Diego County. Tapping into the popularity of gaming and computer science, the Innovation Division and Educational Technology Department Teams working on SDCOE's eSports Initiative aim to provide students safe, fun, and competitive opportunities while introducing them to career pathways in the field of computer science and gaming, and even the potential for college scholarships. San Diego Office of Education (SDCOE) is working with local districts to expand their eSports league this school year. The growing trend of eSports is a way for students to learn about collaboration, strategy, and leadership through online video games, utilizing curriculum and other learning resources that teachers can use to augment student's participation in the leagues.
source_proposal: 15 - Education in the Digital Age.docx

name: The City of San Diego’s Department of Information Technology
description: San Diego Union Tribune Article:https://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/politics/story/2020-10-07/san-diego-unveils-plans-to-boost-crucial-broadband-internet-access-during-pandemic#:~:text=San%20Diego%20unveiled%20plans%20Wednesday,hotspots%20at%20libraries%20and%20parks.&text=Most%20of%20them%20are%20south,Districts%204%2C%208%20and%209. The City of San Diego Department of Information Technology’s mission is to be a national municipal leader and strategic business partner for innovative technology solutions. During the pandemic, the City unveiled plans to boost broadband internet access in the city’s low-income neighborhoods with several initiatives including outdoor wi-fi hotspots at libraries and parks. Activity Focus: Examine the City’s broadband access initiatives and how the City address difficulty of outdoor access during the winter months, particularly regarding students from socioeconomically disadvantaged backgrounds. Community Resources
source_proposal: 15 - Education in the Digital Age.docx

name: Nordson Corporation Foundation
description: The Nordson Corporation Foundation awards grants to non-profits in our communities throughout the United States. Since 1989, the Foundation has awarded more than $60 million in grants to improve the quality of life in our communities, placing a special focus on causes related to education. Employees support the foundation by making donations during their annual A Time to Give Campaign, or by participating in a Community Affairs Committee (CAC). Committees review grant applications and vote to distribute Foundation funds to deserving local causes. During the last financial year, the Foundation gave out 362 grants totaling $6.3 million. Youth Campaigns youthcampaigns.org Youth Campaigns, a non-profit organization based in San Diego, strives to change the culture of underserved communities by equipping young people with the tools to become leaders in the “innovation economy.” The organization aims to create access, awareness, and opportunities for talented minority and low-income youth by providing a pipeline to a career in digital media. Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown). Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $30 for one Adult Ticket for a one-hour narrated tour (south bay or north bay routes); $35 for a full bay two-hour narrated tour which covers it all: ships of the Maritime Museum, Harbor and Shelter Islands, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and more. The full bay tour is about 25 miles in length. Accessibility: The tour begins and ends at the same location downtown along Broadway Pier. Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com Price: $44 for a 1-Day Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) For 30 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours, highlighting the best San Diego attractions. The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50am – 5:00pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $26 for one Adult General Admission Ticket ($1 discount when purchased on-line). Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10am – 5pm (Last admission at 4pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside Navy Pier. Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 17 major museums and cultural institutions, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).

name: Coronado
description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year around due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown. SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $99.99 for one Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) Accessibility: A 15-20-minute drive from downtown San Diego. Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Orca Encounter, Dolphin Days, and Sea Lions Live shows and thrilling rides like Electric Eel, Manta, and Journey To Atlantis. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Hours vary by season.
source_proposal: 15 - Education in the Digital Age.docx

name: Cajon Valley Union School District - Family and Community Engagement (FACE) Office
description: El Cajon, where they teach, is a national refugee resettlement destination. Their district has received over 850 newly arrived students in the 2016-2107 school year alone, from Iraq, Syria, Afghanistan, and a handful of African and Latin American countries. In total, refugee children comprise over 19% of their student body, nearly 1 in 5 students in our district. Their mission is to provide opportunities for Cajon Valley schools and families to build meaningful and productive partnerships committed to student learning. Their work is guided by the Dual-Capacity Building Framework for Family-School Partnerships. This Framework provides a roadmap for conceptualizing, designing, and implementing all of their initiatives. Meeting focus: Learn about the FACE Office and their initiatives to support immigrant and refugee students and families; specifically taking a deeper dive into the Power Up Refugee Student Support strategies and Newcomer Welcome Meetings.
source_proposal: 16 - Supporting Integration and Human Rights of Displaced Persons.docx

name: Chula Vista Learning Community Charter School (CVLCC)
description: The Chula Vista Learning Community Charter School operates three schools, a primary, middle, and high school. Its founders envisioned a school focused on challenging academics with a mindful approach to relationships and social change. CVLCC follows a 50/50 Dual Language Model in grades TK - 12th. This model is meant to connect theory to practice by developing bi-literacy with the goal of promoting multilingualism and multiculturalism in all CLVCC students. At CVLCC it is a core belief that language and bi-literacy are assets rather than a deficit - and that all stakeholders are language learners. They expect faculty, staff, and the community to give equal value to each language. SAY San Diego Crawford Community Connection & San Diego Unified School District (SDUSD) Family
source_proposal: 16 - Supporting Integration and Human Rights of Displaced Persons.docx

name: Engagement Department
description: https://sdusdfamilies.org/ Established in 1990, the Crawford Community Connection (CCC) serves all students and families in City Heights (a city with one of the largest refugee populations in the nation) as a school-based amily resource center located on the Crawford High School campus. CCC ensures that Crawford Cluster schools and their students are linked to a network of services and community resources to eliminate barriers to student access. San Diego Unified School District serves more than 121,000 students in pre-school through grade 12 and is the second largest district in California. The student population represents ethnic groups with more than 60 languages and dialects. The Family and Community Engagement Team’s mission is to support district families, staff, and community partners in engaging in highly effective practices that bring stakeholders together for student success.
source_proposal: 16 - Supporting Integration and Human Rights of Displaced Persons.docx

name: Borderless Scholars Program, San Diego Mesa College
description: The Borderless Scholars’ program is designed to provide a safe and welcoming environment for undocumented students and undocu-allies. They support these students to overcome personal and educational challenges due to their immigration status. They provide personal, career, and academic counseling, on-campus support services, and community resources including free legal services. Advocacy and social justice is their main passion and allows them to be the support students need. Their services include counseling, meal cards, California Dream Act application assistance, immigration consultations, etc. Governmental Resources:
source_proposal: 16 - Supporting Integration and Human Rights of Displaced Persons.docx

name: Welcoming San Diego
description: Welcoming San Diego is a City of San Diego initiative designed to advance the civic, social and economic integration of immigrants and refugees. We envision a vibrant, inclusive, and safe binational region that attracts families and businesses from around the world and that all San Diegans can flourish in. As the birthplace of California, San Diego is a gateway for newcomers searching for freedom and opportunity. Our strength and future is tied to our ability to ensure New Americans can fully participate in civic life, access public resources, and contribute their skills. San Diego was awarded the Gateways for Growth grant to bring together other local government agencies, nonprofits, educational institutions and businesses to develop a strategic plan on immigrant integration. In February of 2019, the City of San Diego formally launched the Welcoming San Diego Initiative accompanied by the Welcoming San Diego Strategic Plan. The City’s Immigrant Affairs Manager is responsible for continuing this effort.
source_proposal: 16 - Supporting Integration and Human Rights of Displaced Persons.docx

name: Rita Fernandez, Director of Global Affairs
description: Rita Fernandez is the current Director of Global Affairs for the newly elected Mayor of San Diego, Todd Gloria. Before her current position, Fernandez was appointed to the position of Immigration Affairs Manager by the former Mayor Kevin Faulconer. Rita Fernandez has a long history of working on immigration policy for lawmakers including Representative Juan Vargas of the 51st Congressional District and Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti. During her tenure with Congressman Juan Vargas’s office, Fernandez worked closely on immigration and border issues. At Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti’s office, she collaborated with stakeholders to identify the needs of immigrant communities and coordinate initiatives like a financial literacy and naturalization program. At the City of San Diego, Fernandez is responsible for implementing policies, reviewing proposals and facilitating the integration of immigrants.
source_proposal: 16 - Supporting Integration and Human Rights of Displaced Persons.docx

name: San Diego Police Department (SDPD) Multi-Cultural Community Relations Office
description: https://www.facebook.com/sdpd.MCCRO/ The San Diego Police Department (SDPD) is the primary law enforcement agency for the city of San Diego. The Multi-Cultural Community Relations Office was established by the SDPD in 1987 to address the specific needs of the growing refugee population in San Diego. Their mission is to maintain open communications with immigrant and refugee communities within the City of San Diego and contribute to the safety and security of these communities by offering crime prevention support and assistance.
source_proposal: 16 - Supporting Integration and Human Rights of Displaced Persons.docx

name: U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) – San Diego Sector
description: The San Diego Sector of the U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) consists of more than 7,000 square miles and 66 linear miles of international boundary with Mexico. The San Diego Sector encompasses coastal beaches and expansive mesas to coastal and inland mountains, rugged canyons and high desert. Directly to the South of San Diego lie the Mexican cities of Tijuana and Tecate, Baja California - with a combined population of more than 2 million.  Today, San Diego Sector is focused on addressing the continuously changing tactics of transnational criminal organizations as well as migration patterns affecting the Southern border. With the increase in smuggling activity in recent years along Southern California's coastal borders, additional Border Patrol agents have been assigned to combat the maritime smuggling of humans and drugs, and San Diego Sector's Primary Operational Domain has increased from 91 coastal border miles to 114. Community and Non-Governmental Resources:
source_proposal: 16 - Supporting Integration and Human Rights of Displaced Persons.docx

name: International Rescue Committee
description: The International Rescue Committee provides opportunities for refugees, asylees, victims of human trafficking, survivors of torture, and other immigrants to thrive in America. Each year, thousands of people, forced to flee violence and persecution, are welcomed by the people of the United States into the safety and freedom of America. These individuals have survived against incredible odds. The IRC collaborates closely with government bodies, civil society actors, and local volunteers to support refugees, asylum-seekers, and other immigrants in San Diego, as they work to rebuild their lives.
source_proposal: 16 - Supporting Integration and Human Rights of Displaced Persons.docx

name: Jewish Family Services – Refugee & Immigration Services
description: https://www.jfssd.org/our-services/refugees-immigration/ Since 1918, Jewish Family Services (JFS) has offered resettlement services to newly arriving refugees and asylees from around the world. Today, their Refugee Resettlement department works with approximately 45 cases each month, helping refugee families adjust to their new lives here in the U.S. JFS helps them learn English and find jobs. They teach them how to navigate the medical system, banks, and public transportation. They provide: a fully furnished apartment, airport pick up, acculturation services, translation/ESL services, employment services, advocacy, and more.
source_proposal: 16 - Supporting Integration and Human Rights of Displaced Persons.docx

name: Alliance San Diego, San Diego Immigrants’ Rights Consortium & Southern Border Communities Coalition
source_proposal: 16 - Supporting Integration and Human Rights of Displaced Persons.docx

name: https://www.immigrantsandiego.org/
description: Alliance San Diego is a community organization whose mission is to build collective power to create an inclusive democracy. They build power by developing leaders, engaging communities, advocating for policies, protecting civil and human rights, and communication strategically. In 2007, Alliance San Diego founded the San Diego Immigrants’ Rights Consortium (SDIRC) which aims to support comprehensive immigration reform, prevent the spread of local policies that violate immigrant’s human rights, and educate immigrants about their rights, as well as enlighten the public about the important contributions immigrants offer to the community. Then in 2011, Alliance San Diego founded the Southern Border Communities Coalition (SBCC) which brings together more than 60 organizations from the southern border to promote policies and solutions that improve the quality of life of border residents.
source_proposal: 16 - Supporting Integration and Human Rights of Displaced Persons.docx

name: Survivors of Torture
description: Survivors of Torture, International is an independent nonprofit organization dedicated to caring for survivors of politically-motivated torture and their families who live in San Diego County. Since 1997, SURVIVORS has helped more than 1,300 torture survivors from more than 70 countries to recover from their traumas. SURVIVORS empowers torture survivors to reclaim the strength and vitality that were stolen from them by brutal dictators and governments.
source_proposal: 16 - Supporting Integration and Human Rights of Displaced Persons.docx

name: Minority Humanitarian Foundation (MHF)
description: https://www.welcomehomelemongrove.com/ The mission of Minority Humanitarian Foundation is to provide a humanitarian response to the issues facing asylum-seekers and refugees on a global scale. MHF believes that all humans should be treated with dignity and respect, despite country of origin. Through on-the-ground relief efforts, health services, housing, transportation services and legal representation they work to ensure the health and safety of the people they work with. Then through education and job placement they work to ensure their success in a new country. In 2021, MHF opened a boutique thrift store and art space called “Welcome Home” seeking to serve as a community space highlighting the local demographics of BIPOC artists. Community Integration Resources
source_proposal: 16 - Supporting Integration and Human Rights of Displaced Persons.docx

name: MAKE Projects
description: https://www.kpbs.org/news/local/2022/04/21/san-diego-immigrant-job-training-program-expands-cafe-and-urban-farm-business MAKE Projects mission is to create an inclusive San Diego by preparing refugees and immigrants to achieve their dreams. They are an employment social enterprise where they operate an urban farm, restaurant, and events/catering company to provide a paid, real-world work experience for low-income refugee and immigrant women and youth. They aim to provide trainees with job readiness skills to help them achieve their dreams. MAKE Projects vision is to see San Diegans cross social, racial, economic, and geographic lines as they gather over a common love of food, flavors, and cultures. They believe in the power of food to bring diverse populations together, unite a community, and educate each other about their history and differences, as well as their communities.

name: San Diego Gateway to College and Career, San Diego Workforce Partnership
description: The San Diego Gateway to College and Career program provides young adults who identify as immigrant, refugee and/or English language learner (ELL) with high-touch and intensive support, stipends and paid internships. Recognizing the strength of your diverse ethnicities and languages, students are also supported to achieve their language learning goals, no matter what language you speak. This program offers help in removing barriers to success, finding what career is right, finding a long-term job, starting school, and learning new job skills.
source_proposal: 16 - Supporting Integration and Human Rights of Displaced Persons.docx

name: YALLA San Diego
description: YALLA is a nonprofit academy that helps assimilate a refugee community revolving soccer. The children and teenagers at Yalla are refugees and immigrants, ages 6 to 18, who have escaped from countries of conflict and resettled with their families in San Diego County. "Yalla" translates to "let's go" in Arabic. Founder Mark Kabban, whose family is from Beirut, Lebanon, understands what it feels like to start life over in an unfamiliar place. He began the nonprofit in 2009 and through soccer and academics the Yalla Academy has empowered over 2,000 kids in the city of El Cajon, California, which has become a hot spot for refugee resettlement since the 1970s. Volunteers work daily after school with the kids on their academics with the main goal of preparing them for college. During the past four years, 88 percent of Yalla graduates have been accepted into four-year universities and have earned $5 million in academic scholarships. Meeting focus: *Possible Volunteer Opportunity* Meet Mark Kabban and/or the team at Yalla to discuss the work they do for refugees and immigrants in El Cajon; possibly volunteer with the group. Legal Resources:

name: Casa Cornelia Law Center
description: Casa Cornelia Law Center is a public interest law firm providing quality legal services to victims of human and civil rights violations. It seeks to educate others regarding the impact of immigration law and policy on the community and the public good. Since 1993, more than 15,000 children, women, and men have turned to Casa Cornelia for critical legal assistance and humanitarian protection. Casa Cornelia is the only non-profit law firm in San Diego County to provide free legal services to detained unaccompanied children.
source_proposal: 16 - Supporting Integration and Human Rights of Displaced Persons.docx

name: Immigration Center for Women and Children, San Diego Office
description: The Immigration Center for Women and Children (ICWC) is a non-profit legal organization providing free and affordable immigration services to underrepresented immigrants in California and Nevada. ICWC strives to provide security and stability for children who are abused, abandoned or neglected and for immigrants who are victims of domestic violence, sexual assault and other violent crimes. Using U.S. federal legislation, ICWC provides immigration legal services (U and T Visas, VAWA, and SIJS) to immigrants who are victims of crimes. The resulting immigration benefits allow individuals to permanently leave their abusers and create safe environments for their families.  ICWC’s overall goal is to assist these victims of domestic violence, human trafficking, sexual assault, and other violent crimes in escaping abusive relationships, live in safety, and become self-sufficient. Academic Resources:

name: UC San Diego Center for Comparative Immigration Studies
description: The Center for Comparative Immigration Studies (CCIS) is an independent research unit at the University of California San Diego. The Center’s global network of research associates has expanded to over 355 Research Associates based in 25 different countries. The Center also has 35 institutional affiliates, 12 of which are located outside the United States. CCIS academic staff and Fellows appear frequently in the local and national media discourse on immigration issues, and their scholarly work informs immigration policy and practice worldwide. CCIS has long been a center for the training of undergraduate and graduate students, with unique academic programming both in La Jolla and through the Mexican Migration Field Research Program.

name: David FitzGerald, CCIS Co-Director and Professor of Sociology, UCSD
description: David FitzGerald is the Theodore E. Gildred Chair in U.S.-Mexican Relations, Professor of Sociology, and Co-Director of the Center for Comparative Immigration Studies at the University of California San Diego. His research analyzes policies regulating migration and asylum in countries of origin, transit, and destination. FitzGerald’s most recent books include Immigrant California: Understanding the Past, Present, and Future of U.S. Policy (Stanford University Press 2021), and Refuge beyond Reach: How Rich Democracies Repel Asylum Seekers (Oxford University Press 2019), winner of the American Sociological Association International Migration Section Best Book Award;

name: Colibrí MX Scholarship – MAAC Project
description: The Consulate General of Mexico in San Diego, in partnership with MAAC, launched the Colibrí MX Scholarship in December 2019. This scholarship aims to promote access to higher education for immigrant students of Mexican or Latinx descent residing in San Diego County. They award a select number of eligible students with a $1,000 USD scholarship. Additionally, students who are eligible for the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program can also apply for a supplementary $500 USD scholarship. Their goal is to provide Mexican or Latinx students with the resources and support needed to start their journey towards a college degree. The Consulate General of Mexico in San Diego has the responsibility of safeguarding the welfare of any Mexican national living in San Diego County. MAAC is the leading provider of comprehensive social services in San Diego County and works to create healthier and stronger communities by providing a space where individuals and families in need can find means to self-sufficiency through advocacy and access to high-quality programs. name: Naval Base San Diego
description: Naval Base San Diego is the largest base of the United States Navy on the west coast of the United States. A thoroughly modern, state-of-the-art naval facility, Naval Base San Diego is homeport to the Pacific Fleet Surface Navy with 56 U.S. Navy ships and two auxiliary vessels including the USNS Mercy. The base often hosts visiting surface ships from foreign Navies, other U.S. homeports and the Coast Gard. Naval Base San Diego is also home to more than 200 tenant commands, each having specific and specialized fleet support purposes.
source_proposal: 17 - U.S.-European Security Challenges.docx

name: San Diego Field Office, Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI)
description: The FBI has 56 field offices centrally located in major metropolitan areas across the U.S. and Puerto Rico, where the agency carries out investigations, assesses local and regional crime threats, and works closely with partners on cases and operations. For 30 years the FBI has served as the primary agency responsible for investigating allegations of election crimes. This includes investigating allegations of voter and ballot fraud, campaign finance crimes, civil rights violations, computer crimes affecting voter registration and electronic voting systems, and threats posed by foreign governments and actors. In advance of the 2020 election, FBI San Diego participated in a National Messaging Campaign to educate citizens about election security and foreign malign influence.
source_proposal: 17 - U.S.-European Security Challenges.docx

name: San Diego Sheriff’s Department
description: The San Diego County Sheriff's Department is the chief law enforcement agency in San Diego County. The department is comprised of over 4,000 employees, both sworn officers and professional support staff. The department provides general law enforcement, detention, and court services for the people of San Diego County in a service area of approximately 4,200 square miles. In addition, the department provides specialized regional services to the entire county, including the incorporated cities and the unincorporated areas of the county. The Sheriff, currently Kelly A. Martinez, is elected by the residents of San Diego County, and is the chief executive of the department.
source_proposal: 17 - U.S.-European Security Challenges.docx

name: US Coast Guard
description: The Coast Guard is a unique branch of the armed forces responsible for an array of maritime duties, from ensuring safe and lawful commerce to performing rescue missions in severe conditions. Over 50,000 men and women are actively serving in the Coast Guard to defend America’s borders and protect the maritime environment. Members of the Coast Guard operate a multi-mission, interoperable fleet of 259 Cutters, 200 fixed and rotary-wing aircraft, and over 1,600 boats. Meeting request to go through federal gatekeepers.
source_proposal: 17 - U.S.-European Security Challenges.docx

name: San Diego FBI Citizens Academy
description: The FBI Citizens Academy program brings the community’s civic, business, and religious leaders together to experience firsthand how the FBI investigates crimes and threats to national security and learn about the various tools and techniques they employ to carry out their mission. As portions of the FBI Citizens Academy curriculum mirrors new-agent training, class members get plenty of hands-on instruction in diverse areas of practice ranging from firearms; fingerprinting; collecting evidence from a crime scene and investigative techniques. This program consists of four hour-long class meetings which are taught by agents and experts from their Laboratory and Training divisions. The course covers various topics including but not limited to: FBI Jurisdiction and Congressional oversight, Structure and operation of FBI field offices and satellite agencies, and intelligence and counter terrorism. These candidates are nominated by FBI employees, former Citizens Academy graduates, and community leaders. Participants are selected by the special agent in charge of the local FBI field office.
source_proposal: 17 - U.S.-European Security Challenges.docx

name: Department of Homeland Security (DHS)
description: The Department of Homeland Security aims to secure the nation from all threats. Employees of DHS complete jobs that range from aviation and border security to emergency response, cybersecurity analysis and chemical factory inspection. DHS maintains a complex mission, which distills down to the goal of keeping Americans safe, secure, and resilient. DHS has six overarching homeland security missions, including counter terrorism and homeland security strengths, and secure U.S. borders and approaches. Meeting request to go through federal gatekeepers.

name: Customs and Border Protection (CBP)
description: With more than 60,000 employees, U.S. CBP is one of the world’s largest law enforcement organizations and is charged with keeping terrorists and their weapons out of the U.S. while facilitating lawful international travel and trade. CBP takes a comprehensive approach to border management and control, combining customs, immigration, border security, and agricultural protection. Meeting request to go through federal gatekeepers. name: United Kingdom Government Affairs Office San Diego
description: The UK Government Affairs Office supports British citizens who are visiting, studying, working, or living in the U.S. This office works alongside the British Consulate General in Los Angeles, and supports the development and maintenance of relationships between the UK and U.S. Their work involves handling a range of political, commercial, cultural, security and economic interests. Specifically, the San Diego office works to promote business, economic and political ties in San Diego. Academic Institutes
source_proposal: 17 - U.S.-European Security Challenges.docx

name: San Diego State University: Graduate Program in Homeland Security; Visualization Center (Viz Center)
description: The mission of the Graduate Program in Homeland Security is to produce leaders from a variety of educational and professional backgrounds who can effectively and efficiently identify, design, and mobilize the appropriate community resources to prevent, deter, preempt, defend against, and respond to terrorist attacks and/or other critical incidents and emergencies on the local, regional, national and international levels. The Viz Center functions not only as a physical space but also as the one that largely represents relationships between people and organizations attempting to positively impact the worlds of Humanitarian Assistance Disaster Relief, Community Resilience, Search and Rescue, and aid to operational Emergency Responders and Homeland Security. The center specializes in organizing and delivering geospatial data over small networks for emergency response and disasters. By linking emerging technologies, innovative back-end processing, and operational needs especially for disaster, the Viz Center community is attempting to assist our community, region, nation, and world in responding to difficult situations with critical information, knowledge, and decision-support tools. Dr. Carl Luna, Political Analyst & Director, Institute for Civil Civic Engagement, University of San Diego
source_proposal: 17 - U.S.-European Security Challenges.docx

name: Institute for Civil Civic Engagement, University of San Diego
description: The Institute for Civil Civic Engagement (ICCE) was formed as a partnership between institutions committed to improving the quality of dialogue and civic engagement in San Diego. Their mission is to encourage, promote, and increase civility in civic discourse by citizens and public officials. They seek to promote ways to be civil in disagreement and respectful in debate, as they confront the political challenges that shape the community. Dr. Carl Luna is the ICCE Director and a frequent commentator on politics for local, national, and international media, including public radio and television, the CBS Morning Show and Evening News, NBC’s Today Show, the BBC, the Associated Press, New York Times, Washington Post and Los Angeles Times.
source_proposal: 17 - U.S.-European Security Challenges.docx

name: Vice Admiral Charles Martoglio, U.S. Navy (retired); lecturer, UCSD School of Global Policy & Strategy
description: Vice Admiral Charles W. Martoglio, U.S. Navy (ret), is a lecturer at the School of Global Policy and Strategy at UC San Diego. Drawing on his extensive background leading large elements of our U.S. military, VADM Martoglio’s focus is on national security affairs and leadership. He spent about half of his military career in the U.S. Navy at sea in cruisers, destroyers and aircraft carriers. VADM Martoglio spent the other half of his career developing strategy and policy, fostering international relations, and conducting operations, initially for the U.S. Navy then for all U.S. military forces. VADM Martoglio is recognized as one of the Defense Department’s preeminent strategic thinkers, with proven expertise in contingency planning, international relations and operations execution. He has served in Asia, the Middle East, and, most recently, in Europe as the Deputy Commander of all U.S. military forces in Europe, Eurasia and Israel. In various capacities he has developed the U.S. Navy’s Strategic Plan, led security-related organizations through significant change, headed the planning effort for some of our nation’s most complex contingency plans, and has overseen the integration of the U.S. Government Interagency into Defense Department operations in both Asia and Europe. Energy Providers
source_proposal: 17 - U.S.-European Security Challenges.docx

name: Sempra
description: Sempra is a global energy infrastructure company focused on leading the way of advancing electrification and promoting energy diversification, resiliency, and affordable access to cleaner forms of energy. From its San Diego headquarters to operations throughout the Americas, Sempra is making strides in developing forward-thinking energy solutions and delivering everyday power to customers. Sempra believes the global energy ecosystem is going to change dramatically over the next 30 years. In advanced economies, the change will take the form of innovation and technology that improves energy efficiency and supports a shift toward new, smart renewable and natural gas infrastructure. In developing nations, improving energy diversity will be the central effort as new, smart infrastructure that supports renewables and natural gas displaces higher carbon forms of energy. San Diego Gas & Electric, Energy Innovation Center (SDG&E) www.sdge.com/eic SDG&E is a regulated public utility that provides energy service to 3.6 million people through 1.4 million electric meters and 873,000 natural gas meters in San Diego and southern Orange counties. A wholly owned subsidiary of Sempra, their service area spans 4,100 square miles. Not only do SDG&E deliver energy to homes and businesses throughout San Diego, but they are actively working to ensure San Diego is at the forefront of concerns shared by the community. This includes wildfire mitigation, electric vehicle adoption, diverse supply chains for a robust economy, and workforce training. International Trade Assistance Institutions
source_proposal: 17 - U.S.-European Security Challenges.docx

name: French-American Chamber of Commerce
description: The French-American Chamber of Commerce aims to boost French and American businesses and individuals to create a more connected community. They help their members gain tremendous momentum to grow their business and connect businesses with crucial resources. Over the last two years, the French-American Chamber of Commerce has facilitated over 100 meetings with leading U.S. businesses. With over 150 members, they are one of the largest foreign networks in San Diego. Meeting focus: Discover how San Diego is promoting economic relationships and interest between U.S. - European audiences.
source_proposal: 17 - U.S.-European Security Challenges.docx

name: German American Chamber of Commerce California
description: The German American Chamber of Commerce California (GACC) serves as the primary contact for German nationals and foreign companies planning projects or seeking economic advancement in the U.S. Their mission is to serve as a bridge for German-American economic relations. They provide a range of services, including market and address research, legal aid, details on intellectual property rights, market entry possibilities, and more. San Diego Regional Economic Development Corporation www.sandiegobusiness.org/ San Diego Regional Economic Development Corporation (EDC) mobilizes business, government, and civic leaders to maximize the region's economic prosperity and global competitiveness. They serve local companies by aiding with expansion plans, programs to help retain businesses, and advocating for policies that enhance the region's economic competitiveness. They lead attraction efforts to bring new investment and new companies to the region. World Trade Center San Diego, an affiliate of San Diego Regional Economic Development Corporation, (WTCSD) is Southern California’s leading international trade association with direct access to the largest international trade network in the world. The organization offers the San Diego region services that allow businesses to gain key global contacts, research and tools to enhance international competitiveness. WTCSD provides comprehensive international business services and global lead-generation to facilitate and expand business internationally for regional clients. Think Tanks, Policy Resources, and Working Groups
source_proposal: 17 - U.S.-European Security Challenges.docx

name: Center on Policy Initiatives
description: The Center on Policy Initiatives (CPI) is a nonprofit research and action institute dedicated to creating economic prosperity, sustainable communities, and a healthy environment for all. They provide analysis, policy solutions, education, and alliances that advance social and economic justice for working people and diverse communities. They carry this out through research, coalition organizing, advocacy, leadership development, and other strategies.
source_proposal: 17 - U.S.-European Security Challenges.docx

name: The University of California Institute on Global Conflict and Cooperation (IGCC)
description: The UC Institute on Global Conflict and Cooperation (IGCC) is a network of researchers from across the University of California and the Los Alamos and Lawrence Livermore national labs who produce and use research to help build a more peaceful, prosperous world. They conduct rigorous social science research on international security, the environment, geoeconomics, nuclear security, and the future of democracy; help to educate and train the next generation of peacemakers; and strive to ensure that what they are discovering contributes to a safer world.  The Institute is based at the School of Global Policy and Strategy at UC San Diego, where several members of the leadership team and a number of researchers are on the faculty. Dr. Tai Ming Cheung, Director Tai Ming Cheung is director of the University of California Institute on Global Conflict and Cooperation and a professor at the School of Global Policy and Strategy at UC San Diego, where he teaches courses on the international relations and national security of China and Chinese security and technology policy. Among the areas of his research focus include China’s efforts to become a world-class science and technology power, and the relationship between geo-economics, innovation, and national security. Dr. Cheung is a long-time analyst of Chinese and East Asian defense and national security affairs, especially defense economic, industrial and science, and technological issues.
source_proposal: 17 - U.S.-European Security Challenges.docx

name: SANDAG: San Diego Regional Military Working Group
description: The San Diego Association of Governments (SANDAG) connects people, places, and innovative ideas by building projects with the San Diego region’s unique and diverse communities. They serve as a vital resource for member agencies and the community to plan for the future, and are committed to creating a San Diego region where every person who visits, works, and lives can thrive. San Diego Regional Military Working Group is committed to provide a collaborative forum for the various branches of the military and SANDAG to address areas of mutual interest, including growth management, habitat, transportation, regional growth, housing, water, energy, and other related topics. The voting members of the Military Working Group include: Navy Region Southwest; Navy Facilities Engineering Command; Marine Corps Installation West; Marine Corps Recruitment Depot; and U.S. Coast Guard San Diego Sector. In addition, the membership includes one representative from jurisdictions including the City of Coronado, City of Imperial Beach, City of Oceanside, City of National City, City of San Diego, and County of San Diego.
source_proposal: 17 - U.S.-European Security Challenges.docx

name: Kroc Institute for Peace and Justice (Kroc IPJ)
description: Kroc IPJ launched with a vision of active peacebuilding. Its mission is to co-create learning with peacemakers – learning that is deeply grounded in the lived experience of peacemakers around the world, that is made rigorous by their place within the University of San Diego’s ecosystem. Kroc IPJ is heavily involved in initiatives building peace at the U.S. – Mexico border. As the closest peace institute to the border, Kroc IPJ seeks to build peace in the border region through research grounded in a nuanced understanding of challenges faced by border communities and in partnership with local scholars, practitioners and policymakers. Kroc IPJ offers educational programs to help transcend the politics and prejudices that promote violence and create injustice on both sides of the border. Border Resources Tour of the San Diego-Tijuana Border The largest land border crossing in the world, the San Ysidro border crossing plays an integral role in San Diego and Tijuana’s close knit, collaborative relationship. The majority of people living in communities on the San Diego side of the border are people of color, with over 50% of residents identifying as Hispanic or Latinx, whose diversity of experience contribute to a rich hub of culture, experience, and opportunity. San Diego and Tijuana have long prospered from good-humored cross border relations, recently made even more successful with the honor of being jointly named the Innovation Design Hub for 2024. However, while cross-border collaboration and innovation are things to celebrate, there is lots of work to do on the ground among the minority and immigrant communities living in the border region, to ensure quality of life and access to resources are supported. Proposed stops on the border tour include:
source_proposal: 17 - U.S.-European Security Challenges.docx

name: San Ysidro Point of Entry: The main artery between San Diego and Tijuana – and, in fact, the U.S. and Mexico – which sees approximately 120,000 passenger vehicles, 60,000 pedestrians, and 6000 trucks crossing back and forth each day, the San Ysidro border is evidence of San Diego and Tijuana’s dynamic relationship. While participants cannot cross into Mexico, they will be able to see over the wall into Mexico, and stand on the bridge atop the border, which leads to the pedestrian crossing site.
url: Cross Border Express (CBX) https://www.crossborderxpress.com/en/ CBX is a pedestrian bridge for passengers of the Tijuana International Airport that allows passengers to cross the U.S.-Mexico border with ease. The facility saves millions of passengers from being delayed at the San Ysidro border crossing by enabling processing via a service terminal on the San Diego side of the border.
description: Friendship Park: Friendship Park is a binational park situated on the U.S.-Mexico border, overlooking the ocean. Since its opening by Pat Nixon 51 years ago, the park has served as a meeting point for families who have been separated by immigration laws. For some families, Friendship Park offers the only opportunity to reunite with loved ones unable to cross the border. Friendship Park, particularly on the Mexico side, has been cultivated by the community into a place of art and gathering, with regular art installations featured and frequent cross-border events like church sermons and yoga classes. We suggest that the tour be accompanied by Rachel Lozano Castro. Rachel Lozano Castro is a public goods professional in San Diego, California and Tijuana, Mexico. She invests her time and energy where community good and equitable economy meet, which can include social entrepreneurship, place making, government upgrades, workforce development and inclusive innovation and investment. In her previous role, Rachel directed the University of San Diego's Brink Small Business Development Center. Today, she is the Director of Innovation at the San Diego Regional Policy and Innovation Center, and facilitates learning experiences around bi-national governance, business, social innovation, design thinking, networking, prototyping and social impact measurement. Note: Should you prefer to tour the border through region through a security lens, Dr. Eric Frost at the SDSU Viz Center is also able to run a border tour. Volunteer Activities
source_proposal: 17 - U.S.-European Security Challenges.docx

name: San Diego River Park Foundation
description: The San Diego River Park Foundation is dedicated to the celebration and care of the San Diego River, and to creating a better quality of life for the community through the creation of a park system along the 52-mile river. Their programs, projects, and events are designed to connect people to the historic San Diego River, and empower the community to steward and celebrate it. Activity Focus: With help from the San Diego River Park Foundation, learn more about the importance of the river as a biodiverse ecosystem in San Diego, and efforts they are doing to connect community to the river. Activities may include planting and revitalizing native plants, watering, and spreading mulch.
source_proposal: 17 - U.S.-European Security Challenges.docx

name: Feeding San Diego
description: Feeding San Diego is the leading hunger relief and food rescue organization in San Diego County. They provide more than 35.4 million meals every year to children, families, seniors, college students, military families, veterans, people facing homelessness, and other underserved populations. In 2022 – 2023, nearly 76% of the food they provided to the community was rescued from becoming waste. Activity Focus: Support Feeding San Diego’s program to package boxes required by a family of four to eat for one week; or another similar activity. ______________________________________________________________ Cultural Activities: San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $67 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).
source_proposal: 17 - U.S.-European Security Challenges.docx

name: Chicano Park
description: Chicano Park is the geographic and emotional heart of Barrio Logan, located in Logan Heights, San Diego's oldest Mexican-American neighborhood. The park is home to the largest concentration of Chicano murals in the world with more than 80 paintings on seven acres dotted with sculpture, gardens, picnic tables and playgrounds. Throughout the year, it hosts festivals of music and Aztec dance, the biggest being Chicano Park Day held each April. Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $30 for one Adult Ticket for a one-hour narrated tour (south bay or north bay routes); $35 for a full bay two-hour narrated tour which covers it all: ships of the Maritime Museum, Harbor and Shelter Islands, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and more. The full bay tour is about 25 miles in length. Accessibility: The tour begins and ends at the same location downtown along Broadway Pier.s Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com Price: $44 for a 1-Day Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) For 30 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours, highlighting the best San Diego attractions. The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50 am – 5:00 pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $26 for one Adult General Admission Ticket ($1 discount when purchased on-line). Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10am – 5pm (Last admission at 4pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside Navy Pier. Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 17 major museums and cultural institutions, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).

name: Coronado
description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year round due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. (Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown.) SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $99.99 for one Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Orca Encounter, Dolphin Days, and Sea Lions Live shows and thrilling rides like Electric Eel, Manta, and Journey To Atlantis. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Hours vary by season. Also enjoy the opening of Sesame Place in March 2022, a Sesame Street themed section of the park with new water, ride, and musical attractions. Accessibility: A 15-20-minute drive from downtown San Diego.

name: Friendship Park / El Parque de la Amistad
description: A historic meeting place on the US-Mexico border, overlooking the Pacific Ocean.  For generations people of good will from both nations have gathered here to visit with family and friends "across the line.” *Please note, although visitors can see Friendship Park on Friday from outside the gates, access to the park is only open on Saturday and Sunday from 10:00 am – 2:00 pm.

name: Presidio Park
description: Presidio Park in San Diego is a tranquil historical site with remnants of the city's original Spanish settlement, offering visitors a chance to step back in time. The Serra Museum within the park provides a deeper understanding of the area's history, while the park's botanical garden and picnic areas invite relaxation. Its elevated location provides a scenic view of San Diego, making it a favorite spot for those seeking a quiet escape, historical insights, or outdoor respite in a peaceful setting.

name: Community Advocates for Just and Moral Governance (MoGo)
description: MoGo was founded by two Black women lawyers who have dedicated their lives and careers to secure racial equality, social justice, and greater access to quality education. Their mission is to promote good governance, and they do this by engaging in litigation and various forms of advocacy that will make government more just and fully accountable to all people, particularly those who have been marginalized from society. After three years of advocating alongside other community organizations, MoGo successfully passed approval within San Diego City Council to create a new privacy and technology ordinance over San Diego’s smart streetlights.

name: City of San Diego Sustainability and Mobility Department
description: The Sustainability and Mobility Department leads the implementation of the City's Climate Action Plan. Focused on interdepartmental coordination, regional alignment and new policies and ordinances, the Department furthers the City's goals for equitable, efficient and effective mobility choices that support residents of all ages and abilities, and facilitates innovative efforts across multiple City departments to enhance equitable, economic, social and environmental sustainability. The Department is also the custodian of the City’s transition to 100% renewable energy through San Diego Community Power and the administrative oversight of the SDG&E franchise.  The Sustainability and Mobility Department was responsible for the execution and oversight of the smart streetlight project at the City of San Diego.

name: Qualcomm
description: While Qualcomm is well known for 5G and its Snapdragon line of processors that power smartphones around the world, the company is also a leader in numerous technologies relevant for the Internet of Things such as AI, modem-RF systems, codecs, digital signal processing, power efficiency management, as well as vision, media, and audio tech. Qualcomm is a leading company in the development and scope of San Diego’s smart streetlight project. For Qualcomm, the rollout of smart streetlights in the city was a step in the right direction concerning innovation, intellectual property, and economic development.

name: The Transparent and Responsible Use of Surveillance Technology San Diego (TRUST SD)
description: The TRUST SD Coalition was originally formed to address the widespread and secretive use, installation, and acquisition of the Smart Streetlights technology being deployed throughout San Diego County. TRUST SD led the call for community oversight of the use of technology and a strong, legally enforceable ordinance to address privacy and civil liberty issues. The TRUST SD Coalition is 100% community-centered and community-driven, made up of 30 local community organizations. Academic Institutions

name: Institute for Civil Civic Engagement
description: https://www.sandiego.edu/institute-for-civil-civic-engagement/ The Institute for Civil Civic Engagement (ICCE) is located at the University of San Diego, one of San Diego's leading tertiary institutions. ICCE works to encourage, promote and increase civility in civic discourse by fellow citizens and public officials, both interpersonally and in all manner of media. The institute seeks to promote ways to be civil in disagreements and respectful in debates, as they confront the political challenges that shape the community. Some of the ICCE's main goals include to encourage the San Diego community to embrace basic elements of civility in dealing with civic activism and political campaigning, to hold community leaders accountable to conducting public discourse, and to develop and implement programs and curriculum providing effective instruction in best methods of civil civic engagement for educational communities. Meeting focus: Meet with representatives of ICCE to learn about their various initiatives and educational resources to promote civil civic engagement within communities in San Diego and beyond.

name: ﻿Zoltan Hainal PhD - Professor at the University of California, San Diego
description: ﻿﻿https://ucsdnews.ucsd.edu/pressrelease/how-to-double-voter-turnout-and-increase- representation-during-local-clections Zoltan Hainal is a professor of political science at the School of Global Policy and Strategy, Hainal teaches courses including Policy Analysis and Public Welfare. Hainal is a respected scholar on U.S. politics and policy, with a specific focus on how disadvantaged populations are represented in American politics and what can be done to ensure better representation of these groups. His research areas span racial and ethnic politics, urban politics, immigration and political behavior. He is the author of multiple award-winning books including "White Backlash: Immigration, Race, and American Politics" (Princeton 2015), "Why Americans Don't Join the Party: Race, Immigration, and the Failure of Political Parties to Engage the Electorate" (Princeton 2011), "America's Uneven Democracy: Race, Turnout, and Representation in City Politics" (Cambridge 2010) and "Changing White Attitudes toward Black Political Leadership" (Cambridge 2006). His research has been featured in The New York Times, Washington Post and a range of other media outlets. Meeting focus: Discuss and explore political behavior across different communities to gain a perspective of how disadvantaged populations are represented in politics.

name: Inewsource
description: inewsource is a nonprofit, nonpartisan newsroom dedicated to improving lives in the San Diego region and beyond through impactful, data-based investigative and accountability journalism. Inewsource values, above all else, the importance of a free and credible press, where truth is the cornerstone of democracy. name: City of San Diego Ethics Commission
description: The Ethics Commission within the City of San Diego is charged with monitoring, administering and enforcing the City's governmental ethics laws and proposing new governmental ethics law reforms; conducting investigations, referring violations to appropriate enforcement agencies and auditing disclosure statements; and advising and educating City officials and the public about governmental ethics laws. This is an independent body, which does not report to the Mayor or City Council. Their mission is to preserve public confidence in San Diego’s City government through education, advice, and the prompt and fair enforcement of local governmental ethics laws.

name: ﻿Meeting focus: Gain an understanding of commission responsibilities and recent initiatives to promote ethics in City government.
url: Department of Purchasing and Contracting, County of San Dlego https://www.sandiegocounty.gov/content/sdc/purchasing.html
description: ﻿The Department of Purchasing and Contracting (DPC) operates to provide County Departments and other associated organizations outstanding procurement support necessary to meet their operational missions and objectives. Procurement of goods and services is completed in compliance with all applicable laws, policies and regulations in a manner that supports the best interests of the County. DPC is committed to transparency and accountability of all purchasing and contracting transactions and making all contracting opportunities available to qualified businesses which can best meet the County's needs. ﻿Meeting Focus: Discuss DPC's effort to promote its transparency and accountability of purchasing and contracting transactions through Measure J.

name: City of San Diego: Performance & Analytics Department
description: The City of San Diego's Performance & Analytics Department is responsible for supporting the improvement of City operations through long-term strategic initiatives, including strategic planning, performance measurement and management, the San Diego Works efficiency and incentives program, Managed Competition, and Open Data. As such, the Department works citywide to implement resident-focused and data-driven solutions that improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the City's service delivery practices and management structures.

name: San Diego Citizens’ Law Enforcement Review Board (CLERB)
description: The role of the Citizens’ Law Enforcement Review Board  is to increase public confidence in government and the accountability of law enforcement by conducting impartial and independent investigations of citizen complaints of misconduct concerning Sheriff's Deputies and Probation Officers employed by the County of San Diego. CLERB receives and investigates complaints about the conduct of peace officers employed by the County Sheriff’s Department and Probation Department. CLERB also investigates deaths that arise out of, or in connection with, the actions of deputies and probation officers, regardless of whether a complaint is filed. Legal Resources

name: San Diegans for Open Government (SDOG) / Briggs Law Corporation
description: Briggs Law Corporation has grown into one of California’s leading law firms on issues relating to government transparency and accountability. They have successfully litigated many public interest cases which involved standing up to the government, politicians, and big corporations when they break rules created to protect taxpayers, the public, and the environment. Briggs Law Corporation has also represented community watchdogs in a variety of lawsuits to obtain information that public officials attempted to cover up. ﻿Meeting Focus: Discuss Briggs Law Corporation efforts to promote open government in the San Diego area through government and municipal litigation, and learn about watchdog cases they have overseen to uncover over 100,000 pages of public records. Government Resources

name: San Diego County Young Democrats
description: San Diego County Young Democrats (SDCYD) is part of the California State Democratic Party, which works closely with local elected officials, and the coun party. Open to registered Democrats under 36, SDCYD members work to improve the San Diego community, and to elect Democrats. SDCYD holds regular events for members around the county, including guest speakers, opportunities for political action, community service, and networking events.

name: Mayor Todd Gloria
description: Mayor Gloria has spent his career in public service. After being elected to the California State Assembly to represent the 78th Assembly District in 2016, Mayor Gloria passed legislation on many major issues San Diego is working to address including affordable housing, fighting gun violence, combatting climate change, and providing resources for unhoused people. A third-generation San Diegan of Filipino, Dutch, Puerto Rican, and Native American descent, Maxat Gloria is motivated to improve San Diego every day.
source_proposal: 18 - Transparency and Accountability in Government.docx

name: Nora Vargas, San Diego County Supervisor District 1
description: https://www.kpbs.org/news/2021/feb/05/first-latina-supervisor-change-san-diego- politics/ Supervisor Nora Vargas represents District 1 in San Diego's South County. She is the first immigrant, first Latina, and first Democrat to represent her district. For the last 25 years, Supervisor Vargas has worked to drive positive change and serve her community through public service. She is committed to ensuring that marginalized voices are included in the public dialogue regarding various important issues like health access, civic engagement, and education. Prior to her election, she was an elected member and President of the Southwestern College Governing Board, the only public institution of higher education within San Diego's South County. Virtual Meeting Focus: Discuss the demographics of Supervisor Vargas's district and the significance her election has on the region.

name: San Diego County District Attorney's Office
description: The San Diego County District Attorney's Office is responsible for prosecuting felony crimes committed in the County. It also prosecutes misdemeanor offenses that occur outside of the City of San Diego. Each year the more than 300 prosecutors in the DA's Office file about 40,000 cases on behalf of the county's more than three million residents. The employees of the San Diego County District Attorney, in partnership with the community we serve, are dedicated to the pursuit of truth, justice and protection of the innocent, and the prevention of crime through the vigorous and professional prosecution of those who violate the law. District Attorney Summer Stephan has devoted her life to protecting children and families, providing justice to the most vulnerable, and is a national leader in the fight against human trafficking and sexual exploitation. In 2022, Summer was named one of "The Five Best Prosecutors in America, " utilizing evaluation factors of integrity, fidelity to the rule of law, responsible innovations, and community relations. Non-Governmental Organizations
