name: San Diego Organizing Project
description: A nonpartisan, multi-faith network, San Diego Organizing Project (SDOP) represents more than 70,000 families across San Diego County. As one of the most diverse grassroots organizations in the region, SDOP bridges racial, cultural, and economic divides, unlocking the power of people to bring justice, equality, and greater opportunity to fruition in their communities. Some ongoing campaigns SDOP is currently focusing on include justice system reform, county government accountability, civic engagement, immigrant rights, and affordable housing and homelessness.
source_proposal: 18 - Transparency and Accountability in Government.docx

name: Partnership for the Advancement of New Americans (PANA)
description: PANA is a research, public policy, and community organizing hub dedicated to advancing the full economic, social and civic inclusion of refugees. Founded, led, and staffed by refugees, PANA is uniquely situated to use relational organizing to bring community into a pathway of ongoing engagement and indigenous community leadership development.
source_proposal: 18 - Transparency and Accountability in Government.docx

name: Alliance of San Diego
description: Alliance San Diego is a non-profit, non-partisan community organization whose mission is to provide a means for diverse individuals and organizations to share information, collaborate on issues and mobilize for change in the pursuit of social justice, especially in low-income communities and communities of color. They seek to build collective power to create an inclusive democracy through leadership development, policy advocacy, communication strategies, and civic engagement. Alliance San Diego's work is guided by three goals: equity and access, voting and governance, and safety and justice. Cultural Activities Cafe 21 www.cafe-21.com/ As one of the most innovative restaurants in San Diego, Cafe21 is committed to changing the way their guests think about food. Everything they do at this Azerbaijani restaurant is made from scratch and with love. San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).
source_proposal: 18 - Transparency and Accountability in Government.docx

name: Chicano Park
description: Chicano Park is the geographic and emotional heart of Barrio Logan, located in Logan Heights, San Diego's oldest Mexican-American neighborhood. The park is home to the largest concentration of Chicano murals in the world with more than 80 paintings on seven acres dotted with sculpture, gardens, picnic tables and playgrounds. Throughout the year, it hosts festivals of music and Aztec dance, the biggest being Chicano Park Day held each April. Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $30 for one Adult Ticket for a one-hour narrated tour (south bay or north bay routes); $35 for a full bay two-hour narrated tour which covers it all: ships of the Maritime Museum, Harbor and Shelter Islands, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and more. The full bay tour is about 25 miles in length. Accessibility: The tour begins and ends at the same location downtown along Broadway Pier. Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com Price: $44 for a 1-Day Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) For 30 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours, highlighting the best San Diego attractions. The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50am – 5:00pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $26 for one Adult General Admission Ticket ($1 discount when purchased on-line). Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10am – 5pm (Last admission at 4pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside Navy Pier.
source_proposal: 18 - Transparency and Accountability in Government.docx

name: Border Field State Park & Friendship Park
description: https://www.friendshippark.org/ Located within the Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve, Border Field State Park sits in the very southwestern corner of the United States, 15 miles south of San Diego. This important wildlife habitat, comprised of sand dunes and salt marshes, gives refuge to critically threatened and endangered birds such as the Western Snowy Plover, the California Least Tern, and the Light-footed Ridgway's Rail. Friendship Park is a binational park located at the western end of the US-Mexico border. For generations people have gathered here to meet up with friends and family "across the line." Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 17 major museums and cultural institutions, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).
source_proposal: 18 - Transparency and Accountability in Government.docx

name: Coronado
description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year around due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown. SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $99.99 for one Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Orca Encounter, Dolphin Days, and Sea Lions Live shows and thrilling rides like Electric Eel, Manta, and Journey To Atlantis. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Hours vary by season. Also enjoy the opening of Sesame Place in March 2022, a Sesame Street themed section of the park with new water, ride, and musical attractions. Accessibility: A 15-20-minute drive from downtown San Diego.
source_proposal: 18 - Transparency and Accountability in Government.docx

name: UCSD Rady School of Management
description: https://rady.ucsd.edu/ The University of California, San Diego Rady School of Management ranks as a top entrepreneurship school with innovative faculty, evidence-driven researchers, and dedicated teachers. The Rady School emphasizes teaching business as a science, preparing students for leadership by creating the essential bridges between science, data, and innovation. Professors at the Rady School of Management researched the economic and social effects of the Voting Rights Act (VRA) on minority populations, specifically Black communities. Study results showed the VRA increased Black voter turnout and decreased the wage gap.
source_proposal: 19 - The Problem We All Live With.docx

name: San Diego State University (SDSU) School of Public Health
description: SDSU’s School of Public Health prepares students for professional and public health careers and hosts leading research and initiatives encompassing the interconnected fields of public health. The Contact Tracing Program where SDSU partnered with the County of San Diego’s Health and Human Services Agency (HHSA) to target minority communities disproportionately affected by the COVID pandemic in San Diego (Black as well as Spanish-, Arabic- and Tagalog-speaking communities). Main Focus: Explore the impact of the COVID pandemic on minorities and how SDSU School of Public Health works to promote equal access to healthcare. Media and Journalism
source_proposal: 19 - The Problem We All Live With.docx

name: Voice of San Diego
description: https://voiceofsandiego.org/2019/09/05/the-learning-curve-teacher-diversity-at-every-school-district-in-san-diego-county-ranked/ Launched in 2005, Voice of San Diego was the first digital, nonprofit news organization in the country to serve a local community. Its founders, longtime columnist and editor Neil Morgan and entrepreneur Buzz Woolley, felt the region desperately needed more reporting, analysis and journalistic competition. VOSD made a name for itself by producing hard-hitting investigative reports along with civic engagement opportunities that gave San Diego residents a new platform to discuss and debate the issues that impact their quality of life.
source_proposal: 19 - The Problem We All Live With.docx

name: The San Diego Tribune
description: https://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/opinion/commentary/story/2024-02-09/opinion-san-diego-tech-industry-diversity-stem-education-workforce San Diego’s largest media company and its oldest business, dating back to 1868. Union-Tribune publications reach over 96% of San Diegan households each week with journalism encompassing local news, sports, business, opinion pieces, entertainment, lifestyle, real estate, and weather in English and Spanish. Reporters at the San Diego Tribune also cover education and have published several pieces investigating what San Diego students are learning about ethnic studies, focusing on racism, bias, and privilege. Government Resources
source_proposal: 19 - The Problem We All Live With.docx

name: City of San Diego: Commission for Arts and Culture
description: The Commission for Arts and Culture is part of the Mayor’s commitment to a City that works for all. The Commission’s purpose is to promote equitable distribution of the City of San Diego’s resources, the Commission for Arts and Culture launched the Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) initiative which includes assessment, training, and public engagement.
source_proposal: 19 - The Problem We All Live With.docx

name: San Diego County Office of Education
description: The San Diego County Office of Education (SDCOE) serves the region's most vulnerable students and supports school leaders, teachers, and students across the county. They support about 780​ schools and nearly 500,000 students, including children educated through the Juvenile Court and Community Schools.
source_proposal: 19 - The Problem We All Live With.docx

name: San Diego County Public Health Office
source_proposal: 19 - The Problem We All Live With.docx

name: https://www.nbcsandiego.com/news/local/san-diego-health-officer-looks-back-on-the-first-year-of-covid-19-wishes-community-took-it-more-seriously/2532517/
description: Public Health Services is dedicated to community wellness and health protection in San Diego County. Public Health Services works to prevent epidemics and the spread of disease, protect against environmental hazards, prevent injuries, promote and encourage healthy behaviors, respond to disasters, assist communities in recovery, and assure the quality and accessibility of health services throughout the county. Their public health officers focus on health disparities and the impacts of epidemics like the H1N1 virus, Hepatitis A, and the COVID pandemic and their effects on the San Diegan Community.
source_proposal: 19 - The Problem We All Live With.docx

name: Cultural Awareness Project- San Diego District Attorney's Office
description: The Cultural Awareness Project is a training program created by the District Attorney’s Office to “foster culturally competent law enforcement officers”. The project relies on focus groups from various cultural minorities to create content that helps police officers respond respectfully to non-emergency situations.
source_proposal: 19 - The Problem We All Live With.docx

name: San Diego Police Department
description: https://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/politics/story/2021-07-06/san-diegos-most-diverse-police-academy-helps-force-look-more-like-citys-population Just over 372 square miles, the San Diego Police Department serves 1.41 million residents from diverse communities. With programs like LGBTQ+ Safe Space, the San Diego Police are trained in diversity and the unique challenges minorities face helping the force to “treat every person with dignity and respect”. Furthermore, San Diego’s Police Academy is starting to reflect the San Diego population with large amounts of minorities being hired into the police force, increasing its racial, ethnic, and thought diversity.
source_proposal: 19 - The Problem We All Live With.docx

name: San Diego County’s Office of Equity and Racial Justice
description: The Office of Equity and Racial Justice (OERJ) was established in 2020 to strengthen the County of San Diego's commitment to racial equity, with the intent that race no longer be a determining factor in a person's life outcomes. This approach supports groups across ethnicity, gender, age, ability, and other identities to live and participate in our society to their full potential.
source_proposal: 19 - The Problem We All Live With.docx

name: San Diego City’s Department of Race and Equity
description: The Department of Race and Equity partners with all San Diego City departments to develop and sustain equity-driven strategies. To achieve this, the department focuses on strategic planning and partnerships, data-driven practices, learning and development, and community engagement. Non-Governmental Organizations
source_proposal: 19 - The Problem We All Live With.docx

name: San Diego Foundation
description: The San Diego Foundation is San Diego’s largest regional community partnership organization that has been incorporating donors, nonprofits, communities, governments, and civil leaders for 50 years. Their mission is to “inspire enduring philanthropy and enable community solutions to improve the quality of life in our region” to create “just, equitable, and resilient communities”.
source_proposal: 19 - The Problem We All Live With.docx

name: Alliance San Diego
description: Alliance San Diego is a community organization whose mission is to build collective power so we can create an inclusive democracy. By working together to engage effectively in the civic process, we can make systemic change and shape a future that belongs to all of us. Together, we can create a more inclusive democracy where all people can achieve their full potential in an environment of harmony, justice, safety, and equality.
source_proposal: 19 - The Problem We All Live With.docx

name: Coronado Historical Association and Museum
description: https://coronadohistory.org/exhibits/current-exhibits/ The new exhibit, “An Island Looks Back: Uncovering Coronado’s Hidden African American History” details the experiences of the black community in the area since the 1880s. These black experiences include successful business ventures, veterans, and leaders displayed next to the horrors of redlining, racially motivated murders, and minstrel shows also faced by the community.
source_proposal: 19 - The Problem We All Live With.docx

name: San Diego African American Museum of Fine Arts
description: The San Diego African American Museum of Fine Arts (SDAAMFA) works to present and preserve the art of African Americans globally and to broaden the knowledge and understanding of the visual arts in Southern California generally and San Diego specifically by collecting, preserving and displaying works of art by and about African Americans; by creating and hosting quality traveling exhibitions; by collecting and preserving fine art and by developing and helping to foster an appreciation of art through meaningful public programs, symposia, and other educational programs.
source_proposal: 19 - The Problem We All Live With.docx

name: Father Joe’s Villages *Possible Community Service Activity
description: https://my.neighbor.org/dei/#:~:text=Father%20Joe's%20Villages%20designs%20programs,members%2Findividuals%20with%20disabilities%20or Father Joe’s Villages addresses one of San Diego’s biggest problems, homelessness, by meeting people’s basic needs, investing in children, making health a priority, and strengthening self-sufficiency. Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) is a key pillar of Father Joe’s Villages’ mission in serving individuals experiencing homelessness who are disproportionately affected by homelessness. name: San Diego Gas & Electric (SDG&E)
description: SDG&E is a regulated public utility that provides energy service to 3.6 million people through 1.4 million electric meters and 873,000 natural gas meters in San Diego and southern Orange counties. Their service area spans 4,100 square miles. In 2013, SDG&E began operating the first utility-scale microgrid in America – the Borrego Springs Microgrid. Last year, it received a federal grant to upgrade the Borrego system to run on 100% renewable energy. In 2017, SDG&E unveiled what was then the world's largest lithium-ion battery storage facility. In 2021, SDG&E launched a vanadium redox flow (VDF) battery to maximize clean energy - the first of its kind connected to the California grid. Since then, the technology used in this battery has been tested for its uses to support zero-emission microgrids. Academic Resources
source_proposal: 2 - Regional Lithium Cooperation.docx

name: San Diego State University Imperial Valley
description: San Diego State University (SDSU) combines the benefits of a small, private research university with the access that comes from being a CSU school. SDSU’s Sustainable Energy Center (SEC), located in Imperial Valley, fosters cutting-edge  renewable energy research, provides academic and professional education relevant to California's energy future, and contributes to the social and economic development of Imperial County. Some of the major elements of SEC include a classroom and training building for workforce training and academic programs; an information and exposition center with future technologies; and a technology park providing R&D space for renewable energy companies. Note: IVC is located in Imperial Valley.
source_proposal: 2 - Regional Lithium Cooperation.docx

name: Imperial Valley College
description: Imperial Valley College (IVC) is a public community college which enrolls approximately 7,000 students per year. The vast majority of students at IVC come from underserved and minority communities, reflecting the demographics of the wider Imperial Valley Community - almost 90% of students at IVC identify as Hispanic of Latino. Amidst the impending lithium boom in Imperial Valley, IVC has launched a program to train students for jobs in the lithium industry. Job projections foresee a drastic need for lithium workers, and IVC is working to ensure that their graduates have the necessary skills to support the industry, in the hopes that some of the financial benefits of lithium mining will be reinvested in the Imperial Valley Community. Note: IVC is located in Imperial Valley. Research Labs and Policy Centers
source_proposal: 2 - Regional Lithium Cooperation.docx

name: Energy Policy Initiatives Center
description: The Energy Policy Initiatives Center is a research center at the University of San Diego School of Law studying how energy policy issues affect California and the San Diego region. TheCenter strives to increase awareness and understanding of energy- climate-related policy issues by conducting research and analysis to inform decision-makers and educating law students. By drawing on expertise in law, policy, economics, and science, the Center brings together students, scholars, and practitioners within the school of law and serves the public interest.
source_proposal: 2 - Regional Lithium Cooperation.docx

name: Laboratory for Energy Storage and Conversion (LESC) at the Jacobs School of Engineering, University of California San Diego (UCSD)
description: https://today.ucsd.edu/story/one-step-closer-to-lithium-metal-batteries-that-function-with-minimal-external-pressure?_gl=1*1v06ut*_ga*Mjc1NTczOTc3LjE3MDE4MDc3NjI.*_ga_PWJGRGMV0T*MTcwMjkyNjI2Ny4xLjAuMTcwMjkyNjI2Ny4wLjAuMA The goal of the Laboratory for Energy Storage and Conversion (LESC), at the University of California San Diego Nanoengineering department, is to design and develop new functional nano-materials and nano-structures for advanced energy storage and conversion applications. Conversion of raw materials into usable energy and storage of the energy produced are common aspects of everyday life. The development of new materials to improve upon current capabilities is a key technological challenge of the 21st century. Advances will allow smaller more powerful batteries and will provide a greater ability to harness more sustainable energy sources. Our research focuses on the direct integration of novel experimental techniques with ab initio computation methods for rational materials characterization and design. A team of researchers led by the UCSD and University of Chicago has developed a new methodology to produce the potentially game-changing thin-film solid-state electrolyte called lithium phosphorus oxynitride (LiPON).
source_proposal: 2 - Regional Lithium Cooperation.docx

name: Griffith Lab, Sustainable Power and Energy Center (SPEC) in the Jacobs School of Engineering at UCSD
description: https://www.kentjgriffith.com/home Griffith Lab is an interdisciplinary research group that investigates relationships in complex energy-related materials. The goal of their work is to advance electrochemical energy storage and other functional semiconductors. Griffith Lab works closely with national and international facilities to further their work. Kent Griffith, Assistant Professor of Chemistry and Biochemistry, heads Griffith Lab, and is also founder of a fast-charging battery startup Nyobolt Limited, and a technical consultancy organization, Niobe Energy LLC. Non-Profit Organizations and Community Resources
source_proposal: 2 - Regional Lithium Cooperation.docx

name: Lithium Valley Community Coalition
description: Lithium Valley Community Coalition aims to ensure that disadvantaged communities an be represented in an equitable manner, and have a seat at the decision-making table. They strive to protect the needs of communities in Lithium Valley, and ensure the community is treated in an equitable, environmentally friendly, and community-conscious manner. Members of Lithium Valley Community Coalition include Comite Civico del Valle, IV Equity & Justice Coalition Advocacy, San Diego & Imperial Counties Labor Council, and Los Amigos de la Comunidad IV. Note: Lithium Valley Community Coalition is located in Imperial Valley.
source_proposal: 2 - Regional Lithium Cooperation.docx

name: Imperial Valley Desert Museum
description: Originally conceived as part of Imperial Valley College, the Imperial Valley Desert Museum (IVDM) as it stands today was opened in 2012. The goal of the museum is to always be actively community-focused, and showcase the Indigenous and historic artifacts found within the Imperial Valley and surrounding region. Their mission is to preserve, interpret, and celebrate the deserts of Southern California through outstanding collections, research, and educational programs. IVDM recognizes the traditional lands of the Kumeyaay, and other nearby Indigenous groups including Quechan, Cahuilla, CoCoPah, and Pai Pai. Meeting focus: Learn about the traditional custodians of Imperial Valley, to gain a more nuanced understanding of what the resource-rich Imperial Valley means to all communities connected to the space. Mining Companies, Energy Facilities, and Startups
source_proposal: 2 - Regional Lithium Cooperation.docx

name: Controlled Thermal Resources
description: https://static1.squarespace.com/static/5bbc837993a6324308c97e9c/t/651a1e606ce64165830e716d/1696210536239/CTR+Brochure_September+2023.pdf Controlled Thermal Resources combines direct lithium extraction with renewable geothermal power to set new benchmarks to provide renewable energy to the western U.S. and to deliver the most sustainable, battery-grade lithium products in the world today. Demand for lithium, which is used in batteries and energy storage systems to power cars, cities, and countries, is expected to surge by approximately 2 million tons per annum by 2030. Controlled Thermal Resources’ leadership team has successfully developed and managed world-scale renewable energy projects in the Salton Sea region for over 20 years. Note: Controlled Thermal Resources is located in Imperial Valley.
source_proposal: 2 - Regional Lithium Cooperation.docx

name: Sempra
description: https://www.sempra.com/groundbreaking-flow-battery-project-helping-advance-clean-energy-microgrids Sempra Energy is a global energy infrastructure company focused on leading the way of advancing electrification and promoting energy diversification, resiliency and affordable access to cleaner forms of energy. From its San Diego headquarters to operations throughout the Americas, Sempra Energy is making strides in developing forward-thinking energy solutions and delivering everyday power to customers. Sempra Energy believes the global energy ecosystem is going to change dramatically over the next 30 years. In advanced economies, the change will take the form of innovation and technology that improves energy efficiency and supports a shift toward new, smart renewable and natural gas infrastructure. In developing nations, improving energy diversity will be the central effort as new, smart infrastructure that supports renewables and natural gas displaces higher carbon forms of energy.
source_proposal: 2 - Regional Lithium Cooperation.docx

name: Ateios Systems
description: Ateios Systems is a battery materials innovation company started by two UC San Diego alumni. They are working to increase the speed of electrode manufacturing, to reduce carbon footprint associated with battery manufacturing, and decrease needed space to create giga factories. Recently, Ateios was awarded $2.4 million by the U.S. Department of Defense to help improve battery material performance and production, strengthening the domestic supply chain for batteries.
source_proposal: 2 - Regional Lithium Cooperation.docx

name: Statevolt
description: Statevolt’s vision is to be a leading player in the energy transition space, working towards a more sustainable future. Their mission is to ensure that American communities and workers reap the benefits of the clean energy economy, by building battery Gigafactories in strategic U.S. locations and pioneering a hyperlocal model that prioritizes sustainability and a domestic supply chain. Recently, Statevolt announced plans to build a battery factory in Imperial Valley, expected to be operational by 2025. It will be one of the largest battery factories in the U.S.
source_proposal: 2 - Regional Lithium Cooperation.docx

name: Tyfast
description: Tyfast is focused on building an ultra-fast-charging and ultra-long-life battery using the proprietary and breakthrough Li3V2O5 (LVO) anode material. This anode enables next-gen batteries to deliver 20x faster charging speed, 20x more cycle life, and enhanced safety over state-of-the-art graphite anodes while maintaining the high energy density needed to meet battery space constraints in consumer devices and mobile electrical platforms. This will enable full electrification of heavy-duty construction equipment, meaning that the construction industry will no longer rely on high-polluting diesel engines. Tyfast also envisions this technology to be used for a multitude of purposes, including smart glasses, prosthetics, and smart watches.
source_proposal: 2 - Regional Lithium Cooperation.docx

name: EnergySource Minerals
description: EnergySource Minerals is a company with a mission to deliver lithium sustainably and profitably. Leading Project ATLiS in Imperial County, California, the company excels in industrial project development and battery materials. Project ATLiS, under development in California, uses EnergySource Minerals’ ILiAD technology to unlock major brine resources. ATLiS is set to be the first geothermal brine lithium production process in the world.
source_proposal: 2 - Regional Lithium Cooperation.docx

name: Rivian
description: Rivian Automotive is an electric vehicle manufacturer, motivated to build a better future and stop the carbonization of Earth’s atmosphere. Rivian aims to create solutions that shift consumer mindsets, and inspire other companies to fundamentally change the way they operate. Rivian has signed the Climate Pledge, to reach a goal of net-zero carbon emissions by 2040, 10 years ahead of the Paris Agreement. 2023 is their first full calendar year.
source_proposal: 2 - Regional Lithium Cooperation.docx

name: Berkshire Hathaway Energy (BHE) Renewables
description: BHE Renewables, a subsidiary of Berkshire Hathaway Energy, is a leader in geothermal energy with 10 power plants in Imperial Valley. They extract super-heated geothermal brine, producing steam that powers turbines. The cooled brine is reinjected into the reservoir for a sustainable cycle. BHE Renewables contributes to the clean energy grid through Imperial Irrigation District's transmission lines, supplying power to various entities. Besides energy, they're exploring lithium recovery from geothermal brine with two ongoing demonstration projects, aiming to start the first commercial plant by 2024 pending successful outcomes. Note: BHE Renewables is located in Imperial Valley. Community Service Activities
source_proposal: 2 - Regional Lithium Cooperation.docx

name: Spring Valley Cleanup Crew
description: Spring Valley Cleanup Crew works to keep Spring Valley and surrounding neighborhoods clean and safe. Spring Valley is home to many underserved, immigrant and BIPOC residents who are forced to endure environmental racism and are not granted the privilege of living in the version of San Diego that we see on postcards and travel blogs. The Tijuana River Valley, in the Spring Valley area, has been declared a state of public health crisis due to the unsanitary and unsafe conditions entering the river, and organizations like the Spring Valley Cleanup Crew are working hard to undo human-caused damage. The Spring Valley Cleanup Crew, led by youth, utilizes social media to promote its grassroots organization. Victoria Abrenica, founder of Spring Valley Cleanup Crew, is a community leader in all things public education, sustainability and environmental justice. She also serves as a Youth4Climate Instructor at San Diego 350, which is building a movement to prevent the worst impacts of climate change and climate injustice. Activity Focus: Participate in a cleanup effort with Spring Valley Cleanup Crew, while learning how they utilize social media to promote their service efforts and community engagement, and the work they are doing for their communities.
source_proposal: 2 - Regional Lithium Cooperation.docx

name: I Love a Clean San Diego
description: As San Diego’s longest running environmental nonprofit, I Love A Clean San Diego (ILACSD) is a pioneering leader in encouraging environmental awareness close to home. Through recycling, education, and cleanups of San Diego’s most beloved areas, ILACSD is the only community-based organization dedicated to the future of the entire county – from inland to the coast. While most known for its beach cleanups, ILACSD is deeply committed to serving its mission – educating the community to actively conserve and enhance the environment. ILACSD prioritizes practical solutions rather than rhetoric, which is often seen in the variety of programs offered: Environmental Education, WasteFreeSd.org, and Community Cleanups. Environmental Education is centered on providing hands-on learning for children, teens, and adults to learn about recycling, waste education, resource conservation, and pollution control. Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown). Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $30 for one Adult Ticket for a one-hour narrated tour (south bay or north bay routes); $35 for a full bay two-hour narrated tour which covers it all: ships of the Maritime Museum, Harbor and Shelter Islands, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and more. The full bay tour is about 25 miles in length. Accessibility: The tour begins and ends at the same location downtown along Broadway Pier. Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com Price: $44 for a 1-Day Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) For 30 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours, highlighting the best San Diego attractions. The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50am – 5:00pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $26 for one Adult General Admission Ticket ($1 discount when purchased on-line). Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10am – 5pm (Last admission at 4pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside Navy Pier. Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 17 major museums and cultural institutions, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).

name: Coronado
description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year around due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown. SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $99.99 for one Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) Accessibility: A 15-20-minute drive from downtown San Diego. Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Orca Encounter, Dolphin Days, and Sea Lions Live shows and thrilling rides like Electric Eel, Manta, and Journey To Atlantis. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Hours vary by season.

name: One Safe Place North County Family Justice Center
description: One Safe Place provides free support services all under one roof to anyone who has experienced child abuse, sexual assault, domestic violence, hate crime, elder abuse, human trafficking, violent loss, family violence, or other abuse or victimization. This model has proven successful across the country and has been designated as a best-practice model for domestic violence intervention and prevention by the U.S. Department of Justice. One Safe Place is a brand new facility, where they have used the same model as Your Safe Place and made it a huge facility offering a wide range of services all in one place such as; Counseling Services, Children's Advocacy, Drop-in Childcare, Food and Clothing Assistance, Immigration Services, Job Skills Training, Referral to Law Enforcement, Legal Assistance, Parenting and Relationship Education, Spiritual Support, Victim Advocacy and Case Management, Healthcare/Wellness Advocacy. City of San Diego: Human Relations Commission www.sandiego.gov/human-relations The mission of the Human Relations Commission is to conduct and promote activities that foster mutual respect and understanding, to protect basic human and civil rights and to create an atmosphere that promotes amicable relations among all members of the San Diego community. The commission collaborates with community groups to create comprehensive educational programs addressing interracial, inter-religious and intercultural understanding.
source_proposal: 20 - Ending Gender Based Violence.docx

name: Your Safe Place: A Family Justice Center
description: Your Safe Place provides confidential and comprehensive services to people who have experienced domestic violence, sexual assault, and more. The Unit annually handles 4,000 new misdemeanor domestic violence cases and is currently prosecuting approximately 12,000 active cases. Under the supervision of one Assistant City Attorney, the Unit consists of a staff of 12 prosecutors, three advocates, three investigators, four legal secretaries, eight clerical positions and one grant analyst. Since its inception in 1986, the Unit has evolved into one of the largest and most comprehensive family violence units in the nation. Law Enforcement & Legal Resources
source_proposal: 20 - Ending Gender Based Violence.docx

name: Out To Protect
description: Out To Protect is working to eliminate homophobia in law enforcement through education and awareness, and to support LGBTQ+ individuals seeking a career in law enforcement. They provide professional development for law enforcement, and have a range of grants and scholarships available for career advancement opportunities among the LGBTQ+ community. They also offer grants and training to provide LGBTQ+ awareness in the community. In addition to professional development and trainings they offer on LGBTQ+ awareness for law enforcement, and law enforcement liaison training, Out To Protect also offers trainings on LGBTQ+ awareness for background investigators, hate crimes investigations for first responders, and more. Casa Cornelia www.casacornelia.org Casa Cornelia responds to the urgent needs of undocumented victims of domestic violence and violent crimes by providing free legal representation to assist them with their visa petitions, empowering them to leave abusive relationships, achieve economic independence, regain their self-esteem and begin a new life for themselves and their children.
source_proposal: 20 - Ending Gender Based Violence.docx

name: WRC
description: WRC is dedicated to stopping domestic violence and sexual assault, with origins as one of the nation’s first rape crisis centers. Today, their shelter has 31 beds for victims of domestic violence and sexual assault. All families in their care have access to case management, counseling, food, clothing, transportation, and more. name: Survivors of Torture, International
description: Survivors of Torture, International are the only accredited torture treatment center in San Diego, serving an estimated 38,000 survivors of torture. They provide services and care including psychiatry, social services, and more, for torture survivors, supporting them on their healing journey. Survivors of Torture envision where torture is ended worldwide, and all torture survivors have access to the care they need to heal and thrive. In addition to programs they run to support the healing process of torture survivors, they also facilitate educational programs to educate the community about torture and its consequences.

name: Indian Health Council
description: The Indian Health Council is a nonprofit working to nurture physical, mental, emotional, and spiritual wellbeing. Serving nine federally recognized Native American tribes in the San Diego region, the Indian Health Council represents several divisions, clinics and services. The Tribal Family Services (TFS) department at Indian Health Council specifically works to ensure the stability and wellbeing of indigenous children and their families. Efforts include providing culturally sensitive case management, support services, and other initiatives to keep children safe.
source_proposal: 20 - Ending Gender Based Violence.docx

name: Center for Community Solutions (CCS)
description: The Center for Community Solutions (CCS) helps more than 10,000 adults and children each year to heal and prevent relationship and sexual violence. CCS has a mission to end relationship and sexual violence by being a catalyst for caring communities and social justice. The nonprofit agency provides emergency domestic violence shelters, hospital and court accompaniment, a 24/7 confidential crisis hotline, and prevention education, as well as legal and counseling services for those affected by domestic violence and sexual assault. CCS also works with local community groups and schools to provide innovative prevention programs to promote healthy relationships and peaceful communities. Institute on Violence, Abuse and Trauma www.ivatcenters.org The Institute on Violence, Abuse and Trauma (IVAT) is a non-profit organization that works to improve current systems of care for violence, abuse and trauma victims on a local, national, and global level.  It focuses on collaborations with various partnering organizations and is working to become a comprehensive resource, training and research center dealing with all aspects of this issue.  IVAT offers workshops and training events to the public where its primary goal is to provide valuable information dissemination to improve the quality of life for those affected by violence, abuse and trauma. In addition, IVAT works in conjunction with The Family Violence and Sexual Assault Institute (FVSAI) offering professional services which include conducting child custody evaluations, psychological testing, forensic evaluations, writing reports to the court, conducting observations of interactions between involved parties, and conducting treatment of a variety of emotional and behavioral problems.

name: YWCA San Diego County (YWCA)
description: YWCA works to serve adults and children in a dignified manner to break the cycle of domestic violence and homelessness. They provide crisis intervention with immediate protection and a 24-hour crisis hotline, long and short term housing and shelter options, and advocacy and legal support including case management and mental health counseling. Visit the YWCA facility to explore how they support victims of gender-based violence, including a walkthrough of care, from short-term to longer-term options. Voices for Children www.speakupnow.org Voices for Children transforms the lives of abused children in San Diego County by providing them with volunteer Court Appointed Special Advocates (CASAs). We believe that every child deserves a safe and permanent home, and to that end, will review and monitor every court file in the system, provide a CASA to every child in the foster care system who needs one, and advocate to improve the lives of San Diego County’s foster children. Restorative Justice Mediation Program www.sdrjmp.org/ The mission of RJMP is to reduce repeat crime and improve the lives of those affected by crime through providing programs, education and services in partnership with government, non-profit organizations and businesses to San Diego County, based upon Restorative Justice practices and principles. The Restorative Justice Mediation Program (RJMP) is the active Victim-Offender Reconciliation Program (VORP) in San Diego County. Restorative Justice emphasizes offender accountability, addresses the victim’s needs, attempts to repair the harm, and seeks to bring both parties together for restitution that is mutually agreeable. Faith-Based Organizations

name: GenerateHope
description: GenerateHope is a Christian faith-based organization providing a long-term, comprehensive housing and recovery program to young women who have been sexually trafficked. Its vision is to see survivors of sex trafficking and exploitation recover from the abuse and trauma of the sex trade. To help young women to reintegrate into society, GenerateHope educates the community and works with local law enforcement and task forces to eradicate human trafficking in San Diego. It also manages the Learning Center, which provides high school education, college preparation and employment, and rehabilitation programs which sustain therapy and support to heal from the trauma of the sex trade. Meeting focus: To learn about programs which assist in personal development; to discuss medical support options for young women recovering from trauma related to abuse and trafficking. Educational Resources Reality Changers www.realitychangers.org/ Reality Changers transforms lives, schools, and communities by providing youth from disadvantaged backgrounds with the academic support, financial assistance and leadership training to become first generation college students. Reality Changers consists of three core programs: COLLEGE TOWN for selected 8th-11th graders who will become first generation college students; COLLEGE APPS ACADEMY for all 11th and 12th seeking to gain admission to college; ALUMNI NETWORK for all program graduates seeking professional connections and lifelong friendships. Round Table: San Diego County Office of Education and San Diego Domestic Violence Council

name: San Diego County Office of Education
description: The San Diego County Office of Education (SDCOE) serves 780 schools including almost 500,000 students, throughout San Diego County. SDCOE is working to reduce the percentage of students qualifying for free or reduced lunch in an effort to address income inequality and broader anti-poverty efforts. In a 2019 Youth Risk Behavior Survey, it was found that one in 16 San Diego students experience physical violence, one in 10 experience sexual violence, and one in five experience emotional violence.

The park is home to the largest concentration of Chicano murals in the world with more than 80 paintings on seven acres dotted with sculpture, gardens, picnic tables, and playgrounds. Throughout the year, it hosts festivals of music and Aztec dance, the biggest being Chicano Park Day held each April. name: Border Field State Park & Friendship Park
description: https://www.friendshippark.org/ Located within the Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve, Border Field State Park sits in the very southwestern corner of the United States, 15 miles south of San Diego. This important wildlife habitat, consisting of sand dunes and salt marshes, gives refuge to critically threatened and endangered birds such as the Western Snowy Plover, the California Least Tern, and the Light-footed Ridgway's Rail. Friendship Park is a binational park located at the western end of the US-Mexico border. For generations, people have gathered here to meet up with friends and family "across the line." name: UCSD Admissions & Aid Office
description: The Admissions & Aid Office at the University of California, San Diego is a critical component of the university, responsible for managing the admission of undergraduate and graduate students. This office plays a pivotal role in shaping the university's student body, ensuring a diverse mix of talents, backgrounds, and perspectives. It oversees the entire admissions process, from application review to final selection, and provides comprehensive financial aid services. The office is dedicated to making UCSD accessible to students from various socio-economic backgrounds, offering financial assistance through scholarships, grants, and loans. They also provide resources and guidance to prospective students, especially international applicants, to navigate the admissions process successfully.
source_proposal: 3- College Admissions and U.S. Higher Education Proposal.docx

name: UCSD Chancellor's Office
description: The Chancellor's Office at UCSD serves as the central executive branch of the university's administration, led by the Chancellor who is the chief spokesperson and leader of the university. This office is responsible for setting the university's strategic direction, overseeing academic and administrative policies, and ensuring the institution's overall success. The Chancellor's Office works closely with various stakeholders, including faculty, staff, students, and the community, to advance UCSD's mission in research, education, and public service. It plays a crucial role in fostering an environment that supports academic excellence, research innovation, and community engagement. The office also addresses university-wide issues such as budgeting, campus development, and institutional advancement. University of San Diego The University of San Diego is a private Roman Catholic research university located in San Diego, California. Known for its commitment to providing a holistic education, USD offers a diverse array of undergraduate and graduate programs, emphasizing liberal arts and professional education. The university is distinguished by its small class sizes, student-focused approach, and a strong emphasis on ethical leadership, social justice, and community service. USD's beautiful campus, with its Spanish Renaissance architectural style, provides a conducive environment for learning and research. The university is also noted for its robust international programs, promoting global awareness and cross-cultural understanding among its students.
source_proposal: 3- College Admissions and U.S. Higher Education Proposal.docx

name: USD International Center
description: The USD International Center plays a crucial role in the university's commitment to global education. It serves as the hub for international activities, facilitating study abroad programs, international student services, and global partnerships. The center provides comprehensive support to international students, including assistance with visas, orientation to life in the U.S., and ongoing academic and social support. It also works to internationalize the campus by promoting cross-cultural engagement and offering programs that enhance global understanding. The International Center is instrumental in helping students gain international perspectives, preparing them for successful careers in an increasingly interconnected world. Note: Interaction with students possible based on timing and availability. San Diego State University (SDSU) San Diego State University is a major public research university located in San Diego, California. As one of the oldest and largest universities in the region, SDSU is known for its diverse and dynamic student body, comprehensive range of undergraduate and graduate programs, and a strong commitment to research, innovation, and community engagement. The university offers a rich academic environment with a focus on both practical and theoretical aspects of education across various disciplines. SDSU is also recognized for its efforts in promoting inclusivity and diversity on campus. With its vibrant campus life, extensive extracurricular opportunities, and strong ties to the San Diego community, SDSU provides an enriching experience for its students, preparing them for global challenges and opportunities.

name: SDSU International Student Center
description: The International Student Center at SDSU plays a vital role in the university’s internationalization efforts. This center is dedicated to supporting the academic and social integration of international students into the university community. It provides a range of services, including visa and immigration assistance, orientation programs, and cultural adjustment support. The center also organizes various events and activities that promote intercultural communication and understanding among students from different backgrounds. Additionally, the International Student Center is a resource for students interested in study abroad opportunities, offering guidance and support for those seeking to enhance their education through international experiences.
source_proposal: 3- College Admissions and U.S. Higher Education Proposal.docx

name: SDSU International Mentorship Program
description: The International Mentorship Program at San Diego State University (SDSU) is a significant initiative designed to support international students in their transition to university life in the United States. This program pairs new international students with experienced SDSU students, who serve as mentors. These mentors provide invaluable guidance and support, helping international students navigate the academic, cultural, and social aspects of university life at SDSU. Note: Interaction with students possible based on timing and availability. Point Loma Nazarene University (PLNU) Point Loma Nazarene University (PLNU), located in San Diego, California, is a private Christian liberal arts university known for its commitment to integrating academic excellence with spiritual development. Affiliated with the Church of the Nazarene, PLNU offers a range of undergraduate and graduate programs, emphasizing small class sizes and a low student-to-faculty ratio for a personalized and nurturing educational experience. The university places a strong emphasis on faith, encouraging students to explore and deepen their spiritual beliefs while also actively engaging in community service and service-learning projects. Set against the backdrop of a picturesque oceanfront campus, PLNU not only provides a serene and inspiring academic environment but also focuses on the personal and professional growth of its students, aiming to cultivate ethical leaders and responsible citizens equipped to contribute positively to their communities and professions.

name: International Student Services at PLNU
description: PLNU's International Student Services is a vital resource for students from around the globe. This office assists with practical matters such as visa processing, orientation to U.S. education and culture, and adaptation to life in San Diego. It also provides ongoing support through academic advising, career services, and counseling, ensuring that international students have a smooth transition and successful experience at the university. The office often organizes events and programs aimed at fostering cross-cultural interactions and helping international students feel connected and integrated into the PLNU community. name: San Diego Miramar College
description: One of three colleges within the San Diego Community College District, San Diego Miramar College offers associate degrees, certificates of completion, and the first two years of a bachelor’s degree. Founded in 1969, and located in Mira Mesa, the college services 14,000 students annually. The College offers 70 associate degrees and 90 career technical education certificates. Partnerships with local industry and the City and County of San Diego prepare students for high demand and well-paying careers in the highly competitive labor market, including biotechnology, paralegal (ABA approved), aviation (FAA-certified), automotive, diesel and advanced transportation and energies. Miramar College is home to the Southern California Biotechnology Center, Advanced Transportation and Energy Center and the San Diego Regional Public Safety Institute, which comprises the San Diego Law Enforcement Academy and the Fire Technology & EMT program.

name: San Diego Mesa College
description: As one of the largest and most successful of California's 116 community colleges, and as the largest college in the San Diego Community College District, Mesa College takes pride in its high academic standards, its excellent programs and services, and its personal approach to helping each individual student succeed. San Diego Mesa College has various career pathways including Art & Design Performance, Business and Entrepreneurship, Earth and Environment, Education and Guidance, Engineering, Mathematics, Sciences and Health and Medicine. College Prep Schools La Jolla Country Day School (LJCDS) La Jolla Country Day School is a beacon of academic excellence nestled in the heart of La Jolla, California. As an independent school that welcomes students from pre-kindergarten through twelfth grade, LJCDS is committed to developing scholars, artists, and athletes of character. With a legacy that spans over half a century, the school prides itself on a curriculum that balances academics with arts and athletics, all within a nurturing community environment. The expansive campus is a vibrant canvas where inspiration meets opportunity, fostering innovative thinking, and a global perspective. At La Jolla Country Day, education is not just about learning — it’s about cultivating the intellectual vitality and moral clarity necessary to change the world.

name: Center for Excellence
description: The Center for Excellence is a distinctive feature of La Jolla Country Day School, designed to provide students with advanced learning opportunities and enrichment programs. This center focuses on cultivating exceptional talents in various areas, including academics, arts, and leadership. It offers specialized programs and resources that go beyond the standard curriculum, encouraging students to explore and excel in their areas of interest. The Center for Excellence aims to foster a culture of high achievement, critical thinking, and creative problem-solving. It also supports students in their preparation for college and future careers, providing them with the skills and knowledge necessary to thrive in a competitive and globalized world. This initiative reflects the school's dedication to fostering holistic development and a lifelong love of learning among its students. name: The Academy of Our Lady of Peace (OLP) College Prep School
description: The Academy of Our Lady of Peace (OLP) is a rigorous college preparatory school with an unparalleled leadership program and a variety of co-curricular activities. For 141 years, they have been educating young women in the spirit of excellence and innovation that characterizes their founding Sisters of St. Joseph of Carondelet. They follow in the footsteps of many a brilliant and dedicated educators who established a holistic view of education that included the mind, body, and spirit. Their mission is to engender a collaborative worldview in the tradition of the Gospels. Additionally, OLP has been recognized as a Blue Ribbon School of Excellence by the U.S. Department of Education. name: The City of San Diego, Sustainability and Mobility Department
description: The Sustainability and Mobility Department leads San Diego's Climate Action Plan. Centered on striving for equitable, efficient, and effective mobility choices that support all communities, the Department continuously works to facilitate innovative efforts to enhance equitable, economic, social, and environmental sustainability. The 2022 Climate Action Plan established a community-wide goal of net zero by 2035, committing San Diego to reducing the use of greenhouse gasses. Focused on interdepartmental coordination, regional alignment, and new policies and ordinances, the Department furthers the City goals for equitable, efficient, and effective mobility choices that support residents of all ages and abilities and facilitates innovative efforts across multiple City departments to enhance equitable, economic, social, and environmental sustainability. The Department is also the custodian of the City’s transition to 100 percent renewable energy through San Diego Community Power (SDCP) and the administrative oversight of the SDG&E franchise. It manages all city SDG& Energy accounts which include overseeing energy account billing and management, tracking citywide energy usage and analyzing rates and opportunities for further reduction. Shelby Rust Bus has a wealth of professional expertise in sustainable building design, mobility, local food-system programs, and climate mitigation practices. In her role as Chief Sustainability Officer (CSO) for the City of San Diego, she serves as the central point of contact, fostering collaboration among departments for the development and implementation of work plans and budgets crucial for the City's comprehensive Climate Action Plan (CAP) update. Rust Bus plays a pivotal role in leading the City's efforts in long-term planning and implementation for decarbonizing buildings and neighborhoods. With her background in community engagement, partnership building, and experience with the U.S. Green Building Council, Rust Bus is poised to ensure a just transition, supporting the construction environment necessary for building housing for all San Diegans. Previously serving as the Chief Resilience Officer for the City of Miami and CSO for the City of Atlanta, Rust Bus has extensive experience in spearheading sustainability initiatives, including clean energy, urban agriculture, health programs, waste diversion, and climate resilience. Her educational background includes a juris doctorate and master's degree in environmental law and policy from Vermont Law School and a bachelor's degree in anthropology, Spanish, and environmental studies from Wake Forest University in North Carolina.
source_proposal: 4- Proposal Sustainable Cities.docx

name: FRED - San Diego
description: Since August 2016, the City of San Diego has partnered with Circuit to provide a 100% electric micro-transit solution for residents and visitors with their program FRED. The all-electric shared vehicles reduce emissions and traffic congestion in your community, while creating jobs and promoting local businesses. At no cost to the rider, Circuit takes rides anywhere within the coverage area zone through their on-demand app by waving down drivers. People can catch a ride to and from San Diego’s favorite spots like Petco Park, Gaslamp Quarter, the San Diego Convention Center and more. Circuit has been proud to contribute to San Diego's efforts to combat climate change. With the recent approval of the Climate Action Plan by the City Council in 2022, which includes a goal of achieving net-zero greenhouse emissions by 2035, Circuit remains committed to providing innovative mobility solutions that promote healthier lifestyles and improve overall living standards for city residents.

name: Pure Water San Diego
description: Pure Water San Diego is the City of San Diego's phased, multi-year program that will provide nearly half of San Diego's water supply locally by the end of 2035. The Pure Water San Diego Program will use proven water purification technology to clean recycled water to produce safe, high-quality drinking water. The Program offers a cost-effective investment for San Diego's water needs and will provide a reliable, sustainable water supply. Pure Water San Diego is the City’s 20-year program to provide a safe, reliable, and drought-proof local drinking water supply for San Diego. The program uses proven water purification technology and is environmentally sustainable. It is also cost effective—it eliminates the need for expensive upgrades to the Point Loma Wastewater Treatment Plant. This project will provide a reliable, sustainable supply sourced from reused/recycled water, reduce the need for imported water, and divert wastewater flows away from the Point Loma Ocean discharge plant.

name: San Diego Gas & Electric, Energy Innovation Center (SDG&E)
description: SDG&E is a regulated public utility that provides energy service to 3.6 million people through 1.4 million electric meters and 873,000 natural gas meters in San Diego and southern Orange counties. Their service area spans 4,100 square miles. The Energy Innovation Center at SDG&E is a working showcase that demonstrates smart energy initiatives and green building practices, all housed in one unique setting. This double LEED Platinum facility offers visitors a venue for learning and exploring the latest in energy efficiency, renewable energy, smart grid, and alternative fuel technologies.

name: South Bay International Wastewater Treatment Plan
description: The SBIWTP is a 25 million gallon per day secondary treatment plant located in San Diego County, California, about 2 miles west of the San Ysidro Port of Entry. The plant treats sewage originating in Tijuana, Mexico and discharges it to the Pacific Ocean through the South Bay Ocean Outfall, a four and one-half mile long 11-foot diameter pipe completed in January 1999. From here you can link to various informative pages about the SBIWTP located in San Ysidro, CA. The South Bay International Wastewater Treatment Plant (SBIWTP) was designed to deal with the growing demand for the treatment of wastewater resulting in the contamination of the Tijuana River in the United States. It has been an ongoing concern since 1934 when the International Boundary Commission (IBC) was instructed by the United States and Mexican governments to cooperate in the preparation of a report on the Tijuana sewage problem. The SBIWTP can provide secondary treatment for 25 million gallons per day (mgd) average daily flows of sewage more than the Tijuana sewage system capacity but has expansion capability of up to 100 mgd. The SBIWTP was built on a 75-acre site near the international boundary in the U.S. immediately north of Tijuana's main wastewater pumping station. Resulting from the establishment of a binational interagency "Clean Water Partnership," the United States and Mexico approved IBWC Minute No. 283 dated July 8, 1990. This Minute authorized the construction of the SBIWTP. The Government of Mexico contributed $16.8 million toward construction of the SBIWTP and currently contributes $2.0 million toward the annual operation and maintenance costs.
source_proposal: 4- Proposal Sustainable Cities.docx

name: East County Advanced Water Purification Project (AWP)
description: AWP stands for advanced water purification. It's a treatment process to turn recycled water into drinking water. The East County AWP is a partnership between Helix Water District, Padre Dam Municipal Water District, the City of El Cajon, and the County of San Diego to produce a sustainable water supply for East County. The participating agencies held a groundbreaking ceremony on June 1, 2022, to launch construction. There are three design and construction "packages" to fund and complete. A fourth package focuses on water treatment byproducts. East County AWP is expected to go online in 2026. The Program uses four advanced water purification steps to produce water that is near distilled in quality. After treatment, the purified water will be blended with water in Lake Jennings and treated again at the R.M. Levy Water Treatment Plant before being distributed as drinking water.

name: San Diego Metropolitan Transit System (MTS) and SANDAG.
description: For more than 135 years, public transit has been serving the San Diego community and helping it thrive. The positive impacts of the San Diego Metropolitan Transit System (MTS) on communities have been, and will continue to be, far-reaching. There are hundreds of thousands of people inside those vehicles that depend on transit to be productive. The all-electric Trolleys and near-zero emission buses reduce burdens associated with negative environmental impacts. MTSs has a positive impact on the regional economy by assessing various aspects, including compensation, services and supplies, capital spending, consumer savings, real estate development, business benefits, tourism, cross-border transit, safety, and CO2 reduction. With plans of expectation and better reach, new developments are in motion like MTS’ Rapid 277 services– high-frequency, limited-stop routes that help move people to their destinations more quickly connecting the communities of Otay Mesa, Nestor, and Imperial Beach with the Iris Avenue Transit Center. SANDAG provides funding and planning for transit services in the San Diego region. They share public transit planning and decision-making responsibilities with Caltrans, Metropolitan Transit System (MTS), North County Transit District (NCTD), and other transit operators. Future transit service builds upon what they have today and includes investments in faster and more frequent service, new rail lines and bus routes, improvements to streets and sidewalks, new bridges and tunnels, additional rail tracks, dedicated transit lanes, and Intelligent Transportation Systems. SANDAG, in partnership with MTS, will be developing a new Mobility Hub in San Ysidro. Mobility Hubs provide people with seamless connections through multiple travel options – walking, biking, transit, and shared mobility – using world-class transportation, amenities, technology, and design.

name: San Diego Green Building Council– Tour of IQHQ Research and Development District (RaDD)
description: Tickets: $25 per person San Diego Green Building Council is a community of members working together to inspire, educate and collaborate to create a better world through better buildings. They catalyze local action to meet building industry standards for global efficiency, climate, and resiliency goals. They offer the green building tour of IQHQ’s Research and Development District (RaDD) located in downtown San Diego on the waterfront. The life science district totals over 1.7m square feet of lab, research, office, and retail space that spans eight city blocks encompassing 10.5 acres and five buildings.  The buildings are substantially complete, and each building is in the process of achieving LEEDv4 Building Design + Construction Core and Shell Gold Certification for all five buildings, in addition to Fitwell Commercial Site Certification. The all-electric buildings include rooftop solar totaling up to 5% of each building’s annual core and shell energy consumption, unique for urban life science buildings, and the district has planned one of the largest EV charging strategies for Southern California.  In addition, dynamic glass was utilized across the district to preserve the best waterfront views in Downtown San Diego. description: The San Diego Green Chamber, a Chapter of the U.S. Green Chamber of Commerce's mission is to empower businesses and communities towards long-term prosperity through economic, environmental, and social sustainability. Having sole proprietor, nonprofit, small business, and multinational corporation as members. Through networking, education, and advocacy they seek to build a sustainable and vibrant business environment. There to support and promote members interests in creating a prosperous and sustainable San Diego region. Their Approach of providing networking opportunities for like-minded business people and civic organizations, offering education in the business case for sustainability and social responsibility, advocating for sustainable business policy, and being a valued resource for those seeking to become more sustainable, the San Diego Chapter of the U.S. Green Chamber of Commerce serves as a partner in advancing a sustainable future for the San Diego region. Committed to teaching ways to lessen energy and water use, and to implement as many sustainability measures as is feasible in home and business life.

name: San Diego Tourism Stewardship Plan
description: The San Diego Tourism Authority is actively preparing the 2024-2035 update for the San Diego Tourism Stewardship Plan, positioning it as the guiding framework for the tourism and hospitality industry over the next decade. This strategic plan aims to uphold San Diego's standing as a premier destination by outlining comprehensive goals, policies, and guidelines for sustainable tourism development, management, and promotion. Inclusive of input from diverse stakeholders such as government entities, tourism boards, local businesses, residents, and community groups, the plan seeks to balance economic growth with the preservation of San Diego's unique identity. The update process, scheduled for 2024, involves extensive research, industry and community engagement, and strategic planning led by the San Diego Tourism Authority and its partners. A dedicated Steering Committee, comprising industry and public sector leaders from entities like San Diego Gas & Electric, San Diego Zoo Wildlife Alliance, Downtown San Diego Partnership, San Diego Regional Chamber of Commerce, and San Diego State University & Sports San Diego, has been established to guide this crucial initiative. The goal is to create a tourism industry that benefits both visitors and the local community, ensuring San Diego's sustained allure and enhancing the overall quality of life for residents in the years to come. Focus: Foster a collaborative and informed discussion on how the preservation of cultural heritage can be seamlessly integrated into sustainable tourism business development, ensuring a positive impact on both the visitor experience and the local community. Healthy Communities

name: Feeding San Diego
description: Established in 2007, Feeding San Diego, the leading hunger-relief and food rescue organization in San Diego County and the only Feeding America partner food bank in the region, is on a mission to connect every person facing hunger with nutritious meals by maximizing food rescue. More than 38% of food produced in the U.S. goes to waste annually, and Feeding San Diego addresses this issue by rescuing high-quality, nutritious surplus food from various donors, including farms and grocery stores. Their flexible decentralized model allows them to choose whether to keep food local or bring it to their distribution center, coordinating with local partners for efficient direct rescue from food donors. This process not only keeps the food fresher but also speeds up the time to distribution, enabling them to serve more people facing hunger. The approach involves three main stages: identifying the needs of the community using data, sourcing needed food through a combination of rescues and purchases and distributing the food in various ways based on community needs. Approximately 76% of the food distributed by Feeding San Diego is rescued, aligning with their commitment to making food rescue a pillar of their method to combat the environmental and economic effects of food waste. Feeding San Diego's impactful work aligns with the global goals of the United Nations, particularly Zero Hunger (SDG 2), Responsible Consumption and Production (SDG 12), Climate Action (SDG 13), and Partnerships (SDG 17). In recognition of their positive impact on local communities with a global reach, the United Nations Association of San Diego awarded Feeding San Diego with the SDGs Champion Seal in April 2021, acknowledging their dedication to providing more than 35.4 million meals to people facing hunger. Ocean Sustainability

name: Ocean Motion Technologies
description: Ocean Motion Technologies aims to scale ocean wave energy through lowering the cost of power at sea and enabling a new era of big blue data. The bluetech sector needs products in small-scale energy to fuel research and development needed to scale wave energy. Ocean Motion Technologies develops devices that are meant to last and reduce the cost for end users. Devices vary from the world’s first adaptive ocean wave energy converters controlled by an advanced artificial system to the world’s first compressed air energy storage system for marine applications.

name: I Love A Clean San Diego
description: I Love A Clean San Diego (ILACSD), with a rich history dating back to its founding as the San Diego War Against Litter Committee in 1954, has been at the forefront of environmental conservation in the region. Over the years, it has evolved to become a leading force in promoting zero waste lifestyles and eliminating litter. The organization engages approximately 100,000 students, adults, and businesses annually through a variety of impactful initiatives, including environmental education, volunteer cleanup programs, and recycling solutions. ILACSD's commitment to Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) is evident in its mission and operations, addressing inequities and enhancing its overall impact. Notable accomplishments include the establishment of WasteFree.SD.org, a zero-waste database and call center, as well as the removal of nearly half a million pounds of pollution annually through community cleanups. ILACSD envisions a zero waste, litter-free, and environmentally engaged San Diego region. The organization's dedication to sustainability is further demonstrated by volunteers' adoption of reusable options during cleanups, contributing to an eco-friendlier approach.
