name: Zero Waste Plan San Diego
description: The City of San Diego plans to divert all solid waste from going into the landfill through our Zero Waste Plan. The city adopted a Zero Waste Plan in 2015 with a goal to reach zero waste by 2040. Zero Waste is a principle that focuses on waste prevention, recycling, composting, and other technologies. Zero waste doesn’t necessarily mean absolutely having no waste in the landfill; it’s a continuous improvement process striving to produce as little waste or discards as possible. San Diego is now capturing the gasses from decomposition and turning them into energy. The City's recycling programs reuse materials and divert waste from the Miramar Landfill. A Resource Recovery Center and “one-stop shop” at Miramar Landfill maximizes waste diversion. The city continuously works on increasing curbside recycling and curbside greenery collection.

name: San Diego Community Power
description: San Diego Community Power is a locally run, not-for-profit public agency that is a new electric generation service provider for San Diego. San Diego Community Power is shifting control from profit-driven investor-owned utility into the hands of customers. This supports local job creation and development of renewable energy projects close to home while reinvesting revenues into the communities they serve. Allowing for more efficient responses during disasters, ensuring that the community can better analyze, manage, and mitigate the impact of disasters on the electricity supply, a critical component in disaster response and recovery. name: University of California, San Diego School of Global Policy, and Strategy
description: The UC San Diego School of Global Policy and Strategy (GPS) is an interdisciplinary, discovery-driven graduate school focusing on international affairs and public policy. We offer an original and rigorous approach to policy, as our goal is to create global policy solutions that matter. Kate Ricke is an associate professor at the School UC San Diego School of Global Policy and Strategy and holds a joint appointment with the Scripps Institution of Oceanography. She is a climate change scientist who integrates tools from the physical and social sciences to analyze climate policy problems. Central to her work is accounting for uncertainty and heterogeneity—both in the effects of climate change and in preferences for how to address them. Ricke recently served as a research associate in the Sibley School of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering at Cornell University and a fellow at the Carnegie Institution for Science. Her current research includes topics ranging from the regional climate effects and international relations implications of solar geo-engineering to decadal climate variability’s influence on international climate agreements. She’s assessed uncertainty in phenomena, including ocean acidification’s effects on coral reefs and the warming effect from an emission of carbon dioxide today. Meeting focus: Develop a deeper understanding on the impact of the U.S Federal System on environmental policy and sustainable development.

description: The San Diego Foundation is committed to enhancing the quality of life in all communities through effective philanthropy, enduring asset building, and promoting community solutions for the common good. Since 2006, the foundation has been a leader in regional efforts to address climate change, emphasizing collaborative action to reduce global warming pollution. Their "Parks for Everyone" research report highlights the disparities in park access, particularly affecting low-income and ethnically diverse communities. The foundation's Strategic Plan focuses on "Building Resilient Communities," aiming to invest in long-term solutions that ensure equitable access to nature, address the impacts of climate change, and support mental health and well-being. Additionally, the plan emphasizes skill-building and education to enable access to higher-pay jobs in a growing economy. name: Asian Business Association
description: Founded in 1990, Asian Business Association of San Diego (ABASD) represents the interests of over 30,000 Asian and Pacific Islander owned businesses throughout San Diego County. ABASD believes in building sustainable communities through inclusive economic development and a qualified diverse workforce. As part of America’s Small Business Development Resource Center (SBDC) network, and one of the region's largest ethnic business associations, ABASD offers educational workshops, technical assistance, business mentorship, advocacy, and access to capital to minority-owned small and disadvantaged businesses, entrepreneurs, and start-ups -- in hard-to-reach communities. Its programming consistently grows a unique client base through its business advisors and support staff dedicated to one-on-one, low to no-cost consulting. Civically, ABASD is among the most influential organizations countywide and is a leader in public policy and advocacy for an inclusive economy that works for everyone. ABASD is an integral part of a greater business coalition of industry associations and has built strategic partnerships with local and state organizations, multiplying its message more effectively and with greater depth. name: Urban Studies and Planning – University of San Diego
description: The Department of Urban Studies and Planning, established in 1971, is a vibrant community focused on addressing the complexities of global urbanization. With over half of the world's population residing in cities and projections indicating a two-thirds urban population by 2050, sustainable urban development is a critical concern. The United Nations' New Urban Agenda, adopted in 2016, sets global standards for sustainable urban development, emphasizing planning, design, finance, governance, and management. The department, offering undergraduate degrees in Urban Studies and Planning, as well as Real Estate and Development, recognizes the importance of educating future urban problem solvers. The department has a diverse community of students, faculty, and staff, fostering engagement through three undergraduate student clubs and affiliations with organizations such as NAIOP, the Urban Land Institute, and the American Planning Association. Students benefit from experiential learning, research, internships, and practicum experiences, focusing on various urban issues like economic development, urban design, affordable housing, sustainable development, and transportation policy. The curriculum prepares students for graduate studies or professional roles in public, private, and nonprofit sectors globally. Alumni pursue diverse paths, including graduate studies in social sciences, urban planning, real estate development, public policy, law, and healthcare. The program equips graduates with analytical skills to creatively address the challenges and opportunities of neighborhoods, cities, and metropolitan regions. Isaac William Martin, a professor and Chair of the department of Urban Studies and Planning at the University of California San Diego, is a distinguished educator and researcher with a focus on housing policy, municipal taxation, and the political economy of inequality. Recognized for his exceptional mentorship, he has received four teaching awards at UC San Diego. Martin is the author of several books, including "Foreclosed America," "Rich People’s Movements," and "The Permanent Tax Revolt." He has also edited influential works like "The New Handbook of Political Sociology" and "The New Fiscal Sociology." His articles, published in reputable journals, contribute to the academic discourse on sociology, law, and urban affairs. Martin's impactful research has garnered coverage in NPR, the New Yorker, and the Washington Post, earning him awards from prestigious associations. He has actively participated in professional societies and served in various editorial roles for prominent sociology journals. Meeting focus: Meet with academic representative to gain an introduction and deeper understanding of innovative practices in urban planning academic degree program. Community Service

name: U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) – San Diego Sector
description: The San Diego Sector of the U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) consists of more than 7,000 square miles and 66 linear miles of international boundary with Mexico. The San Diego Sector encompasses coastal beaches and expansive mesas to coastal and inland mountains, rugged canyons and high desert. Directly to the South of San Diego lie the Mexican cities of Tijuana and Tecate, Baja California - with a combined population of more than 2 million. Today, San Diego Sector is focused on addressing the continuously changing tactics of transnational criminal organizations. Due to increased land border security, transnational criminal organizations have shifted their illegal activities to include the aerial, subterranean, and maritime domains. In order to effectively protect America's borders, Border Patrol agents conduct their enforcement duties on foot, horseback, and mountain bikes, and utilize various types of vehicles including all-terrain vehicles. U.S. Customs and Border Protection's (CBP) - Air and Marine Operations (AMO) CBP’s AMO safeguards our Nation by anticipating and confronting security threats through our aviation and maritime law enforcement expertise, innovative capabilities, and partnerships at the border and beyond. The San Diego Air and Marine Branch is responsible for defending our international land and sea border from terrorists, illegal alien crossings and the smuggling of contraband. The branch provides air and marine response capabilities to the Border Patrol and Field Operations. In addition, the branch closely supports U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement offices throughout California.
source_proposal: 5- IVLP Proposal Towards a More Safe and Secure World – Cooperative Efforts in Combating Transnational Crime.docx

name: U.S. Immigration & Customs Enforcement (ICE): Homeland Security Investigations (HSI)
description: HSI is a critical investigative arm of the Department of Homeland Security and is a vital U.S. asset in combating criminal organizations illegally exploiting America's travel, trade, financial and immigration systems. HSI’s workforce includes special agents, analysts, auditors and support staff. Its men and women are assigned to cities throughout the United States and to offices around the world. HSI’s international force is the department’s largest investigative presence abroad and gives HSI one of the largest international footprints in U.S. law enforcement.
source_proposal: 5- IVLP Proposal Towards a More Safe and Secure World – Cooperative Efforts in Combating Transnational Crime.docx

name: Border Enforcement Security Task Force (BEST)
description: The primary mission of the Homeland Security Investigations’ (HSI) Border Enforcement Security Task Force (BEST) is to combat emerging and existing Transnational Criminal Organizations (TCO) by employing the full range of federal, state, local, tribal and international law enforcement authorities and resources in the fight to identify, investigate, disrupt and dismantle these organizations at every level of operation. The BEST investigative model is a comprehensive response to the growing threat to border security, public safety and national security. BESTs eliminate the barriers between federal and local investigations (access to both federal and state prosecutors) and close the gap with international partners in multinational criminal investigations. BESTs also create an environment that minimizes the vulnerabilities in our operations that TCOs have traditionally capitalized on to exploit our nation’s land and sea borders. investigations, with briefings on: gangs and weapons; human smuggling/human trafficking; marine task force; and contraband smuggling. Note: Usually, the meetings above are directly coordinated by the NPA and then loop SDDC in to arrange logistics. Border Tour *$500 honorarium required SDDC can arrange a half-day tour of the U.S.-Mexico border, with a guide familiar with border operations, policy, and issues. Stops along the tour may include Barrio Logan, Friendship Park, San Ysidro Port of Entry, Otay Mesa Port of Entry, and Cross Border Xpress.
source_proposal: 5- IVLP Proposal Towards a More Safe and Secure World – Cooperative Efforts in Combating Transnational Crime.docx

name: San Diego State University (SDSU), Graduate Program in Homeland Security
description: SDSU’s Graduate Program in Homeland Security was the first graduate-level Homeland Security program offered in the United States. It is consistently rated in the top two graduate-level national security programs. The program focuses on issues ranging from cyber security, counter-human trafficking, child slavery, counter-narcotics, to food and water security issues - seeking not only to eliminate the bad actors who create and capitalize upon human suffering, but also the economic and security conditions that allow black market and organized crime networks to flourish. The program is working hard to help create a world in which people of all nations have enough to eat, have meaningful economic opportunities, and feel safe in their homes, schools, and businesses. Dr. Eric Frost: Dr. Frost is Director of SDSU’s Viz (Visualization) Center and of its Graduate Program in Homeland Security. The Viz Center creates IT products that allow emergency responders to access up-to-the-minute geospatial (mapping) data over handheld devices, allowing them to understand and follow crisis developments in real time. The Graduate Program in Homeland Security trains leaders from a variety of fields to identify, design, and mobilize community resources to prevent, deter, preempt, and respond to terrorist attacks and other critical incidents on the local, regional, national and international levels.
source_proposal: 5- IVLP Proposal Towards a More Safe and Secure World – Cooperative Efforts in Combating Transnational Crime.docx

name: U.S. Coast Guard – San Diego Sector
description: Located within the Homeland Security Department, the U.S. Coast Guard is unique as an armed force. Comprised of active duty, reserve, civilian, and auxiliary members, it provides a broad range of services to the American people in times of peace and war. The Coast Guard manages six major operational mission programs: maritime law enforcement, maritime response, maritime prevention, marine transportation system management, maritime security operations, and defense operations. The 11th Coast Guard District encompasses the states of California, Arizona, Nevada, and Utah; their coastal and offshore waters out over thousand miles; and the offshore waters of Mexico and Central America down to South America. Coast Guard operational units are located throughout the state of California.
source_proposal: 5- IVLP Proposal Towards a More Safe and Secure World – Cooperative Efforts in Combating Transnational Crime.docx

name: San Diego Harbor Police (SDHP)
description: The SDHP operates under the Port of San Diego. It provides law enforcement and public safety services in San Diego Bay, the adjacent tidelands, and at San Diego International Airport. Participants will meet with SDHP officers to learn how this local police authority patrols both the maritime borders of San Diego and the international airport, involving operations on land, sea, and in the air.
source_proposal: 5- IVLP Proposal Towards a More Safe and Secure World – Cooperative Efforts in Combating Transnational Crime.docx

name: U.S. Attorney’s Office of the Southern District of California - Border Enforcement Section
description: https://www.justice.gov/usao-sdca/criminal-division The U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of California is the chief prosecutor for the United States in criminal law cases in the Southern District of California and represents the United States in civil law cases as either the defendant or plaintiff, as appropriate. The Border Enforcement Section is the largest section in the Criminal Division and accounts for approximately 95 percent of the cases prosecuted in the Southern District of California. BES handles a large volume of reactive cases that arise from policing the 141-mile long border between California and Mexico, six Ports of Entry, and the roughly 70 miles of coastline stretching from the U.S.-Mexico border to the northernmost tip of San Diego County. Such cases commonly include illegal entry and reentry, drug importation and smuggling, and alien smuggling prosecutions. BES attorneys try a large number of cases and also often oversee the use of investigative tools like search and tracking warrants, undercover operations and confidential sources.
source_proposal: 5- IVLP Proposal Towards a More Safe and Secure World – Cooperative Efforts in Combating Transnational Crime.docx

name: San Diego Law Enforcement Coordination Center (SD-LECC)
description: The San Diego Law Enforcement Coordination Center (SD-LECC) is the all crimes, all hazards fusion center and serves as the High Intensity Drug Trafficking Area (SD/I HIDTA) Investigative Support Center (ISC) for the San Diego and Imperial County region. The SD-LECC also serves as the Regional Threat Assessment Center (RTAC) for San Diego and Imperial counties and is part of the California State Threat Assessment System (STAS). The SD-LECC operates as a collaborative partnership among federal, state and local law enforcement/public safety agencies focused on enhancing coordination, information sharing, regional preparedness, training and investigative support/analysis for first responders and other public and private partners in the region.
source_proposal: 5- IVLP Proposal Towards a More Safe and Secure World – Cooperative Efforts in Combating Transnational Crime.docx

name: City of San Diego, Office of Homeland Security
description: The San Diego Office of Homeland Security oversees the City's emergency Prevention and Protection Program; Mitigation and Finance Program; Response and Recovery Program; and leads regional efforts for FEMA's Urban Area Security Initiative. The Office of Homeland Security strives to promote a secure and resilient City with the capabilities required across the whole community to prevent, protect against, mitigate, respond to, and recover from threats and hazards that pose the greatest risk. These risks include natural hazards such as wildfires, earthquakes, floods, and tsunami; human-caused threats such as terrorist attacks and cyber-attacks; and technological hazards such as power outages and utility interruptions.
source_proposal: 5- IVLP Proposal Towards a More Safe and Secure World – Cooperative Efforts in Combating Transnational Crime.docx

name: The San Diego Human Trafficking Research and Data Advisory Roundtable (HT-	RADAR)
description: HT-RADAR is a collaborative research environment for San Diego / Tijuana (SD/TJ) region data analysts and researchers who have skills and interests related to human 	trafficking. HT-RADAR was launched by Dr. Jamie Gates from Point Loma Nazarene University / Center for Justice and Reconciliation (PLNU/CJR) and is now evolving into a professional network. PLNU/CJR operates a centralized clearinghouse for human trafficking related research in the SD/TJ region. Meeting focus: Explore the impact of human trafficking on the local border region, and 	how research and university communities contribute to combatting TIP. San Diego County District Attorney's Office www.sdcda.org The San Diego County District Attorney's Office has the responsibility and authority to investigate and prosecute all felonies in San Diego County. The jurisdiction covers 42-hundred square miles. This area stretches from the northern areas of Oceanside and Vista to the eastern area of Alpine all the way to the US-Mexican border at Imperial Beach and Tecate. The District Attorney's Office also prosecutes misdemeanor crimes in unincorporated areas of the County as well as all cities within the County other than the city of San Diego. The San Diego District Attorney's Office is the second largest in the state of California and the sixth largest in the nation, serving a population of approximately three million people. Meeting Focus: Discuss with DA Stephan or an employee of her office efforts to combat crime in a border region, with an emphasis on human trafficking and the role the office plays in extraditions. Case Issuance/Extraditions The Case Issuance and Extradition Division is responsible for reviewing cases for potential charges, coordinating domestic and international extraditions and overseeing a number of units involving clemency, prior criminal conduct and more. Sex Crimes and Human Trafficking Division This division is comprised of a highly-trained and specialized team of Deputy District Attorneys, District Attorney Investigators, paralegals and secretaries who are all dedicated to aggressive and just prosecution of perpetrators of sexual assault and human trafficking crimes. The division strives to treat the victims of sexual assaults with compassion, dignity, and respect. Kearny Mesa Juvenile Facility *** We may be able to highlight one of the many programs run in the facility www.sandiegocounty.gov/probation/juvenile_halls.html Kearny Mesa Juvenile Detention Facility (KMJDF), formerly the San Diego County Juvenile Hall, is located in Birdland, a suburb of San Diego. It has a Board of Corrections maximum capacity of 359 and has housed juvenile offenders since 1954. All youth housed at KMJDF are required to attend school Monday through Friday. The school is called the S.O.A.R. Academy and is run by the San Diego County Office of Education.  Youth may earn credit towards receiving their high school diploma or earn their high school equivalency (HISET).  Youth who already have their diploma or HISET may also have the opportunity to participate in college level courses and earn college credit. KMJDF offer a myriad of programs that are designed to assist our youth towards rehabilitation.  Such programs include, but are not limited to, Alcoholics Anonymous (AA), Narcotics Anonymous (NA), Pet Therapy, Yoga, various Literacy Groups, Book Clubs and programs facilitated by SAY San Diego and Second Chance Programs.  Additionally, special speakers are often times invited to encourage and inspire youth, such as renowned authors, professional athletes, and community leaders/volunteers. _______________________________ Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $58 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. It is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park.
source_proposal: 5- IVLP Proposal Towards a More Safe and Secure World – Cooperative Efforts in Combating Transnational Crime.docx

name: Harbor Cruise
description: Price: $33 for one Adult Ticket for two-hour tour Their deluxe tour covers it all: Harbor and Shelter Islands, Point Loma, Cabrillo National Monument, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and much more. Tour is about 25 miles in length, 2 hour narrated tour. Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego Price: $42 for one Adult Ticket For over 20 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours highlighting the best San Diego attractions. Old Town Trolley Tours is the best way to see the city, highlighting the best San Diego Attractions, with 11 stops and more than 100 points of interest. Old Town offers much to do, from visiting over 23 historic sites to shopping for unique merchandise. They also have many award winning restaurants to choose from. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 29 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 15 major museums, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Coronado Consistently voted one of America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year around due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. From the shores of Silver Strand State Beach to the tip of the Coronado Municipal Beach, you’ll find plenty of wide open sand, gentle waves and gorgeous views. SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $94 for one Adult Ticket Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Shamu show, One Ocean, and thrilling rides like Journey To Atlantis, Shipwreck Rapids and Wild Arctic. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Then dive into the world of sea turtles at the all-new Turtle Reef attraction.
source_proposal: 5- IVLP Proposal Towards a More Safe and Secure World – Cooperative Efforts in Combating Transnational Crime.docx

name: U.S. Naval Base San Diego *Would need D.C. gatekeeper request
description: https://timesofsandiego.com/military/2022/01/24/two-san-diego-based-carrier-groups-enter-disputed-south-china-sea/ Naval Base San Diego (NBSD) is the U.S. Navy's largest base on the West Coast and the principal homeport of the Pacific Fleet. Homeport to 54 ships, the base has 13 piers that stretch over 977 acres of land and 326 acres of water. The total on-base population is 20,000 military personnel and 6,000 civilians. Naval units based at NBSD have played a major role in the Global War on Terrorism and the Navy’s efforts to relieve suffering and build partnerships through disaster relief and humanitarian outreach deployments.
source_proposal: 9 - Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: US Coast Guard *Would need D.C. gatekeeper request
description: The Coast Guard is a unique branch of the military responsible for an array of maritime duties, from ensuring safe and lawful commerce to performing rescue missions in severe conditions. Nearly 42,000 men and women are actively serving in the Coast Guard to defend America’s borders and protect the maritime environment. The Coast Guard has roles in maritime homeland security, maritime law enforcement (MLE), search and rescue (SAR), marine environmental protection (MEP), the maintenance of river, intracoastal and offshore aids to navigation (ATON).
source_proposal: 9 - Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: California Department of Fish and Wildlife
description: The Department of Fish and Wildlife manages and protects the state's fish, wildlife, plant and native habitats. It is responsible for related recreational, commercial, scientific, and educational uses. It also works to prevent illegal poaching. The Marine Region officers patrol the entire coastline of California, and up to 200 miles off the shore. Marine officers enforce commercial and sport fishing laws through spot checks on the water and on land. They work across all fishing-related fields across California including commercial fishing, regulations, ocean and inland sport fishing, and fishing licenses.
source_proposal: 9 - Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: California Coastal Commission (San Diego Coast District):
description: https://www.coastal.ca.gov/contact/#/ The mission of the Coastal Commission is to protect, conserve, restore, and enhance environmental resources of the California coast and ocean for environmentally sustainable and prudent use by current and future generations. The Coastal Commission, in partnership with coastal cities and counties, plans and regulates the use of land and water in the coastal zone. Development activities, which are broadly defined by the Coastal Act to include (among others) construction of buildings, divisions of land, and activities that change the intensity of use of land or public access to coastal waters, generally require a coastal permit from either the Coastal Commission or the local government. The San Diego Coast District stretches 70 miles from the northern border of Camp Pendleton Marine Corps Base to the Mexican border.
source_proposal: 9 - Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission
description: The IATTC is responsible for the conservation and management of tuna and other marine resources, including turtles, in the eastern Pacific Ocean. Each member of the IATTC is represented by up to four Commissioners, appointed by the respective government. The IATTC also has significant responsibilities for the implementation of the International Dolphin Conservation Program (IDCP), and provides the Secretariat for that program. Meeting focus: Learn about the IATTC role and program to protect tuna and turtles in the eastern Pacific Ocean.
source_proposal: 9 - Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) – Southwest Fisheries Science Center
description: https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/about/southwest-fisheries-science-center NOAA is government scientific agency within the United States Department of Commerce that conducts applied scientific research of national and global significance, including protection of ocean and coastal resources and environmental stewardship. Established in 1964 to study the sardine and tuna fisheries of the U.S. West Coast, the Southwest Fisheries Science Center, headquartered in La Jolla, CA (within San Diego County) provides scientific information to support fisheries management and conserve protected species in the California Current, throughout the Pacific Ocean, and in the Southern Ocean off Antarctica. Center staff work with numerous partners and NOAA Fisheries counterparts to provide sound science for national and international management decisions. Academic Resource
source_proposal: 9 - Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: The University of California Institute on Global Conflict and Cooperation (IGCC)
description: The UC Institute on Global Conflict and Cooperation (IGCC) is a network of researchers from across the University of California and the Los Alamos and Lawrence Livermore national labs who produce and use research to help build a more peaceful, prosperous world. We conduct rigorous social science research on international security, the environment, geoeconomics, nuclear security, and the future of democracy; help to educate and train the next generation of peacemakers; and strive to ensure that what we are discovering contributes to a safer world.  The Institute is based at the School of Global Policy and Strategy at UC San Diego, where several members of the leadership team and a number of researchers are on the faculty. Dr. Tai Ming Cheung, Director Tai Ming Cheung is director of the University of California Institute on Global Conflict and Cooperation and a professor at the School of Global Policy and Strategy at UC San Diego, where he teaches courses on the international relations and national security of China and Chinese security and technology policy. Among the areas of his research focus include China’s efforts to become a world-class science and technology power, and the relationship between geo-economics, innovation, and national security. Dr. Cheung is a long-time analyst of Chinese and East Asian defense and national security affairs, especially defense economic, industrial and science, and technological issues. Vice Admiral Charles Martoglio, U.S. Navy (retired); lecturer, UCSD School of Global Policy & Strategy https://gps.ucsd.edu/faculty-directory/charles-martoglio.html Vice Admiral Charles W. Martoglio, U.S. Navy (ret), is a lecturer at the School of Global Policy and Strategy at UC San Diego. Drawing on his extensive background leading large elements of our U.S. military, VADM Martoglio’s focus is on national security affairs and leadership. He spent about half of his military career in the U.S. Navy at sea in cruisers, destroyers and aircraft carriers. VADM Martoglio spent the other half of his career developing strategy and policy, fostering international relations, and conducting operations, initially for the U.S. Navy then for all U.S. military forces. VADM Martoglio is recognized as one of the Defense Department’s preeminent strategic thinkers, with proven expertise in contingency planning, international relations and operations execution. He has served in Asia, the Middle East, and, most recently, in Europe as the Deputy Commander of all U.S. military forces in Europe, Eurasia and Israel. In various capacities he has developed the U.S. Navy’s Strategic Plan, led security-related organizations through significant change, headed the planning effort for some of our nation’s most complex contingency plans, and has overseen the integration of the U.S. Government Interagency into Defense Department operations in both Asia and Europe.
source_proposal: 9 - Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: James M. Cooper, California Western School of Law
description: James Cooper is Professor of Law and Director of International Legal Studies at California Western. Since 1998, Professor Cooper has directed Proyecto ACCESO, a judicial technology transfer project funded by governments, foundations, and international agencies, raising more than $US 5 million for this initiative. He co-founded the One World Blockchain Alliance, a network that debuted at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland and has been an advisor to blockchain companies in Asia
source_proposal: 9 - Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: Training Resources Acquired Maritime Institute
description: Training Resources Limited Maritime Institute (“TRLMI”) offers over 80 U.S. Coast Guard approved courses in San Diego and Alameda and continues to provide exportable training throughout California and select East Coast locations. Their customers include Government organizations such as the U.S. Navy, Military Sealift Command and NOAA; Civilian ship operators such as Maersk Shipping, Disney Cruise Lines, and Foss Maritime; Merchant Mariner Unions such as Sailor’s Union of the Pacific (SUP) and Marine Fireman’s Union (MFOW), and thousands of independent mariners each year. The company provides training to over 4000 mariners annually, in topics that cover every aspect of shipboard safety and operation.
source_proposal: 9 - Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: Scripps Institution of Oceanography (SIO)
description: A department of UC San Diego, Scripps Institution of Oceanography is one of the oldest and most renowned centers for ocean and Earth science research, public service, undergraduate and graduate training in the world. Hundreds of ocean and Earth scientists conduct research with the aid of oceanographic research vessels and shore-based laboratories.
source_proposal: 9 - Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: Samantha Murray, J.D., Executive Director, Master of Advanced Studies, Marine
description: Samantha Murray is the Executive Director of the MAS MBC Program where she also teaches graduate courses, including Ocean Law and Policy. In 2019 she was appointed by Governor Newsom to the California Fish and Game Commission and currently serves as Vice President. Samantha has nearly two decades of professional experience and has directed ocean and water programs at Ocean Conservancy, the Audubon Society, and Oregon Environmental Council, in addition to founding a marine policy consulting business. Samantha played a key role in the design and implementation of California's network of marine protected areas, which now cover 16 percent of state waters. She served on the Marine Protected Area Federal Advisory Committee, has held board positions at Upstream Public Health and Citizens for East Shore Parks, and currently sits on the board at San Diego Coastkeeper. Meeting focus: Explore how the institute leverages research and education to improve the state of marine ecosystems and develop innovative conservation models. Discuss California’s robust network of Marine Protected Areas, how it functions, and the myriad stakeholders who implement and support it. Cross-Border Coordination
source_proposal: 9 - Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve
description: The Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve (TRNERR) preserves, protects, and manages the natural and cultural resources of the Tijuana River Estuary by focusing on research and education with compatible recreation and resource use. The Reserve encompasses beach, dune, mudflat, salt marsh, riparian, coastal sage scrub, and upland habitats surrounded by the growing cities of Tijuana, Imperial Beach, and San Diego. Critical issues confronted by the Reserve include habitat conservation and restoration, management of wastewater from Mexico, sediment management and the integration of recreation.
source_proposal: 9 - Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: Wildcoast
description: Wildcoast is an international team that conserves coastal and marine ecosystems and addresses climate change through natural solutions. They envision a society in which ecologically sensitive and globally significant coastal and marine ecosystems and wildlife are conserved, restored and sustained for future generations. They are non-profit organization who work across the United States and Mexico to conserve globally significant coastal and marine ecosystems and wildlife, conserving more than 38 million acres of ecosystems. Wildcoast is leading efforts in California to conserve over half a million acres of marine-protected area, and to put a stop to overfishing and other destructive practices like offshore drilling and deep-sea mining. Non –Profit and Non-Governmental Organizations
source_proposal: 9 - Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: TMA Blue Tech
description: TMA Blue Tech is the non-profit industry association and cluster organizer for the San Diego ocean and water technologies community. They believe in creating BlueTech and Blue Jobs by promoting sustainable, science-based ocean and water industries. They bring education, policy and technology resources together to promote innovation and economic development in the Blue Economy. They create a strong “Blue Voice” via unique events, information sharing, national and international outreach, networking, research, and workforce development. TMA BlueTech promotes collaboration in the region combined with active national and international outreach. San Diego Coastkeeper www.sdcoastkeeper.org/ San Diego Coastkeeper believes a strategic combination of science, advocacy, education, and community engagement is the most effective way to address existing and emerging water-related issues in San Diego and beyond. The non-profit organization works to locally enforce the provisions of the 1972 Clean Water Act (CWA) and other federal and state laws. The organization works to improve sewage and urban runoff policies, adopt marine protected areas, remove marine debris, reduce sewage spills, and encourage the community to participate in the state’s largest volunteer water quality monitoring program. San Diego Coastkeeper uses community outreach, education and advocacy efforts to empower thousands of San Diegans to be stewards of clean water and a healthy coastal ecosystem. Meeting focus: Discuss San Diego Coastkeeper’s diverse range of work, and specifically explore their ongoing campaigns related to offshore industrial fish farming and the Pacific Ocean Aquafarms project.
source_proposal: 9 - Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: California Sea Grant
description: California Sea Grant is a collaboration of the National Oceanic Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), the State of California and universities across the state to create knowledge, products and services that benefit the economy, the environment and the citizens of California. They work on services and policy issues including grant and fellowship opportunities for scientists and graduate students, news and library services, specialists dedicated to impartial research and outreach, and proposal solicitation and grant administration services. California Sea Grant is administered by Scripps Institution of Oceanography at the University of California, San Diego. Port of San Diego

name: Commercial Fishing
description: Commercial fishing has a long history at the Port of San Diego. The first cannery opened in 1909, and San Diego was once known as the “Tuna Capital of the World”. The Port has extensive amenities at the Tuna Boat Basin including Tuna Boat Pier, Fish Harbor Pier, Fish Market Wharf and three floating docks. The piers not only provide berthing for larger fishing vessels but are used as an area for the servicing and storage of fishing nets, lobster traps, crab traps and other related equipment.
source_proposal: 9 - Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: Harbor Police
description: The mission of the Harbor Police Department is to remain cross-trained to prevent crime on the waterfront and fight fire on the water. Harbor Police services include professional law enforcement and support staff, interacting with the public to ensure a safe and secure environment at the San Diego International Airport, on San Diego Bay and Port tidelands. Their main areas of operation include vehicle patrol, vessel patrol, dive & rescue, marine firefighting, Maritime Tactical Team (Composed of SWAT trained officers), airport patrol, homeland security and training.
source_proposal: 9 - Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: Environmental Services Department
description: The Port of San Diego is a self-supporting public benefit corporation established in 1963 by an act of the California State Legislature. The Port champions the safekeeping and environmental care of San Diego’s diverse ecosystems, stewarding the protection of land, air, and water. As champions in the safekeeping and environmental care of San Diego Bay and its diverse ecosystems, the Port of San Diego has enrolled in Green Marine, North America’s largest voluntary environmental certification program for the maritime industry. The Port’s Environmental Services Department also works extensively to protect the environment through pollution prevention, jurisdictional runoff management program and alternative hull paints, and to conserve the environment through environmental education and community outreach, and natural resources management. _______________________________ Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown). Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $30 for one Adult Ticket for a one-hour narrated tour (south bay or north bay routes); $35 for a full bay two-hour narrated tour which covers it all: ships of the Maritime Museum, Harbor and Shelter Islands, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and more. The full bay tour is about 25 miles in length. Accessibility: The tour begins and ends at the same location downtown along Broadway Pier. The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50am – 5:00pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. name: Coronado
description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year around due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown. Experience the Orca Encounter, Dolphin Days, and Sea Lions Live shows and thrilling rides like Electric Eel, Manta, and Journey To Atlantis. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Hours vary by season.

name: Academic Institutions
url: University of San Diego - Supply Chain Management Institute https://www.sandiego.edu/business/centers/supply-chain-management-institute/
description: The Supply Chain Management Institute (SCMI) at USD’s Knauss School of Business is at the forefront of developing and disseminating supply chain knowledge and industry best practices. In 1986, long before other universities recognized the need to serve the supply chain discipline, the Knauss School of Business at the University of San Diego began conducting annual forums in this evolving field. In 1999, after more than a decade of successful growth, the Supply Chain Management Institute (SCMI) was created. Today, it has earned a reputation for supporting the development of exceptional supply chain professionals who are sought after by industry and the public sector alike.The SCMI shares insights and best practices through online and on-campus graduate programs at USD, executive education classes and workshops and semi-annual conferences. SCMI provides a fertile environment for scholars, students and industry partners to collaborate and drive thought leadership, apply research and create practical solutions for the greater supply chain profession. And by supporting supply chain management students at USD, SCMI is advancing knowledge and developing future leaders.
source_proposal: Building Resilient and Diverse Supply Chains.docx

name: University of California San Diego - Institute for Supply Chain Excellence and Innovation
description: The Institute for Supply Chain Excellence and Innovation (ISEI) at the University of California San Diego provides crucial insights and education to industry partners, executives, policymakers and the greater community. The institute is focused on industry collaboration, the application of research for practical problem solving, and educating the next generation of supply chain leaders who will shape and transform the industry. ISEI is also focused on talent development, innovation, and practices and methods to drive an efficient supply chain. The institute connects industry executives and policymakers with innovative faculty research and talented graduate students to share and develop novel approaches to supply chain management. The institute works closely with industry and community partners through its education efforts, research application and knowledge sharing at symposia, seminars and networking events. University of San Diego - Center for Peace & Commerce www.sandiego.edu/cpc/ The Center for Peace and Commerce (CPC) is a collaborative effort between the School of Business Administration and the Joan B. Kroc School of Peace Studies to prepare new generations of "change agents" who develop and exercise innovative approaches for achieving the 4 Ps- people, profit, planet and peace. CPC contributes to creating new enterprise paradigms and solutions that foster peace-building and poverty alleviation, through courses, scholarship, enterprise development, active engagement with multiple stakeholders and the promotion of good governance.
source_proposal: Building Resilient and Diverse Supply Chains.docx

name: University of California Institute on Global Conflict & Cooperation (IGCC)
description: The UC Institute on Global Conflict and Cooperation (IGCC) is a research network comprised of scholars from across the University of California and the Los Alamos and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratories who produce and use research to help build a more peaceful, prosperous world. The IGCC’s focus is on challenges that have the potential to lead to wide-scale conflict, and that can benefit from global cooperation to solve. IGCC’S mission is to use rigorous research, training, and engagement to improve policies and practices in ways that help reduce conflict and improve global cooperation. The portfolio includes both traditional security issues—defense innovation, strategy and deterrence, nuclear weapons policy, and security cooperation—and emerging and non-traditional challenges such as environmental threats, geoeconomics and great power competition, and threats to democracy. In each of these areas, IGCC builds diverse, multidisciplinary research teams that analyze the causes and consequences of global conflict—and help develop practical solutions. The Institute is based at the School of Global Policy and Strategy at UC San Diego, where several members of the leadership team and a number of researchers are on the faculty. Government Agencies International Trade Administration California San Diego (trade.gov) The International Trade Administration assists and advocates for U.S. businesses in international markets, and helps global companies invest in the United States. They produce in-depth trade analyses and engage with industries on trade strategies. In addition, they work to ensure a level playing field for U.S. industries by defending against unfair trade and ensuring compliance with existing trade agreements. World Trade Center San Diego (WTCSD) World Trade Center San Diego - San Diego Regional EDC (sandiegobusiness.org) As the international affiliate of San Diego Regional EDC, World Trade Center San Diego (WTCSD) is the export-focused small business development center for the San Diego and Imperial Valley region. WTCSD cultivates a pipeline of export-ready firms, maximizes foreign direct investment (FDI) opportunities, and enhances San Diego’s connectivity to the markets that matter most. World Trade Center San Diego works directly with companies – free of charge – to help them expand internationally and grow in San Diego. In addition, they use a cohort-based model, WTCSD’s MetroConnect accelerator that equips sets of 15 San Diego companies with the resources and partners to increase international sales. In its first six years, MetroConnect has helped 95 local, small and mid-sized businesses generate a net increase of $97 million in international sales, 522 international contracts, and 32 overseas facilities.
source_proposal: Building Resilient and Diverse Supply Chains.docx

name: City of San Diego, Economic Development Department – San Diego Foreign Trade Zone
description: https://sandiego.maps.arcgis.com/apps/Cascade/index.html?appid=ebbd39240a5745a69fe339564e841280 The City of San Diego’s Economic Development Department leverages public incentives and assistance to promote community revitalization, attract new businesses, and encourage investment in local businesses so that our region stays competitive in the global economy and international trade. The City of San Diego’s services include helping companies participate in the federal Foreign-Trade Zone (FTZ) program administered federally by the U.S. Department of Commerce. The City of San Diego manages San Diego FTZ 153, handles local FTZ applications, collects annual fees and consults with firms interested in using or operating an FTZ site. Non-Profit Organizations
source_proposal: Building Resilient and Diverse Supply Chains.docx

name: ASCM San Diego Chapter
description: The Association for Supply Chain Management (ASCM) is the global leader in supply chain organizational transformation, innovation and leadership. As the largest non-profit association for supply chain, ASCM is an unbiased partner, connecting companies around the world to the newest thought leadership on all aspects of supply chain. ASCM is built on a foundation of APICS certification and training spanning 60 years. Now, ASCM is driving innovation in the industry with new products, services and partnerships that enable companies to further optimize their supply chains, secure their competitive advantage and positively impact their bottom lines. The ASCM San Diego Chapter is one of the largest and oldest of over 60 chapters strategically located throughout North America and managed by individual volunteers respected as thought-leaders in operations and supply chain management in communities. The ASCM San Diego Chapter connects you to a local supply chain and operations management network. The ASCM offers education, training and professional development, with a pulse on what’s driving growth and opportunities in San Diego County. San Diego and Imperial District Export Council (SDIDEC) SDIDEC Website – SDIDEC The SDIDEC is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization that provides regional leadership on international trade matters to the San Diego and Imperial County communities. Its 25 plus council members are international trade veterans and trade experts appointed by the U.S. Secretary of Commerce. Utilizing a unique relationship with the U.S. Department of Commerce’s U.S. Commercial Service Council members provide trade advocacy, support international trade education and promote the growth of exports from the San Diego and Imperial region through community outreach and by working with like-minded local and regional trade organizations. Incubators and Accelerators
source_proposal: Building Resilient and Diverse Supply Chains.docx

name: Port of San Diego
description: The Port of San Diego is an economic engine, an environmental steward of San Diego Bay and the surrounding tidelands, and a provider of community services and public safety. The Port of San Diego is a self-supporting public-benefit corporation established in 1962 by an act of the California State Legislature. The U.S. Bureau of Transportation Statistics has ranked the Port of San Diego as one of America's top 30 U.S. containership ports bringing in nearly 3,000,000 metric tons (3,000,000 long tons; 3,300,000 short tons) of cargo per year through the Tenth Avenue Marine Terminal and the National City Marine Terminal. San Diego Regional Chamber of Commerce About | San Diego Regional Chamber of Commerce (sdchamber.org) The San Diego Regional Chamber of Commerce is the leading political advocate for business, and the nexus of connections and collaboration amongst businesses in the San Diego-Baja region. For 150 years, the Chamber has been critical in driving the San Diego region forward. Through political advocacy on the city, county, and state level they have fought to make San Diego a place where businesses can succeed and grow while creating jobs, supporting infrastructure and ensuring that neighborhoods thrive. Globe Trade Services Home | Globe Trade Services. Import and Export. Globe Trade Services is a full service U.S. customs broker & freight forwarder, providing logistics management, warehousing/distribution, trade consulting & import/export services to companies engaged in international trade.Globe Trade is headquartered in Otay Mesa, San Diego, California approximately 2 blocks away from the Otay Mesa U.S. Port of Entry on the Mexican border. Globe Trade was established in early 2005 by Roberto Gallegos, after having spent a decade as the corporate licensed customs broker for the brokerage division of a major Japanese electronics company. In that position Mr. Gallegos, who obtained his broker license in early 1994 (license No. 1416), gained valuable experience in many aspects of international trade such as NAFTA rules of origin, maquiladora program, assembly programs, textile, reconciliations, FDA, Mexican customs, customs compliance etc.

name: San Diego Center for International Trade Development
description: The San Diego Center for International Trade Development (CITD) provides a variety of services to clients in San Diego and Imperial counties. If a firm is new to international trade, the CITD international trade specialists can help guide the firm through the complexities of importing and/or exporting to expand their operations globally through informative seminars and workshops as well as one-on-one counseling. The CITD can provide the following services: Export/Import Regulations, Export/Import Documentation, International Financing, International Distribution and Logistics, and International Market Research. name: Chicano Park
description: Chicano Park is the geographic and emotional heart of Barrio Logan, located in Logan Heights, San Diego's oldest Mexican-American neighborhood. The park is home to the largest concentration of Chicano murals in the world with more than 80 paintings on seven acres dotted with sculpture, gardens, picnic tables, and playgrounds. Throughout the year, it hosts festivals of music and Aztec dance, the biggest being Chicano Park Day held each April. name: Border Field State Park & Friendship Park
description: https://www.friendshippark.org/ Located within the Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve, Border Field State Park sits in the very southwestern corner of the United States, 15 miles south of San Diego. This important wildlife habitat, consisting of sand dunes and salt marshes, gives refuge to critically threatened and endangered birds such as the Western Snowy Plover, the California Least Tern, and the Light-footed Ridgway's Rail. Friendship Park is a binational park located at the western end of the US-Mexico border. For generations, people have gathered here to meet up with friends and family "across the line." name: County of San Diego’s Behavioral Health Services (BHS) & Live Well San Diego
description: The County of San Diego’s Behavioral Health Services (BHS) department provides mental health and substance use disorder services to over 111,000 San Diego County residents of all ages. Services are provided through 9 county-operated programs, over 300 contracts, and 800 individual fee-for-service providers. BHS offers services across the lifespan through coordinated systems of care and embraces  Live Well San Diego, the County’s over-arching vision for a region that is building better health, living safely, and thriving. The Live Well San Diego initiative brings together the County of San Diego, community partners and individuals and families to help improve the lives of all 3.2 million people living in the region.
source_proposal: Fentanyl and Other Global Public Health Challenges.docx

name: Harm Reduction Coalition of San Diego
description: The County of San Diego offers a network of healthcare providers, mental health clinicians, activists, and members of the community who support harm reduction policies. These policies include syringe exchange, and supplying Narcan, first aid supplies, contraceptives, and other products that help the community. This organization operates all throughout San Diego County on a needs-based distribution model.
source_proposal: Fentanyl and Other Global Public Health Challenges.docx

name: Syringe Services Program (SSP)
description: The Family Health Centers of San Diego offers comprehensive services to individuals who inject drugs. These services include solutions for recovery and clean syringes. This clinic has two locations; however, they operate throughout San Diego through their mobile SSP unit and telehealth appointments.
source_proposal: Fentanyl and Other Global Public Health Challenges.docx

name: County of San Diego Health and Human Services Agency (HHSA) & It’s Up to US
description: https://www.sandiegocounty.gov/hhsa/ The Health and Human Services Agency is one of four groups or divisions of San Diego County government. The Agency provides a broad range of health and social services to promote wellness, self-sufficiency, and a better quality of life for individuals and families in San Diego County. The Agency integrates health and social services through a unified service-delivery system that is family focused and community-based. Services are delivered in a cost-effective and outcome-driven fashion, and support Live Well San Diego, the County vision for healthy, safe and thriving communities. It’s Up to Us is an ad campaign developed through the HHSA about helping San Diegans talk openly about mental health, recognize signs of challenges, find local resources, and seek help. By raising awareness and highlighting local resources we aim to inspire wellness, reduce stigma, and prevent overdose. Non-governmental Organizations:
source_proposal: Fentanyl and Other Global Public Health Challenges.docx

name: A New Path
description: A New Path is one of many nonprofit organizations working to combat addictive illness in San Diego County. The organization originated from a sequence of preliminary meetings focused on Substance Abuse involving parents, Superior Court Judges, and officials from the criminal justice system during the Spring of 1999. The organization has created a structured and therapeutic treatment plan to help non-violent offenders in the San Diego region. A New Path creates recovery safe spaces and aims to educate staff, volunteers, and allies through shared stories of those affected by substance abuse.
source_proposal: Fentanyl and Other Global Public Health Challenges.docx

name: Father Joe’s Villages
description: Father Joe’s Villages under the guidance of Dr. Jeffrey Norris, the medical officer at Father Joe's Villages, the clinic has increased its medication-assisted treatment program slots by about 50 percent over the last year. These programs provide prescriptions to minimize withdrawals and cravings, catering to the rising need for treatment among those affected by the opioid crisis, including fentanyl addiction. Their operation was established in 1950 and has been serving San Diegans across the county since. Treatment Resources
source_proposal: Fentanyl and Other Global Public Health Challenges.docx

name: Mcalister Institute
description: Since its inception in 1977, McAlister Institute has evolved into a major provider of alcohol and drug treatment in San Diego County. With over 40 years of dedicated service, their innovative and effective programs have aided numerous San Diegans in achieving drug-free, self-reliant, and healthy lives. Annually, they cater to over 13,000 individuals through our 24 diverse programs. These programs cover a comprehensive spectrum of care, including prevention, outreach, intervention, deferred entry, outpatient and inpatient treatments, and sober living facilities.
source_proposal: Fentanyl and Other Global Public Health Challenges.docx

name: Veterans Village of San Diego
description: This nonprofit, the Veterans Village of San Diego serves all of San Diego County. The Veterans Rehabilitation Center is a comprehensive 224-bed facility, state-licensed for drug and alcohol rehabilitation. This center is supported through funding from the Veterans Administration (VA) and the San Diego County Drug-MediCal (DMC) program. Their center offers a Grant Per Diem (GPD) Clinical Treatment Program specifically tailored for veterans diagnosed with substance use disorders and/or mental health conditions who are also facing homelessness. Participants in this residential program engage in a broad array of services and can choose from four specialized tracks: Combat PTSD, Co-Occurring Issues, Chronic Relapse, and Recovery Stabilization.
source_proposal: Fentanyl and Other Global Public Health Challenges.docx

name: True Life Center
description: True Life Center's Fentanyl Rehab Program offers a holistic and personalized approach to recovery for individuals struggling with fentanyl addiction. Their program in San Diego is tailored to meet the distinct needs of each patient, ensuring effective and comprehensive treatment. Their services include, neurobiological integration, intensive outpatient program (IOP), partial hospitalization program (PHP) and a dual diagnosis/co-occurring disorders treatment. Academic Resources:

name: The San Diego Opioid Project
description: The mission statement of the San Diego Opioid Project, “Action against the epidemic,” describes their philosophy on the subject. This organization offers resources on the subject of the opioid crisis. Their innovative campaign aims to educate the public, with a specific focus on debunking misconceptions about the 'safe' abuse of prescription opioids and the dangers associated with them. The campaign also highlights the risks of overdose and the prevalence of pills laced with substances such as fentanyl. Finally, to further amplify the campaign and provide valuable information and resources, the Health and Human Services Agency and the District Attorney’s Office organize a series of Town Hall Meetings across the county.
source_proposal: Fentanyl and Other Global Public Health Challenges.docx

name: UC San Diego Health Center
description: Researchers at the UC San Diego School of Medicine, along with San Diego State University (SDSU) and international collaborators, have developed a prediction model to identify counties at risk of future overdose death outbreaks. This open-source tool aims to predict and prevent deaths by enabling the early deployment of public health resources. Researchers have also explored the opioid epidemic through the rise in fentanyl-related overdoses. The research focuses on understanding the patterns of fatal overdoses due to prescription opioids, heroin, and highly potent synthetic opioids like fentanyl. The goal is to develop tools for predicting and preventing overdose deaths. Finally, UC San Diego's Health Promotion Services launched a campus-wide naloxone distribution zone, providing naloxone nasal spray and fentanyl test strips for pick-up at the Student Health Services building. This initiative aims to address the significant impact of fentanyl on drug overdoses and its lethal potency, even in small amounts. _______________________________ Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants.
