name: High Tech High International (HTH)
description: High Tech High is a network of K-12 public charter schools that increases the number of students within the math and engineering workforce by serving a student body that mirrors the local community. Through the integration of technical and academic education, and a project-based approach, HTH prepares students for post-secondary education in both high tech and liberal arts fields.
source_proposal: Fostering Innovation in Media Studies.docx

name: La Jolla Country Day School (LJCDS)
description: Recognized as one of the best private schools in California and San Diego, LJCDS is an educational leader in our region, committed to offering a robust, student-centered learning experience that considers the students’ social, emotional and intellectual well-being. At LJCDS, students are challenged to identify real-world problems and design innovative solutions to effect positive change for a better world. Innovation is the thread that connects technology to the human. The school’s goal is to teach students not only how to solve technical problems but also how to determine the “right” problems to solve by employing the design thinking process. Some highlights of their innovation and technology initiatives include: Trends in education: Integrating digital learning platforms Spatial Vis App – Developed at UCSD Engineering, gamified sketching to enhance mental rotation and visualization. This app lives on students’ phones for homework on-the-go. Code.org courses and similar programming environments and lessons TinkerCAD lessonsTinkerCAD lessons These platforms shift the focus from content-delivery teaching to a coaching model. Teachers then pair that with independent projects that go beyond technical skills to train the students on project management, collaboration and communication. Partnerships: Torrey Corporate Partnership Model The unique Torrey Corporate Partnership Model connects LJCDS students to real-world problems and professionals. Since Fall 2015, LJCDS has partnered with a number of organizations to have our student design teams work on problems directly related to their field. Our student teams are experienced in various parts of the product development process and have delivered high-quality results in the following areas: Ethnographic Research, Ideation, User Testing, Market Analysis, Physical Engineering, Web & App Design, Computer Programming, Data Analysis. Teacher training and continuing education: Credentials and Online Communities Credentials from online learning platforms: SuperHi. The Computer Science Teachers Association is a modern professional membership organization defining standards, creating online geography-based communities of teachers, and aiding professional growth.
source_proposal: Fostering Innovation in Media Studies.docx

name: Classroom of the Future Foundation (CFF)
description: Since 1997, the Classroom of the Future Foundation (CFF) has united business, community, and educational leaders to create innovative learning environments in San Diego County public schools. CFF, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization, works to advance its mission by ensuring that San Diego students are prepared to thrive in a competitive global society. CFF is an extension of the San Diego County Office of Education and is known for being the convener of business, community, and educational leaders around innovation in education in our region. Moreover, CFF is a catalyst and champion for the creation of learning programs that apply proven business and technology-based practices in the school setting. CFF is also a trusted resource for school districts, and a thought leader on innovation in the classroom. GirlTECH Program www.girltechsandiego.org Hosted by the San Diego Supercomputer Center, the GirlTECH program aims to encourage young women to learn and apply computational thinking and coding skills. Through partnerships with local universities, businesses and non-profit organizations, the program provides scholarships, financial assistance and transportation assistance to girls in middle schools and high schools to participate in coding and computer science opportunities.
source_proposal: Fostering Innovation in Media Studies.docx

name: Qualcomm Thinkabit Lab – The Vista Innovation & Design Academy (VIDA)
description: The Vista Innovation & Design Academy (VIDA) is a design thinking based magnet school for sixth through eighth graders located in Vista, California. In 2016, Qualcomm worked with VIDA to transform a classroom into a dynamic Qualcomm® Thinkabit Lab™. The program has expanded from serving one classroom a year to all 250 sixth grade students at the school. VIDA’s middle school students learn circuitry, programming and inventing during their Thinkabit Lab Signature Experience, and enjoy opportunities to collaborate, build, and present their creations. VIDA engages students in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) activities relating to the real world and helps them acquire the technical skills needed in an innovation economy. VIDA’s educators can also access the free Qualcomm Learning Center, an online resource for STEM education.
source_proposal: Fostering Innovation in Media Studies.docx

name: EdGate
description: EDGate is a comprehensive educational standards management and curriculum alignment platform designed to help educators, publishers, and content providers streamline the process of aligning instructional materials with state, national, and international standards. Through its proprietary ExACT (Exact Alignment and Correlation Tool) system, EDGate enables efficient mapping of curriculum content, assessments, and learning resources to ensure coherence and compliance with evolving educational requirements. By supporting the integration of standards across subjects—including media literacy, technology, and career technical education—EDGate empowers schools and districts to deliver consistent, high-quality education that prepares students for academic and workforce success. University Education & Educational Partnerships:
source_proposal: Fostering Innovation in Media Studies.docx

name: University of California San Diego (UCSD) *Possible roundtable discussion of UCSD’s e-learning education programs as well as partnerships with K-12 students, educators, and professionals.
description: The University of California, San Diego (UC San Diego) is a globally recognized research institution located in the coastal community of La Jolla. Consistently ranked among the top 15 research universities worldwide, UC San Diego is home to six undergraduate colleges, five academic divisions, and five professional schools. Its emphasis on innovation and interdisciplinary collaboration is exemplified by its partnership with VirBela to support virtual distance learning initiatives such as the International Micro-MBA Program. The campus also hosts the California Institute for Telecommunications and Information Technology (Qualcomm Institute), a hub for emerging technology research and digital learning. Within UC San Diego Extension, Sally Ride Science leads dynamic K–12 STEAM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, and Math) education efforts. Programs include the Sally Ride Science Junior Academy, professional development for educators, and online learning through UCTV, all coordinated in partnership with the Scripps Institution of Oceanography and the San Diego Supercomputer Center. Sally Ride Science also promotes representation in science through initiatives highlighting women scientists across the University of California system.
source_proposal: Fostering Innovation in Media Studies.docx

name: San Diego State University – School of Journalism and Media Studies
description: The School of Journalism and Media Studies (JMS) at San Diego State University is a nationally recognized program that prepares students for careers in journalism, public relations, advertising, and media production. With a strong emphasis on ethics and digital innovation, JMS blends academic rigor with hands-on experience to equip students for a rapidly evolving media landscape. The school maintains partnerships with prominent local and national media organizations—including Univision, Entravision, inewsource, and the San Diego Press Club—to offer students practical experience and professional mentorship. In addition, JMS collaborates with community organizations such as NALEO Educational Fund to support civic engagement and multicultural media initiatives. The program also integrates First Amendment education and media literacy into its curriculum, emphasizing the role of journalism in democratic societies. Governmental Resources:
source_proposal: Fostering Innovation in Media Studies.docx

name: San Diego County Office of Education - Educational Technology
description: The San Diego County Office of Education (SDCOE) – Educational Technology Department plays a leading role in supporting more than 40 school districts across the county in the effective use of technology to transform teaching and learning. SDCOE provides professional learning opportunities, instructional coaching, and strategic planning resources that help educators integrate digital tools in meaningful, student-centered ways. Its focus areas include digital literacy, personalized learning, digital citizenship, and equitable access to educational technology. By working closely with teachers, administrators, and community partners, SDCOE helps schools create engaging, future-ready classrooms that equip students with the skills needed to thrive in the 21st century. Youth Engagement
source_proposal: Fostering Innovation in Media Studies.docx

name: Poltifest
description: Politifest San Diego is an annual public affairs summit organized by Voice of San Diego, a nonprofit news organization dedicated to investigative journalism and civic engagement. Held at the University of San Diego’s Joan B. Kroc School of Peace Studies, Politifest serves as a platform for informed discussions on pressing local and national issues. The event features debates, panels, and interviews with elected officials, candidates, journalists, and community leaders, providing attendees with a comprehensive understanding of the political landscape. Past topics have included housing, homelessness, crisis preparedness, and electoral processes .
source_proposal: Fostering Innovation in Media Studies.docx

name: Outside the Lens
description: Outside The Lens (OTL) is a San Diego–based nonprofit media arts organization dedicated to empowering youth through creative media education and workforce development. Serving over 27,000 youth annually, OTL offers hands-on programs in filmmaking, photography, and digital storytelling that foster technical skills, self-expression, and career readiness. Through partnerships with schools, community organizations, and industry professionals, OTL provides a supportive environment where young people can explore media arts, develop leadership skills, and gain access to professional opportunities in the creative economy. Youth Campaigns youthcampaigns.org Youth Campaigns, a non-profit organization based in San Diego, strives to change the culture of communities by equipping young people with the tools to become leaders in the “innovation economy.” The organization aims to create access, awareness, and opportunities for talented  youth by providing a pipeline to a career in digital media. Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown). Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $30 for one Adult Ticket for a one-hour narrated tour (south bay or north bay routes); $35 for a full bay two-hour narrated tour which covers it all: ships of the Maritime Museum, Harbor and Shelter Islands, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and more. The full bay tour is about 25 miles in length. Accessibility: The tour begins and ends at the same location downtown along Broadway Pier. Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com Price: $44 for a 1-Day Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) For 30 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours, highlighting the best San Diego attractions. The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50am – 5:00pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $26 for one Adult General Admission Ticket ($1 discount when purchased on-line). Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10am – 5pm (Last admission at 4pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside Navy Pier. Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 17 major museums and cultural institutions, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).

name: Coronado
description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year around due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown. SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $99.99 for one Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) Accessibility: A 15-20-minute drive from downtown San Diego. Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Orca Encounter, Dolphin Days, and Sea Lions Live shows and thrilling rides like Electric Eel, Manta, and Journey To Atlantis. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Hours vary by season.

name: City of San Diego Human Relations Commission
description: The mission of the Human Relations Commission (HRC) aims to promote activities that foster understanding, respect, and inclusion in San Diego. The HRC believes in protecting basic Human and Civil Rights, while ensuring that San Diegans have the resources available to make positive impacts in their lives. The HRC includes some of the region's most talented and community-focused volunteers that San Diego has to offer. As an advisory commission to the Mayor and City Council, the HRC is empowered to collaborate with civic institutions, educate the public, investigate policy to make our city better, advocate on issues to the Mayor and Council, and mediate disputes of discrimination, exclusion, and bias in the City of San Diego. Roundtable Discussion
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness (1).docx

name: Leon L. Williams San Diego County Human Relations Commission
description: The San Diego County Human Relations Commission (HRC) works to promote positive human relations, respect, and the integrity of every individual regardless of gender, religion, culture, ethnicity, sexual orientation, age, or citizenship status. They carry this work out through strategic goals including fostering healthy relationships, how to become a liaison in civil peace, communicating with and to the public, and more. Their goals and strategic areas aim to increase accessibility and transparency in county government to make better use of resources for community advocacy. They are also working to create safe spaces for the community to host difficult conversations to promote positive human relations and development. Adeem Ismaeil Employment Training Supervisor, International Rescue Committee San Diego County HRC Member The International Rescue Committee helps people affected by humanitarian crises to survive, recover, and rebuild their lives. As Employment Training Supervisor, Adeem is responsible for supporting new Americans in their search for suitable employment, and ensuring that they receive adequate training to enter the workforce. She will predominantly join this conversation as a representative of HRC. Jordan Harrison Inclusion, Diversity & Equity Senior Manager, Vertex Pharmaceuticals
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness (1).docx

name: San Diego County HRC Member
description: Jordan Harrison is an educator working to transform antiqued systems and the inequities that stem from injustice. He is committed to changing the outcomes of low-income, underrepresented and first-generation students from under-served communities worldwide and across different contexts. Jordan will predominantly join this conversation as a representative of HRC. Think Tanks and Community Resources
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness (1).docx

name: Engage San Diego
description: Engage San Diego is a collaborative network of social-justice focused, non-profit groups working to increase civic and voter engagement in historically and systemically excluded communities of San Diego County. Engage San Diego table members are established and effective civic engagement and social change organizations with deep roots in the neighborhoods they serve. They envision a San Diego where the electorate and leadership are reflective of the community.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness (1).docx

name: Interfaith Committee for Worker Justice (IWJ) of San Diego County
description: IWJSD is an affiliate of Interfaith Worker Justice (IWJ), a national network that builds collective power by advancing the rights of workers through unions, worker centers, and other expressions of the labor movement and by engaging diverse faith communities and allies in joint action, from grassroots organizing to shaping policy at the local, state and national levels. The mission of IWJSD aims to advocate, educate, and empower workers, congregations, and communities in support of policies, legislation, and actions that sustain workers’ lives with dignity.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness (1).docx

name: PANA – Partnership for the Advancement of New Americans
description: PANA fights to advance the full economic, social & civic inclusion of refugees in the San Diego region, throughout California, and across the country. A research, public policy, and community organizing hub, PANA is founded, led, and staffed by refugees and is uniquely situated to use relational organizing to bring the community into a pathway of ongoing engagement and indigenous community leadership development.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness (1).docx

name: San Diego Gateway to College and Career, San Diego Workforce Partnership
description: The San Diego Gateway to College and Career program provides young adults who identify as immigrant, refugee and/or English language learner (ELL) with high-touch and intensive support, stipends and paid internships. Recognizing the strength of their diverse ethnicities and languages, students are also supported to achieve their language learning goals, no matter what language they speak. This program offers help in removing barriers to success, finding what career is right, finding a long-term job, starting school, and learning new job skills. Advocacy and Policy Resources
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness (1).docx

name: San Diego African American Museum of Fine Arts
description: The San Diego African American Museum of Fine Arts (SDAAMFA) works to present and preserve the art of African Americans globally and to broaden the knowledge and understanding of the visual arts in Southern California generally and San Diego specifically by collecting, preserving and displaying works of art by and about African Americans; by creating and hosting quality traveling exhibitions; by collecting and preserving fine art and by developing and helping to foster an appreciation of art through meaningful public programs, symposia, and other educational programs. Meeting focus: Examine the historical context of art by African Americans that has been preserved throughout history including key periods during Civil Rights Movements. We propose a roundtable discussion, or half-day session with Alliance San Diego to explore the many facets of their work.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness (1).docx

name: Alliance San Diego, San Diego Immigrants’ Rights Consortium & Southern Border Communities Coalition
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness (1).docx

name: https://www.immigrantsandiego.org/
description: Alliance San Diego is a non-profit, non-partisan 501(c)(3) community organization whose mission is to provide a means for diverse individuals and organizations to share information, collaborate on issues and mobilize for change in the pursuit of social justice, especially in low-income communities and communities of color. They seek to mobilize communities through: leadership development, policy advocacy, communication strategies, and civic engagement. They focus on human rights initiatives, inclusive democracy, educational equity, and tax reform. In 2007, Alliance San Diego founded the San Diego Immigrants’ Rights Consortium (SDIRC) which aims to support comprehensive immigration reform, prevent the spread of local policies that violate immigrant’s human rights, and educate immigrants about their rights, as well as enlighten the public about the important contributions immigrants offer to the community. Alliance San Diego also founded the Southern Border Communities Coalition (SBCC) which brings together more than 60 organizations from the southern border region to promote policies and solutions that improve the quality of life of border residents. Nonprofit Organizations
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness (1).docx

name: Horn of Africa
description: Horn of Africa is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization promoting the successful integration and physical and emotional health of the East African refugee population in San Diego, the largest in California and the second-largest nationwide. Focused on  empowering African refugees in San Diego to become productive members of their new communities and achieve self-sufficiency while preserving and promoting their dignity.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness (1).docx

name: San Diego Pride
description: https://sdpride.org/fernando-lopez/ San Diego Pride is a dynamic 501(c)3 non-profit organization that organizes the annual San Diego Pride parade, provides LGBTQ+ educational training, and offers LGBTQ+ programs in a variety of areas including sports, youth, art, and accessibility. Their mission is to foster pride, equality, and respect for all lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender communities locally, nationally, and globally. In addition to their annual festivities, San Diego Pride has donated more than $3 million dollars to LGBTQ-serving nonprofits and runs multiple year-round education, advocacy, and community service programs. They also offer training on cultural humility, inclusivity and skills, and provide resources for the community to remain civically active. Fernando Zweifach López Jr is the Executive Director for San Diego LGBT Pride, and a local leader with extensive experience in advocacy, nonprofit management, public education, diversity consulting, media relations, and organizing. Meeting focus: Participate in a workshop with San Diego Pride to learn about some of their most effective advocacy and outreach initiatives to grow into one of the leading Pride centers in the U.S., and brainstorm strategies that visitors can use to recreate similar success arcs with their home communities.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness (1).docx

name: North San Diego County National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP)
description: Founded in 1909, the NAACP is the nation's oldest and largest civil rights organization.The NAACP’s principal objective is to ensure the political, educational, social and economic equality of minority citizens of the United States and eliminate race prejudice. This mission is accomplished by seeking the enactment and enforcement of federal, state and local laws securing civil rights, and by informing the public of the adverse effects of racial discrimination. From school desegregation, fair housing, employment and voter registration to health and equal economic opportunity, the NAACP is working successfully with allies of all races and plays a significant role in establishing legal precedents in order to improve the quality of life of America’s downtrodden. Volunteer Activities
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness (1).docx

name: San Diego Rescue Mission
description: Serving San Diego County at multiple locations, the San Diego Rescue Mission helps to restore the lives of people experiencing homelessness, abuse, poverty or addiction through faith-based emergency services, residential rehabilitation programs, children’s services, hunger relief efforts and community outreach. They have been providing meals, shelter, clothing, education and job-skills training for unhoused people throughout San Diego since 1955. Meeting focus: Volunteer for a dinner service or similar volunteer opportunity with the San Diego Rescue Mission to support San Diego’s unhoused population.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness (1).docx

name: Kitchens for Good
description: Kitchens for Good is a 501(c)(3) and social enterprise with the mission to break the cycles of food waste, hunger, and poverty through innovative solutions in workforce training, healthy food production, and social enterprise. Kitchens for Good bridges the gap between wasted food and hunger by rescuing surplus and cosmetically imperfect food from wholesalers and farmers and engaging students in a culinary apprenticeship program to transform these ingredients into nutritious meals for hungry families. This approach addresses the most immediate need of hunger by feeding the food lines, but also helps to shorten the line itself by giving unemployed people the skills to become self-sufficient. Through the power of kitchens and cooking, Kitchens for Good students transform their lives from one of addiction, incarceration, homelessness, and unemployment, to lives of stability, employment, and a brighter future. Meeting focus: Participate in a volunteer activity at the Kitchens for Good food preparation site and learn more about the work that Kitchens for Good does with and for the San Diego community. Academic Resources
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness (1).docx

name: University of San Diego (USD), Joan B. Kroc Institute for Peace and Justice (IPJ) – Violence, Inequality and Power (VIP) Lab
description: The Joan B. Kroc IPJ’s mission is to end cycles of violence in ways that advance justice for all through learning that is deeply grounded in the lived experience of peacemakers around the world and that is made rigorous by our place within a university ecosystem. The Violence, Inequality and Power (VIP) Lab fosters collaborations that question the status quo, that use bridging language, and that expand access to nuanced knowledge and discussion. The VIP Lab aims to deliver practical, actionable ideas that partners can implement at the systems level to confront harmful power inequalities and reduce violence.

name: Point Loma Nazarene University Center for Justice & Reconciliation
description: Point Loma Nazarene University’s (PLNU) Center for Justice & Reconciliation works to remove barriers through education, advocacy, and innovation, to work towards a world free from oppression and exploitation. They host many programs to implement their core values, including the kNOw MORE! Human Trafficking Prevention Program. kNOw MORE! is a drama-based and student-centered human trafficking awareness and prevention curriculum, for middle school- and high school-aged youth in San Diego County. name: Friendship Park / El Parque de la Amistad
description: A historic meeting place on the US-Mexico border, overlooking the Pacific Ocean. name: Presidio Park
description: Presidio Park in San Diego is a tranquil historical site with remnants of the city's original Spanish settlement, offering visitors a chance to step back in time. The Serra Museum within the park provides a deeper understanding of the area's history, while the park's botanical garden and picnic areas invite relaxation. Its elevated location provides a scenic view of San Diego, making it a favorite spot for those seeking a quiet escape, historical insights, or outdoor respite in a peaceful setting.

description: Engage San Diego is a collaborative network of social-justice focused, non-profit groups working to increase civic and voter engagement in historically and systemically excluded communities of San Diego County. Engage San Diego table members are established and effective civic engagement and social change organizations with deep roots in the neighborhoods they serve. They envision a San Diego where the electorate and leadership are reflective of the community.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness.docx

name: Interfaith Committee for Worker Justice (IWJ) of San Diego County
description: IWJSD is an affiliate of Interfaith Worker Justice (IWJ), a national network that builds collective power by advancing the rights of workers through unions, worker centers, and other expressions of the labor movement and by engaging diverse faith communities and allies in joint action, from grassroots organizing to shaping policy at the local, state and national levels. The mission of IWJSD aims to advocate, educate, and empower workers, congregations, and communities in support of policies, legislation, and actions that sustain workers’ lives with dignity.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness.docx

name: PANA – Partnership for the Advancement of New Americans
description: PANA fights to advance the full economic, social & civic inclusion of refugees in the San Diego region, throughout California, and across the country. A research, public policy, and community organizing hub, PANA is founded, led, and staffed by refugees and is uniquely situated to use relational organizing to bring the community into a pathway of ongoing engagement and indigenous community leadership development.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness.docx

name: San Diego Gateway to College and Career, San Diego Workforce Partnership
description: The San Diego Gateway to College and Career program provides young adults who identify as immigrant, refugee and/or English language learner (ELL) with high-touch and intensive support, stipends and paid internships. Recognizing the strength of their diverse ethnicities and languages, students are also supported to achieve their language learning goals, no matter what language they speak. This program offers help in removing barriers to success, finding what career is right, finding a long-term job, starting school, and learning new job skills. Advocacy and Policy Resources
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness.docx

name: San Diego African American Museum of Fine Arts
description: The San Diego African American Museum of Fine Arts (SDAAMFA) works to present and preserve the art of African Americans globally and to broaden the knowledge and understanding of the visual arts in Southern California generally and San Diego specifically by collecting, preserving and displaying works of art by and about African Americans; by creating and hosting quality traveling exhibitions; by collecting and preserving fine art and by developing and helping to foster an appreciation of art through meaningful public programs, symposia, and other educational programs. Meeting focus: Examine the historical context of art by African Americans that has been preserved throughout history including key periods during Civil Rights Movements. We propose a roundtable discussion, or half-day session with Alliance San Diego to explore the many facets of their work.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness.docx

name: Alliance San Diego, San Diego Immigrants’ Rights Consortium & Southern Border Communities Coalition
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness.docx

name: https://www.immigrantsandiego.org/
description: Alliance San Diego is a non-profit, non-partisan 501(c)(3) community organization whose mission is to provide a means for diverse individuals and organizations to share information, collaborate on issues and mobilize for change in the pursuit of social justice, especially in low-income communities and communities of color. They seek to mobilize communities through: leadership development, policy advocacy, communication strategies, and civic engagement. They focus on human rights initiatives, inclusive democracy, educational equity, and tax reform. In 2007, Alliance San Diego founded the San Diego Immigrants’ Rights Consortium (SDIRC) which aims to support comprehensive immigration reform, prevent the spread of local policies that violate immigrant’s human rights, and educate immigrants about their rights, as well as enlighten the public about the important contributions immigrants offer to the community. Alliance San Diego also founded the Southern Border Communities Coalition (SBCC) which brings together more than 60 organizations from the southern border region to promote policies and solutions that improve the quality of life of border residents. Nonprofit Organizations
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness.docx

name: Horn of Africa
description: Horn of Africa is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization promoting the successful integration and physical and emotional health of the East African refugee population in San Diego, the largest in California and the second-largest nationwide. Focused on  empowering African refugees in San Diego to become productive members of their new communities and achieve self-sufficiency while preserving and promoting their dignity.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness.docx

name: San Diego Pride
description: https://sdpride.org/fernando-lopez/ San Diego Pride is a dynamic 501(c)3 non-profit organization that organizes the annual San Diego Pride parade, provides LGBTQ+ educational training, and offers LGBTQ+ programs in a variety of areas including sports, youth, art, and accessibility. Their mission is to foster pride, equality, and respect for all lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender communities locally, nationally, and globally. In addition to their annual festivities, San Diego Pride has donated more than $3 million dollars to LGBTQ-serving nonprofits and runs multiple year-round education, advocacy, and community service programs. They also offer training on cultural humility, inclusivity and skills, and provide resources for the community to remain civically active. Fernando Zweifach López Jr is the Executive Director for San Diego LGBT Pride, and a local leader with extensive experience in advocacy, nonprofit management, public education, diversity consulting, media relations, and organizing. Meeting focus: Participate in a workshop with San Diego Pride to learn about some of their most effective advocacy and outreach initiatives to grow into one of the leading Pride centers in the U.S., and brainstorm strategies that visitors can use to recreate similar success arcs with their home communities.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness.docx

name: North San Diego County National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP)
description: Founded in 1909, the NAACP is the nation's oldest and largest civil rights organization.The NAACP’s principal objective is to ensure the political, educational, social and economic equality of minority citizens of the United States and eliminate race prejudice. This mission is accomplished by seeking the enactment and enforcement of federal, state and local laws securing civil rights, and by informing the public of the adverse effects of racial discrimination. From school desegregation, fair housing, employment and voter registration to health and equal economic opportunity, the NAACP is working successfully with allies of all races and plays a significant role in establishing legal precedents in order to improve the quality of life of America’s downtrodden. Volunteer Activities
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness.docx

name: San Diego Rescue Mission
description: Serving San Diego County at multiple locations, the San Diego Rescue Mission helps to restore the lives of people experiencing homelessness, abuse, poverty or addiction through faith-based emergency services, residential rehabilitation programs, children’s services, hunger relief efforts and community outreach. They have been providing meals, shelter, clothing, education and job-skills training for unhoused people throughout San Diego since 1955. Meeting focus: Volunteer for a dinner service or similar volunteer opportunity with the San Diego Rescue Mission to support San Diego’s unhoused population.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness.docx

name: Kitchens for Good
description: Kitchens for Good is a 501(c)(3) and social enterprise with the mission to break the cycles of food waste, hunger, and poverty through innovative solutions in workforce training, healthy food production, and social enterprise. Kitchens for Good bridges the gap between wasted food and hunger by rescuing surplus and cosmetically imperfect food from wholesalers and farmers and engaging students in a culinary apprenticeship program to transform these ingredients into nutritious meals for hungry families. This approach addresses the most immediate need of hunger by feeding the food lines, but also helps to shorten the line itself by giving unemployed people the skills to become self-sufficient. Through the power of kitchens and cooking, Kitchens for Good students transform their lives from one of addiction, incarceration, homelessness, and unemployment, to lives of stability, employment, and a brighter future. Meeting focus: Participate in a volunteer activity at the Kitchens for Good food preparation site and learn more about the work that Kitchens for Good does with and for the San Diego community. Academic Resources
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness.docx

name: University of San Diego (USD), Joan B. Kroc Institute for Peace and Justice (IPJ) – Violence, Inequality and Power (VIP) Lab
description: The Joan B. Kroc IPJ’s mission is to end cycles of violence in ways that advance justice for all through learning that is deeply grounded in the lived experience of peacemakers around the world and that is made rigorous by our place within a university ecosystem. The Violence, Inequality and Power (VIP) Lab fosters collaborations that question the status quo, that use bridging language, and that expand access to nuanced knowledge and discussion. The VIP Lab aims to deliver practical, actionable ideas that partners can implement at the systems level to confront harmful power inequalities and reduce violence.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness.docx

name: Point Loma Nazarene University Center for Justice & Reconciliation
description: Point Loma Nazarene University’s (PLNU) Center for Justice & Reconciliation works to remove barriers through education, advocacy, and innovation, to work towards a world free from oppression and exploitation. They host many programs to implement their core values, including the kNOw MORE! Human Trafficking Prevention Program. kNOw MORE! is a drama-based and student-centered human trafficking awareness and prevention curriculum, for middle school- and high school-aged youth in San Diego County.  This program was developed based on the pedagogical understanding that students best respond to and retain experiences gained through interaction and creative mediums. ______________________________________________________________ Culture Activities: San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $67 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness.docx

name: Chicano Park
description: Chicano Park is the geographic and emotional heart of Barrio Logan, located in Logan Heights, San Diego's oldest Mexican-American neighborhood. The park is home to the largest concentration of Chicano murals in the world with more than 80 paintings on seven acres dotted with sculpture, gardens, picnic tables and playgrounds. Throughout the year, it hosts festivals of music and Aztec dance, the biggest being Chicano Park Day held each April. Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $30 for one Adult Ticket for a one-hour narrated tour (south bay or north bay routes); $35 for a full bay two-hour narrated tour which covers it all: ships of the Maritime Museum, Harbor and Shelter Islands, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and more. The full bay tour is about 25 miles in length. Accessibility: The tour begins and ends at the same location downtown along Broadway Pier. Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com Price: $44 for a 1-Day Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) For 30 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours, highlighting the best San Diego attractions. The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50 am – 5:00 pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $26 for one Adult General Admission Ticket ($1 discount when purchased on-line). Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10am – 5pm (Last admission at 4pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside Navy Pier. Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 17 major museums and cultural institutions, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness.docx

name: Coronado
description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year around due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. (Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown.) SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $99.99 for one Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Orca Encounter, Dolphin Days, and Sea Lions Live shows and thrilling rides like Electric Eel, Manta, and Journey To Atlantis. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Hours vary by season. Also enjoy the opening of Sesame Place in March 2022, a Sesame Street themed section of the park with new water, ride, and musical attractions. Accessibility: A 15-20-minute drive from downtown San Diego.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness.docx

name: Friendship Park / El Parque de la Amistad
description: A historic meeting place on the US-Mexico border, overlooking the Pacific Ocean.  For generations people of good will from both nations have gathered here to visit with family and friends "across the line.” *Please note, although visitors can see Friendship Park on Friday from outside the gates, access to the park is only open on Saturday and Sunday from 10:00 am – 2:00 pm.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness.docx

name: Presidio Park
description: Presidio Park in San Diego is a tranquil historical site with remnants of the city's original Spanish settlement, offering visitors a chance to step back in time. The Serra Museum within the park provides a deeper understanding of the area's history, while the park's botanical garden and picnic areas invite relaxation. Its elevated location provides a scenic view of San Diego, making it a favorite spot for those seeking a quiet escape, historical insights, or outdoor respite in a peaceful setting.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights Advocacy and Awareness.docx

name: David Victor, PhD - University of California, San Diego
description: Dr. David Victor is a professor of innovation and public policy at the School of Global Policy and Strategy at UC San Diego. He is the Co-Director of the campus-wide Deep Decarbonization Initiative which focuses on real world strategies for bringing the world to nearly zero emissions of warming gasses. His research is at the intersection of climate change science and policy. He authored Global Warming Gridlock which explains why the world hasn’t made much diplomatic progress on the problem of climate change while also exploring new strategies that would be more effective. In 2016, Dr. Victor was appointed Co-Chair, The Brookings Institution’s Initiative on Energy and Climate. He is a member of the World Economic Forum’s Global Future Council on Energy, where his work focuses on the role of natural gas as a transition fuel to deep decarbonization. Organizations/Businesses in San Diego County Archi’s Acres – Colin Archipley About Us – Archis Acres Archi's Acres is a USDA certified HydroOrganic farming enterprise headquartered in Escondido California.It provides business ownership opportunities for veterans and creates a viable, sustainable, organic produce farming business using hydroponic technology. The enterprise seeks to continuously meet their two main objectives; creating a viable sustainable organic produce farming business, and developing a business that provides entrepreneur opportunities for veterans in sustainable organic agriculture. Archi’s methods of crop production are not only highly efficient, they also maximize available natural resources, and capitalize on local sales distribution channels. They have partnered with the University of Minnesota Crookston to create a fully accredited agricultural certificate program. The six-week program is designed to introduce students from propagation to market, to include food safety and good agricultural practices. Meeting focus: Analyze the methods used to bolster economic growth through a facilitation of the small business ownership process in the farming industry with an emphasis in sustainable crop production
source_proposal: IVLP proposal for Environmental engagement.docx

name: Controlled Thermal Resources
description: Controlled Thermal Resources combines direct lithium extraction with renewable geothermal power to set new benchmarks to provide renewable energy to the western U.S. and to deliver the most sustainable, battery-grade lithium products in the world today. Demand for lithium, which is used in batteries and energy storage systems to power cars, cities, and countries, is expected to surge by approximately 2 million tons per annum by 2030. Controlled Thermal Resources’ leadership team has successfully developed and managed world-scale renewable energy projects in the Salton Sea region for over 20 years.
source_proposal: IVLP proposal for Environmental engagement.docx

name: Ocean Motion Technologies
description: Ocean Motion Technologies is an active organization in the bluetech sector. They have been fabricating several innovative small-scale generation and storage devices for marine applications. This includes developing more sustainable, scalable and more efficient marine hydrokinetic energy by focusing on small-scale applications. The bluetech sector needs commercially successful products in small-scale energy to fuel the research and development needed to discover the generation methods and supporting technologies that will unlock scalable wave energy production. Ocean Motion Technologies has been focused on small-scale power needs at sea for scientific/maritime buoys and moorings, offshore aquaculture, and coastal security and defense. Great Ecology Great Ecology | Ecology + Design Great Ecology is headquartered in San Diego, CA with additional staff positioned in Imperial Valley, New York, and Sedona. To date, they have managed over 1,400 projects in 37 states as well as internally in Thailand, China, Canada, Saudi Arabia, Costa Rica, and other countries. Great Ecology is a leading ecological consulting and landscape architecture firm. They deliver innovative environmental designs and solutions to complex environmental issues. Their organization focuses on a variety of fields including ecological restoration and mitigation, landscape architecture, environmental planning and permitting, natural resource assessment and management, and environmental litigation support. Innovation in Agriculture/Biotechnology Cibus, LLC Cibus - Home - Driving Sustainable Agriculture Cibus, LLC generates environmentally-friendly crop traits for the agricultural community. Cibus, LLC works with partners from different sectors of the world’s major crops for trait development programs. Cibus’s gene editing industry works without the use of transgenes or foreign DNA that are associated with GMO technologies. The company's goal is to help farmers tackle the challenges presented by the environment such as disease, weeds and pests in a more sustainable way with less chemicals, fuel and negative environmental impact. Additionally, Cibus, LLC applies the Rapid Trait Development System (RTDS) to create products that meet the needs of an expanding global population. BIOCOM www.biocom.org/ BIOCOM/San Diego’s mission is to enhance and expand the business goals of their member partners through different opportunities in health, agriculture and energy. BIOCOM/San Diego promotes the growth of all sectors of the industry through creation of member value in the areas of public policy, agriculture, member services, education and business networking. BIOCOM/San Diego provides all of their members with the opportunity to connect and collaborate with the influential actors engaged in the different industries. University of California, San Diego – Division of Biological Sciences www.biology.ucsd.edu/ The UC San Diego Division of Biological Sciences strives to enhance the basic knowledge of biological sciences by applying their research findings to promote health, the environment, and economic growth. The team of researchers has made breakthroughs to solve a number of issues including the protection of the world’s food supply. The UC San Diego Division of Biological Sciences is committed to addressing global-issues that affect the environment, health and the economy by collaborating with like-minded research institutions. Government Resources Climate Smart Agriculture Programs under the California Department of Food and Agriculture (CDFA) Statewide Climate Smart Agriculture - Climate and Agriculture in San Diego County (ucanr.edu) CSA includes both on-farm and beyond the farm actions and incorporates technologies, policies, institutions and investment. In response, the Governor of California established three Climate Smart Agriculture (CSA) programs that are aimed to: Increase farm productivity in a sustainable manner, support farming communities to adapt to climate change by building the resilience of agricultural livelihoods and ecosystems, and, wherever possible, and reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) – Border Liaison Office, San Diego Environmental Topics | US EPA In October 1994, EPA established the Border Liaison Office in San Diego, California to support binational efforts that address environmental issues affecting U.S.-Mexico border communities. The mission of the Border Office is to advance the goals and objectives of the binational border environment program with Mexico and to leverage and collaborate with border stakeholders towards this mission. Among other tasks, the Border Office coordinates implementation of the binational U.S./Mexico Border Program, provides support to the Border 2020 Task Forces (currently there are 10 Task Forces), and facilitates dialogue and resolution of issues affecting border communities. Meeting focus: Explore the goals of the Border 2020 initiative, particularly concerning energy efficiency, reducing air pollution, and improving access to clean water; Binational perspective on environmental protection; To examine how food security is linked to environmental, energy and political security California Department of Fish and Wildlife - South Coast Region South Coast Region (ca.gov) The California Department of Fish and Wildlife - South Coast Region serves Los Angeles, San Diego, Santa Barbara, and Ventura counties. Their goal is to manage California's diverse fish, wildlife, and plant resources, and the habitats upon which they depend, for their ecological values and for their use and enjoyment by the public. It is part of the California Department of Fish and Wildlife which is responsible for management of over 1.1 million acres of fish and wildlife habitat spanning over 700 properties statewide. These properties provide habitat for a rich diversity of fish, wildlife, and plant species and comprise habitats from every major ecosystem in the state. In addition, several private lands conservation programs assist landowners with the management of wetlands, riparian habitats, native grasslands and wildlife-friendly farmlands. Water Issues / Water Management
source_proposal: IVLP proposal for Environmental engagement.docx

name: Pure Water San Diego
description: Pure Water San Diego is the City of San Diego's phased, multi-year program that will provide nearly half of San Diego's water supply locally by the end of 2035. The Pure Water San Diego Program will use proven water purification technology to clean recycled water to produce safe, high-quality drinking water. The Program offers a cost-effective investment for San Diego's water needs and will provide a reliable, sustainable water supply. Pure Water San Diego is the City’s 20-year program to provide a safe, reliable and drought-proof local drinking water supply for San Diego. The program uses proven water purification technology and is environmentally sustainable. It is also cost effective—it eliminates the need for expensive upgrades to the Point Loma Wastewater Treatment Plant.
source_proposal: IVLP proposal for Environmental engagement.docx

name: East County Advanced Water Purification Project (AWP)
description: AWP stands for advanced water purification. It's a treatment process to turn recycled water into drinking water. The East County AWP is a partnership between Helix Water District, Padre Dam Municipal Water District, the City of El Cajon, and the County of San Diego to produce a sustainable water supply for East County. The participating agencies held a groundbreaking ceremony on June 1, 2022, to launch construction. There are three design and construction "packages" to fund and complete. A fourth package focuses on water treatment byproducts. East County AWP is expected to go online in 2026. The Program uses four advanced water purification steps to produce water that is near-distilled in quality. After treatment, the purified water will be blended with water in Lake Jennings and treated again at the R.M. Levy Water Treatment Plant before being distributed as drinking water
source_proposal: IVLP proposal for Environmental engagement.docx

name: South Bay International Wastewater Treatment Plan
description: The SBIWTP is a 25 million gallon per day secondary treatment plant located in San Diego County, California, about 2 miles west of the San Ysidro Port of Entry. The plant treats sewage originating in Tijuana, Mexico and discharges it to the Pacific Ocean through the South Bay Ocean Outfall, a four and one-half mile long 11foot diameter pipe completed in January 1999. From here you can link to various informative pages about the SBIWTP located in San Ysidro, CA. The South Bay International Wastewater Treatment Plant (SBIWTP) was designed to deal with the growing demand for the treatment of wastewater resulting in the contamination of the Tijuana River in the United States. It has been an ongoing concern since 1934 when the International Boundary Commission (IBC) was instructed by the United States and Mexican governments to cooperate in the preparation of a report on the Tijuana sewage problem. The SBIWTP is capable of providing secondary treatment for 25 million gallons per day (mgd) average daily flows of sewage in excess of the Tijuana sewage system capacity but has expansion capability of up to 100 mgd. The SBIWTP was built on a 75-acre site near the international boundary in the U.S. immediately north of Tijuana's main wastewater pumping station. Resulting from the establishment of a binational interagency "Clean Water Partnership," the United States and Mexico approved IBWC Minute No. 283 dated July 8, 1990. This Minute authorized the construction of the SBIWTP. The Government of Mexico contributed $16.8 million toward construction of the SBIWTP and currently contributes $2.0 million toward the annual operation and maintenance costs.
source_proposal: IVLP proposal for Environmental engagement.docx

name: Center for the Study of Women in Television and Film at San Diego State University
description: Dedicated to researching and analyzing the representation and portrayal of women in the television and film industry, the Center for the Study of Women in Television focuses on studying various aspects related to women’s participation in these mediums. Through extensive research and data analysis, the center aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of the current state of gender equality and diversity in the television and film industry. It examines key metrics such as the number of women characters, their roles, screen time, and the presence of stereotypes of gender biases in media content.
source_proposal: Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: San Diego School of Creative and Performing Arts
description: Focused on providing comprehensive arts education to students in the San Diego area, the San Diego School of Creative and Performing Arts offers specialized curriculum that integrates academics with intensive training in various artistic disciplines. The school places a strong emphasis on fostering artistic excellence, creativity, and personal growth, providing students with a well-rounded education that encompasses both artistic and academic development. Both its commitment to artistic excellence and academic rigor makes the San Diego School of Creative and Performing Arts a distinguished institution in San Diego’s arts education landscape.
source_proposal: Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: California State University San Marcos (CSUSM) School of Arts
description: The School of Arts at California State University San Marcos fosters a vibrant arts community on campus and the surrounding area. Hosting numerous exhibitions, performances, and events that showcase the talents of students, faculty, and visiting artists. The faculty consists of experienced artists and scholars who provide mentorship and guidance to students, helping them develop their skills and artistic voice. CSUSM School of Arts pushes for community engagement and outreach to contribute to the cultural enrichment and development of the region.

name: California Institute of the Arts
description: California Institute of the Arts, or CalArts, has a unique and innovative approach to arts education, emphasizing interdisciplinary collaboration and experimentation. The institution places a strong emphasis on artistic freedom and self-expression that encourages students to explore their creative potential and push boundaries. Another notable aspect of CalArts is the integration of different art forms and disciplines. The institution encourages students to explore cross-disciplinary collaborations and experimentation, fostering an environment that nurtures artistic innovation and exploration. Incubators and Coalitions

name: San Diego Regional Arts and Culture Coalition
description: The San Diego Regional Arts and Culture Coalition serves as a collective voice for the arts community that strives to raise awareness about the value and impact of arts and culture in the region. It advocates for increased public and private investment in the arts, arts education, and cultural programs. Additionally, the San Diego Regional Arts and Culture Coalition organizes events, workshops, and forums that promote networking, professional development, and knowledge-sharing within the arts community.

name: Disco Riot
description: DISCO RIOT exists to elevate a collaborative art culture in San Diego and beyond — because “the world needs more movement-based art”. They connect dancers and artists who want to move themselves and audiences in ways that push boundaries to make high impact art that promotes community, justice, and movement as a form of radical expression. DISCO RIOT produces and supports innovative dance programming, connects artists across media and form to grow and intensify our community, and provide an educational space that reflects contemporary and progressive professional realities.

name: The Studio Door
description: The Studio Door is an arts incubator and gallery space located in the North Park neighborhood of San Diego. It serves as a creative hub for artists, providing them with affordable studio spaces, exhibition opportunities, and a supportive community. The studio operates as a gallery that showcases the work for local and regional artists. It provides networking opportunities, community events, and collaborations that encourages artists to connect, exchange ideas, and support one another. The Studio Door plays a vital role in the San Diego art scene by providing artists with affordable spaces and exhibition opportunities.

name: Space 4 Art:
description: Space 4 Art is a multidisciplinary arts organization located in downtown San Diego that serves as an art incubator while providing live/work spaces for artists. The organization offers affordable spaces where artists can reside and create. These studios offer a private and focused environment where artists can further develop their artistic practices and engage in experimentation and exploration. Through its initiatives in educational programs and outreach, Space 4 Art strives to bridge the gap between artists and public while also promoting dialogue and understanding of the arts.
source_proposal: Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: A Ship in the Woods
description: A Ship in the Woods is an experimental art space located in Escondido. It is known for its unique approach to showcasing and fostering interdisciplinary and boundary-pushing art forms. The organization encourages artists to experiment, collaborate, and engage in diverse disciplines. The space also organizes public events and workshops that invite audiences to experience and interact with art on display to develop meaningful connections and discussions. A Ship in the Woods is an innovative art space that pushes the boundaries of traditional artistic practices. Business Sector Resources

name: The Old Globe
description: Modeled after Shakespeare’s Old Globe in London, the Old Globe Theatre was built in 1935 for the presentation of abridged versions of Shakespeare’s plays. The Old Globe has been home to some of the most acclaimed national artists, designers, directors, and playwrights in the theater industry. More than 20 productions produced at The Old Globe have gone on to play Broadway and Off Broadway, garnering 13 Tony Awards and numerous nominations. With a current operating budget of approximately $30 million, the Globe is one of San Diego’s largest arts institutions, its leading arts employer, and among the nation’s top-ranked regional theaters. More than 250,000 people annually attend Globe productions and participate in the theater’s arts engagement programs and outreach services.
source_proposal: Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: Bread & Salt
description: Bread & Salt is a 45,000 square-foot gallery and experimental center for the arts with strong community ties. Located 15 miles north of the U.S./Mexico border in San Diego, CA, Bread & Salt hosts original works by local and international artists, eclectic events, and a curated assemblage of artisans, educational entities, and non-profit tenants - alongside a robust residency program and publishing house. It comprises multiple gallery, studio, and event spaces, and serves as a cultural hub and gathering place for the region’s creative community.
source_proposal: Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: La Jolla Playhouse
description: https://lajollaplayhouse.org/without-walls/ La Jolla Playhouse advances theater as an art form, telling stories that inspire empathy and create a dialogue toward a more just future. With their intrepid spirit and eclectic, artist-driven approach they continue to cultivate a local, national and global following with an insatiable appetite for audacious work. La Jolla Playhouse provides unfettered creative opportunities for a community of artists of all backgrounds and abilities. They are committed to being a permanent safe harbor for unsafe and surprising work, offering a glimpse of the new and the next in American theater.
source_proposal: Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: San Diego Symphony Orchestra
description: The San Diego Symphony, through unquestionable commitment to the highest levels of artistic achievement, seeks to elevate human potential by providing a shared sense of pride and belonging to something bigger than any of us can achieve alone. They offer audiences the wonder of live music and transformative learning experiences that develop an understanding and passion for the arts. They serve and shape the culture of the region, by being for all and with all, the musical heart of San Diego. Government Resources
source_proposal: Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: City of San Diego Commission for Arts and Culture
description: https://www.sandiego.gov/sites/default/files/2022-08-25_creative_corp_news_release.pdf The commission’s primary mission is to be able to enhance the quality of life for San Diego residents by fostering a vibrant and diverse arts and culture community. It plays a crucial role in allocating grants to artists, art organizations, and community groups through competitive funding programs. In addition to funding, the commission facilitates partnerships and collaborations among artists, art organizations. and community stakeholders. It also organizes events, workshops, and networking opportunities to foster connections and professional development within the arts community.
source_proposal: Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: Far South/Border North
description: Far South/Border North is a regional collaborative supporting artists and cultural practitioners in communities in San Diego and Imperial counties. To support the social, environmental, and civic engagement of California’s most disproportionately impacted communities, the California Arts Council developed California Creative Corps, which in turn led to the creation of Far South/Border North. The project provides grant funding and development opportunities for artists and cultural practitioners from various mediums, whose work addresses one or more of the program’s goals. Some of these goals include climate mitigation, emergency preparedness, civic engagement, social justice, and community engagement. Meeting focus: Explore how this 2-year investment opportunity is supporting artists throughout San Diego to promote social change and civic engagement. Non-profit Resources David’s Harp Foundation ​​www.davidsharpfoundation.org David’s Harp Foundation aims to inspire, educate and empower at-risk and homeless youth to achieve academic success through music education, sound engineering and multimedia production. Programs include Multimedia Production where instructors teach students to fuse audio, video, still image and animation into a dynamic. The Foundation also hosts a Shelter Nights program in partnership with San Diego Youth Services’ Emergency Youth Shelter. After checking into the shelter for the night, Youth Shelter teens work with instructors in their studio to write, record and produce original music and poetry, motivating teens to stay off the streets and hone their musical interests.
source_proposal: Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: Vanguard Culture
description: Vanguard Culture is an inclusive 501(c)3 nonprofit dedicated to advancing San Diego’s Creative Industries. They provide award-winning arts journalism, cutting edge events, and professional development that create arts jobs, bring diverse communities together and inspire collaboration among the visual, performing, and culinary arts. They have many cultural events, professional development services (mixers and networking), as well as arts coverage.
