name: Museum of Contemporary Art San Diego
description: The Museum of Contemporary Art San Diego is a prominent art institution dedicated to collecting, preserving, and exhibiting contemporary art. The museum focuses on art from the 1950s to the present, showcasing works by renowned national and international artists as well as emerging talents. In addition to its exhibitions, the museum offers a range of educational programs for all ages, including lectures, artists talks, workshops, and guided tours. The museum is also partnered with local schools, organizations, and community groups to provide access to the arts and promote arts education.
source_proposal: Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: Balboa Park Cultural Partnership
description: The Balboa Park Cultural Partnership is a collaborative organization consisting of over 30 cultural institutions located in Balboa Park, San Diego. The partnership serves as a platform for collaboration and coordination among its member institutions, which includes museums, performing art venues, gardens, and other cultural organizations. Additionally, the organization also works closely with the City of San Diego and other stakeholders to advocate for the arts and culture in the park. Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).
source_proposal: Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: Chicano Park
description: Chicano Park is the geographic and emotional heart of Barrio Logan, located in Logan Heights, San Diego's oldest Mexican-American neighborhood. The park is home to the largest concentration of Chicano murals in the world with more than 80 paintings on seven acres dotted with sculpture, gardens, picnic tables and playgrounds. Throughout the year, it hosts festivals of music and Aztec dance, the biggest being Chicano Park Day held each April. Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $30 for one Adult Ticket for a one-hour narrated tour (south bay or north bay routes); $35 for a full bay two-hour narrated tour which covers it all: ships of the Maritime Museum, Harbor and Shelter Islands, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and more. The full bay tour is about 25 miles in length. Accessibility: The tour begins and ends at the same location downtown along Broadway Pier. Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com Price: $44 for a 1-Day Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) For 30 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours, highlighting the best San Diego attractions. The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50am – 5:00pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $26 for one Adult General Admission Ticket ($1 discount when purchased on-line). Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10am – 5pm (Last admission at 4pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside Navy Pier.
source_proposal: Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: Border Field State Park & Friendship Park
description: https://www.friendshippark.org/ Located within the Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve, Border Field State Park sits in the very southwestern corner of the United States, 15 miles south of San Diego. This important wildlife habitat, comprised of sand dunes and salt marshes, gives refuge to critically threatened and endangered birds such as the Western Snowy Plover, the California Least Tern, and the Light-footed Ridgway's Rail. Friendship Park is a binational park located at the western end of the US-Mexico border. For generations people have gathered here to meet up with friends and family "across the line." Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 17 major museums and cultural institutions, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).
source_proposal: Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: Coronado
description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year around due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown. SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $99.99 for one Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Orca Encounter, Dolphin Days, and Sea Lions Live shows and thrilling rides like Electric Eel, Manta, and Journey To Atlantis. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Hours vary by season. Also enjoy the opening of Sesame Place in March 2022, a Sesame Street themed section of the park with new water, ride, and musical attractions. Accessibility: A 15-20-minute drive from downtown San Diego.

ARTS 4 Justice ARTS 4 Justice — A Reason To Survive (ARTS) The ARTS 4 Justice initiative connects system-involved young people with creative arts programming and community-based projects in an effort to confront and respond the root causes of systemic violence and injustice in communities across south San Diego. Youth participants put Creative Youth Development (CYD) practices into action through their stories, ideas, dreams, and visions for a better future that find creative expression in murals, photography, comics, zines, and other works. Poetry Out Loud Write Out Loud | Let us read you a story (writeoutloudsd.com) Poetry Out Loud is a FREE program for High School students. Students select poems from the National Poetry Foundation Anthology, and memorize, interpret, and recite their poems in a competition at the entry level. Two winners from each competition advance to the Regional Competition and one regional winner advances to the State Competition. TranscenDANCE Youth Arts Project transcenDANCE Youth Arts Project (tdarts.org) At transcenDANCE, their mission is to guide young people in under-resourced San Diego County communities to transcend barriers, expand their ambitions, and create positive change for themselves, their families, and communities, through dance and performance. Private Sector The San Diego Symphony Performances | Jacobs Music Center (sandiegosymphony.org) The Linda & Shearn Platt Open Rehearsals are designed specifically for Middle and High School music programs. Open Rehearsals support music educators in their learning goals, encourage instrumental music in schools, and provide a direct connection between student musicians and professional musicians. There is also a paid fellowship for high schoolers which helps them gain experience and work training in the summer. La Jolla Playhouse La Jolla Playhouse Theatre in San Diego, CA La Jolla Playhouse is a world-class theater where many popular shows have originated including the hit musical “Seussical” and “Come From Away.” There is world-class talent and infrastructure at UC San Diego bears lessons for international visitors. The La Jolla playhouse also produces shows from diverse viewpoints, most recently, “Sumo,” a tale of a young Rishiki (Sumo Wrestler) and his ascent through the sport.

Government Resources Commission for Arts and Culture Commission for Arts and Culture | City of San Diego Official Website The City of San Diego Commission for Arts and Culture serves in an advisory capacity to the Mayor and City Council on promoting, encouraging, and increasing support for the region's artistic and cultural assets, integrating arts and culture into community life and showcasing San Diego as an international tourist destination. San Diego County Arts & Culture Commission Arts & Culture (sandiegocounty.gov) The Commission is responsible for promoting greater cultural equity, access, and inclusion; championing the arts as essential to daily life by investing in a vibrant arts community; shaping innovative cultural policy; and building public awareness of the value and benefits of the arts and cultural diversity. Far South/Border North About | Far South Border North | City of San Diego Far South/Border North is a regional collaborative supporting artists and cultural practitioners in communities and the only program of its kind in San Diego and Imperial counties. To fuel positivity and support the social, environmental, and civic engagement of California’s most disproportionately impacted communities, the California Arts Council, in partnership with the State legislature, developed California Creative Corps. Far South/Border North: Artists and Cultural Practitioners in Community (FSBN) was conceived by the City of San Diego and its regional partners as a California Creative Corps arts program for San Diego and Imperial counties to do just that. The San Diego Museum of Art SDMA | Teens - San Diego Museum of Art (sdmart.org) The San Diego Museum of Art’s Teen Council offers high school students the opportunity to take on a collaborative role at the Museum and lend their voices to new and existing programs. Students work with Museum staff and their peers to share ideas, develop programming, and implement a Community and Family Art Drop-In Workshop with the Education department at the Museum. Meetings are held monthly via Zoom with in-person opportunities in Spring 2024. Teens are always free at the museum, and art tutorials are available. Incubators So Say We All Cultivation — So Say We All (sosayweallonline.com) So Say We All offers creative writing and storytelling arts education classes to populations without access, often in partnership with a government or social service entity. Participants learn the fundamentals of narrative, create and rewrite original stories, give and receive feedback on their work from others in the group, and participate in a public reading or performance at the course’s conclusion.

name: Disco Riot
description: DISCO RIOT exists to elevate a collaborative art culture in San Diego and beyond — because “the world needs more movement-based art”. They connect dancers and artists who want to move themselves and audiences in ways that push boundaries to make high impact art that promotes community, justice, and movement as a form of radical expression. DISCO RIOT produces and supports innovative dance programming, connects artists across media and form to grow and intensify their community, and provide an educational space that reflects contemporary and progressive professional realities.

name: The Studio Door
description: The Studio Door is an arts incubator and gallery space located in the North Park neighborhood of San Diego. It serves as a creative hub for artists, providing them with affordable studio spaces, exhibition opportunities, and a supportive community. The studio operates as a gallery that showcases the work for local and regional artists. It provides networking opportunities, community events, and collaborations that encourages artists to connect, exchange ideas, and support one another. The Studio Door plays a vital role in the San Diego art scene by providing artists with affordable spaces and exhibition opportunities.

name: Space 4 Art
description: Space 4 Art is a multidisciplinary arts organization located in downtown San Diego that serves as an art incubator while providing live/work spaces for artists. The organization offers affordable spaces where artists can reside and create. These studios offer a private and focused environment where artists can further develop their artistic practices and engage in experimentation and exploration. Through its initiatives in educational programs and outreach, Space 4 Art strives to bridge the gap between artists and public while also promoting dialogue and understanding of the arts.

name: Scripps Institution of Oceanography at UCSD
description: Scripps Institution of Oceanography at UC San Diego is one of the most important centers for global earth science research and education in the world. Scripps scientists work to understand and protect the planet by investigating our oceans, Earth, and atmosphere to find solutions to our greatest environmental challenges. Scripps leads research in climate change impacts and adaptation, resilience to hazards, conservation and biodiversity, oceans and human health, national security, and innovative technology to observe the planet. Meeting focus: To discuss the cutting edge research that SIO does on every continent and every ocean to protect and proserve marine and aquatic ecosystems.
source_proposal: Promoting Waste Management and Tackling Marine Debris for the Indo-Pacific.docx

name: San Diego State University Coastal and Marine Institute (CMI)
description: The Coastal and Marine Institute (CMI) refers to the consortium of researchers, visiting scientists, students, and volunteers that work at the SDSU Coastal and Marine Institute Laboratory (CMIL). The CMIL was built in 2006 on a prime coastal site at the old Naval Training Center near the airport and San Diego Bay and was conveyed to SDSU by the City of San Diego for the purposes of functioning as a research facility for students and faculty. The mission of the CMIL is to perform basic and applied coastal research and to share our knowledge of the marine environment with the community. The Coastal and Marine Institute Laboratory (CMIL) is a powerful tool for San Diego State University (SDSU) scientists who are researching environmental problems up and down the coast of southern California, offering interdisciplinary solutions to coastal zone problems, with a focus on the San Diego region. The goals of CMIL are to perform research, to protect the coastal environment, and to educate scientists and students of San Diego. Government Agencies
source_proposal: Promoting Waste Management and Tackling Marine Debris for the Indo-Pacific.docx

name: International Boundary and Water Commission
description: Established in 1889, the International Boundary and Water Commission (IBWC) is responsible for applying the boundary and water treaties between the United States and Mexico and settling differences that may arise in their application. The IBWC is an international body composed of the United States Section and the Mexican Section, each headed by an Engineer-Commissioner appointed by his/her respective president. Each Section is administered independently of the other. The San Diego Field office is a dual function office with both Construction and Operation and Maintenance assignments. The functions of the office are to carry out designated operations and maintenance functions which support the U.S. Section of the International Boundary and Water Commission which include: To manage, plan, and administer the operation and maintenance program for the South Bay International Wastewater Treatment Plant (SBIWTP) and facilities, and the International Tijuana River Flood Control Project (ITRFCP). Performance of maintenance on levees, road, channel and flood way; administering the operation and maintenance of the river gage in the Tijuana River; and operation and accounting of flow through the Emergency Connection. To manage, plan, and administer the utilization and maintenance of heavy and light equipment, vehicles, structures, communications systems, support fuels, supplies, and materials to assure the efficient and economical functioning of the Project. The South Bay International Wastewater Treatment Plant (SBIWTP) is located on a 75-acre site near the international border and provides for advanced primary treatment of 25 mgd of Tijuana sewage. The SBIWTP construction was completed in September, 1997 and began full operation in January, 1999 upon completion of the South Bay Ocean Outfall. The Tijuana Flood Control Channel began construction in late 1977, and is used to contain and convey Tijuana River flood flows up to 135,000 cubic feet per second in both the United States and Mexico. In the United States, the channel consists of a partial trapezoidal concrete lined channel, which expands to grouted stone, and then natural soil floodway.
source_proposal: Promoting Waste Management and Tackling Marine Debris for the Indo-Pacific.docx

name: The Public Utilities Department's Ocean Monitoring Program (OMP)
description: The Public Utilities Department's Ocean Monitoring Program (OMP) is the preeminent leader in studying the effects of our regional wastewater treatment processes on the marine environment. The OMP covers over 340 square miles - from northern San Diego to northern Baja California, Mexico - from the shoreline to approximately 10 miles offshore, to depths of over 1,600 ft. The OMP is a requirement of three National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permits for the City's Point Loma Wastewater Treatment Plant and South Bay Water Reclamation Plant, and for the International Boundary & Water Commission's South Bay International Wastewater Treatment Plant.The main objectives of the department include protecting San Diego’s marine environment, documenting changes in marine environment, and determining the quality of recreational waters. Non-Profit and Non-Governmental Organizations

name: I Love a Clean San Diego
description: I Love A Clean San Diego (ILACSD) is an environmental nonprofit supporting residents and businesses of San Diego County. ILACSD was founded in 1954 as the San Diego War Against Litter Committee (WALC). Over the last seven decades, ILACSD has provided programs that go far beyond litter cleanups and serve as environmental catalysts. The programs inspire and empower San Diegans to be environmental and waste-free living leaders in their communities. I Love A Clean San Diego has served as the official organizer of Coastal Cleanup Day in San Diego County since it was founded in 1985. The event is a major part of International Coastal Cleanup, which is facilitated by The Ocean Conservancy and includes many U.S. states and territories and over 70 countries. Over 269,000 volunteers and 5 million pounds of litter and debris removed since 1985.
source_proposal: Promoting Waste Management and Tackling Marine Debris for the Indo-Pacific.docx

name: Ocean Connectors
description: Ocean Connectors was created to address environmental issues in underserved communities of San Diego County and Riviera Nayarit. Using migratory marine life, the organization aims to cultivate a future generation of empowered, globally-aware and passionate coastal residents. Ocean Connectors was founded on the realization that many schoolchildren do not have equal access to explore their coastal environment. Ocean Connector’s vision is to cultivate a future generation of passionate, globally-­aware, and empowered coastal residents who take active steps to enjoy and protect ocean health. Their goals are to educate students to increase academic engagement, support classroom learning goals, and motivate them to pursue ocean-STEM careers, inspire environmental stewardship by introducing children to the tools, knowledge, and awareness to actively practice conservation, and connect youth with the ocean and provide access to diverse, hands-on learning opportunities in coastal environments.
source_proposal: Promoting Waste Management and Tackling Marine Debris for the Indo-Pacific.docx

name: WILDCOAST
description: WILDCOAST is an international team that conserves coastal and marine ecosystems and addresses climate change through natural solutions. The organization envisions a society in which ecologically sensitive and globally significant coastal and marine ecosystems and wildlife are conserved, restored and sustained for future generations. WILDCOAST’s programs establish new marine protected areas, deter poachers and build conservation capacity in local communities. It mitigates the impact of marine debris by organizing beach clean ups, pushing for strict legislation and creating new recycling markets. The organization is also helping to ensure the long term conservation of precious marine ecosystems and the diversity of wildlife found within them. Volunteer Activities

name: San Diego River Park Foundation
description: In 2000, the largest sewer spill in California’s history dumped 34 million gallons of untreated sewage into the San Diego River. Out of this tragedy, a group of concerned citizens formed the San Diego River Park Foundation on July 18, 2001. Since this tragedy, the San Diego River Park Foundation has worked with the community to change San Diego’s relationship to its namesake waterway. SDRP Foundation remain a local, grassroots non-profit organization and relies on donations, support from the community, and public and private grants for their work creating the San Diego River Park, connecting people to the River, and conserving local resources. The san Diego River flows into Mission Bay and the Pacific Ocean.

name: Surfrider Foundation
description: The Surfrider Foundation is dedicated to the protection and enjoyment of the world’s ocean, waves, and beaches, for all people, through a powerful activist network. Their national network of chapter volunteers serve as the first response to local threats in coastal communities across the US. They are the boots on the ground who collaborate on both the local and national level with regional staff and issue experts to carry out their mission through campaign, program and educational initiatives in their local communities. From Imperial Beach to Oceanside, Surfrider San Diego holds up to six public beach cleanups county wide every month. 1st Saturday of each month in Ocean Beach and Oceanside 3rd Saturday of each month in Imperial Beach and Encinitas 4th Saturday of each month in Tamarack State Beach 4th Saturday of each month in Pacific Beach (Every other month + Summer) Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. source_proposal: Promoting Waste Management and Tackling Marine Debris for the Indo-Pacific.docx

name: Border Field State Park & Friendship Park
description: https://www.friendshippark.org/ Located within the Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve, Border Field State Park sits in the very southwestern corner of the United States, 15 miles south of San Diego. This important wildlife habitat, consisting of sand dunes and salt marshes, gives refuge to critically threatened and endangered birds such as the Western Snowy Plover, the California Least Tern, and the Light-footed Ridgway's Rail. Friendship Park is a binational park located at the western end of the US-Mexico border. For generations, people have gathered here to meet up with friends and family "across the line." Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 17 major museums and cultural institutions, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens, and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).
source_proposal: Promoting Waste Management and Tackling Marine Debris for the Indo-Pacific.docx

name: Coronado
description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year-round due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown. SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $99.99 for one Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased online) Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Orca Encounter, Dolphin Days, and Sea Lions Live shows and thrilling rides like Electric Eel, Manta, and Journey To Atlantis. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks, and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Hours vary by season. Also enjoy the opening of Sesame Place in March 2022, a Sesame Street-themed section of the park with new water, ride, and musical attractions. Accessibility: A 15-20-minute drive from downtown San Diego.
source_proposal: Promoting Waste Management and Tackling Marine Debris for the Indo-Pacific.docx

name: Commission on Police Practices
description: The Commission on Police Practices (CPP) is an independent community oversight entity for the San Diego Police Department (SDPD) that has investigatory, review, and auditing powers. This allows the CPP to make recommendations regarding police conduct and declare factors true or false in an investigation. The CPP’s purpose is to perform independent investigations of serious incidents, such as police officer involved shootings and in-custody deaths, and to evaluate complaints against the SDPD. All in all, they review SDPD policies, practices, etc. and recommend changes that would help the community.
source_proposal: Proposal BRAZIL- Policing and Leadership in Multifaceted and Multicultural Communities.docx

name: La Mesa Police Department
description: LMPD’s motto, “Working in Partnership with our Community,” indicates their commitment to community engagement. According to the Police Chief, police/community relations are extremely important when building trust with the community and reducing crime. Within the police department, they have a Community Police Oversight Board that meets and discusses how well the department is serving its community. In addition, the CPOB advises and reviews the on-duty actions of the LMPD.
source_proposal: Proposal BRAZIL- Policing and Leadership in Multifaceted and Multicultural Communities.docx

name: Human Relations Commission
description: The Human Relations Commission (HRC) is an advisory committee to the Mayor and City Council that conducts activities that create mutual respect, protects basic human and civil rights, promotes friendly relations among the San Diego community. They achieve their mission by advising the Mayor/City Council on ways to ensure that all residents have access to economic, political, and educational opportunities. They also mediate discrimination complaints of employment, housing and public accommodations and collaborate with community groups to create programs that provide better intercultural understanding. Members of the HRC were either appointed by the Mayor or by City Council.
source_proposal: Proposal BRAZIL- Policing and Leadership in Multifaceted and Multicultural Communities.docx

name: Citizens Advisory Board on Police/Community Relations
description: The Citizens Advisory Board on Police/Community Relations is an outlet for the community to recommend and review policies, programs, and practices designed to sensitize law enforcement to the needs of the City. Its goal is to actively encourage citizen participation in preventing crime. Previously discontinued, the Citizens Advisory Board was brought back due to the importance of open communication and citizen participation.
source_proposal: Proposal BRAZIL- Policing and Leadership in Multifaceted and Multicultural Communities.docx

name: Safe Place Program
description: The Safe Place Program strives to strengthen community/police relations through impartial policing and culturally conscious police officers. It allows businesses to identify themselves as safe places for victims of harassment and hate crimes to go and report such crimes. This program also aims to facilitate the process of acculturation in immigrant communities, due to the high population of refugees and immigrants.
source_proposal: Proposal BRAZIL- Policing and Leadership in Multifaceted and Multicultural Communities.docx

name: Office of the United States Attorney for the Southern District of California
description: The Southern District of California includes San Diego among a variety of other diverse cities. This office fights crime commonly found in urban areas such as violence, white-collar crimes, and drug related crimes. San Diego, along with its neighboring Mexican city Tijuana make up one of the largest binational areas in the world. Due to the region’s close contact with Mexican cities like Tijuana and Mexicali, it faces problems specific to the area such as human and drug trafficking.
source_proposal: Proposal BRAZIL- Policing and Leadership in Multifaceted and Multicultural Communities.docx

name: San Diego County Sheriff’s Department for Community Inclusion
description: The San Diego County Sheriff’s Department for Community Inclusion is committed to building trust between law enforcement and the local communities. The Community Inclusion department, along with its director, connects and supports local deputies with a multitude of communities, including, but not limited to, faith-based, youth, immigrant and refugee, social justice, LGBTQ+, and persons with disabilities. Since there are many diverse communities in San Diego, the Sheriff’s Department provides many resources for residents through Community Outreach programs including unhoused assistance and crime prevention. Non-Profits, Think Tanks, and Coalitions
source_proposal: Proposal BRAZIL- Policing and Leadership in Multifaceted and Multicultural Communities.docx

name: Via International
description: Via International is a non-profit organization based in Baja California that promotes sustainable and healthy development in developing communities. They achieve this goal by supporting local leaders and their vision and building off the community's strengths and weaknesses. They allow the community to state their own needs and work to provide support in the areas specified. Via International's core principles correspond with social justice, human dignity, peace, and community development to name a few.
source_proposal: Proposal BRAZIL- Policing and Leadership in Multifaceted and Multicultural Communities.docx

name: Alliance San Diego
description: Alliance San Diego is a Non-profit organization whose mission is to create an inclusive democracy in a safe, equal, and justice-driven society. They protect human and civil rights by providing legal assistance and sharing resources that contribute to justice for disadvantaged individuals. They advocate for policies that keep citizens safe and hold law enforcement accountable. Lastly, Alliance partners with various organizations focused on immigration and police accountability.
source_proposal: Proposal BRAZIL- Policing and Leadership in Multifaceted and Multicultural Communities.docx

name: Community Wraparound
description: Community Wraparound is an initiative with the objective of mentoring gang-involved youth. On their team, they have various mentors from the community that have lived through the same experiences these children are going through. This allows for a more personal experience and inspires the youth to not involve themselves in gang activity. Their Transformative and Restorative justice framework focuses on addressing and repairing conditions within the community that contribute to violence.
source_proposal: Proposal BRAZIL- Policing and Leadership in Multifaceted and Multicultural Communities.docx

name: Pillars of the Community
description: Pillars of the Community is an organization rooted in the Islamic faith that advocates for people negatively impacted by law enforcement. They are committed to embracing the rich, historic, and diverse culture of San Diego by aiming to combat the criminalization of urban communities. They believe in the equality of all human beings, being accountable in human and organizational interactions, and collaborating to build stronger communities. Pillars of the Community work with experts and scholars to educate the community on the complex history of San Diego and the US.
source_proposal: Proposal BRAZIL- Policing and Leadership in Multifaceted and Multicultural Communities.docx

name: TRUST SD Coalition
description: TRUST SD Coalition is a community organization addressing the excessive and secretive use of Smart technology throughout San Diego County. TRUST, Transparent and Responsible Use of Surveillance Technology, wants oversight over the use of technology where it concerns residents’ civil liberties. They believe in community oversight and transparency to ensure effective democracy. TRUST authored an ordinance in collaboration with the community and multiple community organizations to address the issues of technology in San Diego County. Academic Institutes
source_proposal: Proposal BRAZIL- Policing and Leadership in Multifaceted and Multicultural Communities.docx

name: Kroc School Institute for Peace and Justice
description: The Kroc School Institute for Peace and Justice works with partners in the San Diego-Tijuana region to champion justice-centered solutions to the cycles of violence for a more peaceful society. The Kroc Institute partners with community-based organizations, local government officials, policymakers, NGOs, and global organizations to develop evidence-based solutions grounded in the lived experiences of these partners. Kroc Institute’s current initiatives include Cross-Border and Urban Violence. As a convergent city for many cultures, San Diego faces struggles with border policies and violence within the city which Kroc Institute actively engages in research to solve these problems.
source_proposal: Proposal BRAZIL- Policing and Leadership in Multifaceted and Multicultural Communities.docx

name: Chula Vista Learning Community Charter (CVLCC)
description: CVLCC, also known as the “Dream School,” is a dual-immersion school with a system of education that focuses on social justice, global perspectives, and community engagement. It’s 50/50 language model develops students' multi-literacy and multiculturalism. By promoting knowledge of geography and current events they challenge their students to explore different perspectives and emphasize with others who may or may not look like them. name: San Diego Union-Tribune
description: The San Diego Union-Tribune is San Diego’s largest print and digital media company and its oldest business, dating back to the founding of the Union in 1868. The San Diego Union-Tribune’s mission is to spread knowledge, build understanding and create opportunity in the communities it serves. They strive to elevate civic discourse though the journalistic pursuit of truth. Fairness, accuracy and honesty are their fundamental values. Jeff McDonald, Reporter
source_proposal: Proposal Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists.docx

name: He is a member of the investigative reporting team at The San Diego Union-Tribune, and was named journalist of the year in 2015 by the local Society of Professional Journalists. He writes about government and institutional misconduct and waste in San Diego County and beyond.
description: Morgan Cook, Reporter
source_proposal: Proposal Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists.docx

name: She is a member of the investigative reporting team at The San Diego Union-Tribune. She was named journalist of the year in 2017 by the local Society of Professional Journalists for a series of stories uncovering tens of thousands of dollars of improper campaign spending by Rep.
source_proposal: Proposal Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists.docx

name: KPBS News
description: KPBS news serves the people of the San Diego region with trustworthy, in-depth information that allows the community to hold its leaders accountable. They show how global and local current affairs change lives, and how San Diego changes the world. KPBS prides itself on telling the community not only what is happening, but why. They the Public Media Code of Integrity and the NPR Ethics Guidelines, and collaborates with Investigative Newsource for investigative projects. The Investigative Newsource staff works in the KPBS newsroom and teams up with KPBS reporters on various projects. This partnership is a vital part of our editorial strategy and allows KPBS to report on issues and stories with the data and resources needed to conduct thorough investigations. Work Shop
source_proposal: Proposal Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists.docx

name: inewsource/Investigative Newsource
description: inewsource is a nonprofit, nonpartisan newsroom dedicated to improving lives in the San Diego region and beyond through impactful, data-based investigative and accountability journalism. They believe that local news, especially investigative reporting, is essential to a functioning democracy. Their work brings to light inequity, injustice and the government’s failure to protect the public. Their journalists help to prevent malfeasance and corruption.
source_proposal: Proposal Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists.docx

name: Cody Dulaney, Investigative Reporter - Social Impact and Government Accountability
description: Cody Dulaney is an investigative reporter focusing on social impact stories. Before joining inewsource, Dulaney worked on investigative teams with newspapers in Florida and South Carolina. At the State newspaper in Columbia, S.C., he exposed a problem of South Carolinians selling family members into the sex trade. His five-part investigative series explored human trafficking in South Carolina — from family living rooms to illicit massage parlors, and everywhere in between. As a result, state lawmakers provided additional protections to victims, and law enforcement moved to shut down more than a dozen massage parlors along the coast.
source_proposal: Proposal Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists.docx

name: Voice of San Diego
description: Launched in 2005, Voice of San Diego was the first digital, nonprofit news organization in the country to serve a local community. They focus on in-depth, investigative reporting and cover issues that are crucial to the region's quality of life: its politics, educational system, environment, housing, economy and more. They cover stories beyond the press releases and press conferences to bring to light the stories that regional leaders and powerful corporations don't want to announce --the kind of stories that result in positive change, uncover vital information for San Diegans, and bring the people together as a community. Voice of San Diego does not report with any right-or left-wing agenda, but instead are inspired by passion to expose what is right and wrong, to drive reform and to spur solutions for the best of the community as a whole. Journalism Advocacy & Support Resources
source_proposal: Proposal Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists.docx

name: San Diego Society of Professional Journalists (San Diego SPJ)
description: The Society of Professional Journalists is a professional organization that includes broadcast, print and online journalists, journalism educators and students interested in journalism as a career. SPJ works to protect the First Amendment guarantees of freedom of speech and of the press, to stimulate high standards and ethical behavior in the practice of journalism, to foster excellence among journalists, to encourage diversity in journalism, and to be the pre-eminent, broad-based membership organization for journalists. The San Diego Pro Chapter sponsors professional development and networking programs throughout the year, sponsors an annual journalism awards contest for professional and college journalists, gives scholarships to student journalists, and hosts an annual awards banquet.
source_proposal: Proposal Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists.docx

name: New Media Rights
description: New Media Rights is an independently funded non-profit program of California Western School of Law that provides legal services to creators, entrepreneurs, and internet users whose projects require specialized internet, intellectual property, privacy, and media law expertise. New Media Rights is known for their work against content bullying. In addition, they turn what they learn into hundreds of freely available video and written legal education guides for creators and consumers. New Media Rights has participated in regulatory proceedings at the Copyright Office, the FCC, and the California Public Utilities Commission, including Net Neutrality, DMCA Anti-circumvention proceedings, Copyright Reform, and the Copyright small claims court proceedings. They also assist organizations that provide better access to public information, more business and government accountability, or new perspectives to the cultural landscape through the use of new technologies. San Diego Press Club www.sdpressclub.org/ The San Diego Press Club is proud of being one of the largest clubs of its kind in the nation with nearly 400 members in the news communications field. Offering a blend of social and professional growth activities, they seek to foster a community where the relevant professional/social needs of news communications professionals can be met in an environment of integrity and high ethical standards. The club is dedicated to promoting social enjoyment, cultivating professional advancement, encouraging friendly communication, providing all advantages of a professional club, and fostering the ethical standards of professional journalism. Meeting focus:  Overview of the San Diego Press Club and how it serves as a space for journalists to feel supported as well as accountable for their reporting.
source_proposal: Proposal Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists.docx

name: Humberto Gurmilan, Press Secretary to Supervisor Nora Vargas (District 1)
description: http://humbertogurmilan.com/ Humberto Gurmilan is currently the Press Secretary for Supervisor Nora Vargas and District 1. Prior to this position, he worked as a journalist for Telemundo in San Diego and as a Journalism and Communications professor at San Diego City College and Southwestern College. Humberto’s community involvement spans nearly two decades and includes work for various boards and organizations. He served on the Board of Directors for Access to Independence, he is a currently a member of the San Diego Mobility Board, the California School Boards Association Delegate Assembly, and the San Ysidro School District Governing Board. Humberto survived a traumatic spinal cord injury in his youth and is now an advocate for people with disabilities. He founded the Gurmilan Foundation, a nonprofit organization to help empower individuals with disabilities to reach their full potential, is a self-published author, and shares his story and passion for surfing to inspire others. Humberto holds an M.A. in Strategic Communication from National University and a B.A. in Communication from San Diego State University. Community news sources and media outlets
source_proposal: Proposal Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists.docx

name: County of San Diego County News Center
description: County News Center (CNC), produced by the County of San Diego Communications Office, recognizes the importance of communicating directly with San Diegans about programs and services that improve their health, safety, and wellbeing. CNC utilizes a variety of communication tools including social media, digital, and traditional media to keep the community proactively and transparently informed. CNC also has its own TV channel, which is “widely considered one of the top ten local government multimedia content providers in the United States”. CNC TV produces Board of Supervisors meetings, all County government video content, department content, and public outreach content on topics ranging from health to libraries to voting. Cybersecurity Focused Resource
source_proposal: Proposal Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists.docx

name: Cyber Center of Excellence (CCOE)
description: A San Diego-based nonprofit dedicated to solving cybersecurity workforce, economic development, and infrastructure challenges through collaboration with industry, academia, and government. The CCOE is instrumental in developing sustainable pipelines of cybersecurity experts to protect San Diego's digital landscape​​.
source_proposal: Proposal Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists.docx

name: San Diego Cyber Clinic
description: A collaborative initiative between the CCOE and multiple academic institutions aimed at growing an inclusive cyber workforce and creating a more secure digital community. This clinic provides hands-on training for students and supports small businesses and under-resourced organizations in San Diego with their cybersecurity needs​​. source_proposal: Proposal Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists.docx

name: School of Journalism & Media Studies
description: The School of Journalism and Media Studies offers nationally accredited programs that prepare undergraduate students for careers in advertising, journalism, public relations, and media. Our graduate students enhance their careers in mass communication and in learning design and technology, and many graduate students go on to pursue their doctorates. Our undergraduate programs in advertising, journalism, and public relations are accredited by the Accrediting Council on Education in Journalism and Mass Communications, putting us among the elite 25% of journalism schools nationwide that hold this specialized accreditation. We are constantly innovating, creating new courses and special topics courses to keep our students and faculty on the cutting edge of changes in the media professions. In the last two years, our new classes have included: Social Media Community Leadership, Digital and Social Media Analytics. Writing for Spanish-language and Latino Media, Fashion Public Relations, Media and Politics, and Games, Play and Learning.
source_proposal: Proposal Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists.docx

name: National Association of Black Journalists at San Diego State
description: The National Association of Black Journalists (NABJ) at SDSU works to provide a space where aspiring Black student journalists can feel supported, affirmed, and heard. Their mission is to provide valuable networking opportunities that can assist members as they navigate their journalism career. Meeting focus: Meet with SDSU journalism students to learn their perspective on communication studies and the future of journalism, and the role of NABJ in supporting their professional growth and sense of community.
source_proposal: Proposal Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists.docx

name: The Daily Aztec
description: The Daily Aztec is San Diego State University’s independent student newspaper, serving a student population of almost 35,000 and a faculty and staff population of more than 4,000. It strives to be a resource for all members of the SDSU community with the news, entertainment, information and advice they need to make their experience as Aztecs the best it can be. Meeting focus: Hear from a small-scale, niche-community media outlet on how they ensure the SDSU community remains engaged in and informed on current events and issues. University of California, San Diego A day-long visit to the University of California, San Diego may include meetings with some of the following resources:
source_proposal: Proposal Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists.docx

name: UC San Diego Department of Communication
description: UC San Diego’s Department of Communication prides itself in its unusual approach to the field of Communication. Faculty comes from fields across the Social Sciences and Humanities to bring multiple disciplinary traditions and methodologies to bear in the study of communication as an institutional, technological, cultural, architectural, and cognitive phenomenon, anchored in and shaped by questions of democracy, diversity, social justice, and social change. The Department is home to 750 undergraduate majors, approximately 50 doctoral students, and 24 ladder-rank and affiliated faculty. Patty Ahn, Ph.D. Assistant Teaching Professor Ppatty Ahn earned their Ph.D. in Cirtical Studies from the University of Southern California, where they developed a research and teaching interest in contemporary Korean and Korean American political economic and cultural history; postcolonial and feminist theory; cultural theories of global media with an emphasis on hallyu (the Korean Wave); and digital storytelling and transmedia activism. Drawing from their background as a community organizer and commercial producer, their work integrates interdisciplinary media research, critical media practice and community-based models of teaching. Meeting focus: Explore how global storytelling and visual politics are shaped by popular culture, especially in the U.S, and the practices of multimodal news dissemination. Boatema Boateng, Ph.D. Associate Professor Dr. Boateng’s research interests include Critical Legal Studies, Critical Race Studies, Cultural Studies, Transnational Gender Studies, and African Diaspora Studies. Her research projects focus on the regulatory dimensions of knowledge and its production, as embedded in legal (and other) regimes and in cultural objects and practices. In her book, The Copyright Thing Doesn't Work Here: Adinkra and Kente Cloth and Intellectual Property in Ghana, she examines the ways that intellectual property law converges with histories of subjugation along lines of nation, gender and race to produce and regulate both subjects and knowledge. She argues that the status of different kinds of knowledge and culture within the law is a function not only of their inherent qualities but also of their location in such histories. In addition, she examines devalued conceptions of knowledge and subjectivity as resources for challenging and critically rethinking intellectual property law. Her current research takes a similar historical perspective in examining U.S. copyright law in relation to the categories of "art" and "craft"; and the racial and gendered consequences of that relation for cultural production Meeting focus: Discuss Dr. Boateng’s research on U.S. copyright law and how they affect communication, investigation, and public perception; and the racial and gendered consequences of these relations for cultural production.
source_proposal: Proposal Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists.docx

name: Democracy Lab
description: The Democracy Lab at UC San Diego is a collective of scholars, community organizers, activists, educators, and practitioners working towards re-envisioning participatory democracy. The lab offers conditions for experimenting with different media-making practices, with an eye toward better understanding the ways such practices foster (or frustrate) public participation, citizen engagement, and civic responsibility in a media-saturated, “infotainment” driven social environment. The Lab offers a collaborative media practice lab, podcasting studio, and networked meeting room for participating faculty and students. They envision a space that allows for opportunities for conversations, collaborations, and events that bring people together with the goal of imagining democratic possibilities. Meeting focus: Examine how investigative journalism can help or hinder a democratically informed and civically engaged population, and what it means to have opened the Democracy Lab amidst the current political and social climate.
source_proposal: Proposal Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists.docx

name: UCSD-TV
description: UCSD-TV reflects San Diego’s rich, intellectual and cultural diversity through television programs that are unique in their intent and scope. As a university based station, UCSD-TV has unusual access to people and events that impact both the campus community and the greater San Diego region. The station’s non-commercial status gives it the autonomy to create content based strictly on relevance, interest and merit and is able to devote significant airtime to in-depth coverage of new ideas, key issues and emerging talent. UCSD-TV is available in English, Spanish, and Portuguese. Meeting focus: Learn about the freedom of releasing content as a non-commercial media source, and what challenges come with this. K-12 school

Then dive into the world of sea turtles at the all-new Turtle Reef attraction.

name: University of San Diego
description: The University of San Diego (USD) is an academic institution with a student population of around 9,000. USD offers comprehensive education across its seven schools and colleges, particularly standing out for its emphasis on business development and entrepreneurship. The School of Business provides students with valuable resources, mentorship programs, and experiential learning opportunities, empowering them to thrive in the ever-evolving business landscape. In addition, the University of San Diego is renowned for its Joan B. Kroc School of Peace Studies, which offers innovative programs and initiatives dedicated to advancing peacebuilding, conflict resolution, and social justice on a global scale. We suggest a full day of programming at USD including the following resources, however, all can be considered as standalone options as well.
source_proposal: Proposal Social Entrepreneurship and Strategic Innovation.docx

name: Master of Arts in Social Innovation
description: Look critically at the roots of social challenges and injustice, and then seek to create real change through bold new responses to poverty, inequality, human rights abuses and humanitarian crises. The Master's in Social Innovation degree is unlike any other in that it starts by diving deep into real social challenges, then pairs that knowledge with critical thinking, inventiveness, leadership and sustainable business design. Through the Fowler Global Social Innovation Challenge, university students in San Diego and Tijuana generate ideas for innovative ventures that respond to a social, economic, environmental, or justice issue of their choice, and compete for seed funding to launch or expand their ventures. Meeting focus: Discuss USD’s capitalization of trends towards academic studies of social entrepreneurship, and their approach on sustainable and scalable social ventures through interactive dialogue and case studies.
source_proposal: Proposal Social Entrepreneurship and Strategic Innovation.docx

name: Fowler Global Social Innovation Challenge
description: The Fowler Global Social Innovation Challenge is an exciting competition hosted by the University of San Diego's Center for Peace and Commerce. It invites students from around the world to develop innovative solutions to pressing social and environmental issues. Participants form teams and undergo a rigorous process of ideation, prototyping, and refining their ideas with the guidance of mentors. The challenge culminates in a live pitch event where finalists present their solutions to a panel of judges and compete for funding and support. Since 2011, they have connected more than 2,500 students, recognizing their outstanding social ventures. They have also distributed more than $600,000 to seed innovative and promising global ventures.
source_proposal: Proposal Social Entrepreneurship and Strategic Innovation.docx

name: Brink Small Business Development Center
description: The Brink SBDC is an incubator focused on innovation, one of only a handful of its kind in the country, hosted at University of San Diego. The Brink SDBC works with business clients running or starting growth-oriented, innovation-based companies with fewer than 500 employees. The Brink SBDC works with entrepreneurs with an innovative product, solution or service and has a larger than local addressable market and a scalable business model. Their expert advisors provide one-on-one consulting, training workshops, and access to valuable resources and networks. Whether it's developing a business plan, securing funding, or navigating regulatory requirements, the Brink SBDC assists entrepreneurs at every stage of their journey.
source_proposal: Proposal Social Entrepreneurship and Strategic Innovation.docx

name: Lavin Entrepreneurship Center, San Diego State University
description: The Lavin Entrepreneurship Center at San Diego State University (SDSU) is a dynamic hub that nurtures and supports aspiring entrepreneurs in their pursuit of innovation and business success. It serves students, entrepreneurs and business leaders through its entrepreneurial curriculum, workshops, internships, resources and events. The Lavin Center has been recognized for having one of the best entrepreneurial programs in the United States by both Princeton Review and Entrepreneur magazine. One of their popular workshops is on Digital Marketing and Social Media Strategies. This workshop dives into the realm of digital marketing, exploring effective tactics and strategies for utilizing social media platforms, creating engaging content, optimizing online advertising, and implementing search engine optimization (SEO) techniques. Participants gain insights into how to effectively leverage digital channels to reach target audiences, build brand awareness, drive customer engagement, and ultimately enhance their online presence.
source_proposal: Proposal Social Entrepreneurship and Strategic Innovation.docx

name: La Jolla Country Day School – Center for Design and Innovation
description: La Jolla Country Day School (LJCDS) is a private college prep school in the coastal community of La Jolla. The school’s Innovation Program challenges students to identify real-world problems and design innovative solutions to effect positive change for a better world. The curriculum from kindergarten to Grade 12 focuses on learning how to use cutting-edge tools and technologies while developing an understanding of the social impacts of technology, solutions and design. LJCDS’ Innovation Lab serves as a collaborative space that is equipped with a laser cutter (built from scratch by Upper School students), 3D printers, microcontrollers, Wacom tablets, drills, screwdrivers, hammers, sticky notes and anything else students may need for creative design and innovation. Additionally, LJCDS offers a venture capital fund for their students called the Torrey Explorer’s Fund (TEF). Whether students seek to start a business, launch a social campaign, invent a technology or create an art installation, TEF will offer mentorship by a team of local entrepreneurs and professionals and/or funding to help bring students’ ideas to fruition.

Hera Hub www.herahub.com Hera Hub is the first international female-focused coworking space – a shared, flexible work and meeting space where entrepreneurial women can create and collaborate in a professional, productive, modern environment. The platform provides members with connections to other business experts, access to educational workshops, and visibility within the community, thus giving women the support they need to be prosperous. In addition, Hera Fund gathers Angel Investors and pairs them with women owned businesses. The company was founded in San Diego, CA in 2011 and has since then been growing with locations sprouting up all over the U.S. and Europe. Their mission is to provide a platform for emerging and established artists, curators, and arts organizations, fostering creativity and innovation. Through curated exhibitions, immersive events, and thought-provoking programs, Vanguard Culture nurtures connections between artists and diverse audiences, cultivating dialogue and engagement. They strive to empower artists, promote inclusivity, and contribute to the cultural vibrancy of San Diego. With a focus on interdisciplinary collaborations and community partnerships, Vanguard Culture plays a pivotal role in supporting and amplifying the local arts community's impact and visibility.

name: UCSD The Basement Accelerator
description: The Basement, established under the Office of Innovation & Commercialization, is a pioneering initiative at UC San Diego, offering a distinctive space for students from diverse academic backgrounds to explore entrepreneurship and innovation. Originating in 2015 with backing from notable alumni and industry leaders, The Basement has evolved from its humble beginnings in Mandeville Center to become a thriving community housed within the Design & Innovation Building. Committed to providing students with the tools, training, and mentorship needed to turn their ideas into reality, The Basement embodies UC San Diego's dedication to fostering student innovation and preparing them for future career opportunities. Upholding values such as integrity, creativity, authenticity, empathy, resilience, and a commitment to equity, diversity, and inclusion, The Basement cultivates an environment where all students are empowered to contribute to meaningful societal change through entrepreneurial endeavors. Through its impactful initiatives and support systems, The Basement continues to shape the entrepreneurial landscape on campus, enabling students to translate their visions into tangible successes. Meeting focus: The meeting will focus on exploring successful models for social innovation, particularly through engagements with social entrepreneurs addressing environmental concerns, while also discussing how technology facilitates fundraising and strategic collaboration. Economic Development and Investment

name: Smart Border Coalition
description: The Smart Border Coalition is a catalyst to bring together leading academic, business, and civic communities from both sides of the San Diego/Tijuana International region to develop databases and policy positions, deliver special events and programs, and growth of the cross-border economy through jobs creation, workforce development and social interaction. Their mission is to make travel and trade easier and more efficient through the ports of entry between San Diego County and the Tijuana Metropolitan Area.
source_proposal: Proposal Social Entrepreneurship and Strategic Innovation.docx

name: San Diego Regional Policy & Innovation Center
description: The Policy & Innovation Center conducts world-class research, supports coordinated governmental and agency relationships, develops consensus regarding the region’s core needs, and recommends policy solutions to assist local leaders in attracting federal and state impact dollars and addressing regional issues such as improving critical infrastructure, creating stable high-paying jobs; and generating other measurable long-term socio-economic and environmental benefits. The Policy & Innovation Center supports recovery from the cascading economic effects of COVID-19 and meets the needs of underserved communities by attracting funding and resources to the region; working with local municipalities and regional agencies to co-design new programs and pursue federal recovery and infrastructure funding; crafting new policy solutions; and driving large-scale private partnerships and investment opportunities.

name: San Diego Regional Chamber of Commerce – Policy
description: The San Diego Regional Chamber of Commerce is committed to making San Diego the most business-friendly region in California. A strong economy creates jobs that support families, neighborhoods, and the entire region. Since the late 1800s, the Chamber has helped San Diego grow by engaging with elected officials, their members, and the public to address the issues most important to job creation and the region. Today, as much as ever, they are committed to an even better future for San Diego. San Diego and Imperial Small Business Development Center The San Diego and Imperial Small Business Development Center (SBDC) is a valuable resource for entrepreneurs and small business owners in the region. As part of the California SBDC network, they offer a wide range of services and support to help businesses succeed. The SBDC provides expert guidance through one-on-one consulting, training workshops, and access to valuable resources and networks. They assist with various aspects of business development, including business planning, marketing strategies, financial management, and accessing capital. The San Diego and Imperial SBDC plays a crucial role in fostering entrepreneurship, job creation, and economic growth by providing tailored assistance and empowering small businesses to thrive in a competitive market. Director of the SBDC, Briana Weisinger, has worked with hundreds of startups as well as opening and closing her own businesses, thus she understands the struggles related to small business ownership. Her personal missions include uplifting equality in the business world and working with multiple local organizations to promote women entrepreneurs. She believes in giving her time generously to these personal missions. She became director of the SBDC after a long and impressive repertoire in the field.

Founders First Capital Partners, LLC www.foundersfirstcapitalpartners.com/ FFCP gives women, minorities, & veteran business owners access to capital. The mission is to empower underserved groups of business owners by providing them with access to growth capital, expertise, and resources to enable them to build sustainable, profitable, and accretive legacy businesses. name: The City of San Diego’s Economic Development Department

The department offers various programs and initiatives, including business development assistance, workforce training, and access to funding opportunities. Two notable examples of their projects include the Business Acceleration Program, which provides tailored support to high-growth startups, and the Small Business Enhancement Program, which offers grants and resources to small businesses for expansion and improvement. Through their initiatives, the Economic Development Department actively supports entrepreneurship, job creation, and economic growth in San Diego. With the goal of promoting economic opportunity for all segments of the population, the City of San Diego leverages public incentives and assistance to foster community revitalization, attract new businesses and encourage investment in local businesses. The City of San Diego not only assists individual businesses but also helps strengthen business organizations and improve business districts throughout San Diego.

The SBA San Diego District offers a range of programs and services, with a particular emphasis on microlending. They collaborate with local microlenders to provide small loans to entrepreneurs and underserved communities, fostering economic development and job creation. The program has been modeled in over 50 regions worldwide. In 2019, Connect and San Diego Venture Group merged, combining the deep histories and wide successes of each organization to create a powerhouse of resources such as mentorship, education, and capital for quality companies.

description: The San Diego Regional Economic Development Corporation (EDC) is an independently funded economic development organization that mobilizes business, government, and civic leaders around an inclusive economic development strategy in order to connect data to decision making, maximize regional prosperity, enhance global competitiveness, and position San Diego effectively for investment and talent. The EDC provides resources, data analysis, and strategic insights to help businesses make informed decisions and navigate the local business landscape. They also engage in advocacy efforts to shape policies that promote economic development and create a favorable business environment.

description: Kitchens for Good is a 501(c)(3) and social enterprise with the mission to break the cycles of food waste, hunger, and poverty through innovative solutions in workforce training, healthy food production, and social enterprise. Kitchens for Good rescues surplus and cosmetically imperfect food from wholesalers and farmers and engages students in a culinary apprenticeship program. Through the power of kitchens and cooking, their students transform their lives from one of addiction, incarceration, homelessness, and unemployment, to lives of stability, employment, and a brighter future.

The chamber recognizes the importance of mentorship in fostering professional growth, providing guidance, and sharing industry expertise. Through their mentorship programs, they connect experienced business professionals with aspiring entrepreneurs or individuals seeking career advancement.

description: Steve Sivitz is a seasoned business professional and mentor at SCORE with over 35 years of experience in hi-technology mobile/wireless industries. He specializes in product definition, enhancement, and delivery, leveraging his expertise in sales strategies, product marketing, and business leadership. With a strong track record of success in improving corporate financial results and expanding product portfolios, Steve offers guidance in various areas including business planning, sales and marketing strategies, and technology. Recognized for his contributions to small business support, he received the Small Business Administration's District Director's Award in May 2022.                                                         	Meeting Focus: Discussions will focus on Steve's experience in product definition, enhancement, and delivery, emphasizing the importance of understanding market needs and problem-solving. Additionally, there will be an exploration of Steve's proficiency in sales strategies, business planning, and technology, offering guidance on developing effective business models and strategies for success. name: Mentoring Coalition of San Diego County
description: The Mentoring Coalition of San Diego County originated from a delegation's inspiration at the "President's Summit on Youth, America's Promise" in 1997, aiming to provide every child with a caring adult mentor. Since its establishment in 1998, the Coalition has fostered monthly networking meetings for program managers to share resources and knowledge, while also advocating for quality mentoring standards at the state level. Through numerous workshops and collaborative efforts, the Coalition continues to support and promote best practices among youth mentoring programs in the region, embodying a commitment to the well-being and development of young people.                                                           Meeting Focus: Meeting revolving around understanding mentorship in social entrepreneurship through engagements with the Mentoring Coalition of San Diego County, particularly focusing on its origins and evolution in providing mentorship to youth. Discussions will include insights gained from meetings with faculty and students at universities offering courses on social entrepreneurship, exploring how mentorship plays a crucial role in nurturing the next generation of social entrepreneurs. Additionally, there will be a focus on understanding the role of new and social media in driving social entrepreneurship through mentorships and other interactive exercises, aligning with the Coalition's commitment to promoting best practices and advocating for quality mentoring standards.

name: Torrey Project
description: The Torrey Project is an innovative initiative focused on empowering the next generation of entrepreneurs and leaders. They provide a platform for young individuals to develop essential skills, network with industry professionals, and gain real-world experience. Through mentorship programs, workshops, and entrepreneurial challenges, participants are equipped with the tools and knowledge needed to succeed in a rapidly changing business landscape. The Torrey Project fosters creativity, critical thinking, and collaboration, encouraging participants to think outside the box and pursue their passions. The Torrey Project Seed Fund is a vital component of the Torrey Project's mission to support and invest in promising startups and early-stage ventures. The seed fund provides crucial financial resources and mentorship to selected entrepreneurs, helping them turn their innovative ideas into successful businesses. The Torrey Project aims to invest in diverse founders and ventures that exhibit strong growth potential, disruptive ideas, and a commitment to making a positive impact. They seek out entrepreneurs with a drive for innovation, a clear vision for their business, and a scalable business model, and focus on supporting those who are typically overlooked by traditional forms of seed capital. The Torrey Project is particularly interested in supporting ventures in emerging industries such as technology, sustainability, healthcare, and social impact. Volunteer Activity

description: HandsOn San Diego vision is to create a thriving community where everyone is empowered to be an active participant in creating a positive change without barriers. Volunteers benefit because they witness first-hand how they are positively impacting the San Diego region. HandsOn San Diego is an affiliate of the Points of Light Global Network, which includes volunteer-mobilizing organizations located in nearly 40 countries around the world. They have been a Service Enterprise certified organization since 2018, engaging volunteers at every level. _______________________________ **Home Hospitality can be offered for the group, as well as a volunteer activity  ** Cafe 21 www.cafe-21.com/ As one of the most innovative restaurants in San Diego, Cafe21 is committed to changing the way their guests think about food. Everything they do at this Azerbaijani restaurant is made from scratch and with love. San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $46 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. It is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park. Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $27 for one Adult Ticket for two-hour tour Their deluxe tour covers it all: Harbor and Shelter Islands, Point Loma, Cabrillo National Monument, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and much more. The tour is about 25 miles in length, 2 hour narrated tour. Old Town Trolley Tour www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com www.trolleytours.com/san-diego Price: $36 for one Adult Ticket For over 20 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours highlighting the best San Diego attractions. Old Town Trolley Tours is the best way to see the city, highlighting the best San Diego Attractions, with 11 stops and more than 100 points of interest. Old Town offers much to do, from visiting over 23 historic sites to shopping for unique merchandise. They also have many award-winning restaurants to choose from. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 29 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 15 major museums, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Coronado Consistently voted one of America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year around due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. From the shores of Silver Strand State Beach to the tip of the Coronado Municipal Beach, you’ll find plenty of wide-open sand, gentle waves and gorgeous views.
