name: Academic Institutions
url: University of San Diego Institute for Civil Civic Engagement https://www.sandiego.edu/institute-for-civil-civic-engagement/
description: The Institute for Civil Civic Engagement (ICCE) is located at the University of San Diego, one of San Diego's leading tertiary institutions. ICCE works to encourage, promote and increase civility in civic discourse by fellow citizens and public officials, both interpersonally and in all manner of media. The institute seeks to promote ways to be civil in disagreements and respectful in debates, as they confront the political challenges that shape the community. Some of the ICCE's main goals include to encourage the San Diego community to embrace basic elements of civility in dealing with civic activism and political campaigning, to hold community leaders accountable to conducting public discourse, and to develop and implement programs and curriculum providing effective instruction in best methods of civil civic engagement for educational communities. Meeting focus: Meet with representatives of ICCE to explore initiatives including CivicTalk San Diego, Student Civility Awards, and Richard Nixon: The Musical. University of San Diego - Center for Peace & Commerce www.sandiego.edu/cpc/ The Center for Peace and Commerce (CPC) is a collaborative effort between the School of Business Administration and the Joan B. Kroc School of Peace Studies to prepare new generations of "change agents" who develop and exercise innovative approaches for achieving the 4 Ps- people, profit, planet and peace. CPC contributes to creating new enterprise paradigms and solutions that foster peace-building and poverty alleviation, through courses, scholarship, enterprise development, active engagement with multiple stakeholders and the promotion of good governance. Media and Journalism Voice of San Diego www.voiceofsandiego.org The mission of the Voice of San Diego is to consistently deliver ground-breaking investigative journalism for the San Diego region and to increase civic participation by giving residents the knowledge and in-depth analysis necessary to become advocates for good government and social progress. Voice of San Diego is a member-based nonprofit investigative news organization that gives concerned citizens the tools they need to engage in important conversations about their community. They are unlike any news outlet in San Diego because they dig deeper to uncover the truth and devote the time necessary to turn the chaos of news into a story people can access and understand. As a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization, they are fully funded by individual donors, major charitable gifts, foundations and community partnerships.

name: Inewsource

The organization helps the public better understand issues affecting them, their loved ones and their neighbors by cutting through complex narratives and data and reporting findings through inclusive, impactful journalism. description: The Commission serves as an advisory body to the Mayor, City Council, and City Manager on issues of interest to youth and pertaining to youth in the City of San Diego. Establishment of a City of San Diego Youth Commission will facilitate the participation of youth and young adults in local government, as well as provide City officials an opportunity to hear and address their ideas and concerns. To identify critical issues affecting youth in the City of San Diego and provide advice and recommendations to the Mayor, City Council, City Manager, and other City officials on issues affecting youth in the City of San Diego. Young Leaders

name: Randy Reyes at the City of San Diego
description: Randy Reyes serves as Mayor Todd Gloria’s Community Representative for Council Districts 2 and 5. In this role, he oversees community engagement and public relations for his assigned council districts and works closely with City staff to address concerns and issues raised by the public. Previously he worked for San Diego City Councilmember, Jennifer Campbell, as a Community Representative and Digital Communications Manager. Previous to that, Randy Reyes worked with the City of San Diego’s Office of Immigrant Affairs as a Communications and Outreach Fellow and before that he was an intern for the Mayor’s Office of Global Affairs. Randy graduated from the University of San Diego with his Bachelor’s and Master’s degrees in International Relations, as he was a part of their BA/MA Dual Degree program. Randy Reyes concentrated his studies on international security, Latin America, and great power competition. During his graduate studies, he co-authored, co-edited, and published a book offering advice to young professionals seeking internships in the field of international relations. Randy Reyes is the son of Mexican immigrants, is fluent in Spanish, and is a proud lifelong San Diego County resident.

He is also a founder of a non profit organization called Students for Attention, which champions inclusive education nationwide. As the youth ambassador for the San Diego International Sister Cities Association, Aaron contributed to building digital equity among Maasai youth in Kenya and also has garnered worldwide support for his role in addressing the United Nations Permanent Forum on Indigenous Issues. name: Youth Will
description: Youth Will is a community based organization located in San Diego, CA, that was founded as the Youth Development Office of San Diego in 2012. Their mission is to create a more equitable future for every individual under the age of 25 through community organizing, grassroots advocacy, and political reform. Very community oriented, Youth Will has created a Youth Bill of Rights, is focused on areas important to San Diego’s youth like housing, healthcare, environment, helping youth find gainful employment., and develops policy priorities and advocates for youth at the city and county level.
source_proposal: Proposal_ Engaging Youth in the Political Process.docx

name: International Rescue Committee (IRC) San Diego
description: The International Rescue Committee (IRC) helps people affected by humanitarian crises - including the climate crisis - to survive, recover and rebuild their lives. Founded at the call of Albert Einstein in 1933, the IRC is now at work in over 50 countries and in 28 U.S. cities to help people affected by humanitarian crises to survive, recover and rebuild their lives. The IRC also fights for a world where women and girls have an equal chance to succeed. As thousands of Afghan refugees have been resettled in California and across the U.S. since August 2021, the IRC in San Diego has been working to ensure that schools are equipped to support refugee youth.
source_proposal: Proposal_ Engaging Youth in the Political Process.docx

name: RISE San Diego
description: RISE San Diego is a non-profit organization focused on boosting the local community through active communication based on civic engagement, non-profit partnerships, and support to assist community members. Focused on urban areas, RISE San Diego wants to foster a safe and healthy environment for local youth and families. Their programs feature leadership and professional development in rising youth to help grow the neighborhoods of San Diego. This “neighborhoods first” agenda partners everyday people at grassroots level to solve and address complex urban issues. Incubators and Accelerators
source_proposal: Proposal_ Engaging Youth in the Political Process.docx

name: San Diego Young Republicans
description: The San Diego Young Republicans are committed to growing an inclusive, tax-opposing, limited-government-supporting group of individuals who love America. They see themselves as a counterpoint for the young, and young at heart, Republican movement in San Diego. The goal of the San Diego Young Republicans (SDYR) is to grow the Republican Party through volunteerism, education and leadership. They are committed to activating the next generation of party leadership by supporting fresh ideas and candidates and engaging young professionals in the political process.
source_proposal: Proposal_ Engaging Youth in the Political Process.docx

name: San Diego Young Democrats for Equality
description: San Diego Democrats for Equality is one of the largest Democratic Clubs in Southern California, and remains one of the oldest active LGBTQ+ organizations in the US. The organization aims to unify and organize everyone interested in supporting and furthering progressive democratic values guaranteed to all Americans. In 2016, San Diego Democrats for Equality chartered a youth chapter with the California Young Democrats. California Young Democrats is the official youth arm of the California Democratic Party made of young people aged 14-35 committed to activating the youth vote, empowering Young Democrats in their community, electing Democrats to office and building a new generation of progressive leadership. As a fully chartered chapter of California Young Democrats, members of San Diego Young Democrats for Equality have the opportunity to travel and participate in CYD conventions, retreats, and other Democratic campaigns across the state, engage with their local community, and develop their skills as young leaders and practitioners of Democratic values Young Professionals Council at the San Diego LGBT Center https://thecentersd.org/young-professionals-council/ The Center's Young Professionals Council (YPC) is a community of LGBTQ+ leaders and allies ages 21-40ish that offers opportunities for connection, career development, friendship, and power-building. YPC helps to advance The Center's twin goals of promoting LGBTQ+ health/wellness and human rights, and fosters a culture of diversity, leadership, advocacy, and camaraderie among its participants. The Academy expands the ranks of young people in the LGBTQ+ justice movement by enhancing their skills, broadening their network, and fostering transformative connections with other community leaders.
source_proposal: Proposal_ Engaging Youth in the Political Process.docx

name: The Children's Advocacy Institute (CAI)
description: The Children's Advocacy Institute (CAI), founded at the nonprofit University of San Diego School of Law in 1989, is one of the nation's premiere academic, research, and advocacy organizations working to improve the lives of children and youth, with special emphasis on improving the child protection and foster care systems and enhancing resources that are available to youth aging out of foster care. Through its offices in San Diego, Sacramento, and Washington, D.C., CAI seeks to leverage change for children and youth through impact litigation, regulatory and legislative advocacy, and public education. Active at the local, state, and federal levels, CAI’s efforts are multi-faceted — comprehensively and successfully embracing all tools of public interest advocacy to improve the lives of children and youth. Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).
source_proposal: Proposal_ Engaging Youth in the Political Process.docx

name: Chicano Park
description: Chicano Park is the geographic and emotional heart of Barrio Logan, located in Logan Heights, San Diego's oldest Mexican-American neighborhood. The park is home to the largest concentration of Chicano murals in the world with more than 80 paintings on seven acres dotted with sculpture, gardens, picnic tables, and playgrounds. Throughout the year, it hosts festivals of music and Aztec dance, the biggest being Chicano Park Day held each April. Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $30 for one Adult Ticket for a one-hour narrated tour (south bay or north bay routes); $35 for a full bay two-hour narrated tour which covers it all: ships of the Maritime Museum, Harbor and Shelter Islands, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and more. The full bay tour is about 25 miles in length. Accessibility: The tour begins and ends at the same location downtown along Broadway Pier. Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com Price: $44 for a 1-Day Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased online) For 30 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours, highlighting the best San Diego attractions. The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50 am – 5:00 pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $26 for one Adult General Admission Ticket ($1 discount when purchased on-line). Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom, and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10 am – 5 pm (Last admission at 4 pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside the Navy Pier.
source_proposal: Proposal_ Engaging Youth in the Political Process.docx

name: Border Field State Park & Friendship Park
description: https://www.friendshippark.org/ Located within the Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve, Border Field State Park sits in the very southwestern corner of the United States, 15 miles south of San Diego. This important wildlife habitat, consisting of sand dunes and salt marshes, gives refuge to critically threatened and endangered birds such as the Western Snowy Plover, the California Least Tern, and the Light-footed Ridgway's Rail. Friendship Park is a binational park located at the western end of the US-Mexico border. For generations, people have gathered here to meet up with friends and family "across the line." Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 17 major museums and cultural institutions, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens, and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).
source_proposal: Proposal_ Engaging Youth in the Political Process.docx

name: Coronado
description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year-round due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown. SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $99.99 for one Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased online) Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Orca Encounter, Dolphin Days, and Sea Lions Live shows and thrilling rides like Electric Eel, Manta, and Journey To Atlantis. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks, and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Hours vary by season. Also enjoy the opening of Sesame Place in March 2022, a Sesame Street-themed section of the park with new water, ride, and musical attractions. Accessibility: A 15-20-minute drive from downtown San Diego.
source_proposal: Proposal_ Engaging Youth in the Political Process.docx

name: University of San Diego
description: The University of San Diego (USD) is an academic institution with a student population of around 9,000. USD offers comprehensive education across its seven schools and colleges, particularly standing out for its emphasis on business development and entrepreneurship. The School of Business provides students with valuable resources, mentorship programs, and experiential learning opportunities, empowering them to thrive in the ever-evolving business landscape. In addition, the University of San Diego is renowned for its Joan B. Kroc School of Peace Studies, which offers innovative programs and initiatives dedicated to advancing peacebuilding, conflict resolution, and social justice on a global scale. Spark @ USD, Joan B. Kroc School of Peace Studies www.sandiego.edu/peace/institutes/ipj Dedicated to fostering peace, cultivating justice, and creating a safer world, the Joan B. Kroc Institute for Peace & Justice (IPJ) of the University of San Diego is an international nonprofit organization working to improve the lives of those caught in the web of armed conflict and human rights abuses. Existing within the Kroc School, Spark is an entrepreneurial hub that fosters innovation and supports aspiring student entrepreneurs. It provides a collaborative space where students can develop their entrepreneurial ideas, connect with mentors, and receive guidance to launch their ventures. Spark offers various resources, including workshops, networking events, and access to a strong network of industry professionals. One of the key meeting focus areas at Spark is social entrepreneurship, where students are encouraged to explore business ideas that address societal challenges and create positive impact.
source_proposal: Proposal_ Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: Master of Arts in Social Innovation
description: Look critically at the roots of social challenges and injustice, and then seek to create real change through bold new responses to poverty, inequality, human rights abuses and humanitarian crises. The Master's in Social Innovation degree is unlike any other in that it starts by diving deep into real social challenges, then pairs that knowledge with critical thinking, inventiveness, leadership and sustainable business design. Through the Social Innovation Challenge, university students in San Diego and Tijuana generate ideas for innovative ventures that respond to a social, economic, environmental, or justice issue of their choice, and compete for seed funding to launch or expand their ventures. Meeting focus: Discuss the university’s focus on social innovation and initiatives to welcome more young entrepreneurs into the space
source_proposal: Proposal_ Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: Fowler Global Social Innovation Challenge
description: The Fowler Global Social Innovation Challenge is an exciting competition hosted by the University of San Diego's Center for Peace and Commerce. It invites students from around the world to develop innovative solutions to pressing social and environmental issues. Participants form teams and undergo a rigorous process of ideation, prototyping, and refining their ideas with the guidance of mentors. The challenge culminates in a live pitch event where finalists present their solutions to a panel of judges and compete for funding and support. Since 2011, they have connected more than 2,500 students, recognizing their outstanding social ventures. They have also distributed more than $600,000 to seed innovative and promising global ventures.
source_proposal: Proposal_ Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: Brink Small Business Development Center
description: The Brink SBDC is a specialty center focused on innovation, one of only a handful of its kind in the country, hosted at University of San Diego. The Brink SDBC works with business clients running or starting growth-oriented, innovation-based companies with fewer than 500 employees. The Brink SBDC works with entrepreneurs with an innovative product, solution or service and has a larger than local addressable market and a scalable business model. Their expert advisors provide one-on-one consulting, training workshops, and access to valuable resources and networks. Whether it's developing a business plan, securing funding, or navigating regulatory requirements, the Brink SBDC assists entrepreneurs at every stage of their journey.
source_proposal: Proposal_ Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: Lavin Entrepreneurship Center, San Diego State University
description: The Lavin Entrepreneurship Center at San Diego State University (SDSU) is a dynamic hub that nurtures and supports aspiring entrepreneurs in their pursuit of innovation and business success. It serves students, entrepreneurs and business leaders through its entrepreneurial curriculum, workshops, internships, resources and events. The Center has developed diverse hands-on learning opportunities that complement and enrich entrepreneur education, enabling students to translate their knowledge into practice. Students experience the challenges of creating business plans, commercializing products and growing new ventures, all while building a diverse network of peers and mentors. The Lavin Center has been recognized for having one of the best entrepreneurial programs in the United States by both Princeton Review and Entrepreneur magazine. With a commitment to fostering an entrepreneurial mindset, the center offers a range of programs, resources, and workshops designed to equip students with the skills and knowledge needed to thrive in the modern business landscape. One of their popular workshops is on Digital Marketing and Social Media Strategies. This workshop dives into the realm of digital marketing, exploring effective tactics and strategies for utilizing social media platforms, creating engaging content, optimizing online advertising, and implementing search engine optimization (SEO) techniques. Participants gain insights into how to effectively leverage digital channels to reach target audiences, build brand awareness, drive customer engagement, and ultimately enhance their online presence.
source_proposal: Proposal_ Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: La Jolla Country Day School – Center for Design and Innovation
description: La Jolla Country Day School (LJCDS) is a private college prep school in the coastal community of La Jolla. The school’s Innovation Program challenges students to identify real-world problems and design innovative solutions to effect positive change for a better world. The curriculum from kindergarten to Grade 12 focuses on learning how to use cutting-edge tools and technologies while developing an understanding of the social impacts of technology, solutions and design. LJCDS’ Innovation Lab serves as a collaborative space that is equipped with a laser cutter (built from scratch by Upper School students), 3D printers, microcontrollers, Wacom tablets, drills, screwdrivers, hammers, sticky notes and anything else students may need for creative design and innovation. Additionally, LJCDS offers a venture capital fund for their students called the Torrey Explorer’s Fund (TEF). Whether students seek to start a business, launch a social campaign, invent a technology or create an art installation, TEF will offer mentorship by a team of local entrepreneurs and professionals and/or funding to help bring students’ ideas to fruition. University of California, San Diego
source_proposal: Proposal_ Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: Office of Innovation and Commercialization
description: https://techtransfer.universityofcalifornia.edu/Default.aspx?campus=SD&KeywordsOperator=All+terms&KeywordsUnformatted=medical&RunSearch=True&ShowDetail=False&SortASC=False&SortColumn=Rank UC San Diego is globally recognized as an innovation leader driving social and economic prosperity. Together with their campus partners, the Office of Innovation and Commercialization aligns resources to encourage and support an innovative community comprised of students, faculty, staff, alumni, and community advocates. Their mission is to accelerate the commercialization of UC San Diego innovations and contribute to a sustainable society by empowering a diverse entrepreneurial culture on campus and strengthening a dynamic innovation ecosystem. Incubators and Accelerators Hera Hub www.herahub.com Hera Hub is the first international female-focused coworking space – a shared, flexible work and meeting space where entrepreneurial women can create and collaborate in a professional, productive, modern environment. The platform provides members with connections to other business experts, access to educational workshops, and visibility within the community, thus giving women the support they need to be prosperous. In addition, Hera Fund gathers Angel Investors and pairs them with women owned businesses. The company was founded in San Diego, CA in 2011 and has since then been growing with locations sprouting up all over the U.S. and Europe. Meeting focus: How a coworking space has empowered women by addressing multiple community needs in San Diego. Representatives will give visitors a tour and discuss how Hera Hub empowers female entrepreneurs. San Diego Hispanic Chamber of e-commerce www.hiscec.com After realizing there was a digital gap between the Hispanic community and the business world, Tayde Aburto founded the Hispanic Chamber of e-Commerce eight years ago. The Chamber aims to empower small businesses run by Hispanics by enabling these businesses to become successful in e-commerce. The Hispanic Chamber of e-Commerce offers courses and consulting services throughout the County to educate small business owners as to the need to have, at the very least, a website, Facebook page, or LinkedIn account. What started as a small group of advocates is today an organization with more than a thousand members. Meeting focus: Learn how new digital technologies can impact the local and regional economic development of small business; Meet with small business owners using new digital technologies to help grow their activity.
source_proposal: Proposal_ Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: Vanguard Culture
description: Vanguard Culture San Diego is a dynamic nonprofit organization dedicated to advancing and celebrating the arts and culture scene in the region. Their mission is to provide a platform for emerging and established artists, curators, and arts organizations, fostering creativity and innovation. Through curated exhibitions, immersive events, and thought-provoking programs, Vanguard Culture nurtures connections between artists and diverse audiences, cultivating dialogue and engagement. They strive to empower artists, promote inclusivity, and contribute to the cultural vibrancy of San Diego. With a focus on interdisciplinary collaborations and community partnerships, Vanguard Culture plays a pivotal role in supporting and amplifying the local arts community's impact and visibility. Economic Development and Investment
source_proposal: Proposal_ Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: Smart Border Coalition
description: The Smart Border Coalition is a catalyst to bring together leading academic, business and civic communities from both sides of the San Diego/Tijuana International region to develop databases and policy positions, deliver special events and programs, and growth of the cross-border economy through jobs creation, workforce development and social interaction. Their mission is to make travel and trade easier and more efficient through the ports of entry between San Diego County and the Tijuana Metropolitan Area.
source_proposal: Proposal_ Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: San Diego Regional Policy & Innovation Center
description: The Policy & Innovation Center conducts world-class research, supports coordinated governmental and agency relationships, develops consensus regarding the region’s core needs, and recommends policy solutions to assist local leaders in attracting federal and state impact dollars and addressing regional issues such as improving critical infrastructure, creating stable high-paying jobs; and generating other measurable long-term socio-economic and environmental benefits. The Policy & Innovation Center supports recovery from the cascading economic effects of COVID-19 and meets the needs of underserved communities by attracting funding and resources to the region; working with local municipalities and regional agencies to co-design new programs and pursue federal recovery and infrastructure funding; crafting new policy solutions; and driving large-scale private partnerships and investment opportunities.
source_proposal: Proposal_ Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: San Diego Regional Chamber of Commerce – Policy
description: The San Diego Regional Chamber of Commerce is committed to making San Diego the most business-friendly region in California. A strong economy creates jobs that support families, neighborhoods, and the entire region. Since the late 1800s, the Chamber has helped San Diego grow by engaging with elected officials, their members, and the public to address the issues most important to job creation and the region. Today, as much as ever, they are committed to an even better future for San Diego. San Diego and Imperial Small Business Development Center The San Diego and Imperial Small Business Development Center (SBDC) is a valuable resource for entrepreneurs and small business owners in the region. As part of the California SBDC network, they offer a wide range of services and support to help businesses succeed. The SBDC provides expert guidance through one-on-one consulting, training workshops, and access to valuable resources and networks. They assist with various aspects of business development, including business planning, marketing strategies, financial management, and accessing capital. The San Diego and Imperial SBDC plays a crucial role in fostering entrepreneurship, job creation, and economic growth by providing tailored assistance and empowering small businesses to thrive in a competitive market. Director of the SBDC, Briana Weisinger, has worked with hundreds of startups as well as opening and closing her own businesses, thus she understands the struggles related to small business ownership. Her personal missions include uplifting equality in the business world and working with multiple local organizations to promote women entrepreneurs. She believes in giving her time generously to these personal missions. She became director of the SBDC after a long and impressive repertoire in the field.
source_proposal: Proposal_ Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: Torrey Project
description: The Torrey Project is an innovative initiative focused on empowering the next generation of entrepreneurs and leaders. They provide a platform for young individuals to develop essential skills, network with industry professionals, and gain real-world experience. Through mentorship programs, workshops, and entrepreneurial challenges, participants are equipped with the tools and knowledge needed to succeed in a rapidly changing business landscape. The Torrey Project fosters creativity, critical thinking, and collaboration, encouraging participants to think outside the box and pursue their passions. The Torrey Project Seed Fund is a vital component of the Torrey Project's mission to support and invest in promising startups and early-stage ventures. The seed fund provides crucial financial resources and mentorship to selected entrepreneurs, helping them turn their innovative ideas into successful businesses. The Torrey Project aims to invest in diverse founders and ventures that exhibit strong growth potential, disruptive ideas, and a commitment to making a positive impact. They seek out entrepreneurs with a drive for innovation, a clear vision for their business, and a scalable business model, and focus on supporting those who are typically overlooked by traditional forms of seed capital. The Torrey Project is particularly interested in supporting ventures in emerging industries such as technology, sustainability, healthcare, and social impact.
source_proposal: Proposal_ Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: The City of San Diego Economic Development Funding Programs, Small Business Enchacement Program (SBEP)
description: The City of San Diego’s The Economic Development Funding Program covers Economic Development and Tourism Support (EDTS) and Citywide Economic Development Support (CEDS), which allocate Transient Occupancy Tax (TOT) revenue to promote San Diego as a business and tourism destination; and the Small Business Enhancement Program (SBEP), which supports small business efforts Citywide and in Microdistricts. Founders First Capital Partners, LLC www.foundersfirstcapitalpartners.com/ FFCP gives women, minorities, & veteran business owners access to capital. The mission is to empower underserved groups of business owners by providing them with access to growth capital, expertise and resources to enable them to build sustainable, profitable, and accretive legacy businesses. Through a 10 – week “bootcamp” process entrepreneurs build a 5 year growth plan, receive funding, and receive acceleration support. Government Resources
source_proposal: Proposal_ Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: The City of San Diego’s Economic Development Department
description: The City of San Diego's Economic Development Department provides valuable resources and support to entrepreneurs and businesses, helping them succeed and contribute to the local economy. The department offers various programs and initiatives, including business development assistance, workforce training, and access to funding opportunities. Two notable examples of their projects include the Business Acceleration Program, which provides tailored support to high-growth startups, and the Small Business Enhancement Program, which offers grants and resources to small businesses for expansion and improvement. Through their initiatives, the Economic Development Department actively supports entrepreneurship, job creation, and economic growth in San Diego.With the goal of promoting economic opportunity for all segments of the population, the City of San Diego leverages public incentives and assistance to foster community revitalization, attract new businesses and encourage investment in local businesses. The City of San Diego not only assists individual businesses but also helps strengthen business organizations and improve business districts throughout San Diego.
source_proposal: Proposal_ Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: U.S Small Business Administration– San Diego District
description: https://www.sba.gov/funding-programs/loans/microloans The U.S. Small Business Administration (SBA) - San Diego District plays a crucial role in supporting small businesses in the region. In the past fiscal year, the San Diego District office provided significant support, including over $200 million in loans to small businesses, helping them access the capital needed to start, grow, and expand their ventures. The SBA San Diego District offers a range of programs and services, with a particular emphasis on microlending. They collaborate with local microlenders to provide small loans to entrepreneurs and underserved communities, fostering economic development and job creation. Through their efforts, the SBA San Diego District is instrumental in driving the success of small businesses and fueling economic growth in the community. Non-profit Resources
source_proposal: Proposal_ Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: San Diego Entrepreneurs Exchange
description: The San Diego Entrepreneurs Exchange (SDEE) is a nonprofit 501(c)(3) organization run by local entrepreneurs for entrepreneurs and pre-entrepreneurs interested in Life Sciences, Biotech, Pharma, Medical Devices, Tech and Alternative Energy. SDEE was founded to provide a voice and resources for early stage startups, to encourage new entrepreneurs, and sponsor networking and educational services to help develop skills necessary to bring new businesses and funding to the San Diego area.
source_proposal: Proposal_ Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: Connect
description: Connect is a non-profit organization that has assisted in the formation and development of more than 3,000 companies in the San Diego region, and is widely regarded as one of the world’s most successful organizations linking inventors and entrepreneurs with the resources they need for commercialization of innovative products in high tech and life sciences. The program has been modeled in more than 50 regions around the world. In 2019, Connect and San Diego Venture Group merged, combining the deep histories and wide successes of each organization to create a powerhouse of resources such as mentorship, education, and capital for quality companies.
source_proposal: Proposal_ Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: San Diego Regional Economic Development Corporation (EDC)
description: The San Diego Regional Economic Development Corporation (EDC) is an independently-funded economic development organization that mobilizes business, government, and civic leaders around an inclusive economic development strategy in order to connect data to decision making, maximize regional prosperity, enhance global competitiveness, and position San Diego effectively for investment and talent. The EDC provides resources, data analysis, and strategic insights to help businesses make informed decisions and navigate the local business landscape. They also engage in advocacy efforts to shape policies that promote economic development and create a favorable business environment.
source_proposal: Proposal_ Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: Women’s Empowerment International
description: Women's Empowerment International (WE) is a nonprofit organization dedicated to empowering women and girls in underserved communities around the world. Their mission is to create sustainable change by providing education, entrepreneurship training, and access to resources. WE believes that when women are given the tools and support to succeed, entire communities benefit. They work in collaboration with local partners to develop programs that address the unique challenges faced by women, including poverty, limited education, and lack of economic opportunities. Through their initiatives, WE aims to break the cycle of poverty, promote gender equality, and empower women to become leaders and change agents in their communities.Women’s Empowerment International (WE Center) STAR program (Support, Training and Assistance to Refugee) Women, a partnership between the International Rescue Committee (IRC) and WE, was created to provide a culturally sensitive setting for refugee and low-income women to receive assistance in starting or expanding a business.
source_proposal: Proposal_ Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: Kitchens for Good
description: Kitchens for Good is a 501(c)(3) and social enterprise with the mission to break the cycles of food waste, hunger, and poverty through innovative solutions in workforce training, healthy food production, and social enterprise. Kitchens for Good rescues surplus and cosmetically imperfect food from wholesalers and farmers, and engages students in a culinary apprenticeship program. Through the power of kitchens and cooking, their students transform their lives from one of addiction, incarceration, homelessness, and unemployment, to lives of stability, employment, and a brighter future.
source_proposal: Proposal_ Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: North San Diego Business Chamber
description: North San Diego Business Chamber is the only 5-star United States Chamber of Commerce accredited organization in San Diego County. North San Diego Business Chamber’s mission is to build vibrant communities through stronger commerce. It provides businesses with benefits designed to meet organizations’ current needs based on the economic climate and to help them succeed and grow, through offerings including a robust mentorship program. The chamber recognizes the importance of mentorship in fostering professional growth, providing guidance, and sharing industry expertise. Through their mentorship programs, they connect experienced business professionals with aspiring entrepreneurs or individuals seeking career advancement. Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).

Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10am – 5pm (Last admission at 4pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside Navy Pier.
source_proposal: Proposal_ Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: Border Field State Park & Friendship Park
description: https://www.friendshippark.org/ Located within the Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve, Border Field State Park sits in the very southwestern corner of the United States, 15 miles south of San Diego. This important wildlife habitat, comprised of sand dunes and salt marshes, gives refuge to critically threatened and endangered birds such as the Western Snowy Plover, the California Least Tern, and the Light-footed Ridgway's Rail. Friendship Park is a binational park located at the western end of the US-Mexico border. For generations people have gathered here to meet up with friends and family "across the line." Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 17 major museums and cultural institutions, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).
source_proposal: Proposal_ Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: Coronado
description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year around due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown. SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $99.99 for one Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Orca Encounter, Dolphin Days, and Sea Lions Live shows and thrilling rides like Electric Eel, Manta, and Journey To Atlantis. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Hours vary by season. Also enjoy the opening of Sesame Place in March 2022, a Sesame Street themed section of the park with new water, ride, and musical attractions. Accessibility: A 15-20-minute drive from downtown San Diego.
source_proposal: Proposal_ Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: California Department of Fish and Wildlife South Coast Region (CDFW)
description: The Mission of the California Department of Fish and Wildlife (CDFW) is to manage California's diverse fish, wildlife, and plant resources, and the habitats upon which they depend, for their ecological values and for their use and enjoyment by the public. The CDFW is guided by the Seven Strategic Initiatives that are: 1. Enhance communications, education and outreach, 2. Develop statewide land stewardship based upon resource needs, 3. Develop strong water resource management program, 4. Develop/enhance partnerships, 5. Improve regulatory programs, 6. Enhance organizational vitality by focusing on employees and internal systems, and 7. Expand scientific capacity.
source_proposal: SDDC Proposal - Conservation, Biodiversity Protection, and National Park Management.docx

name: Biodiverse SD by The City of San Diego
description: Biodiverse SD was developed to preserve a network of habitat and open space, protecting species and ecosystems that improve our quality of life. Biodiverse SD, which includes the City’s Multiple Species Conservation Program, protects 85 species, including endangered species like the California gnatcatcher and other species of concern unique to San Diego such as the western burrowing owl. This program was developed by the City in cooperation with wildlife agencies, property owners, developers, and environmental groups.  Biodiverse SD delineates core biological resource areas and corridors targeted for conservation, called the Multi-Habitat Planning Area (MHPA). Within the MHPA, limited development occurs to ensure the long-term habitat conservation plan for the 85 Covered Species addresses needs of multiple species and the preservation of natural vegetation communities. The goal of protecting these areas is to conserve this land in perpetuity and protect the region’s biodiversity. The City’s City Planning Department maintains and updates the Biodiverse SD Interactive Map (updates in progress), which allows people to see if your home is within or close to the MHPA by entering your address.
source_proposal: SDDC Proposal - Conservation, Biodiversity Protection, and National Park Management.docx

name: Multiple Species Conservation Program (MSCP) by the County of San Diego
description: The Multiple Species Conservation Program (MSCP) preserves San Diego's native habitats and wildlife for future generations. It works across political boundaries, providing a unique framework that balances region-wide conservation efforts with streamlined building regulations and permit processes to support healthy community growth. The MSCP ensures compliance with the Federal Endangered Species Act, State Endangered Species Act, and State Natural Communities Conservation Planning Act. The overall effect of the MSCP is that it provides for large, connected preserve areas that address a number of species needs at the habitat level rather than species-by-species or area-by-area. This creates a more efficient and effective preserve system that better protects rare, threatened, and endangered species in the region. Non Profit Organizations
source_proposal: SDDC Proposal - Conservation, Biodiversity Protection, and National Park Management.docx

name: Environmental Center of San Diego (ECO)
description: The Environmental Center of San Diego is a non-profit organization that envisions a community working together to protect and enhance San Diego’s natural environment through education, advocacy and direct action, and to ensure access to the coast where feasible. The organization’s goal is to protect and enhance the natural environment of San Diego through education, activism and direct action. ECO also provides programs to educate about special San Diego species, restore and ensure public access to the coast in La Jolla, San Diego, and advocates for protecting habitats.
source_proposal: SDDC Proposal - Conservation, Biodiversity Protection, and National Park Management.docx

name: WILDCOAST
description: WILDCOAST is an international team that conserves coastal and marine ecosystems and addresses climate change through natural solutions. The organization envisions a society in which ecologically sensitive and globally significant coastal and marine ecosystems and wildlife are conserved, restored and sustained for future generations. WILDCOAST’s programs establish new marine protected areas, deter poachers and build conservation capacity in local communities. It mitigates the impact of marine debris by organizing beach clean ups, pushing for strict legislation and creating new recycling markets. The organization is also helping to ensure the long term conservation of precious marine ecosystems and the diversity of wildlife found within them.
source_proposal: SDDC Proposal - Conservation, Biodiversity Protection, and National Park Management.docx

name: San Diego Zoo Wildlife Alliances
description: San Diego Zoo Wildlife Alliance is an international, nonprofit conservation organization that runs San Diego Zoo and San Diego Safari Park. The organization integrates wildlife health and care, science, and education to develop sustainable conservation solutions. It is committed to saving species worldwide by uniting our expertise in animal care and conservation science with our dedication to inspiring passion for nature. The San Diego Zoo Wildlife Alliances landed on eight conservation hubs located around the globe that will anchor the conservation work, driving more strategic outcomes for wildlife in these regions. These hubs represent areas where the organization is currently most invested, and therefore hope to have the greatest return on mission and vision. The hubs promote synergy and collaboration among internal and external partners and stakeholders. Academic Resources
source_proposal: SDDC Proposal - Conservation, Biodiversity Protection, and National Park Management.docx

name: Scripps Institution of Oceanography at UCSD
description: The Scripps Institution of Oceanography at UC San Diego is one of the most important centers for global earth science research and education in the world. Scripps scientists work to understand and protect the planet by investigating our oceans, Earth, and atmosphere to find solutions to our greatest environmental challenges. Scripps leads research in climate change impacts and adaptation, resilience to hazards, conservation and biodiversity, oceans and human health, national security, and innovative technology to observe the planet. Meeting focus: To discuss the cutting edge research that SIO does on every continent and every ocean to protect and proserve marine and aquatic ecosystems.
source_proposal: SDDC Proposal - Conservation, Biodiversity Protection, and National Park Management.docx

name: San Diego State University Coastal and Marine Institute (CMI)
description: The Coastal and Marine Institute (CMI) refers to the consortium of researchers, visiting scientists, students, and volunteers that work at the SDSU Coastal and Marine Institute Laboratory (CMIL). The CMIL was built in 2006 on a prime coastal site at the old Naval Training Center near the airport and San Diego Bay and was conveyed to SDSU by the City of San Diego for the purposes of functioning as a research facility for students and faculty. The mission of the CMIL is to perform basic and applied coastal research and to share our knowledge of the marine environment with the community. The Coastal and Marine Institute Laboratory (CMIL) is a powerful tool for San Diego State University (SDSU) scientists who are researching environmental problems up and down the coast of southern California, offering interdisciplinary solutions to coastal zone problems, with a focus on the San Diego region. The goals of CMIL are to perform research, to protect the coastal environment, and to educate scientists and students of San Diego. Incubators and Accelerators
source_proposal: SDDC Proposal - Conservation, Biodiversity Protection, and National Park Management.docx

name: End Extinction San Diego
description: End Extinction San Diego was formed in 2017 to prevent the extinction of local/native species. From the outset, End Extinction San Diego has been about creating and maintaining a wide and inclusive movement. This coalition unites organizations across the spectrum, from conservation non-profits to business partners to policymakers, and more. End Extinction San Diego has a rich collection of conservation organizations to diverse business and economic interests, to policymakers entrusted with the public good.
source_proposal: SDDC Proposal - Conservation, Biodiversity Protection, and National Park Management.docx

name: San Diego National Wildlife Refuge
description: The San Diego National Wildlife Refuge is not just a place for wildlife, but a refuge for the city-dwelling neighbors who surround it. Established in 1996 and at about 12,445 acres from the city of Jamul to communities in Spring Valley and eastern Chula Vista, the refuge is the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service’s contribution to the San Diego Multiple Species Conservation Program (MSCP), a landscape-wide habitat conservation plan to preserve habitat and species while allowing appropriate development. San Diego National Wildlife Refuge also offers one of the last expanses of open space in coastal southern California with exceptional biological, social, historical, and economic values and is protected as a sanctuary not just for plants and animals but also for people. Visitors have the opportunity to go hiking, biking, birding, and horseback riding as well as photograph endangered species and get a tour from a refuge ranger.
source_proposal: SDDC Proposal - Conservation, Biodiversity Protection, and National Park Management.docx

name: San Diego Audubon
description: San Diego Audubon is a chapter of the National Audubon Society, an organization founded in 1905 to stop the slaughter of wild birds for their feathers. The early Audubon Society engineered a series of legal victories, culminating in the Migratory Bird Act of 1913 that halted the plume trade and rescued many of the most beautiful birds that can be seen today from the brink of extinction. The organization’s mission is to defend the region's birds, unique biodiversity, and threatened habitats through advocacy, education, and restoration. San Diego Audubon members are dedicated to protecting and appreciating our local wildlife and their habitats. From the tidal flats of the Tijuana estuary to the fir stands on the crest of Palomar…from the foggy sycamore and oak groves of the coastal canyons to the sun-parched Borrego badlands, the organization actively works to preserve San Diego’s environment. Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).
source_proposal: SDDC Proposal - Conservation, Biodiversity Protection, and National Park Management.docx

name: Chicano Park
description: Chicano Park is the geographic and emotional heart of Barrio Logan, located in Logan Heights, San Diego's oldest Mexican-American neighborhood. The park is home to the largest concentration of Chicano murals in the world with more than 80 paintings on seven acres dotted with sculpture, gardens, picnic tables, and playgrounds. Throughout the year, it hosts festivals of music and Aztec dance, the biggest being Chicano Park Day held each April. Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $30 for one Adult Ticket for a one-hour narrated tour (south bay or north bay routes); $35 for a full bay two-hour narrated tour which covers it all: ships of the Maritime Museum, Harbor and Shelter Islands, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and more. The full bay tour is about 25 miles in length. Accessibility: The tour begins and ends at the same location downtown along Broadway Pier. Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com Price: $44 for a 1-Day Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased online) For 30 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours, highlighting the best San Diego attractions. The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50 am – 5:00 pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $26 for one Adult General Admission Ticket ($1 discount when purchased on-line). Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom, and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10 am – 5 pm (Last admission at 4 pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside the Navy Pier.

name: Pure Water San Diego
description: Pure Water San Diego is the City of San Diego's phased, multi-year program that will provide nearly half of San Diego's water supply locally by the end of 2035. The Pure Water San Diego Program will use proven water purification technology to clean recycled water to produce safe, high-quality drinking water. The Program offers a cost-effective investment for San Diego's water needs and will provide a reliable, sustainable water supply. Pure Water San Diego is the City’s 20-year program to provide a safe, reliable and drought-proof local drinking water supply for San Diego. The program uses proven water purification technology and is environmentally sustainable. It is also cost effective—it eliminates the need for expensive upgrades to the Point Loma Wastewater Treatment Plant.
source_proposal: Wastewater Reuse and Water Conservation.docx

name: East County Advanced Water Purification Project (AWP)
description: AWP stands for advanced water purification. It's a treatment process to turn recycled water into drinking water. The East County AWP is a partnership between Helix Water District, Padre Dam Municipal Water District, the City of El Cajon, and the County of San Diego to produce a sustainable water supply for East County. The participating agencies held a groundbreaking ceremony on June 1, 2022, to launch construction. There are three design and construction "packages" to fund and complete. A fourth package focuses on water treatment byproducts. East County AWP is expected to go online in 2026. The Program uses four advanced water purification steps to produce water that is near-distilled in quality. After treatment, the purified water will be blended with water in Lake Jennings and treated again at the R.M. Levy Water Treatment Plant before being distributed as drinking water
source_proposal: Wastewater Reuse and Water Conservation.docx

name: South Bay International Wastewater Treatment Plan
description: The SBIWTP is a 25 million gallon per day secondary treatment plant located in San Diego County, California, about 2 miles west of the San Ysidro Port of Entry. The plant treats sewage originating in Tijuana, Mexico and discharges it to the Pacific Ocean through the South Bay Ocean Outfall, a four and one-half mile long 11foot diameter pipe completed in January 1999. From here you can link to various informative pages about the SBIWTP located in San Ysidro, CA. The South Bay International Wastewater Treatment Plant (SBIWTP) was designed to deal with the growing demand for the treatment of wastewater resulting in the contamination of the Tijuana River in the United States. It has been an ongoing concern since 1934 when the International Boundary Commission (IBC) was instructed by the United States and Mexican governments to cooperate in the preparation of a report on the Tijuana sewage problem. The SBIWTP is capable of providing secondary treatment for 25 million gallons per day (mgd) average daily flows of sewage in excess of the Tijuana sewage system capacity but has expansion capability of up to 100 mgd. The SBIWTP was built on a 75-acre site near the international boundary in the U.S. immediately north of Tijuana's main wastewater pumping station. Resulting from the establishment of a binational interagency "Clean Water Partnership," the United States and Mexico approved IBWC Minute No. 283 dated July 8, 1990. This Minute authorized the construction of the SBIWTP. The Government of Mexico contributed $16.8 million toward construction of the SBIWTP and currently contributes $2.0 million toward the annual operation and maintenance costs. _______________________________ Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. name: City of San Diego Youth Commission
description: The Commission serves as an advisory body to the Mayor, City Council, and City Manager on issues of interest to youth and pertaining to youth in the City of San Diego. Youth and young adults are impacted by the decisions of City officials, but seldom have the opportunity to directly participate in the process. Establishment of a City of San Diego Youth Commission will facilitate the participation of youth and young adults in local government, as well as provide City officials an opportunity to hear and address their ideas and concerns. To identify critical issues affecting youth in the City of San Diego and provide advice and recommendations to the Mayor, City Council, City Manager, and other City officials on issues affecting youth in the City of San Diego. Community Resources
source_proposal: Youth and Civic Engagement 2025.docx

name: Reality Changers
description: Reality Changers serves youth who will be the first in their families to graduate from college. Our programs support students from racial, ethnic, socio-economic, and academic backgrounds that are typically underrepresented on college campuses and overlooked by institutions. In fact, before Reality Changers, many of our students may not have considered themselves "college material." Reality Changers champions and walks alongside first-generation college students as we work together towards education equity. We are accountable to the diverse communities that we serve and we actively affirm the dignity of all individuals.
source_proposal: Youth and Civic Engagement 2025.docx

name: Aaron Price Fellows Program
description: The mission of the Aaron Price Fellows Program is to prepare a highly motivated and diverse group of San Diego public high school students to be responsible, engaged and caring members of their community. An intensive three-year program teaches Fellows about government, cultural, business and non-profit institutions to illustrate their significance and relevance in their lives; exposes Fellows to exciting career opportunities; and foster friendships between Fellows from diverse ethnic, religious and economic backgrounds. Meeting focus: Learn about this unique, 3-year fellowship opportunity that cultivates youth to be active citizens, caring for their community and helping others. Dive deeper into the fellowship’s curriculum and its emphasis on educating fellows about cultural, business and non-profit institutions' significance.
source_proposal: Youth and Civic Engagement 2025.docx

name: Young Professionals Council at the San Diego LGBT Center
description: The Center’s Young Professionals Council (YPC) is a community of LGBTQ+ leaders and allies ages 21-40ish that offers opportunities for connection, career development, friendship, and power-building. YPC helps to advance The Center’s twin goals of promoting LGBTQ+ health/wellness and human rights, and fosters a culture of diversity, leadership, advocacy, and camaraderie among its participants. The Academy expands the ranks of young people in the LGBTQ+ justice movement by enhancing their skills, broadening their network, and fostering transformative connections with other community leaders. Schools and Academic Resource University of San Diego – Center for Peace & Commerce www.sandiego.edu/cpc/ The Center for Peace and Commerce (CPC) is a collaborative effort between the School of Business Administration and the Joan B. Kroc School of Peace Studies to prepare new generations of "change agents" who develop and exercise innovative approaches for achieving the 4 Ps– people, profit, planet and peace. CPC contributes to creating new enterprise paradigms and solutions that foster peace-building and poverty alleviation, through courses, scholarship, enterprise development, active engagement with multiple stakeholders and the promotion of good governance.
source_proposal: Youth and Civic Engagement 2025.docx

name: The Mulvaney Center for Cultural Awareness and Social Action
description: Through reciprocal community-based learning, the Mulvaney Center engages USD Students, faculty, staff, and alumni to learn and act in partnership with the community, making life-long commitments to promote social change and justice. The Mulvaney Center is a community, one that intentionally welcomes and celebrates students from diverse backgrounds, honoring the wisdom held in communities and striving to learn from and with them through reciprocal partnerships.
source_proposal: Youth and Civic Engagement 2025.docx

name: La Jolla Country Day School (LJCDS) Center for Excellence in Citizenship (CEC)
description: La Jolla Country Day School is an independent college-preparatory school serving students from age 3 through Grade 12 in San Diego’s coastal community of La Jolla. The Center for Excellence in Citizenship (CEC) develops unique opportunities for LJCDS students, faculty and families to engage in the vital work of local, national and global citizenship, focusing on the fundamental importance of human dignity in all interactions. CEC fosters civic engagement and civil discourse, galvanizing students to think about their rights and responsibilities as citizens and to be thoughtful participants in their communities. Non –Profit and Non-Governmental Organizations
source_proposal: Youth and Civic Engagement 2025.docx

name: Jacobs Center
description: The Jacobs Center for Neighborhood Innovation is a nonprofit organization based in Southeast San Diego that focuses on empowering residents, fostering inclusive economic development, and revitalizing historically underserved communities. With a mission rooted in community-driven change, JCNI works alongside local leaders, youth, entrepreneurs, and public-private partners to create opportunities for economic advancement and civic engagement. JCNI’s initiatives span workforce development, small business support, affordable housing, cultural arts, and youth leadership—creating a holistic model for neighborhood transformation. Through its Community Development Strategy, JCNI champions equity by addressing systemic barriers and co-creating solutions with community stakeholders.
source_proposal: Youth and Civic Engagement 2025.docx

name: RISE San Diego
description: RISE San Diego is a non-profit organization whose mission is to elevate and advance urban leadership through dialogue-based civic engagement, dynamic nonprofit partnerships, and direct training and support to increase the capacity of urban residents to effect meaningful community change. RISE San Diego is about developing the people within communities who make it happen. RISE Urban Leadership Fellows Program is a partnership of RISE San Diego and the Leadership Institute at the University of San Diego School of Leadership and Education Sciences (SOLES). RISE’s unique goal and commitment is to help identify and empower a generation of leaders who will not only bring our urban communities up, but also bring them together. Meeting focus: Explore RISE San Diego’s youth-focused grassroots civic engagement programs, non-profit training, and leadership development models, and the impact they have within the  San Diego community. Outside the Lens www.outsidethelens.org Outside the Lens empowers youth to use photography, filmmaking and digital media, catalyzing change within themselves, their community and their world, teaching people from a young age that participation in their community’s future makes a difference. Outside the Lens uses cameras and digital media along with a proven educational strategy that allows youth to think creatively, engage in issues that are important to them, and advocate for social change.
source_proposal: Youth and Civic Engagement 2025.docx

name: Youth Will
description: https://www.kpbs.org/news/2021/jun/15/new-city-office-aims-help-san-diego-youth-amidst-d/ Youth Will’s vision is to fight for every young person to have everything they need to be happy, healthy and prepared to reach their full potential. Their strategies include building youth power, improving youth development, and demanding youth prioritization. It is the only regional organization where young people from the north, south, east, and west unite to drive the change they seek. They envision a youth-led movement by elementary to university students, young adults transitioning out of foster care and formerly incarcerated youth, and everyone in between. Workshops and Leadership Development Sessions
