SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $99.99 for one Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Orca Encounter, Dolphin Days, and Sea Lions Live shows and thrilling rides like Electric Eel, Manta, and Journey To Atlantis. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Hours vary by season. Also enjoy the opening of Sesame Place in March 2022, a Sesame Street themed section of the park with new water, ride, and musical attractions. Accessibility: A 15-20-minute drive from downtown San Diego.
source_proposal: 6 - The Institutional Response to Domestic Violence.docx

name: Grid Alternatives
description: GRID Alternatives was founded by Erica Mackie and Tim Sears, two engineering professionals, in 2001 during the California energy crisis. GRID Alternatives envisions a rapid, equitable transition to a world powered by renewable energy, which benefits everyone through building community-powered solutions that advance economic and environmental justice. GRID developed a model to make solar PV technology practical and accessible for low-income communities while also opening new job opportunities. Their Energy for All Program offers single-family, multifamily, and community solar installation services, project development and technical assistance, and service-learning opportunities. In California, GRID is a statewide program administer for the Single-Family Affordable Solar Homes program, the Disadvantaged Communities – Single-Family Solar Homes program, and the solar portion of the Low-Income Weatherization Program.
source_proposal: 6- Approaches to Climate Change Challenges.docx

name: Climate Action Campaign
description: Climate Action Campaign’s mission is to stop the climate crisis through effective policy action. The Climate Action Campaign (CAC) was founded in San Diego in 2015, by Nicole Capretz, to ensure the City of San Diego’s draft landmark Climate Action Plan (CAP) became law, which Nicole authored while working in the mayor’s office. A broad-based and non-traditional coalition of elected officials, businesses, community planning groups, civic organizations, labor unions, and environmental and social justice organizations emerged, unified behind the trailblazing plan to make up the CAC. Through the lens of equity and justice, the CAC fights for a Zero Carbon future with all-electric homes, world class transit, resiliency, 100% clean energy, and bike able, walkable neighborhoods. CAC understands how the impacts of climate change are not felt equally across all communities because it impacts working class communities of color first and worst.
source_proposal: 6- Approaches to Climate Change Challenges.docx

name: Climate Equity in the San Diego Region
description: Climate Equity in the San Diego Region was developed at the University of San Diego Energy Policy Initiatives Center. The Climate Equity Index was first released in 2019 and evaluated environmental, socioeconomic, mobility, and health factors related to the impact of climate change and related policies. Climate equity is defined as “addressing historical and inequities suffered by people of color, allowing everyone to fairly share the same benefits and burdens from climate solutions and attain full and equal access to opportunities regardless of one’s background and identity.” The Index intended to assess the impact climate change will have on certain communities and the barriers to new energy technologies.
source_proposal: 6- Approaches to Climate Change Challenges.docx

name: Fonna Forman - University of California, Climate Change, Policy and Political Science
description: Forman is a Professor of Political Science and the Founding Director of the Center on Global Justice at UCSD. Forman’s research engages the intersection of urban policy and the city with a focus on climate justice. Research includes an investigation of climate risk and vulnerability in California’s underserved communities. Forman blurs the conventional boundaries of theory and practice and co-leads a variety of urban research agendas and civic/public interventions in the San Diego-Tijuana border region and beyond. Volunteer Organizations
source_proposal: 6- Approaches to Climate Change Challenges.docx

name: San Diego 350
description: https://sandiego350.org/teams/youth4climate/ San Diego 350 is an inclusive volunteer organization building a movement to prevent the worst impacts of climate change and climate injustice. San Diego 350 strives to create a future that supports a livable planet and just society through education and outreach, public policy advocacy, and mobilizing people to act. San Diego 350 envisions an informed, mobilized, and united community that is empowered to reduce their carbon footprint and hold their elected officials accountable to create a low-carbon, sustainable, and just world. San Diego 350 has organized San Diego’s largest climate mobilizations, including the 5,500-person “People’s Climate March,” in April 2017, and the climate walkouts in 2019. San Diego 350 has additionally created Youth4Climate (Y4C), which empowers youth activists with climate change education, skill building, leadership, and activism opportunities. Y4C facilitates programming centered on developing youth leaders and includes an annual Youth Climate Action Summit, summer programs, and after school programs.
source_proposal: 6- Approaches to Climate Change Challenges.docx

name: I Love a Clean San Diego
description: As San Diego’s longest running environmental nonprofit, I Love A Clean San Diego (ILACSD) is a pioneering leader in encouraging environmental awareness close to home. Through recycling, education, and cleanups of San Diego’s most beloved areas, ILACSD is the only community-based organization dedicated to the future of the entire county – from inland to the coast. While most known for its beach cleanups, ILACSD is deeply committed to serving its mission – educating the community to actively conserve and enhance the environment. ILACSD prioritizes practical solutions rather than rhetoric, which is often seen in the variety of programs offered: Environmental Education, WasteFreeSd.org, and Community Cleanups. Environmental Education is centered on providing hands-on learning for children, teens, and adults to learn about recycling, waste education, resource conservation, and pollution control.
source_proposal: 6- Approaches to Climate Change Challenges.docx

name: Environmental Health Coalition
description: The Environmental Health Coalition (EHC) is dedicated to achieving environmental and social justice. The EHC believes justice is accomplished by empowering communities to act together to make social change. The EHC strives to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and air pollution, create clean and affordable public mass transportation, increase public investments in environmental justice, improve children’s health, and maintain and create healthy communities. Climate justice is one of the EHC’s main focuses. The EHC stands with people and communities in creating climate solutions. Climate justice emphasizes how people and communities are the least responsible for warming the planet yet are most at risk for experiencing the impacts of climate change. The EHC echoes that the people most impacted by the climate crisis need to be part of deciding the solution. Meeting focus: Learn about how the EHC empowers communities to come together to create change and environmental justice. Expand on strategies of how to engage volunteer networks and extend public outreach. Hold a workshop on understanding climate justice and the role of creating community networks in achieving climate justice. Environmental Organizations
source_proposal: 6- Approaches to Climate Change Challenges.docx

name: San Diego Coastkeeper
description: The San Diego Coastkeeper was founded in 1995 and originally intended to combat the systematic pollution of the San Diego Bay. Today the San Diego Coast Keeper advocates, educates, and engages with communities across San Diego County to address a multitude of water challenges. As the voice for San Diego’s rivers, streams, and coastline, the San Diego Coastkeeper fights to protect and restore the San Diego waterways for the communities and wildlife that depend on them. This mission is accomplished through promoting legislation to improve stormwater health, holding polluters accountable, educating San Diego’s students about watershed and wildlife, and sending trained volunteers to collect water samples. The San Diego Coastkeeper believes smart, effective, science-based laws and policies are crucial to maintaining the health of the environment. With two decades of advocacy experience, the San Diego Coastkeeper has been at the forefront of advocating for laws, permits, regulations, and policies to protect and restore San Diego’s water. The San Diego Coastkeeper has engaged with state law makers to pass groundbreaking water conservation and efficiency legislation.
source_proposal: 6- Approaches to Climate Change Challenges.docx

name: Controlled Thermal Resources
description: Controlled Thermal Resources combines direct lithium extraction with renewable geothermal power to set new benchmarks to provide renewable energy to the western U.S. and to deliver the most sustainable, battery-grade lithium products in the world today. Demand for lithium, which is used in batteries and energy storage systems to power cars, cities, and countries, is expected to surge by approximately 2 million tons per annum by 2030. Controlled Thermal Resources’ leadership team has successfully developed and managed world-scale renewable energy projects in the Salton Sea region for over 20 years.
source_proposal: 6- Approaches to Climate Change Challenges.docx

name: Nuvve project with Cajon Valley Unified School District and San Diego Gas & Electric
description: https://www.sdgenews.com/article/sdge-and-cajon-valley-union-school-district-flip-switch-regions-first-vehicle-grid-project Combining the world’s most advanced vehicle-to-grid (V2G) technology and an ecosystem of electrification partners, Nuvve dynamically manages power among EV batteries and the grid to deliver new value to EV owners and support the world’s transition to clean energy. By transforming EVs into mobile energy storage assets and networking battery capacity to support shifting energy needs, Nuvve is making the grid more resilient, enhancing sustainable transportation, and supporting energy equity in an electrified world. In July 2022, San Diego Gas & Electric, Nuvve, and Cajon Valley Union School District announced they had successfully deployed an innovative technology, enabling eight electric school buses to put electricity back on the grid when needed.
source_proposal: 6- Approaches to Climate Change Challenges.docx

name: Sempra
description: Sempra Energy is a global energy infrastructure company focused on leading the way of advancing electrification and promoting energy diversification, resiliency, and affordable access to cleaner forms of energy. From its San Diego headquarters to operations throughout the Americas, Sempra Energy is making strides in developing forward-thinking energy solutions and delivering everyday power to customers. Sempra Energy believes the global energy ecosystem is going to change dramatically over the next 30 years. In advanced economies, the change will take the form of innovation and technology, which improves energy efficiency and supports a shift toward new, smart renewable and natural gas infrastructure. In developing nations, improving energy diversity will be the central effort as new, smart infrastructure supports renewables and natural gas displaces higher carbon forms of energy. Government Organizations
source_proposal: 6- Approaches to Climate Change Challenges.docx

name: City of San Diego Department of Sustainability
description: The Sustainability and Mobility Department leads San Diego's Climate Action Plan. Centered on striving for equitable, efficient, and effective mobility choices that support all communities, the Department continuously works to facilitate innovative efforts to enhance equitable, economic, social and environmental sustainability. The 2022 Climate Action Plan established a community-wide goal of net zero by 2035, committing San Diego to reducing the use of greenhouse gasses. Additionally, the Climate Action Plan will facilitate job creation in the renewable energy industry, improve air quality in turn improving public health, conserve water, use existing resource more efficiently, increase clean energy, improve quality of life, ad save taxpayer money.
source_proposal: 6- Approaches to Climate Change Challenges.docx

name: The County of San Diego Green Building Incentive Program
description: The purpose of the Green Building Incentive Program is to encourage homeowners and builders to build using environmentally sound practices. This program is in line with the County’s Strategic Plan which has established goals of safeguarding the San Diego environment, quality of life, and encouraging responsible development. The County of San Diego Green Building Incentive Program is designed to promote energy efficiency, natural resource conservation, and water conservation in new and remodeled residential and commercial buildings. Eligible participants can benefit from program incentives that, along with the potential for long-term savings, make building green a viable alternative to traditional construction. Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve

name: (Overseen by California State Parks and the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service)
description: https://trnerr.org/ The Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve preserves one of the largest remaining examples of coastal wetland habitats in southern California. Located in Imperial Beach, CA, the reserve is situated in a highly urbanized location and is immediately adjacent to Tijuana, Mexico. Three quarters of the reserve's watershed is in Mexico, so reserve programs apply an international perspective to critical issues of habitat restoration, endangered species management, wastewater from Mexico, sediment management, and recreational use. Meeting focus: During a walking tour of the reserve, explore international environmental laws and regulations. Discuss best practices for protecting and conserving international, biodiverse landscapes.
source_proposal: 6- Approaches to Climate Change Challenges.docx

name: California Coastal Commission San Diego Coast District
description: https://www.coastal.ca.gov/contact/#/ The California Coastal Commission (CCC) is tasked with protecting and enhancing California’s coast and ocean for present and future generations. The CCC was established by voter initiative in 1972 and later made permanent by the legislature through the California Coast Act of 1976. The CCC conducts careful planning and regulation of environmentally sustainable development, science, public participation, and education, and effective intergovernmental coordination. The CCC works in partnership with cities and counties around California in order to regulate use of land and water in the coastal zone. Academic Organizations
source_proposal: 6- Approaches to Climate Change Challenges.docx

name: San Diego Regional Climate Collaborative, University of San Diego (USD) School of Leadership and Educational Sciences (SOLES)
description: The San Diego Regional Climate Collaborative (SDRCC) was established as a network for public agencies to advance climate change solutions that mitigate greenhouse gas emissions and adapt to the effects of climate change. Partnering with academia, non-profits, and business and community leaders, the SDRCC raises the profile of regional leadership, shares expertise, and leverages resources. The SDRCC is currently working on ‘Equinox Project’s Quality of Life Dashboard’ which asks the question; is San Diego’s quality of life improving? A large part of what SDRCC looks at in measuring quality of life are environmental trends, particularly air quality, to ensure San Diego County is on a path to greater health, wealth, comfort and sustainability for current and future generations. Meeting focus: Discuss the current climate and environmental state of San Diego. Examine how power generation, transportation, building and construction, and manufacturing in San Diego contribute to the quality of life. Determine what strategic action plans the SDRCC is taking to advance climate change solutions.
source_proposal: 6- Approaches to Climate Change Challenges.docx

name: Scripps Oceanography Institute
description: The Scripps Oceanography Institute (SIO) at the University of California San Diego is one of the oldest and most well-known centers for ocean and earth science research, public service, and training in the world. SIO works to understand and protect the planet through finding solutions for the environmental challenges. SIO research includes climate change impacts, resilience to hazards, human health and the oceans, innovative technology, polar science, biodiversity and conservation, and national security. Hundreds of scientists use and conduct research with the Scripps Oceanography Institute. Most recently, SIO partnered with the University of Washington to conduct research on how different water densities interact in the ocean. The research included the release of environmentally safe pink dye into the ocean to monitor what occurs when fresh water coincides with ocean currents.
source_proposal: 6- Approaches to Climate Change Challenges.docx

name: David Victor, PhD - University of California, San Diego
description: Dr. David Victor is a professor of innovation and public policy at the School of Global Policy and Strategy at UC San Diego. He is the Co-Director of the campus-wide Deep Decarbonization Initiative which focuses on real world strategies bringing the world to nearly zero emissions of warming gasses. His research is at the intersection of climate change science and policy where he focuses on regulated industries and how regulation affects the operation of major energy markets. He authored Global Warming Gridlock which explains why the world has not made diplomatic progress on the problem of climate change while also exploring more effective new strategies. Dr. Victor is also a non-resident senior fellow at The Brookings Institution. He is a member of the World Economic Forum’s Global Future Council on Energy, where his work focuses on the role of natural gas as a transition fuel to deep decarbonization.
source_proposal: 6- Approaches to Climate Change Challenges.docx

name: Chabad of Poway Synagogue
description: Chabad of Poway has become a popular center for Jews of all backgrounds who want to learn more about their Jewish roots. Chabad offers a wide variety of educational and spiritual opportunities, including Torah classes and lectures, Shabbaton dinners, and an array of family and social activities. Traditional Jewish values are brought to life in a joyous, non-judgmental atmosphere. Chabad serves all segments of the Jewish community. Everyone is welcome regardless of their personal level of religious observance. The philosophy is in keeping with the Chabad-Lubavitch approach of joy, scholarship and unconditional acceptance and love for every Jew. Chabad experiences a horrific hate crime in 2019, that resulted in one death, and injuring three others including a rabbi. Chabad of Poway offers an abundance of educational classes for the community to learn about Jewish culture.

name: Jewish Family Service
description: https://www.jfssd.org/our-services/economic-mobility/black-womens-resilience-project/ Jewish Family Service is a client-centered, impact-driven organization working to build a stronger, healthier, more resilient San Diego. Founded in 1918, they are one of San Diego’s most impactful non-profit human services agencies. During the last fiscal year they served more than 71,000 individuals, including more than 14,000 children and 12,400 older adults.  Jewish Family Services offers a wide range of programs to help with anti-semantic hate and to strive towards a safer community. Black Women’s Resilience Project The goal of the Black Women’s Resilience Project (BWRP) is to support and advance culturally relevant strategies to shift human services delivery models for Black women facing the violence of poverty. Through this program, we seek to understand the racial and ethnic experience of poverty as a social construct, rather than a character deficit, and actively develop solutions to eliminate it.

name: Alliance San Diego
description: https://www.alliancesd.org/what_we_do Alliance San Diego is a community organization whose mission is to build collective power to create an inclusive democracy. They believe that by working together to engage effectively in the civic process, they can make systemic change and shape a future that belongs to all of us. Alliance San Diego builds power by developing leaders, engaging communities, advocating for policies, protecting civil and human rights, and communicating strategically.
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism - Community Strategies.docx

name: Partnership for the Advancement of New Americans (PANA)
description: Partnership for the Advancement of New Americans (PANA) focused on ending systematic racism for the Muslim community through civic engagement, tenant protection, policy and campaigns in which they have passed through the City Council the Source of Income Anti-Discrimination ordinance. PANA is founded, led, and staffed by refugees, which makes PANA as an organization uniquely situated to use relational organizing to bring community into a pathway of ongoing engagement and indigenous community leadership development. Meeting focus: learn PANA’s efforts in ending systematic racism for Muslims in San Diego through civic engagement, tenant protection, policy and campaigns.
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism - Community Strategies.docx

name: San Diego Immigrant Rights Consortium (SDIRC)
description: San Diego Immigrant Rights Consortium (SDIRC) is a coalition of various organizations in San Diego that work to protect the rights and dignity of immigrants and refugees. They may also address issues related to hate and discrimination. SDIRC works at all levels; federal through their New Border Vision framework which upholds the dignity and rights of all people at US’s borders, State by monitoring local law enforcement agencies and local to push local measures and resources such as their new campaign “Welcoming San Diego”.
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism - Community Strategies.docx

name: ADL Fighting Hate For Good
description: https://sandiego.adl.org/news/repair-plan-fighting-hate-in-the-digital-world/ ADL San Diego has been the leader in fighting anti-Semitism, and bigotry of all kinds, for over 40 years in America’s Finest City. ADL has expertise in the fields of investigating and monitoring extremism, anti-bias education, and communal security. Each year ADL Serves tens of thousands of local students, educators, and parents through their award-winning education programs, like No Place for Hate®, designed to reduce bias on campus. ADL is on forefront of training local law enforcement in Managing Implicit Bias, designed to reduce the influence of bias on interactions and decision-making, improve police-community relations, build mutual respect and trust, and increase overall safety for officers and civilians. ADL responds to hundreds of anti-Semitic incident reports from community members, working to help victims in the aftermath of hate. In addition, ADL provides local Jewish institutions with security briefings and best practices for safety in an effort to keep all members of the community safe from acts of hate. Lastly, ADL builds coalitions with partner organizations throughout San Diego County to find meaningful solutions to important issues facing our diverse communities. REPAIR Plan ADL’s REPAIR Plan focuses on fighting domestic extremism and terrorism, but goes beyond these issues to address other manifestations and harms of online hate, including harassment, antisemitism, anti-Muslim bigotry, racism and extremist disinformation. Repair stands for Regulation and reform, enforcing at scale, people over profit, access to justice, Interrupting disinformation, Research and innovation. Academic Resource
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism - Community Strategies.docx

name: University of San Diego,  Joan B. Kroc Institute for Peace and Justice
description: https://www.sandiego.edu/peace/institute-for-peace-justice/violence-inequality-power-lab/ The Joan B. Kroc Institute for Peace and Justice (Kroc IPJ) launched in 2001 with a vision of active peacebuilding. In 2007, the Kroc IPJ became part of the newly established Joan B. Kroc School of Peace Studies, a global hub for peacebuilding and social innovation. The core of the Kroc IPJ mission is to co-create learning with peacemakers — learning that is deeply grounded in the lived experience of peacemakers around the world, that is made rigorous by our place within a university ecosystem and that is immediately and practically applied by peacemakers to end cycles of violence. The Violence, Inequality and Power Lab (VIP Lab) At the Violence, Inequality, and Power (VIP) Lab, we seek to understand how inequalities of power shape the landscape of violence. We deliver practical, actionable ideas that partners can implement at the systems level to confront harmful power inequalities and reduce violence.

name: Aaron Price Fellows Program
description: The mission of the Aaron Price Fellows Program is to prepare a highly motivated and diverse group of San Diego public high school students to be responsible, engaged and caring members of their community. An intensive three-year program teaches Fellows about government, cultural, business and non-profit institutions to illustrate their significance and relevance in their lives; exposes Fellows to exciting career opportunities; and foster friendships between Fellows from diverse ethnic, religious and economic backgrounds. Meeting focus: Learn about this unique, 3-year fellowship opportunity that cultivates youth to be active citizens, caring for their community and helping others. Possible youth interaction. Barrio Logan College Institute www.blci.org Barrio Logan College Institute is located in Barrio Logan, a part of the San Diego community that is rich in culture but underserved in resources. Their mission is to break the cycle of poverty by preparing students to be the first in their families to go to college through after school programs that begin in third grade. Located in a traditionally low-income community, BLCI promotes higher education as a ticket out of poverty. To date, 100% of Barrio Logan College Institute’s students have enrolled in college. Government / Law Enforcement Programs

name: Youth Voice San Diego
description: Youth Voice is a youth leadership program held at the Mid-City Police Division weekly. Law enforcement, university interns and community based organizations partner with the goal of providing youth with mentoring and opportunities to positively support their leadership development. Youth Voice focuses on Connection with Self, Connection with Others, Connection with Community, and Connection with Law Enforcement. The voluntary mentoring program is supported by Mid-City Division's Juvenile Services Team and connects youth to themselves, their homes, schools, and communities through trauma informed - resilience building curriculum development.
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism - Community Strategies.docx

name: The City of San Diego, Gang Intervention Unit
description: The Gang Intervention Unit has a unique role within the San Diego Police Department and the community of San Diego. Officers are involved in educating youth about the dangers of gang involvement and aims to reduce juvenile gang initiation and participation through community engagement and other strategies. Gang Resistance Education and Training (G.R.E.A.T.) Program The G.R.E.A.T. program is intended to help with delinquency, deter youth violence and gang membership. Officers work with elementary and middle schools throughout San Diego to provide this educational opportunity. After School and Summer Sports Programs The Gang Intervention Unit partners with local fitness and sports programs to teach young San Diegans sports skills such as soccer, basketball and baseball. This builds confidence and encourages youth to stay healthy and active. Youth Boxing Program SDPD partners with a local boxing gym to offer a free boxing program for youth ages 14-18, who are ready to make changes to their lives and are committed to a team environment. Training takes place three days per week and the Gang Intervention Unit provides transportation to and from classes. Many of the participants of this program have successfully completed their education and found employment. Tattoo Removal Tattoo removal is an integral part of leaving behind gang life. In collaboration with the San Diego District Attorney’s Office, SDPD assists individuals in removing their tattoos for free. An interview is needed prior to acceptance into the program. This program is also open to victims of Human Trafficking. One-on-One Mentorship One on one mentorship and program referral is available with one of SDPD’s experienced gang intervention officers. These officers have access to many community organizations that can assist youth with finding success and achieving their goals. Families in Motion Family input is essential, and the City of San Diego’s Gang Prevention Unit encourage participation from parents and guardians in any intervention program, including their Families in Motion classes that run for five weeks, multiple times per year.
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism - Community Strategies.docx

name: The San Diego Police Department’s Volunteers in Policing (VIP)
description: The San Diego Police Department’s Volunteers in Policing (VIP)’s program offers a unique opportunity for citizen volunteers to become actively involved in providing efficient, effective, and responsive service to our community. The Volunteer Services Administration is dedicated to providing an exciting, challenging, and meaningful work environment. The use of volunteers includes Crisis Interventionists, Retired Senior Volunteer Patrols, and Volunteers in Policing, Reserve Officers, Assist in conducting follow-up research, verifying reports, making phone calls to witnesses and victims, taking police reports over the phone of minor and "no suspect" crimes, completing police crime reports, answering phones, filing and other office tasks. Retired Senior Volunteer Patrol (R.S.V.P.) Program Assist in providing an increased level of crime prevention programs within specific geographic areas, perform vacation house checks and ‘You Are Not Alone’ welfare checks, and promote community awareness and acceptance of R.S.V.P. program. Qualifications for this program are, you must be 50 years of age or older, interest in working with law enforcement officers, effective oral and written communication skills, reliable and trustworthy with confidential information, in good health, valid California Driver's License.
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism - Community Strategies.docx

name: National Gang Center (NGC)
description: The National Gang Center (NGC) is a project funded by the Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention (OJJDP), the Office of Justice Programs (OJP), U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ). The NGC is an integral component of the Justice Department’s mission to provide innovative leadership in coordination with federal, state, local, and tribal justice systems to prevent and reduce crime. The NGC disseminates information, knowledge, and outcome‐driven practices that engage and empower those in local communities with chronic and emerging gang problems to create comprehensive solutions to prevent gang violence, reduce gang involvement, and suppress gang‐related crime. The Gang Resistance Education And Training (G.R.E.A.T.) Program Program is a school‐based, law enforcement officer‐instructed classroom curriculum. The program, whose primary objective is prevention, is intended as an immunization against delinquency, youth violence, and gang membership. G.R.E.A.T. lessons focus on providing life skills to students to help them avoid delinquent behavior and violence to solve problems.
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism - Community Strategies.docx

name: Site Visit at Richard J. Donovan Correctional Facility (RJD)
description: The Mission at Richard J. Donovan Correctional Facility (RJDCF) is a multi-mission institution: RJDCF’s primary mission is to provide housing for General Population and SNY, Level I, II, III & IV inmates serving their term of incarceration at RJDCF. Additionally, RJDCF provides health care services and rehabilitative programs to inmates while incarcerated at RJDCF. RJDCF is a designated institution for inmates with severe mental illness, inmates with developmental disabilities and is responsible for providing officer coverage for inmates being treated in community hospitals throughout San Diego County. Warden, James Hill James Hill has been Acting Warden of R.J. Donovan Correctional Facility since November 2022. He began with the Arizona Department of Corrections prior to his CDCR, which began in January 2000.  He has been assigned to several institutions throughout the state. He has experience working with both male and female members of the incarcerated population. Warden Hill’s priorities are to support CDCR’s vision and mission, with emphasis on rehabilitative and restorative justice programs while exemplifying the Department’s values of service, leadership, integrity, accountability, respect, trust, and collaboration. Bakery/Shoe Factory/Laundry Programs – CALPIA operates a full functioning bakery which produces 9,760 loaves of wheat bread daily. The shoe factory produces 1,000 pairs of shoes daily. Laundry provides service for VA hospitals and local prisons. CALPIA also employs inmates in maintenance, warehouse, and also implemented the Health Care Facility Maintenance program. Over 200 inmates are employed and learn job skills through CALPIA Enterprises at RJDCF. Non –Profit and Non-Governmental Organizations
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism - Community Strategies.docx

name: San Diegans for Gun Violence Prevention (SD4GVP)
description: San Diegans For Gun Violence Prevention (SD4GVP) is a non-profit, grassroots organization that works to prevent gun violence in San Diego through advocacy, education, and community engagement. SD4GVP works closely with National Organizations such as Newtown Action Alliance, Brady United, California Chapter and they also lead a Mental Health and Wellbeing Global Summit that focuses on Post-Traumatic Growth, Positive Stress and Resilience, and the importance of exercise and movement. San Diego County Public Safety Group, Gun Violence Reduction Project The County of San Diego wants to reduce gun violence. To better understand the impact gun violence is having on our communities and what solutions San Diego communities would like to see, the County is conducting a gun violence community needs assessment. This assessment is being conducted between September 2022 - June 2023. Through this assessment, they want to gather data and feedback from the community regarding what communities/populations most impacted, identify existing resources within San Diego communities and best practices in gun violence prevention, intervention, and aftercare/recovery; identify gaps, facilitate alliance building and support shared learning and collaboration amongst those supporting gun violence prevention and produce key findings that can be used to develop strategies.
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism - Community Strategies.docx

name: Gun Violence Reduction Advisory Group
description: An important piece of the community needs assessment will be ongoing communication and collaboration with a Gun Violence Reduction Advisory Group which was formed in September 2022. The Advisory Group is expected to meet five times between September 2022 – April 2023. Members will provide input and feedback related to the creation of the community needs assessment, including community engagement strategy, survey development, planning and outreach for community listening sessions and forums, and recommendations for data and information that are gathered. National Conflict Resolution Center (NCRC) www.ncrconline.com The National Conflict Resolution Center is a non-profit organization that serves a variety of communities in both the public and private sectors regionally, nationally and internationally. With more than twenty years of experience and over 20,000 cases managed, NCRC is recognized as an international leader in mediation instruction and conflict resolution. NCRC provides the resources, training and expertise to help people, organizations and communities manage and solve conflicts, with civility.
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism - Community Strategies.docx

name: Community Services – Restorative Practices in Education and the Juvenile Judicial   System
description: NCRC facilitates the application of Restorative Practices in schools as well as the juvenile justice system. Their programs are an effective alternative to traditional disciplinary action in both the academic and judicial settings, and have achieved great results through partnerships with the San Diego Unified School District and the San Diego District Attorney’s Office.
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism - Community Strategies.docx

name: RISE San Diego
description: RISE San Diego is a non-profit organization whose mission is to elevate and advance urban leadership through dialogue-based civic engagement, dynamic nonprofit partnerships, and direct training and support to increase the capacity of urban residents to effect meaningful community change. RISE San Diego is about developing the people within communities who actually make it happen. RISE Urban Leadership Fellows Program is a partnership of RISE San Diego and the Leadership Institute at the University of San Diego School of Leadership and Education Sciences (SOLES). RISE’s unique goal and commitment is to help identify and empower a generation of leaders who will not only bring our urban communities up, but also bring them together. Meeting focus: Explore RISE San Diego’s youth-focused grassroots civic engagement programs, non-profit trainings, and leadership development models.
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism - Community Strategies.docx

name: Second Chance – Youth Programs
description: Second Chance youth programs are focused on helping local youth overcome neglect, abuse, criminal backgrounds, addiction and poverty. Programs include: Workforce Innovation & Opportunity Act (WIOA), provides occupational skills training and credentials and supportive services for out-of-school youth; Youth Garden, a six-week program combining hands-on urban farming, classes and workforce training; STRIVE Future Leaders provides technical training, professional certifications, life skills and educational opportunities; Youthful Offender Rehabilitation Program (YORP), uses evidence-based curricula and cognitive behavioral interventions to rehabilitate youth incarcerated.
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism - Community Strategies.docx

name: Reality Changers
description: Reality Changers transforms lives, schools, and communities by providing youth from disadvantaged backgrounds with the academic support, financial assistance and leadership training to become first generation college students. Today, Reality Changers’ 500 current members and 500 program graduates have earned approximately $40,000,000 in scholarships.
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism - Community Strategies.docx

name: International Rescue Committee (IRC) San Diego – Youth Programs
description: The International Rescue Committee (IRC) helps people affected by humanitarian crises to survive, recover and rebuild their lives. The IRC is partnering with seven schools in San Diego Unified School District (the second largest school district in California) to offer wrap-around services to students through its Refugee Education, Acculturation, Civic Engagement, and Health (REACH) program. Meeting focus: Explore how IRC youth programs like their wrap-around services to youth new to the U.S. as they navigate their new education system, while fostering leadership development, empowerment and civic engagement to ensure students stay on the right path.
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism - Community Strategies.docx

name: Mid-City CAN Advocacy Network – Youth Council
description: Mid-City Community Advocacy Network is a community collaborative based in City Heights, a dense and diverse urban community of about 95,000 people and home to the San Diego Diplomacy Council office. Their mission is to create a safe, productive, and healthy community through collaboration, advocacy, and organizing. The most pressing issues are raised by the people themselves and are then addressed through Momentum Teams, which are councils made up of residents from City Heights. Mid-City CAN is invested in developing leaders in City Heights. The Mid-City Can Youth Council exists to create change in their “local Black, Indigenous and Communities of Color”. They envision a world where young people thrive and everything is possible when we invest in education, not incarceration. Youth Council’s current campaign is to dismantle institutional policies designed to criminalize and incarcerate youth. By giving youth the voice and power to change these policies, they can lead juvenile justice reform and end the school to prison pipeline. Meeting focus: Meet with community organizers and members for an overview of America’s problematic mass incarceration, and to learn about how Mid-City CAN utilizes Momentum Teams and a Youth Council to develop community leaders and advocate for change in an urban, diverse community. May include interaction with Youth Council members.
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism - Community Strategies.docx

name: 211 San Diego
description: 211 San Diego partners with the San Diego County District Attorney’s office, San Diego County Sheriff’s Department, San Diego County Probation Department, and  San Diego Re-entry Roundtable to improve access to the re-entry resources in San Diego County. 211 San Diego rehabilitation efforts helps those who were recently released from prison, to help them find services and resources to have a successful transition back into San Diego County’s communities and neighborhoods. San Diego Re-entry Roundtable Program The San Diego Re-entry Roundtable (SDRR) is comprised of representatives from correctional institutions, law enforcement, faith-based and community-based organizations, governmental agencies, local planning members, universities, community members, formerly incarcerated individuals and concerned citizens. The SDRR provides a forum for everyone involved in the criminal justice system including former prisoners, their families and the general public to come together in meaningful dialogue about reentry.
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism - Community Strategies.docx

name: San Diego Youth Services
description: San Diego Youth Services’ provides intensive services to more than 17,000 youth every year. San Diego Youth Services offers a continuum of care for children and youth from infancy to age 25. They aim to meet the basic needs of youth such as hunger, poverty and youth homelessness as they are on the rise for many youth and their families today. San Diego Youth Services’ helps meet these basic needs for youth. They also provide safe places to live and long-term solutions through shelter, foster homes, community centers and housing. San Diego Youth Services also help youth focus on positive life changes and healthy relationships as part of providing needed resources and services.
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism - Community Strategies.docx

name: Juvenile Delinquency Prevention, Diversion and Intervention Program (BridgeWays & Community Assessment Team)
description: The San Diego Youth Services provides a wide range of programs including their Juvenile Delinquency Prevention, Diversion and Intervention Program, a community assessment team, and an after-school achievement center. Their Juvenile Diversion comprehensive program, including their partner program BridgeWays, addresses the behavioral health needs of youth involved with the justice system or youth at risk of involvement, up to age 21. This behavioral health needs program provides outpatient clinical services and field support services for youth up to age 21. Their Community Assessment Team provides individualized supportive case management and links youth dealing with behavioral, social or juvenile justice issues and their families with needed resources and services in Central and East regions of San Diego County.
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism - Community Strategies.docx

name: Child Sex Trafficking, Awareness and Recovery Program
description: At San Diego Youth Services, they have helped thousands of children and young adults who are at risk for trafficking, as well as those who have already been trafficked. Their goal is for the youth they serve to become emotionally and financially self-reliant, so that they are able to overcome the trauma they have experienced, heal and lead productive and healthy lives. San Diego Youth Services’ staff members work directly with survivors to get them back on their feet, by providing them with resources, including shelter and food, so that they are able to leave their old lives behind. They also provide mental health services, educational support, employment opportunities, as well as support to their families. Faith Based Organizations
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism - Community Strategies.docx

name: Islamic Center of San Diego (ICSD) – NextGen Youth Group
description: https://www.icsd.org/about-us/our-imams The ICSD resides in the heart of Clairemont and is the largest Mosque in San Diego County. Their Mission is to serve the religious needs of the San Diego Muslim population and work with the larger community to serve the less fortunate, to educate, and to better our nation. In addition to these activities and programs, ICSD is increasingly branching out in working with other San Diego organizations for social causes of interest to all people of faith. ICSD’s NextGen Youth Group develops committed youth Muslim men and women capable of spreading and giving root to comprehensive understanding of Islam and to prepare them to be at the forefront in the development of their communities.
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism - Community Strategies.docx

name: Community Wraparound (Faith Based)
description: Community Wraparound is a gang prevention, positive youth development, and community safety initiative that leverages strategic community alliances to support gang-affiliated youth by offering an alternative to gang life and promoting success through involvement with family, school, work, and community. A partnership between numerous community partners, the program includes educational, civic, and social components such as individual mentoring and comprehensive life planning; family and group meetings; and community involvement and service projects. Community Wraparound is focused on changing the narrative of violence.
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism - Community Strategies.docx

name: Interfaith Community Services
description: Interfaith Community Services is a nonprofit based in San Diego, CA. Our organization provides food, housing, employment, treatment and other emergency resources for local people in crisis. Substance-Use Treatment Program This program’s goal is to create immediate access points for a variety of treatment services. Generally, program members are introduced on a referral basis though our Homelessness Outreach and Shelters program. Submit a request for more information through the “Inquiry Form.” This program helps people detox to achieve short-term stability with goals of transitioning to their residential outpatient programs and residential programs. _______________________________ Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown). Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $30 for one Adult Ticket for a one-hour narrated tour (south bay or north bay routes); $35 for a full bay two-hour narrated tour which covers it all: ships of the Maritime Museum, Harbor and Shelter Islands, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and more. The full bay tour is about 25 miles in length. Accessibility: The tour begins and ends at the same location downtown along Broadway Pier. Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com Price: $44 for a 1-Day Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) For 30 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours, highlighting the best San Diego attractions. The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50am – 5:00pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $26 for one Adult General Admission Ticket ($1 discount when purchased on-line). Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10am – 5pm (Last admission at 4pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside Navy Pier. Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 17 major museums and cultural institutions, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism - Community Strategies.docx

name: Coronado
description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year around due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown. SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $99.99 for one Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) Accessibility: A 15-20-minute drive from downtown San Diego. Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Orca Encounter, Dolphin Days, and Sea Lions Live shows and thrilling rides like Electric Eel, Manta, and Journey To Atlantis. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Hours vary by season.
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism - Community Strategies.docx

name: Youth Voice San Diego
description: Youth Voice is a youth leadership program held at the Mid-City Police Division weekly. Law enforcement, university interns and community based organizations partner with the goal of providing youth with mentoring and opportunities to positively support their leadership development. Youth Voice focuses on Connection with Self, Connection with Others, Connection with Community, and Connection with Law Enforcement. The voluntary mentoring program is supported by Mid-City Division's Juvenile Services Team and connects youth to themselves, their homes, schools, and communities through trauma informed - resilience building curriculum development.
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism.docx

name: The City of San Diego, Gang Intervention Unit
description: The Gang Intervention Unit has a unique role within the San Diego Police Department and the community of San Diego. Officers are involved in educating youth about the dangers of gang involvement and aims to reduce juvenile gang initiation and participation through community engagement and other strategies. Gang Resistance Education and Training (G.R.E.A.T.) Program The G.R.E.A.T. program is intended to help with delinquency, deter youth violence and gang membership. Officers work with elementary and middle schools throughout San Diego to provide this educational opportunity. After School and Summer Sports Programs The Gang Intervention Unit partners with local fitness and sports programs to teach young San Diegans sports skills such as soccer, basketball and baseball. This builds confidence and encourages youth to stay healthy and active. Youth Boxing Program SDPD partners with a local boxing gym to offer a free boxing program for youth ages 14-18, who are ready to make changes to their lives and are committed to a team environment. Training takes place three days per week and the Gang Intervention Unit provides transportation to and from classes. Many of the participants of this program have successfully completed their education and found employment. Tattoo Removal Tattoo removal is an integral part of leaving behind gang life. In collaboration with the San Diego District Attorney’s Office, SDPD assists individuals in removing their tattoos for free. An interview is needed prior to acceptance into the program. This program is also open to victims of Human Trafficking. One-on-One Mentorship One on one mentorship and program referral is available with one of SDPD’s experienced gang intervention officers. These officers have access to many community organizations that can assist youth with finding success and achieving their goals. Families in Motion Family input is essential, and we encourage participation from parents and guardians in any intervention program, including our Families in Motion classes that run for five weeks, multiple times per year. Families in Motion covers topics such as teen DUI, drugs, gang life, violence and mental health. We have lived experience panelists who provide an insight into gang life and the reality of that chosen path. Juveniles are generally indoctrinated into gang life by the age of twelve. Our experienced team is here to help and answer any questions regarding the influence of gangs in the life of your child.
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism.docx

name: The San Diego Police Department’s Volunteers in Policing (VIP)
description: The San Diego Police Department’s Volunteers in Policing (VIP)’s program offers a unique opportunity for citizen volunteers to become actively involved in providing efficient, effective, and responsive service to our community. The Volunteer Services Administration is dedicated to providing an exciting, challenging, and meaningful work environment. The use of volunteers includes Crisis Interventionists, Retired Senior Volunteer Patrols, and Volunteers in Policing, Reserve Officers, Assist in conducting follow-up research, verifying reports, making phone calls to witnesses and victims, taking police reports over the phone of minor and "no suspect" crimes, completing police crime reports, answering phones, filing and other office tasks. Retired Senior Volunteer Patrol (R.S.V.P.) Program Assist in providing an increased level of crime prevention programs within specific geographic areas, perform vacation house checks and ‘You Are Not Alone’ welfare checks, and promote community awareness and acceptance of R.S.V.P. program. Qualifications for this program are, you must be 50 years of age or older, interest in working with law enforcement officers, effective oral and written communication skills, reliable and trustworthy with confidential information, in good health, valid California Driver's License.
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism.docx

name: National Gang Center (NGC)
description: The National Gang Center (NGC) is a project funded by the Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention (OJJDP), the Office of Justice Programs (OJP), U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ). The NGC is an integral component of the Justice Department’s mission to provide innovative leadership in coordination with federal, state, local, and tribal justice systems to prevent and reduce crime. The NGC disseminates information, knowledge, and outcome‐driven practices that engage and empower those in local communities with chronic and emerging gang problems to create comprehensive solutions to prevent gang violence, reduce gang involvement, and suppress gang‐related crime. The Gang Resistance Education And Training (G.R.E.A.T.) Program Program is a school‐based, law enforcement officer‐instructed classroom curriculum. The program, whose primary objective is prevention, is intended as an immunization against delinquency, youth violence, and gang membership. G.R.E.A.T. lessons focus on providing life skills to students to help them avoid delinquent behavior and violence to solve problems.
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism.docx

name: 211 San Diego
description: 211 San Diego partners with the San Diego County District Attorney’s office, San Diego County Sheriff’s Department, San Diego County Probation Department, and  San Diego Re-entry Roundtable to improve access to the re-entry resources in San Diego County. 211 San Diego rehabilitation efforts helps those who were recently released from prison, to help them find services and resources to have a successful transition back into San Diego County’s communities and neighborhoods. San Diego Re-entry Roundtable Program The San Diego Re-entry Roundtable (SDRR) is comprised of representatives from correctional institutions, law enforcement, faith-based and community-based organizations, governmental agencies, local planning members, universities, community members, formerly incarcerated individuals and concerned citizens. The SDRR provides a forum for everyone involved in the criminal justice system including former prisoners, their families and the general public to come together in meaningful dialogue about reentry.
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism.docx

name: The San Diego Workforce Partnership
description: The San Diego Workforce Partnership offers services for job seekers, businesses and students to help their transition back into society. The San Diego Workforce Partnership collaborates with correctional institutions to provide pre-release employment and training services through their varies programs. The San Diego Workforce Partnership believes that Workforce development is much more than finding the next job, that it is helping people connect what they know, love and need with careers that align with each person’s unique talents.
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism.docx

name: Reentry Works Program
description: Reentry Works invests and innovates in evidence-based solutions to best serve the justice-involved population by providing pre-release employment and training services, links to jobs and post-release employment services, earn and learn opportunities, supportive services (such as transportation, housing and access to technology) and community-based connections.
source_proposal: 6-Countering Violent Extremism.docx

name: Site Visit at Richard J. Donovan Correctional Facility (RJD)
description: The Mission at Richard J. Donovan Correctional Facility (RJDCF) is a multi-mission institution: RJDCF’s primary mission is to provide housing for General Population and SNY, Level I, II, III & IV inmates serving their term of incarceration at RJDCF. Additionally, RJDCF provides health care services and rehabilitative programs to inmates while incarcerated at RJDCF. RJDCF is a designated institution for inmates with severe mental illness, inmates with developmental disabilities and is responsible for providing officer coverage for inmates being treated in community hospitals throughout San Diego County. Warden, James Hill James Hill has been Acting Warden of R.J. Donovan Correctional Facility since November 2022. He began with the Arizona Department of Corrections prior to his CDCR, which began in January 2000.  He has been assigned to several institutions throughout the state. He has experience working with both male and female members of the incarcerated population. Warden Hill’s priorities are to support CDCR’s vision and mission, with emphasis on rehabilitative and restorative justice programs while exemplifying the Department’s values of service, leadership, integrity, accountability, respect, trust, and collaboration. Bakery/Shoe Factory/Laundry Programs – CALPIA operates a full functioning bakery which produces 9,760 loaves of wheat bread daily. The shoe factory produces 1,000 pairs of shoes daily. Laundry provides service for VA hospitals and local prisons. CALPIA also employs inmates in maintenance, warehouse, and also implemented the Health Care Facility Maintenance program. Over 200 inmates are employed and learn job skills through CALPIA Enterprises at RJDCF. Non –Profit and Non-Governmental Organizations National Conflict Resolution Center (NCRC) www.ncrconline.com The National Conflict Resolution Center is a non-profit organization that serves a variety of communities in both the public and private sectors regionally, nationally and internationally. With more than twenty years of experience and over 20,000 cases managed, NCRC is recognized as an international leader in mediation instruction and conflict resolution. NCRC provides the resources, training and expertise to help people, organizations and communities manage and solve conflicts, with civility.

name: San Diego Workforce Partnership (SDWP)
description: San Diego Workforce Partnership (SDWP) is the local Workforce Development Board, designated by the City and the County of San Diego to receive state and federal funds to administer job training and employment programs throughout the region. SDWP also receives competitive grants to administer innovative workforce programs. Their programs enable eligible youth and adults to develop the skills and knowledge needed to meet the needs of San Diego’s employers. SDWP Youth/Young Adult Programs In San Diego County, 9.2% of the county’s opportunity youth population (aged 16 – 24) are not working or in school. Additionally, youth disconnection rate is unevenly distributed among Black, Indigenous, and People of Color. SDWP funds youth programs that provide work-readiness training to youth from low-income households as well as youth who are at risk of dropping out of school. Their young adult programs focus on connecting all young adults to education and employment. Connect2Careers (C2C) represents a partnership between the Workforce Partnership and funders who support innovative youth employment programming. C2Cworks with young adults works directly with young adults to develop and support their career goals through work-readiness training, case management, job coaching and paid work experiences.

name: Aaron Price Fellows Program
description: The mission of the Aaron Price Fellows Program is to prepare a highly motivated and diverse group of San Diego public high school students to be responsible, engaged and caring members of their community. An intensive three-year program teaches Fellows about government, cultural, business and non-profit institutions to illustrate their significance and relevance in their lives; exposes Fellows to exciting career opportunities; and foster friendships between Fellows from diverse ethnic, religious and economic backgrounds. Meeting focus: Learn about this unique, 3-year fellowship opportunity that cultivates youth to be active citizens, caring for their community and helping others. Possible youth interaction. Barrio Logan College Institute www.blci.org Barrio Logan College Institute is located in Barrio Logan, a part of the San Diego community that is rich in culture but underserved in resources. Their mission is to break the cycle of poverty by preparing students to be the first in their families to go to college through after school programs that begin in third grade. Located in a traditionally low-income community, BLCI promotes higher education as a ticket out of poverty. To date, 100% of Barrio Logan College Institute’s students have enrolled in college. _______________________________ Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown). Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $30 for one Adult Ticket for a one-hour narrated tour (south bay or north bay routes); $35 for a full bay two-hour narrated tour which covers it all: ships of the Maritime Museum, Harbor and Shelter Islands, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and more. The full bay tour is about 25 miles in length. Accessibility: The tour begins and ends at the same location downtown along Broadway Pier. Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com Price: $44 for a 1-Day Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) For 30 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours, highlighting the best San Diego attractions. The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50am – 5:00pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $26 for one Adult General Admission Ticket ($1 discount when purchased on-line). Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10am – 5pm (Last admission at 4pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside Navy Pier. Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 17 major museums and cultural institutions, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).

name: Coronado
description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year around due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown. SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $99.99 for one Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) Accessibility: A 15-20-minute drive from downtown San Diego. Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Orca Encounter, Dolphin Days, and Sea Lions Live shows and thrilling rides like Electric Eel, Manta, and Journey To Atlantis. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Hours vary by season.
