name: San Diego State University Coastal and Marine Institute Laboratory
description: The Coastal and Marine Institute refers to the consortium of researchers, visiting scientists, students, and volunteers at the SDSU Coastal and Marine Institute Laboratory (CMIL). CMIL was built in 2006 on a prime coastal site at the old Naval Training Center near the airport and San Diego Bay and was conveyed to SDSU by the City of San Diego for the purposes of functioning as a research facility for students and faculty. The mission of CMIL is to perform basic and applied coastal research and to share our knowledge of the marine environment with the community. CMIL offers interdisciplinary solutions to coastal zone problems in the San Diego region. The CMIL is an active member of the National Association of Marine Laboratories (NAML) and the California Aquaculture Association (CAA). Current research projects include topics such as: understanding the impacts of fish farms, the impact of overfishing on reefs, and examining environmental parameters.
source_proposal: 6. Sustainable Fisheries Management.docx

name: Fisheries Biology and Management at UCSD
description: Fisheries biology and management is the study of marine environments and the monitoring and management of their living resources. The field includes ecological studies and analysis, population modeling, data collection, and working with communities to ensure stability. The department hosts CalCOFI, a long-term, interdisciplinary, cross-sectoral ecosystem research program off the coast of California that holistically studies the physics, biogeochemistry, and biology of the marine environment to inform the sustainable management of marine resources in the context of climate change.
source_proposal: 6. Sustainable Fisheries Management.docx

name: Samantha Murray at Scripps Institution of Oceanography: Center for Marine Biodiversity and Conservation
description: The Center for Marine Biodiversity and Conservation at Scripps Institution of Oceanography is a center of interdisciplinary cooperation in research and education. A group of faculty with broad-ranging specialties work in partnership with CMBC to link biological, physical, social and environmental programs, providing a novel integration of disciplines as they seek technically sophisticated, regionally appropriate strategies to prevent and reverse biodiversity collapse. A large component of the center’s research focuses on sustainability and ecosystem-based fisheries management. In collaboration with local fishers, communities, and government agencies, these research groups explore cultural, economic, and policy implications of local and small-scale fisheries globally to improve fisheries management. Samantha Murray is the Executive Director of the MAS MBC Program where she also teaches graduate courses, including Ocean Law and Policy. In 2019 she was appointed by Governor Newsom to the California Fish and Game Commission and currently serves as Vice President. Samantha has nearly two decades of professional experience and has directed ocean and water programs at Ocean Conservancy, the Audubon Society, and Oregon Environmental Council, in addition to founding a marine policy consulting business. Samantha played a key role in the design and implementation of California's network of marine protected areas, which now cover 16 percent of state waters. She served on the Marine Protected Area Federal Advisory Committee, has held board positions at Upstream Public Health and Citizens for East Shore Parks, and currently sits on the board at San Diego Coastkeeper. Meeting focus: Explore how the institute leverages research and education to improve the state of marine ecosystems and develop innovative conservation models. Discuss California’s robust network of Marine Protected Areas, how it functions, and the myriad stakeholders who implement and support it. Learn about U.S. best practices for sustainable marine fisheries management.
source_proposal: 6. Sustainable Fisheries Management.docx

name: University of San Diego – Professor Andrew Tirrell
description: Dr. Andrew Tirrell is an associate professor in the department of Political Science and International Relations at the University of San Diego’s School of Law. Tirrell teaches a range of courses related to environmental politics, human rights, and sustainable development. His research focuses on environmental justice, natural resource management, marine policy, and the Arctic. His current projects engage with environmental politics in border regions, fisheries management policy, and the role of institutions in coupled human-natural systems. He has recently published peer-reviewed journal articles on the role of institutions in fisheries policy, the role of bridge organizations in fostering trust in fisheries management, transboundary water policy at the Mexico-U.S. border, and how the Law of the Sea could have been better equipped to deal with the COVID-19 pandemic. He has also recently published a book chapter with Cambridge University Press on Climate Change and Fisheries Politics. Meeting focus: Develop an understanding of how to develop best practices and policies that foster sustainable economic growth, innovation, and improved market access for fisheries. Examine fisheries management policy through an international economic and environmental politics lens. Government Organizations
source_proposal: 6. Sustainable Fisheries Management.docx

name: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)
description: NOAA Fisheries is a government scientific agency within the United States Department of Commerce and is responsible for the stewardship of the nation’s ocean resources and their habitat. From killer whales slicing through waves to salmon jumping rapids on their journey home, marine life fills and defines the waters of the West Coast. The Southwest Fisheries Science Center conducts scientific research to ensure that the region’s marine and anadromous fish, marine mammal, marine turtle and invertebrate populations remain at healthy and sustainable levels as functional parts of their ecosystems and continue to enhance the quality of life for the public. Meeting focus: Participants will tour the Southwest Fisheries Science Center, located in La Jolla, to discuss the long-term fishery issues faced by the area and become familiar with the U.S. sustainable marine resources management approach.
source_proposal: 6. Sustainable Fisheries Management.docx

name: California Department of Fish and Wildlife: South Coast Region - MPA Management Program
description: https://wildlife.ca.gov/Conservation/Marine/MPAs/Management The Mission of the Department of Fish and Wildlife is to manage California's diverse fish, wildlife, and plant resources, and the habitats upon which they depend, for their ecological values and for their use and enjoyment by the public. As the lead managing agency for the California MPA Network, the Department of Fish and Wildlife implements and enforces the regulations set by the California Fish and Game Commission, and works across all four focal areas of the MPA Management Program. The MPA Management Program is a collaboration between the California Department of Fish and Wildlife, the Ocean Protection Council, the Fish and Game Commission, and the MPA Statewide Leadership Team. This novel partnership-based approach ensures California’s MPA network is adaptively managed and informed by engaged partnerships. Non-Government Organizations
source_proposal: 6. Sustainable Fisheries Management.docx

name: San Diego Coastkeeper
description: Originally established to combat the systematic polluting of San Diego Bay, San Diego Coastkeeper now works to address myriad water challenges across San Diego County and fight to protect and restore San Diego Waterways for the communities and wildlife that depend on them. In October 2020, San Diego Coastkeeper submitted comments to the NOAA opposing large industrial fish farming projects off of the San Diego Coastline. As a larger issue, aquaculture involves the farming of aquatic plants or animals and is most commonly used to produce shellfish or finfish for human consumption. Offshore fish farming currently does not exist in United States federal waters. Meeting focus: Discuss how advocacy groups are heard within the fishing industry and how advocacy is addressed by policymakers. Explore current U.S. marine resource management and predict what best practices look like and the process to adopt best practices.
source_proposal: 6. Sustainable Fisheries Management.docx

name: Waitt Foundation
description: With the rapid decline of marine life and resources, the primary mission of the Waitt Foundation is to protect the oceans from the harmful impacts of overfishing. To achieve this, the Foundation directs efforts toward facilitating the creation of marine protected areas, engaging stakeholders to improve the management of fisheries, fostering sustainable solutions, and raising public awareness through a network of collaborative NGOs and foundations. Their vision is to restore the seas to full productivity for future generations. Funding partnerships and projects in conjunction with its grantees and two institutes, the Waitt Foundation supports a variety of national and international programs concentrating on ocean conservation initiatives and marine related issues. By increasing global awareness, their goal is to reverse the current decline of ocean life while inspiring humanity to make informed choices that contribute to a healthy marine ecosystem Meeting focus: Identify how traditionally opposition parties, advocate groups and marine fisheries, work together to advance sustainable management of marine fisheries resources. Identify the culture shift in regards to public opinion on fisheries and determine methods to utilize public interest to form a successful fishery.
source_proposal: 6. Sustainable Fisheries Management.docx

name: WILDCOAST
description: WILDCOAST is a non-profit organization with a successful conservation record, having protected more than one million acres of coastal wildland and halted the development plans of illegal mega-resorts throughout the Baja California Peninsula and the Sea of Cortez. Through its innovative, successful conservation campaigns, the conservation team has brought critical attention to pressing environmental issues such as protecting the sensitive Cabo Pulmo coral reef from the proposed construction of a 2012 mega-development project. Their conservation activities have focused on U.S.-Mexico Border coast sites that contain globally significant coastal and marine ecosystems and internationally migrating and threatened marine species. The organization is leading efforts in California to conserve 545,280 acres of MPAs.
source_proposal: 6. Sustainable Fisheries Management.docx

name: Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission
description: The Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission (IATTC) is the regional fisheries management organization (RFMO) responsible for the conservation and management of tuna and tuna -like species, associated species and their ecosystems, throughout the Eastern Pacific Ocean, from Canada, in the north, to Chile, in the South. Its mandate and competence are therefore much broader than the reference in its name to tropical tunas – inherited from a distant past – would seem to indicate. It also provides the Secretariat of the 1998 Agreement on the International Dolphin Conservation Program (AIDCP). Meeting focus: Learn about the IATTC role and program to protect tuna and turtles in the eastern Pacific Ocean. Compare the conservation and management system presented by IATTC and compare it to other environmental systems of countries. Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).

name: Chicano Park
description: Chicano Park is the geographic and emotional heart of Barrio Logan, located in Logan Heights, San Diego's oldest Mexican-American neighborhood. The park is home to the largest concentration of Chicano murals in the world with more than 80 paintings on seven acres dotted with sculpture, gardens, picnic tables and playgrounds. Throughout the year, it hosts festivals of music and Aztec dance, the biggest being Chicano Park Day held each April. name: Border Field State Park & Friendship Park
description: https://www.friendshippark.org/ Located within the Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve, Border Field State Park sits in the very southwestern corner of the United States, 15 miles south of San Diego. This important wildlife habitat, comprised of sand dunes and salt marshes, gives refuge to critically threatened and endangered birds such as the Western Snowy Plover, the California Least Tern, and the Light-footed Ridgway's Rail. Friendship Park is a binational park located at the western end of the US-Mexico border. For generations people have gathered here to meet up with friends and family "across the line." Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 17 major museums and cultural institutions, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. name: The Pride Center at San Diego State University (SDSU)
description: The Pride Center is one of nine cultural centers at SDSU. As a result of ongoing efforts, SDSU is ranked as one of the “Best of the Best” for queer students, scoring a 5 out of 5 on the Campus Pride Index. The Pride Center continues to strive to provide and promote a space where all 2SLGBTQIA+ people are seen, accepted, and valued. The Pride Center offers a variety of programming and resources available to students, staff, faculty, and community members. The Pride Center’s ongoing programs consist of peer-led support groups and community events, and throughout the year, The Pride Center also holds events such as a Pride parade contingent, Trans Week of Empowerment, and a retreat for queer and trans people of color. Furthermore, The Pride Center holds a program intended for first year students called Pride House. Pride House is a student living community that blends mentorships with academic and personal growth as 2SLGBTQIA+ students begin their college journey. In addition to providing support and a space for 2SLGBTQIA+ students, The Pride Center provides educational passive programming and events intended to remove educational barriers and allow folks to learn more about the 2SLGBTQIA+ community, history, and resources available.
source_proposal: 7 - 50 Years of Transatlantic Pride.docx

name: LGBTQ+ Studies at San Diego State University (SDSU)
description: LGBTQ+ Studies at SDSU is an independent and interdisciplinary program that is housed in the College of Arts and Letters. It is the second university in the U.S. and the first in California to offer a major in LGBTQ+ Studies. Their mission is to advance knowledge in sexual and gender identity, and increase understanding of the diverse cultural, historical, ethnic/racial, and contemporary experiences of people across sexualities. Throughout the program of study, we consider the full range of genders, sexualities, races, ethnicities, classes, physical abilities, religions, and political persuasions that characterize current LGBTQ+ movements and communities.
source_proposal: 7 - 50 Years of Transatlantic Pride.docx

name: LGBT Resource Center at University of California San Diego (UCSD)
description: The LGBT Resource Center at UCSD is a diverse, open and public space for all members of the university community to explore issues relating to sexual and gender identities, practices and politics. It develops student leadership, builds workplace equity, promotes academic research, and provides resources. The Center challenges existing definitions of variant genders and sexualities by engaging in community building on- and off-campus. This Center sustains and develops visibility, sense of community, and knowledge of diverse queer people. Meeting focus: Interact with students from UCSD who are a part of the LGBT community and learn about how the resource center has helped them throughout their college experience. Identify ways in which the LGBT Resource Center convenes voices on issues relating to intersecting identities within the LGBTQ+ community.
source_proposal: 7 - 50 Years of Transatlantic Pride.docx

name: Department of Youth Advocacy at San Diego Unified School District
description: https://youthadvocacy.us/lgbtqia-education The San Diego Unified School District established the Department of Youth Advocacy which seeks to create environments that promote the safety and affirmation of all students by fostering a culture of care and respect that extends throughout the entire school district, cultivating a platform for student voice that builds agency, ensuring educational justice for all. Within that department is the office of LGBTQIA+ Education and Advocacy which provides school site resources and district support to meet the needs of LGBTQIA+ students and their families. The program provides progressional development opportunities; educator, student, and family resources; and inclusive curriculum. The LGBTQIA+ Education and Advocacy Program additionally collaborates with other district programs and stakeholders to make schools safer and more affirming for all lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer/questioning, intersex, and asexual students. Government Resources
source_proposal: 7 - 50 Years of Transatlantic Pride.docx

name: San Diego City, LGBTQ Advisory Group
description: In alignment with his goal of creating a more equitable and inclusive San Diego, Mayor Todd Gloria announced the appointees to his administration's LGBTQ Advisory Group. As San Diego’s first openly gay mayor he wants to make sure the LGBTQ community has a seat at the table, in which he created the LGBTQ Advisory Group to participate in conversations and decisions made surrounding issues affecting our LGBTQ constituents are balanced and thought-out.
source_proposal: 7 - 50 Years of Transatlantic Pride.docx

name: San Diego Family Justice Center (SDFJC)
description: The San Diego Family Justice Center, part of the Office of the City Attorney, is dedicated to transitioning victims of domestic violence, sexual assault and sex trafficking into survivors. The SDFJC is a team of professionals including therapists, nurses, attorneys, prosecutors, advocates, immigration attorneys, police, and other social service providers all located in one facility – the first such center that has become a model nationally and internationally. The SDFJC provides services free of charge to empower victims to break free of their abusers, end the pattern of violence, and become thriving members of society.
source_proposal: 7 - 50 Years of Transatlantic Pride.docx

name: City of San Diego, Human Relations Commission
description: The Human Relations Commission (HRC) believes in protecting basic Human and Civil Rights, while ensuring people in San Diego have the resources available to make positive impacts in their lives. The HRC strives to provide people with content and resources that will empower them to exercise their motivation to be part of a solution. The commission collaborates with community groups to create educational programs that address interracial, inter-religious, and intercultural understanding. Representatives will overview local government efforts to cultivate a community of equal economic and political rights for all citizens.
source_proposal: 7 - 50 Years of Transatlantic Pride.docx

name: Senator Toni G. Atkins
description: Senator Toni G. Atkins became the first woman and the first openly LGBTQ person to lead the California Legislature’s upper house. Throughout her entire career she has focused on affordable housing, healthcare, women, and the LGBTQ community. California’s 39th State Senate District that she oversees includes most of the City of San Diego, which is a very diverse region of ethnicities, has a large LGBTQ community, and a range of socioeconomic levels. Meeting focus: Meet with Senator Atkins representative regarding how they are helping those in the State’s 39th district who are a part of the LGBTQ+ community and what resources they are providing for them. Explore the impact of the historic Executive Order Advancing LGBTQI+ Equality (2022) on California’s 39th district and how the Executive Order shapes local LGBTQ+ policies.
source_proposal: 7 - 50 Years of Transatlantic Pride.docx

name: Representative Scott Peters
description: Congressman Scott Peters serves California’s 52nd Congressional District, which includes the cities of Coronado, Poway and most of northern San Diego. Scott Peters currently serves on the House Budget Committee and the House Energy and Commerce Committee, as well as the Joint Economic Committee. Congressman Scott Peters has been an advocate for LGBTQ+ rights in which he Introduced an amendment that became law to affirm President Obama’s action to prohibit federal contractors from discriminating against LGBT employees, Cosponsored and helped pass the Equality Act, which would include gender identity and sexual orientation as two identities protected under federal civil rights and supported reauthorization of the Violence Against Women Act (VAWA), which provides for increased protections for victims of domestic violence. The legislation includes expanded protections for Native American women, LGBTQ individuals, students, and immigrant women. Non-profit Resources
source_proposal: 7 - 50 Years of Transatlantic Pride.docx

name: The San Diego LGBT Community Center
description: The San Diego Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Transgender Community Center, Inc., (The Center) is one of the largest and most vibrant LGBTQ community centers in the nation. Functioning as the San Diego LGBTQ community’s anchor organization, The Center provides targeted programs and services to the full diversity of the San Diego LGBTQ community, including lesbian, gay, bisexual, queer, transgender, nonbinary, immigrant, and HIV communities to the betterment of our entire San Diego region. Last year, The Center provided more than 80,000 direct service visits to San Diego community members, and through its events, activities, and advocacy, touched the lives of thousands more. The Center has expanded its housing programs and resources to become a leader in solving San Diego’s housing crisis. Additionally, The Center works to promote LGBTQ  health and wellness through amplifying the voices of low-income residents, communities of color, immigrants, and refugees.
source_proposal: 7 - 50 Years of Transatlantic Pride.docx

name: San Diego Pride
description: https://sdpride.org/fernando-lopez/ San Diego Pride is a dynamic 501(c)3 non-profit organization that organizes the annual San Diego Pride parade, provides LGBTQ+ educational training, and offers LGBTQ+ programs in a variety of areas including sports, youth, art, and accessibility. Their mission is to foster pride, equality, and respect for all lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender communities locally, nationally, and globally. In addition to their annual festivities, San Diego Pride has donated more than $3 million dollars to LGBTQ-serving nonprofits and runs multiple year-round education, advocacy, and community service programs. They also offer training on cultural humility, inclusivity and skills, and provide resources for the community to remain civically active. Fernando Zweifach López Jr is the Executive Director for San Diego LGBT Pride, and a local leader with extensive experience in advocacy, nonprofit management, public education, diversity consulting, media relations, and organizing.
source_proposal: 7 - 50 Years of Transatlantic Pride.docx

name: San Diego Pride Festival
description: July is Pride Month in San Diego, thanks to San Diego Pride’s world-famous Pride Festival. A special two-day event highlighting the best in LGBTQ+ entertainment, culture, and community, San Diego Pride Festival is an annual highlight for the whole city. We suggest visitors stay in San Diego for the Pride Festival Weekend, as the San Diego Diplomacy Council is able to work with our close partners at San Diego Pride to secure discounted or free VIP passes. Additionally, San Diego Diplomacy Council will be marching in the San Diego Pride Parade on July 15. Meeting focus: Attend the San Diego Pride Festival. Meet with local LGBTQ+ leaders, and connect with the San Diego community to celebrate Pride.
source_proposal: 7 - 50 Years of Transatlantic Pride.docx

name: Trans Family Support Services
description: The Trans Family Support Services (TFSS) seeks to save lives by shaping a gender affirming and accepting community through a variety of meetings, programs, and services provided. They have no fee engagement sessions that are in home to help educate and provide resources for families and trans youth. TFSS specializes in training workforces in gender competency and also provides trainings for schools and medical facilities. Additionally, they offer speaker services, support groups, mentoring, and transgender insurance assistance.
source_proposal: 7 - 50 Years of Transatlantic Pride.docx

name: The North County LGBTQ Resource Center
description: The North County LGBTQ Resource Center is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization that serves the lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and questioning community (LGBTQ) in North County San Diego. Their mission is to foster and empower the North County LGBTQ community by providing a safe space, advancing awareness and visibility, and sustaining equality and inclusiveness.  They provide a variety of services including: immigration, homelessness, substance abuse recovery, mental health, name & gender marker changes. They also have a variety of programs like LGBTQ Awareness Trainings, HIV Prevention & Care, Gender Advocacy Project (GAP), Human Trafficking prevention.
source_proposal: 7 - 50 Years of Transatlantic Pride.docx

name: Human Rights Campaign (HRC) - San Diego Branch
description: The Human Rights Campaign (HRC) San Diego is a group of volunteers who are dedicated to creating change in their community and use their experiences to develop a more affirming, inclusive, and equitable community. In addition, HRC mobilizes their LGBTQ+ community on a national-level to gain voter turnout, in order to get policies passed that benefit their people across the country. Furthermore, HRC educates the public about issues that affect the LGBTQ+ community, but they also engage with LGBTQ+ people and allies in the fight for equality, they raise money, and build relationships with local businesses. There are several different programs within HRC San Diego, like fundraising, community engagement, volunteer recruitment, and political action. Meeting focus: Interact with volunteers from HRC San Diego and learn about how their local chapter contributes to the national campaign to mobilize voter turnout. Explore the history of volunteer-led activism and identify strategies in mobilizing marginalized groups.
source_proposal: 7 - 50 Years of Transatlantic Pride.docx

name: PFLAG San Diego County
description: PFLAG San Diego County is a non-profit organization who envisions a world where diversity is celebrated and all people are respected. PFLAG offers support, education, and advocacy to LGBTQ+ persons, their families, friends, and allies through many resources. They offer support groups throughout all of San Diego County, and they also award scholarships to LGBTQ high school students who are going on to higher education. Education is a top priority for PFLAG and PFLAG has many resources for anyone who might want to learn more about the LGBTQ community. Meeting focus: Explore how PFLAG San Diego County advocates and supports LGBTQ+ students through their support groups. Explore how PFLAG awards scholarships to LGBTQ+ high school students for their higher education and expand on the support needed for LGBTQ+ students as they transition into higher education. Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).
source_proposal: 7 - 50 Years of Transatlantic Pride.docx

name: Chicano Park
description: Chicano Park is the geographic and emotional heart of Barrio Logan, located in Logan Heights, San Diego's oldest Mexican-American neighborhood. The park is home to the largest concentration of Chicano murals in the world with more than 80 paintings on seven acres dotted with sculpture, gardens, picnic tables and playgrounds. Throughout the year, it hosts festivals of music and Aztec dance, the biggest being Chicano Park Day held each April. Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $30 for one Adult Ticket for a one-hour narrated tour (south bay or north bay routes); $35 for a full bay two-hour narrated tour which covers it all: ships of the Maritime Museum, Harbor and Shelter Islands, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and more. The full bay tour is about 25 miles in length. Accessibility: The tour begins and ends at the same location downtown along Broadway Pier. Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com Price: $44 for a 1-Day Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) For 30 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours, highlighting the best San Diego attractions. The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50am – 5:00pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $26 for one Adult General Admission Ticket ($1 discount when purchased on-line). Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10am – 5pm (Last admission at 4pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside Navy Pier.
source_proposal: 7 - 50 Years of Transatlantic Pride.docx

name: Border Field State Park & Friendship Park
description: https://www.friendshippark.org/ Located within the Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve, Border Field State Park sits in the very southwestern corner of the United States, 15 miles south of San Diego. This important wildlife habitat, comprised of sand dunes and salt marshes, gives refuge to critically threatened and endangered birds such as the Western Snowy Plover, the California Least Tern, and the Light-footed Ridgway's Rail. Friendship Park is a binational park located at the western end of the US-Mexico border. For generations people have gathered here to meet up with friends and family "across the line." Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 17 major museums and cultural institutions, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).
source_proposal: 7 - 50 Years of Transatlantic Pride.docx

name: Coronado
description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year around due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown. SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $99.99 for one Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Orca Encounter, Dolphin Days, and Sea Lions Live shows and thrilling rides like Electric Eel, Manta, and Journey To Atlantis. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Hours vary by season. Also enjoy the opening of Sesame Place in March 2022, a Sesame Street themed section of the park with new water, ride, and musical attractions. Accessibility: A 15-20-minute drive from downtown San Diego.
source_proposal: 7 - 50 Years of Transatlantic Pride.docx

name: Your Safe Place, A Family Justice Center
description: Your Safe Place – A Family Justice Center provides confidential, comprehensive services to anyone who has experienced domestic violence, family violence, elder abuse, sexual assault, or sex trafficking. At Your Safe Place they provide supportive services in a judgment-free manner that empowers clients to become survivors and move forward with their lives. Recognizing the extreme risk posed by abusers with guns, Your Safe Place also protects clients by obtaining Gun Violence Restraining Orders to remove firearms from dangerous situations before a tragedy occurs. Palomar Health Sexual Assault Response Team Palomar Health’s Sexual Assault Response Team (SART) program is closely linked with law enforcement and district attorneys, ensuring that victims receive the professional care and counseling they need in a timely and effective manner, and that those who perpetrate the attacks can be held responsible in court. The existence of their facilities means that victims who often had to wait for hours for medical attention at area emergency rooms following an attack, no longer have to do so. Within an hour of notification, SART staff can be ready to care for sexual assault victims and give them the undivided attention that is so important during this time. Once there, they undergo a three-hour interview and exam process conducted by specially trained care givers. Often the evidence gathered by members of SART is so strong and compelling that suspects will admit their guilt, sparing victims the necessity of testifying in a public court room San Diego Police Department, Domestic Violence Unit San Diego Police Department's (SDPD) Domestic Violence Unit is located within the Your Safe Place - A Family Justice Center, which houses public and private agencies that work together to address domestic violence. The Domestic Violence Unit works closely with community partners such as the Center for Community Solutions, Rady Children's Hospital-Chadwick Center, San Diego Volunteer Lawyers, San Diego City Attorney's Office, San Diego District Attorney's Office, County and City Victim-Witness programs and numerous others.
source_proposal: 7 - Ending Gender-Based Violence.docx

name: One Safe Place
description: One Safe Place- A family justice center is the bringing together of a multi-agency network, under one roof, dedicated to providing coordinated services to victims of domestic violence and their children. This model has proven successful across the country and has been designated as a best-practice model for domestic violence intervention and prevention by the U.S. Department of Justice. One Safe Place is a brand new facility (less than a year old), where they have used the same model as Your Safe Place and made it a huge facility offering a wide range of services all in one place such as; Counseling Services, Children's Advocacy, Drop-in Childcare, Food and Clothing Assistance, Immigration Services, Job Skills Training, Referral to Law Enforcement, Legal Assistance, Parenting and Relationship Education, Spiritual Support, Victim Advocacy and Case Management, Healthcare/Wellness Advocacy. Note: Your Safe Place and One Safe Place are very similar meetings, and would be a half day workshop to receive a tour, and meet with the different entities.
source_proposal: 7 - Ending Gender-Based Violence.docx

name: SBCS (formerly South Bay Community Services), Domestic Violence Response Team
description: The Domestic Violence Response Team (DVRT) is a 24 hour/7 days a week emergency response unit, the first and only in San Diego’s South County region. Working closely with local law enforcement and stationed at all South Bay Police Departments, DVRT specialists accompany police on all domestic violence calls. DVRT specialists provide crisis intervention to victims and their children and assist children and adult victims plan their immediate and long-term safety.
source_proposal: 7 - Ending Gender-Based Violence.docx

name: Alliance for Hope International
description: Alliance for HOPE International is one of the leading systems and social change organizations in the country focused on creating innovative, collaborative, trauma-informed, hope-centered approaches to meeting the needs of survivors of domestic violence, sexual assault, child abuse, elder abuse, and human trafficking. Alliance for HOPE International and its allied Family Justice Centers serve more than 150,000 survivors of domestic violence and sexual assault and their children each year in the United States.
source_proposal: 7 - Ending Gender-Based Violence.docx

name: Family Justice Center Alliance
description: The Family Justice Center Alliance (FJCA) is a program of Alliance for HOPE International, one of the leading domestic violence and sexual assault prevention and intervention organizations in the United States.  The FJCA serves as the clearinghouse, research center, and national affiliation organization for Family Justice Centers and other multi-agency models that serve victims of domestic violence, sexual assault, elder abuse, child abuse, and/or human trafficking.
source_proposal: 7 - Ending Gender-Based Violence.docx

name: Training Institute on Strangulation Prevention
description: The Training Institute on Strangulation Prevention (Institute), a program of Alliance for HOPE International, was launched in October 2011. The Institute was developed in response to the increasing demand for Intimate Partner Violence Strangulation Crimes training and technical assistance (consulting, planning and support services) from communities across the world.
source_proposal: 7 - Ending Gender-Based Violence.docx

name: Institute on Violence, Abuse, and Trauma (IVAT) (Half Day or Full Day Workshop)
description: IVAT is a one-stop shop to address and end violence. They also host 2 international summits annually, house 3 academic journals, maintain several research databases, provide program evaluation, consultation, and a wide array of trainings addressing violence, abuse and trauma-- many of which can be used toward specialty certificates and continuing education, and offer vital professional and clinical services to San Diego County and beyond. IVAT believes collaboration across systems is key to putting an end to violence and abuse. Note: a workshop with IVAT will require an honorarium _______________________________ Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).

name: University of California San Diego
description: Recognized as one of the top 15 research universities worldwide, the University of California, San Diego (UCSD) lies alongside the Pacific Ocean in the community of  La Jolla. UCSD includes six undergraduate colleges, five academic divisions and five graduate and professional schools. We suggest coordinating meetings with the following resources, ideally as separate interactions for a full-day experience, with the potential of pivoting to a round-table discussion. Meeting with UCSD may also include a discussion on their role as a health service provider, research facility, university and innovative community leader has contributed to preparations for preventing and responding to outbreaks of Covid-19.
source_proposal: 7 - Global Pandemic Collaboration and Recovery.docx

name: Global Health Institute
description: The Global Health Institute aims to coordinate existing global health research and training. Efforts across the campus, and generate new collaborations and programs to meet globally important health challenges. Their mission aims to facilitate multidisciplinary research, education and public-private partnerships to coordinate efforts to combat diseases around the globe. Currently, the Global Health Institute has four working groups; Global Infectious Disease, Global Health Technologies, Global Mental Health and Global Migrant/Refugee Health. Their recent work has largely focused on global responses to the Covid-19 pandemic.
source_proposal: 7 - Global Pandemic Collaboration and Recovery.docx

name: Division of Infectious Diseases and Global Public Health
description: The UC San Diego Division of Infectious Diseases and Global Public Health aims to eliminate the burdens of infectious diseases and health disparities. Its 70+ faculty members deliver outstanding patient care, conduct world-class multidisciplinary health research, assist in the leadership, consultation and training on global public health and infectious-disease-topics-and more. The Division has experience in several major international collaborations with countries including Mozambique, Mexico and South Africa, contributing to its ability to speak to the importance of cross-border collaboration and search for best practices.
source_proposal: 7 - Global Pandemic Collaboration and Recovery.docx

name: San Diego Center for Aids Research
description: The Center for Aids Research at the University of California, San Diego (CFAR) promotes scientific and clinical studies in HIV and fosters researchers using innovative strategies to advance our research priorities of preventing new infections, optimizing HIV care, and developing a cure while promoting health equity for people with and at risk for HIV. The overall objective of the San Diego CFAR is to have a meaningful impact on HIV research by fostering local HIV researchers using innovative and efficient strategies. With support of National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID) funding, CFAR created an operations manual for international institutions to share best practices, and manage funding to yield better outcomes. Other core services offered through San Diego CFAR include biostatistics and modeling, health equity sociobehavioral sciences, genomics and sequencing, and translational virology.
source_proposal: 7 - Global Pandemic Collaboration and Recovery.docx

name: San Diego State University (SDSU), School of Public Health
description: https://publichealth.sdsu.edu/oren/ SDSU’s School of Public Health provides education and training in fields such as epidemiology, biostatistics, health promotion and behavioral science, and global health. The Division of Epidemiology and Biostatistics focuses on research related to infectious diseases, including vaccine-preventable diseases and global collaboration. They collaborate frequently with local and global partners to design and implement studies, clinical trials, and public health interventions. The School of Public Health uses an IIS system called SAS (Statistical Analysis System) to analyze and visualize data, allowing for advanced statistical modeling and data management. A meeting with SDSU School of Public Health may also involve a conversation with Eval Oren, an Associate Professor, and infectious disease and social epidemiologist at the Division of Epidemiology and Biostatistics. His research group focuses on community engaged approaches to addressing population health disparities, with a focus on respiratory infections. The group works on multidisciplinary, collaborative projects that are innovative and emphasize new tools and technologies. Methodologically, the focus is on the intersection between social, environmental and spatial epidemiologic methods, and their application to both health difference and disparities. Government Organizations
source_proposal: 7 - Global Pandemic Collaboration and Recovery.docx

name: San Diego County Border Health Program
description: The County Office of Border Health works with partners in the California-Baja California border region to address the needs of our shared community. The Office serves as a central point of contact for border health information, facilitates intergovernmental task force meetings, and serves as a central point of contact for border health information. Since the beginning of the Covid-19 pandemic, the Office has led cross border communication on updates and response efforts to combat the spread of the disease.
source_proposal: 7 - Global Pandemic Collaboration and Recovery.docx

name: San Diego County Health and Human Services Agency (HHSA)
description: The San Diego County Health and Human Services Agency (HHSA) is responsible for promoting and protecting the health and well-being of the residents of San Diego County. The HHSA provides a wide range of public health services, including disease surveillance and investigation, immunizations, HIV testing and treatment, tuberculosis control, and emergency preparedness and response. The HHSA has been actively involved in public relations campaigns related to the COVID-19 pandemic, providing regular updates and guidance on their website and social media channels. They have also partnered with community organizations to provide testing and vaccination clinics in underserved areas (including the Black Nurses Association and Chicano Federation), collaborated with schools and businesses to develop and implement COVID-19 safety plans, and provided resources and support to individuals and families affected by COVID-19, including financial assistance and mental health services. Think-Tanks and NGOs
source_proposal: 7 - Global Pandemic Collaboration and Recovery.docx

name: La Maestra Community Health Centers
description: A non-profit, Federally Qualified Health Center, La Maestra Community Health Centers: (LMCHC) provides culturally and linguistically competent primary care and specialty services for San Diego's-most culturally diverse and lowest income communities. LMCHC features a comprehensive circle of care approach. The communities that LMCHC serve consist of large-refugee populations, and they provide housing, employment and other services that support the needs of new citizens. The Center has implemented many strategies to cope with the Covid-19 pandemic including providing resources in multiple languages, and creating a mobile unit for patients that may be at risk from Covid-19.
source_proposal: 7 - Global Pandemic Collaboration and Recovery.docx

name: RISE Global Health Initiative
description: RISE GHI works with governments, industry leaders, and community partners to address global health inequities by delivering market based solutions to create economic opportunities and enable the local communities to bedrivers of their health and wellness. Founded in 2011, RISE GHI is a health and community development organization which combines private sector leadership and commitment from the public sector. Our focus is developing scalable solutions to improve access to healthcare, healthcare funding and supply chain management for the global market. We rely on our global alliances with foundations, non-profit organizations, government entities, businesses, and higher academic institutions to create lasting solutions for healthcare delivery and management. Research and Innovation
source_proposal: 7 - Global Pandemic Collaboration and Recovery.docx

name: Becton, Dickinson and Company (BD)
description: https://www.bd.com/en-us/about-bd/esg Becton, Dickinson and Company (BD) is one of the largest medical technology companies in the world and is advancing global health by improving medical discovery, diagnostics and the delivery of care. BD supports the heroes on the frontlines of healthcare by developing innovative technology, services and solutions that help advance both clinical therapy for patients and clinical process for healthcare providers. BD has a presence in virtually every country and partners with organizations around the world to address some of the most challenging global health issues.
source_proposal: 7 - Global Pandemic Collaboration and Recovery.docx

name: Launch Bio
description: https://launchbio.org/webinars LaunchBio is a nonprofit organization that identifies, counsels, and supports high-growth, high-impact life science and biotechnology companies. Its mission is to build an ecosystem of innovation for the benefit of human health and well-being. Launch Bio also hosts webinars on various medical innovation topics such as US Biotech & life sciences private company trends, Micro gravity propels in Life Science and how microbiome is critical and emerging as a tool for drug development. Additionally, Launch Bio discusses the importance of diversity within life sciences for people of color and how to increase gender diversity within life sciences in their “Let’s Talk About” webinar program. Hospitals and Medical Resources
source_proposal: 7 - Global Pandemic Collaboration and Recovery.docx

name: Rady Children's Hospital Division of Infectious Diseases
description: The Division of Infectious Diseases specializes in the diagnosis, management and prevention of serious, complicated or unusual infections in children. Expert care is provided by the infectious disease specialists of Rady Children's Specialists of San Diego. The Division is also an integral part of the teaching program for the University of California, San Diego School of Medicine, training the best and brightest medical students, pediatric residents and pediatric infectious diseases fellows.
source_proposal: 7 - Global Pandemic Collaboration and Recovery.docx

name: UC San Diego Health
description: UCSD Health is a leading academic medical center which provides patient care, conducts research, and offers education and training across various medical specialties, including infectious diseases. They use an integrated information system (IIS) called Epic to manage patient data and coordinate care across departments, allowing healthcare providers to access and share patient information in a secure manner. In addition to Epic, UCSD Health also uses REDCap for managing research data, and Canvas for information and course delivery. Volunteer Opportunity
source_proposal: 7 - Global Pandemic Collaboration and Recovery.docx

name: La Maestra Community Health Centers
description: La Maestra Community Health Centers are agents of change in the community and a medical home to more than 45,000 patients in east, central, and south San Diego County. Since opening in 1990 with one volunteer physician, the organization has grown into a PCMH level III accredited Federally Qualified Health Center with ten locations in underserved communities throughout San Diego County, including school-based clinics and a mobile clinic. Over 500 staff and dozens of volunteers guide more than 45,000 patients per year to access healthcare and social services, most of whom are immigrants, refugees, homeless and low-income individuals with complex health and wellbeing needs.
source_proposal: 7 - Global Pandemic Collaboration and Recovery.docx

name: Red Cross
description: The San Diego Red Cross is a humanitarian organization that provides assistance to people affected by disasters and emergencies, as well as support to military service members and their families. They provide services such as disaster relief, emergency communications, health and safety training, blood donation services, and more. The San Diego Red Cross has a robust Service to the Armed Forces (SAF) program. This provides a range of services and resources to military personnel, veterans and their families. Volunteers with SAF can help with tasks such as assistance at military hospitals, facilitating communication between service members and their families during emergencies, and coordinating outreach efforts. They also provide support for families during times of separation, including deployments.
source_proposal: 7 - Global Pandemic Collaboration and Recovery.docx

name: I love A Clean San Diego
description: Founded as the San Diego War Against Litter Committee (WALC) in 1954, I Love A Clean San Diego (ILACSD) has worked to improve the health and beauty of San Diego for over 67 years. In 1980 it became the organization’s name. In 1989, ILACSD merged with the San Diego Ecology Center, joining two leading environmental organizations together to better serve the community, under one name. Today, the nonprofit is on a mission to create zero waste lifestyles and zero litter throughout San Diego County. ILACSD serves about 100,000 students, adults and businesses every year by providing environmental education, volunteer cleanup and beautification programs, and recycling and zero waste solutions. On average, the organization hosts over 900 workshops and produces 600 community cleanups each year. Community cleanups are responsible for clearing nearly half a million pounds of pollution from the region annually. Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).

name: Center for the Study of Women in Television and Film at San Diego State University
description: Dedicated to researching and analyzing the representation and portrayal of women in the television and film industry, the Center for the Study of Women in Television focuses on studying various aspects related to women’s participation in these mediums. Through extensive research and data analysis, the center aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of the current state of gender equality and diversity in the television and film industry. It examines key metrics such as the number of women characters, their roles, screen time, and the presence of stereotypes of gender biases in media content.
source_proposal: 7 - Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: San Diego School of Creative and Performing Arts
description: Focused on providing comprehensive arts education to students in the San Diego area, the San Diego School of Creative and Performing Arts offers specialized curriculum that integrates academics with intensive training in various artistic disciplines. The school places a strong emphasis on fostering artistic excellence, creativity, and personal growth, providing students with a well-rounded education that encompasses both artistic and academic development. Both its commitment to artistic excellence and academic rigor makes the San Diego School of Creative and Performing Arts a distinguished institution in San Diego’s arts education landscape.
source_proposal: 7 - Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: California State University San Marcos (CSUSM) School of Arts
description: The School of Arts at California State University San Marcos fosters a vibrant arts community on campus and the surrounding area. Hosting numerous exhibitions, performances, and events that showcase the talents of students, faculty, and visiting artists. The faculty consists of experienced artists and scholars who provide mentorship and guidance to students, helping them develop their skills and artistic voice. CSUSM School of Arts pushes for community engagement and outreach to contribute to the cultural enrichment and development of the region.
source_proposal: 7 - Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: California Institute of the Arts
description: California Institute of the Arts, or CalArts, has a unique and innovative approach to arts education, emphasizing interdisciplinary collaboration and experimentation. The institution places a strong emphasis on artistic freedom and self-expression that encourages students to explore their creative potential and push boundaries. Another notable aspect of CalArts is the integration of different art forms and disciplines. The institution encourages students to explore cross-disciplinary collaborations and experimentation, fostering an environment that nurtures artistic innovation and exploration. Incubators and Coalitions
source_proposal: 7 - Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: San Diego Regional Arts and Culture Coalition
description: The San Diego Regional Arts and Culture Coalition serves as a collective voice for the arts community that strives to raise awareness about the value and impact of arts and culture in the region. It advocates for increased public and private investment in the arts, arts education, and cultural programs. Additionally, the San Diego Regional Arts and Culture Coalition organizes events, workshops, and forums that promote networking, professional development, and knowledge-sharing within the arts community.
source_proposal: 7 - Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: Disco Riot
description: DISCO RIOT exists to elevate a collaborative art culture in San Diego and beyond — because “the world needs more movement-based art”. They connect dancers and artists who want to move themselves and audiences in ways that push boundaries to make high impact art that promotes community, justice, and movement as a form of radical expression. DISCO RIOT produces and supports innovative dance programming, connects artists across media and form to grow and intensify our community, and provide an educational space that reflects contemporary and progressive professional realities.
source_proposal: 7 - Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: The Studio Door
description: The Studio Door is an arts incubator and gallery space located in the North Park neighborhood of San Diego. It serves as a creative hub for artists, providing them with affordable studio spaces, exhibition opportunities, and a supportive community. The studio operates as a gallery that showcases the work for local and regional artists. It provides networking opportunities, community events, and collaborations that encourages artists to connect, exchange ideas, and support one another. The Studio Door plays a vital role in the San Diego art scene by providing artists with affordable spaces and exhibition opportunities.
source_proposal: 7 - Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: Space 4 Art:
description: Space 4 Art is a multidisciplinary arts organization located in downtown San Diego that serves as an art incubator while providing live/work spaces for artists. The organization offers affordable spaces where artists can reside and create. These studios offer a private and focused environment where artists can further develop their artistic practices and engage in experimentation and exploration. Through its initiatives in educational programs and outreach, Space 4 Art strives to bridge the gap between artists and public while also promoting dialogue and understanding of the arts.
source_proposal: 7 - Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: A Ship in the Woods
description: A Ship in the Woods is an experimental art space located in Escondido. It is known for its unique approach to showcasing and fostering interdisciplinary and boundary-pushing art forms. The organization encourages artists to experiment, collaborate, and engage in diverse disciplines. The space also organizes public events and workshops that invite audiences to experience and interact with art on display to develop meaningful connections and discussions. A Ship in the Woods is an innovative art space that pushes the boundaries of traditional artistic practices. Business Sector Resources
source_proposal: 7 - Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: The Old Globe
description: Modeled after Shakespeare’s Old Globe in London, the Old Globe Theatre was built in 1935 for the presentation of abridged versions of Shakespeare’s plays. The Old Globe has been home to some of the most acclaimed national artists, designers, directors, and playwrights in the theater industry. More than 20 productions produced at The Old Globe have gone on to play Broadway and Off Broadway, garnering 13 Tony Awards and numerous nominations. With a current operating budget of approximately $30 million, the Globe is one of San Diego’s largest arts institutions, its leading arts employer, and among the nation’s top-ranked regional theaters. More than 250,000 people annually attend Globe productions and participate in the theater’s arts engagement programs and outreach services.
source_proposal: 7 - Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: Bread & Salt
description: Bread & Salt is a 45,000 square-foot gallery and experimental center for the arts with strong community ties. Located 15 miles north of the U.S./Mexico border in San Diego, CA, Bread & Salt hosts original works by local and international artists, eclectic events, and a curated assemblage of artisans, educational entities, and non-profit tenants - alongside a robust residency program and publishing house. It comprises multiple gallery, studio, and event spaces, and serves as a cultural hub and gathering place for the region’s creative community.
source_proposal: 7 - Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: La Jolla Playhouse
description: https://lajollaplayhouse.org/without-walls/ La Jolla Playhouse advances theater as an art form, telling stories that inspire empathy and create a dialogue toward a more just future. With their intrepid spirit and eclectic, artist-driven approach they continue to cultivate a local, national and global following with an insatiable appetite for audacious work. La Jolla Playhouse provides unfettered creative opportunities for a community of artists of all backgrounds and abilities. They are committed to being a permanent safe harbor for unsafe and surprising work, offering a glimpse of the new and the next in American theater.
source_proposal: 7 - Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: San Diego Symphony Orchestra
description: The San Diego Symphony, through unquestionable commitment to the highest levels of artistic achievement, seeks to elevate human potential by providing a shared sense of pride and belonging to something bigger than any of us can achieve alone. They offer audiences the wonder of live music and transformative learning experiences that develop an understanding and passion for the arts. They serve and shape the culture of the region, by being for all and with all, the musical heart of San Diego. Government Resources
source_proposal: 7 - Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: City of San Diego Commission for Arts and Culture
description: https://www.sandiego.gov/sites/default/files/2022-08-25_creative_corp_news_release.pdf The commission’s primary mission is to be able to enhance the quality of life for San Diego residents by fostering a vibrant and diverse arts and culture community. It plays a crucial role in allocating grants to artists, art organizations, and community groups through competitive funding programs. In addition to funding, the commission facilitates partnerships and collaborations among artists, art organizations. and community stakeholders. It also organizes events, workshops, and networking opportunities to foster connections and professional development within the arts community.
source_proposal: 7 - Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: Far South/Border North
description: Far South/Border North is a regional collaborative supporting artists and cultural practitioners in communities in San Diego and Imperial counties. To support the social, environmental, and civic engagement of California’s most disproportionately impacted communities, the California Arts Council developed California Creative Corps, which in turn led to the creation of Far South/Border North. The project provides grant funding and development opportunities for artists and cultural practitioners from various mediums, whose work addresses one or more of the program’s goals. Some of these goals include climate mitigation, emergency preparedness, civic engagement, social justice, and community engagement. Meeting focus: Explore how this 2-year investment opportunity is supporting artists throughout San Diego to promote social change and civic engagement. Non-profit Resources David’s Harp Foundation ​​www.davidsharpfoundation.org David’s Harp Foundation aims to inspire, educate and empower at-risk and homeless youth to achieve academic success through music education, sound engineering and multimedia production. Programs include Multimedia Production where instructors teach students to fuse audio, video, still image and animation into a dynamic. The Foundation also hosts a Shelter Nights program in partnership with San Diego Youth Services’ Emergency Youth Shelter. After checking into the shelter for the night, Youth Shelter teens work with instructors in their studio to write, record and produce original music and poetry, motivating teens to stay off the streets and hone their musical interests.
source_proposal: 7 - Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: Vanguard Culture
description: Vanguard Culture is an inclusive 501(c)3 nonprofit dedicated to advancing San Diego’s Creative Industries. They provide award-winning arts journalism, cutting edge events, and professional development that create arts jobs, bring diverse communities together and inspire collaboration among the visual, performing, and culinary arts. They have many cultural events, professional development services (mixers and networking), as well as arts coverage.
source_proposal: 7 - Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: Museum of Contemporary Art San Diego
description: The Museum of Contemporary Art San Diego is a prominent art institution dedicated to collecting, preserving, and exhibiting contemporary art. The museum focuses on art from the 1950s to the present, showcasing works by renowned national and international artists as well as emerging talents. In addition to its exhibitions, the museum offers a range of educational programs for all ages, including lectures, artists talks, workshops, and guided tours. The museum is also partnered with local schools, organizations, and community groups to provide access to the arts and promote arts education.
source_proposal: 7 - Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: Balboa Park Cultural Partnership
description: The Balboa Park Cultural Partnership is a collaborative organization consisting of over 30 cultural institutions located in Balboa Park, San Diego. The partnership serves as a platform for collaboration and coordination among its member institutions, which includes museums, performing art venues, gardens, and other cultural organizations. Additionally, the organization also works closely with the City of San Diego and other stakeholders to advocate for the arts and culture in the park. Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).
source_proposal: 7 - Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: Chicano Park
description: Chicano Park is the geographic and emotional heart of Barrio Logan, located in Logan Heights, San Diego's oldest Mexican-American neighborhood. The park is home to the largest concentration of Chicano murals in the world with more than 80 paintings on seven acres dotted with sculpture, gardens, picnic tables and playgrounds. Throughout the year, it hosts festivals of music and Aztec dance, the biggest being Chicano Park Day held each April. Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $30 for one Adult Ticket for a one-hour narrated tour (south bay or north bay routes); $35 for a full bay two-hour narrated tour which covers it all: ships of the Maritime Museum, Harbor and Shelter Islands, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and more. The full bay tour is about 25 miles in length. Accessibility: The tour begins and ends at the same location downtown along Broadway Pier. Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com Price: $44 for a 1-Day Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) For 30 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours, highlighting the best San Diego attractions. The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50am – 5:00pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $26 for one Adult General Admission Ticket ($1 discount when purchased on-line). Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10am – 5pm (Last admission at 4pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside Navy Pier.
source_proposal: 7 - Promoting Social Change through the Arts.docx

name: Border Field State Park & Friendship Park
description: https://www.friendshippark.org/ Located within the Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve, Border Field State Park sits in the very southwestern corner of the United States, 15 miles south of San Diego. This important wildlife habitat, comprised of sand dunes and salt marshes, gives refuge to critically threatened and endangered birds such as the Western Snowy Plover, the California Least Tern, and the Light-footed Ridgway's Rail. Friendship Park is a binational park located at the western end of the US-Mexico border. For generations people have gathered here to meet up with friends and family "across the line." Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 17 major museums and cultural institutions, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).
