name: Energy Policy Initiatives Center
description: The Energy Policy Initiatives Center is a research center at the University of San Diego School of Law studying how energy policy issues affect California and the San Diego region. The Center strives to increase awareness and understanding of energy- climate-related policy issues by conducting research and analysis to inform decision-makers and educating law students. By drawing on expertise in law, policy, economics, and science, the Center brings together students, scholars, and practitioners within the school of law and serves the public interest.
source_proposal: 7- Renewable Energy as an Economic Driver_ IVLP Proposal.docx

name: Climate Equity in the San Diego Region
description: Climate Equity in the San Diego Region was developed at the University of San Diego Energy Policy Initiatives Center. The Climate Equity Index was first released in 2019 and evaluated environmental, socioeconomic, mobility, and health factors related to the impact of climate change and related policies. Climate equity is defined as “addressing historical and inequities suffered by people of color, allowing everyone to fairly share the same benefits and burdens from climate solutions and attain full and equal access to opportunities regardless of one’s background and identity.” The Index intended to assess the impact that climate change will have on certain communities and the barriers to new energy technologies.
source_proposal: 7- Renewable Energy as an Economic Driver_ IVLP Proposal.docx

name: David Victor, PhD - University of California, San Diego
description: Dr. David Victor is a professor of innovation and public policy at the School of Global Policy and Strategy at UC San Diego. He is the Co-Director of the campus-wide Deep Decarbonization Initiative which focuses on real world strategies bringing the world to nearly zero emissions of warming gasses. His research is at the intersection of climate change science and policy where he focuses on regulated industries and how regulation affects the operation of major energy markets. He authored Global Warming Gridlock which explains why the world has not made diplomatic progress on the problem of climate change while also exploring more effective new strategies. Dr. Victor is also a non-resident senior fellow at The Brookings Institution. He is a member of the World Economic Forum’s Global Future Council on Energy, where his work focuses on the role of natural gas as a transition fuel to deep decarbonization.
source_proposal: 7- Renewable Energy as an Economic Driver_ IVLP Proposal.docx

name: Fonna Forman - University of California San Diego, Climate Change, Policy and Political Science
description: Forman is a Professor of Political Science and Founding Director of the Center on Global Justice at UCSD. Forman’s research engages the intersection of urban policy and the city with a focus on climate justice with various projects on climate justice including an investigation of climate risk and vulnerability in California’s underserved communities. Forman blurs the conventional boundaries of theory and practice and co-leads a variety of urban research agendas and civic/public interventions in the San Diego-Tijuana border region and beyond. Think Tanks and Working Groups
source_proposal: 7- Renewable Energy as an Economic Driver_ IVLP Proposal.docx

name: Jeremy Martin Vice President Energy & Stability - Institute of the Americas
description: The Institute of the Americas is dedicated to being a catalyst for promoting economic development and integration. The Institute of the Americas undertakes programs, develops policy papers and organizes conferences, roundtable discussions, and webinars addressing emerging issues of importance to countries across the Americas. The Institute’s Energy & Sustainability program has played a crucial role in shaping policy discourse and informing investors on the most important trends in the energy sector. Jeremy M. Martin is Vice President, Energy & Sustainability at the Institute of Americas. Martin has testified before the U.S. Congress on energy issues in Latin America, teaches a graduate course in Latin American Energy Policy at the University of California San Diego and the University of San Diego and serves on the Board of Advisors for the Inter-American Dialogue’s Energy Advisor newsletter. Private Sector Organizations
source_proposal: 7- Renewable Energy as an Economic Driver_ IVLP Proposal.docx

name: Controlled Thermal Resources
description: Controlled Thermal Resources combines direct lithium extraction with renewable geothermal power to set new benchmarks to provide renewable energy to the western U.S. and to deliver the most sustainable, battery-grade lithium products in the world today. Demand for lithium, which is used in batteries and energy storage systems to power cars, cities, and countries, is expected to surge by approximately 2 million tons per annum by 2030. Controlled Thermal Resources’ leadership team has successfully developed and managed world-scale renewable energy projects in the Salton Sea region for over 20 years. Note: Controlled Thermal Resources is located in the Salton Sea, approximately 2.5 hours outside of the San Diego metro region.
source_proposal: 7- Renewable Energy as an Economic Driver_ IVLP Proposal.docx

name: Tenaska Imperial Solar
description: As California electricity providers strive to meet the requirements of the state’s Renewables Portfolio Standard, Tenaska has been developing solar energy projects in Imperial County. Tenaska Solar Ventures, LLC (TSV) manages solar projects in North America. TSV has several utility-scale projects in Imperial County in Southern California. Current projects range from 130 to 160 megawatts (MW) and are among the largest solar generating facilities in California powering almost 100, 000 homes. Tenaska Imperial Solar Energy Center South was the first large-scale solar project to begin construction in Imperial County, and it is the first large-scale solar project to transmit power from the Imperial Valley via San Diego Gas & Electric’s (SDG&E) new Sunrise Powerlink transmission line. It is also one of the largest commercially financed solar projects in the U.S. to date.
source_proposal: 7- Renewable Energy as an Economic Driver_ IVLP Proposal.docx

name: Ocean Motion Technologies
description: Ocean Motion Technologies aims to scale ocean wave energy through lowering the cost of power at sea and enabling a new era of big blue data. The bluetech sector needs products in small-scale energy to fuel research and development needed to scale wave energy. Ocean Motion Technologies develops devices that are meant to last and reduce the cost for end users. Devices vary from the world’s first adaptive ocean wave energy converters controlled by an advanced artificial system to the world’s first compressed air energy storage system for marine applications.
source_proposal: 7- Renewable Energy as an Economic Driver_ IVLP Proposal.docx

name: Nuvve project with Cajon Valley Unified School District and San Diego Gas & Electric
description: https://www.sdgenews.com/article/sdge-and-cajon-valley-union-school-district-flip-switch-regions-first-vehicle-grid-project Combining the world’s most advanced vehicle-to-grid (V2G) technology and an ecosystem of electrification partners, Nuvve dynamically manages power among EV batteries and the grid to deliver new value to EV owners, and support the world’s transition to clean energy. By transforming EVs into mobile energy storage assets and networking battery capacity to support shifting energy needs, Nuvve is making the grid more resilient, enhancing sustainable transportation, and supporting energy equity in an electrified world. In July 2022, San Diego Gas & Electric, Nuvve, and Cajon Valley Union School District announced that it had successfully deployed an innovative technology that enables eight electric school buses to put electricity back on the grid when needed.
source_proposal: 7- Renewable Energy as an Economic Driver_ IVLP Proposal.docx

name: Sempra
description: Sempra Energy is a global energy infrastructure company focused on leading the way of advancing electrification and promoting energy diversification, resiliency and affordable access to cleaner forms of energy. From its San Diego headquarters to operations throughout the Americas, Sempra Energy is making strides in developing forward-thinking energy solutions and delivering everyday power to customers. Sempra Energy believes the global energy ecosystem is going to change dramatically over the next 30 years. In advanced economies, the change will take the form of innovation and technology that improves energy efficiency and supports a shift toward new, smart renewable and natural gas infrastructure. In developing nations, improving energy diversity will be the central effort as new, smart infrastructure that supports renewables and natural gas displaces higher carbon forms of energy. San Diego Gas & Electric, Energy Innovation Center (SDG&E) www.sdge.com/eic SDG&E is a regulated public utility that provides energy service to 3.6 million people through 1.4 million electric meters and 873,000 natural gas meters in San Diego and southern Orange counties. Their service area spans 4,100 square miles. The Energy Innovation Center at SDG&E is a working showcase that demonstrates smart energy initiatives and green building practices, all housed in one unique setting. This double LEED Platinum facility offers visitors a venue for learning and exploring the latest in energy efficiency, renewable energy, smart grid and alternative fuel technologies. Non –Profits and NGOs
source_proposal: 7- Renewable Energy as an Economic Driver_ IVLP Proposal.docx

name: San Diego Community Power
description: San Diego Community Power is a locally run, not-for-profit public agency that is a new electric generation service provider for San Diego. San Diego Community Power is shifting control from profit-driven investor-owned utility into the hands of customers. This supports local job creation and development of renewable energy projects close to home while reinvesting revenues into the communities they serve. Terra Lawson-Remer serves on the Board of Directors and is also San Diego County Supervisor where she is an economist, attorney, grassroots organizer, and educator dedicated to working for social, environmental, and economic justice. Municipal Energy Policy Management
source_proposal: 7- Renewable Energy as an Economic Driver_ IVLP Proposal.docx

name: The City of San Diego, Sustainability and Mobility Department
description: The Sustainability and Mobility Department leads San Diego's Climate Action Plan. Centered on striving for equitable, efficient and effective mobility choices that support all communities, the Department continuously works to facilitate innovative efforts to enhance equitable, economic, social and environmental sustainability. The 2022 Climate Action Plan established a community-wide goal of net zero by 2035, committing San Diego to reducing the use of greenhouse gasses.
source_proposal: 7- Renewable Energy as an Economic Driver_ IVLP Proposal.docx

name: University of San Diego
description: The University of San Diego (USD) is an academic institution with a student population of around 9,000. USD offers comprehensive education across its seven schools and colleges, particularly standing out for its emphasis on business development and entrepreneurship. The School of Business provides students with valuable resources, mentorship programs, and experiential learning opportunities, empowering them to thrive in the ever-evolving business landscape. In addition, the University of San Diego is renowned for its Joan B. Kroc School of Peace Studies, which offers innovative programs and initiatives dedicated to advancing peacebuilding, conflict resolution, and social justice on a global scale. Spark @ USD, Joan B. Kroc School of Peace Studies www.sandiego.edu/peace/institutes/ipj Dedicated to fostering peace, cultivating justice, and creating a safer world, the Joan B. Kroc Institute for Peace & Justice (IPJ) of the University of San Diego is an international nonprofit organization working to improve the lives of those caught in the web of armed conflict and human rights abuses. Existing within the Kroc School, Spark is an entrepreneurial hub that fosters innovation and supports aspiring student entrepreneurs. It provides a collaborative space where students can develop their entrepreneurial ideas, connect with mentors, and receive guidance to launch their ventures. Spark offers various resources, including workshops, networking events, and access to a strong network of industry professionals. One of the key meeting focus areas at Spark is social entrepreneurship, where students are encouraged to explore business ideas that address societal challenges and create positive impact.
source_proposal: 8 - Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: Master of Arts in Social Innovation
description: Look critically at the roots of social challenges and injustice, and then seek to create real change through bold new responses to poverty, inequality, human rights abuses and humanitarian crises. The Master's in Social Innovation degree is unlike any other in that it starts by diving deep into real social challenges, then pairs that knowledge with critical thinking, inventiveness, leadership and sustainable business design. Through the Social Innovation Challenge, university students in San Diego and Tijuana generate ideas for innovative ventures that respond to a social, economic, environmental, or justice issue of their choice, and compete for seed funding to launch or expand their ventures. Meeting focus: Discuss the university’s focus on social innovation and initiatives to welcome more young entrepreneurs into the space
source_proposal: 8 - Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: Fowler Global Social Innovation Challenge
description: The Fowler Global Social Innovation Challenge is an exciting competition hosted by the University of San Diego's Center for Peace and Commerce. It invites students from around the world to develop innovative solutions to pressing social and environmental issues. Participants form teams and undergo a rigorous process of ideation, prototyping, and refining their ideas with the guidance of mentors. The challenge culminates in a live pitch event where finalists present their solutions to a panel of judges and compete for funding and support. Since 2011, they have connected more than 2,500 students, recognizing their outstanding social ventures. They have also distributed more than $600,000 to seed innovative and promising global ventures.
source_proposal: 8 - Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: Brink Small Business Development Center
description: The Brink SBDC is a specialty center focused on innovation, one of only a handful of its kind in the country, hosted at University of San Diego. The Brink SDBC works with business clients running or starting growth-oriented, innovation-based companies with fewer than 500 employees. The Brink SBDC works with entrepreneurs with an innovative product, solution or service and has a larger than local addressable market and a scalable business model. Their expert advisors provide one-on-one consulting, training workshops, and access to valuable resources and networks. Whether it's developing a business plan, securing funding, or navigating regulatory requirements, the Brink SBDC assists entrepreneurs at every stage of their journey.
source_proposal: 8 - Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: Lavin Entrepreneurship Center, San Diego State University
description: The Lavin Entrepreneurship Center at San Diego State University (SDSU) is a dynamic hub that nurtures and supports aspiring entrepreneurs in their pursuit of innovation and business success. It serves students, entrepreneurs and business leaders through its entrepreneurial curriculum, workshops, internships, resources and events. The Center has developed diverse hands-on learning opportunities that complement and enrich entrepreneur education, enabling students to translate their knowledge into practice. Students experience the challenges of creating business plans, commercializing products and growing new ventures, all while building a diverse network of peers and mentors. The Lavin Center has been recognized for having one of the best entrepreneurial programs in the United States by both Princeton Review and Entrepreneur magazine. With a commitment to fostering an entrepreneurial mindset, the center offers a range of programs, resources, and workshops designed to equip students with the skills and knowledge needed to thrive in the modern business landscape. One of their popular workshops is on Digital Marketing and Social Media Strategies. This workshop dives into the realm of digital marketing, exploring effective tactics and strategies for utilizing social media platforms, creating engaging content, optimizing online advertising, and implementing search engine optimization (SEO) techniques. Participants gain insights into how to effectively leverage digital channels to reach target audiences, build brand awareness, drive customer engagement, and ultimately enhance their online presence.
source_proposal: 8 - Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: La Jolla Country Day School – Center for Design and Innovation
description: La Jolla Country Day School (LJCDS) is a private college prep school in the coastal community of La Jolla. The school’s Innovation Program challenges students to identify real-world problems and design innovative solutions to effect positive change for a better world. The curriculum from kindergarten to Grade 12 focuses on learning how to use cutting-edge tools and technologies while developing an understanding of the social impacts of technology, solutions and design. LJCDS’ Innovation Lab serves as a collaborative space that is equipped with a laser cutter (built from scratch by Upper School students), 3D printers, microcontrollers, Wacom tablets, drills, screwdrivers, hammers, sticky notes and anything else students may need for creative design and innovation. Additionally, LJCDS offers a venture capital fund for their students called the Torrey Explorer’s Fund (TEF). Whether students seek to start a business, launch a social campaign, invent a technology or create an art installation, TEF will offer mentorship by a team of local entrepreneurs and professionals and/or funding to help bring students’ ideas to fruition. Incubators and Accelerators Hera Hub www.herahub.com Hera Hub is the first international female-focused coworking space – a shared, flexible work and meeting space where entrepreneurial women can create and collaborate in a professional, productive, modern environment. The platform provides members with connections to other business experts, access to educational workshops, and visibility within the community, thus giving women the support they need to be prosperous. In addition, Hera Fund gathers Angel Investors and pairs them with women owned businesses. The company was founded in San Diego, CA in 2011 and has since then been growing with locations sprouting up all over the U.S. and Europe. Meeting focus: How a coworking space has empowered women by addressing multiple community needs in San Diego. Representatives will give visitors a tour and discuss how Hera Hub empowers female entrepreneurs. San Diego Hispanic Chamber of e-commerce www.hiscec.com After realizing there was a digital gap between the Hispanic community and the business world, Tayde Aburto founded the Hispanic Chamber of e-Commerce eight years ago. The Chamber aims to empower small businesses run by Hispanics by enabling these businesses to become successful in e-commerce. The Hispanic Chamber of e-Commerce offers courses and consulting services throughout the County to educate small business owners as to the need to have, at the very least, a website, Facebook page, or LinkedIn account. What started as a small group of advocates is today an organization with more than a thousand members. Meeting focus: Learn how new digital technologies can impact the local and regional economic development of small business; Meet with small business owners using new digital technologies to help grow their activity.
source_proposal: 8 - Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: Vanguard Culture
description: Vanguard Culture San Diego is a dynamic nonprofit organization dedicated to advancing and celebrating the arts and culture scene in the region. Their mission is to provide a platform for emerging and established artists, curators, and arts organizations, fostering creativity and innovation. Through curated exhibitions, immersive events, and thought-provoking programs, Vanguard Culture nurtures connections between artists and diverse audiences, cultivating dialogue and engagement. They strive to empower artists, promote inclusivity, and contribute to the cultural vibrancy of San Diego. With a focus on interdisciplinary collaborations and community partnerships, Vanguard Culture plays a pivotal role in supporting and amplifying the local arts community's impact and visibility. Economic Development and Investment
source_proposal: 8 - Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: Smart Border Coalition
description: The Smart Border Coalition is a catalyst to bring together leading academic, business and civic communities from both sides of the San Diego/Tijuana International region to develop databases and policy positions, deliver special events and programs, and growth of the cross-border economy through jobs creation, workforce development and social interaction. Their mission is to make travel and trade easier and more efficient through the ports of entry between San Diego County and the Tijuana Metropolitan Area.
source_proposal: 8 - Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: San Diego Regional Policy & Innovation Center
description: The Policy & Innovation Center conducts world-class research, supports coordinated governmental and agency relationships, develops consensus regarding the region’s core needs, and recommends policy solutions to assist local leaders in attracting federal and state impact dollars and addressing regional issues such as improving critical infrastructure, creating stable high-paying jobs; and generating other measurable long-term socio-economic and environmental benefits. The Policy & Innovation Center supports recovery from the cascading economic effects of COVID-19 and meets the needs of underserved communities by attracting funding and resources to the region; working with local municipalities and regional agencies to co-design new programs and pursue federal recovery and infrastructure funding; crafting new policy solutions; and driving large-scale private partnerships and investment opportunities.
source_proposal: 8 - Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: San Diego Regional Chamber of Commerce – Policy
description: The San Diego Regional Chamber of Commerce is committed to making San Diego the most business-friendly region in California. A strong economy creates jobs that support families, neighborhoods, and the entire region. Since the late 1800s, the Chamber has helped San Diego grow by engaging with elected officials, their members, and the public to address the issues most important to job creation and the region. Today, as much as ever, they are committed to an even better future for San Diego. San Diego and Imperial Small Business Development Center The San Diego and Imperial Small Business Development Center (SBDC) is a valuable resource for entrepreneurs and small business owners in the region. As part of the California SBDC network, they offer a wide range of services and support to help businesses succeed. The SBDC provides expert guidance through one-on-one consulting, training workshops, and access to valuable resources and networks. They assist with various aspects of business development, including business planning, marketing strategies, financial management, and accessing capital. The San Diego and Imperial SBDC plays a crucial role in fostering entrepreneurship, job creation, and economic growth by providing tailored assistance and empowering small businesses to thrive in a competitive market. Director of the SBDC, Briana Weisinger, has worked with hundreds of startups as well as opening and closing her own businesses, thus she understands the struggles related to small business ownership. Her personal missions include uplifting equality in the business world and working with multiple local organizations to promote women entrepreneurs. She believes in giving her time generously to these personal missions. She became director of the SBDC after a long and impressive repertoire in the field.
source_proposal: 8 - Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: Torrey Project
description: The Torrey Project is an innovative initiative focused on empowering the next generation of entrepreneurs and leaders. They provide a platform for young individuals to develop essential skills, network with industry professionals, and gain real-world experience. Through mentorship programs, workshops, and entrepreneurial challenges, participants are equipped with the tools and knowledge needed to succeed in a rapidly changing business landscape. The Torrey Project fosters creativity, critical thinking, and collaboration, encouraging participants to think outside the box and pursue their passions. The Torrey Project Seed Fund is a vital component of the Torrey Project's mission to support and invest in promising startups and early-stage ventures. The seed fund provides crucial financial resources and mentorship to selected entrepreneurs, helping them turn their innovative ideas into successful businesses. The Torrey Project aims to invest in diverse founders and ventures that exhibit strong growth potential, disruptive ideas, and a commitment to making a positive impact. They seek out entrepreneurs with a drive for innovation, a clear vision for their business, and a scalable business model, and focus on supporting those who are typically overlooked by traditional forms of seed capital. The Torrey Project is particularly interested in supporting ventures in emerging industries such as technology, sustainability, healthcare, and social impact. Government Resources
source_proposal: 8 - Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: The City of San Diego’s Economic Development Department
description: The City of San Diego's Economic Development Department provides valuable resources and support to entrepreneurs and businesses, helping them succeed and contribute to the local economy. The department offers various programs and initiatives, including business development assistance, workforce training, and access to funding opportunities. Two notable examples of their projects include the Business Acceleration Program, which provides tailored support to high-growth startups, and the Small Business Enhancement Program, which offers grants and resources to small businesses for expansion and improvement. Through their initiatives, the Economic Development Department actively supports entrepreneurship, job creation, and economic growth in San Diego.With the goal of promoting economic opportunity for all segments of the population, the City of San Diego leverages public incentives and assistance to foster community revitalization, attract new businesses and encourage investment in local businesses. The City of San Diego not only assists individual businesses but also helps strengthen business organizations and improve business districts throughout San Diego.
source_proposal: 8 - Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: U.S Small Business Administration– San Diego District
description: https://www.sba.gov/funding-programs/loans/microloans The U.S. Small Business Administration (SBA) - San Diego District plays a crucial role in supporting small businesses in the region. In the past fiscal year, the San Diego District office provided significant support, including over $200 million in loans to small businesses, helping them access the capital needed to start, grow, and expand their ventures. The SBA San Diego District offers a range of programs and services, with a particular emphasis on microlending. They collaborate with local microlenders to provide small loans to entrepreneurs and underserved communities, fostering economic development and job creation. Through their efforts, the SBA San Diego District is instrumental in driving the success of small businesses and fueling economic growth in the community. Non-profit Resources
source_proposal: 8 - Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: San Diego Entrepreneurs Exchange
description: The San Diego Entrepreneurs Exchange (SDEE) is a nonprofit 501(c)(3) organization run by local entrepreneurs for entrepreneurs and pre-entrepreneurs interested in Life Sciences, Biotech, Pharma, Medical Devices, Tech and Alternative Energy. SDEE was founded to provide a voice and resources for early stage startups, to encourage new entrepreneurs, and sponsor networking and educational services to help develop skills necessary to bring new businesses and funding to the San Diego area.
source_proposal: 8 - Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: Connect
description: Connect is a non-profit organization that has assisted in the formation and development of more than 3,000 companies in the San Diego region, and is widely regarded as one of the world’s most successful organizations linking inventors and entrepreneurs with the resources they need for commercialization of innovative products in high tech and life sciences. The program has been modeled in more than 50 regions around the world. In 2019, Connect and San Diego Venture Group merged, combining the deep histories and wide successes of each organization to create a powerhouse of resources such as mentorship, education, and capital for quality companies.
source_proposal: 8 - Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: San Diego Regional Economic Development Corporation (EDC)
description: The San Diego Regional Economic Development Corporation (EDC) is an independently-funded economic development organization that mobilizes business, government, and civic leaders around an inclusive economic development strategy in order to connect data to decision making, maximize regional prosperity, enhance global competitiveness, and position San Diego effectively for investment and talent. The EDC provides resources, data analysis, and strategic insights to help businesses make informed decisions and navigate the local business landscape. They also engage in advocacy efforts to shape policies that promote economic development and create a favorable business environment.
source_proposal: 8 - Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: Women’s Empowerment International
description: Women's Empowerment International (WE) is a nonprofit organization dedicated to empowering women and girls in underserved communities around the world. Their mission is to create sustainable change by providing education, entrepreneurship training, and access to resources. WE believes that when women are given the tools and support to succeed, entire communities benefit. They work in collaboration with local partners to develop programs that address the unique challenges faced by women, including poverty, limited education, and lack of economic opportunities. Through their initiatives, WE aims to break the cycle of poverty, promote gender equality, and empower women to become leaders and change agents in their communities.Women’s Empowerment International (WE Center) STAR program (Support, Training and Assistance to Refugee) Women, a partnership between the International Rescue Committee (IRC) and WE, was created to provide a culturally sensitive setting for refugee and low-income women to receive assistance in starting or expanding a business.
source_proposal: 8 - Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: Kitchens for Good
description: Kitchens for Good is a 501(c)(3) and social enterprise with the mission to break the cycles of food waste, hunger, and poverty through innovative solutions in workforce training, healthy food production, and social enterprise. Kitchens for Good rescues surplus and cosmetically imperfect food from wholesalers and farmers, and engages students in a culinary apprenticeship program. Through the power of kitchens and cooking, their students transform their lives from one of addiction, incarceration, homelessness, and unemployment, to lives of stability, employment, and a brighter future.
source_proposal: 8 - Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: North San Diego Business Chamber
description: North San Diego Business Chamber is the only 5-star United States Chamber of Commerce accredited organization in San Diego County. North San Diego Business Chamber’s mission is to build vibrant communities through stronger commerce. It provides businesses with benefits designed to meet organizations’ current needs based on the economic climate and to help them succeed and grow, through offerings including a robust mentorship program. The chamber recognizes the importance of mentorship in fostering professional growth, providing guidance, and sharing industry expertise. Through their mentorship programs, they connect experienced business professionals with aspiring entrepreneurs or individuals seeking career advancement. Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).
source_proposal: 8 - Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: Chicano Park
description: Chicano Park is the geographic and emotional heart of Barrio Logan, located in Logan Heights, San Diego's oldest Mexican-American neighborhood. The park is home to the largest concentration of Chicano murals in the world with more than 80 paintings on seven acres dotted with sculpture, gardens, picnic tables and playgrounds. Throughout the year, it hosts festivals of music and Aztec dance, the biggest being Chicano Park Day held each April. Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $30 for one Adult Ticket for a one-hour narrated tour (south bay or north bay routes); $35 for a full bay two-hour narrated tour which covers it all: ships of the Maritime Museum, Harbor and Shelter Islands, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and more. The full bay tour is about 25 miles in length. Accessibility: The tour begins and ends at the same location downtown along Broadway Pier. Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com Price: $44 for a 1-Day Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) For 30 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours, highlighting the best San Diego attractions. The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50am – 5:00pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $26 for one Adult General Admission Ticket ($1 discount when purchased on-line). Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10am – 5pm (Last admission at 4pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside Navy Pier.
source_proposal: 8 - Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: Border Field State Park & Friendship Park
description: https://www.friendshippark.org/ Located within the Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve, Border Field State Park sits in the very southwestern corner of the United States, 15 miles south of San Diego. This important wildlife habitat, comprised of sand dunes and salt marshes, gives refuge to critically threatened and endangered birds such as the Western Snowy Plover, the California Least Tern, and the Light-footed Ridgway's Rail. Friendship Park is a binational park located at the western end of the US-Mexico border. For generations people have gathered here to meet up with friends and family "across the line." Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 17 major museums and cultural institutions, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).
source_proposal: 8 - Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: Coronado
description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year around due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown. SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $99.99 for one Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Orca Encounter, Dolphin Days, and Sea Lions Live shows and thrilling rides like Electric Eel, Manta, and Journey To Atlantis. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Hours vary by season. Also enjoy the opening of Sesame Place in March 2022, a Sesame Street themed section of the park with new water, ride, and musical attractions. Accessibility: A 15-20-minute drive from downtown San Diego.
source_proposal: 8 - Entrepreneurship and Small Business Development.docx

name: City of San Diego, Welcoming San Diego
description: Welcoming San Diego is a City of San Diego initiative is designed to advance the civic, social and economic integration of immigrants and refugees. They envision a vibrant, inclusive, and safe binational region that attracts families and businesses from around the world and that all San Diegans can flourish in. As the birthplace of California, San Diego is a gateway for newcomers searching for freedom and opportunity. Their strength and future is tied to our ability to ensure New Americans can fully participate in civic life, access public resources, and contribute their skills. San Diego was awarded the Gateways for Growth grant to bring together other local government agencies, nonprofits, educational institutions and businesses to develop a strategic plan on immigrant integration. In February of 2019, the City of San Diego formally launched the Welcoming San Diego Initiative accompanied by the Welcoming San Diego Strategic Plan. The City’s Immigrant Affairs Manager is responsible for continuing this effort.
source_proposal: 8- Regional Responses to Refugee and Migration Issues.docx

name: City of San Diego, Office of Immigration and Refugee Affairs
description: The Office of Immigration and Refugee Affairs was created with the mission of advancing equality and opportunities for immigrant and refugee communities by removing barriers to help them integrate into society and thrive. They serve as regional experts and leader in immigrant and refugee affairs. OIRA collaborates closely with local resettlement agencies to devote county resources to the immigrant population regardless of immigration, refugee, or visa status. The office also serves as the County Refugee Coordinator to the State of California. Meeting focus: meet with local government officials within the City of San Diego’s Immigrant Affairs and those working in Welcoming San Diego department to learn about how they prepare for refugee arrivals and how they help integrate them into the local community.
source_proposal: 8- Regional Responses to Refugee and Migration Issues.docx

name: San Diego Police Department (SDPD) Multi-Cultural Community Relations Office
description: https://www.facebook.com/sdpd.MCCRO/ The San Diego Police Department (SDPD) is the primary law enforcement agency for the city of San Diego. The Multi-Cultural Community Relations Office was established by the SDPD in 1987 to address the specific needs of the growing refugee population in San Diego. Their mission is to maintain open communications with immigrant and refugee communities within the City of San Diego and contribute to the safety and security of these communities by offering crime prevention support and assistance. Non-Profit Organization Resources:
source_proposal: 8- Regional Responses to Refugee and Migration Issues.docx

name: Border Angels
description: Border Angels is a non-profit organization that started in 1986 with the goal of helping migrants living in the canyons of North San Diego County. Since then, they have expanded their mission to include advocating for human rights, humane immigration reform, and social justice. The goal of their work is to educate and assist communities on both sides of the US-Mexico border in order to reduce the number of fatalities. Some of the services they provide are educational programs, water drops in the desert, day laborer outreach, Familias Reunidas Immigration Bond Fund Program, and Shelter Aid support in Tijuana to aid migrants and asylum seekers in need.
source_proposal: 8- Regional Responses to Refugee and Migration Issues.docx

name: International Rescue Committee
description: The International Rescue Committee provides opportunities for refugees, asylees, victims of human trafficking, survivors of torture, and other immigrants to thrive in America. Each year, thousands of people, forced to flee violence and persecution, are welcomed by the people of the United States into the safety and freedom of America. These individuals have survived against incredible odds. The IRC collaborates closely with government bodies, civil society actors, and local volunteers to support refugees, asylum-seekers, and other immigrants in San Diego, as they work to rebuild their lives.
source_proposal: 8- Regional Responses to Refugee and Migration Issues.docx

name: Jewish Family Services – Refugee & Immigration Services
description: https://www.jfssd.org/our-services/refugees-immigration/ Since 1918, Jewish Family Services (JFS) has offered resettlement services to newly arriving refugees and asylees from around the world. Today, their Refugee Resettlement department works with approximately 45 cases each month, helping refugee families adjust to their new lives here in the U.S. JFS helps them learn English and find jobs. They teach them how to navigate the medical system, banks, and public transportation. They provide: a fully furnished apartment, airport pick up, acculturation services, translation/ESL services, employment services, advocacy, and more.
source_proposal: 8- Regional Responses to Refugee and Migration Issues.docx

name: Alliance for African Assistance
description: The Alliance for African Assistance is a non-profit, which assists with the resettlement of 1,020 asylum seekers, individuals, and families from Afghanistan who began arriving on September 1st with a goal of resettling all in San Diego by the end of February, 2022. They have a partnership with Rancho Santa Fe Foundation to help their supporters maximize their support of the resettlement of Afghan families, the first $50,000 of donations received will be doubled. Meeting focus: learn about Alliance for African Assistance and how they are able to support Afghan families, as well as if they were able to reach their goal of February 2022. In addition, meet with Afghan refugees that have gone through Alliance for African Assistance to get integrated in San Diego, and learn about their experiences. Integration Resources
source_proposal: 8- Regional Responses to Refugee and Migration Issues.docx

name: MAKE Projects
description: https://www.kpbs.org/news/local/2022/04/21/san-diego-immigrant-job-training-program-expands-cafe-and-urban-farm-business MAKE Projects mission is to create an inclusive San Diego by preparing refugees and immigrants to achieve their dreams. They are an employment social enterprise where they operate an urban farm, restaurant, and events/catering company to provide a paid, real-world work experience for low-income refugee and immigrant women and youth. They aim to provide trainees with job readiness skills to help them achieve their dreams. MAKE Projects vision is to see San Diegans cross social, racial, economic, and geographic lines as they gather over a common love of food, flavors, and cultures. They believe in the power of food to bring diverse populations together, unite a community, and educate each other about their history and differences, as well as their communities. Note: a meeting with them can include an opportunity for the participants to join the community meals (on Thursday or Saturday), for about $30-40 per person.
source_proposal: 8- Regional Responses to Refugee and Migration Issues.docx

name: San Diego Gateway to College and Career, San Diego Workforce Partnership
description: The San Diego Gateway to College and Career program provides young adults who identify as immigrant, refugee and/or English language learner (ELL) with high-touch and intensive support, stipends and paid internships. Recognizing the strength of diverse ethnicities and languages, students are also supported to achieve their language learning goals, no matter what language you speak. This program offers help in removing barriers to success, finding what career is right, finding a long-term job, starting school, and learning new job skills.
source_proposal: 8- Regional Responses to Refugee and Migration Issues.docx

name: Catholic Charities of San Diego Refugee Services
description: The Catholic Charities of San Diego works to build a pathway to self-reliance and sense of belonging for refugees and immigrants. Project REACH is a program that the refugee services developed in order for refugees to be integrated into society through Resettlement, Employment, Acculturation, Case Management, and Health. The resettlement part of the program provides opportunities for refugees to be resettled in a safe and stable location that is also affordable. It also helps with things like applying for social security, registering for school, and connecting them with community resources. Along with resettlement the program also helps refugees find employment which enables economic self-sufficiency, develops skills necessary for application and interview processes, and provides one on one case agents to empower and guide clients. Meeting focus: Discuss and learn about the REACH refugee resettlement and integration program. Legal Resources:
source_proposal: 8- Regional Responses to Refugee and Migration Issues.docx

name: Casa Cornelia Law Center
description: Casa Cornelia Law Center is a public interest law firm providing quality legal services to victims of human and civil rights violations. It seeks to educate others regarding the impact of immigration law and policy on the community and the public good. Since 1993, more than 15,000 children, women, and men have turned to Casa Cornelia for critical legal assistance and humanitarian protection. Casa Cornelia is the only non-profit law firm in San Diego County to provide free legal services to detained unaccompanied Children.
source_proposal: 8- Regional Responses to Refugee and Migration Issues.docx

name: Immigration Center for Women and Children, San Diego Office
description: The Immigration Center for Women and Children (ICWC) is a non-profit legal organization providing free and affordable immigration services to underrepresented immigrants in California and Nevada. ICWC strives to provide security and stability for children who are abused, abandoned or neglected and for immigrants who are victims of domestic violence, sexual assault and other violent crimes. Using U.S. federal legislation, ICWC provides immigration legal services (U and T Visas, VAWA, and SIJS) to immigrants who are victims of crimes. The resulting immigration benefits allow individuals to permanently leave their abusers and create safe environments for their families.  ICWC’s overall goal is to assist these victims of domestic violence, human trafficking, sexual assault, and other violent crimes in escaping abusive relationships, live in safety, and become self-sufficient.
source_proposal: 8- Regional Responses to Refugee and Migration Issues.docx

name: San Diego Immigration Court
description: The San Diego Immigration Court falls under the jurisdiction of the Office of the Chief Immigration Judge which is a component of the Executive Office for Immigration review under the Department of Justice. The goal of the Executive of Immigration is to ensure that immigration cases are handled fairly, expeditiously, and uniformly by applying this countrys immigration laws to each case that comes through the court. The San Diego Immigration Court specifically handles cases regarding immigrants and refugees in the San Diego area. They handle everything from asylum seekers to citizenship to visas and green cards. Meeting focus: learn about San Diego Immigration Court, and how they maintain that immigration cases are handled fairly. Academic Resources:
source_proposal: 8- Regional Responses to Refugee and Migration Issues.docx

name: UC San Diego Center for Comparative Immigration Studies
description: The Center for Comparative Immigration Studies (CCIS) is an independent research unit at the University of California San Diego. The Center’s global network of research associates has expanded to over 355 Research Associates based in 25 different countries. The Center also has 35 institutional affiliates, 12 of which are located outside the United States. CCIS academic staff and Fellows appear frequently in the local and national media discourse on immigration issues, and their scholarly work informs immigration policy and practice worldwide. CCIS has long been a center for the training of undergraduate and graduate students, with unique academic programming both in La Jolla and through the Mexican Migration Field Research Program.
source_proposal: 8- Regional Responses to Refugee and Migration Issues.docx

name: Borderless Scholars Program, San Diego Mesa College
description: The Borderless Scholars’ program is designed to provide a safe and welcoming environment for undocumented students and undocu-allies. They support these students to overcome personal and educational challenges due to their immigration status. They provide personal, career, and academic counseling, on-campus support services, and community resources including free legal services. Advocacy and social justice is their main passion and allows them to be the support students need. Their services include counseling, meal cards, California Dream Act application assistance, immigration consultations, etc.
source_proposal: 8- Regional Responses to Refugee and Migration Issues.docx

name: San Diego County Office of Education Migrant Services
description: Migrant Education is a federally funded program designed to provide education and support services to identified migratory children and youth. Migratory youth are defined as children and youth who move periodically with their parent/guardians for seasonal agricultural work. This office serves about 4,000 migratory youth and children in 56 school districts across San Diego and Orange County. Migrant Education collaborates with school districts, charter schools, and community agencies to provide supplemental supports to ensure equitable education for migratory youth and children.
source_proposal: 8- Regional Responses to Refugee and Migration Issues.docx

name: Lexington Elementary
description: Lexington Elementary is located in the San Diego Community of Cajon Valley. They have a huge refugee and immigrant population; in which they are considered a multicultural school with over 60 languages spoken at the school. Lexington Elementary has a special immersion program, where students will have a special class in addition to their other classes where they can ask questions in their native language, and learn English, and integration efforts within a small group of students. Lexington Elementary also offers a food pantry to parents, and translators for any language to have good communication with parents throughout the process. Teachers are also trained to teach with a multicultural focus, and works with each student individually to see where they are struggling to collaborate with the World Language Program. Note: during summer there might not be classrooms for the participants to observe, however they can still receive a tour, and a meeting in case they can’t observe a classroom. Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $58 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown). Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $28 for one Adult Ticket for a one-hour narrated tour (south bay or north bay routes); $33 for a full bay two-hour narrated tour which covers it all: ships of the Maritime Museum, Harbor and Shelter Islands, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and more. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown. name: Women’s Museum of California
description: The Women’s Museum of California was founded as the Women’s History Reclamation Project in 1983 by Mary Maschal. Originally an archival project, Maschal worked diligently to collect and preserve artifacts that demonstrated the history and experiences of women, especially here in San Diego and California. In 2001 the Museum co-founded the San Diego County Women’s Hall of Fame in collaboration with the county and local Women’s Studies programs. By 2011, the Museum outgrew the Art Union Building and moved to the Arts District in Liberty Station and commemorated the milestone event by changing its name to the Women’s Museum of California (WMC).
source_proposal: 8- Regional Responses to Refugee and Migration Issues.docx

name: San Diego Regional Policy and Innovation
description: The Policy & Innovation Center conducts world-class research, supports coordinated governmental and agency relationships, develops consensus regarding the region’s core needs, and recommends policy solutions to assist local leaders in attracting federal and state impact dollars and addressing regional issues such as improving critical infrastructure, creating stable high-paying jobs; and generating other measurable long-term socio-economic and environmental benefits. The Policy & Innovation Center supports recovery from the cascading economic effects of COVID-19 and meets the needs of underserved communities by attracting funding and resources to the region; working with local municipalities and regional agencies to co-design new programs and pursue federal recovery and infrastructure funding; crafting new policy solutions; and driving large-scale private partnerships and investment opportunities.
source_proposal: 8- Social Entrepreneurs in the United States.docx

name: San Diego Entrepreneurs Exchange
description: The San Diego Entrepreneurs Exchange is an organization run by local entrepreneurs for entrepreneurs interested in Life Sciences, Pharma, Biotech, Medical Devices, Tech and Alternative Energy. It was founded to provide a voice and resources for early-stage startups, to encourage entrepreneurs, and sponsor networking and educational services to help develop the necessary skills to bring new businesses and funding to the San Diego area.
source_proposal: 8- Social Entrepreneurs in the United States.docx

name: San Diego and Imperial Small Business Development Center (SBDC)
description: The San Diego & Imperial Small Business Development Center (SBDC) Network is primarily funded by the U.S. Small Business Administration via a cooperative agreement and the California Governor’s Office of Business and Economic Development via grants. Southwestern Community College is the agreement and grant holder for the San Diego & Imperial SBDC Network and provides significant support as well. The San Diego & Imperial SBDC Network provides a vast array of no- and low- cost support to entrepreneurs and small businesses through our nine locations/subcontractors. San Diego Hispanic Chamber of e-commerce www.hiscec.com After realizing there was a digital gap between the Hispanic community and the business world, Tayde Aburto founded the Hispanic Chamber of e-Commerce eight years ago. The Chamber aims to empower small businesses run by Hispanics by enabling these businesses to become successful in e-commerce. The Hispanic Chamber of e-Commerce offers courses and consulting services throughout the County to educate small business owners as to the need to have at the very least, a website, Facebook page, or LinkedIn account. What started as a small group of advocates is today an organization with more than a thousand members. Meeting focus: Learn how new digital technologies can impact the local and regional economic development of small business; Meet with small business owners using new digital technologies to help grow their activity.
source_proposal: 8- Social Entrepreneurs in the United States.docx

name: Hera Hub
description: Hera Hub is the first international female focused co-working space and business accelerator. The platform supports members through education, mentoring, and collaboration, while the office environment gives them access to professional, productive space where they can grow a prosperous business, built on the foundation of a powerful community. Founded in San Diego in 2011, the company has been growing since 2016 through a collaborative licensing model, with locations sprouting up all over the U.S. and Europe. Through this expansion, Hera Hub will achieve its goal of supporting over 20,000 women in launching and growing their businesses. Government Programs and Micro Lending
source_proposal: 8- Social Entrepreneurs in the United States.docx

name: U.S. Small Business Administration- San Diego District
description: The U.S. Small Business Administration (SBA) - San Diego District plays a crucial role in supporting small businesses in the region. In the past fiscal year, the San Diego District office provided significant support, including over $200 million in loans to small businesses, helping them access the capital needed to start, grow, and expand their ventures. The SBA San Diego District offers a range of programs and services, with a particular emphasis on microlending. They collaborate with local microlenders to provide small loans to entrepreneurs and underserved communities, fostering economic development and job creation. Through their efforts, the SBA San Diego District is instrumental in driving the success of small businesses and fueling economic growth in the community.
source_proposal: 8- Social Entrepreneurs in the United States.docx

name: San Diego Regional Chamber of Commerce Policy
description: The San Diego Regional Chamber of Commerce is committed to making San Diego the most business friendly region in California. A strong economy creates jobs that support families, neighborhoods, and the entire region. Since the late 1800s, the Chamber has helped San Diego grow by engaging with elected officials, their members, and the public to address the issues most important to job creation and the region. Today, as much as ever, they are committed to an even better future for San Diego. The San Diego Chamber has initiatives and programs that cater to social entrepreneurs and businesses with a social mission. It often collaborates with organizations and initiatives dedicated to social impact to provide resources, networking opportunities, and support.
source_proposal: 8- Social Entrepreneurs in the United States.docx

name: The City of San Diego’s Economic Development Funding Programs, Small Business Enhancement Program (SBEP)
description: The City of San Diego’s The Economic Development Funding Program covers Economic Development and Tourism Support (EDTS) and Citywide Economic Development Support (CEDS), which allocate Transient Occupancy Tax (TOT) revenue to promote San Diego as a business and tourism destination; and the Small Business Enhancement Program (SBEP), which supports small business efforts Citywide and in Micro districts.
source_proposal: 8- Social Entrepreneurs in the United States.docx

name: The City of San Diego’s Economic Development Department
description: The City of San Diego's Economic Development Department provides valuable resources and support to entrepreneurs and businesses, helping them succeed and contribute to the local economy. The department offers various programs and initiatives, including business development assistance, workforce training, and access to funding opportunities. Two notable examples of their projects include the Business Acceleration Program, which provides tailored support to high-growth startups, and the Small Business Enhancement Program, which offers grants and resources to small businesses for expansion and improvement. Through their initiatives, the Economic Development Department actively supports entrepreneurship, job creation, and economic growth in San Diego.With the goal of promoting economic opportunity for all segments of the population, the City of San Diego leverages public incentives and assistance to foster community revitalization, attract new businesses and encourage investment in local businesses. The City of San Diego not only assists individual businesses but also helps strengthen business organizations and improve business districts throughout San Diego. Empowering Underrepresented Groups
source_proposal: 8- Social Entrepreneurs in the United States.docx

name: Women’s Empowerment International
description: Women’s Empowerment International was founded in San Diego in 2003 with a meeting among friends and colleagues. This group of women had an ambitious goal to disrupt the cycle of poverty for women around the world especially for those experiencing poverty and living in under resourced rural communities. Their mission is to create sustainable change by providing education, entrepreneurship training, and access to resources. WE believe that when women are given the tools and support to succeed, entire communities benefit. They work in collaboration with local partners to develop programs that address the unique challenges faced by women, including poverty, limited education, and lack of economic opportunities. The support, training, and assistance to refugee program also known as STAR is a program created by women for women. It was created to provide culturally sensitive settings for refugee and low-income women to receive assistance in starting and expanding their businesses.
source_proposal: 8- Social Entrepreneurs in the United States.docx

name: Kitchens for Good
description: Kitchens for Good is a social enterprise with the mission to mission to break the cycles of food waste, hunger, and poverty through innovate solutions in workforce training, healthy food production, and social enterprise. Kitchens for Good rescues surplus and cosmetically imperfect food from wholesalers and farmers and engages students in a culinary apprenticeship program. Through the power of kitchens and cooking, our students transform their lives from one of addiction, incarceration, homelessness, and unemployment, to lives of stability, employment, and a brighter future.
source_proposal: 8- Social Entrepreneurs in the United States.docx

name: Paving Great Futures
description: Paving Great Future goal is to increase the health and wealth in underserved communities in order for marginalized and at-risk individuals to thrive socially, economically, and politically. Paving Great Futures believes by addressing these areas they can create a comprehensive work experience programs to help misguided youth transform into productive and empowered community leaders capable of guiding relevant and lasting changes. Some of their programs include free entrepreneurship training, professional writing workshops, and local networks. Academic Resources:
source_proposal: 8- Social Entrepreneurs in the United States.docx

name: University of San Diego- Center for Peace and Commerce
description: The Center for Peace and Commerce at University of San Diego is dedicated to promoting social entrepreneurship and responsible business practices. As a partnership between the business school and the school of peace studies the center works to prepare future generations of changemakers, build a sustainable world through innovative thinking and action, and integrate principles and effective management with unique ideas for peacebuilding and poverty alleviation. The purpose of this center is to promote, guide, and support students driven ideas to launch or contribute to existing social enterprises. The Social Innovation Challenge (SIC) is a student social venture contest organized by the Center for Peace and Commerce at the University of San Diego. Through the SIC, university students in San Diego generate ideas for innovative ventures that respond to a social, economic, environmental, or justice issue of their choice, and compete for seed funding to launch or expand their ventures.
source_proposal: 8- Social Entrepreneurs in the United States.docx

name: La Jolla Country Day- Innovation
description: La Jolla Country Day School (LJCDS) is a private college prep school in the coastal community of La Jolla. The school’s Innovation Program challenges students to identify real-world problems and design innovative solutions to effect positive change for a better world. The curriculum from kindergarten to Grade 12 focuses on learning how to use cutting-edge tools and technologies while developing an understanding of the social impacts of technology, solutions and design. LJCDS’ Innovation Lab serves as a collaborative space that is equipped with a laser cutter (built from scratch by Upper School students), 3D printers, microcontrollers, Wacom tablets, drills, screwdrivers, hammers, sticky notes and anything else students may need for creative design and innovation. Additionally, LJCDS offers a venture capital fund for their students called the Torrey Explorer’s Fund (TEF). Whether students seek to start a business, launch a social campaign, invent a technology or create an art installation, TEF will offer mentorship by a team of local entrepreneurs and professionals and/or funding to help bring students’ ideas to fruition.
source_proposal: 8- Social Entrepreneurs in the United States.docx

name: SDSU Social Entrepreneurship
description: San Diego State University’s social entrepreneurship program works to promotes students’ solutions to social problems around the world. This program and the Lavin Entrepreneurship Center is run by Professor Michael Sloan who works to support students initiatives to accelerate cutting edge approaches and creative solutions to the world’s most pressing social issues. He unites students form different colleges to work on various problems and encourages them to apply their knowledge and passion toward implementing innovations. Professor Sloan’s most recent projects include working with poor farmers to increase grain production, homeless youth in San Diego, and the W.E. Do Good Mentoring Project.
source_proposal: 8- Social Entrepreneurs in the United States.docx

name: Office of Innovation and Commercialization- University of California, San Diego
description: UC San Diego is a globally recognized innovation leader that drives economic prosperity and leads in social innovation. Together with their campus partners, the Office of Innovation and Commercialization aligns resources to encourage and support an innovative community comprised of students, faculty, staff, alumni, and community advocates. Their mission is to accelerate the commercialization of UC San Diego innovations and contribute to a sustainable society by empowering a diverse entrepreneurial culture on campus and strengthening a dynamic innovation ecosystem. Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).

name: Chicano Park
description: Chicano Park is the geographic and emotional heart of Barrio Logan, located in Logan Heights, San Diego's oldest Mexican-American neighborhood. The park is home to the largest concentration of Chicano murals in the world with more than 80 paintings on seven acres dotted with sculpture, gardens, picnic tables and playgrounds. Throughout the year, it hosts festivals of music and Aztec dance, the biggest being Chicano Park Day held each April. name: Border Field State Park & Friendship Park
description: https://www.friendshippark.org/ Located within the Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve, Border Field State Park sits in the very southwestern corner of the United States, 15 miles south of San Diego. This important wildlife habitat, comprised of sand dunes and salt marshes, gives refuge to critically threatened and endangered birds such as the Western Snowy Plover, the California Least Tern, and the Light-footed Ridgway's Rail. Friendship Park is a binational park located at the western end of the US-Mexico border. For generations people have gathered here to meet up with friends and family "across the line." description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year around due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end.
