name: San Diego Food System Alliance
description: San Diego Food System Alliance is a multi-sector coalition comprised of nonprofits, government entities, businesses, and community members focused on creating long-lasting changes in San Diego's community food system. Through bringing together experts and forming Working Groups, we assess the issues in our community, identify solutions, and collectively implement solutions and advocate for changes. Meeting focus: Discussion with members of the San Diego Food System Alliance to learn how they develop and maintain an equitable, healthy and sustainable food system for the benefit of all people in San Diego County.
source_proposal: 9- Best Practices to Improve Food Security.docx

name: Leichtag Foundation
description: The Leichtag Foundation honors the legacy of Lee and Toni Leichtag through igniting and inspiring vibrant Jewish life, advancing self-sufficiency and stimulating social entrepreneurship in coastal North San Diego County and Jerusalem. Since its inception in 1991, the Leichtag Foundation has granted over $111 million to 391different organizations. Of this amount, over $96 million has been granted since becoming independent in late 2007. About 23% has stayed in Encinitas. Leichtag Commons, purchased by the Foundation in December 2012, is the Foundation’s most prominent tool. Leichtag Commons is a physical platform that amplifies the strategic focus areas of the Foundation and is a nexus to bring them all together. Currently, the Foundation is supporting programs and educational activities at Leichtag Commons inspired by ancient Jewish traditions that connect people to community, food, the land, and social justice. Since purchasing the Commons in 2012, the Leichtag Foundation has launched Coastal Roots Farm, a nonprofit community farm and education center.  The Leichtag Foundation established Coastal Roots Farm in response to North County residents’ interest in sustainability and social justice, and to the high number of low-income households currently lacking regular access to fresh, healthy food. Coastal Roots Farm Coastal Roots Farm is an independent organization created by the Leichtag Foundation to help foster a vibrant, healthy community. Coastal Roots Farm integrates Jewish tradition and sustainable agriculture to grow and share healthy food especially with those most in need, learn about and care for the land, and help strengthen connections between neighbors. Each year, they provide tens of thousands of pounds of fresh vegetables to local hunger relief efforts. Meeting focus: Discover the American foundation model and how it plays a major role to promote sustainable agriculture and educational programs International Rescue Committee (IRC): Food Security and Community Health www.rescue.org/us-program/us-san-diego-ca/fsch nextcity.org/daily/entry/op-ed-how-to-grow-food-security-from-the-grassroots
source_proposal: 9- Best Practices to Improve Food Security.docx

name: www.start2farm.gov/programs/reap-refugee-entrepreneurial-agriculture-program
description: The International Rescue Committee’s Food Security and Community Health Program creates innovative and sustainable projects that increase healthy, locally-grown, culturally-appropriate foods for and by San Diego’s refugee and low-income communities. Their programs include community farms stimulating food security and nutrition access, hands-on beginning farmer training programs, and the opportunity for refugees to work with local farmers markets. Mid-City Community Advocacy Network (CAN) www.midcitycan.org/about Mid-City Community Advocacy Network (Mid-City CAN), is a unique collaboration of schools, businesses, nonprofit organizations, government agencies, youth, parents, ethnic and cultural groups, civic associations and faith-based institutions. Mid-City CAN promotes addresses public health concerns of the large refugee populations in the Mid-City area through their various Momentum Their Food Justice Momentum Team successfully encouraged representatives of the San Diego Unified School District in March 2014 to include fresh, organic produce from local refugee farmers, more protein options, and food that is representative of the community’s diverse make-up such as halal food.
source_proposal: 9- Best Practices to Improve Food Security.docx

name: Slow food – San Diego branch
description: “Slow food” is an idea, a way of living and a way of eating. It is a global, grassroots movement with thousands of members around the world that links the pleasure of food with a commitment to community and the environment. Slow Food Urban San Diego is a local chapter, or convivia, of the national organization Slow Food USA, and its parent organization Slow Food International. On a local level, Slow food works on raising public awareness, improving access and encouraging the enjoyment of foods that are local, seasonal and sustainably grown, caring for the land and protecting biodiversity for today’s communities and future generations, performing educational outreach within our communities and working with children in schools and through public programs, identifying, promoting and protecting fruits, vegetables, grains, animal breeds, wild foods and cooking traditions at risk of disappearing, advocating for farmers, fishers and artisans who grow, produce, market, prepare and serve wholesome food and promoting the celebration of food as a cornerstone of pleasure, culture and community. Meeting focus: Learn how new ways of consuming help supporting local economy and producers. Feeding America San Diego www.feedingamericasd.org/ Feeding America San Diego (FASD) is San Diego’s largest hunger-relief organization, distributing more than 23 million pounds of food within the last year. FASD works closely with more than 200 distribution partners, local school districts, corporate partners and a network of volunteers to serve 73,000 children, families and seniors in need each week. They focus on feeding the hungry, advocacy, and education and aim build a hunger-free and healthy San Diego through several programs and collaborative partnerships. Academic Resource University of California, San Diego – Division of Biological Sciences www.biology.ucsd.edu/ The UC San Diego Division of Biological Sciences strives to enhance the basic knowledge of biological sciences by applying their research findings to promote health, the environment, and economic growth. The team of researchers has made breakthroughs to solve a number of issues including the protection of the world’s food supply. The UC San Diego Division of Biological Sciences is committed to addressing global-issues that affect the environment, health and the economy my collaborating with like-minded research institutions.
source_proposal: 9- Best Practices to Improve Food Security.docx

name: San Diego Unified School District – Farm to School Program
description: Farm to School is a program that connects schools (K-12) and local farms with the objectives of serving healthy meals in school cafeterias; improving student nutrition, providing agriculture, health and nutrition education opportunities, and supporting local and regional farmers. Meeting focus: To explore the importance of early-learning in critical matters such as nutrition and agriculture; Discuss the process to ensure healthier school lunches in San Diego county, an initiative the school system has been recognized for University of California Cooperative Extension cesandiego.ucanr.edu/ The University of California Cooperative Extension provides assistance to the agricultural community by helping farmers develop efficient farming methods, develop water-use strategies, solve pest management issues, and support communities by promoting healthy diets, and more nutritious foods. Through their advisors and specialists, the University of California Cooperative Extension brings scientific solutions to issues affecting different communities across California. Cibus, LLC www.cibus.com/index.php Cibus, LLC generates environmentally-friendly crop traits for the agricultural community. Cibus, LLC works with partners from different sectors of the world’s major crops for trait development programs. Additionally, Cibus, LLC applies the Rapid Trait Development System (RTDS) to create products that meet the needs of an expanding global population. BIOCOM www.biocom.org/ BIOCOM/San Diego’s mission is to enhance and expand the business goals of their member partners through different opportunities in health, agriculture and energy.  BIOCOM/San Diego promotes the growth of all sectors of the industry through creation of member value in the areas of public policy, agriculture, member services, education and business networking. BIOCOM/San Diego provides all of their members with the opportunity to connect and collaborate with the influential actors engaged in the different industries.
source_proposal: 9- Best Practices to Improve Food Security.docx

name: Olivewood Gardens
description: Olivewood Gardens and Learning Center’s historic 6.85-acre property in National City, California serves as an interactive, indoor-outdoor classroom for children and adults from around San Diego County.  Our purpose is to build healthy families and a healthy environment.  We do this through science based environmental education lessons, hands-on gardening, and hands-on cooking for students and families from underserved communities. Who We Are: Started in February 2010, Olivewood Gardens, a 501(c) 3, is a garden and nutrition education center.  Olivewood Gardens is a Type 1 supporting organization of the International Community Foundation.   The house, gardens, and property were donated to the Foundation by the Walton family in 2006 and later gifted to Olivewood Gardens in 2010.
source_proposal: 9- Best Practices to Improve Food Security.docx

name: Cooking For Salud Program
description: Cooking for Salud® is a bilingual English and Spanish nutrition education and behavior modification program designed to teach participants how to make healthy changes at home that will improve their families’ short and long-term health outcomes. Cooking for Salud gives participants tools to change their cooking and eating habits, with guest chef volunteers and instruction centered around food and nutrition Government / Law Enforcement Programs U.S. Customs and Border Protection - Otay Mesa Pre-inspection Facility www.cbp.gov The San Diego Sector of the US Customs and Border Protection consists of more than 7,000 square miles and 66 linear miles of international boundary with Mexico. The San Diego Sector encompasses coastal beaches and expansive mesas to coastal and inland mountains, rugged canyons and high desert. Directly to the South of San Diego lie the Mexican cities of Tijuana and Tecate, Baja California - with a combined population of more than 2 million. Setting a precedent for the U.S.-Mexico border, customs officers from both countries are working side-by-side for the first time to inspect northbound shipments of strawberries, tomatoes, green onions, limes and other Mexican produce headed for the United States. The Otay Mesa pre-inspection facility is the first to open in Mexico since a modification of the country’s firearms law last year allowed foreign customs and immigration officers to carry weapons while performing their jobs in the country. Meeting focus: Learn about new mechanisms to facilitate international trade at the US-Mexico border and insure the safety of foreign products being sold on US territory.
source_proposal: 9- Best Practices to Improve Food Security.docx

name: Quality Assurance International (QAI)
description: QAI is a leading USDA-accredited organic product certifying agency. Founded in San Diego, California in 1989, QAI has been an active leader in the organic industry, advocating for high integrity organic regulations since its beginning. QAI is committed to ensuring organic integrity at every link in the organic production chain and providing excellent customer service, domestically and internationally. Today, QAI is a member of the NSF International family of companies. From the land on which the product is grown, to the post-harvest facilities and processing plants, to the retail store where it is available for purchase, QAI verifies organic integrity with every link. QAI brings organic industry knowledge and expertise to many sectors of the industry including crop production, food manufacturing, personal care products, dietary supplements, livestock, honey, maple syrup, poultry and eggs, sea vegetables, dairy, mushrooms, hydroponics, greenhouses, distribution, retail and foodservice. Meeting focus: Explore the organic accreditation process and understand the level of standards required to be certified organic in California and the US County of San Diego – Department of Agriculture, Weights and Measures www.sdcounty.ca.gov/awm/ The Department of Agriculture, Weights and Measures of the County of San Diego, is responsible for overseeing growers and farmers employing pesticide safety, to prevent food-borne illnesses, to promote a thriving agricultural community, as well as  supporting a fair marketplace and consumer confidence. Further, they provide guidance about organic farming, farmer’s markets, crops statistics, and plant and pest prevention.
source_proposal: 9- Best Practices to Improve Food Security.docx

name: San Diego Farm Bureau
description: The San Diego County Farm Bureau is a non-profit organization supported solely by more than 5,000 dues-paying members. There are 53 county Farm Bureaus in California. Established in 1913, the San Diego County Farm Bureau serves the needs of the agriculture community in accordance with its Mission Statement: "The mission of the Farm Bureau of San Diego County is to represent San Diego agriculture through public relations, education, and public policy advocacy in order to promote the economic viability of agriculture balanced with appropriate management of natural resources." In San Diego County the Farm Bureau is the leading advocate for the farm community and works with elected officials, government agencies, educators, the public, and the media. Local Farm Bureau membership reaches well beyond the boundaries of the county. At the state level, the California Farm Bureau Federation serves the county Farm Bureaus as the voice on state issues and works closely with representatives from the American Farm Bureau Federation on issues of national importance. Meeting focus: Discover the importance of a strong advocacy for the agricultural sector, and the understand the most important challenges faced by this Economy Non –Profit and Non-Governmental Organizations Kitchens for Good www.kitchensforgood.org Kitchens for Good is a 501(c)(3) and social enterprise with the mission to break the cycles of food waste, hunger, and poverty through innovate solutions in workforce training, healthy food production, and social enterprise. Kitchens for Good bridges the gap between wasted food and hunger by rescuing surplus and cosmetically imperfect food from wholesalers and farmers and engaging students in a culinary apprenticeship program to transform these ingredients into nutritious meals for hungry families. Discussion Focus: Staff will discuss the innovative enterprise model Kitchens for Good employs as well as the apprenticeship program that specifically serves individuals who are experiencing significantly high unemployment rates. San Diego Roots Sustainable Food Project www.sandiegoroots.org/organization.php The San Diego Roots Sustainable Food Project is a non-profit dedicated to encouraging the growth and consumption of regional food. They work alongside farmers, chefs, citizens, gardeners, teachers and students to bring awareness about economically comprehensive, economically practical and socially fair food systems in San Diego. Additionally, they strive to preserve local farms and teach the public about San Diego’s farming history.
source_proposal: 9- Best Practices to Improve Food Security.docx

name: San Diego Food Bank
description: The Jacobs & Cushman San Diego Food Banks is the largest hunger-relief organization in San Diego County. The Food Bank provides nutritious food to individuals and families in need throughout the San Diego County. They receive food through locally-run food drives, the USDA, growers, retailers, and wholesalers. Once the food arrives at the Food Bank is it categorized by food group and boxed and bagged for distribution. There are over 180 distribution sites throughout the county The Food Bank also provides food to 400 nonprofit organizations. The Food Bank also runs a variety of programs including the Senior Food Program, CalFresh Outreach Program, Food 4 Kids Backpack Program, and many more. There food recoveries aid a multitude of families and residents from all ages and backgrounds.
source_proposal: 9- Best Practices to Improve Food Security.docx

name: San Diego Hunger Coalition
description: The San Diego Hunger Coalition’s mission is to build a successful anti-hunger network that eliminates food insecurity in San Diego County. The Hunger Coalition advocates for maximum participation in and the effectiveness of available food security resources, and the organization fosters collaboration with local anti-hunger organizations to shape public opinion and policy at the local, state, and federal levels. Meeting focus: To learn about the SD Hunger Coalition’s strategy for effective advocacy and methods to shape public opinion and policy at all levels towards food security. Faith Based Organizations
source_proposal: 9- Best Practices to Improve Food Security.docx

name: Catholic Charities – Diocese of San Diego
description: Since the establishment of the Diocese of San Diego in 1936, the role of Catholic Charities has been to provide social welfare programs, witness to the scriptural values of mercy and justice, and advocate for the poor and vulnerable within the diocese. Catholic Charities, while evolving over the past 100 plus years, has remained faithful to its original mandate: assist the child, the family, the immigrant, and the marginalized.
source_proposal: 9- Best Practices to Improve Food Security.docx

name: CalFresh Healthy Living Program
description: The CalFresh Healthy Living Program provides behaviorally focused, evidence-based, nutrition and physical activity education classes to low income individuals in the community. They improve the likelihood that persons eligible for CalFresh Food (SNAP) will make healthy food choices within a limited budget and choose physically active lifestyles consistent with the current Dietary Guidelines for Americans and the Physical Activity Guidelines for Americans. Meeting focus: To learn about their strategy to improve nutrition education and food security within low-income communities.
source_proposal: 9- Best Practices to Improve Food Security.docx

name: UC San Diego’s Center for Community Health – Faith-Based Wellness Program
description: The Faith-Based Wellness Program collaborates with faith-based organizations to improve health outcomes and food security in low-income communities through policy, systems and environmental changes as well as culturally relevant nutrition education. They make great strides to improve health outcomes and food access for San Diego County’s most vulnerable families through a comprehensive faith-based wellness approach — implementing evidence-based and culturally-sensitive health education as well as establishing meaningful partnerships with San Diego County faith-based organizations — regardless of faith. Meeting focus: Learn about their methods to improve food security in San Diego through policy and environmental advocacy.
source_proposal: 9- Best Practices to Improve Food Security.docx

name: Jewish Family Services – Nutrition Assistance
description: Jewish Family Service is a client-centered, impact-driven organization working to build a stronger, healthier, more resilient San Diego. Founded in 1918, they are one of San Diego’s most impactful non-profit human services agencies. Their broad network of staff, volunteers, supporters, and community partners are committed to the pursuit of one shared goal: helping individuals and families in San Diego Move Forward. Jewish Family Service offers a variety of nutrition assistance programs to help keep the San Diego community moving forward. Meeting focus: To learn about the various programs held by Jewish Family Services, emphasis on Nutrition Education and their Hand Up Food Pantry Program. _______________________________ Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown). Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $30 for one Adult Ticket for a one-hour narrated tour (south bay or north bay routes); $35 for a full bay two-hour narrated tour which covers it all: ships of the Maritime Museum, Harbor and Shelter Islands, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and more. The full bay tour is about 25 miles in length. Accessibility: The tour begins and ends at the same location downtown along Broadway Pier. Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com Price: $44 for a 1-Day Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) For 30 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours, highlighting the best San Diego attractions. The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50am – 5:00pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $26 for one Adult General Admission Ticket ($1 discount when purchased on-line). Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10am – 5pm (Last admission at 4pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside Navy Pier. Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 17 major museums and cultural institutions, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).

name: Coronado
description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year around due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown. SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $99.99 for one Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) Accessibility: A 15-20-minute drive from downtown San Diego. Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Orca Encounter, Dolphin Days, and Sea Lions Live shows and thrilling rides like Electric Eel, Manta, and Journey To Atlantis. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Hours vary by season.
source_proposal: 9- Best Practices to Improve Food Security.docx

name: Energy Policy Initiatives Center
description: The Energy Policy Initiatives Center is a research center at the University of San Diego School of Law studying how energy policy issues affect California and the San Diego region. The Center strives to increase awareness and understanding of energy- climate-related policy issues by conducting research and analysis to inform decision-makers and educating law students. By drawing on expertise in law, policy, economics, and science, the Center brings together students, scholars, and practitioners within the school of law and serves the public interest.
source_proposal: Energy as an Economic Driver_ IVLP Proposal.docx

name: David Victor, PhD - University of California, San Diego
description: Dr. David Victor is a professor of innovation and public policy at the School of Global Policy and Strategy at UC San Diego. He is the Co-Director of the campus-wide Deep Decarbonization Initiative which focuses on real world strategies bringing the world to nearly zero emissions of warming gasses. His research is at the intersection of climate change science and policy where he focuses on regulated industries and how regulation affects the operation of major energy markets. He authored Global Warming Gridlock which explains why the world has not made diplomatic progress on the problem of climate change while also exploring more effective new strategies. Dr. Victor is also a non-resident senior fellow at The Brookings Institution. He is a member of the World Economic Forum’s Global Future Council on Energy, where his work focuses on the role of natural gas as a transition fuel to deep decarbonization.
source_proposal: Energy as an Economic Driver_ IVLP Proposal.docx

name: University of California San Diego – Center for Energy Research (CER)
description: The Center for Energy Research (CER) at UC San Diego is a nationally recognized hub for advanced energy innovation, education, and technology transfer. Founded in 1974, CER brings together leading engineers, scientists, and policy experts to address critical challenges in energy generation, storage, distribution, and efficiency. Its research spans renewable energy integration, smart grids, fusion energy, hydrogen systems, and battery storage, with strong collaborations across industry, government agencies, and national laboratories. The center also plays a key role in mentoring future energy leaders and fostering cross-sector solutions that balance technological advancement with environmental stewardship.
source_proposal: Energy as an Economic Driver_ IVLP Proposal.docx

name: University of California San Diego – Deep Carbonization Initiative
description: The Deep Decarbonization Initiative (DDI) at UC San Diego is a leading interdisciplinary research effort focused on the systemic transformations required to eliminate carbon emissions from global energy systems. Combining expertise from economics, engineering, public policy, and climate science, DDI explores pragmatic strategies to decarbonize hard-to-abate sectors such as heavy industry, transportation, and electricity generation. The initiative works closely with policymakers, international organizations, and private industry to design scalable, evidence-based solutions that advance global climate goals while supporting economic growth and energy resilience. Think Tanks and Working Groups
source_proposal: Energy as an Economic Driver_ IVLP Proposal.docx

name: Jeremy Martin Vice President Energy & Stability - Institute of the Americas
description: The Institute of the Americas is dedicated to being a catalyst for promoting economic development and integration. The Institute of the Americas undertakes programs, develops policy papers and organizes conferences, roundtable discussions, and webinars addressing emerging issues of importance to countries across the Americas. The Institute’s Energy & Sustainability program has played a crucial role in shaping policy discourse and informing investors on the most important trends in the energy sector. Jeremy M. Martin is Vice President, Energy & Sustainability at the Institute of Americas. Martin has testified before the U.S. Congress on energy issues in Latin America, teaches a graduate course in Latin American Energy Policy at the University of California San Diego and the University of San Diego and serves on the Board of Advisors for the Inter-American Dialogue’s Energy Advisor newsletter.
source_proposal: Energy as an Economic Driver_ IVLP Proposal.docx

name: San Diego Policy and Innovation Center
description: Created by the San Diego Foundation in 2021, the Policy and Innovation Center (PIC) conducts research, convenes stakeholders, recommends policy, and brings resources to communities to solve complex challenges such as unaffordable housing, climate change, and inequitable economic mobility. Its founding partners also include the County of San Diego and the Brookings Institution, the world’s leading think tank. PIC has experts across various fields with deep expertise in their respective fields and a nuanced understanding of San Diego’s policy environment. Energy and Cleantech Innovators
source_proposal: Energy as an Economic Driver_ IVLP Proposal.docx

name: EDF Renewables North America
description: EDF Renewables North America, headquartered in San Diego, is a leading developer of renewable energy projects, including utility-scale wind, solar, and energy storage. As part of the global EDF Group, the company brings decades of experience in delivering large-scale clean energy solutions across the United States, Canada, and Mexico. EDF Renewables is deeply involved in every stage of energy project development—from site assessment and permitting to construction, operation, and asset management. With a strong emphasis on innovation, sustainability, and community engagement, the company is actively shaping the transition to a decarbonized energy future while contributing to energy security and regional economic growth.
source_proposal: Energy as an Economic Driver_ IVLP Proposal.docx

name: Controlled Thermal Resources
description: Controlled Thermal Resources combines direct lithium extraction with renewable geothermal power to set new benchmarks to provide renewable energy to the western U.S. and to deliver the most sustainable, battery-grade lithium products in the world today. Demand for lithium, which is used in batteries and energy storage systems to power cars, cities, and countries, is expected to surge by approximately 2 million tons per annum by 2030. Controlled Thermal Resources’ leadership team has successfully developed and managed world-scale renewable energy projects in the Salton Sea region for over 20 years. Note: Controlled Thermal Resources is located in the Salton Sea, approximately 2.5 hours outside of the San Diego metro region.
source_proposal: Energy as an Economic Driver_ IVLP Proposal.docx

name: Tenaska Imperial Solar
description: As California electricity providers strive to meet the requirements of the state’s Renewables Portfolio Standard, Tenaska has been developing solar energy projects in Imperial County. Tenaska Solar Ventures, LLC (TSV) manages solar projects in North America. TSV has several utility-scale projects in Imperial County in Southern California. Current projects range from 130 to 160 megawatts (MW) and are among the largest solar generating facilities in California powering almost 100, 000 homes. Tenaska Imperial Solar Energy Center South was the first large-scale solar project to begin construction in Imperial County, and it is the first large-scale solar project to transmit power from the Imperial Valley via San Diego Gas & Electric’s (SDG&E) new Sunrise Powerlink transmission line. It is also one of the largest commercially financed solar projects in the U.S. to date.
source_proposal: Energy as an Economic Driver_ IVLP Proposal.docx

name: Ocean Motion Technologies
description: Ocean Motion Technologies aims to scale ocean wave energy through lowering the cost of power at sea and enabling a new era of big blue data. The bluetech sector needs products in small-scale energy to fuel research and development needed to scale wave energy. Ocean Motion Technologies develops devices that are meant to last and reduce the cost for end users. Devices vary from the world’s first adaptive ocean wave energy converters controlled by an advanced artificial system to the world’s first compressed air energy storage system for marine applications.
source_proposal: Energy as an Economic Driver_ IVLP Proposal.docx

name: Nuvve project with Cajon Valley Unified School District and San Diego Gas & Electric
description: https://nuvve.com/sdge-and-cajon-valley-union-school-district-flip-the-switch-on-regions-first-vehicle-to-grid-project-featuring-local-electric-school-busescapable-of-sending-power-to-the-grid/ Combining the world’s most advanced vehicle-to-grid (V2G) technology and an ecosystem of electrification partners, Nuvve dynamically manages power among EV batteries and the grid to deliver new value to EV owners, and support the world’s transition to clean energy. By transforming EVs into mobile energy storage assets and networking battery capacity to support shifting energy needs, Nuvve is making the grid more resilient, enhancing sustainable transportation, and supporting energy equity in an electrified world. In July 2022, San Diego Gas & Electric, Nuvve, and Cajon Valley Union School District announced that it had successfully deployed an innovative technology that enables eight electric school buses to put electricity back on the grid when needed.
source_proposal: Energy as an Economic Driver_ IVLP Proposal.docx

name: Sempra
description: Sempra Energy is a global energy infrastructure company focused on leading the way of advancing electrification and promoting energy diversification, resiliency and affordable access to cleaner forms of energy. From its San Diego headquarters to operations throughout the Americas, Sempra Energy is making strides in developing forward-thinking energy solutions and delivering everyday power to customers. Sempra Energy believes the global energy ecosystem is going to change dramatically over the next 30 years. In advanced economies, the change will take the form of innovation and technology that improves energy efficiency and supports a shift toward new, smart renewable and natural gas infrastructure. In developing nations, improving energy diversity will be the central effort as new, smart infrastructure that supports renewables and natural gas displaces higher carbon forms of energy.
source_proposal: Energy as an Economic Driver_ IVLP Proposal.docx

name: Carlsbad Energy Center – NRG Energy
description: The Carlsbad Energy Center is a state-of-the-art natural gas-powered facility located in northern San Diego County. Developed and operated by NRG Energy, the plant is designed to support California’s evolving energy needs by providing fast-start, flexible power that complements intermittent renewable sources like solar and wind. Commissioned in 2018, the facility replaced an older, less efficient coastal power plant and incorporates advanced technologies that allow for cleaner, more responsive energy generation. As part of NRG’s broader commitment to sustainability and grid reliability, the Carlsbad Energy Center plays a critical role in ensuring energy security while supporting the transition to a low-carbon energy mix. Non–Profits and NGOs
source_proposal: Energy as an Economic Driver_ IVLP Proposal.docx

name: San Diego Community Power
description: San Diego Community Power is a locally run, not-for-profit public agency that is a new electric generation service provider for San Diego. San Diego Community Power is shifting control from a profit-driven investor-owned utility into the hands of customers. This supports local job creation and development of renewable energy projects close to home while reinvesting revenues into the communities they serve. Terra Lawson-Remer serves on the Board of Directors and is also San Diego County Supervisor, where she is an economist, attorney, grassroots organizer, and educator dedicated to working for social, environmental, and economic justice.
source_proposal: Energy as an Economic Driver_ IVLP Proposal.docx

name: Cleantech San Diego
description: Cleantech San Diego is a nonprofit industry association that positions the San Diego region as a global leader in the cleantech economy. With a membership that includes innovative startups, established corporations, government agencies, and academic institutions, Cleantech San Diego fosters collaboration across sectors to drive the development and deployment of clean technologies. The organization plays a critical role in supporting energy innovation, advocating for forward-thinking policies, and accelerating technology commercialization. Through initiatives such as the Southern California Energy Innovation Network (SCEIN), Cleantech San Diego helps early-stage companies bring emerging energy solutions to market while contributing to regional job creation and sustainable economic growth. Municipal Energy Policy Management

name: The City of San Diego, Sustainability and Mobility Department
description: The Sustainability and Mobility Department leads San Diego's Climate Action Plan. Centered on striving for equitable, efficient and effective mobility choices that support all communities, the Department continuously works to facilitate innovative efforts to enhance equitable, economic, social and environmental sustainability. The 2022 Climate Action Plan established a community-wide goal of net zero by 2035, committing San Diego to reducing the use of greenhouse gasses.

name: San Diego Gas & Electric, Energy Innovation Center (SDG&E)
description: SDG&E is a regulated public utility that provides energy service to 3.6 million people through 1.4 million electric meters and 873,000 natural gas meters in San Diego and southern Orange counties. Their service area spans 4,100 square miles. The Energy Innovation Center at SDG&E is a working showcase that demonstrates smart energy initiatives and green building practices, all housed in one unique setting. This double LEED Platinum facility offers visitors a venue for learning and exploring the latest in energy efficiency, renewable energy, smart grid and alternative fuel technologies.
source_proposal: Energy as an Economic Driver_ IVLP Proposal.docx

name: Port of San Diego – Energy and Sustainability Program
description: The Port of San Diego’s Energy and Sustainability Program is a key component of the Port’s broader mission to balance maritime commerce, public access, and environmental stewardship. Through this program, the Port leads innovative projects focused on energy efficiency, renewable energy deployment, and climate adaptation. Current initiatives include solar panel installations, battery energy storage systems, shore power for docked vessels, electrification of port equipment, and the development of a microgrid. The Port also partners with local utilities, research institutions, and clean technology companies to pilot sustainable infrastructure and reduce greenhouse gas emissions across its operations. name: U.S. Naval Base San Diego *Would need D.C. gatekeeper request
description: https://timesofsandiego.com/military/2022/01/24/two-san-diego-based-carrier-groups-enter-disputed-south-china-sea/ Naval Base San Diego (NBSD) is the U.S. Navy's largest base on the West Coast and the principal homeport of the Pacific Fleet. Homeport to 54 ships, the base has 13 piers that stretch over 977 acres of land and 326 acres of water. The total on-base population is 20,000 military personnel and 6,000 civilians. Naval units based at NBSD have played a major role in the Global War on Terrorism and the Navy’s efforts to relieve suffering and build partnerships through disaster relief and humanitarian outreach deployments.

name: US Coast Guard *Would need D.C. gatekeeper request
description: The Coast Guard is a unique branch of the military responsible for an array of maritime duties, from ensuring safe and lawful commerce to performing rescue missions in severe conditions. Nearly 42,000 men and women are actively serving in the Coast Guard to defend America’s borders and protect the maritime environment. The Coast Guard has roles in maritime homeland security, maritime law enforcement (MLE), search and rescue (SAR), marine environmental protection (MEP), the maintenance of river, intracoastal and offshore aids to navigation (ATON).
source_proposal: Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: California Department of Fish and Wildlife
description: The Department of Fish and Wildlife manages and protects the state's fish, wildlife, plant and native habitats. It is responsible for related recreational, commercial, scientific, and educational uses. It also works to prevent illegal poaching. The Marine Region officers patrol the entire coastline of California, and up to 200 miles off the shore. Marine officers enforce commercial and sport fishing laws through spot checks on the water and on land. They work across all fishing-related fields across California including commercial fishing, regulations, ocean and inland sport fishing, and fishing licenses.
source_proposal: Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: California Coastal Commission (San Diego Coast District):
description: https://www.coastal.ca.gov/contact/#/ The mission of the Coastal Commission is to protect, conserve, restore, and enhance environmental resources of the California coast and ocean for environmentally sustainable and prudent use by current and future generations. The Coastal Commission, in partnership with coastal cities and counties, plans and regulates the use of land and water in the coastal zone. Development activities, which are broadly defined by the Coastal Act to include (among others) construction of buildings, divisions of land, and activities that change the intensity of use of land or public access to coastal waters, generally require a coastal permit from either the Coastal Commission or the local government. The San Diego Coast District stretches 70 miles from the northern border of Camp Pendleton Marine Corps Base to the Mexican border.
source_proposal: Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission
description: The IATTC is responsible for the conservation and management of tuna and other marine resources, including turtles, in the eastern Pacific Ocean. Each member of the IATTC is represented by up to four Commissioners, appointed by the respective government. The IATTC also has significant responsibilities for the implementation of the International Dolphin Conservation Program (IDCP), and provides the Secretariat for that program. Meeting focus: Learn about the IATTC role and program to protect tuna and turtles in the eastern Pacific Ocean.
source_proposal: Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) – Southwest Fisheries Science Center
description: https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/about/southwest-fisheries-science-center NOAA is government scientific agency within the United States Department of Commerce that conducts applied scientific research of national and global significance, including protection of ocean and coastal resources and environmental stewardship. Established in 1964 to study the sardine and tuna fisheries of the U.S. West Coast, the Southwest Fisheries Science Center, headquartered in La Jolla, CA (within San Diego County) provides scientific information to support fisheries management and conserve protected species in the California Current, throughout the Pacific Ocean, and in the Southern Ocean off Antarctica. Center staff work with numerous partners and NOAA Fisheries counterparts to provide sound science for national and international management decisions. Academic Resource
source_proposal: Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: The University of California Institute on Global Conflict and Cooperation (IGCC)
description: The UC Institute on Global Conflict and Cooperation (IGCC) is a network of researchers from across the University of California and the Los Alamos and Lawrence Livermore national labs who produce and use research to help build a more peaceful, prosperous world. We conduct rigorous social science research on international security, the environment, geoeconomics, nuclear security, and the future of democracy; help to educate and train the next generation of peacemakers; and strive to ensure that what we are discovering contributes to a safer world.  The Institute is based at the School of Global Policy and Strategy at UC San Diego, where several members of the leadership team and a number of researchers are on the faculty. Dr. Tai Ming Cheung, Director Tai Ming Cheung is director of the University of California Institute on Global Conflict and Cooperation and a professor at the School of Global Policy and Strategy at UC San Diego, where he teaches courses on the international relations and national security of China and Chinese security and technology policy. Among the areas of his research focus include China’s efforts to become a world-class science and technology power, and the relationship between geo-economics, innovation, and national security. Dr. Cheung is a long-time analyst of Chinese and East Asian defense and national security affairs, especially defense economic, industrial and science, and technological issues. Vice Admiral Charles Martoglio, U.S. Navy (retired); lecturer, UCSD School of Global Policy & Strategy https://gps.ucsd.edu/faculty-directory/charles-martoglio.html Vice Admiral Charles W. Martoglio, U.S. Navy (ret), is a lecturer at the School of Global Policy and Strategy at UC San Diego. Drawing on his extensive background leading large elements of our U.S. military, VADM Martoglio’s focus is on national security affairs and leadership. He spent about half of his military career in the U.S. Navy at sea in cruisers, destroyers and aircraft carriers. VADM Martoglio spent the other half of his career developing strategy and policy, fostering international relations, and conducting operations, initially for the U.S. Navy then for all U.S. military forces. VADM Martoglio is recognized as one of the Defense Department’s preeminent strategic thinkers, with proven expertise in contingency planning, international relations and operations execution. He has served in Asia, the Middle East, and, most recently, in Europe as the Deputy Commander of all U.S. military forces in Europe, Eurasia and Israel. In various capacities he has developed the U.S. Navy’s Strategic Plan, led security-related organizations through significant change, headed the planning effort for some of our nation’s most complex contingency plans, and has overseen the integration of the U.S. Government Interagency into Defense Department operations in both Asia and Europe.
source_proposal: Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: James M. Cooper, California Western School of Law
description: James Cooper is Professor of Law and Director of International Legal Studies at California Western. Since 1998, Professor Cooper has directed Proyecto ACCESO, a judicial technology transfer project funded by governments, foundations, and international agencies, raising more than $US 5 million for this initiative. He co-founded the One World Blockchain Alliance, a network that debuted at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland and has been an advisor to blockchain companies in Asia
source_proposal: Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: Training Resources Acquired Maritime Institute
description: Training Resources Limited Maritime Institute (“TRLMI”) offers over 80 U.S. Coast Guard approved courses in San Diego and Alameda and continues to provide exportable training throughout California and select East Coast locations. Their customers include Government organizations such as the U.S. Navy, Military Sealift Command and NOAA; Civilian ship operators such as Maersk Shipping, Disney Cruise Lines, and Foss Maritime; Merchant Mariner Unions such as Sailor’s Union of the Pacific (SUP) and Marine Fireman’s Union (MFOW), and thousands of independent mariners each year. The company provides training to over 4000 mariners annually, in topics that cover every aspect of shipboard safety and operation.
source_proposal: Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: Scripps Institution of Oceanography (SIO)
description: A department of UC San Diego, Scripps Institution of Oceanography is one of the oldest and most renowned centers for ocean and Earth science research, public service, undergraduate and graduate training in the world. Hundreds of ocean and Earth scientists conduct research with the aid of oceanographic research vessels and shore-based laboratories.
source_proposal: Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: Samantha Murray, J.D., Executive Director, Master of Advanced Studies, Marine
description: Samantha Murray is the Executive Director of the MAS MBC Program where she also teaches graduate courses, including Ocean Law and Policy. In 2019 she was appointed by Governor Newsom to the California Fish and Game Commission and currently serves as Vice President. Samantha has nearly two decades of professional experience and has directed ocean and water programs at Ocean Conservancy, the Audubon Society, and Oregon Environmental Council, in addition to founding a marine policy consulting business. Samantha played a key role in the design and implementation of California's network of marine protected areas, which now cover 16 percent of state waters. She served on the Marine Protected Area Federal Advisory Committee, has held board positions at Upstream Public Health and Citizens for East Shore Parks, and currently sits on the board at San Diego Coastkeeper. Meeting focus: Explore how the institute leverages research and education to improve the state of marine ecosystems and develop innovative conservation models. Discuss California’s robust network of Marine Protected Areas, how it functions, and the myriad stakeholders who implement and support it. Cross-Border Coordination
source_proposal: Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve
description: The Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve (TRNERR) preserves, protects, and manages the natural and cultural resources of the Tijuana River Estuary by focusing on research and education with compatible recreation and resource use. The Reserve encompasses beach, dune, mudflat, salt marsh, riparian, coastal sage scrub, and upland habitats surrounded by the growing cities of Tijuana, Imperial Beach, and San Diego. Critical issues confronted by the Reserve include habitat conservation and restoration, management of wastewater from Mexico, sediment management and the integration of recreation.
source_proposal: Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: Wildcoast
description: Wildcoast is an international team that conserves coastal and marine ecosystems and addresses climate change through natural solutions. They envision a society in which ecologically sensitive and globally significant coastal and marine ecosystems and wildlife are conserved, restored and sustained for future generations. They are non-profit organization who work across the United States and Mexico to conserve globally significant coastal and marine ecosystems and wildlife, conserving more than 38 million acres of ecosystems. Wildcoast is leading efforts in California to conserve over half a million acres of marine-protected area, and to put a stop to overfishing and other destructive practices like offshore drilling and deep-sea mining. Non –Profit and Non-Governmental Organizations
source_proposal: Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: TMA Blue Tech
description: TMA Blue Tech is the non-profit industry association and cluster organizer for the San Diego ocean and water technologies community. They believe in creating BlueTech and Blue Jobs by promoting sustainable, science-based ocean and water industries. They bring education, policy and technology resources together to promote innovation and economic development in the Blue Economy. They create a strong “Blue Voice” via unique events, information sharing, national and international outreach, networking, research, and workforce development. TMA BlueTech promotes collaboration in the region combined with active national and international outreach. San Diego Coastkeeper www.sdcoastkeeper.org/ San Diego Coastkeeper believes a strategic combination of science, advocacy, education, and community engagement is the most effective way to address existing and emerging water-related issues in San Diego and beyond. The non-profit organization works to locally enforce the provisions of the 1972 Clean Water Act (CWA) and other federal and state laws. The organization works to improve sewage and urban runoff policies, adopt marine protected areas, remove marine debris, reduce sewage spills, and encourage the community to participate in the state’s largest volunteer water quality monitoring program. San Diego Coastkeeper uses community outreach, education and advocacy efforts to empower thousands of San Diegans to be stewards of clean water and a healthy coastal ecosystem. Meeting focus: Discuss San Diego Coastkeeper’s diverse range of work, and specifically explore their ongoing campaigns related to offshore industrial fish farming and the Pacific Ocean Aquafarms project.
source_proposal: Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: California Coastal Commission (San Diego Coast District):
description: https://www.coastal.ca.gov/contact/#/ The mission of the Coastal Commission is to protect, conserve, restore, and enhance environmental resources of the California coast and ocean for environmentally sustainable and prudent use by current and future generations. The Coastal Commission, in partnership with coastal cities and counties, plans and regulates the use of land and water in the coastal zone. Development activities, which are broadly defined by the Coastal Act to include (among others) construction of buildings, divisions of land, and activities that change the intensity of use of land or public access to coastal waters, generally require a coastal permit from either the Coastal Commission or the local government. The San Diego Coast District stretches 70 miles from the northern border of Camp Pendleton Marine Corps Base to the Mexican border. Collaborative Resources
source_proposal: Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: California Sea Grant
description: California Sea Grant is a collaboration of the National Oceanic Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), the State of California and universities across the state to create knowledge, products and services that benefit the economy, the environment and the citizens of California. They work on services and policy issues including grant and fellowship opportunities for scientists and graduate students, news and library services, specialists dedicated to impartial research and outreach, and proposal solicitation and grant administration services. California Sea Grant is administered by Scripps Institution of Oceanography at the University of California, San Diego. Port of San Diego
source_proposal: Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: Commercial Fishing
description: Commercial fishing has a long history at the Port of San Diego. The first cannery opened in 1909, and San Diego was once known as the “Tuna Capital of the World”. The Port has extensive amenities at the Tuna Boat Basin including Tuna Boat Pier, Fish Harbor Pier, Fish Market Wharf and three floating docks. The piers not only provide berthing for larger fishing vessels but are used as an area for the servicing and storage of fishing nets, lobster traps, crab traps and other related equipment.
source_proposal: Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: Harbor Police
description: The mission of the Harbor Police Department is to remain cross-trained to prevent crime on the waterfront and fight fire on the water. Harbor Police services include professional law enforcement and support staff, interacting with the public to ensure a safe and secure environment at the San Diego International Airport, on San Diego Bay and Port tidelands. Their main areas of operation include vehicle patrol, vessel patrol, dive & rescue, marine firefighting, Maritime Tactical Team (Composed of SWAT trained officers), airport patrol, homeland security and training.
source_proposal: Enhancing Regional Maritime Governance and Cooperation in the Quad.docx

name: Environmental Services Department
description: The Port of San Diego is a self-supporting public benefit corporation established in 1963 by an act of the California State Legislature. The Port champions the safekeeping and environmental care of San Diego’s diverse ecosystems, stewarding the protection of land, air, and water. As champions in the safekeeping and environmental care of San Diego Bay and its diverse ecosystems, the Port of San Diego has enrolled in Green Marine, North America’s largest voluntary environmental certification program for the maritime industry. The Port’s Environmental Services Department also works extensively to protect the environment through pollution prevention, jurisdictional runoff management program and alternative hull paints, and to conserve the environment through environmental education and community outreach, and natural resources management. _______________________________ Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown). Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $30 for one Adult Ticket for a one-hour narrated tour (south bay or north bay routes); $35 for a full bay two-hour narrated tour which covers it all: ships of the Maritime Museum, Harbor and Shelter Islands, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and more. The full bay tour is about 25 miles in length. Accessibility: The tour begins and ends at the same location downtown along Broadway Pier. Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com Price: $44 for a 1-Day Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) For 30 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours, highlighting the best San Diego attractions. The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50am – 5:00pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $26 for one Adult General Admission Ticket ($1 discount when purchased on-line). Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10am – 5pm (Last admission at 4pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside Navy Pier. Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 17 major museums and cultural institutions, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).

name: Coronado
description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year around due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown. SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $99.99 for one Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) Accessibility: A 15-20-minute drive from downtown San Diego. Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Orca Encounter, Dolphin Days, and Sea Lions Live shows and thrilling rides like Electric Eel, Manta, and Journey To Atlantis. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Hours vary by season.

name: Smart Border Coalition
description: The Smart Border Coalition is a catalyst to bring together leading academic, business, and civic communities from both sides of the San Diego/Tijuana International region to develop databases and policy positions, deliver special events and programs, and growth of the cross-border economy through jobs creation, workforce development and social interaction. Their mission is to make travel and trade easier and more efficient through the ports of entry between San Diego County and the Tijuana Metropolitan Area.
source_proposal: U.S. Foreign Policy – Global Challenges I RP SDDC Proposal.docx

name: Alliance for African Assistance
description: The Alliance for African Assistance is a non-profit, which assists with the resettlement of 1,020 asylum seekers, individuals, and families from Afghanistan who began arriving on September 1st with a goal of resettling all in San Diego by the end of February 2022. They have a partnership with Rancho Santa Fe Foundation to help their supporters maximize their support of the resettlement of Afghan families, the first $50,000 of donations received will be doubled. Meeting focus: learn about the Alliance for African Assistance and how they are able to support Afghan families, as well as if they were able to reach their goal of February 2022. In addition, meet with Afghan refugees that have gone through Alliance for African Assistance to get integrated in San Diego, and learn about their experiences.
source_proposal: U.S. Foreign Policy – Global Challenges I RP SDDC Proposal.docx

name: San Diego Immigrant Rights Consortium (SDIRC)
description: San Diego Immigrant Rights Consortium (SDIRC) is a coalition of various organizations in San Diego that work to protect the rights and dignity of immigrants and refugees. They may also address issues related to hate and discrimination. SDIRC works at all levels; federal through their New Border Vision framework which upholds the dignity and rights of all people at US’s borders, State by monitoring local law enforcement agencies, and local to push local measures and resources such as their new campaign “Welcoming San Diego”.
source_proposal: U.S. Foreign Policy – Global Challenges I RP SDDC Proposal.docx

name: ADL Fighting Hate For Good
description: https://sandiego.adl.org/news/repair-plan-fighting-hate-in-the-digital-world/ ADL San Diego has been the leader in fighting anti-Semitism, and bigotry of all kinds, for over 40 years in America’s Finest City. ADL has expertise in the fields of investigating and monitoring extremism, anti-bias education, and communal security. Each year ADL Serves tens of thousands of local students, educators, and parents through their award-winning education programs, like No Place for Hate®, designed to reduce bias on campus. ADL is on the forefront of training local law enforcement in Managing Implicit Bias, designed to reduce the influence of bias on interactions and decision-making, improve police-community relations, build mutual respect and trust, and increase overall safety for officers and civilians. ADL responds to hundreds of anti-Semitic incident reports from community members, working to help victims in the aftermath of hate. In addition, ADL provides local Jewish institutions with security briefings and best practices for safety in an effort to keep all members of the community safe from acts of hate. Lastly, ADL builds coalitions with partner organizations throughout San Diego County to find meaningful solutions to important issues facing our diverse communities. REPAIR Plan ADL’s REPAIR Plan focuses on fighting domestic extremism and terrorism but goes beyond these issues to address other manifestations and harms of online hate, including harassment, antisemitism, anti-Muslim bigotry, racism, and extremist disinformation. Repair stands for Regulation and reform, enforcing at scale, people over profit, access to justice, Interrupting disinformation, Research and innovation.
source_proposal: U.S. Foreign Policy – Global Challenges I RP SDDC Proposal.docx

name: Lauren Prather, Assistant Professor, UCSD School of Global Policy & Strategy
description: https://gps.ucsd.edu/news-events/news/piecing-together-foreign-aid-perceptions%20.html Lauren Prather is an assistant professor of international relations at the UC San Diego School of Global Policy and Strategy. Her work focuses on the domestic determinants of foreign policy, U.S. foreign policy, democracy promotion and democratization, Middle East politics, and experimental methods. Her research is supported by the National Science Foundation, the Institute for Research in the Social Sciences, the Europe Center, and the Laboratory for the Study of American Values at Stanford University. As part of her dissertation at Stanford University, she analyzed American public opinion on how cash and material aid to help the poor is given domestically and abroad.
source_proposal: U.S. Foreign Policy – Global Challenges I RP SDDC Proposal.docx

name: Jeremy M. Martin, Institute of the Americas Energy Program, University of California San Diego
description: https://sandiegodiplomacy.org/about/board-of-directors/ Jeremy M. Martin is Vice President of Energy & Sustainability at the Institute of the Americas, an inter-American public policy think-tank located at the University of California San Diego. The Institute of the Americas Energy Program works to foster a deeper understanding of the most critical energy issues facing the Western Hemisphere. Martin spends his time delving into the geopolitics of energy and closely following energy industry trends and policy issues across the Americas and is a frequent commentator and writer on Latin American and energy issues. Martin has testified before the U.S. Congress on energy issues in Latin America, teaches a graduate seminar in Latin American Energy Politics at the University of San Diego, and serves as Curator of the energy section of the US-Mexico Network, an online forum hosted by the University of Southern California. Virtual Meeting Focus: Discussion of international energy initiatives, security measures, policies and regulations throughout the Western Hemisphere. Examine the role of academia and research institutions in energy innovation and security.
source_proposal: U.S. Foreign Policy – Global Challenges I RP SDDC Proposal.docx

name: University of San Diego,  Joan B. Kroc Institute for Peace and Justice
description: https://www.sandiego.edu/peace/institute-for-peace-justice/violence-inequality-power-lab/ The Joan B. Kroc Institute for Peace and Justice (Kroc IPJ) was launched in 2001 with a vision of active peacebuilding. In 2007, the Kroc IPJ became part of the newly established Joan B. Kroc School of Peace Studies, a global hub for peacebuilding and social innovation. The core of the Kroc IPJ mission is to co-create learning with peacemakers — learning that is deeply grounded in the lived experience of peacemakers around the world, that is made rigorous by our place within a university ecosystem and that is immediately and practically applied by peacemakers to end cycles of violence. The Violence, Inequality and Power Lab (VIP Lab) At the Violence, Inequality, and Power (VIP) Lab, we seek to understand how inequalities of power shape the landscape of violence. We deliver practical, actionable ideas that partners can implement at the systems level to confront harmful power inequalities and reduce violence.
source_proposal: U.S. Foreign Policy – Global Challenges I RP SDDC Proposal.docx

name: UC San Diego Center for Comparative Immigration Studies
description: The Center for Comparative Immigration Studies (CCIS) is an independent research unit at the University of California San Diego. The Center’s global network of research associates has expanded to over 355 Research Associates based in 25 different countries. The Center also has 35 institutional affiliates, 12 of which are located outside the United States. CCIS academic staff and Fellows appear frequently in the local and national media discourse on immigration issues, and their scholarly work informs immigration policy and practice worldwide. CCIS has long been a center for the training of undergraduate and graduate students, with unique academic programming both in La Jolla and through the Mexican Migration Field Research Program. Congressional Influence in Foreign Policy:
source_proposal: U.S. Foreign Policy – Global Challenges I RP SDDC Proposal.docx

name: Congressman Juan Vargas (Democrat)
description: Juan Vargas is a U.S. Representative for California’s 51st district and has been a member of Congress since 2013. He grew up in the southern San Diego area, earned a BA from University of San Diego, a MA from Fordham University, and a JD from Harvard University. Before his appointment to Congress, he served in the San Diego City council, California State Assembly and California State Senate. He is currently appointed to the House Committee on Foreign Affairs, with assignments to the Subcommittee on Middle East and North Africa and to the Subcommittee on Terrorism, Nonproliferation and Trade. Government Programs

name: City of San Diego, Welcoming San Diego
description: Welcoming San Diego is a City of San Diego initiative is designed to advance the civic, social, and economic integration of immigrants and refugees. They envision a vibrant, inclusive, and safe binational region that attracts families and businesses from around the world and that all San Diegans can flourish in. As the birthplace of California, San Diego is a gateway for newcomers searching for freedom and opportunity. Their strength and future is tied to our ability to ensure New Americans can fully participate in civic life, access public resources, and contribute their skills. San Diego was awarded the Gateways for Growth grant to bring together other local government agencies, nonprofits, educational institutions and businesses to develop a strategic plan on immigrant integration. In February of 2019, the City of San Diego formally launched the Welcoming San Diego Initiative accompanied by the Welcoming San Diego Strategic Plan. The City’s Immigrant Affairs Manager is responsible for continuing this effort.
source_proposal: U.S. Foreign Policy – Global Challenges I RP SDDC Proposal.docx

name: City of San Diego, Office of Immigration and Refugee Affairs
description: The Office of Immigration and Refugee Affairs was created with the mission of advancing equality and opportunities for immigrant and refugee communities by removing barriers to help them integrate into society and thrive. They serve as regional experts and leaders in immigrant and refugee affairs. OIRA collaborates closely with local resettlement agencies to devote county resources to the immigrant population regardless of immigration, refugee, or visa status. The office also serves as the County Refugee Coordinator to the State of California. Meeting focus: Meet with local government officials within the City of San Diego’s Immigrant Affairs and those working in Welcoming San Diego department to learn about how they prepare for refugee arrivals and how they help integrate them into the local community.
source_proposal: U.S. Foreign Policy – Global Challenges I RP SDDC Proposal.docx

name: Immigration Center for Women and Children, San Diego Office
description: The Immigration Center for Women and Children (ICWC) is a non-profit legal organization providing free and affordable immigration services to underrepresented immigrants in California and Nevada. ICWC strives to provide security and stability for children who are abused, abandoned, or neglected and for immigrants who are victims of domestic violence, sexual assault and other violent crimes. Using U.S. federal legislation, ICWC provides immigration legal services (U and T Visas, VAWA, and SIJS) to immigrants who are victims of crimes. The resulting immigration benefits allow individuals to permanently leave their abusers and create safe environments for their families.  ICWC’s overall goal is to assist these victims of domestic violence, human trafficking, sexual assault, and other violent crimes in escaping abusive relationships, living in safety, and become self-sufficient. _______________________________ Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants.
