name: Scripps Institution of Oceanography (SIO), Center for Marine Biodiversity and Conservation (CMBC):
description: A department of UC San Diego, Scripps Institution of Oceanography is one of the oldest and most renowned centers for ocean and Earth science research, public service, undergraduate and graduate training in the world. Hundreds of ocean and Earth scientists conduct research with the aid of oceanographic research vessels and shore-based laboratories. CMBC is an interdisciplinary research center within the Institute, which promotes the education of future leaders in marine biodiversity/conservation and research. It seeks to help find better ways to communicate scientific knowledge to decision makers and the public, and train scientists who work effectively at the interface between the natural and social sciences. Collaboration with these partners and scientists from other academic institutions, government agencies, industry leaders, and conservation organizations around the world, provides for a novel integration of disciplines as CMBC seeks technically sophisticated, regionally appropriate strategies to prevent and reverse biodiversity collapse. Meeting focus: A discussion to explore how the institute uses research and education to improve the state of marine ecosystems and develop innovative conservation models, especially through their aquarium and endangered species rescue program. The institute may also speak on the use of new technologies for conservation.
source_proposal: Conservation and Biodiverity SCP Proposal.docx

name: Samantha Murray, J.D., Executive Director, Master of Advanced Studies, Marine
description: Samantha Murray is the Executive Director of the Master of Advanced Studies Program in Marine Biodiversity and Conservation at Scripps Institution of Oceanography, where she also teaches Ocean Law and Policy. She has nearly two decades of experience in conservation and has directed ocean and water programs at Ocean Conservancy, the Audubon Society and Oregon Environmental Council. Samantha played a key role in the design and implementation of California's network of Marine Protected Areas (MPAs), which now cover 16 percent of state waters, and currently sits on the Marine Protected Area Federal Advisory Committee. Samantha has spoken at conferences around the world on best practices in ocean conservation and is committed to diversity, inclusion and equitable impacts of public policy.
source_proposal: Conservation and Biodiverity SCP Proposal.docx

name: WiLDCOAST:
description: WiLDCOAST is a non-profit organization with a successful conservation recording, having protected more than one million acres of coastal wildland and halted the development plans of illegal mega-resorts throughout the Baja California Peninsula and the Sea of Cortez. Through its innovative, successful conservation campaigns, the conservation team has brought critical attention to pressing environmental issues such as protecting the sensitive Cabo Pulmo coral reef from the proposed construction of a 2012 mega-development project. Their conservation activities have focused on U.S.-Mexico Border coast sites that contain globally significant coastal and marine ecosystems (e.g. coastal dune, mangroves, salt marsh wetlands) and internationally migrating and threatened marine species. Suggested topic: A meeting here would allow participants to learn about WiLDCOAST’s binational campaigns to protect damage to coral reefs and mangrove ecosystems, including transborder considerations. *May include a walking tour of a protected coastal area. Non-Governmental Organizations
source_proposal: Conservation and Biodiverity SCP Proposal.docx

name: San Diego Zoo Wildlife Alliance
description: San Diego Zoo Wildlife Alliance is an international, nonprofit conservation organization with two front doors: the San Diego Zoo and the San Diego Zoo Safari Park. They integrate wildlife health and care, science, and education to develop sustainable conservation solutions. They implement full-spectrum conservation strategies that are collaborative, innovative, and multidisciplinary. Their intent is to partner with the local community, share learnings, and further develop skills and expertise—so that communities, and wildlife that shares the ecosystems, thrive. World-wide Conservation Hubs: The San Diego Zoo Wildlife Alliance has 8 conservation hubs across the world. These hubs represent areas where we are currently most invested, and therefore hope to have the greatest return on mission and vision. The hubs promote synergy and collaboration among internal and external partners and stakeholders. Our hubs will help us build on existing partnerships and collaborations, and have greater impact in a region. Biodiversity Banking: The San Diego Zoo Wildlife Alliance curate and manage diverse biomaterials collections as a global tool for preventing plant and animal extinction. In our work, we seek to maximize genetic diversity and collection integrity of our Frozen Zoo® and other biomaterials collections. We train and advise colleagues in the establishment and expansion of biobanks, and provide biomaterials to scientific collaborators worldwide.

name: Center for Plant Conservation (CPC):
description: The CPC is a one-of-a-kind network of conservation partners, collectively known as CPC Participating Institutions (now including more than 60 institutions), that collaboratively work to save the imperiled plants of the United States and Canada. CPC PIs maintain the CPC National Collection of Endangered Plants, a living conservation collection of imperiled plants, by working to collect and manage living seeds and plants, advancing the understanding of threats as well as means to save these species, and by communicating with partners within the CPC network to ensure that all are using the best and most up-to-date means possible to save plants.

name: San Diego Humane Society Project Wildlife:
description: Project Wildlife serves to improve the quality of life for local wildlife and the community, as the primary resource for animal rehabilitation and conservation education. The project includes qualified medical and rehabilitation teams and modern facilities where rescued animals reside for an average of 12 weeks. Since 1972, Project Wildlife’s staff and volunteers have rehabilitated an average of nearly 12,000 injured, orphaned, and sick wild animals per year as the project as grown into one of the largest wildlife rehabilitation organizations in the United States. San Diego Natural History Museum, Biodiversity Research Center of the Californias (BRCC) www.sdnhm.org/archive/research/mission.html The Biodiversity Research Center of the Californias (BRCC) conducts field explorations and collections-based research to preserve specimens and associated information that document our region's natural history and biodiversity. BRCC provides scientific knowledge about the natural history of our region, and supports the San Diego Natural History Museum's mission by laying the scientific foundation for its operation and programs. Governmental Resources

NOAA is a source of objective scientific information concerning ecosystems, climate, weather and water, and commerce and transportation NOAA is also a steward of U.S. coastal and marine environments. In coordination with federal, state, local, tribal and international authorities, NOAA assists with the management and use of these environments, regulating marine sanctuaries as well as protecting threatened and endangered marine species.

name: Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve:
description: The Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve preserves, protects, and manages the natural and cultural resources of the Tijuana River Estuary by focusing on research and education with compatible recreation and resource use. The Reserve encompasses beach, dune, mudflat, salt marsh, riparian, coastal sage scrub, and upland habitats surrounded by the growing cities of Tijuana, Imperial Beach, and San Diego. Critical issues confronted by the Reserve include habitat conservation and restoration, endangered species management, management of the wastewater from Mexico, sediment management, and the integration of recreation. name: California Coastal Commission (San Diego Coast District):
description: https://www.coastal.ca.gov/contact/#/ The mission of the Coastal Commission is to protect, conserve, restore, and enhance environmental resources of the California coast and ocean for environmentally sustainable and prudent use by current and future generations. The Coastal Commission, in partnership with coastal cities and counties, plans and regulates the use of land and water in the coastal zone. Development activities, which are broadly defined by the Coastal Act to include (among others) construction of buildings, divisions of land, and activities that change the intensity of use of land or public access to coastal waters, generally require a coastal permit from either the Coastal Commission or the local government. The San Diego Coast District stretches 70 miles from the northern border of Camp Pendleton Marine Corps Base to the Mexican border.

name: San Diego City Planning Department, Biodiverse SD
description: Biodiverse SD was developed to preserve a network of habitat and open space, protecting species and ecosystems that improve our quality of life. Biodiverse SD, which includes the City’s Multiple Species Conservation Program, protects 85 species, including endangered species like the California gnatcatcher and other species of concern unique to San Diego such as the western burrowing owl. The program was developed by the City in cooperation with wildlife agencies, property owners, developers, and environmental groups.  Biodiverse SD delineates core biological resource areas and corridors targeted for conservation, called the Multi-Habitat Planning Area (MHPA). Within the MHPA, limited development may occur to ensure the long-term habitat conservation plan for the 85 Covered Species addresses needs of multiple species and the preservation of natural vegetation communities.

From climate action and clean mobility planning, to open space, agricultural, and groundwater resource conservation, the division serves the community and the County’s mission to protect the public’s health and safety, sustain the environment, and improve the quality of life for County residents. name: San Diego State University, Department of Geography
description: https://geography.sdsu.edu/research/environment San Diego University leads innovative ecosystem research funded by the National Science Foundation, the US Forest Service and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA). This includes research efforts examining the role of chaparral shrub land vegetation as a fuel type on wildfire spread, as well as the rate and distribution of vegetation regrowth following fires. A major emphasis of this research is the exploitation of optical remote sensing imagery captured from airborne and satellite imaging to map, monitor and study chaparral fuel loadings, regrowth, and fire spread. Dr. Douglas (Doug) Stow: Is a Distinguished Professor Emeritus at San Diego State University (SDSU) and has been on the faculty there for almost 38 years. He has worked in the remote sensing field for almost 45 years and his research focuses on multitemporal image analysis, with an emphasis on mapping and monitoring of land use and land cover, vegetation and habitat condition, wildfire spread and post-hazard damage. He is the primary instructor of remote sensing courses at SDSU and is the Co-Director of the Center for Earth Systems Analysis Research. Doug has served as major advisor of 14 doctoral and 64 master’s degree students. He has authored 190 refereed publications and served as a principal investigator for 48 grants and contracts with funding totaling over $35 million, mostly on remote sensing topics. Private Sector

name: La Jolla Ecological Reserve:
description: Price: $62 per person. The group can explore La Jolla’s Ecological Reserve through a tour with Everyday California guides which will take the group on a tour of La Jolla Ecological Reserve, a Marine Protected Area that’s home to a thriving underwater ecosystem that boasts one of the highest concentrations of sea-life in all of California! Kayak through the underwater park to experience La Jolla’s Seven Sea Caves, one of San Diego’s coolest attractions. Seasons change, but they’re always running: throughout the summer months you’ll have a chance to see one of the biggest Leopard Shark gatherings in the world, and in the winter witness Gray Whales on their annual migration from Alaska to Baja California. Everyday California tours are suitable for almost everyone 5 years and older. No experience is needed to enjoy a kayak tour; their guides will have you paddling around in no time. **Home Hospitality can be offered for the group, as well as a volunteer activity ** Year-Round Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $56 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. It is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park. Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $27 for one Adult Ticket for two-hour tour Their deluxe tour covers it all: Harbor and Shelter Islands, Point Loma, Cabrillo National Monument, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and much more. Tour is about 25 miles in length, 2 hour narrated tour. Old Town Trolley Tour www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com www.trolleytours.com/san-diego Price: $37.80 for one Adult Ticket Online For over 20 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours highlighting the best San Diego attractions. Old Town offers much to do, from visiting over 23 historic sites to shopping for unique merchandise. They also have many award winning restaurants to choose from. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $22.00 for Adult Admission Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 29 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 15 major museums, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Coronado Consistently voted one of America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year around due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. From the shores of Silver Strand State Beach to the tip of the Coronado Municipal Beach, you’ll find plenty of wide open sand, gentle waves and gorgeous views. SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $91.99 for one Adult Ticket Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Shamu show, One Ocean, and thrilling rides like Journey To Atlantis, Shipwreck Rapids and Wild Arctic. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Then dive into the world of sea turtles at the all-new Turtle Reef attraction.

name: City of San Diego, Welcoming San Diego
description: Welcoming San Diego is a City of San Diego initiative designed to advance the civic, social and economic integration of immigrants and refugees. They envision a vibrant, inclusive, and safe binational region that attracts families and businesses from around the world and that all San Diegans can flourish in. As the birthplace of California, San Diego is a gateway for newcomers searching for freedom and opportunity. Their strength and future is tied to our ability to ensure New Americans can fully participate in civic life, access public resources, and contribute their skills. San Diego was awarded the Gateways for Growth grant to bring together other local government agencies, nonprofits, educational institutions and businesses to develop a strategic plan on immigrant integration. In February of 2019, the City of San Diego formally launched the Welcoming San Diego Initiative accompanied by the Welcoming San Diego Strategic Plan. The City's Immigrant Affairs Manager is responsible for continuing this effort. City of San Diego, Office of Immigration and Refugee Affairs https://www.sandiegocounty.gov/content/sdc/hhsa/programs/hsec/OIRA The Office of Immigration and Refugee Affairs was created with the mission of advancing equality and opportunities for immigrant and refugee communities by removing barriers to help them integrate into society and thrive. They serve as regional experts and leaders in immigrant and refugee affairs. OIRA collaborates closely with local resettlement agencies to devote county resources to the immigrant population regardless of immigration, refugee, or visa status. The office also serves as the County Refugee Coordinator to the State of California.

The Multi-Cultural Community Relations Office was established by the SDPD in 1987 to address the specific needs of the growing refugee population in San Diego. name: U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) - San Diego Sector
description: The San Diego Sector of the U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) consists of more than 7,000 square miles and 66 linear miles of international boundary with Mexico. The San Diego Sector encompasses coastal beaches and expansive mesas to coastal and inland mountains, rugged canyons and high desert. Directly to the South of San Diego lie the Mexican cities of Tijuana and Tecate, Baja California - with a combined population of more than 2 million. Today, San Diego Sector is focused on addressing the continuously changing tactics of transnational criminal organizations as well as migration patterns affecting the Southern border. With the increase in smuggling activity in recent years along Southern California's coastal borders, additional Border Patrol agents have been assigned to combat the maritime smuggling of humans and drugs, and San Diego Sector's Primary Operational Domain has increased from 91 coastal border miles to 114. Meeting request to go through federal gatekeepers.

name: Migrant Protection Protocols - Department of Homeland Security
description: The Migrant Protection Protocols (MPP) are a U.S. Government action whereby certain foreign individuals entering or seeking admission to the U.S. from Mexico – illegally or without proper documentation – may be returned to Mexico and wait outside of the U.S. for the duration of their immigration proceedings, where Mexico will provide them with all appropriate humanitarian protections for the duration of their stay. The program went into effect in January 2019 and was used to send nearly 70,000 migrants back to Mexico. Citing widespread reports of severe human rights violations and seriously logistical problems caused by the program, the Biden administration suspended, and then terminated, the program after President Biden took office. A “reinstated” Remain in Mexico program returned 7,505 people to Mexico from December 2021 to August 2022 as the result of federal court order which was eventually overturned by the Supreme Court. This program does not currently exist anymore in the US. Meeting request to go through federal gatekeepers. Non Profit Organizations

Since then, they have expanded their mission to include advocating for human rights, humane immigration reform, and social justice. The goal of their work is to educate and assist communities on both sides of the US-Mexico border in order to reduce the number of fatalities. Some of the services they provide are educational programs, water drops in the desert, day laborer outreach, Familias Reunidas Immigration Bond Fund Program, and Shelter Aid support in Tijuana to aid migrants and asylum seekers in need.

These individuals have survived against incredible odds. The IRC collaborates closely with government bodies, civil society actors, and local volunteers to support refugees, asylum-seekers, and other immigrants in San Diego, as they work to rebuild their lives.

name: https://www.immigrantsandiego.org/
description: Alliance San Diego is a community organization whose mission is to build collective power to create an inclusive democracy. They build power by developing leaders, engaging communities, advocating for policies, protecting civil and human rights, and communication strategically. In 2007, Alliance San Diego founded the San Diego Immigrants' Rights Consortium (SDIRC) which aims to support comprehensive immigration reform, prevent the spread of local policies that violate immigrant's human rights, and educate immigrants about their rights, as well as enlighten the public about the important contributions immigrants offer to the community. Then in 2011, Alliance San Diego founded the Southern Border Communities Coalition (SBCC) which brings together more than 60 organizations from the southern border to promote policies and solutions that improve the quality of life of border residents. Note: This organization often has low capacity, so it would be up to their schedule if they could meet. They also require honorarium. Minority Humanitarian Foundation (MHF) MHF Immigrant Relief Fund | Philanthropy California The mission of Minority Humanitarian Foundation is to provide a humanitarian response to the issues facing asylum-seekers and refugees on a global scale. MHF believes that all humans should be treated with dignity and respect, despite country of origin. Through on-the-ground relief efforts, health services, housing, transportation services and legal representation they work to ensure the health and safety of the people they work with. Then through education and job placement they work to ensure their success in a new country. In 2021, MHF opened a boutique thrift store and art space called “Welcome Home” seeking to serve as a community space highlighting the local demographics of BIPOC artists. Karen Organization of San Diego Home - Karen Organization of San Diego (karensandiego.org) Established in 2009, KOSD supports Karen and other refugees from Burma in San Diego. They help refugees navigate social service systems, access leadership and employment opportunities, and stay connected to their community and culture. To date, the United States has resettled more than 12,000 refugees from Burma including Karen, Karenni, Chin, Kachin, Shan, Mon, and Burmese. The number of refugees from Burma has dramatically increased since 2007. In 2010, out of 73,000 total refugees admitted to the U.S., about 22% were refugees from Burma. Accordingly, the number of those who resettled in San Diego has also kept increasing; to date, more than 2,100 refugees from Burma have resettled in San Diego. Integration Resources

name: The Center for Comparative Immigration Studies (CCIS) is an independent research unit at the University of California San Diego. The Center’s global network of research associates has expanded to over 355 Research Associates based in 25 different countries. The Center also has 35 institutional affiliates, 12 of which are located outside the United States. CCIS academic staff and Fellows appear frequently in the local and national media discourse on immigration issues, and their scholarly work informs immigration policy and practice worldwide. CCIS has long been a center for the training of undergraduate and graduate students, with unique academic programming both in La Jolla and through the Mexican Migration Field Research Program.
url: David FitzGerald, CCIS Co-Director and Professor of Sociology, UCSD https://ccis.ucsd.edu/people/co-directors-staff/fitzgerald.html
description: David FitzGerald is the Theodore E. Gildred Chair in U.S.-Mexican Relations, Professor of Sociology, and Co-Director of the Center for Comparative Immigration Studies at the University of California San Diego. His research analyzes policies regulating migration and asylum in countries of origin, transit, and destination. FitzGerald’s most recent books include Immigrant California: Understanding the Past, Present, and Future of U.S. Policy (Stanford University Press 2021), and Refuge beyond Reach: How Rich Democracies Repel Asylum Seekers (Oxford University Press 2019), winner of the American Sociological Association International Migration Section Best Book Award; Borderless Scholars Program, San Diego Mesa College Borderless Scholars, Undocumented, AB540, DACA and Dreamers | EOPS | Student Services | San Diego Mesa College (sdmesa.edu) The Borderless Scholars’ program is designed to provide a safe and welcoming environment for undocumented students and undocu-allies. They support these students to overcome personal and educational challenges due to their immigration status. They provide personal, career, and academic counseling, on-campus support services, and community resources including free legal services. Advocacy and social justice is their main passion and allows them to be the support students need. Their services include counseling, meal cards, California Dream Act application assistance, immigration consultations, etc. San Diego County Office of Education Migrant Services https://www.sdcoe.net/special-populations/migrant-education Migrant Education is a federally funded program designed to provide education and support services to identified migratory children and youth. Migratory youth are defined as children and youth who move periodically with their parents/guardians for seasonal agricultural work. This office serves about 4,000 migratory youth and children in 56 school districts across San Diego and Orange County. Migrant Education collaborates with school districts, charter schools, and community agencies to provide supplemental support to ensure equitable education for migratory youth and children.
source_proposal: Collaboration and Cooperation on Refugee and Migration Issues within the United States.docx

name: Lexington Elementary
description: Lexington Elementary is located in the San Diego Community of Cajon Valley. They have a huge refugee and immigrant population; in which they are considered a multicultural school with over 60 languages spoken at the school. Lexington Elementary has a special immersion program, where students will have a special class in addition to their other classes where they can ask questions in their native language, and learn English, and integration efforts within a small group of students. Lexington Elementary also offers a food pantry to parents, and translators for any language to have good communication with parents throughout the process. Teachers are also trained to teach with a multicultural focus, and work with each student individually to see where they are struggling to collaborate with the World Language Program. Border Resources Tour of the San Diego-Tijuana Border The largest land border crossing in the world, the San Ysidro border crossing plays an integral role in San Diego and Tijuana’s close knit, collaborative relationship. The majority of people living in communities on the San Diego side of the border are people of color, with over 50% of residents identifying as Hispanic or Latinx, whose diversity of experience contribute to a rich hub of culture, experience, and opportunity. San Diego and Tijuana have long prospered from good-humored cross border relations, recently made even more successful with the honor of being jointly named the Innovation Design Hub for 2024. However, while cross-border collaboration and innovation are things to celebrate, there is lots of work to do on the ground among the minority and immigrant communities living in the border region, to ensure quality of life and access to resources are supported. Proposed stops on the border tour include:
source_proposal: Collaboration and Cooperation on Refugee and Migration Issues within the United States.docx

name: San Ysidro Point of Entry: The main artery between San Diego and Tijuana – and, in fact, the U.S. and Mexico – which sees approximately 120,000 passenger vehicles, 60,000 pedestrians, and 6000 trucks crossing back and forth each day, the San Ysidro border is evidence of San Diego and Tijuana’s dynamic relationship. While participants cannot cross into Mexico, they will be able to see over the wall into Mexico, and stand on the bridge atop the border, which leads to the pedestrian crossing site.
url: Cross Border Express (CBX) https://www.crossborderxpress.com/en/ CBX is a pedestrian bridge for passengers of the Tijuana International Airport that allows passengers to cross the U.S.-Mexico border with ease. The facility saves millions of passengers from being delayed at the San Ysidro border crossing by enabling processing via a service terminal on the San Diego side of the border.
description: Friendship Park: Friendship Park is a binational park situated on the U.S.-Mexico border, overlooking the ocean. Since its opening by Pat Nixon 51 years ago, the park has served as a meeting point for families who have been separated by immigration laws. For some families, Friendship Park offers the only opportunity to reunite with loved ones unable to cross the border. Friendship Park, particularly on the Mexico side, has been cultivated by the community into a place of art and gathering, with regular art installations featured and frequent cross-border events like church sermons and yoga classes. We suggest that the tour be accompanied by Rachel Lozano Castro. Rachel Lozano Castro is a public goods professional in San Diego, California and Tijuana, Mexico. She invests her time and energy where community good and equitable economy meet, which can include social entrepreneurship, place making, government upgrades, workforce development and inclusive innovation and investment. In her previous role, Rachel directed the University of San Diego's Brink Small Business Development Center. Today, she is the Director of Innovation at the San Diego Regional Policy and Innovation Center, and facilitates learning experiences around bi-national governance, business, social innovation, design thinking, networking, prototyping and social impact measurement. Volunteer Activities
source_proposal: Collaboration and Cooperation on Refugee and Migration Issues within the United States.docx

name: San Diego River Park Foundation
description: The San Diego River Park Foundation is dedicated to the celebration and care of the San Diego River, and to creating a better quality of life for the community through the creation of a park system along the 52-mile river. Their programs, projects, and events are designed to connect people to the historic San Diego River, and empower the community to steward and celebrate it. Activity Focus: With help from the San Diego River Park Foundation, learn more about the importance of the river as a biodiverse ecosystem in San Diego, and efforts they are doing to connect the community to the river. Activities may include planting and revitalizing native plants, watering, and spreading mulch.
source_proposal: Collaboration and Cooperation on Refugee and Migration Issues within the United States.docx

name: Feeding San Diego
description: Feeding San Diego is the leading hunger relief and food rescue organization in San Diego County. They provide more than 35.4 million meals every year to children, families, seniors, college students, military families, veterans, people facing homelessness, and other underserved populations. In 2022 – 2023, nearly 76% of the food they provided to the community was rescued from becoming waste. Activity Focus: Support Feeding San Diego’s program to package boxes required by a family of four to eat for one week; or another similar activity.
source_proposal: Collaboration and Cooperation on Refugee and Migration Issues within the United States.docx

name: I Love a Clean San Diego
description: I Love a Clean San Diego is a non-profit focusing on inspiring communities to actively conserve and enhance the environment through outreach, workshops, after-school programs, and local involvement. They lead the San Diego Clean Beach Coalition (SDCBC) to educate beachgoers about the harms of beach and marine litter and how we can lessen our impact by swapping out single-use, disposable products with reusable alternatives. Activity Focus: Participate in a beach cleanup Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).
source_proposal: Collaboration and Cooperation on Refugee and Migration Issues within the United States.docx

name: Chicano Park
description: Chicano Park is the geographic and emotional heart of Barrio Logan, located in Logan Heights, San Diego's oldest Mexican-American neighborhood. The park is home to the largest concentration of Chicano murals in the world with more than 80 paintings on seven acres dotted with sculpture, gardens, picnic tables, and playgrounds. Throughout the year, it hosts festivals of music and Aztec dance, the biggest being Chicano Park Day held each April. Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $30 for one Adult Ticket for a one-hour narrated tour (south bay or north bay routes); $35 for a full bay two-hour narrated tour which covers it all: ships of the Maritime Museum, Harbor and Shelter Islands, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and more. The full bay tour is about 25 miles in length. Accessibility: The tour begins and ends at the same location downtown along Broadway Pier. Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com Price: $44 for a 1-Day Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased online) For 30 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours, highlighting the best San Diego attractions. The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50 am – 5:00 pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $26 for one Adult General Admission Ticket ($1 discount when purchased on-line). Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom, and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10 am – 5 pm (Last admission at 4 pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside the Navy Pier.
source_proposal: Collaboration and Cooperation on Refugee and Migration Issues within the United States.docx

name: Border Field State Park & Friendship Park
description: https://www.friendshippark.org/ Located within the Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve, Border Field State Park sits in the very southwestern corner of the United States, 15 miles south of San Diego. This important wildlife habitat, consisting of sand dunes and salt marshes, gives refuge to critically threatened and endangered birds such as the Western Snowy Plover, the California Least Tern, and the Light-footed Ridgway's Rail. Friendship Park is a binational park located at the western end of the US-Mexico border. For generations, people have gathered here to meet up with friends and family "across the line." Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 17 major museums and cultural institutions, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens, and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).
source_proposal: Collaboration and Cooperation on Refugee and Migration Issues within the United States.docx

name: Coronado
description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year-round due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown. SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $99.99 for one Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased online) Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Orca Encounter, Dolphin Days, and Sea Lions Live shows and thrilling rides like Electric Eel, Manta, and Journey To Atlantis. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks, and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Hours vary by season. Also enjoy the opening of Sesame Place in March 2022, a Sesame Street-themed section of the park with new water, ride, and musical attractions. Accessibility: A 15-20-minute drive from downtown San Diego.
source_proposal: Collaboration and Cooperation on Refugee and Migration Issues within the United States.docx

name: San Diego Harbor Police (SDHP)
description: The SDHP operates under the Port of San Diego. It provides law enforcement and public safety services in San Diego Bay, the adjacent tidelands, and at San Diego International Airport. Participants will meet with SDHP officers to learn how this local police authority patrols both the maritime borders of San Diego and the international airport, involving operations on land, sea, and in the air.
source_proposal: Fentanyl and Protecting Public Health.docx

name: San Diego Law Enforcement Coordination Center (SD-LECC)
description: The San Diego Law Enforcement Coordination Center (SD-LECC) is the all crimes, all hazards fusion center and serves as the High Intensity Drug Trafficking Area (SD/I HIDTA) Investigative Support Center (ISC) for the San Diego and Imperial County region. The SD-LECC also serves as the Regional Threat Assessment Center (RTAC) for San Diego and Imperial counties and is part of the California State Threat Assessment System (STAS). The SD-LECC operates as a collaborative partnership among federal, state and local law enforcement/public safety agencies focused on enhancing coordination, information sharing, regional preparedness, training and investigative support/analysis for first responders and other public and private partners in the region.
source_proposal: Fentanyl and Protecting Public Health.docx

name: City of San Diego, Office of Homeland Security
description: The San Diego Office of Homeland Security oversees the City's emergency Prevention and Protection Program; Mitigation and Finance Program; Response and Recovery Program; and leads regional efforts for FEMA's Urban Area Security Initiative. The Office of Homeland Security strives to promote a secure and resilient City with the capabilities required across the whole community to prevent, protect against, mitigate, respond to, and recover from threats and hazards that pose the greatest risk. These risks include natural hazards such as wildfires, earthquakes, floods, and tsunami; human-caused threats such as terrorist attacks and cyber-attacks; and technological hazards such as power outages and utility interruptions.
source_proposal: Fentanyl and Protecting Public Health.docx

name: Fentanyl Abatement and Suppression Team (FAST)
description: HSI’s FAST is a multiagency task force, first established in August 2022 and focused on the disruption and dismantlement of criminal organizations that smuggle and distribute fentanyl within San Diego County. HSI’s FAST targets fentanyl smuggling and distribution networks to counter the rising overdose rate and decrease the availability and accessibility of fentanyl. San Diego County has experienced a 700% increase in fentanyl overdose deaths since 2016, linked to fentanyl — counterfeit pills and powder — being smuggled from Mexico into the United States. This multiagency task force uses traditional and advanced investigative techniques to target the individuals and criminal organizations involved in fentanyl smuggling and distribution
source_proposal: Fentanyl and Protecting Public Health.docx

name: United States Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA)
description: The mission of the DEA is to enforce the controlled substance laws and regulations of the United States and bring to criminal and civil justice system of the United States, or any other competent jurisdiction, those organizations and principal members of organizations, involved in the growing, manufacture, or distribution of controlled substances appearing in or destined for illicit traffic in the U.S.; and to recommend and support non-enforcement programs aimed at reducing the availability of illicit controlled substances on the domestic and international markets. The DEA has a division office in San Diego as well as a District Office in San Ysidro (a border city within San Diego County that includes the San Ysidro Port of Entry).
source_proposal: Fentanyl and Protecting Public Health.docx

name: U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) – San Diego Sector
description: The San Diego Sector of the U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) consists of more than 7,000 square miles and 66 linear miles of international boundary with Mexico. The San Diego Sector encompasses coastal beaches and expansive mesas to coastal and inland mountains, rugged canyons and high desert. Directly to the South of San Diego lie the Mexican cities of Tijuana and Tecate, Baja California - with a combined population of more than 2 million. Today, San Diego Sector is focused on addressing the continuously changing tactics of transnational criminal organizations. Due to increased land border security, transnational criminal organizations have shifted their illegal activities to include the aerial, subterranean, and maritime domains. In order to effectively protect America's borders, Border Patrol agents conduct their enforcement duties on foot, horseback, and mountain bikes, and utilize various types of vehicles including all-terrain vehicles. U.S. Customs and Border Protection's (CBP) - Air and Marine Operations (AMO) CBP’s AMO safeguards our Nation by anticipating and confronting security threats through our aviation and maritime law enforcement expertise, innovative capabilities, and partnerships at the border and beyond. The San Diego Air and Marine Branch is responsible for defending our international land and sea border from terrorists, illegal alien crossings and the smuggling of contraband. The branch provides air and marine response capabilities to the Border Patrol and Field Operations. In addition, the branch closely supports U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement offices throughout California.
source_proposal: Fentanyl and Protecting Public Health.docx

name: U.S. Coast Guard – San Diego Sector
description: Located within the Homeland Security Department, the U.S. Coast Guard is unique as an armed force. Comprised of active duty, reserve, civilian, and auxiliary members, it provides a broad range of services to the American people in times of peace and war. The Coast Guard manages six major operational mission programs: maritime law enforcement, maritime response, maritime prevention, marine transportation system management, maritime security operations, and defense operations. The 11th Coast Guard District encompasses the states of California, Arizona, Nevada, and Utah; their coastal and offshore waters out over thousand miles; and the offshore waters of Mexico and Central America down to South America. Coast Guard operational units are located throughout the state of California. Government Resources
source_proposal: Fentanyl and Protecting Public Health.docx

name: Overdose Surveillance and Response
description: This program is a collaborative effort between the County Health and Human Services Agency, Public Health Services, and Behavioral Health Services, with support from the County Medical Examiner's Office and County Emergency Medical Services. Surveillance focuses on the monitoring of overdose data across the County, analyzing it to detect crisis events, identifying geographic hotspots, and tracking trends in substance use. Investigation and Response efforts are initiated as geographic clusters and data spikes are identified, including street-level outreach in affected areas to provide harm reduction supplies such as naloxone (an opioid overdose reversal medication) and fentanyl test strips, along with health and community-based referrals. Community Engagement involves raising awareness of the risks of substance use, promoting harm reduction strategies, and connecting individuals with local resources.
source_proposal: Fentanyl and Protecting Public Health.docx

name: County of San Diego’s Behavioral Health Services (BHS)
description: The County of San Diego’s Behavioral Health Services (BHS) department provides mental health and substance use disorder services to over 111,000 San Diego County residents of all ages. Services are provided through 9 county-operated programs, over 300 contracts, and 800 individual fee-for-service providers. BHS offers services across the lifespan through coordinated systems of care within San Diego.
source_proposal: Fentanyl and Protecting Public Health.docx

name: Live Well San Diego
description: Live Well San Diego is one of BHS services, embraced by the county. The County’s overarching vision for a region that is building better health, living safely, and thriving. The Live Well San Diego initiative brings together the County of San Diego, community partners and individuals and families to help improve the lives of all 3.2 million people living in the region.
source_proposal: Fentanyl and Protecting Public Health.docx

name: Harm Reduction Coalition of San Diego
description: The County of San Diego offers a network of healthcare providers, mental health clinicians, activists, and members of the community who support harm reduction policies. These policies include syringe exchange and supplying Narcan, first aid supplies, contraceptives, and other products that help the community. This organization operates all throughout San Diego County on a needs-based distribution model.
source_proposal: Fentanyl and Protecting Public Health.docx

name: Syringe Services Program (SSP)
description: The Family Health Centers of San Diego offers comprehensive services to individuals who inject drugs. These services include solutions for recovery and clean syringes. This clinic has two locations; however, they operate throughout San Diego through their mobile SSP unit and telehealth appointments. Provide services from exchanging the syringe, case management, opioid safety education, harm reduction education, drug treatment, and detoxification. Treatment Resources
source_proposal: Fentanyl and Protecting Public Health.docx

name: A New Path
description: A New Path is one of many nonprofit organizations working to combat addictive illness in San Diego County. The organization originated from a sequence of preliminary meetings focused on Substance Abuse involving parents, Superior Court Judges, and officials from the criminal justice system during the Spring of 1999. The organization has created a structured and therapeutic treatment plan to help non-violent offenders in the San Diego region. A New Path creates recovery safe spaces and aims to educate staff, volunteers, and allies through shared stories of those affected by substance abuse.
source_proposal: Fentanyl and Protecting Public Health.docx

name: Father Joe’s Villages
description: Father Joe’s Villages focuses on the homeless population and their at-risk needs from serious illness, mental health issues, and substance use disorder. Father Joe’s Villages assists with diabetes, high blood pressure, smoking, COPD and other acute and chronic conditions. In addition to patients who want assistance with quitting the use of alcohol and substances (including heroin and other opioids). The services are individual counseling sessions and daily groups. Topics include: dealing with triggers, coping strategies, forming healthy relationships, building communication skills, and relapse prevention. These programs provide prescriptions to minimize withdrawals and cravings, catering to the rising need for treatment among those affected by the opioid crisis, including fentanyl addiction. Their operation was established in 1950 and has been serving San Diegans across the county since.
source_proposal: Fentanyl and Protecting Public Health.docx

name: Mcalister Institute
description: Since its inception in 1977, McAlister Institute has evolved into a major provider of alcohol and drug treatment in San Diego County. With over 40 years of dedicated service, their innovative and effective programs have aided numerous San Diegans in achieving drug-free, self-reliant, and healthy lives. Annually, they cater to over 13,000 individuals through our 24 diverse programs. These programs cover a comprehensive spectrum of care, including prevention, outreach, intervention, deferred entry, outpatient and inpatient treatments, and sober living facilities.
source_proposal: Fentanyl and Protecting Public Health.docx

name: True Life Center
description: True Life Center's Fentanyl Rehab Program offers a holistic and personalized approach to recovery for individuals struggling with fentanyl addiction. Their program in San Diego is tailored to meet the distinct needs of each patient, ensuring effective and comprehensive treatment. Their services include neurobiological integration, intensive outpatient program (IOP), partial hospitalization program (PHP) and a dual diagnosis/co-occurring disorders treatment. Academic Resources
source_proposal: Fentanyl and Protecting Public Health.docx

name: The San Diego Opioid Project
description: The mission statement of the San Diego Opioid Project, “Action against the epidemic,” describes their philosophy on the subject. This organization offers resources on the subject of the opioid crisis. Their innovative campaign aims to educate the public, with a specific focus on debunking misconceptions about the 'safe' abuse of prescription opioids and the dangers associated with them. The campaign also highlights the risks of overdose and the prevalence of pills laced with substances such as fentanyl. Finally, to further amplify the campaign and provide valuable information and resources, the Health and Human Services Agency and the District Attorney’s Office organize Town Hall Meetings across the county.
source_proposal: Fentanyl and Protecting Public Health.docx

name: UC San Diego Health Center
description: Researchers at the UC San Diego School of Medicine, along with San Diego State University (SDSU) and international collaborators, have developed a prediction model to identify counties at risk of future overdose death outbreaks. This open-source tool aims to predict and prevent deaths by enabling the early deployment of public health resources. Researchers have also explored the opioid epidemic through the rise in fentanyl-related overdoses. The research focuses on understanding the patterns of fatal overdoses due to prescription opioids, heroin, and highly potent synthetic opioids like fentanyl. The goal is to develop tools for predicting and preventing overdose deaths. Finally, UC San Diego's Health Promotion Services launched a campus-wide naloxone distribution zone, providing naloxone nasal spray and fentanyl test strips for pick-up at the Student Health Services building. This initiative aims to address the significant impact of fentanyl on drug overdoses and its lethal potency, even in small amounts.
source_proposal: Fentanyl and Protecting Public Health.docx

name: San Diego Unified School District
description: The San Diego Unified School District has a total of 226 educational facilities. These include 117 traditional elementary schools, 9 K-8 schools, 24 traditional middle schools, 22 high schools, 49 charter schools, 13 atypical/alternative schools, and 5 additional program sites. In this district, they provide resources to raise awareness on the fentanyl crisis. Schools are prepared to respond if an overdose occurs on campus. All San Diego Unified schools are equipped with two doses of naloxone, a medication that reverses an opioid overdose, and has at least three staff members trained in how to administer it. Additionally, all San Diego Unified school police carry naloxone and are trained to administer the life-saving medication. The district hosts webinars for families to hear from local experts and discuss the dangers of fentanyl. Panelists have included public health officials, board-certified physicians, community task force officials and testimonials from local families who have lost a child to a fentanyl overdose. Media Resources
source_proposal: Fentanyl and Protecting Public Health.docx

name: Freelance reporter Lynn Walsh, Voice of San Diego.
description: Launched in 2005, Voice of San Diego was the first digital, nonprofit news organization in the country to serve a local community. Its founders, longtime columnist and editor Neil Morgan and entrepreneur Buzz Woolley, felt the region desperately needed more reporting, analysis and journalistic competition. VOSD made a name for itself by producing hard-hitting investigative reports along with civic engagement opportunities that gave San Diego residents a new platform to discuss and debate the issues that impact their quality of life, becoming a pioneer in the nonprofit news industry through building a sustainable business model based on the support of individual members, sponsors and the investment of local and national foundations. Lynn Walsh is an Emmy award-winning freelance journalist who has worked in investigative, data and TV journalism at the national level as well as locally in California, Ohio, Texas and Florida. She produces content focused on government accountability, public access to information and freedom of expression issues. She’s also helping to rebuild trust between newsrooms and the public through the Trusting News project.
source_proposal: Fentanyl and Protecting Public Health.docx

name: Society of Professional Journalists
description: The Society of Professional Journalists (SPJ) is a professional organization that includes broadcast, print and online journalists, journalism educators, and students interested in journalism as a career. Among other things, SPJ works to protect the First Amendment guarantees of freedom of speech and of the press, to stimulate high standards and ethical behavior in the practice of journalism, to foster excellence among journalists, and to be the pre-eminent, broad-based membership organization for journalists.
source_proposal: Fentanyl and Protecting Public Health.docx

name: Times of San Diego
description: Times of San Diego is a nonprofit news site that captures news coverage within San Diego County. As local media becomes more divided among specialized topics and paywalled sites, this outlet serves this unique community with timely, comprehensive news that’s accessible to everyone. Times of San Diego’s promise is to be both comprehensive — with every local story that matters — and quick, with daily news in brief, easy-to-read formats. If news affects San Diegans, whether it’s from Tijuana, Sacramento, Washington or overseas, the site taps into it. The newsroom covers politics and crime, business and sports, education and arts, military and science, and health and life. It partners with other news sources to deliver in-depth news on topics that matter to San Diego. _______________________________ Cultural Activities Border Tour SDDC can arrange a half-day tour of the U.S.-Mexico border, with a guide familiar with border operations, policy, and issues. name: Casa Cornelia Law Center
description: Casa Cornelia Law Center is a public interest law firm providing quality legal services to victims of human and civil rights violations. It seeks to educate others regarding the impact of immigration law and policy on the community and the public good. Since 1993, more than 15,000 children, women, and men have turned to Casa Cornelia for critical legal assistance and humanitarian protection. Casa Cornelia is the only non-profit law firm in San Diego County to provide free legal services to detained unaccompanied children
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: Engage San Diego
description: Engage San Diego is a collaborative network of social-justice focused, non-profit groups working to increase civic and voter engagement in historically and systemically excluded communities of San Diego County. Engage San Diego table members are established and effective civic engagement and social change organizations with deep roots in the neighborhoods they serve. Its vision is a San Diego where the electorate and leadership are reflective of people who live and work here.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: Mid-City CAN Advocacy Network
description: Mid-City CAN's mission is to create a safe, productive, and healthy community through collaboration, advocacy, and organizing. They work with residents and partners to drive positive change across many systems and issues rather than coming in as an outside force. They hold events open to the public, training to foster growth, and have a Youth Council to inspire and prepare youth to take a more active role in their communities.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: Viet Vote
description: Viet Vote is dedicated to bringing all the information about voting to the Vietnamese community. They are a non-profit, non-partisan organization and therefore do not take a position on candidates. They share information about how and where to vote but not who to vote for. They come together to build community voice, leaders, and meaningful relationships through civic engagement, partnerships, trainings, and events.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: PANA - Partnership for the Advancement of New Americans
description: PANA fights to advance the full economic, social & civic inclusion of refugees in the San Diego region, throughout California, and across the country. PANA is founded, led, and staffed by refugees and are uniquely situated to use relational organizing to bring community into a pathway of ongoing engagement and indigenous community leadership development. Government Resources
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: City of San Diego Human Relations Commission
description: The mission of the Human Relations Commission (HRC) is to promote activities that foster understanding, respect, and inclusion in San Diego. The HRC believes in protecting basic Human and Civil Rights, while ensuring that San Diegans have the resources available to make positive impacts in their lives. The HRC is comprised of some of the region's most talented and community-focused volunteers that San Diego has to offer. As an advisory commission to the Mayor and City Council, the HRC is empowered to collaborate with civic institutions, educate the public, investigate policy to make our city better, advocate on issues to the Mayor and Council, and mediate disputes of discrimination, exclusion, and bias in the City of San Diego. Roundtable Discussion
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: Leon L. Williams San Diego County Human Relations Commission
description: The San Diego County Human Relations Commission (HRC) works to promote positive human relations, respect, and the integrity of every individual regardless of gender, religion, culture, ethnicity, sexual orientation, age, or citizenship status. They carry this work out through strategic goals including fostering healthy relationships, how to become a liaison in civil peace, communicating with and to the public, and more. Their goals and strategic areas aim to increase accessibility and transparency in county government to make better use of resources for community advocacy. They are also working to create safe spaces for the community to host difficult conversations to promote positive human relations and development. Adeem Ismaeil, Employment Training Supervisor, International Rescue Committee San Diego County HRC Member The International Rescue Committee helps people affected by humanitarian crises to survive, recover, and rebuild their lives. As Employment Training Supervisor, Adeem is responsible for supporting new Americans in their search for suitable employment, and ensuring that they receive adequate training to enter the workforce. She will predominantly join this conversation as a representative of HRC. Jordan Harrison, Inclusion, Diversity & Equity Senior Manager, Vertex Pharmaceuticals San Diego County HRC Member https://www.jordanjharrison.com/ Jordan Harrison is an educator working to transform antiqued systems and the inequities that stem from injustice. He is committed to changing the outcomes of low-income, underrepresented and first-generation students from under-served communities worldwide and across different contexts. Jordan will predominantly join this conversation as a representative of HRC.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: Diversity & Inclusion by County of San Diego
description: The County of San Diego's Office of Equity and Racial Justice is dedicated to fostering a community that values diversity, inclusivity, and equity. This department works to dismantle systemic racism and discrimination through strategic policies, practices, and initiatives that promote fair treatment and equal opportunities for all residents. By engaging with the community and addressing their unique needs, the office develops and implements programs that advance equity and justice. The department also collaborates with various stakeholders to ensure that diversity and inclusion are prioritized across all county operations.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: City of San Diego Department of Race and Equity
description: The Department of Race & Equity is grounded in the knowledge that institutional racism, implicit and explicit bias, inequity and injustice are embedded in the systems and structures of government. In the United States, these centuries-long systems of oppression are rooted in white supremacy and anti-Blackness, creating structural disparities that we wrestle with today. The department aims to dismantle institutional racism because racial disparities permeate our current systems of Health, Education, Criminal Justice, Workforce, and Housing – just to name a few. This requires an intersectional lens to address the interconnected oppressions that compound disparities, which occur across the lines of race, ethnicity, gender, sexual orientation, people with disabilities, age, etc. The department's aim is to redesign current systems that are intentionally structured to produce inequitable outcomes, and to collectively build better ones that promote the thriving of all people and neighborhoods in San Diego.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: City of San Diego Committee for Diversity & Inclusion
description: The San Diego City Attorney’s Diversity and Inclusion Committee is dedicated to promoting an inclusive and equitable workplace within the City Attorney’s Office. The committee actively works to foster diversity, eliminate bias, and ensure that all employees have the opportunity to succeed and thrive. Through various initiatives, including training programs, community engagement efforts, and internal policies, the committee strives to create a supportive and welcoming environment that reflects the rich diversity of San Diego's community. Their commitment to diversity and inclusion enhances the office's ability to serve all residents effectively. Integration & Community-Building Resources
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: Union of Pan Asian Communities (UPAC)
description: The Union of Pan Asian Communities (UPAC) is a 501c3 non-profit that provides health and human services focused on improving the overall well-being of underserved diverse populations. Providing assistance in over 30 languages at 15 locations across the county, UPAC recognizes and celebrates the diversity of our region and strives to strengthen these communities to achieve self-sufficiency. Programs focus on mental health counseling, community engagement and business development, addiction treatment & recovery, housing counseling, health promotion and cultural competency education.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: San Diego Gateway to College and Career, San Diego Workforce Partnership
description: The San Diego Gateway to College and Career program provides young adults who identify as immigrant, refugee and/or English language learner (ELL) with high-touch and intensive support, stipends and paid internships. Recognizing the strength of your diverse ethnicities and languages, students are also supported to achieve their language learning goals, no matter what language you speak. This program offers help in removing barriers to success, finding what career is right, finding a long-term job, starting school, and learning new job skills.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: Interfaith Committee for Worker Justice (IWJ) of San Diego County
description: IWJSD is an afiliate of Interfaith Worker Justice (IWJ), a national network that builds collective power by advancing the rights of workers through unions, worker centers, and other expressions of the labor movement and by engaging diverse faith communities and allies in joint action, from grassroots organizing to shaping policy at the local, state and national levels. The mission of IWJSD aims to advocate, educate, and empower workers, congregations, and communities in support of policies, legislation, and actions that sustain workers' lives with dignity.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: PANA - Partnership for the Advancement of New Americans
description: PANA fights to advance the full economic, social & civic inclusion of refugees in the San Diego region, throughout California, and across the country. A research, public policy, and community organizing hub, PANA is founded, led, and staffed by refugees and is uniquely situated to use relational organizing to bring the community into a pathway of ongoing engagement and indigenous community leadership development.

source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: San Diego Immigrants' Rights Consortium
description: The San Diego Immigrant Rights Consortium brings together more than 50 diverse organizations across San Diego County that advocate for policies that advance the civil and human rights of immigrants and refugees. Beginning in 2007 as a project of Alliance San Diego, this organization aims to support comprehensive immigration reform, prevent the spread of local policies that violate immigrant's human rights, and to educate immigrants about their rights, as well as enlighten the public about the important contributions immigrants offer to the community.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: Community Advocates for Just and Moral Governance (MoGo)
description: Community Advocates for Just and Moral Governance (MoGo) promotes good governance. MoGo is committed to engaging in litigation and various forms of advocacy that will make government more just and fully accountable to all people, particularly those who have been marginalized from society. MoGo was founded by two Black women lawyers who have dedicated their lives and careers to secure racial equality, social justice, and greater access to quality education. Current MoGo campaigns include: stopping discriminatory policing practices against Black people, Indigenous people, people of color, LGBTQ individuals, and individuals with disabilities; protecting San Diegans' fourth amendment rights in regard to transparent and responsible use of surveillance technology in San Diego; and working to bring ranked choice voting to San Diego to improve voter turnout.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: MAKE Projects
description: MAKE Projects mission is to create an inclusive San Diego by preparing refugees and immigrants to achieve their dreams. They are an employment social enterprise where they operate an urban farm, restaurant, and events/catering company to provide a paid, real-world work experience for low-income refugee and immigrant women and youth. They aim to provide trainees with job readiness skills to help them achieve their dreams. MAKE Projects vision is to see San Diegans cross social, racial, economic, and geographic lines as they gather over a common love of food, flavors, and cultures. They believe in the power of food to bring diverse populations together, unite a community, and educate each other about their history and differences, as well as their communities.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: The Arc San Diego
description: The Arc of San Diego is the largest, most comprehensive provider of services for people with disabilities in San Diego County. The organization was founded in 1951 by parents and other community members who were concerned about the lack of services available for people with disabilities and their families. The Arc San Diego provides services for people with disabilities at more than 20 locations throughout the county. Through the programs, the Arc San Diego is able to offer support to people with disabilities in living independent and fulfilling lives. Non-Profit Organizations
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

description: Engage San Diego is a collaborative network of social-justice focused, non-profit groups working to increase civic and voter engagement in historically and systemically excluded communities of San Diego County. They envision a San Diego where the electorate and leadership are reflective of the community.

name: Alliance San Diego
description: Alliance San Diego is a non-profit, non-partisan 501(c)(3) community organization whose mission is to provide a means for diverse individuals and organizations to share information, collaborate on issues and mobilize for change in the pursuit of social justice, especially in low-income communities and communities of color. They seek to mobilize communities through: leadership development, policy advocacy, communication strategies, and civic engagement. They focus on human rights, inclusive democracy, educational equity, and tax reform.
