name: Horn of Africa
description: Horn of Africa is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization promoting the successful integration and physical and emotional health of the East African refugee population in San Diego, the largest in California and the second-largest nationwide. Focused on In empowering African refugees in San Diego to become productive members of their new communities and achieve self-sufficiency while preserving and promoting their dignity.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: North San Diego County National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP)
description: Founded in 1909, the NAACP is the nation's oldest and largest civil rights organization. The NAACP's principal objective is to ensure the political, educational, social and economic equality of minority citizens of the United States and eliminate race prejudice. This mission is accomplished by seeking the enactment and enforcement of federal, state and local laws securing civil rights, and by informing the public of the adverse effects of racial discrimination. From school desegregation, fair housing, employment and voter registration to health and equal economic opportunity, the NAACP is working successfully with allies of all races and plays a significant role in establishing legal precedents in order to improve the quality of life of America's downtrodden. LGBTQ+ Resources
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: The San Diego LGBT Community Center
description: The San Diego Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Transgender Community Center, Inc., (The Center) is one of the largest and most vibrant LGBTQ community centers in the nation. Functioning as the San Diego LGBTQ community's anchor organization, The Center provides targeted programs and services to the full diversity of the San Diego LGBTQ community, including lesbian, gay, bisexual, queer, transgender, nonbinary, immigrant, and HIV communities to the betterment of our entire San Diego region. Last year, The Center provided more than 80,000 direct service visits to San Diego community members, and through its events, activities, and advocacy, touched the lives of thousands more.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: San Diego Pride
description: https://sdpride.org/fernando-lopez/ San Diego Pride is a dynamic 501(c)3 non-profit organization that organizes the annual San Diego Pride parade, provides LGBTQ+ educational training, and offers LGBTQ+ programs in a variety of areas including sports, youth, art, and accessibility. Their mission is to foster pride, equality, and respect for all lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender communities locally, nationally, and globally. In addition to their annual festivities, San Diego Pride has donated more than $3 million dollars to LGBTQ-serving nonprofits and runs multiple year-round education, advocacy, and community service programs. They also offer training on cultural humility, inclusivity and skills, and provide resources for the community to remain civically active. Fernando Zweifach López Ir is the Executive Director for San Diego LGBT Pride, and a local leader with extensive experience in advocacy, nonprofit management, public education, diversity consulting, media relations, and organizing. Meeting focus: Discuss San Diego Pride's impact on the region and their international outreach to further
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: LGBTQ+ rights globally.
url: San Diego Unified School District - OUT for Safe Schools https://www.sandiegounified.org/a-to-_z_index/lgbtqia/out_for_safe_schools
description: San Diego Unified School District is participating in the National OUT for Safe Schools campaign, along with nine other large urban school districts across the country. This program was created as a way to encourage school staff to publicly identify as supportive LGBTQIA allies. This visual display of support lets students know that " safe spaces" exist anywhere there is an adult who is wearing this badge. This campaign is designed to create safe spaces and resources for LGBTQIA students, staff and parents, and also to foster an inclusive community for all students to celebrate all identities. Possible Volunteer Activities
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: Beach Cleanup with San Diego Coast Keeper
description: San Diego local beaches are protected by volunteers. Coast Keeper will welcome you to a fun day in the sand with family, friends, and new acquaintances while removing trash and raising awareness about plastic pollution. Take action to protect the environment by removing trash from our coastline. In addition to cleaning the beach, Surfrider can use the data you collect to influence laws that reduce pollution at the source!
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: Foundry Thursday Food Distribution By Foundry Community Church
description: Prepare bags of fresh produce and dry goods to help fight food insecurity within our community.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: Food Distribution with We All We Got San Diego
description: Volunteers help pack food into bags and hand out food in the park. Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: Chicano Park
description: Chicano Park is the geographic and emotional heart of Barrio Logan, located in Logan Heights, San Diego's oldest Mexican-American neighborhood. The park is home to the largest concentration of Chicano murals in the world with more than 80 paintings on seven acres dotted with sculpture, gardens, picnic tables, and playgrounds. Throughout the year, it hosts festivals of music and Aztec dance, the biggest being Chicano Park Day held each April. Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $30 for one Adult Ticket for a one-hour narrated tour (south bay or north bay routes); $35 for a full bay two-hour narrated tour which covers it all: ships of the Maritime Museum, Harbor and Shelter Islands, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and more. The full bay tour is about 25 miles in length. Accessibility: The tour begins and ends at the same location downtown along Broadway Pier. Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com Price: $44 for a 1-Day Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased online) For 30 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours, highlighting the best San Diego attractions. The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50 am – 5:00 pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $26 for one Adult General Admission Ticket ($1 discount when purchased on-line). Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom, and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10 am – 5 pm (Last admission at 4 pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside the Navy Pier.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: Border Field State Park & Friendship Park
description: https://www.friendshippark.org/ Located within the Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve, Border Field State Park sits in the very southwestern corner of the United States, 15 miles south of San Diego. This important wildlife habitat, consisting of sand dunes and salt marshes, gives refuge to critically threatened and endangered birds such as the Western Snowy Plover, the California Least Tern, and the Light-footed Ridgway's Rail. Friendship Park is a binational park located at the western end of the US-Mexico border. For generations, people have gathered here to meet up with friends and family "across the line." Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 17 major museums and cultural institutions, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens, and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: Coronado
description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year-round due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown. SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $99.99 for one Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased online) Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Orca Encounter, Dolphin Days, and Sea Lions Live shows and thrilling rides like Electric Eel, Manta, and Journey To Atlantis. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks, and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Hours vary by season. Also enjoy the opening of Sesame Place in March 2022, a Sesame Street-themed section of the park with new water, ride, and musical attractions. Accessibility: A 15-20-minute drive from downtown San Diego.
source_proposal: Human and Civil Rights for Marginalized Communities.docx

name: Port of San Diego – Maritime Trade & Logistics Division
description: The Port of San Diego manages over 3 million metric tons of cargo annually and serves as a central node for Pacific Rim trade. As a self-funded agency, the Port has invested over $100 million in recent years to modernize its Tenth Avenue Marine Terminal, adding specialized refrigerated storage for perishable imports and new cranes to improve bulk cargo handling. The Port operates both breakbulk and Ro/Ro (roll-on/roll-off) terminals and manages one of the largest auto import facilities on the West Coast, moving over 400,000 vehicles each year. In addition to cargo operations, the Port leads sustainability initiatives like the Clean Air Program and shore power systems to reduce vessel emissions while docked. The Port also partners with U.S. Customs to pilot new electronic manifest systems that speed up processing times. For small Pacific nations looking to streamline imports and expand cold chain capacity, San Diego’s integrated approach offers practical models.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Accelerating Shipping & Supply Chains in the Pacific.docx

name: City of San Diego – Foreign Trade Zone (FTZ) #153
description: FTZ #153 covers over 2,000 acres of designated trade area across San Diego, including facilities adjacent to the Port, the airport, and major industrial parks. Companies operating within the zone can defer or eliminate import duties, consolidate shipments, and store inventory duty-free until goods enter domestic commerce. In 2023 alone, the FTZ facilitated the movement of over $1.3 billion in merchandise, supporting sectors such as electronics, medical devices, and perishable food products. The City of San Diego provides technical assistance to help companies apply for FTZ status, navigate customs requirements, and integrate FTZ processes with their existing supply chain. For Pacific Island economies facing high logistics costs, understanding FTZ structures offers concrete ideas for reducing landed costs and improving competitiveness. .
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Accelerating Shipping & Supply Chains in the Pacific.docx

name: San Diego World Trade Center
description: World Trade Center San Diego is the region’s trade development agency and a strategic affiliate of the San Diego Regional Economic Development Corporation. The WTC helps local companies expand into global markets by offering export readiness assessments, compliance training, and introductions to overseas buyers and logistics providers. The MetroConnect export accelerator, WTC’s flagship program, has helped over 80 companies expand sales into Asia-Pacific markets, resulting in millions of dollars in new export contracts. WTC also collaborates with customs brokers, freight forwarders, and the Port to ensure small exporters can access affordable shipping and navigate complex regulations.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Accelerating Shipping & Supply Chains in the Pacific.docx

name: SANDAG – Freight Stakeholders Taskforce and Sustainable Freight Planning
description: SANDAG is the regional planning agency responsible for designing and coordinating San Diego’s transportation systems. One of SANDAG’s core missions is to create safe, clean, and economically competitive strategies for moving goods throughout the region and across the U.S.–Mexico border. The San Diego region features a complex logistics network that includes deep-water ports, highways, Class I railroads, international airports, and cross-border pipelines. name: San Diego Regional Economic Development Corporation (EDC)
description: The San Diego Regional EDC is a nonprofit, independently funded organization that brings together business, government, and education leaders to drive inclusive economic growth. EDC plays a critical role in shaping regional strategy to position San Diego as a global hub for innovation, trade, and workforce development. The organization promotes international investment, facilitates the expansion of local firms into overseas markets, and advocates for policy and infrastructure that support long-term economic resilience. EDC’s signature initiatives include talent pipeline development, cross-border economic integration with Baja California, and supporting high-growth sectors such as defense tech, life sciences, and clean energy. It also runs programs aimed at helping small and medium enterprises (SMEs) prepare for export and global expansion, often in partnership with state and federal agencies
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Advancing Economic Prosperity.docx

name: Smart Border Coalition
description: The Smart Border Coalition (SBC) is a binational nonprofit based in San Diego that works to improve trade, mobility, and public policy across the U.S.-Mexico border region. Founded in 2007, the coalition brings together stakeholders from government, academia, the private sector, and civil society to identify and implement actionable solutions to cross-border challenges. SBC’s initiatives focus on modernizing ports of entry, reducing border wait times, and improving coordination between customs, transportation agencies, and logistics companies. With a special emphasis on the San Diego–Tijuana region—one of the busiest land-border crossings in the world—the coalition is a key player in strengthening supply chains, cross-border labor markets, and binational investment flows.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Advancing Economic Prosperity.docx

name: Connect San Diego
description: Connect is a nonprofit organization that supports the growth of San Diego’s innovation economy by accelerating the development of early-stage companies in high-tech and life sciences sectors. With a legacy dating back to the 1980s, Connect has helped launch over 3,000 startups and remains a national model for public-private innovation collaboration. The organization provides entrepreneurs with mentorship, business development training, access to venture capital, and pathways to commercialization. Its programs focus on technology transfer from research institutions, building investor networks, and supporting the business scalability of founders in fields like AI, digital health, and green tech.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Advancing Economic Prosperity.docx

name: Port of San Diego – Maritime Trade & Logistics Division
description: The Port of San Diego is one of the primary economic engines of the California coast, managing a diverse portfolio that includes maritime trade, cargo terminals, shipbuilding and repair, cruise tourism, and waterfront real estate. As a self-funded public agency, the Port plays a pivotal role in facilitating global commerce while investing in infrastructure that enhances regional competitiveness. Its maritime division oversees two major cargo terminals and serves as a vital gateway for import/export operations in the Pacific Rim, handling goods such as automobiles, perishables, construction materials, and project cargo. The Port also collaborates with U.S. Customs and Border Protection, environmental regulators, and international partners to modernize supply chains and promote sustainable shipping practices.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Advancing Economic Prosperity.docx

name: University of California San Diego – Office of Innovation and Commercialization (OIC)
description: UC San Diego is ranked among the world’s top public research universities and is a leader in innovation-driven economic development. Its Office of Innovation and Commercialization (OIC) serves as the university’s primary unit for advancing technology transfer, industry collaboration, and global partnerships. The OIC works with researchers and entrepreneurs to move discoveries from the lab to the marketplace through licensing, startup formation, and corporate engagement. With a portfolio that spans biotech, software, clean energy, and advanced materials, UCSD innovations generate patents and companies that impact global industries. Notably, OIC also collaborates with international institutions and incubators to build inclusive innovation ecosystems.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Advancing Economic Prosperity.docx

name: San Diego Regional Policy & Innovation Center
description: The San Diego Regional Policy & Innovation Center is a nonprofit think tank and action hub focused on improving the region’s economic resilience and equity through data-driven policy and investment strategies. It works closely with city and county governments, philanthropic partners, and research institutions to craft solutions to major socioeconomic challenges. Key focus areas include infrastructure development, workforce pipelines, climate resilience, and equitable access to capital and public services. The Center plays a catalytic role in positioning San Diego to compete for federal and state recovery funds, especially those supporting underserved communities and inclusive economic growth.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Advancing Economic Prosperity.docx

name: Rady School of Management – UC San Diego
description: The Rady School of Management is a graduate business school within UC San Diego that offers MBA and executive education programs focused on innovation, entrepreneurship, and global business leadership. Rady’s curriculum integrates real-world business challenges with cutting-edge academic research, preparing students to lead across diverse industries. The school partners with startups, multinational corporations, and government agencies to deliver hands-on learning in areas such as global supply chain management, digital transformation, and strategic innovation. Its Center for Social Innovation and Impact plays a key role in shaping policy discussions on global development and sustainability.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Advancing Economic Prosperity.docx

name: San Diego & Imperial Small Business Development Center (SBDC)
description: The San Diego & Imperial SBDC Network is a regional branch of the nationwide Small Business Development Center program, supported by the U.S. Small Business Administration. It offers no-cost advising, training, and funding assistance to entrepreneurs and small businesses across Southern California. The SBDC supports startups and established firms in navigating challenges related to business planning, market expansion, digital transformation, government contracting, and international trade. Its programs are especially targeted toward women, minority, and veteran entrepreneurs, with a focus on building economic resilience through access to capital and global business development. Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown). Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $30 for one Adult Ticket for a one-hour narrated tour (south bay or north bay routes); $35 for a full bay two-hour narrated tour which covers it all: ships of the Maritime Museum, Harbor and Shelter Islands, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and more. The full bay tour is about 25 miles in length. Accessibility: The tour begins and ends at the same location downtown along Broadway Pier. Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com Price: $44 for a 1-Day Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) For 30 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours, highlighting the best San Diego attractions. The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50am – 5:00pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $26 for one Adult General Admission Ticket ($1 discount when purchased on-line). Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10am – 5pm (Last admission at 4pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside Navy Pier. Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 17 major museums and cultural institutions, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Advancing Economic Prosperity.docx

name: Coronado
description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year around due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown. SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $99.99 for one Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) Accessibility: A 15-20-minute drive from downtown San Diego. Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Orca Encounter, Dolphin Days, and Sea Lions Live shows and thrilling rides like Electric Eel, Manta, and Journey To Atlantis. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Hours vary by season.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Advancing Economic Prosperity.docx

name: San Diego Police Department – Community Engagement Division
description: The SDPD’s Community Engagement Division promotes trust-based policing strategies through youth outreach, neighborhood watch, and violence de-escalation training. Officers engage directly with communities of color, immigrant populations, and religious organizations to prevent the marginalization that can lead to extremism. The department has received national recognition for its refugee community outreach efforts and gang diversion partnerships.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Community Strategies to Counter Violent Extremism.docx

name: San Diego County Probation Department – Reentry Services Division
description: This department coordinates reentry programs for justice-involved individuals, focusing on rehabilitation and reintegration to reduce recidivism and prevent radicalization in and after incarceration. Programs include anger management, substance recovery, vocational training, and mental health counseling. Academic Resources
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Community Strategies to Counter Violent Extremism.docx

name: University of San Diego – Joan B. Kroc Institute for Peace and Justice
description: This academic institute conducts global and domestic programming in peacemaking, conflict resolution, and extremism prevention. Their "Building Trust Partnership" works with San Diego law enforcement and community members to improve public safety through racial equity and trust-building. Non-Profit Resources
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Community Strategies to Counter Violent Extremism.docx

name: Youth Empowerment – Project AWARE (SAY San Diego)
description: Funded by the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA), Project AWARE provides culturally competent mental health services, family outreach, and violence prevention programs in San Diego schools. SAY San Diego also engages in community-wide violence interruption initiatives.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Community Strategies to Counter Violent Extremism.docx

name: Logan Heights CDC – Youth Development and Gang Prevention
description: Located in one of San Diego’s historically underserved communities, Logan Heights CDC operates youth empowerment and gang prevention programs that emphasize leadership, civic identity, and violence resilience. The center partners with local schools, probation officers, and families.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Community Strategies to Counter Violent Extremism.docx

name: Mid-City CAN – Youth Council & Violence Prevention Network
description: Mid-City CAN convenes youth councils and community safety networks focused on violence prevention, restorative justice, and policy advocacy. Their Youth Council trains young leaders in mediation, anti-racism, and systems change.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Community Strategies to Counter Violent Extremism.docx

name: Interfaith Shelter Network of San Diego
description: This coalition of over 100 congregations provides transitional housing and social services to vulnerable populations, including refugees and formerly incarcerated individuals. The network promotes interfaith collaboration as a tool for trauma healing and violence prevention.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Community Strategies to Counter Violent Extremism.docx

name: Alliance San Diego
description: Alliance San Diego is a multi-ethnic, community-based organization that promotes justice and inclusion through civic engagement, human rights advocacy, and leadership training. They address issues of hate-based violence, civil liberties, and law enforcement reform.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Community Strategies to Counter Violent Extremism.docx

name: Pillars of the Community
description: Pillars of the Community work in historically over-policed neighborhoods to build community-led alternatives to incarceration and violence. Their programs include faith-based dialogue, gang intervention, and narrative-change media that counters stigma around justice-involved individuals. name: U.S. Naval Base San Diego
description: The Port Naval Base San Diego is the U.S. Navy’s largest base on the West Coast and the homeport of the Pacific Fleet’s surface ships. The base spans more than 1,600 acres of land and water and hosts over 50 ships and submarines, 200 tenant commands, and more than 25,000 military and civilian personnel. Units stationed here deploy regularly to the Indo-Pacific to conduct freedom of navigation operations, joint exercises with allies, and humanitarian assistance missions. The installation is central to U.S. strategy for deterring aggression, maintaining maritime domain awareness, and responding to crises in the region.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Maritime Policy and Security Coordination.docx

name: U.S. Coast Guard Sector San Diego
description: Sector San Diego oversees all Coast Guard operations from the U.S.–Mexico border north to San Mateo Point and out to 200 nautical miles offshore. With approximately 400 active-duty personnel, the Sector executes missions including maritime law enforcement, port security, counter-drug operations, fisheries enforcement, and environmental protection. Sector San Diego is also home to small boat stations, cutters, and air units that conduct search and rescue and coordinate with Customs and Border Protection and Mexican authorities. These capabilities play an essential role in countering transnational crime and securing maritime infrastructure.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Maritime Policy and Security Coordination.docx

name: Naval Information Warfare Systems Command (NAVWAR)
description: NAVWAR, headquartered in San Diego, is the Navy’s lead organization for developing and deploying information warfare systems that enable secure communications, cyber defense, and real-time decision-making across the fleet. NAVWAR’s portfolio includes tactical networks, unmanned maritime systems, and advanced cybersecurity tools designed to protect critical infrastructure against state and non-state threats. NAVWAR is also deeply involved in developing technologies that underpin integrated deterrence strategies in the Indo-Pacific. Their work represents the forefront of maritime cybersecurity innovation and the convergence of data, networks, and combat readiness.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Maritime Policy and Security Coordination.docx

name: San Diego Harbor Police Department
description: The Harbor Police Department provides comprehensive public safety services on San Diego Bay, including maritime law enforcement, counterterrorism patrols, vessel inspections, and marine firefighting. As the primary law enforcement agency for the Port of San Diego, Harbor Police coordinate closely with federal partners to secure critical facilities, monitor port activity, and respond to incidents ranging from smuggling to environmental hazards. The department’s Maritime Tactical Team is trained in SWAT tactics and homeland security operations, highlighting how local agencies support national security objectives. Academic Resources
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Maritime Policy and Security Coordination.docx

name: The University of California Institute on Global Conflict and Cooperation (IGCC)
description: The UC Institute on Global Conflict and Cooperation (IGCC) is a network of researchers from across the University of California and the Los Alamos and Lawrence Livermore national labs who produce and use research to help build a more peaceful, prosperous world. We conduct rigorous social science research on international security, the environment, geoeconomics, nuclear security, and the future of democracy; help to educate and train the next generation of peacemakers; and strive to ensure that what we are discovering contributes to a safer world.  The Institute is based at the School of Global Policy and Strategy at UC San Diego, where several members of the leadership team and a number of researchers are on the faculty. Dr. Tai Ming Cheung, Director Tai Ming Cheung is director of the University of California Institute on Global Conflict and Cooperation and a professor at the School of Global Policy and Strategy at UC San Diego, where he teaches courses on the international relations and national security of China and Chinese security and technology policy. Among the areas of his research focus include China’s efforts to become a world-class science and technology power, and the relationship between geo-economics, innovation, and national security. Dr. Cheung is a long-time analyst of Chinese and East Asian defense and national security affairs, especially defense economic, industrial and science, and technological issues.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Maritime Policy and Security Coordination.docx

name: Vice Admiral Charles Martoglio, U.S. Navy (retired); lecturer, UCSD School of Global Policy & Strategy
description: Vice Admiral Charles W. Martoglio, U.S. Navy (ret), is a lecturer at the School of Global Policy and Strategy at UC San Diego. Drawing on his extensive background leading large elements of our U.S. military, VADM Martoglio’s focus is on national security affairs and leadership. He spent about half of his military career in the U.S. Navy at sea in cruisers, destroyers and aircraft carriers. VADM Martoglio spent the other half of his career developing strategy and policy, fostering international relations, and conducting operations, initially for the U.S. Navy then for all U.S. military forces. VADM Martoglio is recognized as one of the Defense Department’s preeminent strategic thinkers, with proven expertise in contingency planning, international relations and operations execution. He has served in Asia, the Middle East, and, most recently, in Europe as the Deputy Commander of all U.S. military forces in Europe, Eurasia and Israel. In various capacities he has developed the U.S. Navy’s Strategic Plan, led security-related organizations through significant change, headed the planning effort for some of our nation’s most complex contingency plans, and has overseen the integration of the U.S. Government Interagency into Defense Department operations in both Asia and Europe.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Maritime Policy and Security Coordination.docx

name: Training Resources Maritime Institute
description: Training Resources Maritime Institute is a leading maritime training facility accredited by the U.S. Coast Guard to deliver more than 80 courses covering navigation, shipboard safety, regulatory compliance, and crisis response. TRLMI annually trains over 4,000 mariners including commercial vessel operators, military personnel, and law enforcement agencies. Their instructors bring decades of operational experience, and the curriculum emphasizes best practices that align with U.S. and international maritime regulations. Non-Profit Resources
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Maritime Policy and Security Coordination.docx

name: TMA BlueTech
description: TMA BlueTech is San Diego’s non-profit ocean technology cluster dedicated to growing “Blue Economy” innovation. The association supports the development of technologies, including autonomous maritime systems, cybersecurity platforms, and ocean data collection tools. TMA BlueTech convenes partnerships among startups, defense contractors, research institutions, and policymakers to accelerate solutions that improve maritime security and sustainability. Through advocacy and international collaboration, TMA also contributes to policy frameworks supporting safe and resilient oceans.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Maritime Policy and Security Coordination.docx

name: World Trade Center San Diego
description: World Trade Center San Diego, an affiliate of San Diego Regional Economic Development Corporation, (WTCSD) is Southern California’s leading international trade association with direct access to the largest international trade network in the world. The organization offers the San Diego region services that allow businesses to gain key global contacts, research and tools to enhance international competitiveness. WTCSD provides comprehensive international business services and global lead-generation to facilitate and expand business internationally for regional clients. With services such as global data mining, intercultural communication training, market-entry strategies, export readiness evaluations, trade missions and export documentation and more, WTCSD helps businesses start or expand upon their international operations. Business Sector  Resources Port of San Diego www.portofsandiego.org The Port of San Diego is an economic engine, an environmental steward of San Diego Bay and the surrounding tidelands, and a provider of community services and public safety. The Port of San Diego is a self-supporting public-benefit corporation established in 1962 by an act of the California State Legislature. The U.S. Bureau of Transportation Statistics has ranked the Port of San Diego as one of America's top 30 U.S. containership ports bringing in nearly 3,000,000 metric tons. The Port of San Diego has the heaviest lift capacity on the U.S. West Coast thanks to their electric cranes with a total lift capacity of 400 MT. Additionally, the Port of San Diego offers a Foreign Trade Zone, approved by U.S. Customs and Border Protection and the City of San Diego where foreign and domestic merchandise can be offloaded onto U.S. soil. Meeting focus: During a tour of the Port’s two main terminals, learn about port operations with a focus on exports and imports, use of a Foreign-Trade Zone (FTZ) site, and how the Port contributes to the international trade landscape, particularly as a gateway from the United States into Asia Pacific. name: Historic Preservation Planning- City of San Diego
description: The City of San Diego recognizes the benefits of historical resource preservation to the community as well as to individual property owners. Preservation efforts stabilize neighborhoods, promote cultural heritage tourism, and contribute to a vibrant, diverse and dynamic urban landscape, among other benefits. The City’s historic preservation program is responsible for the City’s long-term planning efforts, developing new ordinances and regulations, and implementing policies and regulations through permitting.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Preserving Cultural Heritage.docx

name: SANDAG Tribal Consultation
description: SANDAG maintains formal agreements with the Southern California Tribal Chairmen’s Association (SCTCA) to collaborate with the region’s 17 sovereign tribal nations. We are responsible for ensuring that our plans for the region protect tribal lands, culture, and resources throughout every stage of the process. For more than 20 years, collaboration efforts with the SCTCA and tribes in the San Diego region have continued and expanded through regular convenings such as quarterly Interagency Technical Working Group on Tribal Transportation Issues (Tribal TWG) and monthly Tribal Task Force meetings, Tribal Symposiums held jointly with the Borders Committee, and quadrennial Tribal Summits held jointly with the Board of Directors. These convenings provide multiple opportunities for meaningful collaboration for the future of the San Diego region.\
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Preserving Cultural Heritage.docx

name: U.S. Customs and Border Protection – San Diego Field Office
description: CBP plays a central role in identifying and intercepting illicit shipments of cultural property. At the San Diego Field Office, officers implement inspection protocols and collaborate with Homeland Security Investigations and INTERPOL to detect trafficked antiquities at border crossings and airports. Their work also supports repatriation efforts in coordination with foreign governments and U.S. museums.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Preserving Cultural Heritage.docx

name: San Diego Harbor Police Department – Criminal Investigations Division
description: The Harbor Police serve as both marine law enforcement and port security for San Diego Bay. Their investigations division coordinates with federal agencies on smuggling and trafficking cases, including cultural goods. The department also engages in public education campaigns to raise awareness about the illegal antiquities trade. Academic Resources
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Preserving Cultural Heritage.docx

name: San Diego State University – Anthropology Department and Cultural Resource Management Program
description: SDSU has a long-standing cultural resource management (CRM) program that partners with local, state, and tribal entities to survey, document, and protect Native American and historic archaeological sites. Faculty and graduate students actively engage in fieldwork across California and the Southwest, providing expertise in conservation policy, site documentation, and GIS mapping for preservation.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Preserving Cultural Heritage.docx

name: University of California, San Diego – Scripps Institution of Oceanography (Underwater Archaeology & Marine Heritage Program)
description: Scripps Institution of Oceanography supports underwater cultural heritage through technology-driven research. Their marine archaeology and seafloor mapping experts have worked on preserving shipwrecks, submerged prehistoric sites, and World War II-era cultural materials using sonar, remote vehicles, and 3D modeling. The lab also collaborates internationally on marine heritage policy.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Preserving Cultural Heritage.docx

name: University of San Diego- Digital Project
description: The San Diego Lowrider Archival Project documents the history of lowriding in San Diego and the surrounding borderlands, from the 1950s through today. The project includes photographs, car club documents and memorabilia, official records, meeting minutes, dance posters and lowrider art. These materials reflect important qualities of the lowrider movement: creativity, independence, cultural pride, resistance, activism, community service, collectivism, tradition and ritual, and cultural community. Non-Profit Resources
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Preserving Cultural Heritage.docx

name: San Diego Archaeology Center
description: The San Diego Archaeological Center is a nonprofit museum where visitors can learn the story of how people have lived in San Diego County for the past 12,000 years. In addition to its role as a museum, the Center serves as an education and research hub and is the primary organization dedicated to the collection, study, curation and exhibition of San Diego County’s archaeological artifacts. The mission of the center is to promote the importance of cultural resources through education and preserve them in partnership with Tribal and other communities. Meanwhile, sustaining an archaeological center where artifacts will not only be cared for in a state-of-the-art environment, but where scientific research can be facilitated and the public can enjoy learning about the prehistory and history of the San Diego region through educational programs and museum-quality exhibits.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Preserving Cultural Heritage.docx

name: Balboa Art Conservation Center
description: Since 1975, Balboa Art Conservation Center has been fulfilling its mission as a nonprofit art conservation and cultural preservation organization to provide conservation and preservation services for works of art, cultural objects, and historic artifacts. Our highly trained conservators offer a rigorous and scientific approach to the preservation, examination, and treatment of cultural heritage objects. Located in San Diego’s Balboa Park, BACC is committed to benefiting the public good by supporting training and education opportunities and partnering with stewards of community cultural collections. Through our programs and services, BACC is growing the existing knowledge base to include culturally conscious and responsive methods of conservation and preservation.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Preserving Cultural Heritage.docx

name: San Diego Museum of Man
description: Located in Balboa Park, the Museum of Us focuses on human culture and anthropology, with ongoing exhibits and dialogue centered on indigenous identity, colonialism, and repatriation. The museum has publicly addressed issues around ethical collecting, holding difficult conversations on provenance, and improving community trust through transparency and engagement.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Preserving Cultural Heritage.docx

name: Barona Cultural Center and Museum
description: The Barona Museum is a tribally operated institution that preserves and interprets the Kumeyaay-Diegueño culture of the Barona Band of Mission Indians. It houses carefully curated ethnographic and archaeological collections and provides educational programming on cultural preservation, language revitalization, and indigenous stewardship of sacred objects.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Preserving Cultural Heritage.docx

name: Save Our Heritage Organization
description: Through education, advocacy, and stewardship, SOHO's mission is to preserve, promote, and support preservation of the architectural, cultural and historical links and landmarks that contribute to the collective identity, depth, and character of our region. Since 1969, Save Our Heritage Organisation (SOHO), a nonprofit organization, has led the community as a powerful catalyst for preservation by raising awareness and appreciation of our region's architectural and cultural heritage. Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown). Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $30 for one Adult Ticket for a one-hour narrated tour (south bay or north bay routes); $35 for a full bay two-hour narrated tour which covers it all: ships of the Maritime Museum, Harbor and Shelter Islands, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and more. The full bay tour is about 25 miles in length. Accessibility: The tour begins and ends at the same location downtown along Broadway Pier. Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com Price: $44 for a 1-Day Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) For 30 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours, highlighting the best San Diego attractions. The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50am – 5:00pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $26 for one Adult General Admission Ticket ($1 discount when purchased on-line). Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10am – 5pm (Last admission at 4pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside Navy Pier. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).

name: Coronado
description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year around due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown. SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $99.99 for one Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) Accessibility: A 15-20-minute drive from downtown San Diego. Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Orca Encounter, Dolphin Days, and Sea Lions Live shows and thrilling rides like Electric Eel, Manta, and Journey To Atlantis. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Hours vary by season.

name: San Diego Law Enforcement Coordination Center (SD-LECC)
description: The SD-LECC is a federal–local fusion center dedicated to intelligence sharing and threat mitigation, including cyber-enabled crime and terrorism. It brings together federal agents, state police, and local law enforcement to detect, analyze, and prevent cybersecurity and critical infrastructure threats across Southern California. The center also trains officers in cyber intelligence, digital evidence handling, and interagency coordination.

name: San Diego Regional Computer Forensics Laboratory (RCFL)
description: The RCFL is a full-service FBI-led digital forensics lab that supports law enforcement agencies across Southern California. The lab specializes in extracting digital evidence from computers, mobile phones, and storage media for use in investigations related to cybercrime, terrorism, trafficking, and fraud. It also serves as a training site for forensic examiners and investigators. Academic Resources

description: HDSI is a leading academic institute driving research in data privacy, AI ethics, algorithmic security, and cyber-physical systems. Faculty and students engage in cybersecurity research across disciplines, combining computer science with public policy, legal studies, and forensics.

name: University of California, San Diego Campus Water Conservation
description: UC San Diego’s utilities & sustainability team has installed and programmed over 250 water, electric, gas, chilled water and high-temperature water meters to transition 1,000 building-level Automatic Meter Reading meters. With each new construction project, UC San Diego installs landscape recycled water piping and expands recycled water distribution throughout campus including landscape areas around School of Medicine, Central Utilities Plant, and Revelle Switch Station. UC San Diego plants low-water-use, native and drought-tolerant plants in 75% of the irrigated campus landscape and ensures compliance with California’s Model Water Efficiency Landscape Ordinance (MWELO). Environmentally sensitive landscape management also improves water and soil quality, promotes biological diversity and lessens our environmental impact. Meeting focus: Address significant water shortages and irrational water usage in agriculture by developing strategies, exploring various methods, and investigating successful practices in water usage and conservation
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - SCP Turkmenistan_ Water Conservation Policy and Sustainable Agriculture.docx

name: Pure Water San Diego
description: Pure Water San Diego is San Diego’s phased, multi-year program that will provide nearly half of San Diego’s water supply locally by the end of 2035. The program aims to create a sustainable and drought-resilient water source by treating recycled water to produce high-quality drinking water. Through advanced water purification, this program ensures that recycled water meets or even exceeds drinking water standards. Pure Water San Diego reduces San Diego’s reliance on imported water sources by enhancing water supply reliability. By implementing innovative water recycling solutions, the program exemplifies the city’s commitment to becoming resilient in the face of drought and water scarcity.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - SCP Turkmenistan_ Water Conservation Policy and Sustainable Agriculture.docx

name: San Diego County Water Authority
description: The Water Authority operates and maintains a regional water delivery system capable of delivering 900 million gallons of water per day. Building and operating the large-scale infrastructure required to meet the region’s water needs now and in the future requires careful planning and technical expertise. The Water Authority uses a sophisticated approach to cost-effectively build, operate, maintain and secure its water facilities as an integrated system. The infrastructure that delivers water to and throughout the San Diego region is a complex and massive network that includes all aspects of transporting, treating and storing water. The Water Authority plans far into the future to ensure that the system will reliably provide long-term supply demand management, emergency water supply, stringent water treatment and system versatility for generations to come.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - SCP Turkmenistan_ Water Conservation Policy and Sustainable Agriculture.docx

name: San Diego Integrated Water Management
description: San Diego Integrated Water Management (SDIRWM) is a collaborative initiative that brings together water retailers, wastewater agencies, stormwater managers, agricultural stakeholders, and nonprofits to improve water resource planning across the San Diego region. Since 2005, the program has implemented over 80 high-priority projects focused on: advanced irrigation techniques, smart water management, drought resilience, & sustainable agricultural practices. They also coordinate with state and federal agencies and have received over $130 million in funding to support water conservation and infrastructure improvements
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - SCP Turkmenistan_ Water Conservation Policy and Sustainable Agriculture.docx

name: Resource Conservation District of Greater San Diego County
description: The mission of the Resource Conservation District of Greater San Diego County is to protect, conserve, and restore natural resources through education, information, and technical assistance programs. As stewards of the regional environment, they partner with a diverse group of landowners, public and private institutions, and concerned citizens to address the diverse conservation and environmental concerns that are unique to San Diego County. The RCD’s programs and priorities help to restore and protect San Diego County watersheds, prevent wildfire damage through education and fuel reduction, promote nutrition and stewardship through sustainable agriculture and soil health, and revitalize pollinator habitats. ﻿Meeting focus: Explore how crop watering methods can become more conservative, to better protect water resources.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - SCP Turkmenistan_ Water Conservation Policy and Sustainable Agriculture.docx

name: San Diego Coastkeeper
description: The San Diego Coastkeeper organization balances advocacy, community outreach, education, and science to promote stewardship of clean water and a healthy coastal ecosystem. From the quality of their educational content to the effectiveness of our advocacy work, they know that Coastkeeper’s approach to protecting and restoring clean water in San Diego County is more effective when it is based on sound science. They run the state’s largest volunteer based water quality monitoring program for ten years, conducted winter stormwater monitoring each rainy season, and regularly participate in supplemental projects and studies from bioassessments to fish gut analysis to debris studies of the habitats around San Diego Bay.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - SCP Turkmenistan_ Water Conservation Policy and Sustainable Agriculture.docx

name: California Water Board, San Diego Commercial Agriculture Regulatory Program
description: Since the 1980s, the San Diego Water Board has regulated discharges from agricultural and nursery operations (Agricultural Operations) within its jurisdictional boundaries by requiring the implementation of management measures and/or best management practices to prevent or minimize the discharge of pollutants that may adversely impact the quality or beneficial uses of the waters of the State. In 2016, the San Diego Water Board adopted Order No. R9-2016-0004 (Third-Party General Order) and Order No. R9-2016-0005 (Individual General Order). Collectively, both Orders are referred to as the General Agricultural Orders. The San Diego Water Board requires all owners or operators of Commercial Agricultural Operations in the San Diego Region to comply with the General Agricultural Orders. Commercial Agricultural Operations are defined as any agricultural business or trade activity, including farms, nurseries, and orchards, that produce crops or ornamental plants with the intent to make a profit.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - SCP Turkmenistan_ Water Conservation Policy and Sustainable Agriculture.docx

name: San Diego County Agriculture - Agricultural Water Quality Program (AWQ)
description: The County of San Diego Agricultural Water Quality Program (AWQ) helps to ensure that our waterways are protected by preventing pollutants from commercial agricultural businesses from entering the County's storm drain system in compliance with our municipal Stormwater permit. AWQ conducts outreach, inspections, and complaint investigations at commercial agriculture businesses to ensure operations are protecting regional water quality through compliance with regional stormwater permit standards.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - SCP Turkmenistan_ Water Conservation Policy and Sustainable Agriculture.docx

name: San Diego Water Conservation Garden
description: The San Diego Water Conservation Garden is a nonprofit organization located in El Cajon, dedicated to promoting water-wise landscaping and environment education. The garden showcases a variety of drought-tolerant plants and sustainable landscaping techniques, providing visitors with inspiration and practical knowledge for creating water-efficient gardens. Through educational programs, workshops, and tours, the garden teaches visitors how to design, install, and maintain landscapes that conserve water and support local biodiversity. Additionally, the garden offers resources and expertise to homeowners and businesses interested in implementing sustainable landscaping practices. By serving as a demonstration site and educational hub, the San Diego Water Conservation Garden plays a vital role in promoting water conservation and environmental stewardship in the region.

name: University of California Cooperative Extension San Diego County
description: The University of California Cooperative Extension (UCCE) San Diego Country is a Branch of the UC Agriculture and Natural Resources division dedicated to serving the local community through research-based education and outreach programs. UCCE works closely with farmers, gardeners, landowners, and other stakeholders to address agricultural, environmental, and community developmental issues. They provide expertise and resources on topics such as sustainable agriculture, water conservation, and natural resource management. Through workshops, seminars, publications, and online resources, UCCE San Diego County spreads information and best practices to help individuals and communities make informed decisions. Overall, UCCE plays a vital role in bridging research and outreach to promote sustainable practices. name: Border Field State Park & Friendship Park
description: https://www.friendshippark.org/ Located within the Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve, Border Field State Park sits in the very southwestern corner of the United States, 15 miles south of San Diego. This important wildlife habitat, comprised of sand dunes and salt marshes, gives refuge to critically threatened and endangered birds such as the Western Snowy Plover, the California Least Tern, and the Light-footed Ridgway's Rail. Operating Hours: 10am – 5pm (Last admission at 4pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside Navy Pier. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Smart Management of U.S. Business Incubators and Accelerators.docx

name: Coronado
description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year around due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown. SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $99.99 for one Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) Accessibility: A 15-20-minute drive from downtown San Diego. Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Orca Encounter, Dolphin Days, and Sea Lions Live shows and thrilling rides like Electric Eel, Manta, and Journey To Atlantis. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Hours vary by season.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Smart Management of U.S. Business Incubators and Accelerators.docx

name: San Diego Human Trafficking Task Force (HTTF)
description: The HTTF is a multidisciplinary effort led by the California Department of Justice, uniting local police departments, sheriff’s offices, Homeland Security Investigations, and prosecutors to combat human trafficking across San Diego County. The task force conducts complex investigations, runs undercover operations to identify trafficking rings, and facilitates rescue and recovery operations. It also provides technical training to other agencies across the region.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Trafficking in Persons  Prevention and Mitigation.docx

name: U.S. Customs and Border Protection – San Ysidro Port of Entry
description: San Ysidro is the busiest land border crossing in the Western Hemisphere and a critical location for intercepting trafficking cases. CBP officers are trained to detect signs of coercion and trafficking among travelers and cargo, using behavioral cues, documentation inconsistencies, and trauma-informed interviewing. The port’s operations involve coordination with victim service providers and child protection agencies for at-risk individuals.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Trafficking in Persons  Prevention and Mitigation.docx

name: San Diego County District Attorney’s Office – Human Trafficking and Sex Crimes Division
description: The District Attorney’s Office leads a dedicated unit for prosecuting human trafficking and sexual exploitation cases, handling both adult and juvenile matters. The division collaborates with law enforcement and nonprofits to build strong cases and secure services for victims. The DA’s office also runs hotel training programs and public awareness campaigns like “The Ugly Truth.” Academic Resources
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Trafficking in Persons  Prevention and Mitigation.docx

name: University of San Diego – Children’s Advocacy Institute (CAI)
description: CAI focuses on the legal rights and protection of vulnerable children, including those at risk of or exploited by trafficking. Through its work in research, litigation, and policy advocacy, the Institute influences laws to better safeguard exploited minors. Faculty members frequently consult on legislative reforms and train future child advocates and attorneys . Non-Profit Resources
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Trafficking in Persons  Prevention and Mitigation.docx

name: Bilateral Safety Corridor Coalition (BSCC)
description: BSCC is a binational coalition made up of over 60 governmental and non-governmental agencies in the U.S. and Mexico. They specialize in cross-border anti-trafficking work, offering 24-hour response to trafficking cases, legal and immigration support, and shelter placement. BSCC plays a key role in coordinating both prevention campaigns and recovery services in San Diego and Tijuana.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Trafficking in Persons  Prevention and Mitigation.docx

name: GenerateHope
description: GenerateHope provides long-term residential treatment and comprehensive care for adult women who have survived sex trafficking. Their trauma-informed program includes medical and mental health services, education, life skills, and job readiness. GenerateHope supports survivors as they rebuild autonomy and pursue independent living.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Trafficking in Persons  Prevention and Mitigation.docx

name: Casa Cornelia Law Center
description: Casa Cornelia is a pro bono legal organization offering immigration services to survivors of trafficking, domestic violence, and unaccompanied minors. The center helps clients obtain T-visas, U-visas, and asylum while ensuring culturally competent, trauma-informed legal representation. It partners with shelters, therapists, and advocacy groups to ensure wraparound care.

name: Project Concern International (PCI), a Global Communities Partner
