name: Institute for Civil Civic Engagement
description: https://www.sandiego.edu/institute-for-civil-civic-engagement/ The Institute for Civil Civic Engagement (ICCE) is located at the University of San Diego, one of San Diego's leading tertiary institutions. ICCE works to encourage, promote and increase civility in civic discourse by fellow citizens and public officials, both interpersonally and in all manner of media. The institute seeks to promote ways to be civil in disagreements and respectful in debates, as they confront the political challenges that shape the community. Some of the ICCE's main goals include to encourage the San Diego community to embrace basic elements of civility in dealing with civic activism and political campaigning, to hold community leaders accountable to conducting public discourse, and to develop and implement programs and curriculum providing effective instruction in best methods of civil civic engagement for educational communities. Meeting focus: Meet with representatives of ICCE to learn about their various initiatives and educational resources to promote civil civic engagement within communities in San Diego and beyond.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Transparency and Accountability in Government.docx

name: ﻿Zoltan Hainal PhD - Professor at the University of California, San Diego
description: ﻿﻿https://ucsdnews.ucsd.edu/pressrelease/how-to-double-voter-turnout-and-increase- representation-during-local-clections Zoltan Hainal is a professor of political science at the School of Global Policy and Strategy, Hainal teaches courses including Policy Analysis and Public Welfare. Hainal is a respected scholar on U.S. politics and policy, with a specific focus on how disadvantaged populations are represented in American politics and what can be done to ensure better representation of these groups. His research areas span racial and ethnic politics, urban politics, immigration and political behavior. He is the author of multiple award-winning books including "White Backlash: Immigration, Race, and American Politics" (Princeton 2015), "Why Americans Don't Join the Party: Race, Immigration, and the Failure of Political Parties to Engage the Electorate" (Princeton 2011), "America's Uneven Democracy: Race, Turnout, and Representation in City Politics" (Cambridge 2010) and "Changing White Attitudes toward Black Political Leadership" (Cambridge 2006). His research has been featured in The New York Times, Washington Post and a range of other media outlets. Meeting focus: Discuss and explore political behavior across different communities to gain a perspective of how disadvantaged populations are represented in politics.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Transparency and Accountability in Government.docx

name: Kroc Institute for Peace and Justice (Kroc IPJ)
description: Kroc IPJ launched with a vision of active peacebuilding. Its mission is to co-create learning with peacemakers – learning that is deeply grounded in the lived experience of peacemakers around the world, that is made rigorous by their place within the University of San Diego’s ecosystem. Kroc IPJ is heavily involved in initiatives building peace at the U.S. – Mexico border. As the closest peace institute to the border, Kroc IPJ seeks to build peace in the border region through research grounded in a nuanced understanding of challenges faced by border communities and in partnership with local scholars, practitioners and policymakers. Kroc IPJ offers educational programs to help transcend the politics and prejudices that promote violence and create injustice on both sides of the border. Media and Journalism
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Transparency and Accountability in Government.docx

name: Inewsource
description: inewsource is a nonprofit, nonpartisan newsroom dedicated to improving lives in the San Diego region and beyond through impactful, data-based investigative and accountability journalism. Inewsource values, above all else, the importance of a free and credible press, where truth is the cornerstone of democracy. Inewsource is also a proud member of The Trust Project, supporting efforts to increase transparency in journalism. Government Resources
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Transparency and Accountability in Government.docx

name: City of San Diego Ethics Commission
description: The Ethics Commission within the City of San Diego is charged with monitoring, administering and enforcing the City's governmental ethics laws and proposing new governmental ethics law reforms; conducting investigations, referring violations to appropriate enforcement agencies and auditing disclosure statements; and advising and educating City officials and the public about governmental ethics laws. This is an independent body, which does not report to the Mayor or City Council. Their mission is to preserve public confidence in San Diego’s City government through education, advice, and the prompt and fair enforcement of local governmental ethics laws.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Transparency and Accountability in Government.docx

name: ﻿Meeting focus: Gain an understanding of commission responsibilities and recent initiatives to promote ethics in City government.
url: Department of Purchasing and Contracting, County of San Dlego https://www.sandiegocounty.gov/content/sdc/purchasing.html
description: ﻿The Department of Purchasing and Contracting (DPC) operates to provide County Departments and other associated organizations outstanding procurement support necessary to meet their operational missions and objectives. Procurement of goods and services is completed in compliance with all applicable laws, policies and regulations in a manner that supports the best interests of the County. DPC is committed to transparency and accountability of all purchasing and contracting transactions and making all contracting opportunities available to qualified businesses which can best meet the County's needs. ﻿Meeting Focus: Discuss DPC's effort to promote its transparency and accountability of purchasing and contracting transactions through Measure J.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Transparency and Accountability in Government.docx

name: City of San Diego: Performance & Analytics Department
description: The City of San Diego's Performance & Analytics Department is responsible for supporting the improvement of City operations through long-term strategic initiatives, including strategic planning, performance measurement and management, the San Diego Works efficiency and incentives program, Managed Competition, and Open Data. As such, the Department works citywide to implement resident-focused and data-driven solutions that improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the City's service delivery practices and management structures.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Transparency and Accountability in Government.docx

name: San Diego Citizens’ Law Enforcement Review Board (CLERB)
description: The role of the Citizens’ Law Enforcement Review Board  is to increase public confidence in government and the accountability of law enforcement by conducting impartial and independent investigations of citizen complaints of misconduct concerning Sheriff's Deputies and Probation Officers employed by the County of San Diego. CLERB receives and investigates complaints about the conduct of peace officers employed by the County Sheriff’s Department and Probation Department. CLERB also investigates deaths that arise out of, or in connection with, the actions of deputies and probation officers, regardless of whether a complaint is filed. Legal Resources
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Transparency and Accountability in Government.docx

name: San Diegans for Open Government (SDOG) / Briggs Law Corporation
description: Briggs Law Corporation has grown into one of California’s leading law firms on issues relating to government transparency and accountability. They have successfully litigated many public interest cases which involved standing up to the government, politicians, and big corporations when they break rules created to protect taxpayers, the public, and the environment. Briggs Law Corporation has also represented community watchdogs in a variety of lawsuits to obtain information that public officials attempted to cover up. ﻿Meeting Focus: Discuss Briggs Law Corporation efforts to promote open government in the San Diego area through government and municipal litigation, and learn about watchdog cases they have overseen to uncover over 100,000 pages of public records. Government Resources
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Transparency and Accountability in Government.docx

name: San Diego County Young Democrats
description: San Diego County Young Democrats (SDCYD) is part of the California State Democratic Party, which works closely with local elected officials, and the coun party. Open to registered Democrats under 36, SDCYD members work to improve the San Diego community, and to elect Democrats. SDCYD holds regular events for members around the county, including guest speakers, opportunities for political action, community service, and networking events.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Transparency and Accountability in Government.docx

name: Mayor Todd Gloria
description: Mayor Gloria has spent his career in public service. After being elected to the California State Assembly to represent the 78th Assembly District in 2016, Mayor Gloria passed legislation on many major issues San Diego is working to address including affordable housing, fighting gun violence, combatting climate change, and providing resources for unhoused people. A third-generation San Diegan of Filipino, Dutch, Puerto Rican, and Native American descent, Maxat Gloria is motivated to improve San Diego every day.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Transparency and Accountability in Government.docx

name: Nora Vargas, San Diego County Supervisor District 1
description: https://www.kpbs.org/news/2021/feb/05/first-latina-supervisor-change-san-diego- politics/ Supervisor Nora Vargas represents District 1 in San Diego's South County. She is the first immigrant, first Latina, and first Democrat to represent her district. For the last 25 years, Supervisor Vargas has worked to drive positive change and serve her community through public service. She is committed to ensuring that marginalized voices are included in the public dialogue regarding various important issues like health access, civic engagement, and education. Prior to her election, she was an elected member and President of the Southwestern College Governing Board, the only public institution of higher education within San Diego's South County. Virtual Meeting Focus: Discuss the demographics of Supervisor Vargas's district and the significance her election has on the region.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Transparency and Accountability in Government.docx

name: San Diego County District Attorney's Office
description: The San Diego County District Attorney's Office is responsible for prosecuting felony crimes committed in the County. It also prosecutes misdemeanor offenses that occur outside of the City of San Diego. Each year the more than 300 prosecutors in the DA's Office file about 40,000 cases on behalf of the county's more than three million residents. The employees of the San Diego County District Attorney, in partnership with the community we serve, are dedicated to the pursuit of truth, justice and protection of the innocent, and the prevention of crime through the vigorous and professional prosecution of those who violate the law. District Attorney Summer Stephan has devoted her life to protecting children and families, providing justice to the most vulnerable, and is a national leader in the fight against human trafficking and sexual exploitation. In 2022, Summer was named one of "The Five Best Prosecutors in America, " utilizing evaluation factors of integrity, fidelity to the rule of law, responsible innovations, and community relations. Non-Governmental Organizations

name: San Diego Organizing Project
description: A nonpartisan, multi-faith network, San Diego Organizing Project (SDOP) represents more than 70,000 families across San Diego County. As one of the most diverse grassroots organizations in the region, SDOP bridges racial, cultural, and economic divides, unlocking the power of people to bring justice, equality, and greater opportunity to fruition in their communities. Some ongoing campaigns SDOP is currently focusing on include justice system reform, county government accountability, civic engagement, immigrant rights, and affordable housing and homelessness.

name: Partnership for the Advancement of New Americans (PANA)
description: PANA is a research, public policy, and community organizing hub dedicated to advancing the full economic, social and civic inclusion of refugees. Founded, led, and staffed by refugees, PANA is uniquely situated to use relational organizing to bring community into a pathway of ongoing engagement and indigenous community leadership development.

name: Alliance of San Diego
description: Alliance San Diego is a non-profit, non-partisan community organization whose mission is to provide a means for diverse individuals and organizations to share information, collaborate on issues and mobilize for change in the pursuit of social justice, especially in low-income communities and communities of color. They seek to build collective power to create an inclusive democracy through leadership development, policy advocacy, communication strategies, and civic engagement. Alliance San Diego's work is guided by three goals: equity and access, voting and governance, and safety and justice. name: Border Field State Park & Friendship Park
description: https://www.friendshippark.org/ Located within the Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve, Border Field State Park sits in the very southwestern corner of the United States, 15 miles south of San Diego. This important wildlife habitat, comprised of sand dunes and salt marshes, gives refuge to critically threatened and endangered birds such as the Western Snowy Plover, the California Least Tern, and the Light-footed Ridgway's Rail. Friendship Park is a binational park located at the western end of the US-Mexico border. For generations people have gathered here to meet up with friends and family "across the line." name: The Preuss School UCSD
description: Recognized by Newsweek as the top transformative high school in the nation for three years in a row, The Preuss School UCSD is a unique charter middle and high school for low income students who strive to become the first in their families to graduate from college. Located on the UC San Diego campus, students come from throughout San Diego County to take advantage of an environment that encourages intellectual risk-taking while offering an array of academic supports.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Addressing the Needs of Underserved and At-Risk Youth.docx

name: San Diego Youth Symphony & Conservatory
description: Through the Community Opus Project we provide community based music programs for at-risk youth in San Diego County. The programs take place on school sites and community centers within those underserved communities and are completely free. Students receive new instruments to begin their musical journey as well as regular expert instruction and mentorship by our Artistic Faculty. SDYS knows there are numerous barriers to participation and has taken great care to eliminate those hurdles for all students, regardless of their families’ socio-economic status.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Addressing the Needs of Underserved and At-Risk Youth.docx

name: School Visit: La Jolla Country Day School (LJCDS) Center for Excellence in Citizenship (CEC)
description: La Jolla Country Day School is an independent college-preparatory school serving students from age 3 through Grade 12 in San Diego’s coastal community of La Jolla. The Center for Excellence in Citizenship (CEC) develops unique opportunities for LJCDS students, faculty and families to engage in the vital work of local, national and global citizenship, focusing on the fundamental importance of human dignity in all interactions. CEC fosters civic engagement and civil discourse, galvanizing students to think about their rights and responsibilities as citizens and to be thoughtful participants in their communities.

name: Monarch School
description: Monarch School nurtures resilience in unhoused youth and their families. They empower students to influence their own growth in the areas of academic success and social emotional learning, and reinforces the existing strength of families so that students can thrive in school and in life. To meet each students’ unique needs, Monarch has developed an innovative approach to learning where students gain the skills they need to improve their lives, develop awareness of their emotions and healthy coping skills, explore their passions and plan for a life of self-sufficient living. The school is a public-private partnership between the San Diego County Office of Education and the nonprofit Monarch School Project. University of San Diego With more than 9,000 students from 85 countries and 50 states,  USD is the youngest independent institution on the U.S. News & World Report list of top 100 universities in the United States. description: Through reciprocal community-based learning, the Mulvaney Center engages USD Students, faculty, staff, and alumni to learn and act in partnership with the community, making life-long commitments to promote social change and justice. name: San Diego State University
description: San Diego State University is the oldest higher-education institute in San Diego. The SDSU community is home to many initiatives, groups, faculty and students exploring civic engagement, community activism and leadership development. Dr. Lisa Gates Dr. Lisa Gates publishes in the fields of Leadership and Communication and is a radically compassionate, equity-minded educator who embodies an abiding fidelity to students. She is committed to student success evidenced by numerous awards for outstanding instruction and advising and, more importantly, through the achievements of her students. She treats students like family -- which means leading with love and compassion and also challenging them to pivot when needed. She views teaching as a communicative act constituted by thoughtful consideration of the actual students present in the learning environment. Lisa has met with many IVLP groups in the past, exploring participants’ understanding of how to strengthen youth leadership capacities – how programs can deepen young people’s understanding of their own aspirations, their roles in their communities, and their leadership styles. Dr. Michael Domínguez Michael Domínguez is Assistant Professor in the department with a focus on youth studies and education. he is passionate about supporting emerging researchers of color, and is presently an instructor for the General Studies program, teaching a course that involves undergraduate students in service-learning and ethnographic field research, while providing them with mentorship as they learn to connect research activities to civic and community outcomes. Dr. Domínguez’ scholarship and research interests focus on the schooling experiences of Chican@ and historically marginalized youth, school athletics and race, Teatro del Oprimido, and liberatory teacher education. He is particularly interested in issues of youth identity construction, socio-political and socio-emotional development, racialization, affect, and community and family ingenuity, as well as decolonizing teaching and teacher education. Dr. Godfried Asante As an educator, Dr. Asante believes he has a responsibility to prepare future and current students for the complex roles they will full fill as parents, community leaders, politicians, and more. He views the classroom as an extension of the “real world” and not outside of it. Based on this belief, he engages his students in critical dialogues where they respectfully challenge each other’s ideas while thinking through local and global issues. An emphasis on critical dialogue is driven by his desire for community-engaged learning, where students critically examine social issues by working with community members. In this way, students see the learning process as not only confined to the classroom but as a collaborative process with their communities. Dr. Asante believes that SDSU stands to make significant contributions to changing this country’s future leaders and is excited to be a part of that legacy. Dr. Jess Whatcott Dr. Whatcott (they/them/theirs) is an interdisciplinary scholar studying state violence through the frameworks of critical disability studies, critical prison studies, and queer studies/queer of color critique. Dr. Whatcott’s current research examines the historic and current relations between carcerality and eugenics, as well as how queer and disabled people resist state violence. In addition to their appointment in Women’s Studies at SDSU, Dr. Whatcott is affiliated with LGBTQ+ Studies and the Digital Humanities Initiative. Digital Humanities Initiative The Digital Humanities Initiative at SDSU (DH@SDSU) was founded to promote such critical engagement by providing a hub for strategic innovation and collaboration across campus. Their goal is to serve faculty and students by providing expertise in digital tools, and to model how collaboration elevates teaching, learning and sense of humanness. Barrio Logan College Institute www.blci.org Barrio Logan College Institute is located in Barrio Logan, a part of the San Diego community that is rich in culture but underserved in resources. Their mission is to break the cycle of poverty by preparing students to be the first in their families to go to college through after school programs that begin in third grade. Located in a traditionally low-income community, BLCI promotes higher education as a ticket out of poverty. To date, 100% of Barrio Logan College Institute’s students have enrolled in college. Social Resources The AjA Project
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Addressing the Needs of Underserved and At-Risk Youth.docx

name: *honorarium needed for workshop. Also possible to have their students lead a tour around the surrounding City Heights neighborhood, also requiring a small honorarium*
description: The AjA Project provides photography-based educational programming to youth affected by war and displacement; students think critically about their identities, develop leadership skills, and become agents of personal and social change. The AjA Project operates Journey, a participatory photography-based program for refugee and immigrant youth in San Diego. The program uses visual storytelling to engage youth to explore their cultural identity, develop communication and leadership skills, and see themselves as agents of personal and social transformation.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Addressing the Needs of Underserved and At-Risk Youth.docx

name: Speak City Heights *Include one or more of the partners, Voice of San Diego, KPBS and Media Arts Center San Diego*
description: Speak City Heights is a media collaborative aimed at amplifying the voices of residents in one of San Diego’s most diverse neighborhoods, City Heights.Through reporting and multimedia projects from our partners—KPBS, voiceofsandiego.org, The AjA Project and Media Arts Center San Diego—the collaborative will help residents and policymakers frame a discussion about what constitutes a healthy community, its barriers and how they’ll overcome them in City Heights.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Addressing the Needs of Underserved and At-Risk Youth.docx

name: Mid-city CAN (Community Advocacy Network) – Youth Council
description: http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/education/sd-me-youthpower-20161019-story.html The Mid-City CAN Youth Council develops and empowers City Heights youth through community organizing. We’re a little different from other youth groups in the sense that we don’t focus primarily on the delivery of direct social-services or activities. The goal is to organize City Heights in order to advocate for changes that improve the community. Over the past year, our members (high school-aged youth who live in City Heights) have been involved in helping create the Community Plan for The California Endowment’s Building Healthy Communities Initiative. We worked alongside adult residents and non-profit representatives in the Mid-City CAN Momentum Teams (Access to Healthcare, Built Community, Food Justice, Peace Promotion, Resident, and School Attendance) to help build the Community Plan. As we move forward, we are working closely with our community partners to develop social consciousness and empowerment among our peers. Meeting focus: Discuss the importance of getting youth civically engaged on issues that matter to them, and discuss their campaign to disrupt the ‘school to prison pipeline’, asking elected officials and communities to address the various factors in juvenile delinquency, rather than ‘locking up’ young people because of behavior.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Addressing the Needs of Underserved and At-Risk Youth.docx

name: Project A.W.A.R.E.
description: Project A.W.A.R.E. aims to educate at-risk youths and prepare them to take responsibility for their thoughts and actions.  By becoming emotionally literate, learning/developing basic social skills, and through self-examination, our young students will not only better themselves and their school environment, but also become productive members of society and establish themselves as community leaders. Project A.W.A.R.E. provides a healthy environment wherein students can safely process their feelings and learn how to effectively incorporate problem-solving skills that they've learned into their daily lives. Meeting focus: Discuss using facilitated discussions as a method to resolve community conflict and build leadership and emotional literacy skills amongst juveniles who have experienced life in and out of the system (foster care, jail, etc)
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Addressing the Needs of Underserved and At-Risk Youth.docx

name: Movement BE
description: The Movement BE platform provides a safe space for individuals to tell their story before others do, raising awareness of local stories to come together to create positive social change. Their work is based in peace, love and justice.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Addressing the Needs of Underserved and At-Risk Youth.docx

name: Rise San Diego
description: To elevate and advance urban leadership through dialogue-based civic engagement, dynamic nonprofit partnerships, and direct training and support to increase the capacity of urban residents to effect meaningful community change. Community Wraparound Community Wraparound | Non-Profit Organization | San Diego (ueniweb.com) A transformative gang prevention and positive youth development initiative that leverages strategic community alliances to support gang-affiliated youth by offering viable alternatives. Their mission is to provide supportive mentoring services through a trauma-informed and lived experience lens to build resilience in youth, families, and communities. They aim to create a society where young individuals can thrive, break from negative influences, and find success with their families, school, work, and community. Formerly incarcerated people may share their work helping young people with homework, food, and hosting events. Formerly incarcerated people become credible messengers, heal, and assist community healing. Employment Resources
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Addressing the Needs of Underserved and At-Risk Youth.docx

name: Urban Corps
description: Urban Corps is a locally-based nonprofit conservation corps that provides a high school education and green job training to young adults ages 18-25. The majority of youth employed at Urban Corps did not succeed in a traditional high school setting and they have little or no job training. At Urban Corps they get a second chance to go back to school and develop new skills, while contributing to the overall quality of life in the San Diego area. Their participation increases the connection these young people feel to their community, their environment, and to their own futures. When they care about all three, it benefits us all. Meeting focus: Explore innovative strategies for green job training and high school education for youth who did not complete traditional high school
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Addressing the Needs of Underserved and At-Risk Youth.docx

name: Second Chance – Youth Programs
description: Second Chance youth programs are focused on helping local youth overcome neglect, abuse, criminal backgrounds, addiction and poverty. Programs include: Workforce Innovation & Opportunity Act (WIOA), provides occupational skills training and credentials and supportive services for out-of-school youth; Youth Garden, a six-week program combining hands-on urban farming, classes and workforce training; STRIVE Future Leaders provides technical training, professional certifications, life skills and educational opportunities; Youthful Offender Rehabilitation Program (YORP), uses evidence-based curricula and cognitive behavioral interventions to rehabilitate youth incarcerated.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Addressing the Needs of Underserved and At-Risk Youth.docx

name: Second Chance Youth Garden
description: Second Chance’s Youth Garden serves young people as they gain hands-on experience with urban agriculture. The program combines classroom and experiential learning as youth participate in healthy cooking classes, job readiness/development training and youth development workshops. Participants take part in an eight-week garden-based holistic training program, teaching students everything from seed cultivation and soil fertility to sales skills and marketing initiatives to sell their produce.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Addressing the Needs of Underserved and At-Risk Youth.docx

name: Resource
description: San Diego Workforce Partnership (SDWP) is the local Workforce Development Board, designated by the City and the County of San Diego to receive state and federal funds to administer job training and employment programs throughout the region. SDWP also receives competitive grants to administer innovative workforce programs. Their programs enable eligible youth and adults to develop the skills and knowledge needed to meet the needs of San Diego’s employers. SDWP Youth/Young Adult Programs In San Diego County, 9.2% of the county’s opportunity youth population (aged 16 – 24) are not working or in school. Additionally, youth disconnection rate is unevenly distributed among Black, Indigenous, and People of Color. SDWP funds youth programs that provide work-readiness training to youth from low-income households as well as youth who are at risk of dropping out of school. Their young adult programs focus on connecting all young adults to education and employment. Connect2Careers (C2C) represents a partnership between the Workforce Partnership and funders who support innovative youth employment programming. C2Cworks with young adults works directly with young adults to develop and support their career goals through work-readiness training, case management, job coaching and paid work experiences. Government Resources City of San Diego, Commission on Gang Prevention and Intervention www.sandiego.gov/gangcommission The Commission's vision is to develop a more strategic, coordinated, and collaborative effort between the City, law enforcement agencies, social service providers, and the general public with the objective of significantly curtailing gang involvement, and its negative impact, in the City of San Diego. The Commission on Gang Prevention & Intervention serves as the official advisory body to the Mayor and City Council on policy issues relating to gang prevention and intervention. The purpose of the commission is to develop a strategic collaborative effort between various agencies who work with gang related issues; make policy recommendations to the Mayor and City Council on issues of gang prevention, intervention, diversion and suppression methods, identify local, state and federal funding sources, and identify best practice efforts; and advocate, formulate, and recommend for adoption proactive gang policies, ordinances and guidelines. San Diego Police Department: Multi-Cultural Community Relations Office www.sandiego.gov/police The San Diego Police Department (SDPD) is the primary law enforcement agency for the city of San Diego. The Multi-Cultural Community Relations Office was established by the San Diego Police Department in 1987 to address the specific needs of the growing refugee population in San Diego. They focus on the Southeast Asian and East African communities, but are available to serve anyone who needs their assistance. Their mission is to maintain open communications with the Southeast Asian and East African communities within the City of San Diego and contribute to the safety and security of these communities by offering crime prevention support and assistance.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Addressing the Needs of Underserved and At-Risk Youth.docx

name: San Diego County District Attorney: Breaking Cycles
description: The Breaking cycles program is a multi-agency program administered by the San Diego county Probation Department that seeks to build positive futures for local at-risk youth. Their goals are to reduce crime and gang activity; to promote school attendance and family and friend relationships while also supporting community service. They achieve their goals by providing screening, assessment, counseling, and therapy through quality service providers. Meeting focus: Overview the strategy used by the Breaking cycles program to turn around the lives of delinquent youth in our community. Explore the ways to set up a similar program and the different potential strategies for success.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Addressing the Needs of Underserved and At-Risk Youth.docx

name: Juvenile Community Supervision
description: When a juvenile is released from custody or is otherwise placed on probation by a juvenile court judge, the youth will be supervised in the community by a probation officer who will make regular contact with the youth at their home, school, and work. Probationers are assessed by their gender, age, prior offense record, and criminal sophistication and placed in a corresponding supervision program. For example, gang members are supervised by probation officers in the gang unit. Probationers may also be required to perform community service, attend school, pay restitution, participate in rehabilitation programs, in addition to maintaining a law-abiding lifestyle.The Probation Department's juvenile division (Juvenile Field Services) is organized to provide a continuum of services for youth at all stages of the criminal justice system, from no criminal record to multiple felony convictions. Meeting focus: To learn more about re-entry programs to support juvenile delinquents, including addressing truancy and school dropout issues Restorative Justice
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Addressing the Needs of Underserved and At-Risk Youth.docx

name: Restorative Justice Mediation Program
description: The mission of RJMP is to reduce repeat crime and improve the lives of those affected by crime by providing victim/offender dialog, education and services in partnership with government, non-profit organizations and businesses to San Diego County, based upon Restorative Justice Principles and practices. The Restorative Justice Mediation Program (RJMP) offers several programs in line with our mission: Victim-Offender Dialogue (VOD), inmate education programs such as the Restorative Justice Reentry Prep Program (RJRPP) and Insight Prison Project's evidence-based Victim-Offender Education Groups (VOEG), and school based training in restorative practices. Restorative Justice views crime as a harm to the victim and the community.  Restorative Justice insists on offender accountability, addresses the victim’s needs, attempts to repair the harm, and seeks to bring both parties together for restitution that is mutually agreeable. Meeting focus: To discuss about the importance for juveniles to address the consequences of crimes committed, and provide a space for individual and community healing
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Addressing the Needs of Underserved and At-Risk Youth.docx

name: The Tariq Khamisa Foundation
description: The Tariq Khamisa Foundation (TKF) was established by the father of Tariq Khamisa, a 20 year old who was murdered by a 14 year old gang member in 1995. The foundation’s goals are to stop youth violence through mentorship, education, and community service programs. They have had great success in stemming the flow of youth in to gangs through their programs and continue to be on the front line of the issue here in San Diego. Meeting focus: Discuss the formation of the foundation and how a society has to come together to progress. Reflect on the difficulty, yet necessity, to forgive in order to build a safer future for our youth; one free of gangs, violence, and drugs. *Time and availability permitting, there may be time for visitors to attend a school meeting and experience one of their workshops. Workshop Addressing Leadership Development National Conflict Resolution Center (NCRC) www.ncrconline.com The National Conflict Resolution Center is a non-profit organization that serves a variety of communities in both the public and private sectors regionally, nationally and internationally. With more than twenty years of experience and over 20,000 cases managed, NCRC is recognized as an international leader in mediation instruction and conflict resolution. NCRC provides the resources, training and expertise to help people, organizations and communities manage and solve conflicts, with civility.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Addressing the Needs of Underserved and At-Risk Youth.docx

name: Community Services – Restorative Practices in Education and the Juvenile Judicial System
description: NCRC facilitates the application of Restorative Practices in schools as well as the juvenile justice system. Their programs are an effective alternative to traditional disciplinary action in both the academic and judicial settings, and have achieved great results through partnerships with the San Diego Unified School District and the San Diego District Attorney’s Office. **Home Hospitality can be offered for the group, as well as a volunteer activity (Saturdays only) ** San Diego Zoo San Diego Zoo | Home page Price: $68-$79 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. It is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park. Harbor Cruise Flagship Cruises & Events | San Diego, California (flagshipsd.com) Price: Starting at $24.75 for one Adult Ticket for one-hour tour Their deluxe tour covers it all: Harbor and Shelter Islands, Point Loma, Cabrillo National Monument, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and much more. Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 15 major museums, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Coronado Consistently voted one of America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year round due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. From the shores of Silver Strand State Beach to the tip of the Coronado Municipal Beach, you’ll find plenty of wide open sand, gentle waves and gorgeous views. SeaWorld San Diego SeaWorld San Diego Theme Park - Aquarium, Zoo & Theme Park in California Price: Starting at $71.99 for one single day Adult Ticket Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Shamu show, One Ocean, and thrilling rides like Journey To Atlantis, Shipwreck Rapids and Wild Arctic. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Then dive into the world of sea turtles at the all-new Turtle Reef attraction.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Addressing the Needs of Underserved and At-Risk Youth.docx

name: Youth Sessions
description: https://www.instagram.com/youthsessions.sd/ Youth Sessions is a community of mentors dedicated share their knowledge and culture with the next generation. Through open/free monthly youth sessions, trainings, events and sharing all community events. Meeting focus: Discuss the programs offered by Youth Sessions to empower underserved youth through education on Hip Hop Freestyle culture. Connect with participants in their mentorship program to learn how this culture has influenced and shaped their personal journeys.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Hip Hop and Civic Engagement  (1).docx

name: Mid-City Community Music
description: Mid-City Community Music is dedicated to fostering creativity and enriching lives through arts education in under-resourced communities and schools throughout San Diego. By providing access to quality arts programs, MCCM aims to empower individuals, cultivate talent, and build stronger, more vibrant communities. MCCM’s mission is to inspire and nurture the next generation of artists, dancers, musicians, and creative thinkers. Justice Involved Youth Program Music and art workshops at six juvenile justice school sites for students who are wards of the court, have been referred by social services, are pregnant or parenting, are on probation, or are incarcerated. Mid-City Entrepreneurs Workshops for teens in underserved neighborhoods that provide everything they need to start their own line of branded merchandise and provides them with design, marketing, and finance skills that will stay with them wherever their careers take them. Teen Performance Workshop Free weekly music program that give teens in City Heights the chance to play in their first band. Meeting focus: Examine the MCCM’s youth-centered initiatives, including the Justice-Involved Youth Program, Mid-City Entrepreneurs, and Teen Performance Workshop, and discuss their real-world impact on marginalized youth.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Hip Hop and Civic Engagement  (1).docx

name: San Diego Creative Youth Development Network
description: Creative Youth Development (CYD) is a holistic approach to deeply engaging young people through the arts and creativity to promote personal well-being and support them in reaching their full potential. In order to fully support young people in creating positive change in themselves and their communities, Creative Youth Development programs need the right resources. Unfortunately, CYD organizations are systemically under-resourced and under-capacity because of inequities facing the field. The San Diego Creative Youth Development Network is a coalition of Young People, Providers, and Partners dedicated to harnessing their collective strength to build the field of creative youth development to maximize impact for youth. Meeting focus: Meet with CYD to learn about their holistic approach to empower youth within the arts and discuss the societal challenges they face.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Hip Hop and Civic Engagement  (1).docx

name: A Reason to Survive (ARTS)
description: A Reason to Survive (ARTS) lifts young people in the South County region of San Diego to become confident, compassionate, and courageous community builders through the transformative power of creativity. ARTS 4 Justice The ARTS 4 Justice initiative connects system-involved young people with creative arts programming and community-based projects in an effort to confront and respond the root causes of systemic violence and injustice in communities across south San Diego. Meeting focus: Discover the ARTS 4 Justice program and explore how they use music to foster positive connections with disenfranchised youth.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Hip Hop and Civic Engagement  (1).docx

name: ArtReach
description: ArtReach programs are inspired by relevant, contemporary visual arts practices with a focus on creating spaces for expression by fostering community and connection in the classroom. Artmaking provides a conduit for igniting the creativity that already resides within each young person, helps students process and express feelings, fosters community with peers, and builds self-esteem in a supportive yet challenging environment. Mural Programs ArtReach believes in the power of community and art to change lives and spaces. A mural provides an opportunity for people to work together while creating something transformative and lasting for their site. The ArtReach Mural Program works directly with youth at schools and community centers to dream up large collaborative works that represent their vision. Meeting focus: Explore ArtReach’s Mural Program and its efforts to empower at-risk students by providing a creative outlet. A visit to a participating school may be arranged, subject to availability.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Hip Hop and Civic Engagement  (1).docx

name: Mid-City CAN: Youth Council Artivism Program
description: Mid-City CAN is a community-based organization located in City Heights that focuses on improving transportation, developing youth into leaders, advocating for juvenile justice, getting residents engaged, and building community power. Their non-profit organization is composed of residents of the Mid-City neighborhood who care about making a lasting impact in this community. They gather around the top issues residents care about, forming teams of volunteers. Mid-City CAN helps organize these teams to accomplish their goals.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Hip Hop and Civic Engagement  (1).docx

name: Youth Council Artivism Program
description: Their 4th Youth Council Artivism Summer Program was collaboration between Mid-City CAN, The AjA Project and Breathable Streets at UC San Diego. Participants explore protest and activism through art, specifically looking at the history of Officer Henwood Park in City Heights and the parallels to Chicano Park in Barrio Logan. Meeting focus:Explore Mid-City CAN’s mission to empower the City Heights community through youth leadership, community engagement, and advocacy. Learn about their Youth Council Artivism Program, which combines art and activism to inspire change, including a focus on the historical and cultural connections of local spaces like Officer Henwood Park and Chicano Park.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Hip Hop and Civic Engagement  (1).docx

name: Museum of Contemporary Art San Diego: Teen Art Collective
description: MCASD invites 11th grade students from San Diego to join their teen program, Teen Art Collective (TAC). This is an opportunity for teens to meet for a year and learn about contemporary art, explore art collections, meet artists and art professionals, create art, and plan a museum exhibition. Meeting focus: Learn about the Museum of Contemporary Art San Diego's Teen Art Collective (TAC), a year-long program for 11th-grade students to engage with contemporary art, connect with artists and professionals, create their own works, and curate a museum exhibition.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Hip Hop and Civic Engagement  (1).docx

name: Finest City Breaking
description: Finest City Breaking was established to deliver high-quality instruction and coaching for youth breaking in San Diego, California. Their program offers structured, tactical training that has successfully guided many young bboys and bgirls toward achieving their goals. Participants must demonstrate commitment and a desire to advance their breaking skills. Their highly experienced instructors provide a safe space where kids can build confidence, foster relationships, and train alongside their peers. Their program is a registered organization with Child of this Culture which ensures that they will hold a safe space, utilize safesport practices, provide general liability, and abuse prevention. Meeting focus: Discover Finest City Breaking, a San Diego-based program dedicated to providing high-quality instruction and coaching for youth in breaking. Learn how their structured training and safe, supportive environment help young bboys and bgirls build skills, confidence, and community.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Hip Hop and Civic Engagement  (1).docx

name: The Origin
description: The Origin is dedicated to supporting the cultural, social, creative, and educational values of Hip Hop. They educate and inspire youth to utilize the genre as a tool for learning. The Origin enjoys broad local support and collaborations with a variety of businesses and private benefactors. Voted Best hip hop dance studio in 2016 and 2017. Their programs including classes, dance crews, camps and after schools programs have been a staple of the community for almost 12 years. Meeting focus: Explore The Origin’s commitment to preserving and promoting the cultural, social, and educational values of Hip Hop through programs like classes, dance crews, camps, and after-school initiatives. Learn how this award-winning studio has inspired youth and served as a community cornerstone for over a decade.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Hip Hop and Civic Engagement  (1).docx

name: TransenDANCE
description: transcenDANCE is a nationally-recognized creative youth development organization that works with youth in under resourced San Diego communities. Their programs change the trajectory of students’​ lives by building resilience, confidence, and creativity and by instilling life-changing skills such as leadership, collaboration, and community engagement. transcenDANCE measures their impact using the PEAR (Program in Education, After School, and Resiliency) assessment tools developed at Harvard to monitor student progress and success. This quantitative data validates the work that transcenDANCE is doing to keep youth in school and help them pursue college, seek leadership positions, and pursue careers. Meeting focus: Engage with transcenDANCE, a nationally recognized creative youth development organization transforming the lives of under-resourced San Diego youth through dance and life skills. Explore how their programs build resilience, leadership, and community engagement while using Harvard-developed PEAR tools to measure student success and impact. Community Building and Civic Engagement Through Arts Resources

name: Culture Shock
description: Culture Shock utilizes dance to cultivate education, entertainment and empowerment to inspire positive change in the communities we serve. They are a troupe of individuals who, through the power of music and dance, cultivate self-worth, dignity, and respect for all people throughout our global community. Providing dance classes, rehearsal experience, and performance opportunities helps dancers of all ages in physical strength, mental stability, and self-confidence. Their dancers gain a network of lifetime supporters. Operating in a non-profit capacity ensures that they are able to foster as many dancers as possible, from various social and socioeconomic backgrounds. This guarantees that their service to the community reflects our mission to cultivate education, entertainment, and empowerment to inspire positive change within the communities that they serve. Meeting focus: Discover Culture Shock’s mission to inspire positive change through dance by fostering education, empowerment, and self-expression. Understand how their nonprofit programs provide dancers of all ages and backgrounds with opportunities for personal growth, community connection, and lifelong support.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Hip Hop and Civic Engagement  (1).docx

name: SD Hip Hop 5K & Festival - Diamond Minds
description: Diamond Minds was established in 2012 as a Community Based Organization. Diamond Minds specializes in creating unique events and programs in underserved communities that stimulate growth and education. As a result, the San Diego Hip Hop Health & Wellness 5K/ Festival launched in 2015 to encourage southeastern San Diego residents of all generations to commit to fitness, health and resource awareness. FMG Futuristic Music Group is a Hip Hop record label based out of San Diego California. FMG is best known for their marquee artists Mike N Keys, who have produced music for artists ranging from 50 Cent, Buddy, G-Eazy and Nipsey Hussle to name a few. Futuristic Music Group is dedicated to bringing quality music to the forefront of Hip Hop culture while reaching back to the community in efforts to raise awareness in regards to health, fitness and total wellness. Meeting focus: Learn about the San Diego Hip Hop 5K & Festival, a collaboration between Diamond Minds and Futuristic Music Group, designed to promote health, fitness, and wellness in southeastern San Diego through community engagement. See how this event unites people of all ages to raise awareness while celebrating the positive impact of Hip Hop culture on wellness.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Hip Hop and Civic Engagement  (1).docx

name: Villa Musica
description: Founded as a 501(c)3 non-profit corporation in November 2005, Villa Musica is a vibrant gathering place where people of all ages and backgrounds can come together to take music lessons, play in an ensemble, or participate in a workshop. Villa Musica’s goal is to create a focal point for community music education in San Diego, where students and teachers can meet to exchange ideas and experience the joy of making music. By creating a supportive and creative environment for the study of music, they aim to inspire many San Diegans to make music making part of their lives. Villa Musica’s vision is to provide a space for people to explore music in their lives across all facets of the artistic experience – from inspiration to mastery, listening to performing, they seek to nurture personal growth and a connection to a vibrant musical community. Meeting focus: Discover Villa Musica, a community-focused nonprofit dedicated to providing music education and performance opportunities for people of all ages and backgrounds in San Diego. Learn how they foster creativity, personal growth, and a vibrant musical community through lessons, workshops, and ensemble experiences. San Diego Activist and Community-Based Artists/Resources SDDC can work to arrange a meeting with these artists, invite them to perform for the participants, or invite the artists to our showcase event. Please note that a performance/meeting with the artist may require an honorarium ($150-250).
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Hip Hop and Civic Engagement  (1).docx

name: The Neighborhood Kids
description: https://theneighborhoodkidsmusic.com/ The Neighborhood Kids are a fast emerging conscious hip-hop band comprised of uniquely talented individuals: Verde, Amon the MC, Niko Rosy, Gatoz Locoz, and DJ JG. Together, they use their music to promote awareness for child abuse, women’s rights, police reform, drug abuse, immigration laws and other marginalized groups. Meeting focus: Meet with the artists of The Neighborhood Kids to learn about their unique talents and collaborative efforts to amplify awareness for social issues.

name: Ground Floor Murals
description: Owned by community-centered artists Signe Ditona and Paul Jimenez. Besides art, one thing that’s super important to them both is community. Their public pieces are our cooperation to the neighborhoods generous enough to welcome us and provide for us a space to carry out their craft. They wish to instill a sense of self-love and pride in the people that will walk by and admire their pieces most frequently. Their drive is to pay homage to the cultures that formed them. The walls that surrounded us shaped them into who they are, so to paint them is their greatest privilege. As artists of color, they feel it is their responsibility and our pleasure to paint the town with hands that are brown. Meeting focus: Meet with artists Signe and Paul to discuss their community-focused projects and explore how their art has amplified stories from specific communities. A site visit to one of their murals may also be arranged.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Hip Hop and Civic Engagement  (1).docx

name: Martha Gonzalez
description: Martha Gonzalez is a Chicana artivista (artist-activist)—a musician, feminist music theorist, and associate professor in the Intercollegiate Department of Chicana/o Latina/o Studies at Scripps College, Claremont. Born and raised in Boyle Heights, Los Angeles, Gonzalez has been awarded MacArthur (2022), Fulbright Garcia Robles (2007-2008), Ford (2012-2013), Woodrow Wilson (2016-2017), and United States Artist (2021) fellowships. Her experience as a singer/songwriter and percussionist for the Grammy Award-winning (2013) band Quetzal has fueled her academic interests. She has explored the relevance of Quetzal’s music and lyrics in a range of academic publications, including her book Chican@ Artivistas: Music, Community, and Transborder Tactics in East Los Angeles (University of Texas, 2020). Quetzal’s latest recording, Puentes Sonoros (Sonic Bridges), was released on Smithsonian Folkways in the fall of 2020. Gonzalez and her partner Quetzal Flores have been instrumental in catalyzing the transnational dialogue between Chicanx/Latinx communities in the US and Jarocho communities in Veracruz, Mexico. Meeting focus: Meet with Martha to discuss her Grammy-winning contributions with Quetzal, her academic research on art and social change, and her efforts to foster transnational connections between Chicanx/Latinx and Jarocho communities.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Hip Hop and Civic Engagement  (1).docx

name: Drummers without Borders
description: Drummers Without Borders was created in  San Diego, Ca in 2004 by Felix Díaz, Silvio Díaz and  Abril Díaz,  (a family of Musicians, Educators and Artists). It began as a music project dedicated to play and experiment with all kinds of drums and percussion instruments. Besides their initial music performances, soon they were invited to create a Program for an underserved community to introduce elementary school students with special needs to Music.                                                                                                                                                            The teaching of Rhythm, the most basic component, became the way to engage the students on the subject and make them feel accomplished from the first moment. Through the years, the program gained experience, evolved and grew to incorporate all levels and ages of students and the general public. Now, as a collective of Musicians, Educators and Artists, their Mission is to continue developing projects, in diverse areas such as Music, Education, Community, Health and Environment well beyond our local geographic area and to collaborate with all kinds of Individuals and organizations with the same interest. Meeting focus: Learn about Drummers Without Borders’ journey from a local music project to a diverse organization serving underserved communities, including special needs students, while advancing initiatives in music, education, health, and environmental awareness.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Hip Hop and Civic Engagement  (1).docx

name: The Music Company
description: The Music Company TMC is a 501(c)(3) organization dedicated to removing the educational, economic, and social barriers that stand between music makers and the realization of their creative visions through affordable professional music workspaces, educational programs, and collaborative project opportunities. They rely on the generosity of donors to help them provide programs and services to our community. They believe in the power of music creation to make the world a little bit better place, and they exist to give music makers of all kinds a creative, welcoming, and inclusive place to do it. Their goal is to build a community of independent music makers who share their vision by providing affordable professional recording, rehearsal, and production spaces as well as educational programming. Whatever age, color, gender, orientation – if you want to make music, TMC is for you. Meeting focus: Engage with The Music Company (TMC and explore their mission to foster an inclusive community of independent musicians and their efforts to remove barriers to creativity for individuals of all backgrounds.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Hip Hop and Civic Engagement  (1).docx

name: KPBS - Rap Diego
description: "Rap Diego" reveals the untold story of San Diego's underground rap scene, a pivotal music moment that launched numerous artists into the mainstream and shaped music culture.  Presented in four acts, this narrative features insights from key figures who experienced it firsthand. Audiences will have the opportunity to hear previously unheard early music and performances, showcasing the rich history of San Diego's Rap and Hip Hop scene. "Rap Diego" is an original podcast by Parker Edison and KPBS. Parker Edison Parker Edison is best known as project manager for Meridien Arts, a micro-label created to produce and present art driven events in the city. It’s core belief being that exposing San Diego city youth to art can change lives. In 2016 M.A. received the Peacemaker Award from the National Conflict Resolution Center for the Reclaiming the Community Music Project which included two albums and a series of independently produced film-shorts. Its newest endeavor, The Parker Edison Project is a KPBS podcast featuring insightful conversations about creativity and community. Meeting focus: Meet with KPBS and Parker Edison to delve into Rap Diego, an original podcast that uncovers the untold story of San Diego’s underground rap scene and its cultural impact. Discuss the podcast’s exploration of local Hip Hop history, its influence on mainstream music, and Edison’s broader work in empowering youth through art and storytelling. Educational Resources
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Hip Hop and Civic Engagement  (1).docx

name: University of San Diego: Music Courses
description: The Department of Music equips students with foundational knowledge and skills to pursue a life in music beyond graduation. Together, students and faculty critically consider the practice and reception of music-making in the world, both historically and today. Every semester, the department hosts 12 to 20 concerts, offering opportunities for students to enhance their performance portfolios and status within the music community. Performances include offerings from our student ensembles and ensembles featuring their faculty.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Hip Hop and Civic Engagement  (1).docx

name: Course Deepdive: Musc 104 | Music in San Diego
description: The city of San Diego has a rich and diverse musical history. Beginning with the question "When is San Diego?," students will consider the people and musical traditions of those who stewarded this land long before its formation as an American city. Today, San Diego is a transnational metropolis that is home to a diverse array of cultural groups, each with their own musical traditions. Studying some of these groups and their music in close detail, students will critically address "Who is San Diego?" In addition to issues relating to the cultural landscape of San Diego, students will explore how this city’s unique topographical and geographical features (deserts, mountains, beaches, proximity to Tijuana) cultivate musical expression specific to this place. Finally, students will learn about cultural sites like Balboa Park, Chicano Park, and historic theaters that have presented music for generations. Meeting focus: Meet with the University of San Diego to explore how the Department of Music showcases San Diego's cultural heritage, followed by a brief overview of Music 104.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Hip Hop and Civic Engagement  (1).docx

name: San Diego State University: Africana Studies
description: Africana studies offers a broad, interdisciplinary program. The curriculum is designed to focus on a variety of subjects pertaining to the Africana experience. It is also concerned with strengthening links between black students and the black community, and developing frameworks for social change and the struggle for black dignity. It seeks, in short, to provide a total educational experience of the Africana culture. The courses offered in Africana studies are available to anyone who is interested. Their program provides excellent preparation for the fields of law, government, foreign service, business administration, research, consulting, librarianship, counseling, program development, program design, program analysis, and writing, to name a few, as well as the more traditional Africana studies profession of teaching.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Hip Hop and Civic Engagement  (1).docx

name: Course Deepdive: AFRAS 476. History and Culture of Hip Hop
description: Genesis of hip hop as a worldwide culture, with attention to major Africana historical, political, sociological, cultural, and aesthetic precursors. Meeting focus: Connect with San Diego State University’s Africana Studies Department to learn about their interdisciplinary program focused on the Africana experience and fostering social change. Explore the curriculum’s relevance to students and communities, including a deep dive into AFRAS 476: History and Culture of Hip Hop, which examines hip hop’s origins and its connections to Africana history and culture.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Hip Hop and Civic Engagement  (1).docx

name: University of San Diego, California: Ethnic Studies
description: Situated in a region where the US-Mexico border zone, indigenous national and tribal governments, and the Asia-Pacific interact to produce a dynamic geopolitical location, UCSD’s Ethnic Studies Department is a vibrant community of scholars committed to the interdisciplinary study of race, ethnicity, indigeneity, gender, sexuality, class, and dis/ability. The department’s innovative approach represents a commitment to transnational, relational, and intersectional methods for producing critical knowledge about power and inequality, including systems of knowledge that have emerged from racialized and indigenous communities in global contexts. Ethnic Studies is devoted to creative, conceptual, and empirical research; critical pedagogy; collaborations with a broad group of affiliated faculty; and social justice projects developed with and for the university, our home communities, and the broader public.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Hip Hop and Civic Engagement  (1).docx

name: Course Deepdive: ETHN 163G. Indigenous Theatre and Performance
description: This theoretical and embodied course examines a selection of indigenous plays and performances (dance, hip hop) and helps students develop the critical vocabulary and contextual knowledge necessary to productively engage with the political and artistic interventions performed by these works. Meeting focus: Meet with the Ethnic Studies Department at UC San Diego to explore their interdisciplinary approach to studying race, ethnicity, indigeneity, gender, and other critical social issues. Delve into their innovative methods for understanding power and inequality, with a focus on ETHN 163G: Indigenous Theatre and Performance, a course that examines indigenous plays and performances like dance and hip hop, and develops the critical vocabulary necessary to engage with their political and artistic impact and find conflict resolution. Government Resources
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Hip Hop and Civic Engagement  (1).docx

name: City of San Diego: Department of Cultural Affairs
description: The Department of Cultural Affairs (DCA) is responsible for the City's arts, culture, and creative industries. Specifically, DCA advances an equitable and inclusive creative economy and arts ecosystem in San Diego that reflects the region's cultural diversity and informs San Diego’s brand as a global city. DCA’s mission is to advance and drive an equitable and inclusive creative economy and cultural ecosystem by investing in the work of artists and creatives and the institutions and systems that amplify creative work and experiences, cultivating local participation and access, and advancing San Diego as a global city. DCA’s vision is a champion for a cultural capital with a global reputation for its diverse and innovative creative workforce, cultural vitality and wholly unique art experiences and opportunities for all.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Hip Hop and Civic Engagement  (1).docx

name: Creative City
description: The City of San Diego is launching a cultural planning process to capture the power of our many traditions, ecologies, and creative capital to propel our city and transborder region forward as a more equitable place of inspiration and prosperity. It supports artists and creative inventions across sectors, fostering greater possibility and sustainability for us all. And it will align arts and culture with the priorities of the City government. Over the course of the project timeline, San Diegans will be presented with multiple opportunities to inform the aspirations and goals of a future with culture and creativity at the center of our collective well-being and livelihood.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Hip Hop and Civic Engagement  (1).docx

name: Far South Border North
description: Far South/Border North is a City of San Diego-led regional collaborative that supports artists and cultural practitioners working in service of the health and well-being of communities in San Diego and Imperial counties. Through Far South/Border North, artists and cultural practitioners connect with one another and the community. The program offers an essential platform for guiding public messaging campaigns to cultivate awareness, social cohesion, and connectivity, particularly in the region's most impacted communities, contributing to health equity. This year, the Far South/Border North artists, cultural practitioners and organizations are implementing their campaigns across a variety of artistic and creative forms, ranging from performing arts, visual arts, and literature to music, film, and media. Their work will engage people, bringing awareness to urgent issues shaping our region today – including public health, civic engagement, climate mitigation, and social justice. Meeting focus:  Explore the City of San Diego’s cultural initiatives like Creative City, a cultural planning process that envisions a future where culture and creativity drive the city’s prosperity, and Far South/Border North, a regional collaborative supporting artists and cultural practitioners working to promote health equity, social justice, and community well-being in San Diego and Imperial counties.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Hip Hop and Civic Engagement  (1).docx

name: Legler Benbough Teen IDEA Lab
description: The Legler Benbough Teen IDEA Lab is a multimedia center where youth can learn new skills in STEAM (science, technology, engineering, arts and mathematics) in a safe, welcoming and collaborative environment. During open hours, dedicated staff are available to assist teens using the advanced equipment. Educational programs will be offered in collaboration with partners Admit One College Prep, the LEAGUE of Amazing Programmers, FAB LAB, Media Arts Center San Diego and Sally Ride Science at UC San Diego. Funding for the project was provided through a combination of private donations and public funding. Working with the San Diego Public Library Foundation, local non-profit the Legler Benbough Foundation invested $1 million to create the teen technology lab, fitting with the organization’s mission to improve the quality of life for San Diegans. This project is also funded with $500,000 in Community Development Block Grant funds provided by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development to the City of San Diego, in addition to PEG (public, educational and governmental) cable television franchise fees. Meeting focus: Meet with the Legler Benbough Teen IDEA Lab team to explore how their multimedia center provides youth with access to advanced equipment and learning opportunities in STEAM fields, including arts and technology. Focus on the Lab’s offerings related to recording and production, and discuss how the space fosters creativity and collaboration among teens in a safe, supportive environment, with partnerships from local organizations like the Media Arts Center San Diego. Showcase Event Opportunity SDDC can organize an exciting showcase event featuring the talented IVLP participants, building on the success of our previous event in 2018, "Art Soup." At "Art Soup," the evening was filled with incredible and inspirational performances, including photography, guitar, drama, and rap, presented by diverse artists from around the world from another international exhcange. The event fostered creativity and promoted social change, leaving a lasting impact on attendees. If given the opportunity, we have the knowledge and skill to plan a similar event that will continue the tradition by offering a platform for the IVLP program participants to share their voices, inspire the community, and spark meaningful conversations through their art. Logistics
