name: San Diego Police Department (SDPD)
description: The SDPD provides law enforcement and public safety services to the City of San Diego, working closely with the local community partners, law enforcement departments in surrounding cities, and national agencies. Participants will meet with SDPD officers to learn how the department serves a community of 1.3 million people while working to ensure fair and impartial policing.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Towards a More Safe and Secure World_  Regional Collaboration to Combat Transnational Crime (1).docx

name: San Diego Harbor Police (SDHP)
description: The SDHP operates under the Port of San Diego. It provides law enforcement and public safety services in San Diego Bay, the adjacent tidelands, and at San Diego International Airport. Participants will meet with SDHP officers to learn how this local police authority patrols both the maritime borders of San Diego and the international airport, involving operations on land, sea, and in the air.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Towards a More Safe and Secure World_  Regional Collaboration to Combat Transnational Crime (1).docx

name: San Diego Law Enforcement Coordination Center (SD-LECC)
description: The San Diego Law Enforcement Coordination Center (SD-LECC) is the all crimes, all hazards fusion center and serves as the High Intensity Drug Trafficking Area (SD/I HIDTA) Investigative Support Center (ISC) for the San Diego and Imperial County region. The SD-LECC also serves as the Regional Threat Assessment Center (RTAC) for San Diego and Imperial counties and is part of the California State Threat Assessment System (STAS). The SD-LECC operates as a collaborative partnership among federal, state and local law enforcement/public safety agencies focused on enhancing coordination, information sharing, regional preparedness, training and investigative support/analysis for first responders and other public and private partners in the region.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Towards a More Safe and Secure World_  Regional Collaboration to Combat Transnational Crime (1).docx

name: U.S. Immigration & Customs Enforcement (ICE): Homeland Security Investigations (HSI)
description: HSI is a critical investigative arm of the Department of Homeland Security and is a vital U.S. asset in combating criminal organizations illegally exploiting America's travel, trade, financial and immigration systems. HSI’s workforce includes special agents, analysts, auditors and support staff. Its men and women are assigned to cities throughout the United States and to offices around the world. HSI’s international force is the department’s largest investigative presence abroad and gives HSI one of the largest international footprints in U.S. law enforcement.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Towards a More Safe and Secure World_  Regional Collaboration to Combat Transnational Crime (1).docx

name: Border Enforcement Security Task Force (BEST)
description: The primary mission of the Homeland Security Investigations’ (HSI) Border Enforcement Security Task Force (BEST) is to combat emerging and existing Transnational Criminal Organizations (TCO) by employing the full range of federal, state, local, tribal and international law enforcement authorities and resources in the fight to identify, investigate, disrupt and dismantle these organizations at every level of operation. The BEST investigative model is a comprehensive response to the growing threat to border security, public safety and national security. BESTs eliminate the barriers between federal and local investigations (access to both federal and state prosecutors) and close the gap with international partners in multinational criminal investigations. BESTs also create an environment that minimizes the vulnerabilities in our operations that TCOs have traditionally capitalized on to exploit our nation’s land and sea borders. trafficking; marine task force; and contraband smuggling. Government Resources
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Towards a More Safe and Secure World_  Regional Collaboration to Combat Transnational Crime (1).docx

name: City of San Diego, Office of Homeland Security
description: The San Diego Office of Homeland Security oversees the City's emergency Prevention and Protection Program; Mitigation and Finance Program; Response and Recovery Program; and leads regional efforts for FEMA's Urban Area Security Initiative. The Office of Homeland Security strives to promote a secure and resilient City with the capabilities required across the whole community to prevent, protect against, mitigate, respond to, and recover from threats and hazards that pose the greatest risk. These risks include natural hazards such as wildfires, earthquakes, floods, and tsunami; human-caused threats such as terrorist attacks and cyber-attacks; and technological hazards such as power outages and utility interruptions.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Towards a More Safe and Secure World_  Regional Collaboration to Combat Transnational Crime (1).docx

name: United States Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA)
description: https://www.dea.gov/divisions/san-diego The mission of the DEA is to enforce the controlled substance laws and regulations of the United States and bring to criminal and civil justice system of the United States, or any other competent jurisdiction, those organizations and principal members of organizations, involved in the growing, manufacture, or distribution of controlled substances appearing in or destined for illicit traffic in the U.S.; and to recommend and support non-enforcement programs aimed at reducing the availability of illicit controlled substances on the domestic and international markets. The DEA has a division office in San Diego as well as a District Office in San Ysidro (a border city within San Diego County that includes the San Ysidro Port of Entry).
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Towards a More Safe and Secure World_  Regional Collaboration to Combat Transnational Crime (1).docx

name: U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) – San Diego Sector
description: The San Diego Sector of the U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) consists of more than 7,000 square miles and 66 linear miles of international boundary with Mexico. The San Diego Sector encompasses coastal beaches and expansive mesas to coastal and inland mountains, rugged canyons and high desert. Directly to the South of San Diego lie the Mexican cities of Tijuana and Tecate, Baja California - with a combined population of more than 2 million. Today, San Diego Sector is focused on addressing the continuously changing tactics of transnational criminal organizations. Due to increased land border security, transnational criminal organizations have shifted their illegal activities to include the aerial, subterranean, and maritime domains. In order to effectively protect America's borders, Border Patrol agents conduct their enforcement duties on foot, horseback, and mountain bikes, and utilize various types of vehicles including all-terrain vehicles. U.S. Customs and Border Protection's (CBP) - Air and Marine Operations (AMO) CBP’s AMO safeguards our Nation by anticipating and confronting security threats through our aviation and maritime law enforcement expertise, innovative capabilities, and partnerships at the border and beyond. The San Diego Air and Marine Branch is responsible for defending our international land and sea border from terrorists, illegal alien crossings and the smuggling of contraband. The branch provides air and marine response capabilities to the Border Patrol and Field Operations. In addition, the branch closely supports U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement offices throughout California.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Towards a More Safe and Secure World_  Regional Collaboration to Combat Transnational Crime (1).docx

name: U.S. Coast Guard – San Diego Sector
description: Located within the Homeland Security Department, the U.S. Coast Guard is unique as an armed force. Comprised of active duty, reserve, civilian, and auxiliary members, it provides a broad range of services to the American people in times of peace and war. The Coast Guard manages six major operational mission programs: maritime law enforcement, maritime response, maritime prevention, marine transportation system management, maritime security operations, and defense operations. The 11th Coast Guard District encompasses the states of California, Arizona, Nevada, and Utah; their coastal and offshore waters out over thousand miles; and the offshore waters of Mexico and Central America down to South America. Coast Guard operational units are located throughout the state of California. Education Resources Border Tour SDDC can arrange a half-day tour of the U.S.-Mexico border, with a guide familiar with border operations, policy, and issues. Stops along the tour may include Barrio Logan, Friendship Park, San Ysidro Port of Entry, Otay Mesa Port of Entry, and Cross Border Xpress. *$250 honorarium required for the guide.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Towards a More Safe and Secure World_  Regional Collaboration to Combat Transnational Crime (1).docx

name: San Diego State University (SDSU), Graduate Program in Homeland Security
description: SDSU’s Graduate Program in Homeland Security was the first graduate-level Homeland Security program offered in the United States. It is consistently rated in the top two graduate-level national security programs. The program focuses on issues ranging from cyber security, counter-human trafficking, child slavery, counter-narcotics, to food and water security issues - seeking not only to eliminate the bad actors who create and capitalize upon human suffering, but also the economic and security conditions that allow black market and organized crime networks to flourish. The program is working hard to help create a world in which people of all nations have enough to eat, have meaningful economic opportunities, and feel safe in their homes, schools, and businesses.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Towards a More Safe and Secure World_  Regional Collaboration to Combat Transnational Crime (1).docx

name: The San Diego Human Trafficking Research and Data Advisory Roundtable (HT-   	RADAR)
description: HT-RADAR is a collaborative research environment for San Diego / Tijuana (SD/TJ) region data analysts and researchers who have skills and interests related to human trafficking. HT-RADAR was launched by Dr. Jamie Gates from Point Loma Nazarene University / Center for Justice and Reconciliation (PLNU/CJR) and is now evolving into a professional network. PLNU/CJR operates a centralized clearinghouse for human trafficking related research in the SD/TJ region. Meeting focus: Explore the impact of human trafficking on the local border region, and how research and university communities contribute to combating TIP.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Towards a More Safe and Secure World_  Regional Collaboration to Combat Transnational Crime (1).docx

name: Partners Against Exploitation at University of San Diego
description: Partners Against Exploitation (PAX) is a USD-led initiative to prevent human trafficking and other forms of exploitation through advocacy, education, and cross-sector partnerships. PAX work is evidence-based and grounded in the social justice values of equity, co-creation and diversity. The PAX Initiative, which is part of the University of San Diego’s Urgent Challenges Collective, is a complex partnership that brings together the campus-wide community of students, faculty and staff changemakers who have established expertise on issues as well as policymakers, advocates and those with lived experiences. Their groundbreaking study "Measuring the Nature and Extent of Gang Involvement in Sex Trafficking in San Diego" and other USD research has driven successful local and state policies which are victim-centered and focused on early intervention. Judiciary Resources
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Towards a More Safe and Secure World_  Regional Collaboration to Combat Transnational Crime (1).docx

name: U.S. Attorney’s Office of the Southern District of California - Border Enforcement Section
description: https://www.justice.gov/usao-sdca/criminal-division The U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of California is the chief prosecutor for the United States in criminal law cases in the Southern District of California and represents the United States in civil law cases as either the defendant or plaintiff, as appropriate. The Border Enforcement Section is the largest section in the Criminal Division and accounts for approximately 95 percent of the cases prosecuted in the Southern District of California. BES handles a large volume of reactive cases that arise from policing the 141-mile long border between California and Mexico, six Ports of Entry, and the roughly 70 miles of coastline stretching from the U.S.-Mexico border to the northernmost tip of San Diego County. Such cases commonly include illegal entry and reentry, drug importation and smuggling, and alien smuggling prosecutions. BES attorneys try a large number of cases and also often oversee the use of investigative tools like search and tracking warrants, undercover operations and confidential sources. San Diego County District Attorney's Office www.sdcda.org The San Diego County District Attorney's Office has the responsibility and authority to investigate and prosecute all felonies in San Diego County. The jurisdiction covers 42-hundred square miles. This area stretches from the northern areas of Oceanside and Vista to the eastern area of Alpine all the way to the US-Mexican border at Imperial Beach and Tecate. The District Attorney's Office also prosecutes misdemeanor crimes in unincorporated areas of the County as well as all cities within the County other than the city of San Diego. The San Diego District Attorney's Office is the second largest in the state of California and the sixth largest in the nation, serving a population of approximately three million people. Case Issuance/Extraditions The Case Issuance and Extradition Division is responsible for reviewing cases for potential charges, coordinating domestic and international extraditions and overseeing a number of units involving clemency, prior criminal conduct and more. Sex Crimes and Human Trafficking Division This division is comprised of a highly-trained and specialized team of Deputy District Attorneys, District Attorney Investigators, paralegals and secretaries who are all dedicated to aggressive and just prosecution of perpetrators of sexual assault and human trafficking crimes. The division strives to treat the victims of sexual assaults with compassion, dignity, and respect. NGO Resources
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Towards a More Safe and Secure World_  Regional Collaboration to Combat Transnational Crime (1).docx

name: Alabaster Jar Project
description: The Alabaster Jar Project is a 501(c)3 nonprofit organization dedicated to empowering survivors of human trafficking and sexual exploitation through long term housing and restorative practices. Based out of North County, AJP has expanded since 2013 to provide three main programs to trafficking survivors. AJP’s Grace House is a long-term community living residential program with customized wraparound services. The organization’s Resource Center provides clothing, toiletries, referrals, and emotional, educational and vocational development programs. Peer Support Groups navigate healing and recovery from trafficking and exploitation, led by survivors with a focus on forging connections and healthy relationships. The Alabaster Jar Project works closely with the local community and public/private partners to raise awareness and continue to support current and future survivors.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Towards a More Safe and Secure World_  Regional Collaboration to Combat Transnational Crime (1).docx

name: San Diego Trafficking Prevention Collective
description: The San Diego Trafficking Prevention Collective (SDPTC) is an end-to-end prevention education program that aims to protect every student from exploitation, working hand-in-hand with school districts to ensure they have the proper prevention measures and agile programming to respond to the unique needs of diverse youth. The SDPTC’s multistage educational program combines effective training of educational staff, early childhood education, participatory theatre, lived-experience expert voices, and age-appropriate classroom-based curricula to decrease the number of children involved in human trafficking in San Diego. The programs are available at no cost to San Diego County Public Schools. SDPTC programs have been implemented at over 300 schools across the United States, educating 50,000+ students and engaging 70,000+ community members.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Towards a More Safe and Secure World_  Regional Collaboration to Combat Transnational Crime (1).docx

name: CSA San Diego County
description: CSA San Diego County is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization whose primary mission is the promotion of social justice and public welfare through programs, services, and advocacy against all forms of discrimination, including advocacy for the eradication of housing discrimination to assure equal housing opportunity for all individuals. Other no cost services include: hate crime prevention, civic engagement and human trafficking prevention and education. CSA is dedicated to helping those who have fallen victim to this heinous crime and providing attorney referrals to victims of labor exploitation and victims of discrimination. They focus on prevention of trafficking, protection of victims, and prosecution of traffickers. CSA provides assistance in the recovery of lost wages, referrals for legal services, educating on constitutional rights, enforcing fair labor laws, and more. Media Resources
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Towards a More Safe and Secure World_  Regional Collaboration to Combat Transnational Crime (1).docx

name: Investigative reporter Monica Dean, NBC 7 San Diego
description: Monica Dean is a National Edward R. Murrow Award-winning anchor/reporter for NBC 7 San Diego, co-anchor of NBC 7’s 4 & 5 p.m. weekday newscasts. Her year-long investigation into the sex trafficking and exploitation of children in San Diego and beyond are the basis of a seven-episode documentary series, “STOLEN”. Since the launch of “STOLEN” in August 2020, Monica’s work has been recognized with a Radio Television Digital News Association (RTDNA) National Murrow Award for “Excellence in Innovation,” three Regional Murrow Awards, a Golden Mike Award, four Emmy Awards, Silver and Bronze “Telly” Awards, and three awards from the Society of Professional Journalists San Diego chapter. In her nearly two decades at NBC 7, Monica has won Emmy Awards for coverage ranging from the 2007 San Diego Firestorms to the 2016 riots at the Donald Trump Rally in San Diego. Monica helped establish the KNSD Academy, an experiential learning program at NBC 7 & Telemundo 20 that introduces high school students to careers in TV News. She regularly emcees galas for a list of non-profit organizations that support children, sex trafficking survivors, and emergency preparedness/response.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Towards a More Safe and Secure World_  Regional Collaboration to Combat Transnational Crime (1).docx

name: Freelance reporter Lynn Walsh, Voice of San Diego.
description: Launched in 2005, Voice of San Diego was the first digital, nonprofit news organization in the country to serve a local community. Its founders, longtime columnist and editor Neil Morgan and entrepreneur Buzz Woolley, felt the region desperately needed more reporting, analysis and journalistic competition. VOSD made a name for itself by producing hard-hitting investigative reports along with civic engagement opportunities that gave San Diego residents a new platform to discuss and debate the issues that impact their quality of life, becoming a pioneer in the nonprofit news industry through building a sustainable business model based on the support of individual members, sponsors and the investment of local and national foundations. Lynn Walsh is an Emmy award-winning freelance journalist who has worked in investigative, data and TV journalism at the national level as well as locally in California, Ohio, Texas and Florida. She produces content focused on government accountability, public access to information and freedom of expression issues. She’s also helping to rebuild trust between newsrooms and the public through the Trusting News project. Policy Maker Resources
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Towards a More Safe and Secure World_  Regional Collaboration to Combat Transnational Crime (1).docx

name: Office of Senator Toni G. Atkins, California State Senate.
description: Senator Toni G. Atkins, born in Virginia, moved to San Diego in 1985 where she began her career advocating for women’s healthcare. After working as an aide to LGBT trailblazer Christine Kehoe, Atkins was elected to the San Diego City Council and later served as interim mayor. She was elected to the California Assembly in 2010, becoming the first LGBTQ+ Speaker in 2014. In 2016, she joined the state Senate, becoming its first female and openly LGBTQ President pro Tempore. A champion for affordable housing, healthcare, veterans, and the LGBTQ community, Atkins has authored landmark legislation, including affordable housing initiatives and a constitutional amendment for abortion rights. She lives in San Diego with her spouse and their two dogs. Meeting focus: Meet with Senator Atkins’ San Diego Office staff to discuss her role in Senate Bill 970 (Atkins, 2018), which required hotels and motels to provide at least 20 minutes of prescribed training and education regarding human trafficking awareness. Discuss broader policy avenues to combat human trafficking.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal_ Towards a More Safe and Secure World_  Regional Collaboration to Combat Transnational Crime (1).docx

name: Center on Policy Initiatives
description: CPI is a nonprofit research and action institute dedicated to creating economic prosperity, sustainable communities, and a healthy environment for all.  CPI serves a unique role in the San Diego region, providing the analysis, policy solutions, education, and alliances that advance social and economic justice for working people and diverse communities. They also bring a focus on racial justice to their work for economic justice. Equity for all communities requires correcting for past discrimination and oppression, in addition to providing equal opportunities.

name: San Diego Regional Human Trafficking & Commercial Sexual Exploitation of Children (CSEC) Advisory Council
description: The San Diego Regional Human Trafficking and Commercial Sexual Exploitation of Children Advisory Council’s (HT-CSEC Advisory Council) vision is a united San Diego region working collaboratively to create long term, systematic change effectively addressing human trafficking and the commercial sexual exploitation of children. Formed in 2011, HT Advisory Council serves as an advisory committee of the County of San Diego Board of Supervisors. They provide recommendations and implementation proposals with the goal of identifying best practices and promising trends in addressing the root causes of trafficking and exploitation, advancing public policy, standardizing training and protocols, and enhance victim services by creating an optimized, seamless service delivery system. The HT Advisory Council consists of representatives from ten distinct groups representing different disciplines involved in the anti-human trafficking community that evolved over time. Meetings are open to the public. Note: Please keep in mind that federal meetings must be taken care of by the NPA through the gatekeeper. SDDC is happy to take care of logistics once secured. _______________________________ Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $58 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. It is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park.

name: Harbor Cruise
description: Price: $33 for one Adult Ticket for two-hour tour Their deluxe tour covers it all: Harbor and Shelter Islands, Point Loma, Cabrillo National Monument, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and much more. Tour is about 25 miles in length, 2 hour narrated tour. Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego Price: $42 for one Adult Ticket For over 20 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours highlighting the best San Diego attractions. Old Town Trolley Tours is the best way to see the city, highlighting the best San Diego Attractions, with 11 stops and more than 100 points of interest. Old Town offers much to do, from visiting over 23 historic sites to shopping for unique merchandise. They also have many award winning restaurants to choose from. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 29 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 15 major museums, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Coronado Consistently voted one of America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year around due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. From the shores of Silver Strand State Beach to the tip of the Coronado Municipal Beach, you’ll find plenty of wide open sand, gentle waves and gorgeous views. SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $94 for one Adult Ticket Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Shamu show, One Ocean, and thrilling rides like Journey To Atlantis, Shipwreck Rapids and Wild Arctic. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Then dive into the world of sea turtles at the all-new Turtle Reef attraction.

name: BHE Renewables - Imperial Valley Geothermal Area
description: The Imperial Valley Geothermal Project consists of 10 generating plants in the Salton Sea, in Southern California's Imperial Valley. The project has a combined capacity of approximately 327 net megawatts. Geothermal plants can generate emissions-free, renewable electricity constantly using the Earth’s natural heat to generate clean energy, unlike solar panels or wind turbines. To meet California's energy goals by 2045, geothermal energy is rising in popularity. A meeting in this region may be supported by a driving tour, accompanied by a representative to discuss the growing and evolving renewable energy movement in California and the U.S. Sustainable Energy & Green Building Solutions Tenaska Imperial Solar https://www.tenaska.com/ As California electricity providers strive to meet the requirements of the state's Renewables Portfolio Standard, Tenaska has been developing solar energy projects in Imperial County. Tenaska Solar Ventures, LLC (TSV) manages solar projects in North America. TSV has several utility-scale projects in Imperial County in Southern California. Current projects range from 130 to 160 megawatts (MW) and are among the largest solar generating facilities in California powering almost 100,000 homes. Tenaska Imperial Solar Energy Center South was the first large-scale solar project to begin construction in Imperial County, and it is the first large-scale solar project to transmit power from the Imperial Valley via San Diego Gas & Electric's (SDG&E) new Sunrise Powerlink transmission line. It is also one of the largest commercially financed solar projects in the U.S. to date. Nonprofits Combating Climate Change

name: Climate Action Campaign
description: Climate Action Campaign's mission is to stop the climate crisis through effective policy action. Climate Action Campaign (CAC) was founded in San Diego in 2015 by their Executive Director, Nicole Capretz to ensure the City of San Diego's draft landmark Climate Action Plan (CAP) became law, which Nicole authored while working in the Mayor's office. A broad-based and non-traditional coalition of elected officials, businesses, community planning groups, civic organizations, labor unions, and environmental and social justice organizations emerged, unified behind the trailblazing plan. Through the lens of equity and justice, they are fighting for a Zero Carbon future with all-electric homes, world class transit, resiliency, 100% clean energy, and bike-able, walkable neighborhoods. They believe change happens from the group up.
source_proposal: IVLP_ Digital Innovation in Climate Resilience Proposal.docx

name: The Maritime Alliance
description: The Maritime Alliance (TMA) is a leading non-profit industry association dedicated to advancing the San Diego maritime technology sector. As a cluster organizer, TMA focuses on promoting innovation and economic development within the Blue Economy. Their mission centers on fostering BlueTech and advancing sustainable, science-based practices within ocean and water industries through education, policy advocacy, and technology resources. Grid Alternatives www.gridalternatives.org Grid Alternatives is a non-profit solar installer that leads teams of volunteers and job trainees to install solar electric systems exclusively for low-income homeowners. Through their core program, the Solar Affordable Housing Program, they have installed more than 12 mega-watts of clean, renewable power for over 4,000 families, preventing the release of 340,000 tons of greenhouse gasses over the systems’ lifetimes and providing more than $110 million in energy cost savings. More than 15,000 volunteers and job trainees have also received hands-on solar installation experience to-date. Education Resources University of California San Diego, Adaptation and Solutions Adaptation and Solutions (ucsd.edu) The University of California San Diego, Adaptation and Solutions program supports positive change in the future through social engagement and offers mitigation strategies for the current negative impacts of climate change. This research theme encompasses energy alternatives, infrastructure, engineering, urban planning, sustainable food production and green industry. In addition, sociologists, psychologists, artists and communications researchers focus on the social implications of adaptation. StartBlue StartBlue, an accelerator program by the Scripps Institution of Oceanography and the Rady School of Management, supports the development of advanced science and engineering startups focused on ocean-related challenges. The program aims to drive innovation and address critical issues affecting ocean ecosystems through entrepreneurial ventures. Center for Energy Research The Center for Energy Research at UC San Diego is dedicated to solving society’s energy supply challenges through interdisciplinary research. The center focuses on a range of energy solutions, including fusion energy, renewable resources, and advanced technologies to meet growing energy demands. UC San Diego Deep Decarbonization Initiative The Deep Decarbonization Initiative at UC San Diego aims to guide the global economy towards net-zero carbon emissions. The initiative focuses on understanding the transition from existing energy systems to new, sustainable ones and the pace at which these changes occur, providing valuable insights for policymakers and investors.

name: City of San Diego Our Climate Our Future
description: The City of San Diego's "Our Climate, Our Future" initiative is a plan to achieve net zero greenhouse gas emissions citywide by 2035. This initiative focuses on equitable and sustainable solutions, aiming to enhance economic opportunities, protect vulnerable communities, and improve both urban and natural environments. Key strategies include increasing the use of renewable energy, expanding green infrastructure, promoting sustainable transportation, and building climate resilience. The plan underscores the city's commitment to addressing climate change while ensuring a healthy, thriving future for all residents.

name: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) – Border Liaison Office, San Diego - Border 2025
description: Established in 1994, the EPA Border Liaison Office in San Diego supports binational efforts to address environmental issues along the U.S.-Mexico border. The U.S.-Mexico Environmental Program: Border 2025 is a five-year initiative (2021-2025) aimed at protecting the environment and public health in the border region. The program focuses on energy efficiency, reducing air pollution, and improving access to clean water, while engaging with border stakeholders for long-term environmental conservation. Meeting focus: Examine the goals of the Border 2025 initiative, particularly in relation to energy efficiency, air pollution reduction, and clean water access. Discuss the binational perspective on environmental protection and explore ways to enhance environmental initiatives with neighboring border countries.

name: San Diego County Health and Human Services Agency (HHSA)
description: The Health and Human Services Agency (HHSA) in San Diego plays a critical role in safeguarding the health and well-being of the community through its comprehensive public health services. The HHSA is responsible for a wide range of initiatives, including disease prevention, emergency preparedness, vaccination campaigns, and the management of infectious disease outbreaks. With a focus on reducing health disparities, the HHSA works to ensure equitable access to care for all residents, particularly vulnerable populations. By coordinating resources, conducting health education, and promoting preventive measures, the HHSA is instrumental in building a healthier, more resilient San Diego.

name: The Public Health Alliance of Southern California
description: The Public Health Alliance of Southern California is a coalition of health organizations and experts committed to advocating for policies that promote better public health, with a particular focus on underserved communities. Their work centers on health equity, policy reform, and fostering collaboration to address public health challenges, including infectious diseases. The Alliance aims to leverage data and collective action to advance both health and racial equity, mobilizing health departments to collaborate and adopt policies that are equitable and inclusive. Through cross-sector partnerships involving government agencies, legislators, hospitals, health plans, and community advocates, they champion bold policies and programs that drive health justice and racial equity.

name: UC San Diego Global Health Program
description: UC San Diego’s Global Health Program emphasizes transnational health issues, determinants, and solutions; involves many disciplines within and beyond the health sciences and promotes interdisciplinary collaboration; and is a synthesis of population-based prevention with individual-level clinical care.  UC San Diego is one of only a handful global health programs in North America where students can gain a comprehensive initiation to the exciting and rapidly growing field of Global Health.

name: Radhika Bhavsar, Global Public Health and the Center on Gender Equity and Health
description: Radhika Bhavsar is a public health strategist and certified health educator with expertise in designing and managing programs in resource limited settings using an entrepreneurial lens. Radhika has 13 years of comprehensive work experience in community and government healthcare systems in the U.S., East Africa, and West Africa. In 2016 she was a Global Health Corp Fellow working in collaboration with the Ministry of Health, Rwanda on digital health tools and currently works for Partners In Health leading efforts to decrease community spread of COVID-19. Areas of interest include health system strengthening, implementation science, population health, health equity, strategic planning and communications, monitoring and evaluation, and program and project management using lean methodology.

name: San Diego Center for Aids Research
description: The San Diego CFAR promotes scientific and clinical studies in HIV and fosters researchers using innovative strategies to advance our research priorities of preventing new infections, optimizing HIV care, and developing a cure while promoting health equity for people with and at risk for HIV. The overall objective of the San Diego CFAR is to have a meaningful impact on HIV research by fostering our local HIV researchers using innovative and efficient strategies. A key service of San Diego CFAR is the Health Equity Sociobehavioral Science Core, designed to improve health equity and decrease disparities across the HIV prevention and treatment continuum. Their foremost goal is to increase access to and retention in HIV prevention and treatment for vulnerable and underserved communities, including gender minorities, women who have experience violence, and women engaged in sex work. PCI focuses on tackling pressing public health issues such as HIV/AIDS, maternal health, and infectious disease prevention. Through innovative programs and partnerships, PCI has reached over 4.4 million people globally and has helped build long-term resilience in vulnerable populations. name: San Diego Refugee Communities Coalition
description: The San Diego Refugee Communities Coalition (SDRCC) is a community-based organization dedicated to advocating for and supporting refugees and immigrants in the San Diego region. With a focus on empowering refugee communities, SDRCC provides vital resources, including access to healthcare, education, housing, legal services, and employment opportunities. The coalition works closely with refugee populations to address their unique needs, including the prevention and treatment of infectious diseases, and strives to reduce health disparities faced by these vulnerable groups. By promoting integration and self-sufficiency, SDRCC helps refugees and immigrants navigate their new lives while fostering community solidarity and resilience. Through partnerships with local health systems and community organizations, SDRCC is committed to advancing health equity and improving the overall well-being of refugee populations.

Through public health education, testing, and treatment services, the branch plays a critical role in combating these diseases, especially in vulnerable populations. By engaging in public health campaigns and ensuring that preventative measures, such as vaccination and education, are accessible, they work to reduce the spread of infectious diseases. Their initiatives are guided by a focus on health equity and reducing the burden of communicable diseases in marginalized communities.

description: The San Diego Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Transgender Community Center, Inc., (The Center) is one of the largest and most vibrant LGBTQ community centers in the nation. Functioning as the San Diego LGBTQ community’s anchor organization, The Center provides targeted programs and services to the full diversity of the San Diego LGBTQ community, including lesbian, gay, bisexual, queer, transgender, nonbinary, immigrant, and HIV communities to the betterment of our entire San Diego region. name: The San Diego County Black Infant Health Program (BIH):
description: https://www.sandiegocounty.gov/content/sdc/hhsa/programs/phs/black_infant_health_program.html The San Diego County Black Infant Health Program (BIH) works to improve African-American infant and maternal health, as well as decrease health and social inequities for Black women and infants. The program uses a group-based approach with complementary client-centered case management to help participants develop life skills, strategies to reduce stress, and build social support. Pregnant African-American women benefit from the program by becoming empowered to make positive choices in their life, not only for themselves, but for their families, and future generations of African-American women, infants, and communities.

name: Binational Border Health:
description: https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/OBBH/Pages/OBBHHome.aspx The County Office of Border Health was established in February 1993 with the goal of facilitating communication and collaboration among local, state, and federal organizations working in the United States-Mexico border region. Local and cross-border health activities include coordinating binational meetings among public health officials and practitioners, organizing binational symposiums on a variety of shared health topics, facilitating communication around communicable disease control and prevention, and preparing for public health emergencies and threats. name: Chronic Disease and Health Equity Unit:
description: The mission of the Chronic Disease and Health Equity (CDHE) Unit is to promote wellness and prevention of illness, disability, and premature death from chronic disease by increasing health equity. not every neighborhood enjoys the advantages of healthy choices, such as access to fresh, locally grown food, safe physical activity options, or smoke-free environments. Since 2010, CDHE has led administration of HHSA programming known as Healthy Works. Healthy Works is a cornerstone of the Building Better Health component of Live Well San Diego, the County of San Diego's vision for creating healthy, safe, and thriving communities. Healthy Works aims to reduce and prevent chronic diseases by making healthy living easier and more affordable in the places we live, work, learn, and play. Healthy Works projects address lifestyle issues such as tobacco use, poor nutrition, and physical inactivity.  These three risk factors contribute to the four major chronic diseases—cancer, heart disease and stroke, type 2 diabetes, and lung disease—that lead to more than 50 percent of deaths in the county. Meeting focus: Explore how government efforts in San Diego are addressing key health concerns in the region and beyond. An exploration of one or more of the above campaigns may be explored, along with a discussion on the County’s cornerstone proactive initiatives through Live Well San Diego. name: San Diego Refugee Communities Coalition
description: The San Diego Refugee Communities Coalition (SDRCC) is a community-based organization dedicated to advocating for and supporting refugees and immigrants in the San Diego region. With a focus on empowering refugee communities, SDRCC provides vital resources, including access to healthcare, education, housing, legal services, and employment opportunities. The coalition works closely with refugee populations to address their unique needs, including the prevention and treatment of infectious diseases, and strives to reduce health disparities faced by these vulnerable groups. By promoting integration and self-sufficiency, SDRCC helps refugees and immigrants navigate their new lives while fostering community solidarity and resilience. Through partnerships with local health systems and community organizations, SDRCC is committed to advancing health equity and improving the overall well-being of refugee populations.

A broad-based and non-traditional coalition of elected officials, businesses, community planning groups, civic organizations, labor unions, and environmental and social justice organizations emerged, unified behind the trailblazing plan. The most pressing issues are raised by the people themselves and are then addressed through Momentum Teams, which are councils made up of residents from City Heights. description: The Institute of the Americas is dedicated to being a catalyst for promoting economic development and integration. The Institute of the Americas undertakes programs, develops policy papers and organizes conferences, roundtable discussions, and webinars addressing emerging issues of importance to countries across the Americas. The Institute’s Energy & Sustainability program has played a crucial role in shaping policy discourse and informing investors on the most important trends in the energy sector. Jeremy M. Martin is Vice President, Energy & Sustainability at the Institute of Americas. Martin has testified before the U.S. Congress on energy issues in Latin America, teaches a graduate course in Latin American Energy Policy at the University of California San Diego and the University of San Diego and serves on the Board of Advisors for the Inter-American Dialogue’s Energy Advisor newsletter. CleanTech San Diego www.cleantechsandiego.org CleanTech San Diego is a member organization that aims to stimulate innovation and advance the adoption of clean technologies and sustainable industry practices to augment the cleantech incubation cluster in San Diego. Their membership spans business and financial leaders, academic and research institutions, and government and non-profit organizations. Private Sector for Renewable Energy San Diego Gas & Electric, Energy Innovation Center (SDG&E) www.sdge.com/eic SDG&E is a regulated public utility that provides energy service to 3.6 million people through 1.4 million electric meters and 873,000 natural gas meters in San Diego and southern Orange counties. Their service area spans 4,100 square miles. The Energy Innovation Center at SDG&E is a working showcase that demonstrates smart energy initiatives and green building practices, all housed in one unique setting. This double LEED Platinum facility offers visitors a venue for learning and exploring the latest in energy efficiency, renewable energy, smart grid and alternative fuel technologies.

name: Sempra
description: Sempra Energy is a global energy infrastructure company focused on leading the way of advancing electrification and promoting energy diversification, resiliency and affordable access to cleaner forms of energy. From its San Diego headquarters to operations throughout the Americas, Sempra Energy is making strides in developing forward-thinking energy solutions and delivering everyday power to customers. Sempra Energy believes the global energy ecosystem is going to change dramatically over the next 30 years. In advanced economies, the change will take the form of innovation and technology that improves energy efficiency and supports a shift toward new, smart renewable and natural gas infrastructure. In developing nations, improving energy diversity will be the central effort as new, smart infrastructure that supports renewables and natural gas displaces higher carbon forms of energy.

name: Ocean Motion Technologies
description: Ocean Motion Technologies aims to scale ocean wave energy through lowering the cost of power at sea and enabling a new era of big blue data. The bluetech sector needs products in small-scale energy to fuel research and development needed to scale wave energy. Ocean Motion Technologies develops devices that are meant to last and reduce the cost for end users. Devices vary from the world’s first adaptive ocean wave energy converters controlled by an advanced artificial system to the world’s first compressed air energy storage system for marine applications.

name: Nuvve project with Cajon Valley Unified School District and San Diego Gas & Electric
description: https://www.sdgenews.com/article/sdge-and-cajon-valley-union-school-district-flip-switch-regions-first-vehicle-grid-project Combining the world’s most advanced vehicle-to-grid (V2G) technology and an ecosystem of electrification partners, Nuvve dynamically manages power among EV batteries and the grid to deliver new value to EV owners, and support the world’s transition to clean energy. By transforming EVs into mobile energy storage assets and networking battery capacity to support shifting energy needs, Nuvve is making the grid more resilient, enhancing sustainable transportation, and supporting energy equity in an electrified world. In July 2022, San Diego Gas & Electric, Nuvve, and Cajon Valley Union School District announced that it had successfully deployed an innovative technology that enables eight electric school buses to put electricity back on the grid when needed. description: The Sustainability and Mobility Department leads San Diego's Climate Action Plan. Centered on striving for equitable, efficient and effective mobility choices that support all communities, the Department continuously works to facilitate innovative efforts to enhance equitable, economic, social and environmental sustainability. The 2022 Climate Action Plan established a community-wide goal of net zero by 2035, committing San Diego to reducing the use of greenhouse gasses.

description: The San Diego Regional Clean Cities Coalition works with vehicle fleets, fuel providers, community leaders, and other stakeholders to identify community-driven choices that save energy and promote the use of alternative fuels and advanced vehicle technologies in transportation. Education Resources University of California, San Diego –  Center for Energy Research Jacobs School of Engineering: Advanced Energy Research Initiative www.jacobsschool.ucsd.edu/aeri/ UCSD’s Center for Energy Research was established to develop solutions for the growing challenges of energy supply and utilization, and is now one of UCSD’s largest organized research units. Members include internationally recognized scientists, faculty from various UCSD departments, visiting scholars, and students. Together, they perform basic and applied research in fusion, solar energy, fuel cells, energy storage, and related disciplines, to create solutions for the growing challenges of energy supply, distribution, and utilization.

name: Professor Byron Washom, Director of Strategic Energy Initiatives
description: Byron Washom is UC San Diego's first director of strategic energy initiatives. He has been a strategic advisor on a wide range of clean energy technologies to the World Bank, the International Energy Agency, U.S. Department of Energy, national laboratories, and numerous regulated utilities and corporations.  Future projects at UCSD include energy storage systems that adjust to the intermittency of renewable energy and provide permanent load shifting; strategic purchasing of renewable energy from the grid during periods of surpluses; co-production of hydrogen from its fuel cell system; utilizing cold ocean water from the adjacent La Jolla Trench; and converting the campus vehicle transportation fleet into cleaner, alternative fuels. A visit to UCSD would involve a discussion with Professor Byron Washom about how he is promoting UCSD’s sustainability initiatives, and a visit to the Center for Energy Research to explore how they foster an interdisciplinary approach to energy studies among a cross-section of university stakeholders. We also propose exploring UCSD’s energy microgrid and electric vehicle charging availability. UCSD reports savings of over $800,000 monthly thanks to energy provided by its very own microgrid University of California San Diego, Adaptation and Solutions Adaptation and Solutions (ucsd.edu) The University of California San Diego, Adaptation and Solutions program supports positive change in the future through social engagement and offers mitigation strategies for the current negative impacts of climate change. description: The Energy Policy Initiatives Center is a research center at the University of San Diego School of Law studying how energy policy issues affect California and the San Diego region. The Center strives to increase awareness and understanding of energy- climate-related policy issues by conducting research and analysis to inform decision-makers and educating law students. By drawing on expertise in law, policy, economics, and science, the Center brings together students, scholars, and practitioners within the school of law and serves the public interest.

name: Climate Equity in the San Diego Region
description: Climate Equity in the San Diego Region was developed at the University of San Diego Energy Policy Initiatives Center. The Climate Equity Index was first released in 2019 and evaluated environmental, socioeconomic, mobility, and health factors related to the impact of climate change and related policies. Climate equity is defined as “addressing historical and inequities suffered by people of color, allowing everyone to fairly share the same benefits and burdens from climate solutions and attain full and equal access to opportunities regardless of one’s background and identity.” The Index intended to assess the impact that climate change will have on certain communities and the barriers to new energy technologies. name: Tenaska Imperial Solar
description: As California electricity providers strive to meet the requirements of the state’s Renewables Portfolio Standard, Tenaska has been developing solar energy projects in Imperial County. Tenaska Solar Ventures, LLC (TSV) manages solar projects in North America. TSV has several utility-scale projects in Imperial County in Southern California. Current projects range from 130 to 160 megawatts (MW) and are among the largest solar generating facilities in California powering almost 100, 000 homes. Tenaska Imperial Solar Energy Center South was the first large-scale solar project to begin construction in Imperial County, and it is the first large-scale solar project to transmit power from the Imperial Valley via San Diego Gas & Electric’s (SDG&E) new Sunrise Powerlink transmission line. It is also one of the largest commercially financed solar projects in the U.S. to date.

name: BHE Renewables - Imperial Valley Geothermal Area
description: The Imperial Valley Geothermal Project consists of 10 generating plants in the Salton Sea, in Southern California's Imperial Valley. The project has a combined capacity of approximately 327 net megawatts. Geothermal plants can generate emissions-free, renewable electricity constantly using the Earth’s natural heat to generate clean energy, unlike solar panels or wind turbines. To meet California's energy goals by 2045, geothermal energy is rising in popularity. A meeting in this region may be supported by a driving tour, accompanied by a representative to discuss the growing and evolving renewable energy movement in California and the U.S.

name: Controlled Thermal Resources
description: By combining direct lithium extraction with renewable geothermal power, Controlled Thermal Resources is setting new benchmarks to provide renewable energy to the western U.S. and to deliver the most sustainable, battery-grade lithium products in the world today. Demand for lithium, which is used in batteries and energy storage systems to power cars, cities, and countries, is expected to surge by approximately 2 million tons per annum by 2030. The Controlled Thermal Resources leadership team has successfully developed and managed world-scale renewable energy projects in the Salton Sea region for over 20 years. Pattern Energy: Ocotillo Wind Project www.ocotillowind.com The Ocotillo Wind facility, owned by Pattern Energy, is an investment in the Imperial Valley region that is creating many economic benefits, including jobs and substantial growth in the property tax base. The Ocotillo Wind Project consists of 112 turbines, which have the annual power equivalent equal to the needs of approximately 125,000 homes. The project sells 100% of its electricity generation to San Diego Gas & Electric (“SDG&E”) under a long-term power purchase agreement. Ocotillo connects to the SDG&E 500 kV transmission system. The project is located on approximately 12,500 acres in Imperial County, CA and is almost entirely on federal land administered by the Bureau of Land Management. The project was granted a right-of-way by the Bureau of Land Management. Nonprofits for Renewable Energy California Center for Sustainable Energy (CCSE) www.energycenter.org The California Center for Sustainable Energy is an independent, nonprofit 501(c)(3) corporation that helps residents, businesses and public agencies save energy, reduce grid demand and generate their own power through a variety of re-bate, technical assistance and education programs. CCSE also provides the community with objective information, re-search, analysis and long-term planning on energy issues and technologies. They envision a future where transportation, buildings and communities are sustainable, equitable, and resilient.

description: The Naval Base Coronado (NBC), known as the "Navy's West Coast Quarterdeck in America's Finest City” is dedicated to providing exceptional base operating support programs and services that enhance the operational readiness of both ashore and afloat commands. Enjoy a tour of the U.S.S. Canberra while discussing how NBC is the U.S. Navy's largest base on the West Coast and the principal homeport of the Pacific Fleet. name: U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) – San Diego Sector
description: The San Diego Sector of the U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) consists of more than 7,000 square miles and 66 linear miles of international boundary with Mexico. The San Diego Sector encompasses coastal beaches and expansive mesas to coastal and inland mountains, rugged canyons and high desert. Directly to the South of San Diego lie the Mexican cities of Tijuana and Tecate, Baja California - with a combined population of more than 2 million. Today, San Diego Sector is focused on addressing the continuously changing tactics of transnational criminal organizations. Due to increased land border security, transnational criminal organizations have shifted their illegal activities to include the aerial, subterranean, and maritime domains. In order to effectively protect America's borders, Border Patrol agents conduct their enforcement duties on foot, horseback, and mountain bikes, and utilize various types of vehicles including all-terrain vehicles. U.S. Customs and Border Protection's (CBP) - Air and Marine Operations (AMO) CBP’s AMO safeguards our Nation by anticipating and confronting security threats through our aviation and maritime law enforcement expertise, innovative capabilities, and partnerships at the border and beyond. The San Diego Air and Marine Branch is responsible for defending our international land and sea border from terrorists, illegal alien crossings and the smuggling of contraband. The branch provides air and marine response capabilities to the Border Patrol and Field Operations. In addition, the branch closely supports U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement offices throughout California.
source_proposal: IVLP_ U.S. Foreign Policy - Global Challenges Proposal (1).docx

name: U.S. Immigration & Customs Enforcement (ICE): Homeland Security Investigations (HSI)
description: HSI is a critical investigative arm of the Department of Homeland Security and is a vital U.S. asset in combating criminal organizations illegally exploiting America's travel, trade, financial and immigration systems. HSI’s workforce includes special agents, analysts, auditors and support staff. Its men and women are assigned to cities throughout the United States and to offices around the world. HSI’s international force is the department’s largest investigative presence abroad and gives HSI one of the largest international footprints in U.S. law enforcement.
source_proposal: IVLP_ U.S. Foreign Policy - Global Challenges Proposal (1).docx

name: Border Enforcement Security Task Force (BEST)
description: The primary mission of the Homeland Security Investigations’ (HSI) Border Enforcement Security Task Force (BEST) is to combat emerging and existing Transnational Criminal Organizations (TCO) by employing the full range of federal, state, local, tribal and international law enforcement authorities and resources in the fight to identify, investigate, disrupt and dismantle these organizations at every level of operation. The BEST investigative model is a comprehensive response to the growing threat to border security, public safety and national security. BESTs eliminate the barriers between federal and local investigations (access to both federal and state prosecutors) and close the gap with international partners in multinational criminal investigations. BESTs also create an environment that minimizes the vulnerabilities in our operations that TCOs have traditionally capitalized on to exploit our nation’s land and sea borders. (Note: Usually, the meetings above are directly coordinated by the NPA and then loop SDDC in to arrange logistics.) Border Tour *$500 honorarium required Tour of the San Diego-Tijuana Border The largest land border crossing in the world, the San Ysidro border crossing plays an integral role in San Diego and Tijuana’s close knit, collaborative relationship. The majority of people living in communities on the San Diego side of the border are people of color, with over 50% of residents identifying as Hispanic or Latinx, whose diversity of experience contributes to a rich hub of culture, experience, and opportunity. San Diego and Tijuana have long prospered from good-humored cross border relations, recently made even more successful with the honor of being jointly named the Innovation Design Hub for 2024. However, while cross-border collaboration and innovation are things to celebrate, there is lots of work to do on the ground among the minority and immigrant communities living in the border region, to ensure quality of life and access to resources are supported. Proposed stops on the border tour include:

name: San Ysidro Point of Entry: The main artery between San Diego and Tijuana – and, in fact, the U.S. and Mexico – which sees approximately 120,000 passenger vehicles, 60,000 pedestrians, and 6000 trucks crossing back and forth each day, the San Ysidro border is evidence of San Diego and Tijuana’s dynamic relationship. While participants cannot cross into Mexico, they will be able to see over the wall into Mexico, and stand on the bridge atop the border, which leads to the pedestrian crossing site.
url: Cross Border Express (CBX) https://www.crossborderxpress.com/en/ CBX is a pedestrian bridge for passengers of the Tijuana International Airport that allows passengers to cross the U.S.-Mexico border with ease. The facility saves millions of passengers from being delayed at the San Ysidro border crossing by enabling processing via a service terminal on the San Diego side of the border.
description: Friendship Park: Friendship Park is a binational park situated on the U.S.-Mexico border, overlooking the ocean. Since its opening by Pat Nixon 51 years ago, the park has served as a meeting point for families who have been separated by immigration laws. For some families, Friendship Park offers the only opportunity to reunite with loved ones unable to cross the border. Friendship Park, particularly on the Mexico side, has been cultivated by the community into a place of art and gathering, with regular art installations featured and frequent cross-border events like church sermons and yoga classes. description: UDW is a union made up of more than 171,000 home care and family child care providers throughout California. Created by members of the Cesar Chavez movement - they noticed that care work was excluded from labor rights and protections. UDW has fought systemic injustices garnering care workers paid sick time, vacation pay, and overtime.

name: Unite Here! - Local 30, San Diego County Hotel and Food Service Workers’ Union
description: UNITE HERE Local 30 is the leading hotel and hospitality workers’ union in San Diego, representing over 6,000 dedicated employees in the hotel, gaming, and food service sectors across San Diego County. Their mission is to empower workers to earn a living wage and work with dignity, advocating for better wages, benefits, and workplace conditions for our members. With a strong focus on negotiating excellent contracts, giving workers a voice on the job, and organizing non-union workers, UNITE HERE Local 30 stands at the forefront of labor rights in the region. American Federation of State, County, and Municipal Employees (AFSCME) Local 127 afscme127.org American Federation of State, County, and Municipal Employees (AFSCME) Local 127 is a prominent union that represents workers in a wide range of public service sectors, including state, county, and municipal employees. With a deep-rooted commitment to improving the lives of public workers, AFSCME Local 127 advocates for fair wages, better working conditions, and the protection of workers' rights. Businesses Empowering Women

name: NAWBO San Diego
description: The National Association of Women Business Owners (NAWBO) is the voice of America's 10.6 million women-owned businesses. Since 1975, NAWBO has helped women evolve their businesses by sharing resources and providing a single voice to shape economic and public policy. NAWBO is a non-profit organization of more than 8,000 members that represents women business owners across all industries to strengthen the wealth-creating capacity of members and promote economic development within the entrepreneurial community. NAWBO San Diego is one of about 80 chapters across the U.S. Meeting focus: This meeting will provide a valuable networking opportunity with leaders from the National Association of Women Business Owners (NAWBO), where attendees will have the chance to learn how NAWBO members advocate for policies that foster a supportive business environment for women entrepreneurs.

name: Athena San Diego
description: Athena San Diego’s mission is to promote professional growth for women executives and rising managers in science and technology fields such as life sciences, healthcare, defense, engineering, and related industries, as well as the service providers who support these sectors. Personal and professional growth is fostered through unique educational and motivational programs that address key issues in these industries. Athena also provides networking opportunities that contribute to the vitality of women’s roles in business and nurtures the next generation of women executives. Meeting focus: Examining the policies and initiatives that help women leaders advance in STEM sectors and break through the traditional, male-dominated hierarchy of the labor market.

name: National Organization for Women (NOW) – San Diego Chapter
description: NOW is a powerful force for gender equality, advocating for the rights of women across various sectors, including labor, education, healthcare, and politics. NOW is one of the most influential feminist organizations in the U.S., with a mission to achieve equal rights for all women. The San Diego chapter of NOW plays a key role in advancing women’s rights in the local community, with a strong focus on addressing workplace issues and improving the representation of women in leadership roles. Through grassroots advocacy, public education, and direct action, NOW San Diego works to eliminate discrimination based on gender, race, and sexual orientation. Hera Hub www.herahub.com Hera Hub is the first international female-focused co-working space – a shared, flexible work and meeting space where entrepreneurial women can create and collaborate in a professional, productive, modern environment. The platform provides members with connections to other business experts, access to educational workshops, and visibility within the community, thus giving women the support they need to be prosperous. The company was founded in San Diego, CA in 2011 and has since then been growing with locations sprouting up all over the U.S. and Europe. Hera Hub has supported over 20,000 women. name: Congresswoman-elect Sara Jacobs
description: Sara Jacobs is the U.S. Representative for California's 53rd congressional district. Before winning election for California’s 53rd congressional district, Sara is the Founder and Chair of San Diego for Every Child: The Coalition to End Child Poverty. In addition to her role at San Diego for Every Child, Sara has dedicated much of her time and energy to electing a new generation of leaders — women, young people, people of color, members of the LGBTQ+ community, and other underrepresented communities. Sara has also served in policy positions at the U.S. State Department during the Obama Administration, UNICEF, and the United Nations, and as a Scholar in Residence at the Joan B. Kroc School of Peace Studies at the University of San Diego. Run Women Run www.runwomenrun.org Run Women Run was founded in 2008 by a group of forward-thinking women who demonstrated that individuals with a passion can change the status quo. The non-partisan, membership association seeks to bring rationality and accountability back to government by identifying, mentoring and supporting the election of progressive, pro-choice women to state and local government in San Diego County. name: San Diego County Sustainable Ground Water Management
description: San Diego County overlies a complex, finite, yet renewable groundwater resource that varies greatly throughout the region. This resource provides the only supply of water for most residents living in the eastern two thirds of the County (shown in green on map). The western portion of the County is mostly supplied with imported water from member agencies of the San Diego County Water Authority. To facilitate drought and water shortage preparedness for state small water systems and domestic wells, Planning & Development Services in collaboration with the Department of Environmental Health and Quality maintains a list of drought resources (provided below) to implement short- and long-term solutions for residents and communities facing a risk of water shortage.
source_proposal: Proposal - Building Drought Preparedness and Resilience.docx

name: California Water Board, San Diego Commercial Agriculture Regulatory Program
description: Since the 1980s, the San Diego Water Board has regulated discharges from agricultural and nursery operations (Agricultural Operations) within its jurisdictional boundaries by requiring the implementation of management measures and/or best management practices to prevent or minimize the discharge of pollutants that may adversely impact the quality or beneficial uses of the waters of the State. In 2016, the San Diego Water Board adopted Order No. R9-2016-0004 (Third-Party General Order) and Order No. R9-2016-0005 (Individual General Order). Collectively, both Orders are referred to as the General Agricultural Orders. The San Diego Water Board requires all owners or operators of Commercial Agricultural Operations in the San Diego Region to comply with the General Agricultural Orders. Commercial Agricultural Operations are defined as any agricultural business or trade activity, including farms, nurseries, and orchards, that produce crops or ornamental plants with the intent to make a profit.
source_proposal: Proposal - Building Drought Preparedness and Resilience.docx

name: San Diego County Agriculture - Agricultural Water Quality Program (AWQ)
description: The County of San Diego Agricultural Water Quality Program (AWQ) helps to ensure that our 		waterways are protected by preventing pollutants from commercial agricultural businesses 				from entering the County's storm drain system in compliance with our municipal Stormwater 			permit. AWQ conducts outreach, inspections, and complaint investigations at commercial a			griculture businesses to ensure operations are protecting regional water quality through compliance 		       with regional stormwater permit standards. Non-Profit Organizations Surfrider Foundation San Diego County Chapter Surfrider San Diego County The Surfrider foundation San Diego Chapter is a local branch of the Surfrider Foundation, a nonprofit organization dedicated to the protection and preservation of oceans, waves, and beaches worldwide. The San Diego Country Chapter focuses specifically on coastal issues and water quality concerns in the San Diego area. Through advocacy, education, and community engagement, the chapter works to address threats to coastal ecosystems such as pollution, habitat degradation, and climate change impacts. They organize beach cleanups, water quality monitoring programs, and campaigns to reduce plastic pollution and promote ocean-friendly practices. By mobilizing volunteers and partnering with local stakeholders, the Surfrider Foundation strives to safeguard the health and sustainability of San Diego's coastal environments for future generations. San Diego Coastkeeper San Diego Environmental Nonprofits | San Diego Coastkeeper - San Diego Coastkeeper (sdcoastkeeper.org) San Diego Coastkeeper is a nonprofit organization dedicated to the protection and restoration of water resources in San Diego County, their mission encompasses a range of activities with the goal of promoting water quality and environmental advocacy. The organization conducts water quality monitoring programs to assess the health of local watersheds and identify pollution sources. They also engage in advocacy efforts to address issues such as stormwater pollution and water policy reform. San Diego Coastkeeper works to empower residents through community outreach, education, and volunteer initiatives. Site Visits San Diego Water Conservation Garden VISIT - The Water Conservation Garden (thegarden.org) The San Diego Water Conservation Garden is a nonprofit organization located in El Cajon, dedicated to promoting water-wise landscaping and environment education. The garden showcases a variety of drought-tolerant plants and sustainable landscaping techniques, providing visitors with inspiration and practical knowledge for creating water-efficient gardens. Through educational programs, workshops, and tours, the garden teaches visitors how to design, install, and maintain landscapes that conserve water and support local biodiversity. Additionally, the garden offers resources and expertise to homeowners and businesses interested in implementing sustainable landscaping practices. By serving as a demonstration site and educational hub, the San Diego Water Conservation Garden plays a vital role in promoting water conservation and environmental stewardship in the region. M eeting Focus: Explore sustainable landscaping techniques and the usefulness of drought-tolerant plants.
