name: San Diego County Sustainable Ground Water Management
description: San Diego County overlies a complex, finite, yet renewable groundwater resource that varies greatly throughout the region. This resource provides the only supply of water for most residents living in the eastern two thirds of the County (shown in green on map). The western portion of the County is mostly supplied with imported water from member agencies of the San Diego County Water Authority. To facilitate drought and water shortage preparedness for state small water systems and domestic wells, Planning & Development Services in collaboration with the Department of Environmental Health and Quality maintains a list of drought resources (provided below) to implement short- and long-term solutions for residents and communities facing a risk of water shortage.
source_proposal: Proposal - Improving Water Resource Management.docx

name: California Water Board, San Diego Commercial Agriculture Regulatory Program
description: Since the 1980s, the San Diego Water Board has regulated discharges from agricultural and nursery operations (Agricultural Operations) within its jurisdictional boundaries by requiring the implementation of management measures and/or best management practices to prevent or minimize the discharge of pollutants that may adversely impact the quality or beneficial uses of the waters of the State. In 2016, the San Diego Water Board adopted Order No. R9-2016-0004 (Third-Party General Order) and Order No. R9-2016-0005 (Individual General Order). Collectively, both Orders are referred to as the General Agricultural Orders. The San Diego Water Board requires all owners or operators of Commercial Agricultural Operations in the San Diego Region to comply with the General Agricultural Orders. Commercial Agricultural Operations are defined as any agricultural business or trade activity, including farms, nurseries, and orchards, that produce crops or ornamental plants with the intent to make a profit.
source_proposal: Proposal - Improving Water Resource Management.docx

name: San Diego County Agriculture - Agricultural Water Quality Program (AWQ)
description: The County of San Diego Agricultural Water Quality Program (AWQ) helps to ensure that our waterways are protected by preventing pollutants from commercial agricultural businesses from entering the County's storm drain system in compliance with our municipal Stormwater permit. AWQ conducts outreach, inspections, and complaint investigations at commercial agriculture businesses to ensure operations are protecting regional water quality through compliance with regional stormwater permit standards. Non-Profit Organizations San Diego Coastkeeper San Diego Environmental Nonprofits | San Diego Coastkeeper - San Diego Coastkeeper (sdcoastkeeper.org) San Diego Coastkeeper is a nonprofit organization dedicated to the protection and restoration of water resources in San Diego County, their mission encompasses a range of activities with the goal of promoting water quality and environmental advocacy. The organization conducts water quality monitoring programs to assess the health of local watersheds and identify pollution sources. They also engage in advocacy efforts to address issues such as stormwater pollution and water policy reform. San Diego Coastkeeper works to empower residents through community outreach, education, and volunteer initiatives. Overall, they play a critical role in promoting stewardship and environmental awareness in San Diego County. Site Visits San Diego Water Conservation Garden VISIT - The Water Conservation Garden (thegarden.org) The San Diego Water Conservation Garden is a nonprofit organization located in El Cajon, dedicated to promoting water-wise landscaping and environment education. The garden showcases a variety of drought-tolerant plants and sustainable landscaping techniques, providing visitors with inspiration and practical knowledge for creating water-efficient gardens. Through educational programs, workshops, and tours, the garden teaches visitors how to design, install, and maintain landscapes that conserve water and support local biodiversity. Additionally, the garden offers resources and expertise to homeowners and businesses interested in implementing sustainable landscaping practices. By serving as a demonstration site and educational hub, the San Diego Water Conservation Garden plays a vital role in promoting water conservation and environmental stewardship in the region. University of California Cooperative Extension San Diego County SAN DIEGO COUNTY (ucanr.edu) The University of California Cooperative Extension (UCCE) San Diego Country is a Branch of the UC Agriculture and Natural Resources division dedicated to serving the local community through research-based education and outreach programs. UCCE works closely with farmers, gardeners, landowners, and other stakeholders to address agricultural, environmental, and community developmental issues. They provide expertise and resources on topics such as sustainable agriculture, water conservation, and natural resource management. Through workshops, seminars, publications, and online resources, UCCE San Diego County spreads information and best practices to help individuals and communities make informed decisions. Overall, UCCE plays a vital role in bridging research and outreach to promote sustainable practices. _______________________________ **Home Hospitality can be offered for the group, as well as a volunteer activity (Saturdays only) ** San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $46 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. It is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park. Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $27 for one Adult Ticket for two-hour tour Their deluxe tour covers it all: Harbor and Shelter Islands, Point Loma, Cabrillo National Monument, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and much more. Tour is about 25 miles in length, 2 hour narrated tour. Old Town Trolley Tour www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com www.trolleytours.com/san-diego Price: $36 for one Adult Ticket For over 20 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours highlighting the best San Diego attractions. Old Town Trolley Tours is the best way to see the city, highlighting the best San Diego Attractions, with 11 stops and more than 100 points of interest. Old Town offers much to do, from visiting over 23 historic sites to shopping for unique merchandise. They also have many award winning restaurants to choose from. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 29 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 15 major museums, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Coronado Consistently voted one of America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year around due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. From the shores of Silver Strand State Beach to the tip of the Coronado Municipal Beach, you’ll find plenty of open sand, gentle waves and gorgeous views. SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $84 for one Adult Ticket Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Shamu show, One Ocean, and thrilling rides like Journey To Atlantis, Shipwreck Rapids and Wild Arctic. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Then dive into the world of sea turtles at the all-new Turtle Reef attraction.
source_proposal: Proposal - Improving Water Resource Management.docx

name: City of San Diego Human Relations Commission
description: The mission of the Human Relations Commission (HRC) aims to promote activities that foster understanding, respect, and inclusion in San Diego. The HRC believes in protecting basic Human and Civil Rights, while ensuring that San Diegans have the resources available to make positive impacts in their lives. The HRC includes some of the region's most talented and community-focused volunteers that San Diego has to offer. As an advisory commission to the Mayor and City Council, the HRC is empowered to collaborate with civic institutions, educate the public, investigate policy to make our city better, advocate on issues to the Mayor and Council, and mediate disputes of discrimination, exclusion, and bias in the City of San Diego. Leon L. Williams San Diego County Human Relations Commission https://www.sandiegocounty.gov/content/sdc/lwhrc.html The San Diego County Human Relations Commission (HRC) works to promote positive human relations, respect, and the integrity of every individual regardless of gender, religion, culture, ethnicity, sexual orientation, age, or citizenship status. They carry this work out through strategic goals including fostering healthy relationships, how to become a liaison in civil peace, communicating with and to the public, and more. Their goals and strategic areas aim to increase accessibility and transparency in county government to make better use of resources for community advocacy. They are also working to create safe spaces for the community to host difficult conversations to promote positive human relations and development. Adeem Ismaeil Employment Training Supervisor, International Rescue Committee San Diego County HRC Member The International Rescue Committee helps people affected by humanitarian crises to survive, recover, and rebuild their lives. As Employment Training Supervisor, Adeem is responsible for supporting new Americans in their search for suitable employment, and ensuring that they receive adequate training to enter the workforce. She will predominantly join this conversation as a representative of HRC. Jordan Harrison Inclusion, Diversity & Equity Senior Manager, Vertex Pharmaceuticals
source_proposal: Proposal - Promoting Human Rights (AutoRecovered).docx

name: San Diego County HRC Member
description: Jordan Harrison is an educator working to transform antiqued systems and the inequities that stem from injustice. He is committed to changing the outcomes of low-income, underrepresented and first-generation students from under-served communities worldwide and across different contexts. Jordan will predominantly join this conversation as a representative of HRC. International Rescue Committee www.rescue.org/united-states/san-diego-ca The International Rescue Committee provides opportunities for refugees, asylees, victims of human trafficking, survivors of torture, and other immigrants to thrive in America. Each year, thousands of people, forced to flee violence and persecution, are welcomed by the people of the United States into the safety and freedom of America. These individuals have survived against incredible odds. The IRC collaborates closely with government bodies, civil society actors, and local volunteers to support refugees, asylum-seekers, and other immigrants in San Diego, as they work to rebuild their lives.

name: San Diego Housing Commission
description: The San Diego Housing Commission’s (SDHC) homelessness action plan, HOUSING FIRST – SAN DIEGO, is an effective, diverse funding and housing strategy that has created thousands of housing opportunities for individuals and families experiencing homelessness in the City of San Diego.
source_proposal: Proposal - Promoting Human Rights (AutoRecovered).docx

name: Community Advocates for Just and Moral Governance (MoGo)
description: Community Advocates for Just and Moral Governance (MoGo) promotes good governance. MoGo is committed to engaging in litigation and various forms of advocacy that will make government more just and fully accountable to all people, particularly those who have been marginalized from society. MoGo was founded by two Black women lawyers who have dedicated their lives and careers to secure racial equality, social justice, and greater access to quality education. Current MoGo campaigns include: stopping discriminatory policing practices against Black people, Indigenous people, people of color, LGBTQ individuals, and individuals with disabilities; protecting San Diegans' fourth amendment rights in regard to transparent and responsible use of surveillance technology in San Diego; and working to bring ranked choice voting to San Diego to improve voter turnout.
source_proposal: Proposal - Promoting Human Rights (AutoRecovered).docx

name: Alliance San Diego
description: Alliance San Diego is a community organization whose mission is to build collective power so we can create an inclusive democracy. By working together to engage effectively in the civic process, we can make systemic change and shape a future that belongs to all of us. Together, we can create a more inclusive democracy where everyone can exercise their human dignity in an environment of harmony, safety, equality and justice. San Diego Immigrant Rights Consortium www.immigrantsandiego.org The San Diego Immigrant Rights Consortium seeks to continue fostering our region’s values by defending the civil and human rights of immigrants and refugees, educating and empowering immigrants and refugees on their rights and the resources available to them, and countering the myths and untruths made about immigrants and refugees. NonProfit Organizations HandsOn San Diego www.handsonsandiego.org/ HandsOn engage individuals as well as small and large groups by connecting them with local nonprofit organizations where they can donate their time and talent for a variety of projects and activities. Nonprofit organizations benefit because volunteer engagement increases their reach and capacity. Volunteers benefit because they witness first-hand how they are positively impacting the San Diego region.
source_proposal: Proposal - Promoting Human Rights (AutoRecovered).docx

name: United Women of East Africa
description: UWEAST is a San Diego nonprofit providing health services, education and advocacy for the well-being of the East African community, women and families. A community-based organization comprised of approximately 100 East African women, we operate the East African Cultural and Community Center in City Heights, and offer programs and services with the goal of responding to the overlooked health needs of East African women and their families.
source_proposal: Proposal - Promoting Human Rights (AutoRecovered).docx

name: Horn of Africa
description: Horn of Africa is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization promoting the successful integration and physical and emotional health of the East African refugee population in San Diego, the largest in California and the second-largest nationwide. Focused on empowering African refugees in San Diego to become productive members of their new communities and achieve self-sufficiency while preserving and promoting their dignity.
source_proposal: Proposal - Promoting Human Rights (AutoRecovered).docx

name: Somali Youth United
description: Somali Youth United is a non-profit community based organization in San Diego. Their focus is to promote peace, prosperity and unity within the community through youth development, cultural/intellectual exchange and community engagement. Rahmo Abdi, Executive Director Abdi came to the United States as a refugee from Somalia and personally understands the many difficulties adjusting to life in a new country while preserving one’s cultural heritage. Abdi founded the International Refugee Girls Association where she focused on keeping immigrants connected with their native cultures while stressing importance of education, financial literacy, self-esteem, and sexual health issues in a new environment. Abdi is a strong advocate for increased access to healthcare in the Somali and East African Community which suffer disproportionately from chronic health conditions. Rahmo Abdi has been the Executive Director of Somali Youth United since 2015. North San Diego County National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) https://www.nsdcnaacp.org/ Founded in 1909, the NAACP is the nation's oldest and largest civil rights organization.The NAACP’s principal objective is to ensure the political, educational, social and economic equality of minority citizens of the United States and eliminate race prejudice. This mission is accomplished by seeking the enactment and enforcement of federal, state and local laws securing civil rights, and by informing the public of the adverse effects of racial discrimination. From school desegregation, fair housing, employment and voter registration to health and equal economic opportunity, the NAACP is working successfully with allies of all races and plays a significant role in establishing legal precedents in order to improve the quality of life of America’s downtrodden.
source_proposal: Proposal - Promoting Human Rights (AutoRecovered).docx

name: Catholic Charities Diocese of San Diego
description: Catholic Charities Diocese of San Diego exists to exemplify the scriptural values of mercy and hospitality by Witnessing the gospel message contained in “Matthew 25:“; to advocate for a just society by Calling individuals and institutions to action on behalf of the poor, the vulnerable and the marginalized; and to acknowledge the sacredness of the human person by Accompanying those we serve on their journey toward achieving their full potential as persons created in the image and likeness of God. Border Angels www.borderangels.org/ We are a non-profit organization that is dependent on volunteers. We advocate for human rights, humane immigration reform, and social justice. This work is done in an attempt to reduce the number of fatalities along the US-Mexico border by educating and assisting the communities on both sides of the border. Services include educational programs, Water Drops in the desert, Day Laborer Outreach, Familias Reunidas Immigration Bond Fund program, and Shelter Aid support in Tijuana to aid migrants and asylum seekers in need.
source_proposal: Proposal - Promoting Human Rights (AutoRecovered).docx

name: Engage San Diego
description: Engage San Diego is a collaborative network of social-justice focused, non-profit groups working to increase civic and voter engagement in historically and systemically excluded communities of San Diego County. Engage San Diego table members are established and effective civic engagement and social change organizations with deep roots in the neighborhoods they serve. They envision a San Diego where the electorate and leadership are reflective of the community. Jewish Family Service of San Diego www.jfssd.org Jewish Family Service is a people-centered, impact-driven organization working to create a stronger, healthier community where everyone can thrive. Founded in 1918, today JFS is considered one of San Diego’s most impactful nonprofit human services agencies, providing compassionate care and supportive services to more than 70,000 people every year. Our diverse network of staff, volunteers, supporters, and community partners are committed to the pursuit of one shared goal: helping individuals and families in our community move forward. Conferences Amnesty International’s 2023 Annual General Meeting www.amnestyusa.org/virtual-annual-general-meeting-2023/ This meeting occurred from March 3rd to the 5th at the San Diego Omni Hotel. The AGM’23 was an opportunity for members and activists to come together and inspire one another, to learn about each other’s efforts and campaigns, to share stories and experiences, and to listen and participate in their sessions and panels.

name: San Diego African American Museum of Fine Arts
description: The San Diego African American Museum of Fine Arts (SDAAMFA) works to present and preserve the art of African Americans globally and to broaden the knowledge and understanding of the visual arts in Southern California generally and San Diego specifically by collecting, preserving and displaying works of art by and about African Americans; by creating and hosting quality traveling exhibitions; by collecting and preserving fine art and by developing and helping to foster an appreciation of art through meaningful public programs, symposia, and other educational programs. Meeting focus: Examine the historical context of art by African Americans that has been preserved throughout history including key periods during Civil Rights Movements.

name: Generation Citizen
description: The mission of Generation Citizen is to empower young people to become active and informed participants in our democracy. As a nonpartisan organization, they provide engaging civic education and hands-on experiences that equip students with the knowledge, skills, and confidence to address social issues and drive positive change in our communities. Meeting topic: Explore how civic engagement and volunteerism empower youth through their Generation Citizen to address community challenges, featuring discussions on best practices in volunteer recruitment and retention.
source_proposal: Proposal - Volunteerism and Civic Action.docx

name: American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) of San Diego & Imperial Counties
description: The mission of ACLU’s work is guided by a vision of a just and fair society in which all can participate, prosper, and reach their full potential. An engaging community of passionate volunteers, ACLU-SDIC NextGen empowers emerging leaders, community activists, and young professionals to actively support the fight for civil liberties and social justice. Through regular advocacy and fundraising opportunities, members gain valuable insights into local, statewide, and national policies, while fostering connections with like-minded peers. This inclusive program encourages collaboration across diverse backgrounds, all while inspiring members to contribute to meaningful social change in their communities. Meeting topic: Learn about ACLU-SDIC NextGen, a unique volunteer program that empowers young leaders to become active citizens committed to social justice and civil liberties. Explore how the program fosters community engagement, provides advocacy and fundraising opportunities, and emphasizes the significance of local, statewide, and national policies in protecting civil rights.
source_proposal: Proposal - Volunteerism and Civic Action.docx

name: San Diego Peace Corps Association (SDPCA)
description: The San Diego Peace Corps Association is dedicated to fostering a community of Returned Peace Corps Volunteers (RPCVs) and their families, promoting peace and understanding through active engagement. They support RPCVs and local communities by facilitating social, educational, and community service activities. Their commitment includes providing funding for overseas Peace Corps projects and advocating for the continued evolution and impact of the Peace Corps program. They create meaningful connections that empower individuals and promote global harmony. The Mark J. Tonner International Support Fund provides financial assistance to Peace Corps Volunteers (PCVs) from the San Diego area and those currently serving worldwide, with a preference for San Diego affiliates. Since 1988, they have awarded over 140 grants, helping PCVs implement valuable projects that enhance the lives of the communities they serve. Meeting topic: Explore the impact of the Mark J. Tonner Program. Learn how funding small projects supports Peace Corps Volunteers in implementing community-driven initiatives, fostering growth and empowerment in underserved areas. Discuss ways to engage local communities in this transformative program and maximize its impact on educational, environmental, and health-related projects. Human Rights Organizations
source_proposal: Proposal - Volunteerism and Civic Action.docx

name: Alliance San Diego
description: Alliance San Diego offers various volunteer opportunities focused on advancing human rights through community engagement, political involvement, and advocacy. Volunteers can connect with community members through outreach, assisting with voter mobilization, and educating residents on civic rights and resources. The organization’s “Show-up Squad” encourages volunteers to engage in local government by submitting public comments and participating in events like the Truth Act Forum. Additional roles include administrative support, event assistance, and immigration workshop aid, which are all aimed at empowering the community and supporting social justice initiatives. Meeting Topic: discussion on ways to support human rights efforts through volunteerism. This meeting will cover opportunities to directly engage with the community, promote civic engagement, and contribute to meaningful social change.
source_proposal: Proposal - Volunteerism and Civic Action.docx

name: International Rescue Committee (IRC)
description: The International Rescue Committee (IRC) in San Diego offers multiple volunteer roles, each dedicated to supporting refugees, immigrants, and low-income communities. Tax Preparation Volunteers join the VITA program to assist low-income families during tax season, while Vocational English as a Second Language (VESL) Volunteers help students build essential language skills for work. Front Desk Assistants welcome clients and provide administrative support, and Women's Economic Empowerment Specialists assist women facing economic challenges through financial training and employment guidance. Other roles include Food Security Volunteers aiding the Refugee and Immigrant Pantry Education (RIPE) Program, Immigration Administrative Volunteers supporting equitable access to legal services, and Refugee Resettlement Volunteers, who play a crucial role in helping new arrivals adapt to life in San Diego. Meeting Topic: Meet with IRC San Diego to explore impactful volunteer opportunities that foster human rights and provide vital resources to underserved communities. This session will discuss how volunteers can directly support refugees, immigrants, and low-income families in building a stable foundation for their future. Faith-based organization
source_proposal: Proposal - Volunteerism and Civic Action.docx

name: San Diego Habitat for Humanity
description: San Diego Habitat for Humanity is dedicated to putting God’s love into action by uniting individuals and families to build simple, decent, and affordable homes. Since 1988, they have empowered communities to foster dignity and safety, ensuring that every person has a place to call home. Through their collaborative efforts, they strive to create lasting hope and transformative change for families in need. SDHH offers the Cars for Homes program, providing a simple and impactful way for community members to support affordable housing efforts. Meeting topic: Learn about San Diego Habitat for Humanity and their recruitment efforts for their Cars for Homes program. Furthermore, discuss ways to engage communities in this transformative program and maximize its impact.

name: Catholic Charities of San Diego
description: Catholic Charities of San Diego exists to exemplify the scriptural values of mercy and hospitality by Witnessing the gospel message contained in “Matthew 25:“; to advocate for a just society by Calling individuals and institutions to action on behalf of the poor, the vulnerable and the marginalized; and to acknowledge the sacredness of the human person by accompanying those they serve on their journey toward achieving their full potential as persons created in the image and likeness of God.  One of their programs, Rachel’s Women’s Center offers a safe and supportive environment for unhoused or very low-income women. This inclusive program fosters socialization and empowers women to begin and continue their self-help efforts, creating a community of support and resilience. Meeting topic: Explore how Rachel’s Women’s Center embodies the American tradition of volunteering by offering vital wrap-around services for unhoused and low-income women. This project examines the impact of volunteerism in alleviating hunger, promoting social empowerment, and supporting at-risk populations, while fostering a safe environment for women to engage in self-help efforts and community connection. Schools and Academic Resource San Diego State University (SDSU) With an enrollment of 35,000 students from diverse backgrounds, including 47% students of color and 6% international students, SDSU is committed to fostering academic excellence and community engagement. As a top public research university, SDSU encourages innovation and prepares students for leadership in a global society.

description: The Center for Student Involvement offers various different opportunities for students 	to get involved with volunteerism. Additionally, the Center of Student Involvement offers support in finding volunteer 	opportunities during summer and spring break their Alternative Breaks program. Other 	Volunteer program include their Clinton Global Initiative University (CGI), a fall event 	where students gather to discuss world's most pressing challenges, Community Health 	Project Program, Education Corps, where students can sign up to volunteer in a K-12 	classroom in San Diego, and their Justice Corps Program, where students assist to 	provide legal information to self-represented community members. name: The City of San Diego - Parks and Recreation Services
description: The mission of the City of San Diego's Park and Recreation Department is to enhance the quality of life for residents and visitors by providing diverse recreational opportunities, maintaining parks and facilities, and promoting environmental stewardship. name: Point La Jolla and the California Sea Lion
description: Point La Jolla is a vital sanctuary for California sea lions along the San Diego coastline, located between La Jolla Cove and Boomer Beach. This habitat plays a crucial role during the annual pupping season from early May to October, attracting many visitors eager to observe these remarkable animals. The mission of Point La Jolla is to promote responsible wildlife viewing and educate the public on the importance of respecting the space of sea lions, particularly during this sensitive time. By adhering to guidelines set by the federal Marine Mammal Protection Act, they aim to protect these animals and preserve their habitat, balancing public enjoyment with the conservation of this essential coastal ecosystem. Meeting topic: Meet with representatives and volunteers of the City of San Diego Park and Recreation Department to explore initiatives and programs at Point La Jolla that promote responsible wildlife viewing and community engagement, emphasizing public awareness about California sea lions and the importance of protecting their habitat during the annual pupping season. name: Balboa Park
description: Balboa Park is dedicated to inspiring and educating the public through a diverse array of cultural, artistic, and scientific experiences. Their mission encompasses providing vibrant attractions and experiences—ranging from diverse food offerings to shopping, tours, and Go City Passes—while ensuring access to beautiful parks, trails, and gardens. They promote sustainability and collaboration among our institutions and visitors, creating a welcoming space for exploration and connection."

name: Forever Balboa Park
description: In the summer of 2023, Forever Balboa Park welcomed six high school interns from the Aaron Price Fellows Program to provide a youthful perspective to the organization. The interns were organized into two focused groups; Group Facilitation Interns and Marketing Communications Interns. Both projects are invaluable resources for Forever Balboa Park as they strive to create an environment where all visitors feel at home. By integrating the voices of young people, the organization aims to foster a vibrant and inclusive community that values the rich cultural and natural heritage of Balboa Park. Meeting topic: Learn About How Forever Balboa Park Engages Youth Voices to Foster Community Inclusion and identify strategies for further empowering youth and enriching the community experience.

name: Chicano Park
description: Chicano Park’s mission is to celebrate and preserve the cultural heritage and history of the Chicano community. It aims to promote social justice, community pride, and awareness through public art, cultural events, and educational programs. The park serves as a space for activism and cultural expression, honoring the contributions of Chicano and Latino communities while fostering inclusivity and engagement among diverse populations. Through its programs and initiatives, Chicano Park seeks to empower individuals and strengthen community bonds.
source_proposal: Proposal - Volunteerism and Civic Action.docx

name: Chicano Park Steering Committee
description: The CPSC is a grassroots organization comprised of individuals who volunteer their time and energy to ensure that the original stated goals of the development and expansion of Chicano Park "all the way to the bay" are never forgotten or abandoned. It was established in April 1970 with the mission to develop Chicano Park in a Chicano/Mexicano/Indigenous style, transforming the area into a vibrant representation of Chicano culture. The park is now home to world-famous murals, making it the largest outdoor art gallery globally. A key objective is to realize the vision of "Chicano Park all the way to the bay," ensuring a continuous park space from Interstate 5 to San Diego Bay. Additionally, the CPSC actively engages in preserving the park’s murals during infrastructure projects and organizes community events, like the annual Chicano Park Day Celebrations, to foster cultural pride and community involvement. Meeting topic: Engage with the CPSC to Explore Their Vision for Cultural Preservation and Community Empowerment. Discuss the mission of the CPSC and their ongoing efforts to develop Chicano Park as a vibrant space that reflects Chicano/Mexicano/Indigenous culture. Explore how they inspire community members of all backgrounds, particularly young people, to engage in cultural preservation and activism. Learn about their initiatives to maintain the park’s murals and the vision of "Chicano Park all the way to the bay," fostering a sense of civic responsibility and pride in local heritage. Participants will also have the opportunity to attend the Chicano Park Museum. There is a $250 honorarium for the meeting/tour of Chicano Park.
source_proposal: Proposal - Volunteerism and Civic Action.docx

name: Old Town Park
description: The Iipay ~Tipai Kumeyaay Mut Niihepok (Land of the First People) honors the rich heritage and enduring legacy of the Kumeyaay Nation, the original inhabitants of San Diego County. Old Town’s mission is to preserve and celebrate the culture, history, and contributions of the Kumeyaay people, fostering understanding and respect for their enduring relationship with the land and the San Diego River. Through education, community engagement, and the revitalization of historical spaces, they strive to create a welcoming environment that acknowledges the past and inspires future generations to appreciate the profound impact of the Kumeyaay on California's history and identity. Meeting topic: Explore the Iipay ~Tipai Kumeyaay Mut Niihepok (Land of the First People) and learn about the rich heritage and enduring legacy of the Kumeyaay Nation, the original inhabitants of San Diego County. Discuss how Old Town’s mission to preserve and celebrate the culture, history, and contributions of the Kumeyaay people fosters understanding and respect for their relationship with the land and the San Diego River. Sports organizations Note: Participants can join all the sports organizations listed for an organized volunteer activity

name: Waves 4 All
description: Waves 4 All is dedicated to enhancing the quality of life for individuals with disabilities by providing inclusive ocean experiences. Their mission focuses on promoting accessibility and fostering a sense of community through adaptive surf programs, empowering participants to enjoy the ocean safely and confidently. By creating a welcoming environment, Waves 4 All aims to inspire personal growth and promote physical and mental well-being for all participants. Meeting topic: Meet with the founders of Waves 4 All to discuss their vision for promoting civic engagement through surfing and how they inspire volunteers of all backgrounds, especially young people, to cultivate a culture of service and civic responsibility while supporting individuals with disabilities in enjoying inclusive ocean experiences.

name: Rolls to Success

They provide experiences and opportunities that foster growth, compassion, and awareness, helping to build a stronger, more inclusive community for all. Meeting topic: Explore Rolls to Success’s youth-focused grassroots civic engagement programs, including their inspiring initiatives like the wheelchair basketball invitational, and learn about volunteer opportunities with Civic Action, as well as the overall impact these efforts have within the San Diego community.
source_proposal: Proposal - Volunteerism and Civic Action.docx

name: Un Mar de Colores (An Ocean of Colors)
description: At Un Mar De Colores believe in the ocean's power to connect us all, reminding us of our relationship with nature and each other. They embrace the ocean as a welcoming space that fosters a sense of belonging, regardless of circumstance or background. Their commitment to protecting the environment is rooted in their responsibility as surfers to safeguard the places where we play. They engage in conversations around intersectional environmentalism, recognizing that true climate justice must consider the complexities of inequity. Through the joy of surfing and play, they inspire passion and purpose in children, equipping them with the tools and experiences to build confidence and a lifelong commitment to ocean stewardship. Meeting topic: Discuss the mission and initiatives of Un Mar De Colores, focusing on how the organization fosters community through ocean stewardship, promotes intersectional environmentalism, and inspires youth through the joy of surfing and play. Explore opportunities for collaboration and ways to engage the community in meaningful conversations about environmental and social equity. Volunteer Activities Beach Clean Ups: San Diego Surfrider Foundation, Coastal Cleanup Day, San Diego Coastkeeper Description: Volunteers will help in preserve the environment by cleaning up some of San Diego’s most beautiful beaches.  San Diego Surfrider Foundation is a non-profit dedicated to protecting and preserving the 70-mile stretch of coastline in San Diego San Diego Food Bank Description: Volunteers will volunteer at the downtown food bank, passing out meals and care packages to those who need them. This opportunity is limited, and only available at an at-need basis. San Diego River Park Foundation Description:  The San Diego River Park Foundation works to clean up pollution in water ways around San Diego, specifically within Mission Valley. Participants will get the opportunity to tour the river, and plant native plants through activities consisting of weeding, watering, trail maintenance and other easy gardening projects. The San Diego River Park Foundation works to preserve our environment while restoring and maintaining rivers, parks and gardens in San Diego. Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown). Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $30 for one Adult Ticket for a one-hour narrated tour (south bay or north bay routes); $35 for a full bay two-hour narrated tour which covers it all: ships of the Maritime Museum, Harbor and Shelter Islands, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and more. The full bay tour is about 25 miles in length. Accessibility: The tour begins and ends at the same location downtown along Broadway Pier. Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com Price: $44 for a 1-Day Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) For 30 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours, highlighting the best San Diego attractions. The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50am – 5:00pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $26 for one Adult General Admission Ticket ($1 discount when purchased on-line). Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10am – 5pm (Last admission at 4pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside Navy Pier. Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 17 major museums and cultural institutions, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).

name: Coronado
description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year around due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown.

With a strong emphasis on science, technology, engineering, and the arts, UCSD serves as a hub for  research and development, making it a vital player in the local economy and a catalyst for driving sustainable growth through small business initiatives.With initiatives like the Jacobs School of Engineering's entrepreneurial programs like the Institute for the Global Entrepreneur and the Rady School of Management's resources for startups, UCSD actively promotes small business development and economic growth.
