name: Randy Reyes at the City of San Diego
description: Randy Reyes serves as Mayor Todd Gloria’s Community Representative for Council Districts 2 and 5. In this role, he oversees community engagement and public relations for his assigned council districts and works closely with City staff to address concerns and issues raised by the public. Previously he worked for San Diego City Councilmember, Jennifer Campbell, as a Community Representative and Digital Communications Manager. Previous to that, Randy Reyes worked with the City of San Diego’s Office of Immigrant Affairs as a Communications and Outreach Fellow and before that he was an intern for the Mayor’s Office of Global Affairs. Randy graduated from the University of San Diego with his Bachelor’s and Master’s degrees in International Relations, as he was a part of their BA/MA Dual Degree program. Randy Reyes concentrated his studies on international security, Latin America, and great power competition. During his graduate studies, he co-authored, co-edited, and published a book offering advice to young professionals seeking internships in the field of international relations. Randy Reyes is the son of Mexican immigrants, is fluent in Spanish, and is a proud lifelong San Diego County resident.
source_proposal: Youth in the Political Process.docx

name: Milan Shah
description: Milan Shah is a high school student in San Diego with a passion for improving his community. He is the founder of www.reelvoices.org, a student-led storytelling film project that amplifies youth voices. He was first inspired by his interviews with high school students at the El Cajon Valley Community Center who have overcome immeasurable obstacles just to arrive in the United States. That experience, combined with his work at several nonprofits in San Diego focused on serving refugees and vulnerable youth, led him to combine his passion for film with his pursuit to create a more equitable and inclusive community. Milan has created award-winning movies. At Westview High School, he is president of the Film Club and a member of both the Mock Trial and Tennis Teams. Outside of school, Milan is a Youth Attorney with the police department and presents cases in front of a judge and jury. He is a paid fellow for the UC San Diego Youth Ambassador-Scholar Program, iCivics, and Learning 4 Equity, which all focus on community-based equity and education. He is proud to serve as a youth member of the San Diego Human Relations Commission and as Chair of the Youth Commission. Non-Profit and Non-Governmental Organizations
source_proposal: Youth in the Political Process.docx

name: Youth Will
description: Youth Will is a community based organization located in San Diego, CA, that was founded as the Youth Development Office of San Diego in 2012. Their mission is to create a more equitable future for every individual under the age of 25 through community organizing, grassroots advocacy, and political reform. Very community oriented, Youth Will has created a Youth Bill of Rights, is focused on areas important to San Diego’s youth like housing, healthcare, environment, helping youth find gainful employment., and develops policy priorities and advocates for youth at the city and county level.
source_proposal: Youth in the Political Process.docx

name: International Rescue Committee (IRC) San Diego
description: The International Rescue Committee (IRC) helps people affected by humanitarian crises - including the climate crisis - to survive, recover and rebuild their lives. Founded at the call of Albert Einstein in 1933, the IRC is now at work in over 50 countries and in 28 U.S. cities to help people affected by humanitarian crises to survive, recover and rebuild their lives. The IRC also fights for a world where women and girls have an equal chance to succeed. As thousands of Afghan refugees have been resettled in California and across the U.S. since August 2021, the IRC in San Diego has been working to ensure that schools are equipped to support refugee youth.
source_proposal: Youth in the Political Process.docx

name: SAY (Social Advocates for Youth) San Diego
description: Social Advocates for youth provide over 30 programs which strengthen the whole child, the whole family, and the whole community. From before- and after-school programs and early childhood services to therapy services for youth and adults, to support for key populations, like the region’s local military families, SAY San Diego strives to make sure that every San Diegan can get the help they need, whenever and wherever they need it.Through their programs, Elevated, provides an outlet for leadership opportunities, public speaking trainings, camp retreats, and much more. Along with becoming active members in their community, students develop friendships with students from high schools across San Diego County by attending monthly Friday Night Live meetings, while learning the importance of civic engagement.
source_proposal: Youth in the Political Process.docx

name: RISE San Diego
description: RISE San Diego is a non-profit organization focused on boosting the local community through active communication based on civic engagement, non-profit partnerships, and support to assist community members. Focused on urban areas, RISE San Diego wants to foster a safe and healthy environment for local youth and families. Their programs feature leadership and professional development in rising youth to help grow the neighborhoods of San Diego. This “neighborhoods first” agenda partners everyday people at grassroots level to solve and address complex urban issues.
source_proposal: Youth in the Political Process.docx

name: Engage San Diego
description: Engage San Diego is a fiscally sponsored non-profit civic engagement table that works to build a strategic, diverse, powerful and permanent progressive movement in San Diego. Through the facilitation of capacity building and development of trusted community-based organizations who are trusted partners within BIPOC, Youth and LGBTQ communities. With focus on training the leaders within the community on voter engagement, policy advocacy, and community leadership.
source_proposal: Youth in the Political Process.docx

name: San Diego Leadership Alliance (SDLA)
description: SDLA is a non­par­ti­san non­profit formed to develop San Diego's pro­gres­sive leadership by providing the skills, relationship and opportunities to build a sustainable progressive infrastructure in the San Diego region. The SDLA’s flagship program is the SDLA Institute, a six-month intensive skills and relationship building program for progressive young professionals. From leadership development, skill building in policy analysis, political management to fundraising for politics and nonprofits. Incubators and Accelerators
source_proposal: Youth in the Political Process.docx

name: San Diego Young Republicans
description: The San Diego Young Republicans are committed to growing an inclusive, tax-opposing, limited-government-supporting group of individuals who love America. They see themselves as a counterpoint for the young, and young at heart, Republican movement in San Diego. The goal of the San Diego Young Republicans (SDYR) is to grow the Republican Party through volunteerism, education and leadership. They are committed to activating the next generation of party leadership by supporting fresh ideas and candidates and engaging young professionals in the political process.
source_proposal: Youth in the Political Process.docx

name: San Diego Young Democrats for Equality
description: San Diego Democrats for Equality is one of the largest Democratic Clubs in Southern California, and remains one of the oldest active LGBTQ+ organizations in the US. The organization aims to unify and organize everyone interested in supporting and furthering progressive democratic values guaranteed to all Americans. In 2016, San Diego Democrats for Equality chartered a youth chapter with the California Young Democrats. California Young Democrats is the official youth arm of the California Democratic Party made of young people aged 14-35 committed to activating the youth vote, empowering Young Democrats in their community, electing Democrats to office and building a new generation of progressive leadership. As a fully chartered chapter of California Young Democrats, members of San Diego Young Democrats for Equality have the opportunity to travel and participate in CYD conventions, retreats, and other Democratic campaigns across the state, engage with their local community, and develop their skills as young leaders and practitioners of Democratic values Young Professionals Council at the San Diego LGBT Center https://thecentersd.org/young-professionals-council/ The Center's Young Professionals Council (YPC) is a community of LGBTQ+ leaders and allies ages 21-40ish that offers opportunities for connection, career development, friendship, and power-building. YPC helps to advance The Center's twin goals of promoting LGBTQ+ health/wellness and human rights, and fosters a culture of diversity, leadership, advocacy, and camaraderie among its participants. The Academy expands the ranks of young people in the LGBTQ+ justice movement by enhancing their skills, broadening their network, and fostering transformative connections with other community leaders.
source_proposal: Youth in the Political Process.docx

name: The Children's Advocacy Institute (CAI)
description: The Children's Advocacy Institute (CAI), founded at the nonprofit University of San Diego School of Law in 1989, is one of the nation's premiere academic, research, and advocacy organizations working to improve the lives of children and youth, with special emphasis on improving the child protection and foster care systems and enhancing resources that are available to youth aging out of foster care. Through its offices in San Diego, Sacramento, and Washington, D.C., CAI seeks to leverage change for children and youth through impact litigation, regulatory and legislative advocacy, and public education. Active at the local, state, and federal levels, CAI’s efforts are multi-faceted — comprehensively and successfully embracing all tools of public interest advocacy to improve the lives of children and youth.
source_proposal: Youth in the Political Process.docx

name: Alliance San Diego
description: Alliance is a community organization whose mission is to build collective power so we can create an inclusive democracy. By working together to engage effectively in the civic process, focusing on making systemic change and shaping a future that belongs to all of us. Through collaboration and togetherness results in creation of a more inclusive democracy where everyone can exercise their human dignity in an environment of harmony, safety, equality and justice. Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).
source_proposal: Youth in the Political Process.docx

name: Chicano Park
description: Chicano Park is the geographic and emotional heart of Barrio Logan, located in Logan Heights, San Diego's oldest Mexican-American neighborhood. The park is home to the largest concentration of Chicano murals in the world with more than 80 paintings on seven acres dotted with sculpture, gardens, picnic tables, and playgrounds. Throughout the year, it hosts festivals of music and Aztec dance, the biggest being Chicano Park Day held each April. Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $30 for one Adult Ticket for a one-hour narrated tour (south bay or north bay routes); $35 for a full bay two-hour narrated tour which covers it all: ships of the Maritime Museum, Harbor and Shelter Islands, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and more. The full bay tour is about 25 miles in length. Accessibility: The tour begins and ends at the same location downtown along Broadway Pier. Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com Price: $44 for a 1-Day Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased online) For 30 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours, highlighting the best San Diego attractions. The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50 am – 5:00 pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $26 for one Adult General Admission Ticket ($1 discount when purchased on-line). Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom, and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10 am – 5 pm (Last admission at 4 pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside the Navy Pier.
source_proposal: Youth in the Political Process.docx

name: Border Field State Park & Friendship Park
description: https://www.friendshippark.org/ Located within the Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve, Border Field State Park sits in the very southwestern corner of the United States, 15 miles south of San Diego. This important wildlife habitat, consisting of sand dunes and salt marshes, gives refuge to critically threatened and endangered birds such as the Western Snowy Plover, the California Least Tern, and the Light-footed Ridgway's Rail. Friendship Park is a binational park located at the western end of the US-Mexico border. For generations, people have gathered here to meet up with friends and family "across the line." Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 17 major museums and cultural institutions, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens, and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).
source_proposal: Youth in the Political Process.docx

name: Coronado
description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year-round due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown. SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $99.99 for one Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased online) Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Orca Encounter, Dolphin Days, and Sea Lions Live shows and thrilling rides like Electric Eel, Manta, and Journey To Atlantis. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks, and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Hours vary by season. Also enjoy the opening of Sesame Place in March 2022, a Sesame Street-themed section of the park with new water, ride, and musical attractions. Accessibility: A 15-20-minute drive from downtown San Diego.
source_proposal: Youth in the Political Process.docx

name: Beach Cleanup with Surfrider Foundation
description: Point of Contact: Gabriel Racca, San Diego Chapter Beach Cleanups Coordinator, gracca@sandiego.surfrider.org                                                                                                      Join the Surfrider Foundation for a hands-on coastal cleanup aimed at reducing plastic pollution and preserving San Diego’s shoreline. Participants will learn about local conservation efforts and spend the morning removing debris from one of the city’s most iconic beaches. This activity combines environmental stewardship with community engagement and offers a direct look at how grassroots volunteers protect California’s coast.

name: Habitat Restoration with San Diego River Park Foundation
description: Point of Contact: Kristen Die Spittle, Manager - Volunteer Program, kristen@sandiegoriver.org                                                                                                              Participants will take part in an environmental restoration day supporting the long-term health of the San Diego River watershed. Activities typically include planting native trees or shrubs, removing invasive species, and assisting with habitat rehabilitation. This activity provides a meaningful opportunity to contribute to urban ecological resilience while learning about the river’s importance to local biodiversity, flood mitigation, and regional water quality.

name: Food Sorting & Distribution at Feeding San Diego
description: Point of Contact: volunteersd@feedingsandiego.org                                                                                                                     Volunteers will support Feeding San Diego’s hunger-relief operations through sorting, inspecting, and packaging donated food for distribution to families in need across the region. This activity highlights how community-based organizations combat food insecurity, manage supply chains, and reduce food waste. It is indoors, highly organized, and accessible for groups of all sizes — a dependable service activity with immediate community impact.

name: Community Cleanup with I Love A Clean San Diego (ILACSD)

Participants will remove litter, learn about waste reduction, and contribute to improving environmental quality throughout the region. This activity offers a flexible, outdoor service opportunity that showcases San Diego’s commitment to sustainability and civic engagement while making an immediate, visible impact on shared public spaces.

name: San Diego County Sheriff's Department – Narcotics Task Force (NTF)
description: NTF is a multi-agency enforcement unit disrupting drug trafficking organizations (DTOs). It includes partnerships with DEA, CBP, and international agencies, focusing on fentanyl seizures, criminal networks, and cross-border surveillance.

name: U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) – San Diego Field Office
description: CBP manages interdiction at key San Diego border crossings, where most fentanyl enters the U.S. The San Diego Field Office uses detection technologies and coordinates with foreign enforcement partners.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Combating Synthetic Opioids (1).docx

name: Homeland Security Investigations (HSI) – San Diego
description: HSI leads transnational investigations targeting fentanyl production and trafficking, cyber marketplaces, and chemical precursors. San Diego is a critical hub in HSI’s international cooperation programs.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Combating Synthetic Opioids (1).docx

name: San Diego County – Health & Human Services Agency (HHSA), Behavioral Health Services (BHS)
description: HHSA leads the region’s opioid response, tracking overdose data, distributing naloxone, and coordinating prevention and treatment services. They also lead the San Diego Opioid Task Force. BHS oversees mental health and substance use disorder services for more than 100,000 residents annually.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Combating Synthetic Opioids (1).docx

name: San Diego Law Enforcement Coordination Center (SD-LECC)
description: The SD-LECC serves as the region’s all-crimes, all-hazards fusion center and is the High Intensity Drug Trafficking Area (HIDTA) Investigative Support Center for San Diego and Imperial Counties. It integrates federal, state, and local partners to enhance coordination, preparedness, and analysis to counter fentanyl trafficking networks.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Combating Synthetic Opioids (1).docx

name: San Diego Harbor Police (SDHP)
description: The Harbor Police provide law enforcement and public safety services across San Diego Bay, adjacent tidelands, and the international airport. They are cross-trained in maritime and aviation safety, uniquely positioned to monitor trafficking routes that exploit seaports and air cargo channels. Academic Resources
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Combating Synthetic Opioids (1).docx

name: SDSU Institute for Public Health – Center for Alcohol & Drug Studies and Services (CADSS)
description: Located within SDSU’s School of Public Health, CADSS conducts research, evaluation, and training in substance use prevention, treatment, and harm reduction. It partners with county departments and community-based organizations to address the opioid crisis, including fentanyl trends. The center leads programs like harm reduction outreach, naloxone distribution studies, and community surveillance for synthetic opioid outbreaks.
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Combating Synthetic Opioids (1).docx

name: San Diego Opioid Project
description: The San Diego Opioid Project is a public education campaign that raises awareness of the opioid epidemic, with a particular emphasis on fentanyl. Through media campaigns, town hall meetings, and partnerships with public officials, the project aims to debunk myths about prescription drug misuse and highlight the dangers of counterfeit pills laced with fentanyl. Its community-based outreach model demonstrates how public awareness can complement law enforcement and treatment efforts. Nonprofit Ressources
source_proposal: IVLP Proposal - Combating Synthetic Opioids (1).docx

name: McAlister Institute – Addiction Recovery & Community Outreach
description: Since its founding in 1977, the McAlister Institute has grown into one of the most recognized treatment providers in San Diego County. With 24 programs serving more than 13,000 individuals annually, McAlister emphasizes evidence-based interventions and community reintegration, helping individuals achieve stability and independence.

name: U.S. Naval Base San Diego *Would need D.C. gatekeeper request
description: Naval Base San Diego (NBSD) is the U.S. Navy's largest base on the West Coast and the principal homeport of the Pacific Fleet. Homeport to 54 ships, the base has 13 piers that stretch over 977 acres of land and 326 acres of water. The total on-base population is 20,000 military personnel and 6,000 civilians. Naval units based at NBSD have played a major role in the Global War on Terrorism and the Navy’s efforts to relieve suffering and build partnerships through disaster relief and humanitarian outreach deployments.
source_proposal: IVLP25_ Enhancing Maritime Security in the Quad .docx

name: NAVWAR
description: Naval Information Warfare Systems Command (NAVWAR) is one of six major Department of Navy acquisition commands. While other Navy acquisition commands, like Naval Air Systems Command (NAVAIR) and Naval Sea Systems Command (NAVSEA), focus on specific platforms, NAVWAR focuses on capable and secure communications and networks that span platforms and facilities.NAVWAR provides research and development, systems engineering, testing and evaluation, technical, in-service and support services to its respective acquisition program executive offices (PEOs) during all phases of a program’s lifecycle. NAVWAR consists of bicoastal reporting Naval Information Warfare Centers (NIWCs), which collectively account for more than 11,000 civilian, active duty and reserve professionals located around the world.
source_proposal: IVLP25_ Enhancing Maritime Security in the Quad .docx

name: US Coast Guard, Sector San Diego *Would need D.C. gatekeeper request
description: The Coast Guard is a unique branch of the military responsible for an array of maritime duties, from ensuring safe and lawful commerce to performing rescue missions in severe conditions. Nearly 42,000 men and women are actively serving in the Coast Guard to defend America’s borders and protect the maritime environment.The Coast Guard has roles in maritime homeland security, maritime law enforcement (MLE), search and rescue (SAR), marine environmental protection (MEP), the maintenance of river, intracoastal and offshore aids to navigation (ATON).
source_proposal: IVLP25_ Enhancing Maritime Security in the Quad .docx

name: California Department of Fish and Wildlife
description: The Department of Fish and Wildlife manages and protects the state's fish, wildlife, plant and native habitats. It is responsible for related recreational, commercial, scientific, and educational uses. It also works to prevent illegal poaching. The Marine Region officers patrol the entire coastline of California and up to 200 miles off the shore. Marine officers enforce commercial and sport fishing laws through spot checks on the water and on land. They work across all fishing-related fields across California, including commercial fishing, regulations, ocean and inland sport fishing, and fishing licenses.
source_proposal: IVLP25_ Enhancing Maritime Security in the Quad .docx

name: California Coastal Commission (San Diego Coast District):
description: The mission of the Coastal Commission is to protect, conserve, restore, and enhance environmental resources of the California coast and ocean for environmentally sustainable and prudent use by current and future generations. The Coastal Commission, in partnership with coastal cities and counties, plans and regulates the use of land and water in the coastal zone. Development activities, which are broadly defined by the Coastal Act to include (among others) construction of buildings, divisions of land, and activities that change the intensity of use of land or public access to coastal waters, generally require a coastal permit from either the Coastal Commission or the local government. The San Diego Coast District stretches 70 miles from the northern border of Camp Pendleton Marine Corps Base to the Mexican border.
source_proposal: IVLP25_ Enhancing Maritime Security in the Quad .docx

name: Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission
description: The IATTC is responsible for the conservation and management of tuna and other marine resources, including turtles, in the eastern Pacific Ocean. Each member of the IATTC is represented by up to four Commissioners, appointed by the respective government. The IATTC also has significant responsibilities for the implementation of the International Dolphin Conservation Program (IDCP), and provides the Secretariat for that program. Meeting focus: Learn about the IATTC role and program to protect tuna and turtles in the eastern Pacific Ocean.
source_proposal: IVLP25_ Enhancing Maritime Security in the Quad .docx

name: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) – Southwest Fisheries Science Center
description: https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/about/southwest-fisheries-science-center NOAA is a government scientific agency within the United States Department of Commerce that conducts applied scientific research of national and global significance, including protection of ocean and coastal resources and environmental stewardship. Established in 1964 to study the sardine and tuna fisheries of the U.S. West Coast, the Southwest Fisheries Science Center, headquartered in La Jolla, CA (within San Diego County) provides scientific information to support fisheries management and conserve protected species in the California Current, throughout the Pacific Ocean, and in the Southern Ocean off Antarctica. Center staff work with numerous partners and NOAA Fisheries counterparts to provide sound science for national and international management decisions. Maritime Security and Infrastructure Port of San Diego
source_proposal: IVLP25_ Enhancing Maritime Security in the Quad .docx

name: Commercial Fishing
description: Commercial fishing has a long history at the Port of San Diego. The first cannery opened in 1909, and San Diego was once known as the “Tuna Capital of the World”. The Port has extensive amenities at the Tuna Boat Basin, including Tuna Boat Pier, Fish Harbor Pier, Fish Market Wharf and three floating docks. The piers not only provide berthing for larger fishing vessels but are used as an area for the servicing and storage of fishing nets, lobster traps, crab traps and other related equipment.
source_proposal: IVLP25_ Enhancing Maritime Security in the Quad .docx

name: Harbor Police
description: The mission of the Harbor Police Department is to remain cross-trained to prevent crime on the waterfront and fight fire on the water. Harbor Police services include professional law enforcement and support staff, interacting with the public to ensure a safe and secure environment at the San Diego International Airport, on San Diego Bay and Port tidelands. Their main areas of operation include vehicle patrol, vessel patrol, dive & rescue, marine firefighting, Maritime Tactical Team (Composed of SWAT-trained officers), airport patrol, homeland security and training.
source_proposal: IVLP25_ Enhancing Maritime Security in the Quad .docx

name: Environmental Services Department
description: The Port of San Diego is a self-supporting public benefit corporation established in 1963 by an act of the California State Legislature. The Port champions the safekeeping and environmental care of San Diego’s diverse ecosystems, stewarding the protection of land, air, and water. As champions in the safekeeping and environmental care of San Diego Bay and its diverse ecosystems, the Port of San Diego has enrolled in Green Marine, North America’s largest voluntary environmental certification program for the maritime industry. The Port’s Environmental Services Department also works extensively to protect the environment through pollution prevention, jurisdictional runoff management program and alternative hull paints, and to conserve the environment through environmental education and community outreach, and natural resources management.
source_proposal: IVLP25_ Enhancing Maritime Security in the Quad .docx

name: World Trade Center SD
description: World Trade Center San Diego is the export and investment-focused affiliate of the San Diego Regional Economic Development Corporation. It supports the region’s global economic integration by helping small- and mid-sized businesses access export markets, attracting foreign direct investment, and raising San Diego’s international profile. Through programs like the MetroConnect export accelerator and no‑cost advising services, WTCSD has guided hundreds of firms to increase export sales, expand overseas partnerships, and strengthen supply chains—contributing to resilience in sectors including life sciences, defense, and maritime technologies
source_proposal: IVLP25_ Enhancing Maritime Security in the Quad .docx

name: Qualcomm
description: Headquartered in San Diego, Qualcomm is a global leader in wireless technology and semiconductor innovation, driving advances in 5G, AI, edge computing, and the Internet of Things (IoT). While widely known for transforming mobile communications, Qualcomm also plays a vital role in national security and defense innovation by developing secure, high-performance systems that enable real-time communication, navigation, and situational awareness. In the context of maritime security, Qualcomm’s technologies support next-generation communications infrastructure. This includes secure mesh networks, low-latency data transmission, and autonomous system integration—critical for monitoring vast ocean spaces and coordinating rapid responses across maritime domains. Their innovations help power smart ports, autonomous surface and underwater vessels, disaster response networks, and remote sensing systems, all of which are central to improving maritime governance and resilience. Through global partnerships, including in the Indo-Pacific, Qualcomm is actively shaping how emerging technologies can be deployed to address cross-border security challenges, including natural disasters, illicit trafficking, and cyber threats. Defense Contractors
source_proposal: IVLP25_ Enhancing Maritime Security in the Quad .docx

name: General Atomics
description: Headquartered in San Diego, General Atomics is a pioneering defense and technology company recognized globally for its work in advanced unmanned aerial systems (UAS), intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance (ISR) technologies, electromagnetic systems, and nuclear energy research. Best known for producing the MQ-9 Reaper drone and a wide range of cutting-edge autonomous systems, General Atomics plays a key role in enhancing situational awareness and operational readiness in maritime and coastal regions. The company is deeply involved in advancing technologies that support national security and international defense cooperation, particularly in the Indo-Pacific. General Atomics’ innovations help secure critical maritime infrastructure, detect illicit activities at sea, and improve interoperability among allied forces. Its work intersects with key areas of interest to the Quad—such as maritime domain awareness, cybersecurity, and disaster response—through the integration of AI, data fusion, and long-range sensing platforms. With a strong focus on research and development, General Atomics supports multi-domain operations that link sea, air, space, and cyber capabilities for a more resilient and informed maritime governance strategy.
source_proposal: IVLP25_ Enhancing Maritime Security in the Quad .docx

name: Skapa by Saab
source_proposal: IVLP25_ Enhancing Maritime Security in the Quad .docx

name: Skapa, Swedish for "to create, to shape," is an operational innovation incubator within Saab USA, based in Point Loma, San Diego. Formed in April 2024, Skapa brings together experts from startups, military, academia, and government to fast-track advanced defense technologies, especially in autonomy, AI, robotics, maritime domain awareness, secure mesh networks, and information systems. Central to its work is the converted Enforcer 3.1, an autonomous Combat Boat 90 prototype used as a live testbed for sensors, computer vision, and AI-enhanced maritime surveillance. Over its first year, Skapa has earned multiple DoD contracts, partnered on ethics‑driven AI frameworks like ASIMOV with DARPA/MIT, and launched initiatives in autonomy and responsible AI. Proximity to major naval bases, NAVWAR, NIWC-Pacific, UC San Diego, and a thriving unmanned systems ecosystem makes San Diego a fertile ground for collaborative defense innovation
description: Michael founded and served as the first Commodore of Task Force 59, the US Navy's first dedicated Robotics and AI task force, and strongly contributed to NATO's innovative efforts. name: The University of California Institute on Global Conflict and Cooperation (IGCC)
description: The UC Institute on Global Conflict and Cooperation (IGCC) is a network of researchers from across the University of California and the Los Alamos and Lawrence Livermore national labs who produce and use research to help build a more peaceful, prosperous world. We conduct rigorous social science research on international security, the environment, geoeconomics, nuclear security, and the future of democracy; help to educate and train the next generation of peacemakers; and strive to ensure that what we are discovering contributes to a safer world.  The Institute is based at the School of Global Policy and Strategy at UC San Diego, where several members of the leadership team and a number of researchers are on the faculty. Dr. Tai Ming Cheung, Director Tai Ming Cheung is director of the University of California Institute on Global Conflict and Cooperation and a professor at the School of Global Policy and Strategy at UC San Diego, where he teaches courses on the international relations and national security of China and Chinese security and technology policy. Among the areas of his research focus include China’s efforts to become a world-class science and technology power, and the relationship between geo-economics, innovation, and national security. VADM Martoglio spent the other half of his career developing strategy and policy, fostering international relations, and conducting operations, initially for the U.S. Navy then for all U.S. military forces. VADM Martoglio is recognized as one of the Defense Department’s preeminent strategic thinkers, with proven expertise in contingency planning, international relations and operations execution. He has served in Asia, the Middle East, and, most recently, in Europe as the Deputy Commander of all U.S. military forces in Europe, Eurasia and Israel. description: Sambuddha Ghatak, Ph.D., is an Assistant Professor at the School of Public Affairs at San Diego State University (SDSU). name: Wildcoast

The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50am – 5:00pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $26 for one Adult General Admission Ticket ($1 discount when purchased on-line). Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10am – 5pm (Last admission at 4pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside Navy Pier. Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 17 major museums and cultural institutions, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).

name: San Diego State University’s Homeland Security Graduate Program offers an interdisciplinary, applied curriculum focused on national and international security issues including disaster preparedness, cybersecurity, counterterrorism, and infrastructure protection. Leveraging San Diego’s strategic location, the program partners with government agencies, the military, and industry to provide students with real-world experience and research opportunities. Faculty and students contribute to resilience planning across sectors critical to maritime and coastal security.
description: Sambuddha Ghatak, Ph.D., is an Assistant Professor at the School of Public Affairs at San Diego State University (SDSU). He teaches in the Criminal Justice and Homeland Security program at the SDSU Imperial Valley campus. Before taking on this role in fall 2023, he was an assistant professor at San Jose State University in their criminal justice program. Ghatak’s research focuses primarily on the structural causes of terrorism. He has published in journals such as International Interactions, Conflict Management and Peace Science and the Journal of Conflict Resolution. Ghatak’s current research focuses on the strategies and target selection of terrorist organizations and exploring the logic on civil war onset by terrorist groups. Research and teaching interests: International Security, Conflict Processes, Terrorism, Insurgency, Civil War, Interstate War, Contentious Politics and Social Movement, Intrastate and Interstate Conflict in South Asia, Politics and Government in India, State Weakness
source_proposal: IVLP25_ Trilateral Maritime Workforce Development .docx

name: Training Resources Acquired Maritime Institute
description: Training Resources Limited Maritime Institute (“TRLMI”) offers over 80 U.S. Coast Guard approved courses in San Diego and Alameda and continues to provide exportable training throughout California and select East Coast locations. Their customers include Government organizations such as the U.S. Navy, Military Sealift Command and NOAA; Civilian ship operators such as Maersk Shipping, Disney Cruise Lines, and Foss Maritime; Merchant Mariner Unions such as Sailor’s Union of the Pacific (SUP) and Marine Firemen's Union (MFOW), and thousands of independent mariners each year. The company provides training to over 4000 mariners annually, in topics that cover every aspect of shipboard safety and operation.
source_proposal: IVLP25_ Trilateral Maritime Workforce Development .docx

name: Scripps Institution of Oceanography (SIO)
description: A department of UC San Diego, Scripps Institution of Oceanography is one of the oldest and most renowned centers for ocean and Earth science research, public service, undergraduate and graduate training in the world. Hundreds of ocean and Earth scientists conduct research with the aid of oceanographic research vessels and shore-based laboratories.
source_proposal: IVLP25_ Trilateral Maritime Workforce Development .docx

name: Samantha Murray, J.D., Executive Director, Master of Advanced Studies, Marine
description: Samantha Murray is the Executive Director of the MAS MBC Program where she also teaches graduate courses, including Ocean Law and Policy. In 2019 she was appointed by Governor Newsom to the California Fish and Game Commission and currently serves as Vice President. Samantha has nearly two decades of professional experience and has directed ocean and water programs at Ocean Conservancy, the Audubon Society, and Oregon Environmental Council, in addition to founding a marine policy consulting business. Samantha played a key role in the design and implementation of California's network of marine protected areas, which now cover 16 percent of state waters. She served on the Marine Protected Area Federal Advisory Committee, has held board positions at Upstream Public Health and Citizens for East Shore Parks, and currently sits on the board at San Diego Coastkeeper. Meeting focus: Explore how SIO develops scientists, policymakers, and conservation professionals through graduate programs and applied marine research. Explore how the institute leverages research and education to improve the state of marine ecosystems and develop innovative conservation models. Discuss California’s robust network of Marine Protected Areas, how it functions, and the myriad stakeholders who implement and support it. Non–profit and Non-Governmental Organizations
source_proposal: IVLP25_ Trilateral Maritime Workforce Development .docx

name: San Diego Workforce Partnership
description: The San Diego Workforce Partnership is dedicated to enhancing the region's workforce development by connecting individuals with employment opportunities and providing businesses with skilled labor. By focusing on training programs, skill development, and education initiatives, the organization plays a crucial role in ensuring that local businesses can access a qualified workforce, ultimately driving economic growth and stability. The partnership examines the factors that influence entrepreneurship to understand the impact of small businesses on the regional economy.
source_proposal: IVLP25_ Trilateral Maritime Workforce Development .docx

name: TMA Blue Tech
description: TMA Blue Tech is the non-profit industry association and cluster organizer for the San Diego ocean and water technologies community. They believe in creating BlueTech and Blue Jobs by promoting sustainable, science-based ocean and water industries. They bring education, policy and technology resources together to promote innovation and economic development in the Blue Economy. They create a strong “Blue Voice” via unique events, information sharing, national and international outreach, networking, research, and workforce development. TMA BlueTech promotes collaboration in the region combined with active national and international outreach. San Diego Coastkeeper www.sdcoastkeeper.org/ San Diego Coastkeeper believes a strategic combination of science, advocacy, education, and community engagement is the most effective way to address existing and emerging water-related issues in San Diego and beyond. The non-profit organization works to locally enforce the provisions of the 1972 Clean Water Act (CWA) and other federal and state laws. The organization works to improve sewage and urban runoff policies, adopt marine protected areas, remove marine debris, reduce sewage spills, and encourage the community to participate in the state’s largest volunteer water quality monitoring program. San Diego Coastkeeper uses community outreach, education and advocacy efforts to empower thousands of San Diegans to be stewards of clean water and a healthy coastal ecosystem. Meeting focus: Discuss San Diego Coastkeeper’s diverse range of work, and specifically explore workforce opportunities related to ongoing campaigns surrounding offshore industrial fish farming and the Pacific Ocean Aquafarms project. Cross-Border Coordination
source_proposal: IVLP25_ Trilateral Maritime Workforce Development .docx

name: Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve
description: The Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve (TRNERR) preserves, protects, and manages the natural and cultural resources of the Tijuana River Estuary by focusing on research and education with compatible recreation and resource use. The Reserve encompasses beach, dune, mudflat, salt marsh, riparian, coastal sage scrub, and upland habitats surrounded by the growing cities of Tijuana, Imperial Beach, and San Diego. Critical issues confronted by the Reserve include habitat conservation and restoration, management of wastewater from Mexico, sediment management and the integration of recreation.
source_proposal: IVLP25_ Trilateral Maritime Workforce Development .docx

name: Wildcoast
description: Wildcoast is an international team that conserves coastal and marine ecosystems and addresses climate change through natural solutions. They envision a society in which ecologically sensitive and globally significant coastal and marine ecosystems and wildlife are conserved, restored and sustained for future generations. They are non-profit organization that works across the United States and Mexico to conserve globally significant coastal and marine ecosystems and wildlife, conserving more than 38 million acres of ecosystems. Wildcoast is leading efforts in California to conserve over half a million acres of marine-protected area, and to put a stop to overfishing and other destructive practices like offshore drilling and deep-sea mining. _______________________________ Cultural Activities San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $62 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown). Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $30 for one Adult Ticket for a one-hour narrated tour (south bay or north bay routes); $35 for a full bay two-hour narrated tour which covers it all: ships of the Maritime Museum, Harbor and Shelter Islands, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and more. The full bay tour is about 25 miles in length. Accessibility: The tour begins and ends at the same location downtown along Broadway Pier. Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com Price: $44 for a 1-Day Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) For 30 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours, highlighting the best San Diego attractions. The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50am – 5:00pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $26 for one Adult General Admission Ticket ($1 discount when purchased on-line). Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10am – 5pm (Last admission at 4pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside Navy Pier. Maritime Museum of San Diego sdmaritime.org Price: $28 dollars for one Adult General Admission ticket Step aboard a fleet of historic ships including Star of India (the world’s oldest active sailing ship), HMS Surprise, and San Salvador, and explore hands-on exhibits that bring five centuries of seafaring history to life. Visitors can wander the decks, learn from interpretive displays, and enjoy harbor views from beautifully restored vessels. Operating hours: 10am - 5pm daily (Last admission at 4pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown on The Embarcadero. Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 17 major museums and cultural institutions, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).
source_proposal: IVLP25_ Trilateral Maritime Workforce Development .docx

name: Coronado
description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year around due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown. SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $99.99 for one Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) Accessibility: A 15-20-minute drive from downtown San Diego. Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Orca Encounter, Dolphin Days, and Sea Lions Live shows and thrilling rides like Electric Eel, Manta, and Journey To Atlantis. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Hours vary by season.

name: Vietnamese Heritage Museum
description: The Vietnamese Heritage Museum (VHM) is a non-profit organization dedicated to the preservation and exhibition of our Vietnamese refugees’ heritage. VHM collects and shares the testimonies and artifacts that tell the stories of the Vietnamese refugees. Such as being an outlet to contact any notable Vietnamese professionals or dignitaries who deserve recognition, providing oral history interviews, memorial walls, and many more. VHM provides a historic opportunity to listen, learn, grow, change, and invest in new ways to serve Vietnamese’s increasingly diverse communities. Their goal is to preserve this heritage for present and future generations to reflect upon.
source_proposal: IVLP_ Arts Ambassadors_ 30 Years of U.S.-Vietnam Cooperation in Creative Industries_.docx

name: Little Saigon San Diego Foundation
description: The Little Saigon San Diego Foundation is a non-profit organization incorporated on November 20, 2008 with the purpose of preserving and celebrating the rich Vietnamese cultural heritage that makes San Diego unique, vibrant, and resilient. Projects, including special events and festivals, district branding, and economic revitalization of neighborhoods, are eclectic approaches to empowering and promoting cultural equity, belonging, and well-being for the Little Saigon community.
source_proposal: IVLP_ Arts Ambassadors_ 30 Years of U.S.-Vietnam Cooperation in Creative Industries_.docx

name: Vietnamese American Youth Alliance (VAYA)
description: The Vietnamese American Youth Alliance (V.A.Y.A), a 501(c)3 non-profit, non-partisan, community-based organization, was founded in 2004 as a means for Vietnamese American youth to organize socially and culturally within the local communities. VAYA works to promote youth leadership, cultural awareness, social activism, and community development. They bring together young professionals and students from different colleges and high schools to build unity and solidarity among Vietnamese American youths in San Diego, cross-promote local events, and promote Vietnamese American culture, language, and history.

name: Viet Voices
description: Viet Voices is dedicated to building a resilient and thriving Vietnamese community in San Diego. Through grassroots community organizing, we seek to elevate the voice of the Vietnamese community to create a future of abundance for all.  Through the focus on events, outreach, training, and civic engagement to strengthen the power of the Vietnamese people and advocate for the community at every level of governance. Viet Voices support local AAPI artists to dream, create, and celebrate our cultures and identity. Government

name: City of San Diego, Cultural Affairs
description: Cultural Affairs (DCA), a division within the Economic Development Department, is responsible for the City's arts, culture and creative industries. Specifically, DCA advances a creative economy and arts ecosystem in San Diego that reflects the region's cultural diversity and informs San Diego’s brand as a global city. By investing in the work of artists and creatives and the institutions and systems that amplify creative work and experiences, cultivating local participation and access, and advancing San Diego as a global city. DCA interacts with the City’s Commission for Arts and Culture, which serves in an advisory capacity to the Mayor, City Council, and DCA. The Commission's primary role is to promote, encourage, and increase support for the region's artistic and cultural assets, integrate arts and culture into community life, and showcase San Diego as an international tourist destination. Creative Hubs

name: Pacific Arts Movement
description: Pacific Arts Movement presents Asian and Asian American Pacific Islander media arts to San Diego residents and visitors in order to inspire, entertain, and support a more compassionate society. Through film festivals, screenings, and education programs, Pacific Arts Movement’s programs celebrate and amplify AAPI artists while fostering community connections through diverse, culturally enriching events. Such as, including Reel Voices, Youth Days, Artists in Schools, and internships, empower and inspire the next generation through immersive arts and media experiences. In addition to, Film Festivals and Screenings: Pacific Arts Movement's film festivals, including the San Diego Asian Film Festival and SDAFF Spring Showcase, celebrate diverse Asian and Asian American voices through impactful screenings and spotlight films.

name: San Diego Asian Film Festival
description: The San Diego Asian Film Festival (SDAFF) is the flagship event of the Pacific Arts Movement. The festival is dedicated to highlighting the diversity and breadth of Asian Pacific Islander and Asian international images, from impassioned independent voices and provocative documentary subjects to the top hits from the world’s biggest continent, the latest works from the masters of cinema, and the fresh points of view of Asian Pacific Islander American filmmakers.
source_proposal: IVLP_ Arts Ambassadors_ 30 Years of U.S.-Vietnam Cooperation in Creative Industries_.docx

name: Little Saigon Cultural and Commercial District
description: Beginning in the 1970s, Vietnamese businesses began to populate storefronts along El Cajon Boulevard, clustering in the six-block stretch between Highland Avenue and Euclid Avenue.  Today, a majority of the businesses within the boundaries of the Little Saigon District are owned and operated by Vietnamese-Americans.  Defining the area as a “Little Saigon Cultural and Commercial District” validates the incredible amount of perseverance, hard work, and dedication the residents of the district have shown over the past 30 years. The El Cajon Boulevard BIA and the Little Saigon Foundation work closely with local businesses and residents to revitalize the business economy on El Cajon Boulevard.

name: Mingei International Museum
description: Mingei was founded in 1978 and presents works of folk art, craft, and design. The Museum has a rich history and commitment to furthering the understanding of art of the people (mingei) from all eras and cultures. Objects in our Collection reflect a joy in making, by hand, useful objects of timeless beauty that are satisfying to the human spirit. Mingei aims to inspire people to celebrate human creativity, as well as recognize, embrace, and cultivate their own creativity, in ways big or small through an inviting, fresh, sometimes surprising and always engaging look at a diverse range of thoughtfully designed, carefully crafted and passionately made objects from around the world, often created by unknown artists and craftspeople for everyday use.

name: Veterans Museum
description: The Veterans Museum of Balboa Park honors those who have served in the U.S. military, showcasing the history of the Army, Air Force, Navy, Marines, Coast Guard, and Merchant Marine. Set in the former chapel of the nearby Naval Hospital, the museum’s exhibits of patriotic and war-related memorabilia and artifacts bear witness to San Diego’s role in historic military events. Public programs raise awareness of and commemorate the sacrifices and contributions of service members past and present. Features exhibits on the Vietnam War, among other military conflicts, showcasing memorabilia, documents, and personal stories from the troops.

name: House of Vietnam
description: The "House of Vietnam" is an official Vietnamese cultural organization within Balboa Park's House of Pacific Relations (HPR) International Cottages. While they are still working to build their own cottage, they currently host events and share Vietnamese culture, arts, and history in the shared House of Nations space within Balboa Park. House of Vietnam is dedicated to promoting and preserving Vietnamese culture, heritage, and community. name: TMA BlueTech
description: TMA Blue tech is the leading U.S. BlueTech cluster driving innovation in maritime defense, advanced maritime, and ocean resilience technologies. A combination of industry, academia and government breaking down silos to explore and discover dual-use applications that advance both commercial and defense technologies. This includes strategic collaboration, by leading critical conversations, generating market intelligence, accelerating solutions and creating commercial opportunities-helping members stay ahead in a rapidly evolving global landscape. CleanTech San Diego www.cleantechsandiego.org CleanTech San Diego is a member organization that aims to stimulate innovation and advance the adoption of clean technologies and sustainable industry practices to augment the cleantech incubation cluster in San Diego. They accomplish this through a series of programs, including education and outreach, policy advocacy and leadership opportunities. Their membership spans business and financial leaders, academic and research institutions, and government and non-profit organizations.

name: Teledyne RD Instruments (Holding Company for Blue Tech):
description: Teledyne began as a small collection of unique marine solution providers and has expanded to a powerhouse of highly engineered, high-performance solutions for a broad range of markets. Teledyne Marine now offers the largest breadth of marine technology in the industry. With technologies divided into 5 core segments; Imaging, Instruments, Interconnect, Seismic and Vehicles, Teledyne Marine sales staff can address not only brand-level solutions, but turn-key, customized systems that leverage the full range of technology. They provide one-stop purchasing capability, worldwide customer support, and the technical expertise to solve the toughest challenges.
source_proposal: IVLP_ Innovative Solutions for a Resilient _Blue Economy_.docx

name: The San Diego Green Business Network
description: The San Diego Green Business Network is a program offering valuable resources for businesses in San Diego to enhance their sustainability efforts. By promoting energy and water efficiency, waste reduction, and improved air quality, the program not only benefits the environment but also contributes to significant cost savings for businesses. The initiative has expanded its impact through collaboration with the San Diego Regional Green Business Network, providing members with a comprehensive platform to access resources and strategies for achieving both economic and environmental success. Businesses are encouraged to join the network, tapping into a wealth of tools and support aimed at fostering a greener and more prosperous future for their operations.
source_proposal: IVLP_ Innovative Solutions for a Resilient _Blue Economy_.docx

name: Ocean Motion Technologies
description: Ocean Motion Technologies aims to scale ocean wave energy by lowering the cost of power at sea and enabling a new era of big blue data. The bluetech sector needs products in small-scale energy to fuel research and development needed to scale wave energy. Ocean Motion Technologies develops devices that are meant to last and reduce the cost for end users. Devices vary from the world’s first adaptive ocean wave energy converters controlled by an advanced artificial system to the world’s first compressed air energy storage system for marine applications. Nonprofits
source_proposal: IVLP_ Innovative Solutions for a Resilient _Blue Economy_.docx

name: Waitt Institute
description: The Waitt Institute is a non-profit that partners with committed governments and local communities to create and implement sustainable ocean plans to benefit people, the economy, and the environment. The Waitt Institute brings a team of technical experts to help facilitate the policymaking process, assessments and support for effective implementation and long-term success through expertise, funding, and tools focusing on Marine Spatial Planning, Blue Economy, and Sustainable Fisheries.
source_proposal: IVLP_ Innovative Solutions for a Resilient _Blue Economy_.docx

name: Maritime Institute
description: The Maritime Institute, a Service-Disabled Veteran Owned Small Business, opened in 1976 in San Diego, CA and soon became a national leader in providing the most complete, comprehensive and up-to-date USCG (United States Coast Guard) approved courses for professional working mariners with an emphasis on safety and environmental awareness. Maritime Institute is different from traditional maritime colleges and universities because its student body consists of individuals with an exceptionally wide range of responsibilities. There are private boat owners, law enforcement, active duty and retired military, commercial boat and ship operators from sportfishing, towing and passenger ferries.
source_proposal: IVLP_ Innovative Solutions for a Resilient _Blue Economy_.docx

name: I Love A Clean San Diego
description: I Love A Clean San Diego (ILACSD), with a rich history dating back to its founding as the San Diego War Against Litter Committee in 1954, has been at the forefront of environmental conservation in the region. Over the years, it has evolved to become a leading force in promoting zero waste lifestyles and eliminating litter. The organization engages approximately 100,000 students, adults, and businesses annually through a variety of impactful initiatives, including environmental education, volunteer cleanup programs, and recycling solutions. ILACSD's commitment to Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) is evident in its mission and operations, addressing inequities and enhancing its overall impact. Notable accomplishments include the establishment of WasteFree.SD.org, a zero-waste database and call center, as well as the removal of nearly half a million pounds of pollution annually through community cleanups. ILACSD envisions a zero-waste, litter-free, and environmentally engaged San Diego region. The organization's dedication to sustainability is further demonstrated by volunteers' adoption of reusable options during cleanups, contributing to an eco-friendlier approach.
source_proposal: IVLP_ Innovative Solutions for a Resilient _Blue Economy_.docx

name: Surfrider Foundation, San Diego Chapter
description: The Surfrider Foundation is a grassroots nonprofit organization dedicated to the protection and enjoyment of oceans, waves and beaches through a powerful network. With nearly 70 miles of coastline to protect, the San Diego County Chapter is one of the largest and most active chapters in the world. The foundation is focused on the following programs: Beach Cleanups, Rise Above Plastics, Hold On To Your Butt, No Border Sewage, Ocean Friendly Gardens, Know Your H2O, and Beach Preservation.
source_proposal: IVLP_ Innovative Solutions for a Resilient _Blue Economy_.docx

name: San Diego River Park Foundation
description: The San Diego River, stretching approximately 52 miles from the hills near Julian to the Pacific Ocean, is envisioned as a green ribbon weaving through diverse landscapes, including valleys, agricultural areas, industrial zones, residential developments, and urban settings. Distinguished by signature Cottonwood and Willow trees, the river holds historical and ecological significance, serving as the namesake waterway of the San Diego region. The vision is to protect and enhance this resource, fostering a new perspective on the relationship between nature and sustainable communities. The San Diego River Park aims to realize this vision by creating a continuous park system along the river's length. This system will offer diverse opportunities, including community plazas, public art, educational facilities, trails, and open spaces. The goal is to connect and unify the local landscape, instill local pride for future generations, and conserve natural spaces. The envisioned green ribbon serves as a symbol of this initiative, emphasizing the importance of embracing the river's legacy for a high quality of life. Wildcoast www.wildcoast.net WiLDCOAST has successfully protected more than one million acres of coastal wildland and halted the development plans of illegal mega-resorts throughout the Baja California Peninsula and the Sea of Cortez. Through its innovative, successful campaigns, the team has brought critical attention to pressing issues such as protecting the sensitive Cabo Pulmo coral reef from the proposed construction of a 2012 mega-development project. Their activities have focused on U.S.-Mexico Border coast sites that contain globally significant coastal and marine ecosystems (e.g. coastal dune, mangroves, salt marsh wetlands) and internationally migrating and threatened marine species. Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve (TRNERR) www.trnerr.org/ The Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve preserves, protects, and manages the natural and cultural resources of the Tijuana River Estuary by focusing on research and education with compatible recreation and resource use. The Reserve encompasses beach, dune, mudflat, salt marsh, riparian, coastal sage scrub, and upland habitats surrounded by the growing cities of Tijuana, Imperial Beach, and San Diego. Critical issues confronted by the Reserve include habitat protection and restoration, endangered species management, management of the wastewater from Mexico, sediment management, and the integration of recreation. Education Resources University of California San Diego, Adaptation and Solutions Adaptation and Solutions (ucsd.edu) The University of California San Diego, Adaptation and Solutions program supports positive change in the future through social engagement and offers mitigation strategies for the climate-related issues. This research theme encompasses energy alternatives, infrastructure, engineering, urban planning, and food production. In addition, sociologists, psychologists, artists and communications researchers focus on the social implications of adaptation.

name: StartBlue
description: StartBlue, an accelerator program by the Scripps Institution of Oceanography and the Rady School of Management, supports the development of advanced science and engineering startups focused on ocean-related challenges. The program aims to drive innovation and address critical issues affecting ocean ecosystems through entrepreneurial ventures.
source_proposal: IVLP_ Innovative Solutions for a Resilient _Blue Economy_.docx

name: Center for Energy Research
description: The Center for Energy Research at UC San Diego is dedicated to solving society’s energy supply challenges through interdisciplinary research. The center focuses on a range of energy solutions, including fusion energy, renewable resources, and advanced technologies to meet growing energy demands.
source_proposal: IVLP_ Innovative Solutions for a Resilient _Blue Economy_.docx

name: UC San Diego Deep Decarbonization Initiative
description: The Deep Decarbonization Initiative at UC San Diego aims to guide the global economy towards net-zero carbon emissions. The initiative focuses on understanding the transition from existing energy systems to new, sustainable ones and the pace at which these changes occur, providing valuable insights for policymakers and investors.
source_proposal: IVLP_ Innovative Solutions for a Resilient _Blue Economy_.docx

name: University of San Diego, San Diego Regional Climate Collaborative Hub
description: Established in 2011, the San Diego Regional Climate Collaborative is a network of public agencies focused on advancing solutions to mitigate and adapt to climate impacts. The Climate Collaborative acts as a resilience hub, addressing energy efficiency, coastal resilience, adaptation, and water issues through collaborative and cross-jurisdictional efforts.

name: Ocean Discovery Institute
description: The Ocean Discovery Institute uses ocean science to empower young people from urban communities to transform their lives, their community, and the world as scientific leaders. Working in the San Diego community of City Heights, they deliver rigorous educational, scientific research, and community stewardship experiences that build curiosity, science understanding and skills, and leadership in the next generation. Meeting focus: To learn about innovative educational methods to build climate change and ocean awareness among young people Government Resources
