name: Port of San Diego.
description: The Port of San Diego is an economic engine, a steward of the San Diego Bay and the surrounding tidelands, and a provider of community services and public safety. The Port of San Diego is a self-supporting public-benefit corporation established in 1962 by an act of the California State Legislature. It is located on San Diego Bay in southwestern San Diego County, California. The mission of the Harbor Police Department is to provide uniformed police services and marine firefighting within the territorial limits of the Port of San Diego. Harbor Police services include professional law enforcement and support staff, interacting with the public to ensure a safe and secure environment at the San Diego International Airport, on San Diego Bay and Port tidelands. We strive to provide superior customer service while meeting the needs of Port District tenants and the community.
source_proposal: IVLP_ Innovative Solutions for a Resilient _Blue Economy_.docx

name: CA Department of Fish and Wildlife
description: The Department of Fish and Wildlife manages and protects the state's fish, wildlife, plant and native habitats. It is responsible for related recreational, commercial, scientific, and educational uses. It also works to prevent illegal poaching. The department employs wardens to protect California's wildlife and natural resources. CDFW wardens are armed law enforcement officers with statewide arrest authority. Their primary mission is to enforce California state laws related to hunting, fishing, pollution, endangered species, and wildlife habitat destruction. The Marine Region officers patrol the entire coastline of California, and up to 200 miles off the shore. Marine officers enforce commercial and sport fishing laws through spot checks on the water and on land. As of 2001, 63 officers piloting 65-foot, 54-foot, and 40-foot mono-hull patrol vessels and multiple 18-foot and 24-foot rigid-hull inflatable patrol boats patrolled the Marine Region. CA Coastal Commission www.coastal.ca.gov The Coastal Commission is committed to protecting and enhancing California’s coast and ocean for present and future generations. It does so through careful planning and regulation of development, rigorous use of science, strong public participation, education, and effective intergovernmental coordination. In partnership with coastal cities and counties, the Coastal Commission plans and regulates the use of land and water in the coastal zone. Development activities, which are broadly defined by the Coastal Act to include (among others) construction of buildings, divisions of land, and activities that change the intensity of use of land or public access to coastal waters, generally require a coastal permit from either the Coastal Commission or the local government. The Commission is an independent, quasi-judicial state agency. The Commission is composed of twelve voting members, appointed equally (four each) by the Governor, the Senate Rules Committee, and the Speaker of the Assembly. Six of the voting commissioners are locally elected officials, and six are appointed from the public at large. Three ex officio (non-voting) members represent the Resources Agency, the California State Transportation Agency, and the State Lands Commission.
source_proposal: IVLP_ Innovative Solutions for a Resilient _Blue Economy_.docx

name: SANDAG Regional Resilience Framework
description: SANDAG’s regional perspective and climate expertise position it well to advocate, facilitate, and support local agencies to become more resilient to the climate. SANDAG recognizes the importance of a collaborative, transparent, and regional approach to adaptation planning because the hazards that threaten the San Diego region go beyond jurisdictional boundaries. The Regional Resilience Framework aims to simplify, unify, and streamline the adaptation planning process for the San Diego region. The Framework provides step-by-step guidance to adaptation planning, resilience tools for practitioners, and relevant resources for local jurisdictions.  The project builds off the California Adaptation Planning Guide and previous SANDAG adaptation work completed for local planning staff, practitioners, and decision-makers through the Holistic Implementation of Adaptation and Transportation Resilience Strategies (HIATRS) project.
source_proposal: IVLP_ Innovative Solutions for a Resilient _Blue Economy_.docx

name: South Bay International Wastewater Treatment Plan
description: The SBIWTP is a 25 million gallon per day secondary treatment plant located in San Diego County, California, about 2 miles west of the San Ysidro Port of Entry. The plant treats sewage originating in Tijuana, Mexico and discharges it to the Pacific Ocean through the South Bay Ocean Outfall, a four-and-a-half-mile-long 11-foot diameter pipe completed in January 1999. The South Bay International Wastewater Treatment Plant (SBIWTP) was designed to deal with the growing demand for the treatment of wastewater resulting in the contamination of the Tijuana River in the United States. It has been an ongoing concern since 1934, when the International Boundary Commission (IBC) was instructed by the United States and Mexican governments to cooperate in the preparation of a report on the Tijuana sewage problem. The SBIWTP can provide secondary treatment for 25 million gallons per day (mgd) average daily flows of sewage, more than the Tijuana sewage system capacity, but has expansion capability of up to 100 mgd. The SBIWTP was built on a 75-acre site near the international boundary in the U.S. immediately north of Tijuana's main wastewater pumping station. Resulting from the establishment of a binational interagency "Clean Water Partnership," the United States and Mexico approved IBWC Minute No. 283 dated July 8, 1990. This Minute authorized the construction of the SBIWTP. The Government of Mexico contributed $16.8 million toward construction of the SBIWTP and currently contributes $2.0 million toward the annual operation and maintenance costs.
source_proposal: IVLP_ Innovative Solutions for a Resilient _Blue Economy_.docx

name: San Diego Tourism Stewardship Plan
description: The San Diego Tourism Authority is actively preparing the 2024-2035 update for the San Diego Tourism Stewardship Plan, positioning it as the guiding framework for the tourism and hospitality industry over the next decade. This strategic plan aims to uphold San Diego's standing as a premier destination by outlining comprehensive goals, policies, and guidelines for tourism development, management, and promotion. Inclusive of input from stakeholders such as government entities, tourism boards, local businesses, residents, and community groups, the plan seeks to balance economic growth with the preservation of San Diego's unique identity. The update process, scheduled for 2024, involves extensive research, industry and community engagement, and strategic planning led by the San Diego Tourism Authority and its partners. A dedicated Steering Committee, comprising industry and public sector leaders from entities like San Diego Gas & Electric, San Diego Zoo Wildlife Alliance, Downtown San Diego Partnership, San Diego Regional Chamber of Commerce, and San Diego State University & Sports San Diego, has been established to guide this crucial initiative. The goal is to create a tourism industry that benefits both visitors and the local community, ensuring San Diego's sustained allure and enhancing the overall quality of life for residents in the years to come.
source_proposal: IVLP_ Innovative Solutions for a Resilient _Blue Economy_.docx

name: Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission
description: The oldest tuna regional fisheries management organization in the world, IATTC is a major contributor to research in the study of tropical tuna and marine habitats. Formed through an agreement between international fishery management bodies, they work to observe and manage tuna species and associated ecosystems in different regions of the world. Through their work around the world, IATTC leads research and management programs to ensure the long-term health of tuna and related species across international waters. San Diego Zoo San Diego Zoo | Home page Price: $68-$79 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. It is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park. Harbor Cruise Flagship Cruises & Events | San Diego, California (flagshipsd.com) Price: Starting at $24.75 for one Adult Ticket for one-hour tour Their deluxe tour covers it all: Harbor and Shelter Islands, Point Loma, Cabrillo National Monument, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and much more. From the shores of Silver Strand State Beach to the tip of Coronado Municipal Beach, you’ll find plenty of wide open sand, gentle waves and gorgeous views. name: University of San Diego (USD), Department of Communication Studies
description: The Department of Communication Studies at USD is committed to providing students with knowledge of foundational theories of communication; prevailing communication research paradigms; media industry structure and practices; prevailing criticism of media practice and performance; media influence on individuals and groups; the interplay of media systems in a global context; roles and functions of communication in interpersonal, group, organizational, and public contexts; conventions of public address and advocacy; and the impact and ethics of persuasion.
source_proposal: Proposal - Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists – Media Accountability.docx

name: Gina Lew, Professor of Practice of Communication Studies at University of San Diego
description: Gina Lew is Professor of Practice at the University of San Diego. She teaches Media Writing, Introduction to Media Studies and Advanced Journalism.  Lew is a former award-winning broadcast journalist who has worked for CBS, NBC, and FOX news in Los Angeles and San Diego. Her extensive background in reporting allows her to offer a “real world” understanding of the media. Her courses offer a practical look at how the media think, react and respond to current events. Lew’s creative and practical work focuses on understanding current events, the dying industry of the newspaper business, and explains how that impacts both the media and society at large. Media is changing. How people receive information is changing. Deciding what is newsworthy and why, and then offering different perspectives of the story, keeps people informed, and having an informed public is the foundation of a true democracy. Throughout her career as a reporter and anchor, Lew has earned awards for excellence in journalism. She anchored the top-rated morning and noon news for CBS in San Diego at KFMB. As a Spanish speaker, she has covered stories regarding border issues.
source_proposal: Proposal - Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists – Media Accountability.docx

name: Mary Brinson, Assistant Professor of Communication Studies at the University of San Diego
description: Mary Brinson, PhD, received her doctorate at the University of California, Santa Barbara and is a visiting assistant professor at the University of San Diego. Brinson's PhD was completed in the Department of Communication with an emphasis in the areas of Media Studies and Intergroup/Intercultural Communication. Brinson's current research focuses on media coverage of terrorism and anti-Muslim bias in the media. Her research projects included analyzing media coverage of terrorism in the U.S., U.K., the Middle East, and India. Brinson currently teaches Research Methods, Media Processes and Effects, Introduction to Media Studies, and Gender Communication. Her work has been presented at several conferences including ICA, NCA, Western States Communication Association, the World Organization Congress for Middle Eastern Studies in Barcelona, the Faces of Terrorism Conference in Liverpool, International Studies Association, and the Middle East & Central Asia conference. Her work has also appeared in The Journal of International and Intercultural Communication, The Journal of Arab & Muslim Media Studies, The Harvard Asian Pacific Review, Arab Studies Quarterly, and in David Canter's (Ed.) The Faces of Terrorism: Cross-Disciplinary Explorations.
source_proposal: Proposal - Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists – Media Accountability.docx

name: UCSD Disinformation Institute – (UC San Diego’s School of Global Policy & Strategy)
description: The Disinformation Summer Institute at UC San Diego is an interdisciplinary program bringing together scholars, technologists, journalists, and policy professionals to address the global spread of disinformation and its impact on democratic institutions. Hosted by UC San Diego’s School of Global Policy & Strategy in collaboration with departments across political science, communications, and data science, the institute explores the complex social, psychological, and technological drivers of disinformation. Topics include foreign influence operations, AI-generated content, platform responsibility, digital literacy, and resilience against propaganda. The institute emphasizes evidence-based solutions and public education strategies.
source_proposal: Proposal - Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists – Media Accountability.docx

name: San Diego State University – School of Journalism and Media Studies
description: The School of Journalism & Media Studies (JMS) at San Diego State University is a nationally recognized program that prepares students for careers in journalism, public relations, and digital media with a strong foundation in ethics, media literacy, and social responsibility. The school conducts interdisciplinary research on the role of media in society, with particular emphasis on digital communication, misinformation, media effects, and audience behavior. Through its innovative labs and community partnerships, JMS is actively engaged in addressing challenges related to disinformation and the evolving media landscape.
source_proposal: Proposal - Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists – Media Accountability.docx

name: Dr. Nathan Rodriguez
description: Dr. Nathian Shae Rodriguez specializes in critical-cultural and digital media studies. He grew up in Balmorhea, Texas and was valedictorian of his graduating class. He attended the University of Texas of the Permian Basin where he received a B.A. in Mass Communication. He went on to receive a Masters of Journalism and Mass Communication with a Concentration in Public Relations from Kent State University and a Ph.D. from Texas Tech University. Journalism/Media Resources:
source_proposal: Proposal - Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists – Media Accountability.docx

name: Brooke Binkowski
description: Brooke Binkowski is a veteran local, national, and international journalist who was born and mostly raised in San Diego. Before returning to her hometown, she worked as a reporter for KNX and KPCC in Los Angeles; as an anchor and reporter for CNN in Atlanta; as an anchor and reporter for KFQD in Anchorage, Alaska; and as a far-ranging independent journalist all over the world. After working as a beat reporter in Los Angeles, she spent years traveling and reporting on humanitarian and post-conflict situations in every medium. She is widely recognized as an expert in disinformation and propaganda and how to effectively combat it with responsible and transparent enterprise journalism.
source_proposal: Proposal - Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists – Media Accountability.docx

name: Voice of San Diego
description: Voice of San Diego is a nonprofit investigative news organization dedicated to in-depth, independent journalism serving the San Diego region. Founded in 2005, it operates with a mission to promote transparency, accountability, and informed civic participation through rigorous reporting and fact-based storytelling. Unlike traditional for-profit media, Voice of San Diego relies on memberships, grants, and donations to maintain editorial independence and focus on stories of public interest—especially those involving government oversight, social justice, and community issues. Voice of San Diego is widely recognized for its commitment to transparency in funding and editorial processes, clear corrections policies, and nonpartisan reporting. It collaborates with other local and national news outlets, academics, and community organizations to tackle misinformation and foster media literacy. The organization’s digital-first approach and engagement strategies also prioritize building trust with diverse audiences and encouraging civic dialogue in an era of increasing disinformation.
source_proposal: Proposal - Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists – Media Accountability.docx

name: San Diego Union-Tribune
description: The San Diego Union-Tribune is the largest daily newspaper in San Diego County and one of the most influential news sources in Southern California. Founded in 1868, it has a long history of delivering comprehensive coverage on local, regional, national, and international news. Now part of The Los Angeles Times Media Group, the Union-Tribune combines traditional journalism values with modern digital innovation to serve a diverse and growing audience. The newsroom is dedicated to producing investigative reporting, breaking news, and in-depth feature stories while maintaining high standards of accuracy, fairness, and editorial independence. As misinformation and disinformation have increasingly impacted public discourse, the Union-Tribune has implemented rigorous fact-checking procedures and transparency policies to uphold trust with its readers. Through its print and digital platforms, the paper continues to play a critical role in informing the community, supporting civic engagement, and holding power accountable.
source_proposal: Proposal - Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists – Media Accountability.docx

name: KPBS Fronteras Desk
description: KPBS is San Diego’s public broadcasting service, affiliated with both NPR and PBS. As a nonprofit news organization, KPBS is committed to delivering accurate, fair, and nonpartisan journalism across television, radio, and digital platforms. With a strong emphasis on transparency, editorial independence, and community trust, KPBS produces in-depth local reporting, fact-based investigations, and public affairs programming that serves the diverse needs of the San Diego–Baja California region. The station also partners with educational institutions to promote media literacy and civic engagement. Nonprofits & NGOs
source_proposal: Proposal - Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists – Media Accountability.docx

name: inewsource
description: Inewsource is a nonprofit, nonpartisan newsroom dedicated to improving lives in the San Diego region and beyond through impactful, data-based investigative and accountability journalism. inewsource launched in 2009, amid a deep recession and a catastrophic downsizing of newspapers and network media in San Diego and across the country. Some of the greatest casualties of the disruption were investigative journalists, bulldogs in the industry whose passion was uncovering wrongs and wrongdoers in the name of the public good. Local news, especially investigative reporting, is essential to a functioning democracy. Their work brings to light inequity, injustice and the government's failure to protect the public. Since they began publishing in 2009, inewsource has received multiple national and regional awards. Lorie Hearn is the chief executive officer and editor of inewsource. She is a lifelong news-aholic who started her reporting career writing her Girl Scout newsletter at age 12. High school and college were filled with school newspaper work, and after graduation, she worked as a reporter for newspapers on both coasts. At The San Diego Union-Tribune, when she relinquished her front seat on the world as a reporter, she became an assistant editor, then Metro Editor and finally Senior Editor for Metro and Watchdog Journalism.
source_proposal: Proposal - Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists – Media Accountability.docx

name: Society of Professional Journalists
description: The Society of Professional Journalists (SPJ) is a professional organization that includes broadcast, print and online journalists, journalism educators, and students interested in journalism as a career. Among other things, SPJ works to protect the First Amendment guarantees of freedom of speech and of the press, to stimulate high standards and ethical behavior in the practice of journalism, to foster excellence among journalists, to encourage diversity in journalism, and to be the pre-eminent, broad-based membership organization for journalists.
source_proposal: Proposal - Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists – Media Accountability.docx

name: Media Literacy Initiatives – SD Public Libraries
description: The San Diego Public Library (SDPL) is a pivotal community resource dedicated to promoting literacy, education, and civic engagement across San Diego. Serving over 1.4 million residents through its 37 branches, SDPL offers a diverse array of programs aimed at enhancing digital and media literacy. In partnership with organizations like the National Association of Hispanic Journalists and the American Library Association, SDPL has developed initiatives such as Breaking News @ The Library and Fact o Ficción, which provide workshops and panel discussions on topics ranging from identifying misinformation to understanding media coverage of race and identity. These programs are designed to equip patrons with the critical thinking skills necessary to navigate today's complex media landscape. **Home Hospitality can be offered for the group, as well as a volunteer activity (Saturdays only) ** San Diego Zoo San Diego Zoo | Home page Price: $68-$79 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. name: San Diego Law Enforcement Coordination Center (SD-LECC)
description: The SD-LECC serves as the region’s all-crimes, all-hazards fusion center and is the High Intensity Drug Trafficking Area (HIDTA) Investigative Support Center for San Diego and Imperial Counties. It integrates federal, state, and local partners to enhance coordination, preparedness, and analysis to counter fentanyl trafficking networks.
source_proposal: Proposal Combatting Illicit Fentanyl and Synthetic Drugs.docx

name: Homeland Security Investigations (HSI): Border Enforcement Security Task Force (BEST)
description: BEST is a multiagency task force dismantling Transnational Criminal Organizations (TCOs) involved in narcotics trafficking. In San Diego, HSI leads fentanyl-specific initiatives targeting smuggling and precursor diversion, while also coordinating with Mexican counterparts to track synthetic drug flows across borders. The task force model provides a framework for real-time intelligence sharing and operational trust-building, aligning with program objectives of disrupting supply chains and strengthening cross-border collaboration.
source_proposal: Proposal Combatting Illicit Fentanyl and Synthetic Drugs.docx

name: United States Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA): San Diego Division
description: DEA San Diego leads efforts to dismantle fentanyl and other synthetic drug distribution networks, including clandestine labs, pill press operations, and precursor chemical diversion. Working closely with CBP, HSI, and local law enforcement, DEA San Diego targets both supply chain disruption and network dismantlement across the U.S.-Mexico border. Its initiatives emphasize not only interdiction but also intelligence sharing, joint investigations, and community engagement.
source_proposal: Proposal Combatting Illicit Fentanyl and Synthetic Drugs.docx

name: U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP): San Ysidro & Otay Mesa Ports of Entry
description: As the busiest land and commercial ports in California, CBP San Ysidro and Otay Mesa play a frontline role in detecting fentanyl and other synthetic drug shipments hidden in pedestrian, vehicle, and cargo flows. These ports employ advanced scanning technologies, canine detection teams, and intelligence-driven targeting to interdict illicit substances while facilitating lawful trade. Their operations provide a practical demonstration of binational interdiction strategies and information-sharing protocols that align with program objectives of disrupting supply chains (Objective 1) and strengthening bilateral collaboration (Objective 3).
source_proposal: Proposal Combatting Illicit Fentanyl and Synthetic Drugs.docx

name: City of San Diego, Office of Homeland Security
description: The Office of Homeland Security leads the City’s preparedness, protection, and response to natural and human-caused threats. It coordinates across local, state, and federal partners to manage risks. Within the context of synthetic drug threats, the office plays a critical role in resilience planning and interagency coordination.
source_proposal: Proposal Combatting Illicit Fentanyl and Synthetic Drugs.docx

name: Fentanyl Abatement and Suppression Team (FAST)
description: FAST is a multiagency task force led by HSI and the California DOJ targeting fentanyl smuggling and distribution networks. The team has been instrumental in dismantling trafficking cells, interdicting counterfeit pill shipments, and reducing local overdose deaths through enforcement-driven prevention.
source_proposal: Proposal Combatting Illicit Fentanyl and Synthetic Drugs.docx

name: San Diego Harbor Police (SDHP)
description: The Harbor Police provide law enforcement and public safety services across San Diego Bay, adjacent tidelands, and the international airport. They are cross-trained in maritime and aviation safety, uniquely positioned to monitor trafficking routes that exploit seaports and air cargo channels.
source_proposal: Proposal Combatting Illicit Fentanyl and Synthetic Drugs.docx

name: U.S. Postal Inspection Service (USPIS) - San Diego Division
description: The U.S. Postal Inspection Service is the federal law enforcement agency that investigates crimes involving the postal system, including the trafficking of synthetic drugs like fentanyl through mail and parcel networks. With fentanyl increasingly shipped in small, concealable quantities, USPIS plays a critical role in intercepting packages at international mail facilities and disrupting e-commerce supply chains. San Diego inspectors work closely with DEA, CBP, and Homeland Security Investigations to identify, trace, and dismantle fentanyl distribution operations that exploit the postal system. Public Health & Harm Reduction Resources
source_proposal: Proposal Combatting Illicit Fentanyl and Synthetic Drugs.docx

name: Overdose Surveillance and Response (OSAR): County of San Diego
description: OSAR monitors overdose trends, detects geographic spikes, and coordinates rapid response teams to deploy naloxone, fentanyl test strips, and other harm reduction supplies. It integrates data from EMS, hospitals, and the Medical Examiner’s Office to provide near real-time awareness. When spikes occur, OSAR partners with community groups and law enforcement for targeted outreach and treatment referrals, supporting program objectives of early warning, cross-agency collaboration, and community resilience.
source_proposal: Proposal Combatting Illicit Fentanyl and Synthetic Drugs.docx

name: Harm Reduction Coalition of San Diego
description: The coalition provides syringe services, naloxone distribution, fentanyl test strips, and community outreach across San Diego County. It works directly with vulnerable populations to reduce overdose deaths and connect individuals to health and social services.
source_proposal: Proposal Combatting Illicit Fentanyl and Synthetic Drugs.docx

name: Family Health Centers of San Diego: Syringe Services Program (SSP)
description: Through fixed and mobile units, SSP provides syringe exchange, naloxone distribution, fentanyl test strips, education, and linkage to treatment and recovery programs. The program reduces the spread of infectious diseases and helps individuals navigate pathways to care and stability.
source_proposal: Proposal Combatting Illicit Fentanyl and Synthetic Drugs.docx

name: County of San Diego’s Behavioral Health Services (BHS)
description: BHS oversees mental health and substance use disorder services for more than 100,000 residents annually. With over 300 contracted providers, BHS delivers a continuum of prevention, treatment, and recovery programs, addressing both immediate crises and long-term rehabilitation needs.
source_proposal: Proposal Combatting Illicit Fentanyl and Synthetic Drugs.docx

name: Live Well San Diego
description: Live Well San Diego is a county-wide vision to build better health, live safely, and thrive. The initiative brings together more than 500 partner organizations, aligning resources to address health and safety threats, including the fentanyl crisis, and other illicit drugs. Its “Living Safely” component empowers communities to reduce risks and engage in proactive prevention. Treatment Resources
source_proposal: Proposal Combatting Illicit Fentanyl and Synthetic Drugs.docx

name: True Life Center
description: True Life Center’s Fentanyl Rehab Program provides a holistic and personalized approach to recovery for individuals battling fentanyl addiction. Their model combines traditional clinical practices with neurobiological integration, addressing both the psychological and physiological dimensions of substance use disorder. Located in San Diego, True Life is well-positioned to serve diverse populations impacted by the fentanyl crisis, including young adults, professionals, and families.
source_proposal: Proposal Combatting Illicit Fentanyl and Synthetic Drugs.docx

name: McAlister Institute
description: Since its founding in 1977, the McAlister Institute has grown into one of the most recognized treatment providers in San Diego County. With 24 programs serving more than 13,000 individuals annually, McAlister emphasizes evidence-based interventions and community reintegration, helping individuals achieve stability and independence.
source_proposal: Proposal Combatting Illicit Fentanyl and Synthetic Drugs.docx

name: A New PATH (Parents for Addiction Treatment & Healing)
description: A New PATH is a nonprofit organization founded by parents of children with substance use disorders, advocating for recovery over punishment. Since its inception in 1999, it has grown into a prominent voice in San Diego for policy reform, community education, and family-driven support networks. The organization provides recovery-safe spaces, stigma reduction initiatives, and advocacy campaigns aimed at shifting public opinion and government policy toward treatment-focused solutions.
source_proposal: Proposal Combatting Illicit Fentanyl and Synthetic Drugs.docx

name: Scripps Mercy Hospital: McDonald Center
description: The McDonald Center is a nationally recognized addiction recovery facility in San Diego offering detoxification, residential programs, outpatient care, and relapse prevention.
source_proposal: Proposal Combatting Illicit Fentanyl and Synthetic Drugs.docx

name: San Diego Youth Services: Teen Recovery Programs
description: San Diego Youth Services provides prevention, intervention, and recovery programs for teens struggling with substance use, including fentanyl and other synthetic drugs. Programs focus on early intervention, counseling, peer support, and family involvement to reduce risks and prevent escalation into chronic addiction. Academic Resources
source_proposal: Proposal Combatting Illicit Fentanyl and Synthetic Drugs.docx

name: UC San Diego Health Center
description: UC San Diego’s Health Center and School of Medicine conduct leading research on substance use disorder, overdose prediction, and fentanyl-specific treatment interventions. Their work includes developing open-source prediction models to identify counties at risk of overdose spikes, as well as campus-wide harm reduction initiatives such as naloxone and fentanyl test strip distribution. UC San Diego also collaborates with public health officials in Mexico and abroad, offering an international lens to its research.
source_proposal: Proposal Combatting Illicit Fentanyl and Synthetic Drugs.docx

name: San Diego State University (SDSU): Homeland Security Program & Viz Center
description: SDSU’s Graduate Program in Homeland Security, one of the first in the U.S., trains leaders in counter-narcotics, cross-border threats, and emergency management. The program’s Visualization (Viz) Center provides geospatial mapping tools and real-time data visualization used by law enforcement to monitor trafficking routes and emerging threats. By integrating academic training with hands-on technology, SDSU bridges the gap between theory and operational response.
source_proposal: Proposal Combatting Illicit Fentanyl and Synthetic Drugs.docx

name: San Diego Opioid Project
description: The San Diego Opioid Project is a public education campaign that raises awareness of the opioid epidemic, with a particular emphasis on fentanyl. Through media campaigns, town hall meetings, and partnerships with public officials, the project aims to debunk myths about prescription drug misuse and highlight the dangers of counterfeit pills laced with fentanyl. Its community-based outreach model demonstrates how public awareness can complement law enforcement and treatment efforts.
source_proposal: Proposal Combatting Illicit Fentanyl and Synthetic Drugs.docx

name: SDSU & UC San Diego: Ph.D. in Interdisciplinary Research on Substance Use (IRSU)
description: A joint Ph.D. program that trains researchers in addiction, substance use, analytic methods, prevention, policy, and treatment. Offers an academic pipeline producing experts in substance use with strong capacity to contribute to research-based strategies for synthetic drug response. Media & Community Engagement Resources
source_proposal: Proposal Combatting Illicit Fentanyl and Synthetic Drugs.docx

name: Voice of San Diego: Independent Media
description: Voice of San Diego is a nonprofit, investigative news organization that pioneered digital civic reporting in the region. Known for in-depth coverage of public accountability issues, it highlights how government policies and cross-border challenges affect local communities. Their reporting on drug trafficking, overdose trends, and public health responses offers insights into how independent media shapes public awareness and policy debates.
source_proposal: Proposal Combatting Illicit Fentanyl and Synthetic Drugs.docx

name: Society of Professional Journalists: San Diego Chapter
description: The Society of Professional Journalists (SPJ) advocates for high standards of ethics in reporting and defends freedom of speech and press. The San Diego Chapter brings together journalists, educators, and students to promote integrity and responsible coverage of sensitive issues, including drug trafficking and public safety. Their work highlights how professional standards can counter misinformation and foreign malign narratives.
source_proposal: Proposal Combatting Illicit Fentanyl and Synthetic Drugs.docx

name: Times of San Diego
description: Times of San Diego is a nonprofit digital news outlet that delivers timely, accessible coverage of local and regional issues. With reporting across politics, health, crime, and border security, it connects San Diegans to developments that directly impact their safety and wellbeing. Its emphasis on fast, fact-based reporting makes it a trusted source for community awareness on issues like fentanyl trafficking and overdose prevention. Substance Use & Overdose Prevention Taskforce (SUOPT) ccrconsulting.org The Taskforce is a media advocacy initiative that leverages data-driven campaigns, coalition partnerships, and multimedia resources to change community norms around substance use and overdose prevention. By producing accessible videos, infographics, and culturally relevant public messaging, SUOPT engages schools, local leaders, and health providers to amplify awareness of fentanyl and synthetic drug dangers. Their work not only educates the public but also mobilizes community stakeholders to advocate for prevention policies and expand harm reduction services. ______________________________________________________________ Cultural Activities: Border Tour SDDC can arrange a half-day tour of the U.S.-Mexico border, with a guide familiar with border operations, policy, and issues. Stops along the tour may include Barrio Logan, Friendship Park, San Ysidro Port of Entry, Otay Mesa Port of Entry, and Cross Border Xpress. *$250 honorarium required for the guide. San Diego Zoo www.sandiegozoo.org Price: $76 for one Adult Ticket The 100-acre (40-hectare) Zoo is home to over 3,700 rare and endangered animals representing more than 650 species and subspecies, and a prominent botanical collection with more than 700,000 exotic plants. Accessibility: The zoo is located just north of downtown San Diego in Balboa Park (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).

name: Chicano Park
description: Chicano Park is the geographic and emotional heart of Barrio Logan, located in Logan Heights, San Diego's oldest Mexican-American neighborhood. The park is home to the largest concentration of Chicano murals in the world with more than 80 paintings on seven acres dotted with sculpture, gardens, picnic tables and playgrounds. Throughout the year, it hosts festivals of music and Aztec dance, the biggest being Chicano Park Day held each April. Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $35 for one Adult Ticket for a one-hour narrated tour (south bay or north bay routes); $40 for a full bay two-hour narrated tour which covers it all: ships of the Maritime Museum, Harbor and Shelter Islands, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and more. The full bay tour is about 25 miles in length. Accessibility: The tour begins and ends at the same location downtown along Broadway Pier. Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com Price: $52 for a 1-Day Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) For 30 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours, highlighting the best San Diego attractions. The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50 am – 5:00 pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $39 for one Adult General Admission Ticket Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10am – 5pm (Last admission at 4pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside Navy Pier. Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 17 major museums and cultural institutions, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).

name: Coronado
description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year round due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. (Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown.) SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $61.99+ for one Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Orca Encounter, Dolphin Days, and Sea Lions Live shows and thrilling rides like Electric Eel, Manta, and Journey To Atlantis. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Hours vary by season. Also enjoy the opening of Sesame Place in March 2022, a Sesame Street themed section of the park with new water, ride, and musical attractions. Accessibility: A 15-20-minute drive from downtown San Diego.

name: Friendship Park / El Parque de la Amistad
description: A historic meeting place on the US-Mexico border, overlooking the Pacific Ocean.  For generations people of good will from both nations have gathered here to visit with family and friends "across the line.” *Please note, although visitors can see Friendship Park on Friday from outside the gates, access to the park is only open on Saturday and Sunday from 10:00 am – 2:00 pm.
source_proposal: Proposal Combatting Illicit Fentanyl and Synthetic Drugs.docx

name: Presidio Park
description: Presidio Park in San Diego is a tranquil historical site with remnants of the city's original Spanish settlement, offering visitors a chance to step back in time. The Serra Museum within the park provides a deeper understanding of the area's history, while the park's botanical garden and picnic areas invite relaxation. Its elevated location provides a scenic view of San Diego, making it a favorite spot for those seeking a quiet escape, historical insights, or outdoor respite in a peaceful setting.
source_proposal: Proposal Combatting Illicit Fentanyl and Synthetic Drugs.docx

name: San Diego Workforce Partnership (SDWP)
description: The San Diego Workforce Partnership (SDWP) is a nationally recognized leader in workforce development and labor market analysis. As the regional workforce board, SDWP uses real-time economic data to identify priority sectors and align education and training programs with employer demand. Its research guides public investments in workforce initiatives and helps community colleges, universities, and training providers design programs that reflect San Diego’s evolving economy. Through initiatives like Career Centers and OpportunitySD, SDWP emphasizes inclusive growth, connecting historically underserved populations to high-demand careers in biotechnology, information technology, and clean energy. The organization’s partnerships with local employers, educators, and government agencies make it a model for evidence-based workforce planning.
source_proposal: Proposal IVLP U.S. Approaches to Market-driven Education.docx

name: San Diego Regional Economic Development Corporation (EDC)
description: The San Diego Regional Economic Development Corporation (EDC) drives economic growth by connecting businesses, academic institutions, and government leaders to promote a competitive and inclusive regional economy. Its Inclusive Growth Initiative focuses on creating opportunities that enable all San Diegans to thrive in high-skill, high-wage industries. The EDC conducts extensive research on workforce trends, housing, and regional competitiveness, providing data-driven insights that shape both policy and education programs. It collaborates with K–12 districts, community colleges, and universities to identify skill gaps and design responsive curricula that prepare students for future jobs. The EDC also engages in public–private partnerships that strengthen San Diego’s innovation ecosystem and connect local talent to global opportunities.
source_proposal: Proposal IVLP U.S. Approaches to Market-driven Education.docx

name: San Diego and Imperial Regional Consortium (SDI RC)
description: The San Diego and Imperial Regional Consortium (SDIRC) unites 10 community colleges across the San Diego and Imperial Valley regions to coordinate career education and workforce programs. Funded through the California Community Colleges Chancellor’s Office, SDIRC bridges higher education and industry by aligning curricula with labor market demand. The consortium focuses on high-growth sectors such as advanced manufacturing, energy, information technology, and health sciences—areas that drive the Southern California economy. By leveraging labor market analytics, SDIRC ensures that training programs provide students with the technical and soft skills employers need most. It also facilitates partnerships among educators, workforce boards, and regional employers to share best practices and improve student employability. Higher Education & Accreditation Resources
source_proposal: Proposal IVLP U.S. Approaches to Market-driven Education.docx

name: University of California, San Diego (UC San Diego) Extended Studies
description: UC San Diego is a globally ranked research university that plays a central role in regional workforce development. Through its Division of Extended Studies, UCSD offers professional certificates, microcredentials, and continuing education programs designed in partnership with employers to address emerging labor market needs. These programs emphasize applied learning and innovation in fields such as biotechnology, data science, climate technology, and healthcare management. UCSD also leads initiatives that promote access for first-generation and underrepresented students, bridging academic research with practical workforce applications. Its partnerships with organizations like BIOCOM and the San Diego Regional EDC exemplify how higher education can drive inclusive economic growth while maintaining rigorous standards for academic quality and accreditation.
source_proposal: Proposal IVLP U.S. Approaches to Market-driven Education.docx

name: San Diego State University (SDSU)
description: San Diego State University (SDSU) is one of California’s leading public institutions, known for integrating career readiness into its academic mission. The SDSU Career Services Center provides students with data-informed advising, labor market insights, and employer engagement opportunities across multiple disciplines. Through strong partnerships with regional industries and government agencies, SDSU ensures that academic programs reflect workforce needs in sectors such as business, engineering, and public health. The university also operates several innovation hubs, including the ZIP Launchpad and the Economic Crisis Response Team, which connect entrepreneurship, career advising, and student success initiatives. SDSU’s focus on experiential learning, internships, and practical skill development exemplifies the U.S. model of higher education that balances academic quality with market responsiveness.
source_proposal: Proposal IVLP U.S. Approaches to Market-driven Education.docx

name: San Diego Community College District (SDCCD)
description: SThe San Diego Community College District (SDCCD) serves over 80,000 students annually through its three campuses—City, Mesa, and Miramar Colleges—and Continuing Education Division. It is nationally recognized for developing career and technical education (CTE) programs that respond directly to regional workforce needs. Each college works closely with employer advisory boards and the San Diego Workforce Partnership to ensure programs remain aligned with local labor market demands. SDCCD’s offerings in biotechnology, cybersecurity, advanced manufacturing, and allied health prepare students for immediate employment and upward mobility. The district also prioritizes accessibility and inclusion through flexible schedules, stackable credentials, and veteran-focused services. K–12 Resources
source_proposal: Proposal IVLP U.S. Approaches to Market-driven Education.docx

name: Cajon Valley Unified School District – World of Work Initiative
description: Cajon Valley Unified School District’s World of Work (WoW) Initiative has become a national model for early career exploration and workforce alignment. The program integrates career awareness, exploration, and development into K–12 curricula, helping students connect classroom learning to real-world opportunities. Using local labor market data, Cajon Valley educators expose students to diverse career pathways through partnerships with employers, community colleges, and universities. The initiative fosters self-awareness, collaboration, and practical skills—core competencies for success in a rapidly evolving economy. WoW also emphasizes equity by ensuring all students, regardless of background, have access to meaningful career guidance from an early age.
source_proposal: Proposal IVLP U.S. Approaches to Market-driven Education.docx

name: San Diego County Office of Education (SDCOE)
description: The San Diego County Office of Education (SDCOE) provides leadership, professional development, and technical support to the region’s 42 school districts, serving over half a million students. SDCOE works at the intersection of K–12 education and workforce readiness, emphasizing college and career preparation through programs such as CTE (Career Technical Education) Pathways, Linked Learning, and Work-Based Learning Networks. These initiatives help schools align curricula with regional industry needs and provide students with exposure to high-growth sectors through internships and apprenticeships. SDCOE also supports equity-focused programs that ensure access for students with disabilities, English learners, and those from underrepresented communities. Its coordination with regional workforce partners makes it a key bridge between early education and employability. Industry & Innovation Resources
source_proposal: Proposal IVLP U.S. Approaches to Market-driven Education.docx

name: BIOCOM California
description: BIOCOM California is the state’s largest and most influential life sciences association, representing over 1,700 member companies in biotechnology, pharmaceuticals, and medical technology. Headquartered in San Diego, BIOCOM serves as a bridge between industry, academia, and workforce organizations. It partners with universities, community colleges, and training providers to identify emerging skill needs and co-develop educational programs tailored to the life sciences sector. BIOCOM also provides career development resources, workforce training grants, and policy advocacy to ensure California remains globally competitive in biotech innovation. Its deep collaboration with local education partners makes it a valuable model for aligning specialized industry needs with higher education and workforce strategies.

name: CONNECT San Diego
description: CONNECT is a nonprofit accelerator that builds bridges between entrepreneurs, investors, and academic institutions to drive innovation and talent development. Founded in San Diego, CONNECT has helped launch and scale hundreds of startups by pairing innovators with business mentorship and skilled local graduates. The organization maintains close partnerships with local universities, workforce agencies, and private firms to promote entrepreneurship as a pathway to economic growth and job creation. CONNECT’s model exemplifies how education and industry can jointly cultivate practical skills, leadership, and innovation capacity in the workforce. Its programs also prioritize inclusion, ensuring that women and underrepresented founders have access to opportunities in San Diego’s thriving innovation ecosystem. Governmental Resources

name: San Diego Association of Governments (SANDAG)
description: SANDAG is the regional planning agency responsible for integrating transportation, housing, environmental, and economic planning across San Diego County. Its Regional Workforce and Economic Development Program uses comprehensive data and forecasting tools to identify employment trends and skill gaps. SANDAG collaborates with agencies such as the San Diego Workforce Partnership, community colleges, and local governments to align education and training efforts with long-term economic goals. The agency’s regional data dashboards and forecasting models are key resources for policymakers and educators designing programs responsive to market shifts. Through its convening power, SANDAG connects diverse stakeholders to promote coordinated, data-driven regional growth.

name: California Independent System Operator (CAISO)
description: CAISO is a nonprofit public benefit corporation that manages the flow of electricity across California’s high-voltage transmission system, one of the largest in the world. Its mission is to ensure reliable, accessible, and environmentally sustainable energy for millions of Californians. The organization operates a wholesale power market that matches electricity supply with demand in real time, optimizing efficiency while keeping costs stable. CAISO plays a critical role in integrating renewable resources like wind and solar into the grid, balancing intermittent generation with demand. It also manages transmission planning, ensuring that California’s infrastructure can meet future energy needs. Importantly, CAISO collaborates on cross-border transmission with neighboring states and Mexico, making it central to regional energy cooperation. Its work directly supports California’s ambitious energy targets while maintaining reliability during extreme weather events. As an independent entity, CAISO also ensures transparency and fair access to the grid, fostering innovation and competition in the energy sector.
source_proposal: Proposal U.S. Energy Market and Regulatory Infrastructure with Mexico.docx

name: San Diego Gas & Electric (SDG&E)
description: SDG&E, a subsidiary of Sempra, serves 3.7 million people across San Diego and southern Orange counties, delivering both electricity and natural gas. With a history of over 140 years, the utility has evolved into a leader in safety, reliability, and energy innovation. SDG&E operates more than 10,000 miles of power lines and has made major investments in wildfire mitigation, grid modernization, and renewable integration. The company is recognized nationally for its strong record in safety and service reliability. Its clean energy initiatives include increasing the share of renewables in its portfolio and advancing battery storage and electric vehicle infrastructure. SDG&E is also deeply engaged in cross-border cooperation, given its service territory’s proximity to Mexico and key energy infrastructure at Otay Mesa. Through community partnerships, environmental stewardship, and innovation, SDG&E exemplifies the role of a utility in supporting both local and regional energy needs. Cross-Border Infrastructure & Private Sector Resources
source_proposal: Proposal U.S. Energy Market and Regulatory Infrastructure with Mexico.docx

name: Otay Mesa Energy Center / Cross-Border Transmission Site
description: The Otay Mesa Energy Center is a 510-megawatt natural gas-fired combined-cycle power plant located near the U.S.–Mexico border in San Diego County. It provides reliable baseload and peaking power to the California grid, while its location makes it a key component in regional cross-border energy flows. The facility uses advanced combined-cycle technology, which increases efficiency by capturing and reusing waste heat from gas turbines to produce additional electricity. Operated under the oversight of the California Energy Commission, Otay Mesa supports grid reliability during periods of peak demand and extreme weather. Its proximity to natural gas pipelines and international transmission lines positions it as a strategic site for U.S.–Mexico energy integration. The center also plays a role in balancing energy sources by providing stable generation when solar or wind production fluctuates. Border Project (Otay Mesa, San Diego) https://www.energy.ca.gov/powerplant/simple-cycle/border-project The Border Project is a 49.5-megawatt simple-cycle natural gas-fired facility located in the Otay Mesa section of San Diego, just north of the U.S.–Mexico border. Owned by CalPeak Power, the plant began operation in 2001 under emergency authorization to address California’s electricity shortages. It uses a Pratt & Whitney Twinpac turbine system and incorporates selective catalytic reduction to reduce emissions. Originally permitted as a peaking facility to meet demand surges, the plant has since been granted long-term certification by the California Energy Commission. In 2022, the site was approved to integrate a battery energy storage system (Border BESS), marking its evolution into a hybrid facility that combines traditional and renewable-supporting technologies. This dual role highlights California’s approach to balancing natural gas reliability with renewable energy integration. Border’s location near the U.S.–Mexico border makes it strategically important for regional grid stability and potential cross-border energy flows.
source_proposal: Proposal U.S. Energy Market and Regulatory Infrastructure with Mexico.docx

name: Sempra Infrastructure (U.S. & IEnova in Mexico)
description: Sempra Infrastructure, headquartered in San Diego, develops, builds, operates, and invests in energy infrastructure across North America. The company focuses on three key areas: LNG & net-zero solutions, renewable power, and modern energy networks. It is one of the leading exporters of liquefied natural gas (LNG) from the U.S., with projects designed to expand global access to reliable energy. In Mexico, through its subsidiary IEnova, Sempra Infrastructure operates pipelines, storage facilities, and renewable projects that are central to the country’s energy transition. The company is deeply committed to the global energy transition, advancing carbon capture, hydrogen, and other low-carbon technologies. With billions in assets, Sempra Infrastructure combines financial strength with technical expertise to support large-scale binational projects. Its cross-border presence underscores the importance of private sector leadership in advancing energy security and integration. By championing safety, sustainability, and innovation, Sempra Infrastructure demonstrates how U.S. companies can drive regional cooperation while enabling a more reliable energy future. Imperial Valley Geothermal Projects
source_proposal: Proposal U.S. Energy Market and Regulatory Infrastructure with Mexico.docx

name: Black Rock Geothermal Project
description: The Black Rock Geothermal Project is a proposed 140 MW net geothermal power facility in Imperial County, California, near the Salton Sea. Developed by Controlled Thermal Resources, the project would utilize advanced steam turbine technology powered by deep geothermal reservoirs. Its design integrates production and injection wells, cooling towers, and associated infrastructure to provide baseload renewable energy. The project highlights Imperial Valley’s role as one of the most geothermal-rich regions in the world. Importantly, the site is also positioned within the “Lithium Valley” initiative, combining geothermal energy with lithium extraction for critical mineral supply. This dual-use model could simultaneously advance renewable generation and battery supply chains. The project is currently under review with the California Energy Commission.
source_proposal: Proposal U.S. Energy Market and Regulatory Infrastructure with Mexico.docx

name: Morton Bay Geothermal Project (MBGP)
description: The Morton Bay Geothermal Project is a 140 MW net proposed facility to be developed by Morton Bay Geothermal, LLC, a subsidiary of BHE Renewables. Located on the southern shore of the Salton Sea in Imperial County, the project would use a steam turbine system supported by more than 20 geothermal production and injection wells. With its planned infrastructure—including cooling towers, fluid handling systems, and a direct interconnection to the Imperial Irrigation District—the project would deliver reliable, carbon-free electricity. Like other Salton Sea geothermal projects, MBGP demonstrates how California is expanding renewable baseload generation alongside intermittent solar and wind. Its location in the “Lithium Valley” corridor means it could eventually integrate with lithium recovery operations, supporting electric vehicle and battery supply chains. The project is currently under review with the California Energy Commission.
source_proposal: Proposal U.S. Energy Market and Regulatory Infrastructure with Mexico.docx

name: San Diego Regional Chamber of Commerce
description: The San Diego Regional Chamber of Commerce is the largest and most active business advocacy organization in California, representing thousands of businesses and over half a million employees. Since the late 1800s, it has played a central role in shaping San Diego’s growth through policy engagement and cross-border collaboration. The Chamber’s Policy Department leads initiatives that promote economic development, trade, and binational cooperation, with a special emphasis on U.S.–Mexico relations. Its committees and councils focus on infrastructure, workforce development, energy, and innovation, providing a platform for businesses and policymakers to align priorities. The Chamber organizes binational delegations to Mexico City and Tijuana, advocating for infrastructure investments and regulatory alignment that strengthen the regional economy. Through its Border Infrastructure Council, it engages stakeholders on energy integration, cross-border projects, and economic growth. Academic & Research Resources
source_proposal: Proposal U.S. Energy Market and Regulatory Infrastructure with Mexico.docx

name: UC San Diego – Center for Energy Research
description: The Center for Energy Research (CER) at UC San Diego is a leading hub for energy science and technology innovation. It brings together over 100 researchers, faculty, and students working across disciplines to tackle critical challenges in renewable energy, energy storage, nuclear systems, and grid integration. CER conducts pioneering research in areas such as fusion energy, geothermal systems, fuel cells, and advanced materials. Its collaborative model links science with engineering and policy applications, ensuring discoveries have practical impact on energy markets and regulatory frameworks. Located in a binational border region, CER also engages in U.S.–Mexico collaborations, making it well-positioned to contribute to cross-border energy initiatives. The center’s testbeds and demonstration projects have become national models for renewable integration and grid resilience.
source_proposal: Proposal U.S. Energy Market and Regulatory Infrastructure with Mexico.docx

name: General Atomics (San Diego HQ)
description: Founded in 1955 and headquartered in San Diego, General Atomics is a privately held company at the forefront of advanced science and technology development. Best known for its leadership in energy research, GA operates the DIII-D National Fusion Facility, the largest magnetic fusion research facility in the United States. The company is a global leader in nuclear fuel development, small modular reactor technologies, and advanced fusion systems. GA’s Energy Group focuses on commercializing safe, sustainable next-generation nuclear technologies, while its multidisciplinary expertise extends into defense, space systems, and unmanned aircraft. In the energy sector, GA’s work on critical mineral supply chains and reactor design directly contributes to U.S. energy security and resilience. It also leads multi-institutional initiatives to advance fusion data ecosystems, accelerating the path toward practical fusion power. ______________________________________________________________ Cultural Activities: Border Tour SDDC can arrange a half-day tour of the U.S.-Mexico border, with a guide familiar with border operations, policy, and issues. name: Chicano Park
description: Chicano Park is the geographic and emotional heart of Barrio Logan, located in Logan Heights, San Diego's oldest Mexican-American neighborhood. The park is home to the largest concentration of Chicano murals in the world with more than 80 paintings on seven acres dotted with sculpture, gardens, picnic tables and playgrounds. Throughout the year, it hosts festivals of music and Aztec dance, the biggest being Chicano Park Day held each April. Harbor Cruise www.sdhe.com Price: $35 for one Adult Ticket for a one-hour narrated tour (south bay or north bay routes); $40 for a full bay two-hour narrated tour which covers it all: ships of the Maritime Museum, Harbor and Shelter Islands, North Island Naval Air Station, the Submarine Base, as well as the Coronado Bridge, and more. The full bay tour is about 25 miles in length. Accessibility: The tour begins and ends at the same location downtown along Broadway Pier. Old Town Trolley Tour www.trolleytours.com/san-diego www.oldtownsandiegoguide.com Price: $52 for a 1-Day Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) For 30 years, Old Town Trolley Tours has been providing sightseeing tours, highlighting the best San Diego attractions. The Tours are designed so that you can hop on and off the trolley and explore on your own at any time throughout the day. Hours of operation are generally 8:50 am – 5:00 pm, with later hours in the Spring and Summer. The fleet of orange and green trolleys travel frequently throughout San Diego and over the iconic San Diego-Coronado Bridge to Coronado on a continuous 25-mile loop visiting 10 neighborhoods with 10 destination stops. USS Midway Museum www.midway.org Price: $39 for one Adult General Admission Ticket Imagine experiencing life at sea aboard one of America’s longest-serving aircraft carriers. Visitors to the USS Midway Museum enter a floating city at sea and walk in the footsteps of 225,000 Midway sailors who served our country and upheld the American ideals of strength, freedom and peace. Guests can spend the day exploring more than 60 exhibits with a collection of 30 restored aircraft. The self-guided audio tour, narrated by Midway sailors, brings the carrier's history to life. Operating Hours: 10am – 5pm (Last admission at 4pm). Accessibility: The museum is located downtown alongside Navy Pier. Balboa Park www.balboapark.org Home to 17 major museums and cultural institutions, renowned performing arts venues, beautiful gardens and the San Diego Zoo, Balboa Park has an ever-changing calendar of museum exhibitions, plays, musicals, concerts, and classes—all in the beautiful and timeless setting of this must-see San Diego attraction. Accessibility: Balboa Park is conveniently located just north of downtown San Diego (a 5-10-minute drive from downtown).
