name: Coronado
description: https://www.sandiego.org/explore/things-to-do/beaches-bays/coronado.aspx A drive across the 200-foot tall Coronado Bridge treats you to one of the best views in all of San Diego, as you descend upon the charming and picturesque oceanfront community of Coronado. Consistently voted among America’s finest beaches by The Travel Channel, Coronado’s beaches glisten year round due to the mineral Mica in the sand, while gentle waves caress the shoreline. Coronado Central Beach runs along Ocean Boulevard with a backdrop of fine homes and mansions and the Hotel del Coronado at the southern end. Accessibility: Coronado is a popular stop on the Old Town Trolley Tour and can be accessed from Downtown using the Coronado Ferry or a water taxi. (Coronado is a 15-20-minute drive from downtown.) SeaWorld San Diego www.seaworldparks.com/en/seaworld-sandiego Price: $61.99+ for one Adult Ticket (discounted when purchased on-line) Come celebrate the wonders of the sea at SeaWorld San Diego. Experience the Orca Encounter, Dolphin Days, and Sea Lions Live shows and thrilling rides like Electric Eel, Manta, and Journey To Atlantis. Feed and touch dolphins and get up-close to beluga whales, polar bears, sharks and penguins. Enjoy fascinating aquariums and exotic birds from around the world. Hours vary by season. Also enjoy the opening of Sesame Place in March 2022, a Sesame Street themed section of the park with new water, ride, and musical attractions. Accessibility: A 15-20-minute drive from downtown San Diego.
source_proposal: Proposal U.S. Energy Market and Regulatory Infrastructure with Mexico.docx

name: Friendship Park / El Parque de la Amistad
description: A historic meeting place on the US-Mexico border, overlooking the Pacific Ocean.  For generations people of good will from both nations have gathered here to visit with family and friends "across the line.” *Please note, although visitors can see Friendship Park on Friday from outside the gates, access to the park is only open on Saturday and Sunday from 10:00 am – 2:00 pm.
source_proposal: Proposal U.S. Energy Market and Regulatory Infrastructure with Mexico.docx

name: Presidio Park
description: Presidio Park in San Diego is a tranquil historical site with remnants of the city's original Spanish settlement, offering visitors a chance to step back in time. The Serra Museum within the park provides a deeper understanding of the area's history, while the park's botanical garden and picnic areas invite relaxation. Its elevated location provides a scenic view of San Diego, making it a favorite spot for those seeking a quiet escape, historical insights, or outdoor respite in a peaceful setting.
source_proposal: Proposal U.S. Energy Market and Regulatory Infrastructure with Mexico.docx

name: City of San Diego Youth Commission
description: The Commission serves as an advisory body to the Mayor, City Council, and City Manager on issues of interest to youth and pertaining to youth in the City of San Diego. Youth and young adults are impacted by the decisions of City officials, but seldom have the opportunity to directly participate in the process. The City of San Diego Youth Commission facilitates the participation of youth and young adults in local government, as well as provide City officials an opportunity to hear and address their ideas and concerns. The commission works to identify critical issues affecting youth in the City of San Diego and provide advice and recommendations to the Mayor, City Council, City Manager, and other City officials on issues affecting youth in the City of San Diego. Schools and Academic Resource
source_proposal: Youth Engagement in the Political Process.docx

name: La Jolla Country Day School (LJCDS) Center for Excellence in Citizenship (CEC)
description: La Jolla Country Day School is an independent college-preparatory school serving students from age 3 through Grade 12 in San Diego’s coastal community of La Jolla. The Center for Excellence in Citizenship (CEC) develops unique opportunities for LJCDS students, faculty and families to engage in the vital work of local, national and global citizenship. CEC fosters civic engagement and civil discourse, galvanizing students to think about their rights and responsibilities as citizens and to be thoughtful participants in their communities. University of San Diego – Center for Peace & Commerce www.sandiego.edu/cpc/ The Center for Peace and Commerce (CPC) is a collaborative effort between the School of Business Administration and the Joan B. Kroc School of Peace Studies to prepare new generations of "change agents" who develop and exercise innovative approaches for peace-building. CPC contributes to creating new enterprise paradigms and solutions that foster peace-building and poverty alleviation, through courses, scholarship, enterprise development, active engagement with multiple stakeholders and the promotion of good governance. Non –Profit and Non-Governmental Organizations
source_proposal: Youth Engagement in the Political Process.docx

name: Mid-City CAN Youth Council
description: The Mid-City CAN Youth Council is a youth leadership group based in City Heights that teaches how local government works and puts those lessons into practice. Members meet with officials, testify at public hearings, and run issue campaigns on neighborhood priorities such as parks, transportation, and community safety. The council meets weekly, welcomes participants ages 13 to 18, and offers language interpretation so more young people can take part.
source_proposal: Youth Engagement in the Political Process.docx

name: Youth Will
description: https://www.kpbs.org/news/2021/jun/15/new-city-office-aims-help-san-diego-youth-amidst-d/ Youth Will’s vision is to fight for every young person to have everything they need to be happy, healthy and prepared to reach their full potential. Their strategies include building youth power, improving youth development, and demanding youth prioritization. It is the only regional organization where young people from the north, south, east, and west unite to drive the change they seek. They envision a youth-led movement by elementary to university students, young adults transitioning out of foster care and formerly incarcerated youth, and everyone in between.
source_proposal: Youth Engagement in the Political Process.docx

name: Jacobs Center
description: The Jacobs Center for Neighborhood Innovation is a nonprofit organization based in Southeast San Diego that focuses on empowering residents, fostering inclusive economic development, and revitalizing communities. With a mission rooted in community-driven change, JCNI works alongside local leaders, youth, entrepreneurs, and public-private partners to create opportunities for economic advancement and civic engagement. JCNI’s initiatives span workforce development, small business support, affordable housing, cultural arts, and youth leadership—creating a holistic model for neighborhood transformation.
source_proposal: Youth Engagement in the Political Process.docx

name: RISE San Diego
description: RISE San Diego is a non-profit organization whose mission is to elevate and advance urban leadership through dialogue-based civic engagement, dynamic nonprofit partnerships, and direct training and support to increase the capacity of urban residents to effect meaningful community change. RISE San Diego is about developing the people within communities who make it happen. RISE Urban Leadership Fellows Program is a partnership of RISE San Diego and the Leadership Institute at the University of San Diego School of Leadership and Education Sciences (SOLES). RISE’s unique goal and commitment is to help identify and empower a generation of leaders who will not only bring our communities up, but also bring them together. Meeting focus: Explore RISE San Diego’s youth-focused grassroots civic engagement programs, non-profit training, and leadership development models, and the impact they have within the  San Diego community. Outside the Lens www.outsidethelens.org Outside the Lens empowers youth to use photography, filmmaking and digital media, catalyzing change within themselves, their community and their world, teaching people from a young age that participation in their community’s future makes a difference. Outside the Lens uses cameras and digital media along with a proven educational strategy that allows youth to think creatively, engage in issues that are important to them, and advocate for their communities. Community Resources
source_proposal: Youth Engagement in the Political Process.docx

name: Reality Changers
description: Reality Changers serves youth who will be the first in their families to graduate from college. Their programs support students who may not have been considering college as a possibility. Reality Changers champions and walks alongside first-generation college students as they work together towards developing their skills to enter the workforce.
source_proposal: Youth Engagement in the Political Process.docx

name: Aaron Price Fellows Program
description: The mission of the Aaron Price Fellows Program is to prepare a highly motivated group of San Diego public high school students to be responsible, engaged and caring members of their community. An intensive three-year program teaches Fellows about government, cultural, business and non-profit institutions to illustrate their significance and relevance in their lives; exposes Fellows to exciting career opportunities; and foster friendships between Fellows from across the city. Meeting focus: Learn about this unique, 3-year fellowship opportunity that cultivates youth to be active citizens, caring for their community and helping others. Dive deeper into the fellowship’s curriculum and its emphasis on educating fellows about cultural, business and non-profit institutions' significance. Workshops and Leadership Development Sessions
source_proposal: Youth Engagement in the Political Process.docx

name: Alliance San Diego
description: Alliance San Diego is a community empowerment organization working to ensure that all people can achieve their full potential in an environment of harmony and safety. They seek to mobilize communities through: leadership development, policy advocacy, communication strategies, and civic engagement. Alliance San Diego focuses on issues of human rights, inclusive democracy, education, and tax reform. Additionally, Alliance San Diego works to engage voters and community members through their Civic Engagement Programs that reach thousands of people every year. Their signature Civic Engagement Programs include WeVote, California Calls, Engage San Diego and Redistricting. National Conflict Resolution Center (NCRC) www.ncrconline.com The National Conflict Resolution Center is a non-profit organization that serves a variety of communities in both the public and private sectors regionally, nationally and internationally. With more than twenty years of experience and over 20,000 cases managed, NCRC is recognized as an international leader in mediation instruction and conflict resolution. NCRC provides the resources, training and expertise to help people, organizations and communities manage and solve conflicts, with civility.
source_proposal: Youth Engagement in the Political Process.docx

name: Community Services – District Attorney Juvenile Diversion Initiative
description: The Juvenile Diversion Initiative (JDI) is a county-wide early intervention program that prioritizes diversion options for youth instead of filing criminal charges. The goal of JDI is to reduce the number of youth who enter the juvenile justice system, engage the community and stakeholders in the youth’s rehabilitation, and address the causes of the youth’s unsafe behaviors while at the same time fostering accountability to crime victims and community. Community Service Activities
source_proposal: Youth Engagement in the Political Process.docx

name: Spring Valley Cleanup Crew
description: Spring Valley Cleanup Crew works to keep Spring Valley and surrounding neighborhoods clean and safe. The Tijuana River Valley, in the Spring Valley area, has been declared a state of public health crisis due to the unsanitary and unsafe conditions entering the river, and organizations like the Spring Valley Cleanup Crew are working hard to make their community clean and safe. The Spring Valley Cleanup Crew, led by youth, utilizes social media to promote its local organization. Activity Focus: Participate in a cleanup effort with Spring Valley Cleanup Crew, while learning how they utilize social media to promote their service efforts and community engagement, and the work they are doing for their communities. Think Tanks, Public-Private Cooperation Initiatives, and Community Centers
source_proposal: Youth Engagement in the Political Process.docx

name: Youth Voice San Diego - Community Wraparound
description: Youth Voice aims to create safer communities by educating and empowering youth to realize their potential and become solution-oriented activists. This unique and innovative initiative helps youth recognize their innate gifts, collaborate with peers, engage in community service, advocate for their community, develop public speaking skills, and develop the leadership abilities to partner with community groups and law enforcement agencies. Providing our youth with leadership opportunities helps them grow into responsible and engaged members of their community. By giving them the chance to develop effective life skills—skills that allow them to manage time, work as a team, set goals, solve problems, facilitate meetings, defend positions, and make effective presentations—we ensure a successful trajectory where they can lead their peers through community challenges. Media and Journalism: Voice of San Diego www.voiceofsandiego.org The mission of the Voice of San Diego is to consistently deliver ground-breaking investigative journalism for the San Diego region and to increase civic participation by giving residents the knowledge and in-depth analysis necessary to become advocates for good government and social progress. Voice of San Diego is a member-based nonprofit investigative news organization that gives concerned citizens the tools they need to engage in important conversations about their community. They are unlike any news outlet in San Diego because they dig deeper to uncover the truth and devote the time necessary to turn the chaos of news into a story people can access and understand. As a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization, they are fully funded by individual donors, major charitable gifts, foundations and community partnerships.

The San Diego Union-Tribune’s mission is to spread knowledge, build understanding and create opportunity in the communities it serves. They strive to elevate civic discourse though the journalistic pursuit of truth. Fairness, accuracy and honesty are their fundamental values.
